Academic Costume was first worn at <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> in 1786, after the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> voted on March 13 that "in future, the Candidates for Bachelors degrees, being Alumni of the College should be clad at <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> in black flowing robes &amp; caps similar to those used at other Universities.<cite><a href="Academic costume.html">Academic costume</a></cite>
In 1912 the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> passed laws regulating academic costume.<cite><a href="Academic costume.html">Academic costume</a></cite>
The 1912 regulations also prescribed black hoods, three feet long for bachelor’s degree, three and one-half feet for the master’s, and four feet for the doctor’s, lined with the official color, brown.<cite><a href="Academic costume.html">Academic costume</a></cite>
Traditional black gowns were worn until 1968, when Brown, following the lead of Harvard, Columbia and others, adopted the school colors for the gowns worn by recipients of advanced degrees.<cite><a href="Academic costume.html">Academic costume</a></cite>
Given by an anonymous donor in 1964, it was designed by Anne S. K. Brown, an authority on military dress, who traveled with her husband, John Nicholas Brown, to Ireland to arrange with Walter Conan, master maker of gowns for the Irish universities, for the gown to be made by Irish craftsmen.<cite><a href="Academic costume.html">Academic costume</a></cite>
<a href="President.html">President</a> Keeney first wore the gown at the Bicentennial <a href="Convocation.html">Convocation</a> in the Colony House in Newport in the fall of 1964.<cite><a href="Academic costume.html">Academic costume</a></cite>
"Actaeus," subtitled "a journal of arts and criticism published at Brown University," appeared in two issues in January and May 1971, published under the auspices of the Brown Literary Board.<cite><a href="Actaeus.html">Actaeus</a></cite>
C(larence) Raymond Adams (1898-1965), professor of mathematics, was born on April 10, 1898, which was Easter Sunday, in Cranston, Rhode Island, his exact place of birth being the Rhode Island Training School for Boys (Sockanosset) where his father was employed as an engineer.<cite><a href="Adams, Clarence Raymond.html">Adams, Clarence Raymond</a></cite>
After graduation from Cranston High School and a summer spent as night watchman at the reform school where he was born, Adams entered Brown University in the fall of 1915, expecting to major in economics with a business career in mind.<cite><a href="Adams, Clarence Raymond.html">Adams, Clarence Raymond</a></cite>
Clarence Raymond Adams was able by accelerating his studies to graduate in 1918, and delivered a commencement address entitled "The Mathematical Concept of Infinity."<cite><a href="Adams, Clarence Raymond.html">Adams, Clarence Raymond</a></cite>
Clarence Raymond Adams was encouraged by Professor R. G. D. Richardson to do graduate work at Harvard and received his Ph.D. in 1922 for his thesis on partial difference equations, written under the direction of G. D. Birkhoff.<cite><a href="Adams, Clarence Raymond.html">Adams, Clarence Raymond</a></cite>
In 1923 Clarence Raymond Adams returned to Brown as instructor in mathematics and never left again until his retirement in 1965.<cite><a href="Adams, Clarence Raymond.html">Adams, Clarence Raymond</a></cite>
During Clarence Raymond Adams's tenure as chairman of the Department of Mathematics from 1942 to 1960, a number of fine scholars were added to the department.<cite><a href="Adams, Clarence Raymond.html">Adams, Clarence Raymond</a></cite>
Clarence Raymond Adams was, of course, occasionally absent from Brown, traveling for business or pleasure, and he once responded to a class reunion questionnaire which asked the high and low spots of his life: "High spot – Pike’s Peak, 1934, 14,108 feet.<cite><a href="Adams, Clarence Raymond.html">Adams, Clarence Raymond</a></cite>
Low spot – Death Valley – 280 feet, sunk to this level in 1940."<cite><a href="Adams, Clarence Raymond.html">Adams, Clarence Raymond</a></cite>
Clarence Raymond Adams died on October 15, 1965.<cite><a href="Adams, Clarence Raymond.html">Adams, Clarence Raymond</a></cite>
Adams House at 12 George Street, acquired in 1945, is named for Vice-<a href="President.html">President</a> James P. Adams.<cite><a href="Adams House.html">Adams House</a></cite>
A three-storied stucco building with double doors, it was built by Thomas Poynton Ives in the late 1820s.<cite><a href="Adams House.html">Adams House</a></cite>
Adams House was opened as a dormitory for 32 students in 1946.<cite><a href="Adams House.html">Adams House</a></cite>
After serving as a dormitory for both undergraduate and graduate students and for faculty offices, it was unused for two years before being renovated in 1961 as the headquarters of the Institute for Health Sciences which had been housed in Partridge Hall.<cite><a href="Adams House.html">Adams House</a></cite>
James Pickwell Adams (1895-1969), professor of economics and vice-president of Brown University, was born in Carson City, Michigan on January 27, 1895.<cite><a href="Adams, James P..html">Adams, James P.</a></cite>
James P. Adams received his A.B. and A.M. degrees from the University of Michigan and began his teaching career as assistant professor of economics there in 1919.<cite><a href="Adams, James P..html">Adams, James P.</a></cite>
James P. Adams came to Brown as assistant professor in 1921, became a full professor in 1927, and in 1928 was named chairman of the Economics Department at the age of 33, the youngest to be named a department head at the University.<cite><a href="Adams, James P..html">Adams, James P.</a></cite>
James P. Adams was acting vice-president of the University in 1931-32 while President Barbour was in the Far East, and was vice-president from 1932 to 1945.<cite><a href="Adams, James P..html">Adams, James P.</a></cite>
During the first semester of 1936-37 James P. Adams was acting president during the illness of President Barbour and before the arrival of President Wriston.<cite><a href="Adams, James P..html">Adams, James P.</a></cite>
James P. Adams was also acting comptroller in 1927 and 1932-33 and the first administrator of the student loan system which he helped to establish.<cite><a href="Adams, James P..html">Adams, James P.</a></cite>
James P. Adams left Brown in 1945 to become provost at the University of Michigan.<cite><a href="Adams, James P..html">Adams, James P.</a></cite>
James P. Adams came back to Rhode Island in 1951 to retire in Little Compton.<cite><a href="Adams, James P..html">Adams, James P.</a></cite>
In 1955 James P. Adams was appointed to the Board of Trustees of State Colleges and served five of the seven years of his term before cataracts in his eyes caused him to resign.<cite><a href="Adams, James P..html">Adams, James P.</a></cite>
James P. Adams died of a heart attack on February 27, 1969.<cite><a href="Adams, James P..html">Adams, James P.</a></cite>
Jasper Adams (1793-1841), professor of mathematics and natural philosophy, was born in East Medway, Massachusetts, August 27, 1793, prepared for college with Rev. Luther Wright, and graduated from Brown in 1815.<cite><a href="Adams, Jasper.html">Adams, Jasper</a></cite>
Jasper Adams was a tutor at Brown during the year 1818-19, and in 1819 was named professor of mathematics and natural philosophy.<cite><a href="Adams, Jasper.html">Adams, Jasper</a></cite>
Jasper Adams was ordained an Episcopal deacon in 1819 and a priest in 1820.<cite><a href="Adams, Jasper.html">Adams, Jasper</a></cite>
Jasper Adams left Brown in 1824 to become president of Charleston College, where he remained until 1826.<cite><a href="Adams, Jasper.html">Adams, Jasper</a></cite>
The trustees of Charleston called him back in 1828 and the college continued to advance under Jasper Adams's administration.<cite><a href="Adams, Jasper.html">Adams, Jasper</a></cite>
Jasper Adams resigned for the second time in 1836.<cite><a href="Adams, Jasper.html">Adams, Jasper</a></cite>
Jasper Adams served as chaplain and professor of geography, history, and ethics at the U.S. Military Academy at West Point from 1838 to 1840, and then had charge of a seminary in Pendleton, S. C. for a brief time before his death on October 25, 1841.<cite><a href="Adams, Jasper.html">Adams, Jasper</a></cite>
Solomon Drowne of the class of 1773, in an entry in his diary for June 30, 1770, described his examination by <a href="President.html">President</a> Manning and tutor David Howell, which consisted of five verses in the Greek Testament, seven lines in Cicero’s Orations, and five lines in Virgil’s Georgics, after which he was pronounced fit to enter, which he did two days later.<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
The Laws of 1783 prescribed that "No person may expect to be admitted into this College, unless ... able to read accurately construe and parse Tully and the Greek Testament, and Virgil; and ... able to write true Latin in prose, and hath learned the rules of Prosody and Vulgar Arithmetic; and shall bring suitable Testimony of a blameless life &amp; conversation."<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
In 1826 the question of age arose in the requirement that an applicant must have completed his fourteenth year, and at this time, in addition to the usual classical attainments the person "must also be acquainted with ancient and modern Geography, Arithmetic, and <a href="English.html">English</a> Grammar."<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
The Catalogue for 1828-29 added the requirement of "Algebra, as far as Quadratick Equations."<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
A significant change occurred in 1850 with the introduction of Wayland’s "New System."<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
Applicants continued to be examined in Greek, Latin, mathematics, and <a href="English.html">English</a> (geography fell by the wayside in 1874) with the addition of French in 1876 and German (as an alternative to French) in 1891.<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
Two new policies regarding admission were added in 1892.<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
In 1902 Brown joined seven other colleges in the formation of the New England College Entrance Certificate Board for the purpose of approving secondary schools from which students could enter by certificate.<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
The first year that the CECB examination was substituted for Brown’s entrance examination was 1905.<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
In 1915-16 students could be admitted at both the beginning and the middle of the academic year to accommodate midwinter graduates of secondary schools.<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
In 1916 the entrance requirements for the Bachelor of Science degree were eased by making physics or chemistry optional as a prerequisite, and allowing the substitution of an ancient language for a modern language.<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
A requirement that freshman take psychological tests before admission was adopted in 1922.<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
A new policy adopted in 1927 specified that only students in the upper fifth of their high school classes could be admitted by certificate.<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
Also in 1927 the admission of women, which had long been handled by the University <a href="Registrar.html">Registrar</a>, was turned over to the newly-appointed Director of Admission and Personnel of the Women’s College, Eva A. Mooar.<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
In 1934 each alumnus received a copy of the latest edition of "Student Life at Brown," the publication for prospective students, with the request of <a href="President.html">President</a> Barbour that the booklet be placed in the hand of a promising applicant, preferably one for the next fall.<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
In 1948 the eight institutions of the Ivy Group made an agreement that applicants would have until June 15 to accept admission regardless of the date of notification of acceptance, thus making it easier for the student to select a college after hearing from all of them.<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
In 1961 the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> institutions issued a joint statement of admission policies.<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
In January 1963 Brown announced the receipt of a $155,000 grant from the Ford Foundation for an unusual experiment in the admission of "academic risks," to be conducted over a seven-year period.<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
A study was undertaken to discover, through a survey of the success in life of graduates of the early 1950s, why many with poor secondary school records succeed, and to use this information as new criteria for admission.<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
Charles H. Doebler IV, director of admission, reported on the findings of the study in 1970.<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
After 1966, the score was adjusted to 620, a respectable score, to be sure, but an able student is still a risk when he competes against those of even higher ability.<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
In 1972 forty freshmen on the deferred admission plan chose to take a year off before beginning their studies.<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
A new emphasis on attracting transfer students resulted in the admission of more than one hundred in 1972, compared to twenty the year before.<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
In 1973 the eight <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> colleges and M.I.T. agreed on common admission procedures including an early evaluation of applicants and non-binding notification of their likelihood of acceptance.<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
One student, Daniel Snyder, admitted to the Class of 1979, came highly recommended in a letter from none other than renowned Professor Josiah Carberry (q.v.).<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
In 1974 seven of the 9,441 applicants, all high scorers on Latin proficiency tests, received their letters of acceptance in Latin in the style of Cicero, written by classics professor John Rowe Workman.<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
In 1979 the "Brown Alumni Monthly" proclaimed Brown the "most popular private competitive college in the country," with 11,400 applications for admission, a twenty-five per cent increase in two years.<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
In 1980 when applications for admission reached 11,900, it was possible to accept only 2,500 students in order to end up with a freshman class of 1,275.<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
The use of Scholastic Aptitude Test (SAT) scores as one of the factors in admission was challenged by students in 1987 in a referendum recommending that the SAT be an optional requirement.<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
Emery R. Walker was <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> of Admission from 1946 to 1957, and was followed by Lloyd W. Cornell, <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> of Admission and Financial Aid in 1957-58 and Director of Financial Aid from 1958 to 1969, Charles V. Doebler, Director of Admission from 1958 to 1969, and for the women students, Eva A. Mooar from 1947 to 1953, Alberta F. Brown from 1954 to 1970.<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
The separate offices of admission and financial aid merged in July 1987.<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
Alan P. Maynard, who had been Director of Financial Aid since 1974, retired in 1987; James H. Rogers, who had been Director of Admission since 1969, resigned in 1988; and Eric Widmer was named <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> of Admission and Financial Aid.<cite><a href="Admission.html">Admission</a></cite>
African Americans first came to Brown in the 1870s.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
The first known African American graduates were Inman Page and George Washington Milford in the class of 1877.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
Whether there were African American students who entered and left before graduation is unknown, but the account of <a href="Class Day.html">Class Day</a> in the "Providence Journal" in 1877 stated, "Mr.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
Gabriel N. Grisham 1878, who entered in 1874 and left college during his sophomore year, received his bachelor’s degree by special vote in 1900, after he had taught mathematics and astronomy at Lincoln Institute in Missouri and had become principal of Lincoln High School in Kansas City.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
Between 1877 and 1912, Brown graduated five black men who were to become presidents of black colleges, who thus passed their education on to innumerable others.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
Inman Page 1877 was president of Oklahoma’s Agricultural and Normal University, Western Baptist College in Missouri, Roger Williams University in Tennessee, and Lincoln University in Missouri.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
John Hope 1894 taught at Roger Williams University and at Morehouse College and was president of Morehouse and of Atlanta University.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
John William Beverly 1894 was president of Alabama State Normal School, from which he himself had graduated before he came to Brown.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
William Dinkins ’12 spent most of his life at Selma University and was its president from 1935 to 1950.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
Another Brown graduate who had an impact on black education was Joseph T. Robert 1828, a white ordained minister and holder of a medical degree, who took over the care of Augusta Institute for colored ministers in 1871 and moved with that institution when it merged with the Atlanta Baptist Seminary under his presidency.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
Of this venture John Hope said in his class day oration in 1894, "From this small beginning has grown a strong school in the state of Georgia.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
The first African American to receive an advanced degree from Brown was John Wesley Gilbert 1888, who received his A.M. degree in 1891.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
Samuel M. Nabrit was the first African American to earn a Ph.D. at Brown in 1932.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
A graduate of Morehouse College, he was encouraged to apply to Brown by John Hope 1894, who, as Nabrit said, "had a fantasy that one of his students would go back to Brown and indicate that he had developed a college – Morehouse – that enabled students to have the strengths to make it at an <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> school like Brown."<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
Brown awarded him an honorary degree in 1962, and he was the the first African American trustee, elected in 1967.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
After twenty years as professor at Atlanta University, Nabrit became president of Texas Southern University in 1955.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
A Brown chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People was established in 1955.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
The Afro-American Society was founded in the spring of 1967, when its constitution was accepted by the University upon agreement that white students would not be barred from membership.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
The first Black Arts Festival, "New Souls of Black Folks," was held in April 1968.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
In December 1968 65 of the 85 black students enrolled marched down College Hill to the Congdon Street Baptist Church, where they camped for three days in an attempt to force the University to increase the number of blacks in each entering class to eleven per cent, the percentage of blacks in the national population.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
The next year there were 128 black students in the entering class of 1973.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
On December 10 and 11, 1969 black students boycotted classes in a protest aimed at an agreement of specific goals to increase black faculty and administrators.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
The affirmative action report required by the federal government in 1972 indicated that Brown had 19 black faculty members out of a total of 607.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
The number of black students had risen from 85 (2.3 per cent) in 1968 to 417 (8.9 per cent) in 1972.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
In 1969 the Afro-American Society was given quarters in Afro House at 227 Bowen Street, which for an annual rent of one dollar provided meeting rooms and offices on the first floor and living accommodations above.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
In 1972 the Society moved to <a href="Churchill House.html">Churchill House</a> and changed its name to the Organization of United African Peoples (OUAP), The controversy over the change of name pitted those students who believed the organization ought to concern itself with University issues against those who felt it should be a black nationalist group concerned with community and even international issues.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
On April 24 and 25, 1975 members of the Third World Coalition led by the OUAP took over <a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a> to protest cuts in financial aid, citing the effect on admission of minority students.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
On February 1, 1978, Shaun D. Braun became president of the Undergraduate Council of Students and the first black woman to head the student body of an <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> College.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
Alpha Gamma chapter of Alpha Phi Alpha was established in Providence by a few professional men and some Brown students in 1921.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
In 1947 George Lima ’48 and Charles Bentley ’44 were initiated into Gamma chapter of Omega Psi Phi in Boston.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
Theta Epsilon was for a time in the 1950s a graduate chapter, then gained more undergraduate members in the late 1950s, before becoming inactive from 1962 to 1970.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
Alpha Phi Alpha was reactivated in the 1970s.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
The Class of 1993, admitted in 1989 had 111 African Americans, eight per cent of the class.<cite><a href="African Americans.html">African Americans</a></cite>
Afro-American Studies entered the curriculum when Jay Saunders Redding ’28 was a visiting professor at Brown during the first semester of 1949-50.<cite><a href="Afro-American Studies.html">Afro-American Studies</a></cite>
In September 1968 the administration responded to student demand and added a course in American negro literature to the already planned history course, "<a href="History.html">History</a> of the Negro in America," a colloquium limited to twenty students and conducted by Professor John L. Thomas.<cite><a href="Afro-American Studies.html">Afro-American Studies</a></cite>
In January 1969 a seminar on "Black assertion" was taught by Professor Edward N. Beiser and <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> William A.<cite><a href="Afro-American Studies.html">Afro-American Studies</a></cite>
By the end of 1968-69 an independent concentration in Afro-American Studies designed by a committee of both faculty and students headed by Charles H. Philbrick was approved.<cite><a href="Afro-American Studies.html">Afro-American Studies</a></cite>
Professor Charles H. Nichols arrived in July 1969 to became chairman of the new interdepartmental concentration.<cite><a href="Afro-American Studies.html">Afro-American Studies</a></cite>
In 1969-70 one of the "Special Topics in Literature" courses offered in the Department of <a href="English.html">English</a> was "Negro Literature in America from the Harlem Renaissance to the Present," taught by Professor Nichols.<cite><a href="Afro-American Studies.html">Afro-American Studies</a></cite>
An announcement of Afro-American Studies courses appeared as an insert in the annual catalogue for 1970-71, which announced the Afro-American Studies Program with W. A. Jeanpierre as chairman, and listed new courses which focused attention on aspects of the black experience which were not covered by the courses related to Afro-American studies in the <a href="Anthropology.html">Anthropology</a>, <a href="English.html">English</a>, French, <a href="History.html">History</a>, <a href="Music.html">Music</a>, and <a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a> Departments.<cite><a href="Afro-American Studies.html">Afro-American Studies</a></cite>
In 1971 the Afro-American Studies Program, the undergraduate Afro-American Society and the Graduate Minority Association received <a href="Churchill House.html">Churchill House</a> for use as as academic and cultural center.<cite><a href="Afro-American Studies.html">Afro-American Studies</a></cite>
In 1981 the program was ranked in the top fifteen in the country by the Chicago Center for Afro-American Studies and ranked fourth in articles published in scholarly black studies journals and fifth in service on editorial boards of such journals.<cite><a href="Afro-American Studies.html">Afro-American Studies</a></cite>
Rites and Reason, the research theatre and performing arts component of Afro-American Studies, formed in 1970, provided interaction with the local Afro-American community.<cite><a href="Afro-American Studies.html">Afro-American Studies</a></cite>
Bass had been an assistant to poet Langston Hughes from 1959 to 1964.<cite><a href="Afro-American Studies.html">Afro-American Studies</a></cite>
In April 1971 the new group performed Bass’s "Black Masque."<cite><a href="Afro-American Studies.html">Afro-American Studies</a></cite>
The first of these was based on a 1973 independent study, "Oral <a href="History.html">History</a> as An Index to Change," in which Jones’s students interviewed elderly blacks on the subject of race relations in Providence from 1920 to 1940.<cite><a href="Afro-American Studies.html">Afro-American Studies</a></cite>
The resulting performance was "The Providence Garden Blues," written by Bass and staged in 1975.<cite><a href="Afro-American Studies.html">Afro-American Studies</a></cite>
In 1988 Rites and Reason was cited by the New England Theatre Conference for "original work on the New World and Afro-American Experience," and by the National Council for Culture and Arts for sustained "excellence in Afro-American Theatre."<cite><a href="Afro-American Studies.html">Afro-American Studies</a></cite>
"Mulebone," a Rites and Reason play, was produced on Broadway in 1989.<cite><a href="Afro-American Studies.html">Afro-American Studies</a></cite>
In 1992 Rites and Reason was the first black theatre invited to represent the United States at the International Theatre Festival, at which "Letters from a New England Negro," written by Sherley Anne Williams ’73 A.M. and directed by Benny Sato Ambush ’73, was performed.<cite><a href="Afro-American Studies.html">Afro-American Studies</a></cite>
Agricultural lands were awarded to Brown as a result of the Morrill Act passed by Congress in July 1862, giving land scrip to states and territories which established a college or department of agriculture and the mechanic arts, at which some students would be educated at the rate of $100 a year to the extent of the annual income from the sale of the lands.<cite><a href="Agricultural lands.html">Agricultural lands</a></cite>
In January 1863 the Rhode Island legislature accepted the grant of 120,000 acres (thirty thousand for each senator and representative from the state) and transferred the land scrip to Brown University.<cite><a href="Agricultural lands.html">Agricultural lands</a></cite>
In the summer of 1863 <a href="President.html">President</a> Sears and Horace T. Love 1836 inspected the land, which was located in Kansas.<cite><a href="Agricultural lands.html">Agricultural lands</a></cite>
Since the first payment on the sale of the land was due in 1866 and the deadline for establishing the agricultural department was July 1867, Professor George Ide Chace, president "ad interim" after the resignation of Barnas Sears, arranged a program of courses from the existing curriculum, which was printed in the annual catalogue.<cite><a href="Agricultural lands.html">Agricultural lands</a></cite>
Two of the appointed state beneficiaries arrived in 1869.<cite><a href="Agricultural lands.html">Agricultural lands</a></cite>
By 1873 there were 25 students receiving the scholarships, six of them in the senior class.<cite><a href="Agricultural lands.html">Agricultural lands</a></cite>
In 1871 the state legislature had come to the conclusion that the instruction which the University was able to provide did not satisfy the requirements of the Morrill Act.<cite><a href="Agricultural lands.html">Agricultural lands</a></cite>
He reported in 1873 that he had delivered "a brief course of lectures to those members of the senior class who, late in the year, obtained agricultural scholarships.... For the purpose of illustration, one day, after the close of the course, was devoted to an examination of the farm of G. F. Wilson Esq., in East Providence; and another to dissections of neat stock, in the extensive slaughter-house of Mr. Comstock.<cite><a href="Agricultural lands.html">Agricultural lands</a></cite>
In 1881 the junior class in general zoology visited the East Providence farm of William H. Hopkins to learn about raising cattle.<cite><a href="Agricultural lands.html">Agricultural lands</a></cite>
When the Hatch Act of 1887 was passed, appropriating $15,000 annually for agricultural activities in the colleges, an amendment, influenced by the organization of farmers known as the Grange, stated that the money need not be applied to the existing land grant colleges, but could be used for agricultural experiment stations not connected with the colleges.<cite><a href="Agricultural lands.html">Agricultural lands</a></cite>
The General Assembly of Rhode Island, having become increasingly critical of Brown’s agricultural endeavors, chose to establish a new agricultural school in Kingston, which opened with 33 students on September 23, 1890.<cite><a href="Agricultural lands.html">Agricultural lands</a></cite>
On May 19, 1892 the General Assembly converted the agricultural school in Kingston into Rhode Island College for the Agricultural and Mechanic Arts and awarded it the funds from the second Morrill Act.<cite><a href="Agricultural lands.html">Agricultural lands</a></cite>
In its January 1894 session the General Assembly approved an agreement in which Brown would repay the $50,000 received from the sale of the land in Kansas and assume the expense of educating the present holders of the state scholarships, and in return would receive $40,000 in compensation for the education of earlier state scholars and would be relieved of the responsibility for agricultural education assumed in connection with the Morrill Act of 1863.<cite><a href="Agricultural lands.html">Agricultural lands</a></cite>
It was founded by students from seven European countries in 1948 to strengthen international relations through the exchange of student workers.<cite><a href="AIESEC.html">AIESEC</a></cite>
Since about 1959 Brown has participated in this student-run operation and, as a member of the Rhode Island branch composed of students from Brown, Providence College and Rhode Island College, solicits aid from local corporations to send students abroad as trainees, sponsors conferences and brings speakers from the business world to the campus, holds fruit basket sales to help with expenses, and handles arrangements for the students who become summer trainees in foreign countries.<cite><a href="AIESEC.html">AIESEC</a></cite>
Aldrich-Dexter Field, consisting of thirty-nine acres within the stone wall along Hope Street, Stimson Avenue, Angell Street, Arlington Avenue, and Lloyd Avenue, was purchased in 1957 as an athletic facility for the University.<cite><a href="Aldrich-Dexter Field.html">Aldrich-Dexter Field</a></cite>
In 1824, the property, known at the time as the Neck Farm, was left to the city of Providence under the will of Ebenezer Knight Dexter as a poor farm for indigent freemen.<cite><a href="Aldrich-Dexter Field.html">Aldrich-Dexter Field</a></cite>
The wall around the farm was built in 1835.<cite><a href="Aldrich-Dexter Field.html">Aldrich-Dexter Field</a></cite>
The Commissioners of the Dexter Donation reported in 1840, "The whole length of the wall is six thousand two hundred and twenty and one-half feet, and contains seven thousand eight hundred and forty cords of stone.<cite><a href="Aldrich-Dexter Field.html">Aldrich-Dexter Field</a></cite>
In 1947 the city petitioned the Superior Court for permission to sell the land and use the proceeds in other ways "to ameliorate the conditions of the poor" as Dexter’s will intended.<cite><a href="Aldrich-Dexter Field.html">Aldrich-Dexter Field</a></cite>
After lengthy proceedings the sale of the land by sealed bids on September 26, 1957 was authorized.<cite><a href="Aldrich-Dexter Field.html">Aldrich-Dexter Field</a></cite>
Playing fields for sports other than football were laid out on Aldrich-Dexter Field, and through the years buildings for athletic purposes have been added; <a href="Meehan Auditorium.html">Meehan Auditorium</a>, the hockey rink, in 1961; Smith Swim Center in 1972; <a href="Olney-Margolies Athletic Center.html">Olney-Margolies Athletic Center</a> in 1981; and <a href="Pizzitola Sports Center.html">Pizzitola Sports Center</a> in 1989.<cite><a href="Aldrich-Dexter Field.html">Aldrich-Dexter Field</a></cite>
The baseball field was named <a href="Aldrich Field.html">Aldrich Field</a> in 1959 in honor of Edward B. Aldrich 1893.<cite><a href="Aldrich-Dexter Field.html">Aldrich-Dexter Field</a></cite>
The soccer field was named Stevenson Field in 1979 in honor of coach Cliff Stevenson.<cite><a href="Aldrich-Dexter Field.html">Aldrich-Dexter Field</a></cite>
The whole athletic complex was renamed the Wendell R. <a href="Erickson Athletic Complex.html">Erickson Athletic Complex</a> in 1988.<cite><a href="Aldrich-Dexter Field.html">Aldrich-Dexter Field</a></cite>
Aldrich Field on Elmgrove Avenue was dedicated at a baseball game on May 16, 1925, before a crowd of 7000, which filled the new grandstand and "a small wooden stand ... hastily erected to accommodate the overflow."<cite><a href="Aldrich Field.html">Aldrich Field</a></cite>
Two brothers, Henry L. Aldrich 1876 and Charles T. Aldrich 1877, were there to hear the field named for them.<cite><a href="Aldrich Field.html">Aldrich Field</a></cite>
They also gave a demonstration of 1870s pitching, with Charles as pitcher and Henry as catcher, before the main event, a game with Dartmouth which Brown won, 3-2.<cite><a href="Aldrich Field.html">Aldrich Field</a></cite>
In 1924 the Aldrich brothers had subscribed $100,000 toward the new athletic facilities, and on April 8, 1925 added $500,000 on condition that the University could match this amount from other sources.<cite><a href="Aldrich Field.html">Aldrich Field</a></cite>
In the summer of 1943, and again in 1944, plots of land at Aldrich Field were made available to faculty and employees of the University to plant "Victory Gardens," in which to raise their own vegetables as part of the <a href="World War II.html">World War II</a> effort.<cite><a href="Aldrich Field.html">Aldrich Field</a></cite>
During the week after <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> in 1931 both brothers died within four days of each other.<cite><a href="Aldrich Field.html">Aldrich Field</a></cite>
The field was their memorial, and after the new athletic fields were acquired in 1958, Aldrich Field was sold in 1961 for a residential development which included streets named for Presidents Maxcy, Faunce, Barbour, and Wriston.<cite><a href="Aldrich Field.html">Aldrich Field</a></cite>
Zachariah Allen (1795-1882), scientist and inventor, was born in Providence on September 15, 1795.<cite><a href="Allen, Zachariah.html">Allen, Zachariah</a></cite>
Zachariah Allen graduated from Brown in 1813, studied law in the office of James Burrill, and was admitted to the bar in 1815.<cite><a href="Allen, Zachariah.html">Allen, Zachariah</a></cite>
In 1825 Zachariah Allen went to Europe to observe woolen manufactures and wrote "The Practical Tourist."<cite><a href="Allen, Zachariah.html">Allen, Zachariah</a></cite>
Zachariah Allen published "Philosophy of the Mechanics of Nature" in 1851 and "Solar Light and Heat" in 1879.<cite><a href="Allen, Zachariah.html">Allen, Zachariah</a></cite>
Zachariah Allen invented the automatic cut-off valve, which was patented in 1833.<cite><a href="Allen, Zachariah.html">Allen, Zachariah</a></cite>
Zachariah Allen founded the Manufacturers’ Mutual Fire Insurance Company in 1835, introducing his system of basing premiums on the effectiveness of safety equipment.<cite><a href="Allen, Zachariah.html">Allen, Zachariah</a></cite>
In support of the working man, Allen was instrumental in the founding of the first free evening school in New England in 1840, and in the establishment of the Providence Association of Manufacturers and Mechanics.<cite><a href="Allen, Zachariah.html">Allen, Zachariah</a></cite>
Zachariah Allen's article "On the Volume of the Niagara River" in 1844 provided the first calculation of the volume of Niagara Falls.<cite><a href="Allen, Zachariah.html">Allen, Zachariah</a></cite>
Throughout his life Zachariah Allen had a continuing interest in the University, serving as a trustee from 1826 to 1882.<cite><a href="Allen, Zachariah.html">Allen, Zachariah</a></cite>
Zachariah Allen died in Providence on March 17, 1882.<cite><a href="Allen, Zachariah.html">Allen, Zachariah</a></cite>
Anne Crosby Emery Allinson (1871-1932), second dean (and first woman dean) of the Women’s College, was Miss Emery when she took office at the Women’s College in September 1900.<cite><a href="Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery.html">Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery</a></cite>
Anne Crosby Emery Allinson was born in Hancock Point, Maine, on January 1, 1871.<cite><a href="Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery.html">Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery</a></cite>
A graduate of Bryn Mawr in 1892, Anne Crosby Emery Allinson studied abroad for two years on the "European scholarship," the highest honor that could be won by a Bryn Mawr student.<cite><a href="Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery.html">Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery</a></cite>
After study at the University of Leipzig, Anne Crosby Emery Allinson returned to Bryn Mawr to receive her Ph.D. degree in 1896, writing a thesis, "The Historical Present in Early Latin."<cite><a href="Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery.html">Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery</a></cite>
In 1897 Anne Crosby Emery Allinson became assistant professor of classical philology and the first dean of women at the University of Wisconsin., which had four hundred women students.<cite><a href="Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery.html">Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery</a></cite>
In 1900, when Anne Crosby Emery Allinson became dean, the Women’s College at Brown had only 149 students.<cite><a href="Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery.html">Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery</a></cite>
Upon her marriage to <a href="Allinson, Francis Greenleaf.html">Francis Greenleaf Allinson</a> in 1905 she resigned as dean to be a homemaker and step-mother to Susanne Allinson, who later married Mrs. Allinson’s brother, Henry Emery.<cite><a href="Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery.html">Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery</a></cite>
Anne Crosby Emery Allinson also published "Roads from Rome" in 1913, "Children of the Way" in 1923, and "Friends with Life" in 1924.<cite><a href="Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery.html">Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery</a></cite>
Anne Crosby Emery Allinson was called back to serve as dean in 1921 and remained through the first semester of 1923-24.<cite><a href="Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery.html">Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery</a></cite>
Anne Crosby Emery Allinson led a campaign for a building and auditorium for the Club, which was built in 1926 at Abbott Park Place.<cite><a href="Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery.html">Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery</a></cite>
In 1925 Anne Crosby Emery Allinson was elected member-at-large of the Providence School Committee, and served until 1931, when she declined to seek reelection.<cite><a href="Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery.html">Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery</a></cite>
In the fall of 1926 Anne Crosby Emery Allinson became editor of the women’s page of the "Providence Evening Bulletin," and her column, "The Distaff," appeared for the next six years.<cite><a href="Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery.html">Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery</a></cite>
In 1929 a building at the University of Wisconsin was named for Anne Crosby Emery Allinson's.<cite><a href="Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery.html">Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery</a></cite>
Mrs. Allinson was killed in a tragic accident in Ellsworth, Maine, near her summer home at Hancock Point, August 16, 1932.<cite><a href="Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery.html">Allinson, Anne Crosby Emery</a></cite>
Francis Greenleaf Allinson (1856-1931), professor of classical philology, was born in Burlington, New Jersey, on December 16, 1856.<cite><a href="Allinson, Francis Greenleaf.html">Allinson, Francis Greenleaf</a></cite>
Francis Greenleaf Allinson taught at Haverford, the University School in Baltimore, and Williams before becoming associate professor of Greek at Brown in 1895.<cite><a href="Allinson, Francis Greenleaf.html">Allinson, Francis Greenleaf</a></cite>
Francis Greenleaf Allinson was named professor of classical philology in 1898.<cite><a href="Allinson, Francis Greenleaf.html">Allinson, Francis Greenleaf</a></cite>
In 1905, some years after the death of his first wife, Francis Greenleaf Allinson married Dean Anne Crosby Emery of the Women’s College and together they wrote "Greek Lands and Letters," which was published in 1909.<cite><a href="Allinson, Francis Greenleaf.html">Allinson, Francis Greenleaf</a></cite>
Francis Greenleaf Allinson was Annual Professor at the American School at Athens in 1910-11, Sather Lecturer at the University of California in 1917, and president of the American Philological Association in 1922-23.<cite><a href="Allinson, Francis Greenleaf.html">Allinson, Francis Greenleaf</a></cite>
Professor Allinson retired from active teaching in 1928 and died June 23, 1931 at Hancock Point, Maine.<cite><a href="Allinson, Francis Greenleaf.html">Allinson, Francis Greenleaf</a></cite>
The Alma Mater made its first appearance in "The <a href="Brown Paper.html">Brown Paper</a>" of 1860 (which for some reason was that year entitled "The <a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a>)."<cite><a href="Alma Mater.html">Alma Mater</a></cite>
James Andrews DeWolf 1861 had been appointed Psi Upsilon’s editor for the paper and had been urged to write a poem.<cite><a href="Alma Mater.html">Alma Mater</a></cite>
The song he wrote, named "Old Brown," did not gain the hoped-for popularity among the students at that time, but was later discovered by the Glee Club and sung at a concert in 1869.<cite><a href="Alma Mater.html">Alma Mater</a></cite>
The Alumnae Association began in 1900, when by invitation of the Class of 1899 of the Women’s College the first association of women graduates of Brown was formed and named the Andrews Association in honor of E. Benjamin Andrews.<cite><a href="Alumnae Association.html">Alumnae Association</a></cite>
Charlotte Tillinghast 1896 was elected temporary president, and the next year became the first president of the permanent organization.<cite><a href="Alumnae Association.html">Alumnae Association</a></cite>
In 1906, when the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> provided for alumnae representation on the Advisory Council for the Women’s College, the Andrews Association with its voluntary membership became the all-inclusive Alumnae Association of Brown University.<cite><a href="Alumnae Association.html">Alumnae Association</a></cite>
In 1914 the Alumnae Association was admitted to membership in the Association of Collegiate Alumnae.<cite><a href="Alumnae Association.html">Alumnae Association</a></cite>
In 1909 Boston and New York alumnae clubs were formed, followed by a Connecticut Valley club, and a Washington club.<cite><a href="Alumnae Association.html">Alumnae Association</a></cite>
The Providence Club was formed in 1923 and immediately subscribed $5000 for the building of <a href="Alumnae Hall.html">Alumnae Hall</a>.<cite><a href="Alumnae Association.html">Alumnae Association</a></cite>
In 1952 the New York and Providence clubs changed their names from Brown Alumnae Club to <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a> Club.<cite><a href="Alumnae Association.html">Alumnae Association</a></cite>
After the merger of <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a> with Brown University in 1971, the alumnae clubs began to merge with the Brown Clubs.<cite><a href="Alumnae Association.html">Alumnae Association</a></cite>
There was a separate alumnae meeting at <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> for the first time in 1933, which took place at the same time as the meeting of alumni.<cite><a href="Alumnae Association.html">Alumnae Association</a></cite>
Among the executive secretaries of the Association were Elizabeth L. Young ’24 from 1927 to 1929, Gertrude Allen McConnell ’10 from 1929 to 1955, Doris Hopkins Stapelton ’28 from 1955 to 1972, and Mary Louise Reece Barksdale ’51 in 1972-73.<cite><a href="Alumnae Association.html">Alumnae Association</a></cite>
On June 3, 1973 the Brown Alumnae Association merged with the <a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a>.<cite><a href="Alumnae Association.html">Alumnae Association</a></cite>
Alumnae Hall on the Pembroke <a href="Campus.html">Campus</a> was dedicated on October 11, 1927.<cite><a href="Alumnae Hall.html">Alumnae Hall</a></cite>
Funds for the building had been raised through the efforts of the <a href="Alumnae Association.html">Alumnae Association</a> which initiated its campaign at its annual meeting in June 1923, when it was announced that Stephen O. Metcalf would duplicate all gifts of students and alumnae.<cite><a href="Alumnae Hall.html">Alumnae Hall</a></cite>
The campaign continued until 1926, when the $50,000 contributed by the students and the $150,000 contributed by the alumnae, together with Mr. Metcalf’s matching funds, were deemed sufficient to start the building.<cite><a href="Alumnae Hall.html">Alumnae Hall</a></cite>
The cornerstone was laid on May 11, 1926.<cite><a href="Alumnae Hall.html">Alumnae Hall</a></cite>
It was informally opened in April 1927 to ease the overcrowding of <a href="Pembroke Hall.html">Pembroke Hall</a>.<cite><a href="Alumnae Hall.html">Alumnae Hall</a></cite>
When "The Gate," a snack bar with a white picket fence, was opened in Alumnae Hall in 1947, Pembroke students, who were allowed in the Blue Room in <a href="Faunce House.html">Faunce House</a> only when escorted by a Brown man, now had a place of their own, where Brown men were welcome, but only when accompanied by a Pembroker.<cite><a href="Alumnae Hall.html">Alumnae Hall</a></cite>
Alumni Field Day became part of the <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> festivities in 1958.<cite><a href="Alumni Field Day.html">Alumni Field Day</a></cite>
Two years earlier the class of 1951 had held a Thayer Field carnival at its reunion.<cite><a href="Alumni Field Day.html">Alumni Field Day</a></cite>
In 1957 the classes of 1949, 1950, and 1951 joined in a similar celebration of their off-year on-campus reunion in a tent, with activities for the whole family.<cite><a href="Alumni Field Day.html">Alumni Field Day</a></cite>
Alumni Field Day took place in 1958 on newly acquired <a href="Aldrich-Dexter Field.html">Aldrich-Dexter Field</a> with a circus tent for headquarters and a smaller tent for the twenty-fifth reunion class.<cite><a href="Alumni Field Day.html">Alumni Field Day</a></cite>
The event was renamed Brown Field Day in 1974.<cite><a href="Alumni Field Day.html">Alumni Field Day</a></cite>
Alumni House was a nineteenth century dwelling (the White residence) at 17 Benevolent Street into which the Alumni Offices moved in September 1947.<cite><a href="Alumni House.html">Alumni House</a></cite>
From 1970 to 1974 the house at 159 George Street was Alumni House.<cite><a href="Alumni House.html">Alumni House</a></cite>
In 1974 the Alumni offices moved into the <a href="Maddock Alumni Center.html">Maddock Alumni Center</a>.<cite><a href="Alumni House.html">Alumni House</a></cite>
The building at 59 George Street was occupied by the Department of <a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a> in 1970 and named Steiger House in 1984 in recognition of the generosity of W. Sheldon Steiger ’34.<cite><a href="Alumni House.html">Alumni House</a></cite>
Ambassadors and ministers to foreign countries have included Brown men since the early nineteenth century, among them: Jonathan Russell 1791, ambassador to Sweden and Norway; Henry Wheaton 1802, minister to Prussia; Christopher Robinson 1825, minister to Peru; George Van Ness Lothrop 1838, minister to Russia; Lewis Richmond 1842, minister to Portugal; Samuel Sullivan Cox 1846, minister to Turkey; James Burrill Angell 1849, minister to China and Turkey; John Hay 1858, ambassador to Great Britain; John Meredith Read 1858, minister to Greece; Frederick M. Sackett 1890, ambassador to Germany; Leland Howard Littlefield 1892, ambassador to Great Britain; Noble B. Judah ’04, ambassador to Cuba; Ely E. Palmer ’08, ambassador to Afghanistan; Roy Tasco Davis ’10, minister to Guatemala and Costa Rica, and Panama; Warren Randolph Burgess ’12, ambassador to NATO; Dana Gardner Munro ’12, minister to Haiti; Willard L. Beaulac ’20, ambassador to Paraguay, Columbia, Cuba, Chile, and Argentina; John J. Muccio ’21, ambassador to Korea, Iceland, and Guatemala; Will Mercer Cook A.M.’31, ambassador to Niger and Senegal; Clinton E. Knox A.M.’31, ambassador to Dahomey; Thomas J. Watson, Jr. ’37, ambassador to the U.S.S.R.; Taylor G. Belcher ’41, ambassador to Cyprus; William H. Sullivan ’43, ambassador to Laos; and Nathaniel Davis ’46, ambassador to Guatemala.<cite><a href="Ambassadors and ministers.html">Ambassadors and ministers</a></cite>
The American Band played at Brown graduations from at least 1847, when Brown paid eighty dollars for its services.<cite><a href="American Band.html">American Band</a></cite>
The band was called the American Brass Band in 1837 when it emerged as a reorganization of the Providence Brass Band founded in 1826 by Joe Greene.<cite><a href="American Band.html">American Band</a></cite>
David Wallis Reeves became the leader in 1866.<cite><a href="American Band.html">American Band</a></cite>
Reeves wrote more than one hundred marches and he "adapted" the Brown <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> March, which has been played during the procession to the <a href="First Baptist Church.html">First Baptist Church</a> since 1869 and was first published as a piano solo in 1891.<cite><a href="American Band.html">American Band</a></cite>
The band played for Commencements until 1970, after which the Brown Band accompanied the procession.<cite><a href="American Band.html">American Band</a></cite>
The American Civilization program began in 1945 as an interdepartmental effort under a general committee headed by Professor Randall Stewart, and featured Stewart’s course, "Studies in American Literature," James B. Hedges’ "<a href="History.html">History</a> of American Economic Life," Guy Dodge’s "American Political Theory," and Hans Kurath’s "<a href="History.html">History</a> of American <a href="English.html">English</a>."<cite><a href="American Civilization.html">American Civilization</a></cite>
In 1949 a $36,500 grant from the Carnegie <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> of New York financed new courses in the history of science, philosophy, and art and architecture in the United States as aspects of its life and culture.<cite><a href="American Civilization.html">American Civilization</a></cite>
American Civilization, at first a graduate program leading to a master of arts or a Ph.D. degree, became an undergraduate concentration in 1949.<cite><a href="American Civilization.html">American Civilization</a></cite>
The program continued to be administered by an interdepartmental committee, which has been chaired or co-chaired by Donald Fleming, William G. McLoughlin, Hyatt H. Waggoner, Barry D. Karl, John L. Thomas, George Monteiro, Howard P. Chudacoff, David H. Hirsch, Bruce A. Rosenberg, Barton St. Armand, and Wilson J. Moses, In 1988 the program received departmental status and has been chaired by Mari Jo Buhle and Richard A. Meckle.<cite><a href="American Civilization.html">American Civilization</a></cite>
In the first edition in 1903, Brown graduates and faculty members so honored were John Howard Appleton 1863 (chemistry), Henry Parker Manning 1883 (mathematics), Hermon Carey Bumpus 1884 (zoology), Alfred D. Ames House, built about 1830 by Samuel Ames 1823 on the corner of Power and Brook Streets, was given to Brown in 1937 by Mrs. John Ormsbee Ames and Frank Mauran, Jr. Twenty-four rooms were remodeled to house thirty-eight graduate students who moved in the next year.<cite><a href="Ames House.html">Ames House</a></cite>
In 1949, before the <a href="Wriston Quadrangle.html">Wriston Quadrangle</a> was built, Ames House was deeded to the city of Providence in return for the Thayer Street School, which stood within the confines of the proposed quadrangle.<cite><a href="Ames House.html">Ames House</a></cite>
The city razed the building, and replaced it with the Brook Street Fire Station in 1950.<cite><a href="Ames House.html">Ames House</a></cite>
In 1958 the name was given to a dormitory at 150 George Street, which was half of the building at the corner of Thayer Street.<cite><a href="Ames House.html">Ames House</a></cite>
In 1961, when the Department of <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a> moved into the other half of the house, that section was named <a href="Howell House.html">Howell House</a>, taking its name from the former home of the <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a> Department on College Street.<cite><a href="Ames House.html">Ames House</a></cite>
The building continued to be identified by its two sections, Ames House and <a href="Howell House.html">Howell House</a> until about 1971, when the name of <a href="Howell House.html">Howell House</a> was applied to the entire building (now identified as 153-155 Thayer Street).<cite><a href="Ames House.html">Ames House</a></cite>

George Kumler Anderson (1901-1980), professor of English, was born in Springfield, Illinois, on October 20, 1901.<cite><a href="Anderson, George K..html">Anderson, George K.</a></cite>
George K. Anderson graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy at the age of thirteen, and spent a postgraduate year there before entering Harvard, where he earned three degrees, a bachelor of arts in 1920, a master of arts in 1921, and a Ph.D. in 1925.<cite><a href="Anderson, George K..html">Anderson, George K.</a></cite>
He taught for several years at <a href="Washington, George.html">George Washington</a> University before coming to Brown as assistant professor in 1927.<cite><a href="Anderson, George K..html">Anderson, George K.</a></cite>
George K. Anderson was promoted to associate professor in 1930 and professor in 1947.<cite><a href="Anderson, George K..html">Anderson, George K.</a></cite>
Anderson published "The Literature of the Anglo-Saxons" in 1949, and "English Literature from the Beginnings to 1485" in 1950.<cite><a href="Anderson, George K..html">Anderson, George K.</a></cite>
In 1945 George K. Anderson was granted a Guggenheim fellowship for research on the legend of the Wandering Jew, which culminated in "The Legend of the Wandering Jew," published in 1965.<cite><a href="Anderson, George K..html">Anderson, George K.</a></cite>
George K. Anderson was chairman of the Department of English from 1950 to 1960, and retired in 1972.<cite><a href="Anderson, George K..html">Anderson, George K.</a></cite>
George K. Anderson died on January 2, 1980 in Providence.<cite><a href="Anderson, George K..html">Anderson, George K.</a></cite>
K(arl) Brooke Anderson (1892-1975), executive secretary of the Brown Christian Association, was born in Cardwell, Virginia, on August 31, 1892.<cite><a href="Anderson, Karl Brooke.html">Anderson, Karl Brooke</a></cite>
After graduation from the University of Richmond in 1916 and graduate work at Cornell, Karl Brooke Anderson worked with the French Army Ambulance Service for two years, and was awarded the Silver Star.<cite><a href="Anderson, Karl Brooke.html">Anderson, Karl Brooke</a></cite>
In 1921 Karl Brooke Anderson entered Yale Divinity School.<cite><a href="Anderson, Karl Brooke.html">Anderson, Karl Brooke</a></cite>
When Karl Brooke Anderson graduated in 1924, he chose not to be ordained in any particular faith, as he wanted to work with all young people.<cite><a href="Anderson, Karl Brooke.html">Anderson, Karl Brooke</a></cite>
From 1924 to 1928 Karl Brooke Anderson was executive secretary of the first college YMCA in the country at the University of Virginia.<cite><a href="Anderson, Karl Brooke.html">Anderson, Karl Brooke</a></cite>
In 1928 Karl Brooke Anderson came to Brown as executive secretary of the Brown Christian Association and remained until his retirement in 1957.<cite><a href="Anderson, Karl Brooke.html">Anderson, Karl Brooke</a></cite>
Karl Brooke Anderson took two leaves of absence, in 1947 to raise money for YMCA work in Europe and Asia, and in 1949 to work with Palestine refugees.<cite><a href="Anderson, Karl Brooke.html">Anderson, Karl Brooke</a></cite>
Karl Brooke Anderson retired from Brown in 1957, but remained active, and took part in a Vietnam war demonstration in Newport in 1971.<cite><a href="Anderson, Karl Brooke.html">Anderson, Karl Brooke</a></cite>
Karl Brooke Anderson died on October 18, 1975 in Newton Lower Falls, Massachusetts.<cite><a href="Anderson, Karl Brooke.html">Anderson, Karl Brooke</a></cite>
Elisha Benjamin Andrews (1844-1917), eighth president of Brown University, was born in Hinsdale, New Hampshire, on January 10, 1844.<cite><a href="Andrews, Elisha Benjamin.html">Andrews, Elisha Benjamin</a></cite>
Elisha Benjamin Andrews rose to the rank of second lieutenant, and was severely wounded in a battle on the James River on August 24, 1864.<cite><a href="Andrews, Elisha Benjamin.html">Andrews, Elisha Benjamin</a></cite>
Elisha Benjamin Andrews lost the sight of his left eye, which was replaced by a glass eye in 1884.<cite><a href="Andrews, Elisha Benjamin.html">Andrews, Elisha Benjamin</a></cite>
Elisha Benjamin Andrews was mustered out of the army in October 1864.<cite><a href="Andrews, Elisha Benjamin.html">Andrews, Elisha Benjamin</a></cite>
Elisha Benjamin Andrews entered Brown in 1866 at the age of 22 and graduated in 1870.<cite><a href="Andrews, Elisha Benjamin.html">Andrews, Elisha Benjamin</a></cite>
Elisha Benjamin Andrews graduated from Newton Theological Institution in 1874, and was ordained in Beverly, Massachusetts, where he served as pastor for one year until he was called to the presidency of Denison University in 1875.<cite><a href="Andrews, Elisha Benjamin.html">Andrews, Elisha Benjamin</a></cite>
Andrews left Denison in 1879, possibly because his liberal ideas irritated the trustees, although he remained a trustee until 1892.<cite><a href="Andrews, Elisha Benjamin.html">Andrews, Elisha Benjamin</a></cite>
Elisha Benjamin Andrews became a professor of homiletics and pastoral theology at Newton, where he remained until 1882.<cite><a href="Andrews, Elisha Benjamin.html">Andrews, Elisha Benjamin</a></cite>
While still at Newton in 1882, he also taught a philosophy course at Colby College taking the place of the president, who was ill. Andrews was appointed professor of history and political economy at Brown in 1882, but was allowed a year to study in Germany, while others continued the courses formerly taught by Professor J. Lewis Diman, who had died in 1881.<cite><a href="Andrews, Elisha Benjamin.html">Andrews, Elisha Benjamin</a></cite>
Arriving at Brown in September 1883, Andrews taught the history course and electives in Roman law, political economy, and international law.<cite><a href="Andrews, Elisha Benjamin.html">Andrews, Elisha Benjamin</a></cite>
Elisha Benjamin Andrews wrote two historical textbooks, "Brief Institutes of Our Constitutional History, English and American" in 1886, a book written for use as a students’ syllabus of his lectures, and "Brief Institutes of General History" in 1887, an outline of history to the late nineteenth century.<cite><a href="Andrews, Elisha Benjamin.html">Andrews, Elisha Benjamin</a></cite>
Elisha Benjamin Andrews's later works, the four-volume set of "History of the United States," published in 1894, and "The Last Quarter-Century of the United States," in 1896, were written for popular consumption and were not up to his former standards.<cite><a href="Andrews, Elisha Benjamin.html">Andrews, Elisha Benjamin</a></cite>
Elisha Benjamin Andrews was a very effective teacher and was extremely popular with the students, and many were disappointed when he left in 1888 to teach at Cornell.<cite><a href="Andrews, Elisha Benjamin.html">Andrews, Elisha Benjamin</a></cite>
In his annual report for 1892 Andrews, after pointing out that the chemical laboratory, the botanical laboratory, Sayles Hall, and the dormitories were all outgrown, dared to present the greatest challenge yet.<cite><a href="Andrews, Elisha Benjamin.html">Andrews, Elisha Benjamin</a></cite>
In the summer of 1896 a few of his personal letters, which were published, indicated that Elisha Benjamin Andrews had adopted the position that the United States should begin the free coinage of silver at the ratio of sixteen ounces of silver to one ounce of gold, without waiting for the cooperation of other countries.<cite><a href="Andrews, Elisha Benjamin.html">Andrews, Elisha Benjamin</a></cite>
When this issue became paramount in the presidential election campaign of 1896, Andrews was far away in Europe, but was being freely quoted to the dismay of Corporation members who felt that his views were adversely affecting the prospects of the University.<cite><a href="Andrews, Elisha Benjamin.html">Andrews, Elisha Benjamin</a></cite>
At the Corporation meeting in June 1897 it was resolved that a committee be appointed "to confer with the president in regard to the interests of the University."<cite><a href="Andrews, Elisha Benjamin.html">Andrews, Elisha Benjamin</a></cite>
In the midst of the controversy in the summer of 1897, Andrews had also accepted the offer received from John Brisben Walker, editor of "Cosmopolitan Magazine," of the presidency of his proposed "Cosmopolitan University," a tuition-free correspondence school for the educational benefit of the public.<cite><a href="Andrews, Elisha Benjamin.html">Andrews, Elisha Benjamin</a></cite>
Meanwhile, an open letter to the Corporation by twenty-four Brown professors urged that the resignation not be accepted lest the reaction "would stamp this institution, in the eyes of the country, as one in which freedom of thought and expression is not permitted when it runs counter to the views generally accepted in the community or held by those from whom the University hopes to obtain financial support.&amp;8221; Six hundred alumni signed petitions that requested the Corporation to "take action upon the resignation of President Andrews which will effectually refute the charge that reasonable liberty of utterance was, or ever is to be denied to any teacher of Brown University."<cite><a href="Andrews, Elisha Benjamin.html">Andrews, Elisha Benjamin</a></cite>
Elisha Benjamin Andrews resigned in July 1898 to become superintendent of the Chicago public schools.<cite><a href="Andrews, Elisha Benjamin.html">Andrews, Elisha Benjamin</a></cite>
After two years in Chicago Elisha Benjamin Andrews was named chancellor of the University of Nebraska, which position he held until his retirement because of ill health in 1908.<cite><a href="Andrews, Elisha Benjamin.html">Andrews, Elisha Benjamin</a></cite>
Elisha Benjamin Andrews died after an illness of several years on October 20, 1917 in Interlachen, Florida.<cite><a href="Andrews, Elisha Benjamin.html">Andrews, Elisha Benjamin</a></cite>
Andrews Field was opened for athletic events on May 6, 1899.<cite><a href="Andrews Field.html">Andrews Field</a></cite>
The property, nearly seven acres between Camp and Ivy Streets, was acquired in 1897 through the bequest of John Wilson Smith.<cite><a href="Andrews Field.html">Andrews Field</a></cite>
The field was named for <a href="President.html">President</a> Andrews, who had resigned in 1898.<cite><a href="Andrews Field.html">Andrews Field</a></cite>
It was replaced by the <a href="Marston Field House.html">Marston Field House</a> in 1907.<cite><a href="Andrews Field.html">Andrews Field</a></cite>
A new football stand erected by the Athletic Association in 1910 increased the seating capacity by 1,050, and in October of that year a large Irwin scoreboard was installed.<cite><a href="Andrews Field.html">Andrews Field</a></cite>
Andrews Field was superseded in 1925 by the new stadium on Elmgrove Avenue and the baseball field named <a href="Aldrich Field.html">Aldrich Field</a>, across the street from the stadium.<cite><a href="Andrews Field.html">Andrews Field</a></cite>
Andrews Hall, named for Elisha Benjamin Andrews, president of the University who was instrumental in the admission of women in 1891, was built in 1947, joining Miller and Metcalf Halls and nearly doubling the dormitory capacity of <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a>.<cite><a href="Andrews Hall.html">Andrews Hall</a></cite>
The murals in the dining room are of wallpaper printed from hand carved blocks by J. Zuber and Company of Rixheim, Alsace, from original paintings called "Scenic America," done by Z. Zepelius and Ehramann in 1834 in Mulhouse, Germany.<cite><a href="Andrews Hall.html">Andrews Hall</a></cite>
At the dedication of Andrews Hall on November 2, 1947, greetings were received from <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a> in Cambridge University in England.<cite><a href="Andrews Hall.html">Andrews Hall</a></cite>
The Andrews Hall dining room was used daily until 1969 or 1970 and later for special gatherings.<cite><a href="Andrews Hall.html">Andrews Hall</a></cite>
Andrews House, at 13 Brown Street, was opened on January 4, 1939, as a 50-bed infirmary, replacing the former infirmary at 10 Manning Street.<cite><a href="Andrews House.html">Andrews House</a></cite>
The property had been purchased in 1922 and used as the <a href="Faculty Club.html">Faculty Club</a> since that time.<cite><a href="Andrews House.html">Andrews House</a></cite>
The 29-room mansion, of which Ogden Codman of New York was the architect, was erected in 1901 for James Coats and was later the residence of Alfred P. Coats, textile manufacturer.<cite><a href="Andrews House.html">Andrews House</a></cite>
It served as the Governor’s Mansion during the administration of R. Livingston Beekman, Governor of Rhode Island from 1915 to 1921, who resided there in the <a href="English.html">English</a> splendor he so much admired.<cite><a href="Andrews House.html">Andrews House</a></cite>
The remodelling as an infirmary was made possible through the gift of $330,000 by Charles Henry Hare 1885 and $60,000 from other sources.<cite><a href="Andrews House.html">Andrews House</a></cite>
Angell Hall was the name given to the former Psi Upsilon house on Thayer Street in 1951, when it was turned over to the Department of <a href="Biology.html">Biology</a> for freshman laboratory instruction and for use of members of the biology faculty associated with freshman courses.<cite><a href="Angell Hall.html">Angell Hall</a></cite>
It was named for James Burrill Angell 1849, noted member of the Brown chapter of Psi Upsilon.<cite><a href="Angell Hall.html">Angell Hall</a></cite>
After the building of the Sciences <a href="Library.html">Library</a>, Angell Hall, whose tenants had removed to the new bio-medical buildings, was razed in September 1972 to make room for the landscaped entrance to the <a href="Library.html">Library</a>.<cite><a href="Angell Hall.html">Angell Hall</a></cite>
James Burrill Angell (1829-1916), professor of modern languages at Brown and later president of the University of Michigan, was born in Scituate, Rhode Island, on January 7, 1829.<cite><a href="Angell, James Burrill.html">Angell, James Burrill</a></cite>
James Burrill Angell prepared at Lapham Institute and the University Grammar School and graduated from Brown in 1849 as valedictorian of his class.<cite><a href="Angell, James Burrill.html">Angell, James Burrill</a></cite>
James Burrill Angell spent the winter of 1850-51 in the South with his friend and classmate Rowland Hazard 1849, and went to Europe in December of 1851 to study.<cite><a href="Angell, James Burrill.html">Angell, James Burrill</a></cite>
James Burrill Angell began to write editorials for the "Providence Journal" at the request of Senator Henry Bowen Anthony 1833 and was offered the editorship of the paper in 1860.<cite><a href="Angell, James Burrill.html">Angell, James Burrill</a></cite>
James Burrill Angell became president of the University of Vermont in 1866 and president of the University of Michigan in 1871.<cite><a href="Angell, James Burrill.html">Angell, James Burrill</a></cite>
In 1879 President Hayes sent him to China to secure the ratification of treaties limiting Chinese emigration to the United States.<cite><a href="Angell, James Burrill.html">Angell, James Burrill</a></cite>
In 1887 President Cleveland appointed him to the International Commission of Canadian Fisheries to establish American rights in the waters of British North America.<cite><a href="Angell, James Burrill.html">Angell, James Burrill</a></cite>
In 1886 James Burrill Angell became Minister to Turkey for one year.<cite><a href="Angell, James Burrill.html">Angell, James Burrill</a></cite>
James Burrill Angell thought of resigning as president at Michigan in 1905, but was persuaded to remain until 1909, when he retired at the age of eighty.<cite><a href="Angell, James Burrill.html">Angell, James Burrill</a></cite>
Angell was present at the dedication of the <a href="Hay, John.html">John Hay</a> Library in 1910.<cite><a href="Angell, James Burrill.html">Angell, James Burrill</a></cite>
James Burrill Angell died on April 1, 1916 in Ann Arbor, Michigan.<cite><a href="Angell, James Burrill.html">Angell, James Burrill</a></cite>
When Angell married Sarah Caswell, daughter of professor of mathematics <a href="Caswell, Alexis.html">Alexis Caswell</a>, in 1855, the students declared that he had won the "mathematical prize."<cite><a href="Angell, James Burrill.html">Angell, James Burrill</a></cite>
In appreciation, Angell invited them to a party when the child was a year old, and the students sang "The Angell Cradle," a song written especially for the occasion by <a href="Hay, John.html">John Hay</a> 1858, to the tune, "Cocachelunk."<cite><a href="Angell, James Burrill.html">Angell, James Burrill</a></cite>
The Annmary Brown Memorial at 21 Brown Street was built in 1907 by Rush Christopher Hawkins as a memorial to his wife, who was the daughter of Nicholas Brown 1811 and the granddaughter of Nicholas Brown 1786, whose name the University adopted in 1804, and sister of Carrie Brown Bajnotti, whose memorial is <a href="Carrie Tower.html">Carrie Tower</a>.<cite><a href="Annmary Brown Memorial.html">Annmary Brown Memorial</a></cite>
Hawkins pursued the goal of acquiring the first book of each of the presses which were printing by 1500, and he did realize a collection of 225 first and second books from 130 of the 238 fifteenth-century presses.<cite><a href="Annmary Brown Memorial.html">Annmary Brown Memorial</a></cite>
He engaged Alfred W. Pollard to prepare a catalogue of the collection, which was published in 1910 by the Oxford University Press.<cite><a href="Annmary Brown Memorial.html">Annmary Brown Memorial</a></cite>
The Memorial was deeded to the University in 1948, at which time Margaret B. Stillwell, librarian of the collections since 1917, joined the staff of the University with the rank of full professor and continued in that position until her retirement in 1953.<cite><a href="Annmary Brown Memorial.html">Annmary Brown Memorial</a></cite>
The Annmary Brown Memorial collections, except for the paintings, were removed to the John Hay <a href="Library.html">Library</a> in 1990.<cite><a href="Annmary Brown Memorial.html">Annmary Brown Memorial</a></cite>
Anthropology was reintroduced in 1956 by Professor J. Louis Giddings, who was appointed at the time of the acquisition of the <a href="Haffenreffer Museum.html">Haffenreffer Museum</a> of the American Indian.<cite><a href="Anthropology.html">Anthropology</a></cite>
Professor Alpheus S. Packard had first given a course in anthropology to six seniors in 1891.<cite><a href="Anthropology.html">Anthropology</a></cite>
In 1898, with 32 students in his course, Packard reported the urgent need for anthropological monographs and journals which he could not afford to buy and an important addition of "flint implements from the Danish refuse-heaps, comprising stone hammers, celts, lance-heads, knives, etc., received by exchange from the Rhode Island Historical Society."<cite><a href="Anthropology.html">Anthropology</a></cite>
The anthropology course ceased with the death of Packard in 1905.<cite><a href="Anthropology.html">Anthropology</a></cite>
With the arrival of Giddings in 1956, the Department of <a href="Sociology.html">Sociology</a> added courses in human origins, cultural anthropology, and the American Indian.<cite><a href="Anthropology.html">Anthropology</a></cite>
Giddings was joined in 1959 by Dwight B. Heath, and a program in anthropology was begun within the <a href="Sociology.html">Sociology</a> Department, which changed its name to Department of <a href="Sociology.html">Sociology</a> and Anthropology.<cite><a href="Anthropology.html">Anthropology</a></cite>
The first master of arts degree in anthropology was awarded in 1962.<cite><a href="Anthropology.html">Anthropology</a></cite>
Philip E. Leis joined the faculty in 1962, and the curriculum was expanded to include courses in non-western and Latin American societies.<cite><a href="Anthropology.html">Anthropology</a></cite>
Alex F. Ricciardelli, who had been visiting assistant professor in 1962-63, was named director of the <a href="Haffenreffer Museum.html">Haffenreffer Museum</a> in 1968 and taught courses in archaeological methods and theory.<cite><a href="Anthropology.html">Anthropology</a></cite>
Douglas D. Anderson joined the department in 1965, Robert R. Jay came in 1966, and George L. Hicks in 1967.<cite><a href="Anthropology.html">Anthropology</a></cite>
James Deetz also came to Brown in 1967, and was at the same time appointed assistant director of Plimoth Plantation.<cite><a href="Anthropology.html">Anthropology</a></cite>
Anthropology was part of the Department of <a href="Sociology.html">Sociology</a> and Anthropology until 1970 when, with eleven faculty members, 25 graduate students, and sixty undergraduates, a separate Department of Anthropology was established with Philip E. Leis as chairman.<cite><a href="Anthropology.html">Anthropology</a></cite>
The department moved in 1970 to <a href="Giddings House.html">Giddings House</a>.<cite><a href="Anthropology.html">Anthropology</a></cite>
The first Ph.D. in anthropology was awarded in 1972.<cite><a href="Anthropology.html">Anthropology</a></cite>
In the 1970s the department was enlarged by the arrival of William O. Beeman in 1973, Marida C. Hollos in 1974, and Lina M. Fruzzetti in 1975.<cite><a href="Anthropology.html">Anthropology</a></cite>
Jane Powell Dwyer, associate professor of anthropology, founded the graduate program in museum studies in 1977.<cite><a href="Anthropology.html">Anthropology</a></cite>
Philip Leis was program director from 1968 to 1970, with Alex F. Ricciardelli as acting program director in 1969-70.<cite><a href="Anthropology.html">Anthropology</a></cite>
Since Anthropology became a department in 1970, the chairpersons have been Philip Leis, George L. Hicks, Douglas D. Anderson, Richard A. Gould, and Lina M. Fruzzetti.<cite><a href="Anthropology.html">Anthropology</a></cite>
"Anubis" was a four-page newspaper selling for five cents which appeared unnumbered sometime during the academic year 1985-86.<cite><a href="Anubis.html">Anubis</a></cite>
Thomas Baird Appleget (1893-1982), vice-president of the University from 1949 to 1959, was born in Hightstown, New Jersey, on January 16, 1893.<cite><a href="Appleget, Thomas B..html">Appleget, Thomas B.</a></cite>
After graduation from high school in 1910 Thomas B. Appleget worked for three years as a clerk, and entered Brown in 1913.<cite><a href="Appleget, Thomas B..html">Appleget, Thomas B.</a></cite>
The day after his graduation in 1917 Thomas B. Appleget was appointed executive secretary to President Faunce.<cite><a href="Appleget, Thomas B..html">Appleget, Thomas B.</a></cite>
After a year in the Army in 1918, Thomas B. Appleget returned to the job, which included managing the Brown Loyalty Fund, alumni and public relations, and student recruitment.<cite><a href="Appleget, Thomas B..html">Appleget, Thomas B.</a></cite>
In 1925 Thomas B. Appleget's title was changed to Assistant to the President.<cite><a href="Appleget, Thomas B..html">Appleget, Thomas B.</a></cite>
In 1926 Thomas B. Appleget left Brown to become executive secretary to <a href="Rockefeller, John D., Jr..html">John D. Rockefeller</a>, Jr. 1897.<cite><a href="Appleget, Thomas B..html">Appleget, Thomas B.</a></cite>
In 1929 Appleget became vice-president of the Rockefeller Foundation.<cite><a href="Appleget, Thomas B..html">Appleget, Thomas B.</a></cite>
In 1949 Thomas B. Appleget was appointed vice-president of the University, with responsibility for alumni and public relations and fund raising.<cite><a href="Appleget, Thomas B..html">Appleget, Thomas B.</a></cite>
