Thomas B. Appleget resigned in 1959.<cite><a href="Appleget, Thomas B..html">Appleget, Thomas B.</a></cite>
Thomas B. Appleget died in Greenwich, Connecticut, on October 21, 1982.<cite><a href="Appleget, Thomas B..html">Appleget, Thomas B.</a></cite>
John Howard Appleton (1844-1930), professor of chemistry, was born in Portland, Maine, on February 3, 1844.<cite><a href="Appleton, John Howard.html">Appleton, John Howard</a></cite>
John Howard Appleton graduated from Brown with a bachelor of philosophy degree in 1863 and was immediately appointed instructor in chemistry.<cite><a href="Appleton, John Howard.html">Appleton, John Howard</a></cite>
John Howard Appleton was appointed professor of chemistry applied to the arts in 1868 and remained until his mandatory retirement at the age of 70, as head of the Department of Chemistry for half a century and the first Newport Rogers Professor of Chemistry.<cite><a href="Appleton, John Howard.html">Appleton, John Howard</a></cite>
John Howard Appleton was a Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, and in 1928 was elected an honorary member of the American Institute of Chemistry.<cite><a href="Appleton, John Howard.html">Appleton, John Howard</a></cite>
At the time of John Howard Appleton's retirement in 1914 members of the faculty presented him with an inscribed loving cup.<cite><a href="Appleton, John Howard.html">Appleton, John Howard</a></cite>
At a testimonial dinner for Appleton held on June 19, 1922, President Faunce, his former student, said of him, "No student ever had to ask him to put a question a second time.<cite><a href="Appleton, John Howard.html">Appleton, John Howard</a></cite>
At the testimonial dinner, he singled out one, John Brown Francis Herreshoff 1870, whom he called "the leading industrial chemist in the United States," saying, "You notice that I do not say that I am "proud" of him – I would be if I had created him – but as his teacher I only shine with a pale reflected light."<cite><a href="Appleton, John Howard.html">Appleton, John Howard</a></cite>
The John Howard Appleton Club, of which all friends of the Department Chemistry were considered members, was founded on Class Day in 1927 and held annual dinners.<cite><a href="Appleton, John Howard.html">Appleton, John Howard</a></cite>
Appleton died in Providence on February 18, 1930.<cite><a href="Appleton, John Howard.html">Appleton, John Howard</a></cite>
Applied <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a> instruction at Brown University began in 1941 to fill a need for applied mathematicians in industry, which had been brought to attention a year earlier in a report prepared by Thornton T. Fry of Bell Telephone Laboratories for the National Resources Planning Board.<cite><a href="Applied Mathematics.html">Applied Mathematics</a></cite>
A Program of Advanced Instruction and Research in Mechanics, a twelve-week course in the summer of 1941, was organized by <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> Roland G. D. Richardson with the support of the U.S. Office of <a href="Education.html">Education</a> and the Carnegie Foundation.<cite><a href="Applied Mathematics.html">Applied Mathematics</a></cite>
In the fall of 1941 William Prager and John L. Synge joined the faculty of the program which had an enrollment of thirty.<cite><a href="Applied Mathematics.html">Applied Mathematics</a></cite>
The Program awarded the first Brown Ph.D. degree in applied mathematics to Joaquin B. Diaz in 1945.<cite><a href="Applied Mathematics.html">Applied Mathematics</a></cite>
Formally established as the Graduate Division of Applied <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a> in May 1946 and staffed by faculty of the Departments of <a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a>, <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a>, and <a href="Physics.html">Physics</a>, the program began to offer graduate courses the next semester.<cite><a href="Applied Mathematics.html">Applied Mathematics</a></cite>
In 1949 the first professor appointed to the Graduate Division of Applied <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a> was E. H. Lee, who became chairman in 1954.<cite><a href="Applied Mathematics.html">Applied Mathematics</a></cite>
Also in 1954 the name of the department was changed to Division of Applied <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a> when an undergraduate curriculum leading to the Bachelor of Science degree in applied mathematics was instituted.<cite><a href="Applied Mathematics.html">Applied Mathematics</a></cite>
The first Bachelor of Science in Applied <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a> degrees were awarded in 1956.<cite><a href="Applied Mathematics.html">Applied Mathematics</a></cite>
In 1948 Professor Rohn Truell organized the Metals Research Laboratory, a semi-autonomous research group concerned primarily with the study of ultrasonic wave propagation in solids.<cite><a href="Applied Mathematics.html">Applied Mathematics</a></cite>
From its earliest days the division has been recognized internationally as a center for the study of solid mechanics, ranging from the ground-breaking work on the mathematical theory of plasticity under the direction of Professor Prager to the emphasis on viscoelasticity theory under Professor E. H. Lee in the 1950s, followed by Professor R. S. Rivlin’s work on nonlinear and hereditary response, and Truell’s on transport properties and crystalline defects.<cite><a href="Applied Mathematics.html">Applied Mathematics</a></cite>
In 1957 and 1958 Ulf Grenander was professor of probability and statistics.<cite><a href="Applied Mathematics.html">Applied Mathematics</a></cite>
He returned to Brown in 1966 from the Directorship of the Institute of Insurance <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a> and Mathematical Statistics in Stockholm.<cite><a href="Applied Mathematics.html">Applied Mathematics</a></cite>
Professor Philip Davis, formerly director of the Numerical Analysis section of the National Bureau of Standards, joined the department in 1963.<cite><a href="Applied Mathematics.html">Applied Mathematics</a></cite>
The Brown Center for Dynamical Systems was established in 1964 by Solomon Lefschetz and Professor J. P. LaSalle for research and advanced study.<cite><a href="Applied Mathematics.html">Applied Mathematics</a></cite>
In 1965 the Center organized an international symposium, held in Puerto Rico and co-sponsored by the U.S. Air Force’s Office of Scientific Research, which was attended by one hundred of the world’s leading mathematicians.<cite><a href="Applied Mathematics.html">Applied Mathematics</a></cite>
The Center was dedicated to Lefschetz in August, 1974.<cite><a href="Applied Mathematics.html">Applied Mathematics</a></cite>
In 1986, with the sponsorship of the Federal University Research Initiative Program, the division acquired three new centers: the Laboratory for Fluid Mechanics, Turbulence, and Computation (in cooperation with the Division of <a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a>); the Center for Control Sciences; and the Center for Intelligent Control Systems (in cooperation with Harvard and M.I.T.).<cite><a href="Applied Mathematics.html">Applied Mathematics</a></cite>
Two major periodicals edited in the division since their foundation are the "Quarterly of Applied <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a>," founded by Professor Prager in 1942, and the "Journal of Differential Equations," founded in 1965.<cite><a href="Applied Mathematics.html">Applied Mathematics</a></cite>
The division has been housed since March 1953 in the elegant Henry Pearce House at 182 George Street, designed by Angell and Swift and built in 1898.<cite><a href="Applied Mathematics.html">Applied Mathematics</a></cite>
When the <a href="Center for Information Technology.html">Center for Information Technology</a> building was opened in 1988, the division acquired the use of the former <a href="Computing Laboratory.html">Computing Laboratory</a> at 180 George Street.<cite><a href="Applied Mathematics.html">Applied Mathematics</a></cite>
Raymond Clare Archibald (1875-1955), professor of mathematics, was born in Colchester County, Nova Scotia, on October 7, 1875.<cite><a href="Archibald, Raymond C..html">Archibald, Raymond C.</a></cite>
Raymond C. Archibald received a second bachelor’s degree from Harvard in 1896, and a master’s degree in 1897.<cite><a href="Archibald, Raymond C..html">Archibald, Raymond C.</a></cite>
From 1898 to 1900 Raymond C. Archibald studied in Germany, first at the University of Berlin and then at the University of Strasbourg, where he received a doctorate in 1900.<cite><a href="Archibald, Raymond C..html">Archibald, Raymond C.</a></cite>
In 1894-95 and again from 1900 to 1907 Raymond C. Archibald was at Mount Allison Ladies College, where he taught mathematics and violin and was in charge of the library.<cite><a href="Archibald, Raymond C..html">Archibald, Raymond C.</a></cite>
In 1907-08 Raymond C. Archibald was professor of mathematics at Acadia University.<cite><a href="Archibald, Raymond C..html">Archibald, Raymond C.</a></cite>
Raymond C. Archibald became assistant professor in 1911, associate professor in 1917, and professor in 1928.<cite><a href="Archibald, Raymond C..html">Archibald, Raymond C.</a></cite>
As Librarian of the American Mathematical Society from 1921 to 1941 Raymond C. Archibald also supervised the growth of that library.<cite><a href="Archibald, Raymond C..html">Archibald, Raymond C.</a></cite>
After his retirement in 1943, Raymond C. Archibald collected and presented in honor of his mother the Mary Mellish Memorial Library of American and English poetry and drama to Mount Allison University.<cite><a href="Archibald, Raymond C..html">Archibald, Raymond C.</a></cite>
Raymond C. Archibald's published works included "Carlyle’s First Love, Margaret Gordon, Lady Bannerman" in 1910, "Euclid’s book On Division of Figures" in 1915, "A Semicentennial History of the American Mathematical Society, 1888-1938" in 1938, and "Outline of the History of Mathematics" in 1932 and five subsequent editions.<cite><a href="Archibald, Raymond C..html">Archibald, Raymond C.</a></cite>
In 1939 he was named chairman of a National Research Council on tables, which led to the founding of a journal, "Mathematical Tables and Other Aids to Computation," of which Archibald was editor.<cite><a href="Archibald, Raymond C..html">Archibald, Raymond C.</a></cite>
Raymond C. Archibald died on July 26, 1955, in Sackville, New Brunswick.<cite><a href="Archibald, Raymond C..html">Archibald, Raymond C.</a></cite>
Sinclair Wallace Armstrong (1897-1959), professor of history, was born in Middletown, Connecticut, on March 31, 1897, the son of a professor of philosophy at Wesleyan.<cite><a href="Armstrong, Sinclair W..html">Armstrong, Sinclair W.</a></cite>
Sinclair W. Armstrong graduated from Princeton in 1918, served in the Field Artillery in World War I, and returned to Princeton to earn his master’s degree in 1920.<cite><a href="Armstrong, Sinclair W..html">Armstrong, Sinclair W.</a></cite>
Sinclair W. Armstrong taught at St. George’s School in Newport from 1923 to 1928.<cite><a href="Armstrong, Sinclair W..html">Armstrong, Sinclair W.</a></cite>
Sinclair W. Armstrong came to Brown as an instructor in history in 1930, and was promoted to assistant professor in 1935, associate professor in 1946, and full professor in 1949.<cite><a href="Armstrong, Sinclair W..html">Armstrong, Sinclair W.</a></cite>
Sinclair W. Armstrong received his Ph.D. degree from the University of Wisconsin in 1935.<cite><a href="Armstrong, Sinclair W..html">Armstrong, Sinclair W.</a></cite>
Sinclair W. Armstrong died in Providence on March 20, 1959.<cite><a href="Armstrong, Sinclair W..html">Armstrong, Sinclair W.</a></cite>
The Arnold Fellowships were established in 1964 by Thomas J. Watson, Jr. ’37.<cite><a href="Arnold Fellowships.html">Arnold Fellowships</a></cite>
The fellowships, originally intended for male students, were extended in 1971 to include women students, the first of whom was Barbara Reisman ’71.<cite><a href="Arnold Fellowships.html">Arnold Fellowships</a></cite>
Arnold Laboratory was built in 1915 at a cost of $80,000 furnished by the bequest of Dr. Oliver H. Arnold 1865.<cite><a href="Arnold Laboratory.html">Arnold Laboratory</a></cite>
He had visited in Vienna, Berlin, London, and Glasgow from 1883 to 1885, while his wife studied Semitic languages with famous German professors.<cite><a href="Arnold Laboratory.html">Arnold Laboratory</a></cite>
In 1938 the first floor auditorium became the Biological Sciences <a href="Library.html">Library</a>, and three modern laboratories for beginning classes were installed on the first floor.<cite><a href="Arnold Laboratory.html">Arnold Laboratory</a></cite>
Samuel Tomlinson Arnold (1892-1956), first provost of Brown University, was born in Fall River, Massachusetts, on August 23, 1892, the son of a minister.<cite><a href="Arnold, Samuel T..html">Arnold, Samuel T.</a></cite>
Samuel T. Arnold graduated from Brown in 1913 with final honors in chemistry, having been a <a href="Manning, James.html">James Manning</a> and a <a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Francis Wayland</a> scholar, a Carpenter Prize speaker, and elected to both Phi Beta Kappa and Sigma Xi.<cite><a href="Arnold, Samuel T..html">Arnold, Samuel T.</a></cite>
Samuel T. Arnold stayed on at Brown, earning an A.M. degree in 1914 and a Ph.D. in 1916.<cite><a href="Arnold, Samuel T..html">Arnold, Samuel T.</a></cite>
Samuel T. Arnold was appointed assistant in chemistry in 1913-14, and was promoted to instructor in 1914, assistant professor in 1917, associate professor in 1922, and full professor in 1930.<cite><a href="Arnold, Samuel T..html">Arnold, Samuel T.</a></cite>
In 1929 Samuel T. Arnold was Acting Dean of the University during Dean Randall’s leave of absence, with responsibility for the three upper classes of students.<cite><a href="Arnold, Samuel T..html">Arnold, Samuel T.</a></cite>
In 1930 Samuel T. Arnold was given the new title of Dean of Undergraduates.<cite><a href="Arnold, Samuel T..html">Arnold, Samuel T.</a></cite>
In 1937 Samuel T. Arnold was named Dean of the College, and in 1946 the title of Dean of the University was revived for him, with a wider meaning as his academic responsibilities now extended to include the Graduate School, Pembroke College, and the Veterans College.<cite><a href="Arnold, Samuel T..html">Arnold, Samuel T.</a></cite>
On the day of his death, December 22, 1956, Samuel T. Arnold presided at a special Christmas Chapel, conducted business in his office as usual, and was about to attend an evening party for the employees of Citizens Savings Bank, when he suffered a fatal heart attack on his way to his car.<cite><a href="Arnold, Samuel T..html">Arnold, Samuel T.</a></cite>
The Art Department began in 1892 with the appointment of William Carey Poland, who had been professor of classics for some years, to the new chair of professor of the history and criticism of the fine arts.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
In 1871 Marshall Woods offered three thousand dollars for the establishment of a "Lectureship on the Fine Arts, and on their Application to the Mechanic Arts, or Industrial Pursuits."<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
The Marshall Woods Lectures did not, however, begin until 1919.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
An item in the "<a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a>," February 6, 1875, announced, "Prof. Diman will give lectures on art Saturdays without dictation.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
In 1877-78 an elective course in the history of architecture was offered to the seniors by Professor Diman.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
In 1892 Professor Poland had just returned from a year in Athens as Annual Director of the American School of Classical Antiquities, and had brought back some antiquities in the form of casts for the Museum of Classical Archaeology, which was set up on the lower floor of <a href="Manning Hall.html">Manning Hall</a>.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
At the request of Professor Poland, Professor Benjamin F. Clarke gave a course of lectures in 1893 on "Architecture, its <a href="History.html">History</a> and Construction."<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
In 1895 the study of architecture, taught by Providence architect Norman Isham, was placed in the Department of Fine Arts, and the first Ph.D. degree in the department was earned by Daniel Goodwin for a dissertation entitled "The Return of the Gods from Exile, a Study of the Mutual Influence of Renaissance Art and Christianity in Italy."<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
In 1896 music, which was taught by Joseph N. Ashton, was also added to the department.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
In 1901 <a href="President.html">President</a> Faunce recommended that a scheme of cooperation be arranged with the <a href="Rhode Island School of Design.html">Rhode Island School of Design</a> which would allow students of the School to take such courses as <a href="English.html">English</a>, modern languages, and mathematics at Brown and open courses in architectural and free-hand drawing at the School to Brown students.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
The arrangement took effect in 1901-02.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
Professor Poland reported in 1914 that the Museum of Fine Arts in <a href="Manning Hall.html">Manning Hall</a> had been open to the public four hours a week, and was also being used by teachers and classes in the Providence schools.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
On the retirement of Poland in 1915, the direction of the Museum was transferred to the Department of Greek.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
John Shapley was instructor in art from 1915 to 1919 and assistant professor from 1919 to 1924.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
A new policy in art was ushered in by the appointment of Will S. Taylor as assistant professor of art in 1926.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
A grant from the Carnegie <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> in 1931-32 allowed the department to add an assistant professor, George E. Downing, to move the department offices and library into 44 Benevolent Street, and to reconstruct the building at 41 Benevolent Street for a studio in mural painting.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
For several years beginning in 1931 Professor Curt Ducasse’s course in aesthetics was listed as a course in both the Art Department and the <a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a> Department, as was Professor C. Alexander Robinson’s course in classical archaeology in the Art Department and the <a href="Classics.html">Classics</a> Department.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
In November 1932 Brown University and the <a href="Rhode Island School of Design.html">Rhode Island School of Design</a> conducted a three-day Institute of Art, made possible by a special grant of the Carnegie Foundation.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
In June of 1949 the University purchased a house at 191 Thayer Street, the former residence of Henry W. Cooke, for the use of the Art Department.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
Taylor’s studio was moved in the fall of 1949 to a site in back of <a href="Brunonia.html">Brunonia</a> (Richardson) Hall, thereby clearing its former lot for the building of the Refectory.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
First, on the art history side, the arrival of Thomas Reed in 1950 augmented George Downing’s lectures in modern and medieval art with instruction in Renaissance and baroque art.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
William Loerke, a medievalist, came in 1950, allowing Professor Downing to concentrate on the field of his greatest interest.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
In studio art Walter Feldman replaced Professor Taylor, who retired in 1953.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
William Jordy, arriving in 1955, made architecture popular and inspiring to future architects and many other students.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
Professor Feldman’s specialities in painting and printmaking were augmented by those of Hugh Townley, who arrived in 1961 as Brown’s first sculptor.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
In the 1960s Profesors Reed and Loerke left, the former for the <a href="Rhode Island School of Design.html">Rhode Island School of Design</a>, the latter to head Dunbarton Oaks in Washington.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
When the city of Florence was flooded in November of 1966, Bates Lowry and Fred Licht initiated the organization of the nationwide Committee to Rescue Italian Art (CRIA), which provided both funds and the advice of art experts in salvaging the city’s art treasures.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
Both Licht and Lowry left the department in 1968, Licht to become director of the Florida State University Study Center in Florence and Lowry to become director of the Museum of Modern Art.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
In 1968 Juergen Schulz, an authority in the history of architecture, came to Brown as chairman of the department.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
In the fall of 1966 a new graduate program in art history began with thirteen graduate students.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
From 1967 to 1992 students entering the master’s program in art history have mounted an exhibition and published a series of widely acclaimed exhibition catalogues.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
The <a href="List Art Building.html">List Art Building</a>, designed by Phillip Johnson and opened in 1971, provided lecture rooms, studios, and exhibition space in the David Winton Bell Gallery.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
In 1988 the Art Department split into two sections – the Program in the Visual Arts headed by Professor Hugh Townley and the Program in the <a href="History.html">History</a> of Art and Architecture headed by Juergen Schulz.<cite><a href="Art.html">Art</a></cite>
Asa Clinton Crowell (1862-1936), professor of Germanic languages and literature, was born in Pawtucket on May 20, 1862.<cite><a href="Asa Clinton Crowell.html">Asa Clinton Crowell</a></cite>
He prepared for college at the <a href="University Grammar School.html">University Grammar School</a> and graduated from Brown in 1882.<cite><a href="Asa Clinton Crowell.html">Asa Clinton Crowell</a></cite>
He received his A.M. degree from Brown in 1889, and his Ph.D. in 1894.<cite><a href="Asa Clinton Crowell.html">Asa Clinton Crowell</a></cite>
He was principal of the high school at Milston Mills, New Hampshire, and teacher of Latin and French at Dummer Academy in South Byfield, Massachusetts, before returning to Brown as instructor in French in 1890.<cite><a href="Asa Clinton Crowell.html">Asa Clinton Crowell</a></cite>
He was instructor in French and German in 1891-92, and instructor in German from 1892 to 1894.<cite><a href="Asa Clinton Crowell.html">Asa Clinton Crowell</a></cite>
He was appointed assistant professor of Germanic languages and literature in 1894, and promoted to associate professor in 1901.<cite><a href="Asa Clinton Crowell.html">Asa Clinton Crowell</a></cite>
On October 1, 1891 he was the first instructor to teach a class of women students at the University.<cite><a href="Asa Clinton Crowell.html">Asa Clinton Crowell</a></cite>
In 1898 the alumnae of the Women’s College established the Asa Clinton Crowell premiums in German to be awarded to at least two members of the entering class of the Women’s College.<cite><a href="Asa Clinton Crowell.html">Asa Clinton Crowell</a></cite>
He retired in 1932 and died in Providence on June 26, 1936.<cite><a href="Asa Clinton Crowell.html">Asa Clinton Crowell</a></cite>
His writings included a translation of Mortenson’s "Handbook of Norse Mythology "in 1913, translations of old Dutch letters in "Narratives of the New Netherlands "in 1909, and "Lessons in Old Icelandic "in 1911.<cite><a href="Asa Clinton Crowell.html">Asa Clinton Crowell</a></cite>
The first known was Sau-Ahbrah 1877 from Henthada, Burma, who was a Karen convert sent to Brown with the expectation that he would return to Burma as a Christian missionary.<cite><a href="Asians.html">Asians</a></cite>
He came in the company of Willis Thomas 1877, the son of Benjamin C. Thomas 1847, who had as an undergraduate heard Adoniram Judson 1807 speak at Brown and decided that he also would become a missionary to Burma.<cite><a href="Asians.html">Asians</a></cite>
Sau-Ahbrah left Brown after his junior year, graduated from Newton Theological Institution in 1879, and received an M.D. degree from Jefferson Medical College in 1882.<cite><a href="Asians.html">Asians</a></cite>
Heita Okada 1895 came to Brown from Tokyo by way of Worcester Academy.<cite><a href="Asians.html">Asians</a></cite>
Julius Kumpei Matsumoto, a graduate of the University of Tokyo, earned a master of arts degree in 1894.<cite><a href="Asians.html">Asians</a></cite>
His brother, Matsuzo Matsumoto, was a member of the class of 1894.<cite><a href="Asians.html">Asians</a></cite>
In the 1940s Pack was a member of the Representative Democratic Council of Korea.<cite><a href="Asians.html">Asians</a></cite>
In 1951 he was kidnapped by North Koreans and was not heard from again.<cite><a href="Asians.html">Asians</a></cite>
In 1906 the Chinese government sent forty students from Tien Tsin University to be educated in the United States.<cite><a href="Asians.html">Asians</a></cite>
The five who entered Brown, all in the sophomore class, in the fall of 1906 were Chen Ju-Hsiang, Chou Tsung-Hua, Ho Hou-Wei, Hua Yu-Peng and Ma Tai-Cheng.<cite><a href="Asians.html">Asians</a></cite>
The last three named all received Ph.B. degrees from the Sheffield Scientific School in 1908.<cite><a href="Asians.html">Asians</a></cite>
In 1933 Kuo-P’ing Chou ’35 won the newly instituted Brown University scholarship offered at several Japanese and Chinese universities and came to Pembroke as a junior, transferring from Yenching University.<cite><a href="Asians.html">Asians</a></cite>
In 1945 the <a href="Alumnae Association.html">Alumnae Association</a> held a Kuo-P’ing Chou Day to augment a fund which had been started the year before to help her and Yenching University, both in need because of the war.<cite><a href="Asians.html">Asians</a></cite>
Siheung Daniel Rhee came from Korea in 1927, graduated in 1931, remained in the United States, became a chemist, started a firm to manufacture elastic thread, and sent his son, Michael Rhee ’55, to Brown.<cite><a href="Asians.html">Asians</a></cite>
In 1911-1912 an international exchange of lecturers between Japan and the United States was undertaken at the instigation of Hamilton Holt, editor of the "Independent," and under the supervision of <a href="President.html">President</a> Nicholas Murray Butler of Columbia.<cite><a href="Asians.html">Asians</a></cite>
Dr. Inazo Nitobe, professor at the Imperial University of Tokyo, arrived at Brown in October 1911 to begin his lecture tour, the object of which was the interpretation of his country’s culture and people to Americans.<cite><a href="Asians.html">Asians</a></cite>
In 1924 Brown awarded an honorary degree to Masanao Hanihara, Japanese ambassador to the United States, an action which did much to establish good feeling between Japan and the United States, which had suffered from the Japanese immigration restriction act, and indirectly led to the admission several years later of Asian American student John F. Aiso ’31.<cite><a href="Asians.html">Asians</a></cite>
In the late 1960s the small number of Asian American students at Brown became interested in exploring their ethnic identity, and a Group Independent Study Project in the fall of 1969 brought together about a dozen of them under the care of Professor James Sakoda of <a href="Sociology.html">Sociology</a>.<cite><a href="Asians.html">Asians</a></cite>
Active recruitment of students from Hawaii in the late 1960s began a steady enrolment from that state, which further increased the number of Asian Americans.<cite><a href="Asians.html">Asians</a></cite>
Asian Americans accounted for 12.4 per cent of the Class of 1993, admitted in 1989, up from 9.7 per cent the previous year.<cite><a href="Asians.html">Asians</a></cite>
In November 1991, as part of Asian Awareness Month, a panel discussion was sponsored by the Brown Organization of Multiracial and Biracial Students (BOMBS).<cite><a href="Asians.html">Asians</a></cite>
The Associated Alumni was incorporated in 1919, when the organization known as the Alumni Association until 1891 and as the Associated Alumni since 1892 reorganized under a new constitution designed to involve the alumni in closer cooperation with the University.<cite><a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a></cite>
The first meeting of an alumni association recorded was in 1823.<cite><a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a></cite>
William Rogers 1769 was chairman and a fund was started to provide medals for contests in declamation and composition.<cite><a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a></cite>
In 1825 the medals, bearing the legend "Alumni Fund of Brown University," were awarded at the "anniversary exercises of the Alumni Society."<cite><a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a></cite>
A later alumni association was formed in response to resolutions by Professor William G. Goddard at a meeting of the alumni on September 6, 1842, with the intent of bringing together annually the graduates of the University to attend literary exercises and share a dinner.<cite><a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a></cite>
John Pitman 1799, and celebrated at dinner.<cite><a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a></cite>
Meetings were held from 1845 until 1853, but the address and dinner were omitted.<cite><a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a></cite>
In 1853 an arrangement was made for the Alumni to hold their literary exercises on alternate years with <a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a>, but they did this only in 1855 and 1857.<cite><a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a></cite>
In 1868 <a href="President.html">President</a> Caswell revived the association by inviting the alumni to a meeting before <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> to consult on the interests of the University, specifically the founding of scholarships.<cite><a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a></cite>
A committee of the alumni reported in 1869 in favor of a permanent association to meet annually at <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> and recommended the formation of local associations.<cite><a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a></cite>
Thus the Brown Clubs began, as the local associations were established in New York in 1869, and in Philadelphia and Boston in 1870.<cite><a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a></cite>
"Articles of Organization of the Alumni Association of Brown University" were adopted on June 25, 1872.<cite><a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a></cite>
In 1875 the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> and the Alumni agreed on a plan allowing the alumni to vote on nominations for trustees of the University.<cite><a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a></cite>
At the 1919 annual meeting a new constitution under the name, "Associated Alumni of Brown University, Incorporated" was proposed and accepted.<cite><a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a></cite>
In 1922 Alfred H. Gurney ’07 took the job and remained until June 1939, his title having been changed in 1925 to Alumni Secretary.<cite><a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a></cite>
Dues were abolished in 1925, and the financial support of the the association was assumed by the Loyalty Fund.<cite><a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a></cite>
In 1931, the Advisory Board was replaced by a larger Advisory Council, which included the president or representative of each Brown Club and an additional delegate for clubs with membership of fifty or more, the officers of the Associated Alumni, the members of the Board of Directors, and all Alumni Trustees not on the Board of Directors.<cite><a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a></cite>
James L. Whitcomb ’36 took the place of Alfred Gurney in January 1940, with the title of Director of Alumni Relations.<cite><a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a></cite>
Later in that year he went on leave, and remained on leave until his resignation in February 1946.<cite><a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a></cite>
In May 1946 William McCormick ’23 was appointed Alumni Executive Officer for the Associated Alumni.<cite><a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a></cite>
Paul Mackesey ’32 succeeded McCormick in 1962 and served until 1976.<cite><a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a></cite>
A further reorganization of the Associated Alumni in 1973 provided for an executive committee made up of the four elected officers, five appointed local directors, and 62 appointed regional directors.<cite><a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a></cite>
In 1973 the <a href="Alumnae Association.html">Alumnae Association</a> merged with the Associated Alumni, and in 1979 Phyllis Van Horn Tillinghast ’51 became the first woman president of the Associated Alumni.<cite><a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a></cite>
In 1984 the Alumni Recognition Ceremony was initiated, at which the Brown <a href="Bear.html">Bear</a> and Alumni Service Awards honored service to Brown and the <a href="William Rogers Award.html">William Rogers Award</a> recognized outstanding achievement of a graduate.<cite><a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a></cite>
On the advice of an ad hoc Committee on Governance in 1986, a new streamlined Board of Governors replaced the old Board of Directors and the executive committee.<cite><a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a></cite>
The Association of American Universities was organized in 1900 and had fourteen original member institutions.<cite><a href="Association of American Universities.html">Association of American Universities</a></cite>
In 1933 Brown became the sixteenth of the additional universities invited, and one of the few universities without professional schools.<cite><a href="Association of American Universities.html">Association of American Universities</a></cite>
The Association of Class Officers began as the Association of Class Secretaries in 1902, when the Brown Alumni Monthly, scarcely two years old, gave a dinner at the University Club for the secretaries of the classes from 1857 to 1902, hoping to encourage subscriptions to the "Monthly," and to organize the secretaries to work for the interests of the University.<cite><a href="Association of Class Officers.html">Association of Class Officers</a></cite>
The Association of Class Secretaries was duly formed and elected George L. Miner 1897 its first secretary.<cite><a href="Association of Class Officers.html">Association of Class Officers</a></cite>
The next admitted to membership were the class presidents, and by 1977, after the vice-presidents and treasurers of the classes were admitted, the group became the Association of Class Officers.<cite><a href="Association of Class Officers.html">Association of Class Officers</a></cite>
In 1768 Morgan Edwards, who was collecting subscriptions in England, was instructed to purchase a telescope.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
There is no record that he did so, but the College later received from Joseph Brown a Gregorian reflecting telescope of 4-inch aperture and 24-inch focal length, made by Watkins and Smith of London, and purchased by him for $500 for the purpose of observing the transit of Venus on June 3, 1769.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
"Ferguson’s Astronomy" is mentioned as a study of the third year in the curriculum outlined in the Laws of 1783.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
In July 1782 Joseph Brown wrote to David Howell of "the Ingury our Tellescope has receved in attempting to have the tarnish or rust taken off the metal speculums.#8221; In 1800 funds from Samuel Elam paid for the repair of the telescope and also for an orrery.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
Joseph Brown was professor of natural history in 1784-85.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
Benjamin West was appointed professor of mathematics and astronomy in 1786, but did not begin to teach until 1788.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
Astronomy, which may have been taught in the course in natural philosophy, appears in the 1827-28 annual catalogue as a separate subject.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
Alexis Caswell joined the faculty as professor of mathematics and natural philosophy in 1828, and from 1850 to 1863 was professor of mathematics and astronomy.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
The textbooks used were the works of John Gummere and Sir John F. W. Herschel, and after 1840 William Augustus Norton’s treatise on astronomy.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
When Foucault performed his famous pendulum experiment in Paris in 1851 to prove the rotation of the earth, there was skepticism in Rhode Island and letters to the editor of the "Providence Journal," expressing disbelief.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
Caswell’s letters in reply explaining the theory did not satisfy, so he and William A. Norton (the author of the textbook in use, who was appointed professor of natural philosophy and civil engineering in 1850) repeated the experiment by hanging a cannonball at the end of a wire 97 feet long in the tower of the Providence railroad station.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
In 1864 Samuel Stillman Greene was appointed professor of natural history and philosophy.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
In his report for 1869 he mentioned the use of Loomis’ new textbook on astronomy for the first time and the use of the black globe and Vail’s Terrestrial and Celestial Sphere.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
In 1878 he wrote, "From the necessary brevity of the course, their attention was confined chiefly to Spherical Astronomy.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
In his first report in 1884, he noted that the textbook in use was Newcomb’s and Holden’s Astronomy.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
In 1888 he had, in addition to the students in the required course in the fundamental conception of astronomy, one student in his elective course in applied astronomy.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
In 1891 the observatory, a gift of Governor Ladd, was a reality.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
Frank W. Very was professor "pro tempore" of astronomy and director of <a href="Ladd Observatory.html">Ladd Observatory</a> in 1896-97, while Upton was in Peru working for the Harvard College Observatory.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
Frederick Slocum 1895 received the first Ph.D. in astronomy at Brown in 1898 and served as assistant professor of astronomy from 1899 to 1909.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
When Upton was on leave of absence in 1910-11, his place was filled by acting assistant professor Robert H. Baker from the University of Pittsburgh.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
A new course introduced in 1902 covered the principles of navigation using sextant, compass, and chart.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
After Upton’s death in 1914, the Department of Astronomy was merged with the Department of <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a>.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
Charles H. Smiley came to Brown in 1930 as assistant professor of mathematics.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
In 1938 astronomy was reestablished as a separate department with Smiley as chairman.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
On May 5, 1932, a group of amateur astronomers met at <a href="Ladd Observatory.html">Ladd Observatory</a> and formed an organization which took the name, "The Skyscrapers’ Amateur Astronomical Society of Rhode Island."<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
The society, with Smiley and Brown librarian Harry Lyman Koopman as active members, used the facilities of <a href="Ladd Observatory.html">Ladd Observatory</a> until 1936, when, newly incorporated as "Skyscrapers Inc.," it purchased the observatory formerly owned by Frank E. Seagrave in North Scituate, Rhode Island.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
Over the years the Skyscrapers cooperated in sponsoring a number of solar eclipse expeditions led by Smiley, and assisted in the construction of a Schmidt camera, f/1 of four inches aperture, from the mathematical design by Smiley for use in photographing the 1937 eclipse in Peru.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
In 1939-40 the group aided in building a Schwarzchild camera, f/3.5 of twelve inches aperture, the second of its kind in the country, which was used at the total solar of eclipse of October 1, 1940.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
Smiley taught astronomy enthusiastically until 1970, and probably led more eclipse expeditions than anyone.<cite><a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a></cite>
<a href="President.html">President</a> Caswell, in his annual report in 1870, expressed his fear that "the College is ... losing scholarship by the very great interest ... in boating and baseball."<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
An Athletic Association was founded on November 30, 1875, but was inactive until it was revived in the fall of 1878, when the first field day was held.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
Another field day was held on May 22, 1879 after several postponements caused by inclement weather, with the result that, according to the "<a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a>," "the attendance was diminished from a probable two thousand to six or seven hundred."<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
The New England Intercollegiate Athletic Association was organized in 1886, and Brown began to send representatives to the meets.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
When <a href="President.html">President</a> Andrews wrote his annual report in 1895, he hailed physical exercise and competition as healthful for the body and also morally and mentally uplifting.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
The Brown University Athletic Association was organized in September 1895.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
In February 1898 Brown was host to a conference on intercollegiate athletics, with representatives of Brown, Columbia, Cornell, Dartmouth, Harvard, Princeton and the University of Pennsylvania in attendance.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
In January 1904 the board of directors of the Brown University Athletic Association repealed by a 7-2 vote the rule which barred students who had ever engaged in athletics outside the University for money from representing Brown in intercollegiate contests.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
In 1906 undergraduates were given more responsibility.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
In the "<a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a> Rules and Regulations" for 1895 are included rules of the committee "On Athletic and other Student Organizations," governing eligibility.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
In 1906 a new constitution of the Brown University Athletic Association put the organization in the hands of the students.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
In 1907 Brown and Dartmouth severed athletic relations.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
In 1904-05 athletics showed a profit of only $168.08 after expenses had been subtracted from receipts of $14,306.57.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
By 1923-24 sports were making money as the receipts of $98,449.99 minus expenses left a profit of $19,949.63.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
The largest attendance at a football game prior to the opening of the stadium in 1925 was 8,000 at the Brown-Colgate Thanksgiving game in 1916.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
The <a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a> Rules of 1914 called for the appointment by the <a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a> of a Supervisor of Athletics to oversee the schedules, managers, and finances of athletic teams.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
A rule barring freshmen from intercollegiate competition was passed in 1922-23.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
In December 1923 the advisory committee to the coaching staff recommended to the accessory committee that football coach Edward N. Robinson and his assistant coach, Reginald W. P. Brown, should not be rehired.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
In January 1924 the football advisory committee resigned and was nonexistent in 1924 and 1925.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
In December 1925 the accessory committee reconsidered continuance of Robinson as coach and recommended the removal of both Robinson and Brown.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
A committee to provide better athletic facilities was formed in 1921 and made recommendations, which led to another committee, with Clinton C. White 1900 as chairman, charged with raising funds to build an amphitheater.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
The stadium and the baseball field at <a href="Aldrich Field.html">Aldrich Field</a> were built in 1925.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
To keep the attention of alumni and friends, the News Service began in 1925-26 a magazine called "Brunotes," which brought out news of athletics three times a year.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
In June 1926 new regulations were adopted by the Advisory and Executive Committee of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a>, organizing in place of the Athletic Association the Brown University Athletic Council.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
In 1938 the Advisory and Executive Committee of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> defined the duties of the Athletic Council as purely policy-making, and made the Director of Athletics directly responsible to the University administration.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
More changes were made in 1944, when it was decreed that the Director of Athletics would be designated an officer of administration responsible to the University rather than to the Athletic Council.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
Athletic directors at Brown have been Fred Eugene Parker from 1895 to 1903, Frederick W. Marvel from 1903 to 1938, Thomas W. Taylor from 1938 to 1942, Walter H. Snell, acting director from January to June 1943 and director until 1946, Paul F. Mackesey from 1947 to 1962, Edward R. Durgin from 1962 to 1963, Philip R. Theibert from 1963 to 1968, John M. Heffernan from 1968 to 1971, Ferdinand A.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
"Andy" Geiger from 1971 to 1975, Robert A. Seiple from 1975 to 1979, and John C. Parry from 1979 to 1990.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
Stephen Gladstone was acting director in 1990.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
David T. Roach became director on July 1, 1990.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
Huggins came to Brown in 1901 as a trainer for the football team, and later added the other sports teams to his duties.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
He started intercollegiate swimming at Brown, and helped to coach baseball, taking over the 1924 team during the illness of coach Wally Snell.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
McKinnon, who came as an assistant to his brother-in-law Huggins, worked for seven Brown football coaches from 1909 to 1959, taking over as head trainer when Huggins died in 1924, on the day of the football game with Yale.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
When McKinnon died in 1962, Frank Lanning, "Providence Journal" cartoonist, said of him, "He eased more than physical aches and pains on the hill" for troubled students.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
In 1905 the newly organized Athletic Association awarded six "BW" letters to women athletes.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
<a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a> was being played by the women as early as 1920.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
An apparatus team was added in 1924, and a pyramid squad in 1925.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
There was a swim team in 1924-25.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
A "Providence Journal" article in 1928 reported "rapid strides ... in women’s athletics at the university, with the recent addition of Danish gymnastics, archery, horseback riding, and swimming."<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
In the fall of 1928 a new sport called field-ball became popular with the Pembroke students, who promptly formed class teams.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
In 1929 an "honorary" varsity field-ball team was selected.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
Field hockey was reintroduced in 1930.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
In the 1930s fencing, coached by Lois Campbell, was also a popular activity, and there was a woman’s lacrosse team.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
Forty women students traveled to Connecticut College in 1933 to take part in a sports day competition.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
In February 1934 the Pembroke Athletic Association returned the invitation to a sports day which featured bowling, apparatus, ping-pong, and ring tennis, followed by a basketball game and a track meet.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
The athletic program was further expanded in 1934-35, when a modern dance group was formed, the first annual riding meet was held in November at Royal Riding School in Seekonk, and an intercollegiate telegraphic archery tournament took place, at which each college competed on its own premises and telegraphed its members’ scores.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
The dance group under the direction of Mrs. Flora Hopkins held its first public recital on May 8, 1935.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
In 1935 Pembroke students were allowed to play golf at Wannamoisett Country Club.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
Also in 1935 the Pembroke <a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a> Department branched out with the purchase of equipment for horseshoes, badminton, croquet, and deck tennis.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
Woman athletes acquired "points," which entitled them to awards, as a white blazer with a letter "P" for 1600 points, and a class numeral for a lesser number varying from 600 to 750.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
The state of athletics at women’s colleges in 1937 was the subject of a "Providence Journal" article headed "They’re Giving the Men Back Their Athletic Sports."<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
Bessie Rudd was director of physical education in charge of all athletic programs at <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a> 1930 to 1961.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
Women’s intercollegiate athletics, which had been funded as a student activity, began to share in the funds for all University athletic programs in 1973-74, following the Title IX legislation of the Educational Amendments to the Higher <a href="Education.html">Education</a> Act of 1972, and fifteen varsity level women’s teams were established.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
Arlene Gorton ’52, who succeeded Miss Rudd at Pembroke, was named director of physical education and assistant director of athletics at Brown in 1973.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
<a href="President.html">President</a> Swearer, speaking out about the need for reform in college athletics in 1981, suggested that major college teams might give up their amateur status and become professional farm teams.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
The number of varsity sports at Brown, men’s and women’s, grew to 31, before four varsity sports were dropped in 1991 as part of the University’s budget reduction.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
The Brown University Sports Foundation was established in 1983 to help the Brown athletic program and the University by raising money for sports programs so that more of the University funds formerly spent on sports could be directed to other needs.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
The foundation was officially launched on September 30, 1983, with exercises at which a ten-foot sculptured University coat of arms on the <a href="Olney-Margolies Athletic Center.html">Olney-Margolies Athletic Center</a> was unveiled.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
The Foundation holds annual winter weekend sports-related events, which have featured as guests Penn State coach Joe Paterno ’50 in 1984, broadcaster Howard Cosell in 1985, broadcaster Frank Gifford in 1986, Dallas Cowboys quarterback Roger Staubach in 1987, and Minnesota Vikings tight end Steve Jordan ’82 in 1988.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
In 1989 Chris Berman ’77, ESPN sportscaster, who got his start as the Voice of the Bruins on <a href="WBRU.html">WBRU</a>, spoke at the Sports Foundation Weekend <a href="Convocation.html">Convocation</a> in April.<cite><a href="Athletics.html">Athletics</a></cite>
Rev. Morgan Edwards may be said to have delivered the first baccalaureate sermon when he preached to the graduates in the evening of the first <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> day in 1769.<cite><a href="Baccalaureate.html">Baccalaureate</a></cite>
<a href="President.html">President</a> Caswell was asked to deliver a baccalaureate sermon by the Class of 1872, the class which was entering college when he assumed the presidency and was leaving as he retired.<cite><a href="Baccalaureate.html">Baccalaureate</a></cite>
In February 1944, when a winter commencement was held during wartime without the usual ceremony, Mr. Wriston delivered a baccalaureate address at the request of the graduates.<cite><a href="Baccalaureate.html">Baccalaureate</a></cite>
In 1988 another president, Howard Swearer, was the baccalaureate speaker at the last exercises before leaving the presidency.<cite><a href="Baccalaureate.html">Baccalaureate</a></cite>
William Whitman Bailey (1843-1914), professor of botany, was born on February 22, 1843 at West Point, where his father, Jacob Bailey, was professor of chemistry, mineralogy, and geology.<cite><a href="Bailey, William Whitman.html">Bailey, William Whitman</a></cite>
When his father died in 1857, William Whitman Bailey moved to Providence where an uncle lived.<cite><a href="Bailey, William Whitman.html">Bailey, William Whitman</a></cite>
William Whitman Bailey entered Brown with the Class of 1864, became a private in the Tenth Rhode Island Volunteers, and did not finish college.<cite><a href="Bailey, William Whitman.html">Bailey, William Whitman</a></cite>
William Whitman Bailey was assistant in chemistry at Brown in 1865 and at M.I.T. in 1866.<cite><a href="Bailey, William Whitman.html">Bailey, William Whitman</a></cite>
While working at M.I.T. in 1867, Bailey heard that Clarence King, heading the U. S. Geological Exploration of the Fortieth Parallel, was looking for a botanist to join the expedition.<cite><a href="Bailey, William Whitman.html">Bailey, William Whitman</a></cite>
Bailey left the expedition because of ill health in 1868 and returned to Providence, where he served as Deputy Secretary of State under John R. Bartlett and assistant librarian at the Providence Athenaeum.<cite><a href="Bailey, William Whitman.html">Bailey, William Whitman</a></cite>
In 1871 William Whitman Bailey went to New York to have a try at journalism.<cite><a href="Bailey, William Whitman.html">Bailey, William Whitman</a></cite>
William Whitman Bailey taught botany at private schools in Providence from 1872 to 1877.<cite><a href="Bailey, William Whitman.html">Bailey, William Whitman</a></cite>
In 1875 a new suggestion from Asa Gray was that Bailey should attend the Summer School of Botany at Harvard, which he did for three summers.<cite><a href="Bailey, William Whitman.html">Bailey, William Whitman</a></cite>
In the spring of 1877, at the suggestion of Professor <a href="Poland, William Carey.html">William Carey Poland</a>, he applied to President Robinson for permission to start a private class in botany at the University.<cite><a href="Bailey, William Whitman.html">Bailey, William Whitman</a></cite>
Bailey wrote, "At the end of the season I was voted thirty dollars, and was tempted to go on by the title of instructor and the advanced pay of fifty dollars for the season of 1878."<cite><a href="Bailey, William Whitman.html">Bailey, William Whitman</a></cite>
William Whitman Bailey continued to teach until 1906, having been appointed professor of botany in 1881.<cite><a href="Bailey, William Whitman.html">Bailey, William Whitman</a></cite>
Brown awarded him a Bachelor of Philosophy degree in 1873 and a Master of Arts in 1883.<cite><a href="Bailey, William Whitman.html">Bailey, William Whitman</a></cite>
William Whitman Bailey's publications included "Botanical Collectors’ Handbook" (1881), "Botanical Note-book" (1894-97), "Among Rhode Island Wild Flowers" (1895 and 1896), "New England Wild Flowers" (1895), and "Botanizing" (1899).<cite><a href="Bailey, William Whitman.html">Bailey, William Whitman</a></cite>
When William Whitman Bailey retired because of illness in 1906, he was the first Brown professor to have a Carnegie pension.<cite><a href="Bailey, William Whitman.html">Bailey, William Whitman</a></cite>
William Whitman Bailey died on February 22, 1914, and was allowed to be buried near his father in the Academy grounds at West Point.<cite><a href="Bailey, William Whitman.html">Bailey, William Whitman</a></cite>
The Brown Alumni Monthly published its first issue, eight pages long, in June 1900.<cite><a href="BAM Brown Alumni Monthly.html">BAM Brown Alumni Monthly</a></cite>
A committee appointed by a meeting of the class secretaries, the members of which were Winslow Upton 1875, Robert P. Brown 1871, and Walter B. Jacobs 1882, had recommended the establishment of an alumni publication.<cite><a href="BAM Brown Alumni Monthly.html">BAM Brown Alumni Monthly</a></cite>
An advisory board of nine alumni, which would select its own successors, appointed Henry R. Palmer 1890 as the first editor, Joseph N. Ashton 1891 as associate editor, and William L. Clark 1901 as business manager.<cite><a href="BAM Brown Alumni Monthly.html">BAM Brown Alumni Monthly</a></cite>
Beginning with the second issue in July, 1900, which contained twenty pages, coated paper was used and photographs were included.<cite><a href="BAM Brown Alumni Monthly.html">BAM Brown Alumni Monthly</a></cite>
Henry Robinson Palmer remained editor-in-chief for thirty-one years, personally editing 309 of the 310 issues in that time (he was abroad in May 1902, the only issue which did not receive his immediate supervision).<cite><a href="BAM Brown Alumni Monthly.html">BAM Brown Alumni Monthly</a></cite>
His employment since his graduation in 1890 was with the Providence Journal Company, where he rose to editor of the "Providence Sunday Journal" and chief editorial writer.<cite><a href="BAM Brown Alumni Monthly.html">BAM Brown Alumni Monthly</a></cite>
His son, Louis B. Palmer ’28, who has called the magazine his "father’s first child" remembers the magazine as part of his childhood: In March 1927, following the lead of other college magazines, the "Monthly" adopted a larger size page and a self-cover with a cover photograph.<cite><a href="BAM Brown Alumni Monthly.html">BAM Brown Alumni Monthly</a></cite>
Clinton C. White ’00 and Henry S. Chafee ’09 were the committee from the <a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a> who broached this subject to Mr. Palmer, who responded by offering the <a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a> the magazine "free and clear" after May 1931.<cite><a href="BAM Brown Alumni Monthly.html">BAM Brown Alumni Monthly</a></cite>
Henry S. Chafee was Chairman of the Board from 1931 to June 1945.<cite><a href="BAM Brown Alumni Monthly.html">BAM Brown Alumni Monthly</a></cite>
He resigned the chairmanship in 1942 and was succeeded by Louis B. Palmer, but when Palmer went in the Navy, he resumed his former office.<cite><a href="BAM Brown Alumni Monthly.html">BAM Brown Alumni Monthly</a></cite>
Beginning in 1945, the <a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a> was able to send the "Brown Alumni Monthly" free to all Brown men with financing by the University.<cite><a href="BAM Brown Alumni Monthly.html">BAM Brown Alumni Monthly</a></cite>
In 1952, after budget cuts throughout the University, the appropriation was decreased and would finance only eight issues a year.<cite><a href="BAM Brown Alumni Monthly.html">BAM Brown Alumni Monthly</a></cite>
At this time the <a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a> asked for voluntary contributions which paid for the ninth issue until 1954, when the University subscription increased again.<cite><a href="BAM Brown Alumni Monthly.html">BAM Brown Alumni Monthly</a></cite>
There have been only four editors of the "Monthly," Henry Robinson Palmer, from 1900 to 1931, W. Chesley Worthington from 1931 to 1968, Robert A. Reichley, 1968 to 1971, and Robert M. "Dusty" Rhodes, who has been editor since March of 1971.<cite><a href="BAM Brown Alumni Monthly.html">BAM Brown Alumni Monthly</a></cite>
John F. "Jay" Barry ’50 was assistant and associate editor from 1955 to 1983.<cite><a href="BAM Brown Alumni Monthly.html">BAM Brown Alumni Monthly</a></cite>
Timothy Whiting Bancroft (1837-1890), professor of English, was born in Worcester, Massachusetts, on March 9, 1837.<cite><a href="Bancroft, Timothy Whiting.html">Bancroft, Timothy Whiting</a></cite>
Timothy Whiting Bancroft graduated from Brown in 1859.<cite><a href="Bancroft, Timothy Whiting.html">Bancroft, Timothy Whiting</a></cite>
In 1868 Timothy Whiting Bancroft became professor of rhetoric and English literature at Brown after the death of Professor Robinson Potter Dunn.<cite><a href="Bancroft, Timothy Whiting.html">Bancroft, Timothy Whiting</a></cite>
Timothy Whiting Bancroft suffered a breakdown in 1883 but, after traveling in the South and in Europe, returned to his teaching duties, which became increasingly burdensome.<cite><a href="Bancroft, Timothy Whiting.html">Bancroft, Timothy Whiting</a></cite>
Timothy Whiting Bancroft's disappearance in December of 1890 was viewed with apprehension and handbills were circulated, offering a fifty dollar reward for information leading to his discovery.<cite><a href="Bancroft, Timothy Whiting.html">Bancroft, Timothy Whiting</a></cite>
Arthur Mangun Banta (1877-1946), professor of biology, was born in Greenwood, Indiana, on December 31, 1877.<cite><a href="Banta, Arthur M..html">Banta, Arthur M.</a></cite>
After receiving a bachelor of science degree from Central Normal College in Danville, Indiana, in 1898, Arthur M. Banta earned a bachelor of arts degree in 1903 and a master of arts degree in 1904 at the University of Indiana, where he began his work under Carl Eigenmann, investigating fauna of a local cave.<cite><a href="Banta, Arthur M..html">Banta, Arthur M.</a></cite>
After receiving his Ph.D. degree from Harvard in 1907, Arthur M. Banta became professor of biology at Marietta College.<cite><a href="Banta, Arthur M..html">Banta, Arthur M.</a></cite>
Beginning in 1909, Arthur M. Banta conducted research at the Cold Spring Harbor (Long Island) Station for Experimental Evolution of the Carnegie Institution of Washington.<cite><a href="Banta, Arthur M..html">Banta, Arthur M.</a></cite>
Arthur M. Banta came to Brown in 1929 as visiting professor of biology and was named research professor the following year.<cite><a href="Banta, Arthur M..html">Banta, Arthur M.</a></cite>
In 1939 the Carnegie Institution published Banta’s "Studies on the Physiology, Genetics and Evolution of some Cladocera" (water flea), which he had researched at Cold Spring Harbor and completed at Brown after a temporary setback when two suitcases which contained the results of five years of his research were stolen from his locked car in New York City.<cite><a href="Banta, Arthur M..html">Banta, Arthur M.</a></cite>
Arthur M. Banta retired from teaching in June of 1945, with the intention of concluding some of his investigations, but died on January 2, 1946, his great work still unfulfilled.<cite><a href="Banta, Arthur M..html">Banta, Arthur M.</a></cite>
Clarence Augustus Barbour (1867-1937), tenth president of Brown University, was born in Hartford, Connecticut on April 21, 1867.<cite><a href="Barbour, Clarence A..html">Barbour, Clarence A.</a></cite>
Clarence A. Barbour graduated from Brown in 1888.<cite><a href="Barbour, Clarence A..html">Barbour, Clarence A.</a></cite>
In 1891 Clarence A. Barbour graduated from Rochester Theological Seminary and was ordained to the Baptist ministry.<cite><a href="Barbour, Clarence A..html">Barbour, Clarence A.</a></cite>
In 1909 Clarence A. Barbour resigned to become associate secretary of the Religious Work Department of the International Committee of the Y.M.C.A.<cite><a href="Barbour, Clarence A..html">Barbour, Clarence A.</a></cite>
In 1915 Clarence A. Barbour was named Wyckoff Professor of Homiletics and president of Rochester Theological Seminary.<cite><a href="Barbour, Clarence A..html">Barbour, Clarence A.</a></cite>
Clarence A. Barbour was instrumental in the merger of Colgate Theological Seminary and Rochester Theological Seminary to form the Colgate Rochester Divinity School in 1928.<cite><a href="Barbour, Clarence A..html">Barbour, Clarence A.</a></cite>
Barbour was unanimously elected by the Corporation on October 10, 1928 to be president of Brown on the retirement of William H. P. Faunce in 1929.<cite><a href="Barbour, Clarence A..html">Barbour, Clarence A.</a></cite>
Among their conclusions: that Brown had ceased to be a typical New England college and become a University; that Rhode Island depended on Brown as the chief educational institution in the State; that administrative development had failed to keep pace with the growth of the University; that entering students were found by various psychological tests to be above average freshmen, with the women scoring slightly higher than the men; that the Honors courses adopted in 1920 had not been effective as hoped, as the achievement of Brown graduates in professional schools lagged behind that of graduates of comparable schools; that Pembroke should be given more independence in Clarence A. Barbour's organization and offerings; that the Graduate School was providing Brown with nation-wide clientele from which to build her its staff; that there was need for reorganization of the curriculum and methods of instruction to stimulate students.<cite><a href="Barbour, Clarence A..html">Barbour, Clarence A.</a></cite>
In September 1931, the day after presiding at the opening of the academic year, Barbour left for a nine month trip to the Orient with the Laymen’s Committee on Foreign Missions.<cite><a href="Barbour, Clarence A..html">Barbour, Clarence A.</a></cite>
Speaking to the alumni at the first Homecoming dinner in 1935, Barbour said, "I came to Brown with lofty dreams and with visions of things to be accomplished.<cite><a href="Barbour, Clarence A..html">Barbour, Clarence A.</a></cite>
On January 22, 1936, Clarence A. Barbour was overcome by a sudden attack of appendicitis at the Brown Club of Providence dinner.<cite><a href="Barbour, Clarence A..html">Barbour, Clarence A.</a></cite>
Clarence A. Barbour was relieved of his presidential duties in September 1936 and planned to retire in February 1937.<cite><a href="Barbour, Clarence A..html">Barbour, Clarence A.</a></cite>
Clarence A. Barbour died in Providence on January 16, 1937, two weeks before his scheduled retirement.<cite><a href="Barbour, Clarence A..html">Barbour, Clarence A.</a></cite>
Elisha Bartlett (1804-1855), "Brown’s most eminent medical graduate" according to William Osler, was born in Smithfield in 1804.<cite><a href="Bartlett, Elisha.html">Bartlett, Elisha</a></cite>
Elisha Bartlett earned an M.D. degree at Brown’s medical school in 1826.<cite><a href="Bartlett, Elisha.html">Bartlett, Elisha</a></cite>
At the age of 32 Elisha Bartlett was elected the first mayor of Lowell, and in 1841 he was elected to the Massachusetts State legislature.<cite><a href="Bartlett, Elisha.html">Bartlett, Elisha</a></cite>
Elisha Bartlett taught in nine schools, his appointments being professor of pathological anatomy and materia medica at the Berkshire Medical Institute in Pittsfield, Massachusetts in 1832, professor at Dartmouth in 1839, professor of the theory and practice of medicine at Transylvania University in Lexington, Kentucky in 1841 and at the University of Maryland in 1844, professor of materia medica and obstetrics at Vermont Medical College in 1844 (he taught a course for thirteen weeks each year until 1854), and professor of the theory and practice of medicine at the University of Louisville in March 1849 for one session only, after which he went to the University of New York.<cite><a href="Bartlett, Elisha.html">Bartlett, Elisha</a></cite>
Elisha Bartlett traveled to Europe again in 1844-45.<cite><a href="Bartlett, Elisha.html">Bartlett, Elisha</a></cite>
Elisha Bartlett's other career was as a medical writer with the "Monthly Journal of Medical Literature and American Student’s Gazette" (of which there were only three issues), and "Medical Magazine" from 1832 to 1835.<cite><a href="Bartlett, Elisha.html">Bartlett, Elisha</a></cite>
In 1831 Elisha Bartlett translated "Sketches of the Character and Writings of Eminent Living Surgeons and Physicians of Paris" from the French of J. L. H. Peisse.<cite><a href="Bartlett, Elisha.html">Bartlett, Elisha</a></cite>
In 1844 Elisha Bartlett wrote "An Essay on the Philosophy of Medicine."<cite><a href="Bartlett, Elisha.html">Bartlett, Elisha</a></cite>
But his main work was that on fevers, published in 1842 with three subsequent editions, one of the most notable medical works known as "Bartlett on Fevers."<cite><a href="Bartlett, Elisha.html">Bartlett, Elisha</a></cite>
When illness which was to result in paralysis struck Bartlett in 1854, he passed his time writing a little volume entitled "Simple Settings in Verse, for Six Portraits and Pictures from Mr. Dickens’s Gallery," which he sent as a farewell gift to his friends before his death on July 19, 1855.<cite><a href="Bartlett, Elisha.html">Bartlett, Elisha</a></cite>
The Barus and Holley Building, dedicated on June 4, 1965, was named in honor of faculty member and physicist Carl Barus and alumnus and engineer Alexander Lyman Holley 1853.<cite><a href="Barus and Holley Building.html">Barus and Holley Building</a></cite>
The groundbreaking for the building had occurred on September 16, 1963, after over a year of controversy.<cite><a href="Barus and Holley Building.html">Barus and Holley Building</a></cite>
A sculpture by Mario J. Kujawski ’66 was placed beside the building in 1966.<cite><a href="Barus and Holley Building.html">Barus and Holley Building</a></cite>
Carl Barus (1856-1935), professor of physics and dean of the Graduate Department, was born in Cincinnati on February 19, 1856, the son of German immigrant parents who had met and married after coming to the United States.<cite><a href="Barus, Carl.html">Barus, Carl</a></cite>
In 1874 Carl Barus graduated from Woodward High School in the same class as William Howard Taft.<cite><a href="Barus, Carl.html">Barus, Carl</a></cite>
Carl Barus spent two years at Columbia studying mining engineering, but was lured away by the attraction of pure science to Würzberg, where he studied under F. W. G. Kohlrausch and earned his Ph.D. degree, "summa cum laude," in 1879 for his dissertation on the relations of hardness of steel to its electrical and thermoelectric properties and its magnetization.<cite><a href="Barus, Carl.html">Barus, Carl</a></cite>
In 1880 Carl Barus was engaged to take charge of the purely physical work of the newly organized United States Geological Survey, which was directed by Clarence King.<cite><a href="Barus, Carl.html">Barus, Carl</a></cite>
After twelve years of important research in Nevada, New York, New Haven, Philadelphia, and Washington, Barus found his work with the Survey terminated by the withdrawal of government grants in 1892.<cite><a href="Barus, Carl.html">Barus, Carl</a></cite>
During 1891-92 Carl Barus was professor of meteorology at the United States Weather Bureau.<cite><a href="Barus, Carl.html">Barus, Carl</a></cite>
From 1893 to 1895 Carl Barus was a physicist at the Smithsonian Institution, where he assisted Samuel Langley in his experiments with flying machines.<cite><a href="Barus, Carl.html">Barus, Carl</a></cite>
In 1895 Carl Barus accepted the Hazard professorship of physics at Brown and remained in that position for thirty-one years.<cite><a href="Barus, Carl.html">Barus, Carl</a></cite>
Carl Barus's scientific research at Brown produced 350 articles and monographs from 1895 to 1929.<cite><a href="Barus, Carl.html">Barus, Carl</a></cite>
Carl Barus was appointed the first dean of the Graduate Department in 1903, which he ran out of his office in Wilson Hall.<cite><a href="Barus, Carl.html">Barus, Carl</a></cite>
Barus’s reputation was recognized by the many worldwide honors that came to him – he was a corresponding member of the British Association for the Advancement of Science, an honorary member of the Royal Institution of Great Britain, of the First International Congress of Radiology and Electricity at Brussels in 1905, and of the Physikalisch-Medizinische Sozietät at Erlangen.<cite><a href="Barus, Carl.html">Barus, Carl</a></cite>
In the United States Carl Barus was a member of the American Philosophical Society, the youngest member ever of the National Academy of Sciences in 1892, the fourth president of the American Physical Society in 1905 and 1906, and a member of the advisory committee on physics in connection with the organization of the Carnegie Institution of Washington.<cite><a href="Barus, Carl.html">Barus, Carl</a></cite>
In 1900 Carl Barus was awarded the Rumford Medal of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences for his researches in heat.<cite><a href="Barus, Carl.html">Barus, Carl</a></cite>
Barus continued as dean of the Graduate Department until his retirement in 1926.<cite><a href="Barus, Carl.html">Barus, Carl</a></cite>
Carl Barus died in Providence on September 20, 1935 in Providence.<cite><a href="Barus, Carl.html">Barus, Carl</a></cite>
The Class of 1865 team as freshmen captured the championship of Providence by defeating the Dexters and was challenged by the freshman team of Harvard.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
Guild for the account of Brown’s first intercollegiate game on June 27, 1863, written for the "Providence Journal," which described the details of the encounter from meeting the Harvard team at the railroad station, taking them to Humphreys’ for lunch, touring them through the library and laboratory, to escorting them to the Dexter Training Ground for the game.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
The class of 1870 had an especially strong team, and in 1868 members of that team accounted for eight players of the varsity nine.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
On the arrival of the Lowells from Boston, they were told that Smith (the only varsity player not of the class of 1870) was ill, so that the University nine could not play them.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
However, they were offered a game with the Class of 1870 team.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
At the Hammer and Tongs entertainment in the evening following the game, Edward K. Glezen 1866 presented, on behalf of the young ladies present at the game, a shield of flowers bearing the letters "B.U.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
June 17th, 1868," definitely a day to be remembered.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
The freshman team of 1872 took an unprecedented tour in July of 1869 to play against five other colleges.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
From September 1870 to June 1871 the varsity won eight of its thirteen games, losing three times to Harvard and twice to the Boston Red Stockings.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
<a href="Lincoln Field.html">Lincoln Field</a> was laid out on the back campus in 1880.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
J. Lee Richmond 1880 pitched the first perfect game in professional baseball, a 1-0 victory for Worcester over Cleveland, on June 12, 1880, four days before his graduation.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
Walter Angell 1880 pointed out some time later that the Worcester-Cleveland game was actually Richmond’s second game of the day, since at about 4:30 A.M. he had taken part in the traditional early morning game which followed the seniors’ class supper, and then hopped the train to Worcester.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
In the 1879 season Richmond had led the Brown team to a college championship, won in the last minutes of the final game with Yale.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
When <a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a> was built, the baseball team had an on-site training facilityin its basement, which was in 1889, according to the "<a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a>," improved by "the construction of a narrow track around the sides of the basement floor to the north of the batting cage.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
Baseball revived in the early 1890s with Fred Woodcock 1891 and Frank Sexton 1893 pitching and Fred Tenney 1894 as catcher.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
Several of the players of the 1890s went on to play major league ball, Woodcock with Pittsburgh, Sexton, Tenney, and outfielder John "Daff" Gammons 1893 with the Boston Nationals, Thomas Dowd 1893 with the Washington Senators, and William Lauder 1898 with the Philadelphia Phillies and the New York Giants.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
The Brown team, defeated only by Holy Cross and Harvard, won 27 of 31 games in 1896 for the college baseball championship of the country.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
