The 1897 varsity won 24 of 30 games, and as champions of the East traveled to Chicago to meet and win two games of three in a series with the champions of the West, the University of Chicago.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
In 1900 Libe Washburn’s pitching brought the team to second place among college teams, defeating both Harvard and Yale.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
The team of 1903, with pitchers M. J. Lynch ’04 and H. F. Hatch ’06, won fifteen of its twenty regularly scheduled games.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
The team and the college were looking forward to a great season in 1904, but the entire team played summer ball and was disqualified.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
The 1904 team was therefore made up entirely of inexperienced men who had never played on a varsity squad, with the expected result of a losing season brightened by unexpected victories over Princeton, Holy Cross, and Dartmouth.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
The 1911 team won twenty games and lost five.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
In 1912 a team which included pitchers Joe Conzelman ’12 and Eddie Warner ’12, and shortstop Ken Nash ’12, won nineteen games and lost five.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
The 1913 team won seventeen of its twenty games, losing to Yale twice and to Holy Cross.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
During the 1913 season Frank Gilbreth, an efficiency expert residing in Providence, took motion picture films of the baseball players to use in improving their batting and throwing.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
In 1915 the varsity won seventeen and lost four, and for the first time a second team was organized and won six of its eleven scheduled games.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
The team of 1919, with pitcher Ralph Knight ’21, won thirteen of sixteen games, losing to Rhode Island and twice to Holy Cross, and even playing seven innings against the Boston Braves.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
In the early 1900s athletic director Fred Parker, and former players Frank Sexton and Fred Woodcock served as coaches.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
Harry Pattee ’06, who played shortstop for two of his undergraduate years and also played for the Brooklyn Dodgers, coached the Brown team from 1912 to 1921.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
The teams of the 1920s, under coaches Wally Snell and Jean Dubuc, had some great pitchers – Hal Neubauer ’25, who won 23 and lost 7 in his four Brown seasons and played with the Boston Red Sox, Irving "Bump" Hadley ’28, who played on the freshman team before dropping out to begin his professional career with the Washington Senators and then moving on to the New York Yankees, and Haskell Billings ’29, who was both pitcher and third baseman at Brown and later pitched for the Detroit Tigers.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
One of Brown’s most memorable games was played on June 7, 1924, when Brown and Providence College played a twenty-inning game, which was eventually won by Providence, 1-0.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
Two years later Reynolds of Providence College again pitched in a long game against Brown on May 22, 1926.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
Coach John Kelleher’s twelve teams from 1930 to 1941 had four winning, five losing, and three tied seasons.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
After a three year slump Kelleher’s last two teams in 1940 and 1941 improved to the extent that they had equal wins and losses, with the help of pitcher Walt Jusczyk ’41, who caused Providence College two losses to Brown in one season for the first time, and in 1941 struck out 106 men in 102 innings and allowed only eight earned runs.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
With the advent of year-round operation of the University in 1942 there were two baseball seasons, spring and summer, neither of them successful for Brown.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
Eddie Eayrs ’16 coached from 1942 to 1948.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
Wilfred "Lefty" Lefebrve, who coached from 1949 to 1963, achieved a record of 105-120-2, as a part-time coach with a full time high school teaching job, which left little opportunity for recruiting.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
His 1952 team tied Cornell for the Eastern Intercollegiate title.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
Stanley Ward’s teams from 1965 to 1968 had a 40-57-2 record.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
After that, Bill Livesey (43-41-5) coached from 1969 to 1971, and George Woodworth (60-91-4) coached from 1972 to 1980.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
Dave Stenhouse, whose thirteen-year professional pitching career included stints with the Chicago Cubs and the Washington Senators, coached the Brown team from 1981 to 1990.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
His 1986 team had 23 wins, the most in Brown baseball history for a season, and eighteen losses.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
In college he was All-Ivy and All-EIBL in 1973 and 1974, and after playing for the Padres, he returned to Brown as coach in 1992, replacing Frank Castelli, who had coached in 1991 and 1992.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
Brown’s best finish in the league was a tie with Cornell for the title in 1952.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
There have been four league batting champions from Brown: Al Gauthier in 1951 (.385), Tom Skenderian in 1966 (.514), Scott Bingham in 1972 (.394), and John King in 1979 (.512).<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
Brown’s two All-Americans are David DeLuca ’64, who led New England batters in 1964 with a .397 average, and Bill Almon ’75, who was named College Baseball Player of the Year in 1974, when he batted .350, made ten home runs, batted in 31 runs, and stole twenty bases.<cite><a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a></cite>
Basketball began at Brown in 1901.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
In February 1900 the "Brown Daily Herald" had reported, "The game of hand polo has been a very popular indoor game at Brown.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
The next year on January 5, 1901, the "Herald" carried a notice which read, "Will all those who are at all interested in basket-ball meet at 11 <a href="Slater Hall.html">Slater Hall</a> at 1:30 today.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
The early games were generally low-scoring, with the occasional exception (Brown 60, Massachusetts 8 in 1905).<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
Brown’s first winning season came in 1905 with a 12-6 record and Brown’s first victory over Dartmouth, 18-17, in a game in which Oscar Rackle scored 16 points.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
The 1905 team had been accused of receiving money for a game at Wickford.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
One highlight of that season was Pryor’s single-game record of 34 points, which was unbroken until 1938.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
The 1907-08 team, again captained by Pryor, played a variety of opponents, defeating Norwich, M.I.T., Harvard, Wesleyan, Colgate, Andover, Manhattan, Syracuse, Levy Tech and Trinity, and losing to Tufts, Penn, Fordham, Wesleyan and Williams.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
There was less success for the teams of the next few years, and in 1910 the varsity disbanded because of lack of interest and support.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
In March 1912 Brown dropped basketball.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
It was 1919 before basketball at Brown was revived through the efforts of Louis A. R. Pieri ’20.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
In the 1920s there were three winning seasons under coaches Wally Snell ’13 and Harold "Chick" Evans, 13-10 in 1922, and 10-6 in 1925 and 1926.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
The team of 1938-39, coach George "Eck" Allen’s first team, was chosen to represent New England in the first championship tournament conducted by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
That team, undefeated on the home court, won seventeen of its twenty games, beat every New England opponent excepting Dartmouth and including Providence College for the first time since 1922, but lost to Villanova, 42-30, in the tournament.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
Harry Platt ’40 broke all of Brown’s scoring records with a single game score of 48 points against Northeastern in 1938, a season scoring record of 404 in 1937-38, and a career record of 866.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
In 1945 the team, led by George "Woody" Grimshaw ’47, won the New England title.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
After 1945 Brown basketball experienced a long run of losing seasons, but had its star players.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
The high point of the 8-11 season of 1950-51 was Brown’s first victory on Rhode Island State’s home court in sixteen years, a one-point win on a basket by Fred Kozak ’50 in the last three seconds of the game.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
Stan Ward’s fifteen-year coaching record from 1954 to 1969 was 133-261.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
A low point in Brown’s basketball history was the 3-23 season in 1969-70.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
Under coach James G. "Gerry" Alaimo ’58 the team improved slowly, and in 1972-73 had its first winning season since 1959-60, as five sophomores, Phil Brown ’75, Jim Busam ’75, Vaughan Clarke ’75, Lloyd Desvigne ’75, and Eddie Morris ’75, finished 14-12 and third in the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a>, and went on to 17-9 and a tie for second in the league in 1973-74, and 14-12 and a tie for third in 1974-75.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
Alaimo left in 1978 with an 88-148 record, 57-59 in the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a>.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
Joe Mullaney, successful coach at Providence College, took over and coached until 1981, and was followed by Mike Cingiser ’62.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
The disappointing seasons continued until 1985-86, when Brown, in its first winning season (16-11) since 1975, won its first <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> championship, but lost to Syracuse, 101-52, in the opening round of the regional NCAA tournament.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
Wally Snell coached from 1921 to 1923 and Harold Evans from 1923 to 1926.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
Two football coaches did double duty as coaches of the basketball team, DeOrmond "Tuss" McLaughry from 1926 to 1929, and Charles A.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
"Rip" Engle from 1942 to 1946.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
Arthur D. Kahler coached from 1931 to 1938, George E. "Eck" Allen from 1938 to 1941, William H. H. Dye in 1941-42, Wilbur C. "Weeb" Ewbank (who much later made a name for himself in pro football by coaching both the Baltimore Colts and the New York Jets to league championships) in 1946-47, Robert B. Morris from 1947 to 1954, Stan Ward from 1954 to 1969, Gerry Alaimo from 1969 to 1978, Joe Mullaney from 1978 to 1981, Mike Cingiser from 1981 to 1991, and the present coach, Frank "Happy" Dobbs.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
In 1903 the seniors won, defeating the freshmen 16-2, in a game which was pronounced a financial success with a profit of $16.50.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
In the first year of intercollegiate competition since the 1960s the women’s team, led by Sara Diedrick ’76, compiled a 13-1 record in 1973-74, and on February 16, 1974, with Providence College, was one of the first woman’s athletic teams to compete in the Providence Civic Center.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
The Brown women were 16-4 in 1974-75 and 13-7 in 1975-76.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
The women’s teams have been coached by Mary Avery in 1958, Sarah Phillips in 1960, Jan Lutz in 1972-73, Gail Davis from 1973 to 1975; Carole Kleinfelder from 1975-76, Gail Klock from 1976 to 1980; Maureen Enos from 1980 to 1988; and Jean Marie Burr since 1988.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
In <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> competition the women’s team finished in second place in 1974-75.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
1975-1976, 1977-78, 1989-90, and 1990-91, and won the championship in 1983-84, 1984-85 (shared with Princeton), and 1991-92.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
Coach Jean Marie Burr’s record for four years since 1988 is 73-31 overall and 41-15 in the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a>.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
The 1990-91 team set new records of 1,850 points, nineteen victories, and 71 three-pointers.<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
The 1991-92 team broke the school record for most wins in a season, 22-4 (13-1 in the League).<cite><a href="Basketball.html">Basketball</a></cite>
George Houston Bass (1938-1990), professor of Afro-American studies, was born in Nashville on April 23, 1938.<cite><a href="Bass, George H..html">Bass, George H.</a></cite>
George H. Bass graduated from Fisk University with honors in mathematics in 1959, and pursued graduate study in business at Columbia University.<cite><a href="Bass, George H..html">Bass, George H.</a></cite>
At that time George H. Bass met Langston Hughes, changed his interest to literature and went on to receive a master of arts degree from New York University’s Film School in 1964.<cite><a href="Bass, George H..html">Bass, George H.</a></cite>
In the years after that George H. Bass was a free lance writer and director in New York and attended the Yale School of Drama from 1966 to 1968.<cite><a href="Bass, George H..html">Bass, George H.</a></cite>
George H. Bass was also associate producer and story editor of a series of original plays entitled "On Being Black" produced on WGBH-TV in 1968 and 1969 and aired nationally over the Public Broadcasting System.<cite><a href="Bass, George H..html">Bass, George H.</a></cite>
George H. Bass was Langston Hughes’s secretary and literary assistant from 1959 to 1964, and became co-executor of Hughes’s estate in 1967.<cite><a href="Bass, George H..html">Bass, George H.</a></cite>
George H. Bass founded the Langston Hughes Society in 1981 and the next year started "The Langston Hughes Review."<cite><a href="Bass, George H..html">Bass, George H.</a></cite>
He was honored by the Yale School of Drama, which performed his plays at George Bass Day in 1967, and received the Harlem Cultural Council award in 1969.<cite><a href="Bass, George H..html">Bass, George H.</a></cite>
George H. Bass's first appointment at Brown was lecturer in the Department of English in 1970.<cite><a href="Bass, George H..html">Bass, George H.</a></cite>
George H. Bass was named associate professor of English and theatre arts in 1973, associate professor of theatre arts and Afro-American studies in 1976, and was promoted to full professor in 1985.<cite><a href="Bass, George H..html">Bass, George H.</a></cite>
George H. Bass died suddenly of an apparent heart attack in Providence on September 19, 1990.<cite><a href="Bass, George H..html">Bass, George H.</a></cite>
Charles Augustus Baylis (1902-1975), professor of philosophy, was born in Portland, Oregon, on April 2, 1902.<cite><a href="Baylis, Charles A..html">Baylis, Charles A.</a></cite>
Charles A. Baylis received his A.B. and A.M. degrees from the University of Washington in 1923 and 1924, and his Ph.D. from Harvard in 1926.<cite><a href="Baylis, Charles A..html">Baylis, Charles A.</a></cite>
Charles A. Baylis came to Brown in 1927 as an instructor, and became assistant professor in 1930 and associate professor in 1937.<cite><a href="Baylis, Charles A..html">Baylis, Charles A.</a></cite>
Charles A. Baylis resigned in 1949 to become head of the Philosophy Department at the University of Maryland.<cite><a href="Baylis, Charles A..html">Baylis, Charles A.</a></cite>
In 1952 Charles A. Baylis became professor of philosophy at Duke University, where he was also director of graduate studies until 1956.<cite><a href="Baylis, Charles A..html">Baylis, Charles A.</a></cite>
Charles A. Baylis retired in 1970, and died on August 30, 1975.<cite><a href="Baylis, Charles A..html">Baylis, Charles A.</a></cite>
The "Brown Daily Herald" first appeared on Wednesday, December 2, 1891.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
The secret planning for the paper was actually begun about a month earlier by Ted Baylies 1895 and George Hunter 1893, who, as readers of the Harvard "Crimson" and the "Yale Daily News" were convinced that they could put out a daily newspaper at Brown.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
They enlisted the help of John 1893 and Edward Casey 1893, who were putting themselves through college in their printing shop at the foot of College Hill.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
Baylies and Steve Hopkins 1893 rounded up advertising for the whole year to insure the financial soundness of their proposed venture.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
Ben Johnson 1893, H. Anthony Dyer 1894, and Guy A. Andrews 1895 were also named to the board of editors.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
The "Herald" received a cool reception from the "<a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a>," which in 1890 had welcomed the "<a href="Brown Magazine.html">Brown Magazine</a>" as a new literary publication and devoted its own pages to news, but had rejected the idea of daily publication.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
Nevertheless, the "Herald" survived and even began to have a social life, holding its first banquet at the Crown Hotel in 1903, and playing the first of a long series of annual baseball games against the "<a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a>" in 1907.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
As a supporter of Charles Evans Hughes 1881 for president in 1916, the "Herald" happily and in large print proclaimed his victory on November 8, before learning that he had actually lost the election.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
The word "Daily" was dropped in May 1917 when publication was limited to three days a week.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
In the fall of 1918 the paper became a semi-weekly.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
On February 1, 1919, daily publication was resumed.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
After the war, the paper turned its attention to other matters, printing a green issue for St. Patrick’s Day in 1920, and on January 20, 1921, an editorial on the immoral behavior of Brown students and their dates, the "social buds," who came to Brown dances and checked their corsets with the hat-check attendant.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
The "Literary Supplement of the Brown Daily Herald," a twelve-page collection of poetry and short pieces of prose, priced at fifteen cents, made two appearances, in April and May of 1921, and then disappeared.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
For some reason, in December 1921, when the "Herald" was celebrating its thirtieth anniversary, the masthead began to include the words, "Founded in 1866, Daily since 1891."<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
Perhaps the "Herald," decided to adopt its rival, the "<a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a>," with which it had coexisted, as an antecedent, and to stretch its life back to 1866, when another "<a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a>," this one a rival of the "<a href="Brown Paper.html">Brown Paper</a>," appeared.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
On October 19, 1924, a newspaper appeared with the title, "Brown Daily Drivel," a single issue printed by students as a travesty on the "Brown Daily Herald."<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
In 1933 the Herald caused a considerable stir by launching an editorial campaign urging students at Brown and at other colleges to sign petitions pledging "not to bear arms except when the country is invaded."<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
When a destructive hurricane struck New England on September 21, 1938, during freshman week, eight upperclassmen who were on campus to greet the freshmen managed to get out by candlelight a mimeographed one-page edition of the "Herald," followed by a similar two-page issue the next day.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
During the second World War the "Brown Daily Herald" again suspended publication on January 12, 1943.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
From March 10 to August 13, 1943 the paper was published weekly and called the "Brown Herald."<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
From August 20, 1943 to October 5, 1945 the weekly "Brown Herald-Record" replaced the "Brown Herald" and the "<a href="Pembroke Record.html">Pembroke Record</a>," and during that time had a woman editor, Audrey Mishel ’44.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
In September 1947, when the "Herald" resumed daily publication, it published a magazine called "Midnight," a manual of sorts for the "Herald" staff.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
Its duration is not, however, as long as its numbering suggests, having been inadvertently extended on January 18, 1959, when the volume number abruptly changed from 68 to 88, an error on which all subsequent numbering has been based.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
The "Brown Daily Herald Supplement" was first published on September 28, 1959.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
The "Supplement" continued to be a weekly (although not always on the same day of the week) publication until 1963.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
The "Brown Herald Review," containing literary pieces, art, and book reviews, was published eight times during the academic year from October 1963 until January 1966.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
A hoax issue of the "Herald" which went wrong was that of December 6, 1965, with its oversized headline, "Pembrokers Get Apartments; Experiment Begins in Spring," and related stories.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
On March 27, 1964, a similar effort proclaiming "Pembroke No Longer ‘Coordinate’; <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> Makes Brown ‘Co-ed’" and "Keeney Selects Special Committee to Supervise ‘Herald’" had brought forth no more than a cheerful communication to the managing board from <a href="President.html">President</a> Keeney, probably because of the proximity to April Fool’s Day.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
In 1968 Beverly Hodgson ’70 was acclaimed by the press as "First Woman <a href="Editor.html">Editor</a> of <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> Daily" (and coincidentally later married the nephew of Audrey Mishel, the woman editor of the "Herald-Record" of <a href="World War II.html">World War II</a>), and with her managing editor, another woman, Laura Hersh ’70, got the "Herald" out from its new offices at 195 Angell Street.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
In 1973 the Brown Daily Herald Voluntary Publishing Association, which took in outside printing jobs as well as publishing the "Herald," was facing financial difficulties after purchasing typesetting equipment.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
Its first appearance was in the "Brown Daily Herald" of February 15, 1973.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
In February 1975 an editorial staff separate from that of the "Herald" took over the publication of "Fresh Fruit."<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
The "Herald," still in debt after a 1974 operating loss of $10,000, began an alumni subscription drive, filed claims against its creditors, and sought incorporation under the laws of Rhode Island.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
With the <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> issue of 1975 the Brown Daily Herald Voluntary Publishing Association became the Brown Daily Herald, Inc.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
In 1985 the "Herald" entered into a contract with the Undergraduate Council of Students, in which the UCS agreed to purchase 5,500 subscriptions at five dollars each for every member of the student body.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
A weekend insert called "good clean fun "" was added in 1986.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
In September 1989 a new supplement, intended to be monthly, appeared under the title, "In Depth."<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
On November 2, 1991, the "Brown Daily Herald" held a one-hundredth anniversary celebration, at which William Kovach was the keynote speaker.<cite><a href="BDH Brown Daily Herald.html">BDH Brown Daily Herald</a></cite>
The first such handbook was called "Student’s Hand-Book of Brown University" and was published by the Young Men’s Christian Association in 1888.<cite><a href="Bear Facts.html">Bear Facts</a></cite>
In 1891 additional information was included, such as banks, telegraph offices, and the location of over 200 fire alarm boxes in the city.<cite><a href="Bear Facts.html">Bear Facts</a></cite>
In 1892 Brown University buildings, points of interest in Providence, and a catalogue of the portraits in <a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a> were added.<cite><a href="Bear Facts.html">Bear Facts</a></cite>
The title was changed to "Hand-book of Brown University" in 1903 and by 1924 to "The <a href="Bear.html">Bear</a> Facts."<cite><a href="Bear Facts.html">Bear Facts</a></cite>
In 1960 "<a href="Bear.html">Bear</a> Facts" was a joint publication of the University Christian Association and the "<a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a>," in 1961 was published for the University Christian Association by <a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a> Publications, and was published by <a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a> Publications from 1962 until 1978, when it was taken over by the Office of the <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> of Freshmen.<cite><a href="Bear Facts.html">Bear Facts</a></cite>
Publication of a student handbook for women students by the Christian Association of the Women’s College began in 1901.<cite><a href="Bear Facts.html">Bear Facts</a></cite>
In 1933 it was published by the Freshman Council of <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a> and later by the <a href="Question Club.html">Question Club</a>.<cite><a href="Bear Facts.html">Bear Facts</a></cite>
The Bear, as the mascot of Brown University, had its beginning when Theodore Francis Green 1887, a member of the building committee for Rockefeller Hall, placed the head of a real Brown bear above the arch that was the central feature of the trophy room in time for the opening of the new student union in January 1904.<cite><a href="Bear.html">Bear</a></cite>
The only known earlier attempt to have a mascot had occurred in 1902, when the "Brown Daily Herald" carried this notice on October 24: "Isaac L. Goff, the real estate man, has presented to the student body a brown and white burro, to be used as a mascot at the Harvard game, Saturday.<cite><a href="Bear.html">Bear</a></cite>
In the fall of 1905 the celebration committee decided to have a mascot for the Brown-Dartmouth football game and appointed W. Douglas Swaffield ’06 to obtain a brown bear and to escort it to Springfield.<cite><a href="Bear.html">Bear</a></cite>
The five-foot-six bronze bear in the yard at <a href="Maddock Alumni Center.html">Maddock Alumni Center</a> is the work of sculptor Nicholas Swearer, son of <a href="President.html">President</a> Howard Swearer, from whom the statue was commissioned by the Class of 1949 as a parting recognition of the end of his administration.<cite><a href="Bear.html">Bear</a></cite>
The statue was dedicated on November 12, 1988.<cite><a href="Bear.html">Bear</a></cite>
George Wyllys Benedict (1872-1966), professor of English, was born in Burlington, Vermont, on January 12, 1872.<cite><a href="Benedict, George W..html">Benedict, George W.</a></cite>
George W. Benedict graduated in 1893 from the University of Vermont, where his maternal grandfather had been president and his paternal grandfather professor of natural sciences and acting president.<cite><a href="Benedict, George W..html">Benedict, George W.</a></cite>
George W. Benedict taught at Phillips Andover Academy, and in 1895-96 studied at the University of Freiburg with German philologists Kluge and Thurneysen.<cite><a href="Benedict, George W..html">Benedict, George W.</a></cite>
George W. Benedict received his master’s degree from Harvard in 1897 and his Ph.D., also from Harvard, in 1899, his dissertation being a study of Sir Kay, seneschal of King Arthur’s court.<cite><a href="Benedict, George W..html">Benedict, George W.</a></cite>
In 1899 George W. Benedict came to Brown as an instructor, advancing to assistant professor in 1901, associate professor in 1906, and full professor in 1923.<cite><a href="Benedict, George W..html">Benedict, George W.</a></cite>
George W. Benedict was an expert machinist, and in 1917 he worked for Builders Iron Foundry, which made marine engines for the Emergency Shipbuilding Corporation.<cite><a href="Benedict, George W..html">Benedict, George W.</a></cite>
Benedict retired in 1937 and died in Providence on February 7, 1966 at the age of 94.<cite><a href="Benedict, George W..html">Benedict, George W.</a></cite>
Albert Arnold Bennett (1888-1971), professor of mathematics, was born on June 2, 1888 in Yokohama, Japan, where his father, Albert A. Bennett 1872, was a missionary and president of the Baptist Theological Seminary.<cite><a href="Bennett, Albert A. ’10.html">Bennett, Albert A. ’10</a></cite>
Albert A. ’10 Bennett graduated from Brown in 1910 and earned his master of science degree in 1911.<cite><a href="Bennett, Albert A. ’10.html">Bennett, Albert A. ’10</a></cite>
Albert A. ’10 Bennett received his Ph.D. from Princeton in 1915, having spent a year at the mathematical center at Göttingen.<cite><a href="Bennett, Albert A. ’10.html">Bennett, Albert A. ’10</a></cite>
Albert A. ’10 Bennett taught at the University of Texas and Lehigh University, where he was head of the Mathematics Department, before coming back to Brown as professor of mathematics in 1927.<cite><a href="Bennett, Albert A. ’10.html">Bennett, Albert A. ’10</a></cite>
Albert A. ’10 Bennett retired from Brown, but continued teaching courses at Southern Illinois University, the University of Rhode Island, and Boston College, where he was teaching the week before his death in Providence on February 17, 1971 at the age of 83.<cite><a href="Bennett, Albert A. ’10.html">Bennett, Albert A. ’10</a></cite>
Samuel John Berard (1875-1971), professor of engineering, was born in 1875.<cite><a href="Berard, Samuel J..html">Berard, Samuel J.</a></cite>
Samuel J. Berard graduated with a bachelor of philosophy degree in 1908, and earned a Mechanical Engineering degree in 1910.<cite><a href="Berard, Samuel J..html">Berard, Samuel J.</a></cite>
Samuel J. Berard came to Brown as assistant professor of drawing and machine design in 1921, and was promoted to associate professor of engineering drawing in 1929.<cite><a href="Berard, Samuel J..html">Berard, Samuel J.</a></cite>
Samuel J. Berard retired in 1945.<cite><a href="Berard, Samuel J..html">Berard, Samuel J.</a></cite>
Samuel J. Berard died in Florida on November 21, 1971.<cite><a href="Berard, Samuel J..html">Berard, Samuel J.</a></cite>
The Bicentennial celebration began on March 2, 1964, with a formal convocation in <a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a> at noon, with John Nicholas Brown as the principal speaker, after which the American flag was lowered and hoisted again with the Bicentennial <a href="Flag.html">Flag</a> of the University flying below.<cite><a href="Bicentennial celebration.html">Bicentennial celebration</a></cite>
Then several University delegates traveled to East Greenwich, where the <a href="Charter.html">Charter</a> had been granted on March 2, 1764, to present a plaque to the Old Colony House in commemoration of this event.<cite><a href="Bicentennial celebration.html">Bicentennial celebration</a></cite>
The celebration of the bicentennial year included a variety of events between September 1964 and June 1965.<cite><a href="Bicentennial celebration.html">Bicentennial celebration</a></cite>
On Wednesday, September 2, 1964 the annual meeting of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> was held in the Colony House in Newport where the first <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> met for the first time on the first Wednesday in September 1764, when 24 of the original incorporators took the oath of office.<cite><a href="Bicentennial celebration.html">Bicentennial celebration</a></cite>
A commemorative plaque inscribed "In this building on September 5, 1764 was held the first meeting of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> of ’the College in the <a href="English.html">English</a> Colony of Rhode Island,’ now Brown University" was unveiled and installed in the Colony House.<cite><a href="Bicentennial celebration.html">Bicentennial celebration</a></cite>
The Bicentennial Medallion was presented at the Bicentennial Alumni <a href="Convocation.html">Convocation</a> on February 6, 1965 by <a href="President.html">President</a> Keeney to 24 illustrious graduates and <a href="President.html">President</a> Emeritus Henry M. Wriston.<cite><a href="Bicentennial medallion.html">Bicentennial medallion</a></cite>
Bruce Macmillan Bigelow (1903-1954), vice-president and director of admissions, was born in Norwood, Rhode Island, on August 27, 1903.<cite><a href="Bigelow, Bruce M..html">Bigelow, Bruce M.</a></cite>
After graduation from Brown in 1924, Bruce M. Bigelow became an assistant in the History Department.<cite><a href="Bigelow, Bruce M..html">Bigelow, Bruce M.</a></cite>
Bruce M. Bigelow was an instructor in history at M.I.T. from 1926 to 1928, and received his master’s degree from Harvard in 1927 and his Ph.D. from Brown in 1930.<cite><a href="Bigelow, Bruce M..html">Bigelow, Bruce M.</a></cite>
Bruce M. Bigelow was appointed instructor in history at Brown in 1930, assistant professor in 1935, associate professor in 1943, and professor in 1947.<cite><a href="Bigelow, Bruce M..html">Bigelow, Bruce M.</a></cite>
Bruce M. Bigelow became associate dean of the college in 1940, dean of students in 1943, and vice-president of the University in 1945.<cite><a href="Bigelow, Bruce M..html">Bigelow, Bruce M.</a></cite>
Bruce M. Bigelow also became acting director of admissions in 1931 and director of admissions the next year.<cite><a href="Bigelow, Bruce M..html">Bigelow, Bruce M.</a></cite>
Bruce M. Bigelow was largely responsible for the development of the "Identification and Criticism of Ideas" curriculum introduced in 1952.<cite><a href="Bigelow, Bruce M..html">Bigelow, Bruce M.</a></cite>
Bruce M. Bigelow's sudden death of a heart attack on December 27, 1954 shocked the University.<cite><a href="Bigelow, Bruce M..html">Bigelow, Bruce M.</a></cite>
Biology was part of the curriculum during the existence of the early medical school from 1811 to 1827, when undergraduates were admitted to the lectures in anatomy, chemistry, and botany.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
When the medical program ended and its professors departed, <a href="President.html">President</a> Francis Wayland, who had studied medicine, undertook to continue the courses by delivering lectures in natural history in 1828 and in anatomy and physiology in 1829-30.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
Chace, who had been teaching natural philosophy and chemistry, was sent to Philadelphia to attend lectures, and in 1836 was appointed professor of chemistry, physiology, and geology.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
Chace’s physiology course was described in the laws of 1850, "In the course in Physiology it will be the design of the Professor to teach the classifications of the animal and vegetable kingdom, the most important modifications of organized structure, and the laws to which animal and vegetable life is subjected, with special reference to the subjects of health and regimen."<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
Chace kept in touch with leading scientists and introduced Agassiz and Gould’s "Principles of Zoology" as a textbook for his course in 1849, the year after its publication.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
After 1850 he offered an advanced course for those "who may desire to pursue the science by the aid of the knife and microscope."<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
The physiology course was taught from 1863 to 1865 by Nathaniel P. Hill, who continued to deliver the lectures prepared by Chace.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
In 1865 Dr. Parsons began teaching the course, apparently by some informal arrangement at first, as he was formally appointed "Lecturer in Physiology" only in 1867, when Chace became acting president.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
Not receiving a permanent appointment, Parsons left in 1870, at which time the physiology course was simply added to the duties of the new professor of physics, Eli Whitney Blake.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
In 1875, under <a href="President.html">President</a> Robinson, a separate professorship of physiology was established and Parsons returned to that position.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
The appointments of John Whipple Potter Jenks as professor of agricultural zoology in 1874 in accordance with the requirements of the Morrill Act, of William Whitman Bailey as instructor in botany in 1877, and of Alpheus Spring Packard as professor of zoology and geology in 1878 made it possible for Parsons finally to devote his course to human anatomy and physiology.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
In 1882 Parsons resigned because of his health, and Charles V. Chapin was appointed in his place.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
Chapin’s course at first was taught in the junior year, but in 1885 was shortened to two hours per week and offered to sophomores, whose lack of preparation in chemistry and physics disturbed Chapin, as did the short time allotted.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
When Chapin was ill during the second term of 1884-85, Dr. George Frederic Keene 1875 took over the physiology course.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
In 1889 the course was restored to the junior year, and after Edmund B. Delabarre began to teach psychology in 1892, Chapin was able to drop the teaching of the nervous system.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
He was ill in 1892-93, and after his return the physical culture title was dropped.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
He continued to teach until 1895, but observed that the course, which had been intended as an elementary course in human anatomy and physiology was now elected chiefly by students intending to study medicine, and recommended that "the time has come to drop ‘Physiology,’ in the meaning that it has had in the past from the curriculum, and to strengthen the department of general biology."<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
Alpheus Spring Packard joined the department in 1878 and taught electives in zoology and geology.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
In 1882 a laboratory was set up in the basement of <a href="Rhode Island Hall.html">Rhode Island Hall</a>, a place which turned out to be cold and damp and was replaced three years later by a large and well lighted room upstairs in <a href="Rhode Island Hall.html">Rhode Island Hall</a> adjacent to the museum.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
The department was radically changed by the arrival in 1890 of Hermon Carey Bumpus as assistant professor of zoology.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
Bumpus’ teaching methods as described by Walter were quoted in "Hermon Carey Bumpus; Yankee Naturalist," by his son, Hermon Carey Bumpus, Jr. ’12: Frederic P. Gorham joined the department in 1893 and introduced the study of bacteriology.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
When Bumpus went abroad in 1893, George W. Field 1887, who had recently received his Ph.D. degree from Johns Hopkins, was appointed to take his place with the title of Associate Professor of Cellular Biology.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
In 1895 Albert Mead returned with his Ph.D. from the University of Chicago, and was appointed instructor in comparative anatomy.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
In the spring vacation of 1897 the steamer "John M. Long" was chartered to survey the waters of Narragansett Bay, and the students collected marine animals for the museum.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
The appointment of Bumpus in 1897 to the Rhode Island Inland Fish Commission and in 1898 as director of research of the Woods Hole station of the U. S. Fish Commission began an involvement of the Biology Department in the study of the protection of young lobsters.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
One of the graduate students, Ernest W. Barnes, was named assistant superintendent of the Wickford Laboratory in 1903 and became superintendent in 1906.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
In 1935 the Commission of Inland Fisheries was discontinued.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
The lobster hatchery suffered damage in the hurricanes of 1938 and 1944, and the work there was discontinued.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
Biology courses for women students were traditionally taught by a woman, beginning with Ada Wing, who was appointed instructor in 1896 and later named assistant professor of physiology and sanitary science.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
Miss Wing resigned in 1901 and married professor Albert D. Mead.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
Marion L. Shorey was instructor in physiology and household economics from 1904 to 1906, as was Alice W. Wilcox from 1906 to 1913.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
Florence H. Danielson, assistant in biology from 1909 to 1916, was followed by Helen B. Whiting from 1916 to 1919, and Helen F. Ordway from 1919 to 1921.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
Magel C. Wilder was instructor and later assistant professor from 1921 to 1947.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
Philip H. Mitchell joined the department as instructor in 1907 and taught until 1949.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
J. Walter Wilson ’18 began as an assistant in 1919, as did Charles Arthur Stuart ’19 in 1921.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
Stuart retired in 1960 and Wilson in 1966.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
<a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a> and graduate students worked during the summer at Woods Hole, where Professor Mitchell was research director of the Laboratory of the U.S. Bureau of Fisheries from 1917 to 1921, and at Cold Springs Harbor, where Professor Walter was assistant director of the Marine Biological Laboratory of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, later the Long Island Biological Association.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
A bequest of $50,000 established the Robert P. Brown Professorship in Biology in 1923, and Albert Davis Mead was its first incumbent.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
Dr. Wilfred Pickles, a physician, was part of the department from 1925 to 1944.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
Ivon Ray Taylor taught from 1927 to 1943, Arthur M. Banta from 1929 to 1945, and Paul B. Sawin from 1931 to 1947.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
In 1929 Dr. Herman C. Pitts of Providence asked for and received help from Professors Gorham and chemistry professor Charles A. Kraus in cancer research to study the uses of lead, radium and x-ray to combat tumors in mice with money collected from local individuals and a fund from Rhode Island Hospital.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
The department, which had a staff of three full professors, three assistant professors, and six assistants in 1945, began to expand in the following years with the addition of Frederick G. Sherman in 1946, Herman B.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
Chase, Mac V. Edds, William Montagna, and Paul B. Weisz, all in 1947, and Paul F. Fenton in 1949.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
Elizabeth H. Leduc, who came in 1945 as assistant, became an assistant professor in 1953, associate professor in 1957, and professor in 1964, the first woman full professor in a teaching position.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
In 1973 she was named <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> of the Division of Biological and Medical Sciences and Frank L. Day Professor of Biology.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
Walter J. Kenworthy joined the department in 1951, Richard J. Goss in 1952, Richard Ellis in 1956, George W. Hagy in 1957, and Seymour Lederberg in 1958.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
In 1915 the department moved out of <a href="Rhode Island Hall.html">Rhode Island Hall</a> into the new <a href="Arnold Laboratory.html">Arnold Laboratory</a> built especially for biology.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
In the late 1920s, when the space problem was again critical, the house at 91 Waterman Street was acquired, and was equipped with electricity and plumbing with funds which Dr. Herman C. Pitts had obtained to promote cancer research.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
With a grant from the National Cancer Institute the house at Brown and Waterman Street, a bequest of Dr. Herbert Partridge 1892, was converted into a laboratory named Partridge Hall.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
A new building, designed by Conrad Green ’36 of Robinson, Green and Beretta, to house the laboratories of Biochemistry, Physiology, Microbiology, and Plant Physiology, was opened in 1962 and named for J. Walter Wilson.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
In 1989 a one-million dollar grant was received from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute and assigned to such purposes as thematic biology courses, summer research by Brown undergraduates and minority students from other colleges, sabbatic leave programs for secondary-school teachers, student-faculty collaboration, and upgrading equipment.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
Chairmen of the department have been Frederic P. Gorham from 1928 to 1933, Philip Mitchell from 1933 to 1945, J. Walter Wilson from 1945 to 1960, Mac V. Edds from 1960 to 1963.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
The Division of Biological and Medical Sciences was formed in 1965 under the administration of an Executive Council chaired by Professor Paul F. Fenton.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
Professor Mac V. Edds, who had been chairman of the Division of Medical Science since 1963, became Director of Medicine and Professor Herman B.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
Dr. Pierre Galletti, M.D. was chairman of the division from 1968 to 1972.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
In 1972 Dr. Galletti was named University Vice <a href="President.html">President</a> (Biology and Medicine).<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
In 1973 Dr. Stanley Aronson, M.D. was named <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> of Medical Affairs, responsible for the development of the the six-year program leading to the Master of Medical Science degree.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
In 1977 Dr. Richard Goss, Ph.D. was named <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> of Biological Science, and Dr. David Greer, M.D. succeeded Dr. Aronson as <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> of Medicine.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
Dr. Frank G. Rothman succeeded Goss as <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> of Biology from 1984 until he was named <a href="Provost.html">Provost</a> of the University in 1990.<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
In 1992 the sections in Biology were: Artificial Organs, Biomaterials, and Cellular Technology (Patrick Aebisher, chair), Biochemistry (John Biggins, chair), Molecular and Biochemical Pharmacology (Edward Hawrot, chair), Molecular, Cell and Developmental Biology (Paul M. Knopf, chair), Neuroscience (Robert Patrick, chair), Physiology (Leon Goldstein, chair), and Population Biology, Morphology, and Genetics (Douglass Morse, chair).<cite><a href="Biology.html">Biology</a></cite>
The Bio-Medical Building was designed by Shepley Bulfinch, Richardson and Abbott, and built in 1969 to house a four-story medical research tower, a two-story teaching and laboratory area below ground level, and a five-story animal care facility.<cite><a href="Bio-Medical Building.html">Bio-Medical Building</a></cite>
The ceremonies of dedication of the building began on October 3, 1969, at a dinner at which the principal speaker was Isaac Asimov.<cite><a href="Bio-Medical Building.html">Bio-Medical Building</a></cite>
In 1982 the vacant space between the first floor of the building and the terrace was used for construction of the Center for Health Care Studies, an attached building housing a lecture hall for 120 persons, lounge and office areas, and facilities for three community health programs with headquarters at Brown, the National Hospice Study, the Southeastern New England Long Term Care <a href="Gerontology Center.html">Gerontology Center</a>, and the Institute for Rehabilitation and Restorative Care.<cite><a href="Bio-Medical Building.html">Bio-Medical Building</a></cite>
In 1990 the <a href="Grimshaw-Gudewicz Medical Building.html">Grimshaw-Gudewicz Medical Building</a> was added to the medical complex.<cite><a href="Bio-Medical Building.html">Bio-Medical Building</a></cite>
The program, which offers an undergraduate concentration in the ethical problems raised by recent advances in biology and medicine, was a result of informal meetings beginning about 1972 of a group of professors who met to exchange views on medical ethics.<cite><a href="Biomedical ethics.html">Biomedical ethics</a></cite>
A grant by the the Ittleson Family Foundation to the Division of Biological Medical Sciences in 1973 formalized the committee consisting of John Ladd and Dan W. Brock, professors of philosophy, Sidney Cobb, an epidemiologist and professor of community medicine and psychiatry, David Kass, psychiatrist, Robert P. Davis, professor of medical science, and Sumner B. Twiss, professor of religious studies.<cite><a href="Biomedical ethics.html">Biomedical ethics</a></cite>
The Bio-Medical Research Laboratory, built in 1964, is a four-story building connecting <a href="Arnold Laboratory.html">Arnold Laboratory</a> and the <a href="Metcalf Research Laboratory.html">Metcalf Research Laboratory</a>.<cite><a href="Bio-Medical Research Laboratory.html">Bio-Medical Research Laboratory</a></cite>
Eli Whitney Blake (1836-1895), professor of physics, was born in New Haven on April 20, 1836.<cite><a href="Blake, Eli Whitney.html">Blake, Eli Whitney</a></cite>
Eli Whitney Blake graduated from Yale in 1857, after having blown off the ends of two of his fingers in a chemical experiment.<cite><a href="Blake, Eli Whitney.html">Blake, Eli Whitney</a></cite>
Between 1866 and 1870 Eli Whitney Blake taught at the University of Vermont, Columbia, and Cornell.<cite><a href="Blake, Eli Whitney.html">Blake, Eli Whitney</a></cite>
In 1870 Eli Whitney Blake was named the first Hazard Professor of Physics at Brown.<cite><a href="Blake, Eli Whitney.html">Blake, Eli Whitney</a></cite>
William Ely 1879 assisted Blake in the laboratory.<cite><a href="Blake, Eli Whitney.html">Blake, Eli Whitney</a></cite>
James D. Earle 1879 and John J. Greene 1879 strung a wire between their rooms at opposite ends of Hope College in 1877 and were able to converse.<cite><a href="Blake, Eli Whitney.html">Blake, Eli Whitney</a></cite>
At about this time, Alexander Graham Bell had patented Eli Whitney Blake's telephone after submitting a crude model with his application on February 14, 1876.<cite><a href="Blake, Eli Whitney.html">Blake, Eli Whitney</a></cite>
In the late winter or early spring of 1877 at Rowland Hazard’s house at 45 Williams Street, where Professor Blake was living, there was a demonstration of the telephone by Blake with William Ely assisting.<cite><a href="Blake, Eli Whitney.html">Blake, Eli Whitney</a></cite>
Walter Lee Munro 1879 wrote this recollection of the event:<cite><a href="Blake, Eli Whitney.html">Blake, Eli Whitney</a></cite>
Ralph Mason Blake (1889-1950), professor of philosophy, was born in Greenfield, Massachusetts, on July 19, 1889.<cite><a href="Blake, Ralph M..html">Blake, Ralph M.</a></cite>
Ralph M. Blake graduated from Williams College in 1911 and earned A.M. and Ph.D. degrees at Harvard in 1912 and 1915.<cite><a href="Blake, Ralph M..html">Blake, Ralph M.</a></cite>
Ralph M. Blake was instructor in philosophy at Princeton from 1915 to 1917, acting professor at Wells College for one year, and was named assistant professor at the University of Washington in 1919.<cite><a href="Blake, Ralph M..html">Blake, Ralph M.</a></cite>
Ralph M. Blake was visiting professor at the University of Chicago in 1927, at Harvard in 1928, and at Columbia in 1941.<cite><a href="Blake, Ralph M..html">Blake, Ralph M.</a></cite>
Ralph M. Blake came to Brown as professor in 1930 and taught until his death in Providence on April 15, 1950.<cite><a href="Blake, Ralph M..html">Blake, Ralph M.</a></cite>
Ralph Leon Blanchard (1888-1960), professor of English, was born in Cumberland Center, Maine, on March 30, 1888.<cite><a href="Blanchard, Ralph L..html">Blanchard, Ralph L.</a></cite>
Ralph L. Blanchard graduated from Brown in 1915.<cite><a href="Blanchard, Ralph L..html">Blanchard, Ralph L.</a></cite>
In 1917 Ralph L. Blanchard enlisted in the army, served in France, and rose to the rank of captain in the field artillery.<cite><a href="Blanchard, Ralph L..html">Blanchard, Ralph L.</a></cite>
From 1919 to 1923 Ralph L. Blanchard lived in India as manager of a sisal hemp plantation and director of the Angus Company in Calcutta.<cite><a href="Blanchard, Ralph L..html">Blanchard, Ralph L.</a></cite>
Ralph L. Blanchard became instructor in English at Brown in 1930, assistant professor in 1937, and associate professor in 1947.<cite><a href="Blanchard, Ralph L..html">Blanchard, Ralph L.</a></cite>
In 1942, at the age of 54, Ralph L. Blanchard left for World War II service as a major in the chemical warfare corps, and served with the 101st Airborne Division in the Battle of the Bulge, earning seven battle stars.<cite><a href="Blanchard, Ralph L..html">Blanchard, Ralph L.</a></cite>
Ralph L. Blanchard returned to Brown, gained the rank of full professor and retired in 1957.<cite><a href="Blanchard, Ralph L..html">Blanchard, Ralph L.</a></cite>
Ralph L. Blanchard died in Bristol on January 24, 1960.<cite><a href="Blanchard, Ralph L..html">Blanchard, Ralph L.</a></cite>
Blistein House at 57 Waterman Street, was dedicated at <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a>, 1983, in honor of Professor of <a href="English.html">English</a> Elmer M. Blistein ’42, as a gift of Philip S. Hayes ’53.<cite><a href="Blistein House.html">Blistein House</a></cite>
The Boat House which first served the college crews suffered in a great gale in 1869 which carried away the wharf and float, after which the boat house was removed to a more convenient location on the east side of the Seekonk River.<cite><a href="Boat House.html">Boat House</a></cite>
In December 1870 several gentlemen of Providence purchased the Providence Skating Rink and donated the building to the University Boat Club.<cite><a href="Boat House.html">Boat House</a></cite>
"The Annual Illustrated Catalogue and Oarsman’s Manual" for 1871 described a boat house connected with the Brown University Boat Club as "located on the Seekonk River, at the foot of Angel (sic) Street.<cite><a href="Boat House.html">Boat House</a></cite>
On the evening of November 8, 1874 a disaster occurred.<cite><a href="Boat House.html">Boat House</a></cite>
Henry Lippitt 1878 was in charge of collecting money for a new boat house, which was built during the summer of 1875 by Peabody and Wilbur.<cite><a href="Boat House.html">Boat House</a></cite>
Interest in boating lapsed in the 1880s and it was many years before a boat house was needed again.<cite><a href="Boat House.html">Boat House</a></cite>
In 1937 a contribution of $10,000 by the Class of 1907 at its 30th reunion made possible the acquisition of the Narragansett Boat Club boat house on the Seekonk River.<cite><a href="Boat House.html">Boat House</a></cite>
The boat house was dedicated on May 7, 1938 at an Intercollegiate Dinghy Racing Association Regatta sponsored by the Brown Yacht Club.<cite><a href="Boat House.html">Boat House</a></cite>
<a href="Marston Boat House.html">Marston Boat House</a> was acquired in 1967, and the old boat house was condemned as unsafe in 1973.<cite><a href="Boat House.html">Boat House</a></cite>
It was destroyed on July 29, 1974, in a fire allegedly set by a twelve-year old boy.<cite><a href="Boat House.html">Boat House</a></cite>
Leighton Teeterick Bohl (1889-1971), professor of engineering, was born in Osceolo, Ohio, on July 23, 1889.<cite><a href="Bohl, Leighton T..html">Bohl, Leighton T.</a></cite>
Leighton T. Bohl received the degree of bachelor of science in civil engineering from Brown in 1913.<cite><a href="Bohl, Leighton T..html">Bohl, Leighton T.</a></cite>
After a few months with the American Locomotive Company, Leighton T. Bohl was instructor in civil engineering at Brown from 1913 to 1917, when he left to join the army.<cite><a href="Bohl, Leighton T..html">Bohl, Leighton T.</a></cite>
After several years of employment by engineering firms, Leighton T. Bohl returned to Brown in 1922 as assistant professor of civil engineering, becoming associate professor in 1924 and professor in 1929.<cite><a href="Bohl, Leighton T..html">Bohl, Leighton T.</a></cite>
In 1945 Leighton T. Bohl was head of a YMCA program to train returning veterans.<cite><a href="Bohl, Leighton T..html">Bohl, Leighton T.</a></cite>
In 1950 Leighton T. Bohl was a consultant for the city of Newport in the investigation of the construction of a seawall.<cite><a href="Bohl, Leighton T..html">Bohl, Leighton T.</a></cite>
Leighton T. Bohl retired in 1955.<cite><a href="Bohl, Leighton T..html">Bohl, Leighton T.</a></cite>
Leighton T. Bohl died on June 1, 1971 in Providence.<cite><a href="Bohl, Leighton T..html">Bohl, Leighton T.</a></cite>
James Robinson Boise (1815-1895), professor of Greek, was born in Blandford, Massachusetts, on January 27, 1815.<cite><a href="Boise, James R..html">Boise, James R.</a></cite>
James R. Boise studied at a school in Hamilton, New York, and entered Brown in 1835.<cite><a href="Boise, James R..html">Boise, James R.</a></cite>
James R. Boise spent the year 1837-38 teaching at the academy in Suffield, Connecticut, and graduated from Brown with the class of 1840.<cite><a href="Boise, James R..html">Boise, James R.</a></cite>
James R. Boise was a tutor at Brown for three years, then was adjunct professor of Greek from 1843 to 1845, and professor of the Greek language and literature from 1845 to 1850.<cite><a href="Boise, James R..html">Boise, James R.</a></cite>
In 1868 James R. Boise was appointed to the same post at the University of Chicago, and in 1877 he became professor of New Testament Interpretation at the Baptist Union Theological Seminary.<cite><a href="Boise, James R..html">Boise, James R.</a></cite>
James R. Boise retired in 1891 at the age of 76, and died in Chicago on February 9, 1895.<cite><a href="Boise, James R..html">Boise, James R.</a></cite>
Botany was taught at Brown in 1811 by Solomon Drowne 1773, professor of materia medica and botany, in the newly established medical lectures.<cite><a href="Botany.html">Botany</a></cite>
Park 1826 was one of those students, and recalled his experience:"I had a very pleasant acquaintance with Dr. Solomon Drowne, and attended one course of his lectures on Botany.<cite><a href="Botany.html">Botany</a></cite>
Drowne’s lectures ended when the medical lectures were discontinued in 1827.<cite><a href="Botany.html">Botany</a></cite>
In February 1877 the "<a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a>" announced, "Mr. W. W. Bailey of the class of ’64, has very kindly volunteered to give some lectures preparatory to the course in Field Botany ...<cite><a href="Botany.html">Botany</a></cite>
He also placed in the Museum an herbarium of 2000 mounted and labelled specimens.<cite><a href="Botany.html">Botany</a></cite>
In 1881 Bailey was appointed to the newly established professorship of natural history, including botany, which was made possible through $25,000 from the estate of Stephen Thayer Olney, whose bequest also included his herbarium, his microscopes, 712 botanical books, and a $10,000 fund of which the income would be used for the purchase of plants and books.<cite><a href="Botany.html">Botany</a></cite>
In November 1880 James Lawrence Bennett, a local botanist, donated his herbarium of about 13,000 specimens.<cite><a href="Botany.html">Botany</a></cite>
The herbaria were increased in 1883 by the purchase of the collection of James F. Robinson of Manchester, England, and the gift of the herbarium of W. W. Ayres of Wickford, Rhode Island.<cite><a href="Botany.html">Botany</a></cite>
An advanced course in botany for juniors was introduced in 1889-90.<cite><a href="Botany.html">Botany</a></cite>
In 1890 James L. Bennett was placed in charge of the herbaria.<cite><a href="Botany.html">Botany</a></cite>
The herbarium moved once again in December 1895, this time to the basement of <a href="Maxcy Hall.html">Maxcy Hall</a> where modern cases with 660 shelves had been provided.<cite><a href="Botany.html">Botany</a></cite>
Winthrop J. V. Osterhout 1893 was instructor in the department from 1893 to 1895, and Haven Metcalf 1896 from 1896 to 1899.<cite><a href="Botany.html">Botany</a></cite>
After Bennett’s departure, James Franklin Collins was curator of the herbarium from 1894 to 1911, and curator of the museum of economic botany in 1894-95.<cite><a href="Botany.html">Botany</a></cite>
He was instructor in botany from 1899 to 1905, and assistant professor until 1911.<cite><a href="Botany.html">Botany</a></cite>
Bailey retired in 1905, and Collins was replaced as assistant professor in 1911 by Harlan H. York, who had recently earned a Ph.D. degree at Johns Hopkins University, and had been an instructor in botany at the University of Texas from 1906 to 1909.<cite><a href="Botany.html">Botany</a></cite>
A greenhouse, 18 by 25 feet, was erected in 1912 in the rear of the house at 100 George Street.<cite><a href="Botany.html">Botany</a></cite>
The Bureau of Plant Industry of the United States Department of Agriculture installed a laboratory of forest pathology in <a href="Maxcy Hall.html">Maxcy Hall</a> in 1913 with J. Franklin Collins in charge.<cite><a href="Botany.html">Botany</a></cite>
In 1913 Collins also rejoined the faculty as demonstrator in botany.<cite><a href="Botany.html">Botany</a></cite>
York left for West Virginia, and Walter H. Snell ’13, who had been assistant in botany in 1915-16 and instructor in 1919-20, took his place.<cite><a href="Botany.html">Botany</a></cite>
The greenhouse was removed for the building of <a href="Littlefield Hall.html">Littlefield Hall</a> in 1925 and replaced by another one built to the east of <a href="Maxcy Hall.html">Maxcy Hall</a>.<cite><a href="Botany.html">Botany</a></cite>
A new greenhouse was acquired from government surplus in 1947.<cite><a href="Botany.html">Botany</a></cite>
George L. Church joined the department as instructor in 1928, became assistant professor in 1934, associate professor in 1946, and professor in 1951.<cite><a href="Botany.html">Botany</a></cite>
Professor Hubert J. Dyer came in 1950.<cite><a href="Botany.html">Botany</a></cite>
Professor Snell was named Stephen T. Olney Professor in 1942.<cite><a href="Botany.html">Botany</a></cite>
He retired in 1959, and Professor Church became chairman of the department in 1958.<cite><a href="Botany.html">Botany</a></cite>
In 1965 the Departments of Botany and <a href="Biology.html">Biology</a> and the Division of Medical Science were merged into the Division of Biological and Medical Sciences.<cite><a href="Botany.html">Botany</a></cite>
Leicester Bradner (1899-1989), professor of English, was born in New York City on January 14, 1899.<cite><a href="Bradner, Leicester.html">Bradner, Leicester</a></cite>
Leicester Bradner received his bachelor’s degree in 1920, his master’s in 1923, and his Ph.D. in 1926, all from Yale University.<cite><a href="Bradner, Leicester.html">Bradner, Leicester</a></cite>
Leicester Bradner taught at Los Alamos Ranch School in 1920-21 and at Union College in 1924-25, before coming to Brown as instructor in English in 1926.<cite><a href="Bradner, Leicester.html">Bradner, Leicester</a></cite>
Leicester Bradner was promoted to assistant professor in 1930, associate professor in 1934, and professor in 1945.<cite><a href="Bradner, Leicester.html">Bradner, Leicester</a></cite>
Leicester Bradner published "Musae Anglicanae: a History of Anglo-Latin Poetry" in 1940, and "Edmund Spenser and the Faerie Queen" in 1948.<cite><a href="Bradner, Leicester.html">Bradner, Leicester</a></cite>
With Professor C. Arthur Lynch Leicester Bradner edited "The Latin Epigrams of Thomas More," in 1953.<cite><a href="Bradner, Leicester.html">Bradner, Leicester</a></cite>
After his retirement in 1968, Leicester Bradner continued to work for Brown, donating one day a week to catalogue search projects in the Rockefeller Library.<cite><a href="Bradner, Leicester.html">Bradner, Leicester</a></cite>
When his work day happened to coincide with the Great Blizzard of 1978, Leicester Bradner found himself trapped in Providence, sleeping on the floor of the Holiday Inn until he was able to make his way through the East Side Tunnel to the home of Professor Andrew Sabol, and at the end of the week to return to his home in Wickford.<cite><a href="Bradner, Leicester.html">Bradner, Leicester</a></cite>
Leicester Bradner worked until the early 1980s, when his failing eyesight interfered.<cite><a href="Bradner, Leicester.html">Bradner, Leicester</a></cite>
Leicester Bradner died on April 11, 1989 in North Kingstown.<cite><a href="Bradner, Leicester.html">Bradner, Leicester</a></cite>
Carl Bridenbaugh (1903-1992), professor of history, was born in Philadelphia on August 10, 1903.<cite><a href="Bridenbaugh, Carl.html">Bridenbaugh, Carl</a></cite>
Carl Bridenbaugh graduated from Dartmouth in 1925, studied for two years at the University of Pennsylvania, and earned his A.M. degree in 1930 and his Ph.D. in 1936, both at Harvard.<cite><a href="Bridenbaugh, Carl.html">Bridenbaugh, Carl</a></cite>
Carl Bridenbaugh was a member of the faculty of M.I.T. from 1927 to 1938, and was a Francis Parkman Fellow at Harvard in 1929-30.<cite><a href="Bridenbaugh, Carl.html">Bridenbaugh, Carl</a></cite>
Carl Bridenbaugh came to Brown as associate professor of history in 1938.<cite><a href="Bridenbaugh, Carl.html">Bridenbaugh, Carl</a></cite>
That year Carl Bridenbaugh's book, "Cities in the Wilderness: The First Century of Urban Life in America: 1625-1742," was awarded the Justin Winsor prize by the American Historical Association for the best book by a young scholar on the history of the Americas.<cite><a href="Bridenbaugh, Carl.html">Bridenbaugh, Carl</a></cite>
Carl Bridenbaugh left Brown for naval service in 1942, and in in 1945 organized the Institute of Early American History and Culture in Williamsburg, Virginia, and became its first director.<cite><a href="Bridenbaugh, Carl.html">Bridenbaugh, Carl</a></cite>
From 1950 to 1962 Carl Bridenbaugh was the Margaret Byrne professor of American history at the University of California in Berkeley.<cite><a href="Bridenbaugh, Carl.html">Bridenbaugh, Carl</a></cite>
Carl Bridenbaugh was a State Department specialist on India in 1956, a fellow for the Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences in 1956-58, and a Guggenheim fellow in 1958 and 1962.<cite><a href="Bridenbaugh, Carl.html">Bridenbaugh, Carl</a></cite>
Carl Bridenbaugh returned to Brown as professor of history in 1962 and taught until his retirement.<cite><a href="Bridenbaugh, Carl.html">Bridenbaugh, Carl</a></cite>
Carl Bridenbaugh was the author of "Rebels and Gentlemen: Philadelphia in the Age of Franklin," published in 1942.<cite><a href="Bridenbaugh, Carl.html">Bridenbaugh, Carl</a></cite>
"Cities in Revolt: Urban Life in America, 1743-1776," in 1955, "Mitre and Sceptre: Transatlantic Faith, Ideas, Personalities, and Politics," in 1962, "Vexed and Troubled Englishmen, 1590-1642," in 1968, "Fat Mutton and Liberty of Conscience: Society in Rhode Island, 1636-1690," in 1974, "The Spirit of ’76: the Growth of American Patriotism before Independence," in 1975, "Jamestown, 1544-1699," in 1980, and "Early Americans," in 1981.<cite><a href="Bridenbaugh, Carl.html">Bridenbaugh, Carl</a></cite>
Carl Bridenbaugh was injured in an automobile accident in 1989, and resided at Hallworth House in Providence until his death on January 6, 1992.<cite><a href="Bridenbaugh, Carl.html">Bridenbaugh, Carl</a></cite>
Bridge-Prop is the title given to the sculpture on the College Green near <a href="Faunce House.html">Faunce House</a>, executed by Henry Moore and given to the University in 1974 by Mr. and Mrs. David Finn of New Rochelle, New York, the parents of three Brown students.<cite><a href="Bridge-Prop.html">Bridge-Prop</a></cite>
Moore visited the campus in May 1974 to view the sculpture and officiate at the opening of an exhibition in the <a href="List Art Building.html">List Art Building</a> of photographs which David Finn had taken of it.<cite><a href="Bridge-Prop.html">Bridge-Prop</a></cite>
Walter Cochrane Bronson (1862-1928), professor of English and author of "The History of Brown University, 1764-1914," was born in Roxbury, Massachusetts, on August 17, 1862.<cite><a href="Bronson, Walter C..html">Bronson, Walter C.</a></cite>
Walter C. Bronson's mother was the daughter of Jeremiah Chaplin 1799, the first president of Waterville (Colby) College.<cite><a href="Bronson, Walter C..html">Bronson, Walter C.</a></cite>
Walter C. Bronson postponed entering college because of illness and graduated from Brown in 1887.<cite><a href="Bronson, Walter C..html">Bronson, Walter C.</a></cite>
Walter C. Bronson studied at Harvard Divinity School the next year and did graduate work at Cornell from 1888 to 1890.<cite><a href="Bronson, Walter C..html">Bronson, Walter C.</a></cite>
Walter C. Bronson was appointed Fellow in English Literature at Cornell in 1889 and professor of English at DePauw University in 1890.<cite><a href="Bronson, Walter C..html">Bronson, Walter C.</a></cite>
Walter C. Bronson became associate professor of English literature at Brown in 1892, and full professor in 1895.<cite><a href="Bronson, Walter C..html">Bronson, Walter C.</a></cite>
Walter C. Bronson edited "Poems of William Collins" and volumes of English and American poetry and prose, and was the author of "A Short History of American Literature" in 1900, and "The History of Brown University, 1764-1914," written in the sesquicentennial year of the University.<cite><a href="Bronson, Walter C..html">Bronson, Walter C.</a></cite>
Bronson retired in 1927 and traveled to the south of France for his health.<cite><a href="Bronson, Walter C..html">Bronson, Walter C.</a></cite>
Walter C. Bronson died in Oxford, England, on June 2, 1928.<cite><a href="Bronson, Walter C..html">Bronson, Walter C.</a></cite>
The Brown <a href="Bear.html">Bear</a> Awards for notable alumni service were created in 1940 by the Brown Club of New York, which had the trophy designed and made awards for three years.<cite><a href="Brown Bear awards.html">Brown Bear awards</a></cite>
During <a href="World War II.html">World War II</a> no awards were made, and in 1946 the <a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a>, with the permission of the Brown Club took over the sponsorship of the award.<cite><a href="Brown Bear awards.html">Brown Bear awards</a></cite>
While the award came as a surprise to many recipients, that was especially so in 1962 because the recipients, who were the Alumni Secretary and the <a href="Editor.html">Editor</a> of the "Brown Alumni Monthly," usually privy to advance information about the awards, had been told that there would be none that year.<cite><a href="Brown Bear awards.html">Brown Bear awards</a></cite>
The first woman to receive a Brown <a href="Bear.html">Bear</a> Award was Doris Hopkins Stapelton ’28 in 1972.<cite><a href="Brown Bear awards.html">Brown Bear awards</a></cite>
The "Brown Bedel" appeared in December 1931, announcing its attempt "to be something, new, smart, and different in college magazines, an undergraduate review."<cite><a href="Brown Bedel.html">Brown Bedel</a></cite>
The second and last issue in March 1932 contained a suggestion that the University build a new house for each fraternity with the provision that the chapters pay off the debt or rent the houses.<cite><a href="Brown Bedel.html">Brown Bedel</a></cite>
Benjamin Williams Brown (1897-1955), professor of English and director of Sock and Buskin, born in Danielson, Connecticut, on December 1, 1897, was a direct descendant of Roger Williams.<cite><a href="Brown, Benjamin W..html">Brown, Benjamin W.</a></cite>
By the time he graduated from Brown in 1919, he had already begun his dramatic career, spending a summer with the Albee stock company and six weeks playing the Keith circuit.<cite><a href="Brown, Benjamin W..html">Brown, Benjamin W.</a></cite>
Benjamin W. Brown taught at Deerfield Academy in 1920-21.<cite><a href="Brown, Benjamin W..html">Brown, Benjamin W.</a></cite>
After earning his master of arts degree at Brown in 1921, he was appointed to teach drama, public speaking and playwriting.<cite><a href="Brown, Benjamin W..html">Brown, Benjamin W.</a></cite>
Benjamin W. Brown was promoted to assistant professor of English and public speaking in 1926 and associate professor in 1936.<cite><a href="Brown, Benjamin W..html">Brown, Benjamin W.</a></cite>
Benjamin W. Brown was named director of dramatic productions in 1939 and full professor in 1951.<cite><a href="Brown, Benjamin W..html">Brown, Benjamin W.</a></cite>
Benjamin W. Brown was interested in theatre in other countries, and studied in Touraine in 1925 and in Salzburg in 1927.<cite><a href="Brown, Benjamin W..html">Brown, Benjamin W.</a></cite>
After a visit to Russia Benjamin W. Brown wrote "Theatre at the Left," on the Russian theatre, in 1938.<cite><a href="Brown, Benjamin W..html">Brown, Benjamin W.</a></cite>
Benjamin W. Brown published "Upstage, Downstage," an instructional volume on play production, in 1947.<cite><a href="Brown, Benjamin W..html">Brown, Benjamin W.</a></cite>
When classes resumed in January 1955 after the Christmas recess, Ben Brown did not appear.<cite><a href="Brown, Benjamin W..html">Brown, Benjamin W.</a></cite>
Charles Wilson Brown (1874-1974), professor of geology, was born in what is now Overton, Nebraska, on August 11, 1874.<cite><a href="Brown, Charles Wilson.html">Brown, Charles Wilson</a></cite>
The family was driven back toward the East by grasshoppers and drought in 1883, and his father, the Reverend <a href="Wheaton, Henry.html">Henry Wheaton</a> Brown, served as a Methodist pastor in Wisconsin.<cite><a href="Brown, Charles Wilson.html">Brown, Charles Wilson</a></cite>
After another move to Sioux Falls, South Dakota in 1891, at the age of 17, Charles Wilson Brown went to work for an insurance, building and loan, and trust company where he learned stenography and bookkeeping.<cite><a href="Brown, Charles Wilson.html">Brown, Charles Wilson</a></cite>
Before the next move in 1895 Charles Wilson Brown had become assistant secretary-treasurer of the Sioux Falls Linen Mills.<cite><a href="Brown, Charles Wilson.html">Brown, Charles Wilson</a></cite>
In 1895, now settled in Stoughton, Massachusetts, Charles Wilson Brown went back to school at Wilbraham Academy.<cite><a href="Brown, Charles Wilson.html">Brown, Charles Wilson</a></cite>
He went to Boston University for a year, transferred to Brown in 1897, and received a bachelor of philosophy degree in 1900.<cite><a href="Brown, Charles Wilson.html">Brown, Charles Wilson</a></cite>
In January 1905 Professor Packard, who was ill, was planning to be on leave from Brown and asked that Charles Brown take over the work.<cite><a href="Brown, Charles Wilson.html">Brown, Charles Wilson</a></cite>
In September 1905, only five years after his graduation, Charles Brown was installed in the basement of Sayles Hall, in charge of the Geology Department, which had formerly been affiliated with zoology and other subjects.<cite><a href="Brown, Charles Wilson.html">Brown, Charles Wilson</a></cite>
Charles Wilson Brown learned to drive in 1906 and took many geological trips about the country, including a 22,000 mile excursion, much of it on gravel roads, during his 1921 sabbatical leave.<cite><a href="Brown, Charles Wilson.html">Brown, Charles Wilson</a></cite>
Charles Wilson Brown stopped in Hawaii in 1929 on his way to Tokyo to attend a World Power Conference and a World Engineering Congress.<cite><a href="Brown, Charles Wilson.html">Brown, Charles Wilson</a></cite>
