In 1968 he donated to the Boy Scouts a rescue boat which was named "Charlie Brown," and decorated with a likeness of the comic strip character of that name.<cite><a href="Brown, Charles Wilson.html">Brown, Charles Wilson</a></cite>
Charlie Brown died in Providence on August 11, 1974, just three weeks short of his one hundredth birthday.<cite><a href="Brown, Charles Wilson.html">Brown, Charles Wilson</a></cite>
The <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> created by the <a href="Charter.html">Charter</a> in 1764 consisted of two branches, the Trustees and the Fellows.<cite><a href="Brown Corporation.html">Brown Corporation</a></cite>
An Executive Board, composed of conservative members and entrusted with some of the functions which the <a href="Charter.html">Charter</a> had reserved for the Board of Fellows, was created in 1850.<cite><a href="Brown Corporation.html">Brown Corporation</a></cite>
In 1863 the University also created a committee of public lands to be responsible for the agricultural lands assigned to the University as a result of the Morrill Act in 1862.<cite><a href="Brown Corporation.html">Brown Corporation</a></cite>
The <a href="Charter.html">Charter</a> was amended in 1926 to add six trustees, to be chosen without regard to religious affiliation, bringing the number of trustees to 42.<cite><a href="Brown Corporation.html">Brown Corporation</a></cite>
In 1942 another amendment removed all denominational requirements for <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> members.<cite><a href="Brown Corporation.html">Brown Corporation</a></cite>
In 1927 Nettie Goodale Murdock ’95 and Magel Wilder ’19 addressed a letter to the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> suggesting that women should be represented.<cite><a href="Brown Corporation.html">Brown Corporation</a></cite>
The <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> replied on October 21, 1927 that "the time had not arrived for the election of a woman to membership."<cite><a href="Brown Corporation.html">Brown Corporation</a></cite>
At the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> meeting in June 1928 it was voted to add an alumna to the Executive Committee of the Women’s College.<cite><a href="Brown Corporation.html">Brown Corporation</a></cite>
The first woman member of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> was Anna Canada Swain ’11, who was chosen as a term trustee in 1949.<cite><a href="Brown Corporation.html">Brown Corporation</a></cite>
In 1965 for the first time a Pembroke alumna was nominated for a membership on the Board of Trustees under a new agreement between the <a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a> and the Pembroke <a href="Alumnae Association.html">Alumnae Association</a>.<cite><a href="Brown Corporation.html">Brown Corporation</a></cite>
The method of fulfilling this ratio after the initial four women were elected was the provision that after 1970 two alumni would be elected each year and one alumnae would be elected in four out of every five years.<cite><a href="Brown Corporation.html">Brown Corporation</a></cite>
The first elected alumna trustee was Elizabeth Goodale Kenyon ’39 in 1965.<cite><a href="Brown Corporation.html">Brown Corporation</a></cite>
Appointed to the Board of Fellows in 1969 were first woman member, Doris Brown Reed ’27, who had been a term trustee since 1963, the first African-American member, Jay Saunders Redding ’28, and the first Jewish member, Alfred Joslin H. ’35  Although the <a href="Charter.html">Charter</a> provided that a trustee or fellow may hold his office "during life or until resignation," the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> has chosen to impose some limitations on the length of terms.<cite><a href="Brown Corporation.html">Brown Corporation</a></cite>
Until 1981 the Fellows were elected for life.<cite><a href="Brown Corporation.html">Brown Corporation</a></cite>
Since 1981 they have been elected for eleven year terms and are eligible for reelection.<cite><a href="Brown Corporation.html">Brown Corporation</a></cite>
The Secretaries of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> have been Thomas Eyres from 1764 to 1776; Thomas Arnold 1771 from 1776 to 1780; David Howell from 1780 to 1806; Samuel Eddy 1787 from 1806 to 1829; Nathan Bourne Crocker from 1829 to 1837; Theron Metcalf 1805 from 1837 to 1843; William Giles Goddard 1812 from 1843 to 1846; Nathan Bourne Crocker from 1846 to 1853; John Kingsbury 1826 from 1853 to 1874; Samuel Lunt Caldwell from 1875 to 1889; Thomas D. Anderson 1874 from 1890 to 1924; Hermon Carey Bumpus 1884 from 1924 to 1937; Albert L. Scott 1900 from 1937 to 1945; Fred B. Perkins ’19 from 1945 to 1963; John Nicholas Brown from 1963 to 1972; Alfred H. Joslin ’35 from 1972 to 1982; Ruth Burt Ekstrom  ’53 from 1982 to 1988; and Henry D. Sharpe, Jr. ’45 since 1988.<cite><a href="Brown Corporation.html">Brown Corporation</a></cite>
As Moses Brown said in a letter to <a href="President.html">President</a> Wayland in 1833, discussing the relocation of the college from Warren to Providence, "Thou may see by this, our family had an interest in promoting the Institution now called Brown University, besides the purchase of the name by my worthy nephew Nicholas."<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
The founding father of the Brown family in America was Chad Brown, who came from England to Boston in 1638.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
This James, grandson of John who emigrated with his father in his youth, died in 1739, leaving five sons ranging in age from one to fifteen years.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
The oldest, James, died in 1750.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
William G. Roelker described other accomplishments of the Browns, "In 1773, also with the aid of a lottery, they built the Market House.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
In 1775-76, they had contracts with the Secret Committee to cast cannon at the Hope Furnace.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
From 1775 to 1796, John Brown was <a href="Treasurer.html">Treasurer</a> of the College.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
In 1783, he offered half of the sum for Philosophical Apparatus and the <a href="Library.html">Library</a>.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
In 1784, Joseph Brown was Professor of Experimental <a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a>.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
In 1786, John commenced building his ‘Red-Brick-Mansion-on-the-Hill.’ In 1787 he sent the first ship from Narragansett Bay to China, his General Washington.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
In 1790, Moses induced Samuel Slater to come to Rhode Island to start cotton manufacturing.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
In 1791, John and Moses founded the Providence Bank.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
In 1793 John built the Washington Bridge.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
In 1796, he proposed the canal to Worcester.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
In 1799, the Providence Insurance Company was founded, at the initiative of the Browns."<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
<a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a> were awarded to Joseph Brown in 1770 and to John Brown in 1773.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
A number of the Brown family attended the University, among them Nicholas Brown 1786, for whom the college was named in 1804, and his brother, Moses Brown 1790, who died in 1791.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
They were the sons of Nicholas Brown, 1729-1791, treasurer, builder and benefactor of the College.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
Two sons of Nicholas Brown 1786 attended, Nicholas Brown 1811, United States Consul in Italy from 1845 to 1853, and John Carter Brown 1816, donor of the funds for the library building which is now <a href="Robinson Hall.html">Robinson Hall</a>, and founder of the collection of Americana which constitutes the John Carter Brown <a href="Library.html">Library</a>.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
John Carter Brown 1816 had two sons, John Nicholas Brown 1885 and Harold Brown 1886, both of whom died in May 1900, leaving their estates to the three-month old John Nicholas Brown, Jr. Young John Nicholas led a secluded life as a child, partly because of his frailty, which may have been caused by growth.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
In December 1903 he participated in the laying of the cornerstone of the <a href="John Nicholas Brown Gate.html">John Nicholas Brown Gate</a> in memory of his father, John Nicholas Brown.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
In May 1904 he presented the keys of the John Carter <a href="Library.html">Library</a> to <a href="President.html">President</a> Faunce.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
He was walking with his nurse on the campus when the seniors of the Class of 1905 were posing for a group photograph, and the students placed him in front of <a href="President.html">President</a> Faunce for the photograph and made him an honorary member of the class.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
Later in life he attended their class reunions and posed again in 1955 with them.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
John Nicholas Brown went to Harvard, but continued his association with Brown as a Trustee from 1930 to 1935, when he became a Fellow, and as Secretary of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> from 1963 to 1971.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
Their second son, J. Carter Brown, former director of the National Gallery of <a href="Art.html">Art</a>, was awarded an honorary degree in 1970.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
Their daughter, Angela Brown Fischer, was a term trustee from 1975 to 1980.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
J. Carter Brown <a href="http://www.brown.edu/news/2001-02/01-157.html">died</a> in 2002.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
The campus buildings which are associated with the Brown family are <a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a>, which was built by Nicholas Brown and Company, <a href="Hope College.html">Hope College</a> and <a href="Manning Hall.html">Manning Hall</a>, which were given by Nicholas Brown 1786, <a href="Rhode Island Hall.html">Rhode Island Hall</a>, to which Nicholas Brown 1786 made a generous donation, <a href="Robinson Hall.html">Robinson Hall</a>, which was built as a library with a bequest from John Carter Brown 1816, the John Carter Brown <a href="Library.html">Library</a>, built with a bequest from John Nicholas Brown 1885 to house the collection begun by John Carter Brown 1816, <a href="Carrie Tower.html">Carrie Tower</a>, erected by Paul Bajnotti as a memorial to his wife, Carrie Mathilde Brown, daughter of Nicholas Brown 1811, and the <a href="Annmary Brown Memorial.html">Annmary Brown Memorial</a> erected by Rush C. Hawkins as a memorial to his wife, Annmary Brown Hawkins, also the daughter of Nicholas Brown 1811.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
The <a href="http://www.brown.edu/news/1987-95/93-168.html">Nightingale-Brown House</a>, a National Historic Landmark and home to five generations of the Brown family, was given to the University in 1995 as a museum and study center for scholars.<cite><a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a></cite>
Harcourt Brown (1900-1990), professor of French, was born in Toronto, Canada, on May 30, 1900.<cite><a href="Brown, Harcourt.html">Brown, Harcourt</a></cite>
Harcourt Brown received his B.A. degree in modern languages in 1925 and his M.A. degree in French in 1926, both from the University of Toronto.<cite><a href="Brown, Harcourt.html">Brown, Harcourt</a></cite>
Harcourt Brown taught at Queen’s College in Kingston, Ontario, and at Brooklyn College and the University of Rochester before earning his Ph.D. degree at Columbia in 1934.<cite><a href="Brown, Harcourt.html">Brown, Harcourt</a></cite>
He taught at Washington University from 1935 until 1937, when he came to Brown as professor of French language and literature.<cite><a href="Brown, Harcourt.html">Brown, Harcourt</a></cite>
Harcourt Brown became interested in the history of science, and his first book, written while he was at Columbia, was "Scientific Organizations in Seventeen-century France (1620-1680)."<cite><a href="Brown, Harcourt.html">Brown, Harcourt</a></cite>
Harcourt Brown became a member of the History of Science Society in 1934, and was its president in 1952.<cite><a href="Brown, Harcourt.html">Brown, Harcourt</a></cite>
In 1938 Harcourt Brown was awarded the Prix Moulin of the Academie des Sciences, Arts et Belles Lettres of Caen for his paper on French physician André Graindorge.<cite><a href="Brown, Harcourt.html">Brown, Harcourt</a></cite>
Harcourt Brown was one of the founders of the "Annals of Science," and served as associate editor from 1935 to 1974.<cite><a href="Brown, Harcourt.html">Brown, Harcourt</a></cite>
A collection of Harcourt Brown's papers, "Science and Human Comedy: Natural Philosophy in French Literature from Rabelais to Maupertuis" was published in 1976.<cite><a href="Brown, Harcourt.html">Brown, Harcourt</a></cite>
After retiring from teaching in 1969, Harcourt Brown returned to Canada, and died on November 17, 1990 in Winnipeg, Manitoba.<cite><a href="Brown, Harcourt.html">Brown, Harcourt</a></cite>
Brownies was an all-college society of the Women’s College founded in 1904 to promote college spirit and to foster the relationship between the undergraduates and the alumnae by social activities such as dances, stunts, and <a href="May Day.html">May Day</a> festivities.<cite><a href="Brownies.html">Brownies</a></cite>
In 1956, when Brown and Pembroke began to cooperate in social activities, the name of the society was changed to the Pembroke Social Organization.<cite><a href="Brownies.html">Brownies</a></cite>
It was initiated by Daniel H. Kulp ’13 in 1921 after he had spent six years at the College.<cite><a href="Brown-in-China.html">Brown-in-China</a></cite>
In 1921-22 Professor James Q. Dealey spent a semester teaching at Shanghai College, and in 1923-24 Professor Harold S. Bucklin spent a year there, while Kulp spent the year at Brown, teaching and studying.<cite><a href="Brown-in-China.html">Brown-in-China</a></cite>
Herbert D. Lamson ’24 joined the Brown-in-China effort in social work and teaching in Shanghai in 1926, but returned in the spring of 1927 because of unsettled conditions in China.<cite><a href="Brown-in-China.html">Brown-in-China</a></cite>
The "Brown Jug," Brown’s humor magazine, started its life in February 1920.<cite><a href="Brown Jug.html">Brown Jug</a></cite>
The cover proclaimed this the "Coming Out Number," and the masthead identified it as "Vintage of 1920 ... Jugful Number 1."<cite><a href="Brown Jug.html">Brown Jug</a></cite>
In the fall of 1933 it ceased publication.<cite><a href="Brown Jug.html">Brown Jug</a></cite>
In January 1967 there was a revival of the "Brown Jug" which continued into the fall of 1968.<cite><a href="Brown Jug.html">Brown Jug</a></cite>
The Brown Key was created in 1930 as a junior honorary society, replacing <a href="Pi Kappa.html">Pi Kappa</a>.<cite><a href="Brown Key.html">Brown Key</a></cite>
When first suggested and considered by <a href="Pi Kappa.html">Pi Kappa</a> in 1924, the proposed "Key Club" had been inspired by the formation of the Green Key of Dartmouth, the Red Key of Cornell, and the Purple Key of Williams College.<cite><a href="Brown Key.html">Brown Key</a></cite>
In 1930 "<a href="Bear Facts.html">Bear Facts</a>" announced, "Brown Key is a Junior honorary organization having for its purpose the entertainment of visiting athletic teams.<cite><a href="Brown Key.html">Brown Key</a></cite>
From 1938 to 1944 the members of the Key were elected by the sophomore class.<cite><a href="Brown Key.html">Brown Key</a></cite>
A new constitution in 1944 returned the right of election to the members and added to the duties of the Key the supervision of athletic rallies and the cheerleaders.<cite><a href="Brown Key.html">Brown Key</a></cite>
Once again in 1947 the sophomores were able to vote on Key members.<cite><a href="Brown Key.html">Brown Key</a></cite>
In 1949 the Key took on the care and feeding of the live bear cubs who performed as the college mascot, "Bruno."<cite><a href="Brown Key.html">Brown Key</a></cite>
In 1949 the Vigilance Committee came under the supervision of the Key.<cite><a href="Brown Key.html">Brown Key</a></cite>
In 1957 the Brown Key amended its constitution, changed its stated purpose from an honor society to a service organization, the members of which would be elected from a ballot of forty men chosen on the basis of interviews.<cite><a href="Brown Key.html">Brown Key</a></cite>
In 1953 the Eastern Intercollegiate Key Association was formed for the coordination of Key societies in over forty Eastern colleges and their mutual improvement through the sharing of ideas and policies.<cite><a href="Brown Key.html">Brown Key</a></cite>
In March 1958 Brown was host to the sixth annual conference of the Association, attended by representatives of twenty colleges.<cite><a href="Brown Key.html">Brown Key</a></cite>
In 1980 the Brown Key Society was described in "<a href="Bear Facts.html">Bear Facts</a>" as "A service oriented organization which is responsible for balloons and ushers at hockey games, sponsors a series of post football game parties, holds an annual Valentines’ dance, sponsors a faculty lecture series, assists the Alumni Relations office, organizes a Marathon on <a href="Spring Weekend.html">Spring Weekend</a>, and runs the bulletin board under Faunce Arch."<cite><a href="Brown Key.html">Brown Key</a></cite>
The "Brown Literary Quarterly" came out in December 1928, brought forth by the University Manuscript Club, formerly the <a href="English.html">English</a> Club, stating its purpose "to present to you four times during the college year the best that is written in verse and prose among the undergraduates, faculty and alumni of Brown University ...<cite><a href="Brown Literary Quarterly.html">Brown Literary Quarterly</a></cite>
The "Quarterly" was last published in May, 1930, when it was decided to enlarge it into a publication of statewide interest, which was named "<a href="Town and Gown.html">Town and Gown</a>."<cite><a href="Brown Literary Quarterly.html">Brown Literary Quarterly</a></cite>
The "Brown Magazine" first appeared in April 1890.<cite><a href="Brown Magazine.html">Brown Magazine</a></cite>
Henry R. Palmer 1890, <a href="Editor.html">Editor</a>-in-Chief, wrote of its purpose, "The BROWN MAGAZINE aims to be the exponent of the university’s best literary attainment and expression.<cite><a href="Brown Magazine.html">Brown Magazine</a></cite>
The March 1891 issue noted a tendency to criticize the magazine’s policy of "freely admitting the professors to its pages."<cite><a href="Brown Magazine.html">Brown Magazine</a></cite>
Also admitted to pages were the newly arrived women students, and in 1893-94 the name of Mary Emma Woolley 1894 appeared in the list of editors (although she was not included in their photograph).<cite><a href="Brown Magazine.html">Brown Magazine</a></cite>
Contributors who later pursued literary careers were editor Henry Robinson Palmer 1890, pageant writer William Chauncy Langdon 1892, editor and dramatist Albert Ellsworth Thomas 1894, professor and author Dallas Lore Sharp 1895, and newspaperman F. Severance Johnson 1899.<cite><a href="Brown Magazine.html">Brown Magazine</a></cite>
The "Brown Magazine" ceased publication with the issue of June 1898.<cite><a href="Brown Magazine.html">Brown Magazine</a></cite>
The Brown Medical Association (officially the Brown University Medical Association) was begun at a meeting held on November 9, 1811 by Dr. William Ingalls, professor in the recently established medical lectures, and six other doctors.<cite><a href="Brown Medical Association.html">Brown Medical Association</a></cite>
The minutes of the society continue until 1825, with a break between September 1816 and May 1823.<cite><a href="Brown Medical Association.html">Brown Medical Association</a></cite>
One hundred and fifty years later a different type of Brown Medical Association was formed in 1974 in connection with the new medical program.<cite><a href="Brown Medical Association.html">Brown Medical Association</a></cite>
At its annual banquet the Association presents its W. W. Keen award, named for Dr. William Williams Keen 1859, to an alumnus or faculty member for exceptional contributions to medicine, the community and Brown.<cite><a href="Brown Medical Association.html">Brown Medical Association</a></cite>
The Brown Office Building on Thayer Street opened in 1970.<cite><a href="Brown Office Building.html">Brown Office Building</a></cite>
The first "Brown Paper," which appeared in November 1857, was initiated by Zeta Psi as a college paper conducted by editors from the several secret societies, its object being "to furnish a list of the members of the secret societies, and to communicate information pertaining to them, and to the other public and social organizations existing in Brown University."<cite><a href="Brown Paper.html">Brown Paper</a></cite>
In 1860 and 1861 the title of the paper was the "<a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a>."<cite><a href="Brown Paper.html">Brown Paper</a></cite>
A rival paper, also called "<a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a>" and brought about by a split in the senior class election, was issued in 1866 in addition to the regularly published "Brown Paper."<cite><a href="Brown Paper.html">Brown Paper</a></cite>
In December 1865 the open Greek letter society Gamma Nu and other non-society students published the "<a href="Caduceus.html">Caduceus</a>," a paper similar to the "Brown Paper."<cite><a href="Brown Paper.html">Brown Paper</a></cite>
A second issue of the "<a href="Caduceus.html">Caduceus</a>" came out in December 1868.<cite><a href="Brown Paper.html">Brown Paper</a></cite>
By 1867 the "Brown Paper" had doubled in size, but the next year the appearance of a new magazine, the "<a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a>," provided literary articles and college news on a more frequent basis, and the "Brown Paper" reverted to its original size, and in December 1869 was superseded by the first yearbook, "<a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a>" of the Class of 1870.<cite><a href="Brown Paper.html">Brown Paper</a></cite>
The "Brown Review," subtitled "The Magazine of Brown University, formerly <a href="Brunonia.html">Brunonia</a>," first appeared in the fall of 1960, announcing that it would be published quarterly by the students of Brown University in cooperation with the <a href="English.html">English</a> Department and the Committee on Student Organizations.<cite><a href="Brown Review.html">Brown Review</a></cite>
There were four issues the first year, one the second, and two the third, after which the magazine was superseded by the "Brown Daily Herald Review," published by the "Herald" from October 1963 to January 1966.<cite><a href="Brown Review.html">Brown Review</a></cite>
A new "Brown Review," which superseded the "Brown Daily Herald Review" ran from April 1966 to the fall of 1966, and was superseded by the "<a href="Literary Magazine of Brown University.html">Literary Magazine of Brown University</a>."<cite><a href="Brown Review.html">Brown Review</a></cite>
Sharon Osborne Brown (1891-1965), professor of English, was born in Calais, Maine, on March 10, 1891.<cite><a href="Brown, Sharon.html">Brown, Sharon</a></cite>
He graduated from Brown in 1915, served as an assistant in the English Department for a year, then taught at Phillips Academy in Andover, at Oregon State College, and served in the army during World War I, before coming back to Brown in 1923 as assistant professor.<cite><a href="Brown, Sharon.html">Brown, Sharon</a></cite>
Sharon Brown published "Poetry of Our Times" and "Essays of Our Times" in 1928, and "The Engineer’s Manual of English" and "Present Tense" in 1941.<cite><a href="Brown, Sharon.html">Brown, Sharon</a></cite>
Sharon Brown was promoted to full professor in 1945 and retired in 1961.<cite><a href="Brown, Sharon.html">Brown, Sharon</a></cite>
The work was mostly his, although Sharon Brown turned it over to others in the last year before his death in Providence on December 17, 1965.<cite><a href="Brown, Sharon.html">Brown, Sharon</a></cite>
The "Brown Spectator" began publication in the spring of 1986, and announced in its first issue, "As an opinion journal, we shall make it our concern to devote our attention to issues of both national and campus concern, addressing issues others have ignored, while generating rational discussion where others have been silent.... Should some of the expressed viewpoints prove hateful to the Brown community’s majority opinion, we are reminded of the majority’s fallibility and the academic virtue of ideas held in contention.<cite><a href="Brown Spectator.html">Brown Spectator</a></cite>
The title, "Brown Spectator," was also used in 1984 by a two-page offering of student writing on brightly colored paper, which was the product of a Group Independent Study Project.<cite><a href="Brown Spectator.html">Brown Spectator</a></cite>
Brown Town was the name given to the temporary housing for veterans of <a href="World War II.html">World War II</a> which was erected in 1946 near <a href="Marvel Gymnasium.html">Marvel Gymnasium</a> on the city-owned Sessions Street playground at the corner of Elmgrove Avenue and Sessions Street.<cite><a href="Brown Town.html">Brown Town</a></cite>
Half of the apartment buildings were removed in 1950, and the rest were taken down in June 1951, when almost all the married veterans had finished their education.<cite><a href="Brown Town.html">Brown Town</a></cite>
The Brown Union was formed in 1903 to provide an organization to have charge of the new Rockefeller Hall, its object being "to further the social and religious life of the members of Brown University and to unite them in good fellowship."<cite><a href="Brown Union.html">Brown Union</a></cite>
"College Nights at the Union" were a feature which began in 1914 and set aside Tuesday evenings for speakers, concerts, dramatic readings and a social gathering sponsored by the Brown Union and the Brown Christian Association.<cite><a href="Brown Union.html">Brown Union</a></cite>
In 1904 the Union opened a dining room for regular boarders and a lunch room for general patronage in the charge of Arthur Jefferson (Jumbo).<cite><a href="Brown Union.html">Brown Union</a></cite>
In 1914 the dining room moved from the basement to a "large and airy apartment" on the first floor.<cite><a href="Brown Union.html">Brown Union</a></cite>
At some time the dining room reappeared in the basement where, in 1922, it was decorated by murals of early Rhode Island history by Percy F. Albee ’22 and Stacy Tolman.<cite><a href="Brown Union.html">Brown Union</a></cite>
In 1937 the student board was reorganized to consist of the chairmen of eight activity committees, which were the Camera Club Committee, the Dance Committee, the Movie Committee, the <a href="Music.html">Music</a> Committee, the Table <a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a> Committee, the Publicity Committee, the Billiard Committee, and the Bridge Committee.<cite><a href="Brown Union.html">Brown Union</a></cite>
Under a new constitution adopted in 1950 the board grew to include twenty chairmen of the various activities and forty active associate members.<cite><a href="Brown Union.html">Brown Union</a></cite>
The all male board of governors also changed, as "<a href="Bear Facts.html">Bear Facts</a>" announced in 1958 that membership on the board was limited to eight Brown men and two Pembrokers from each class.<cite><a href="Brown Union.html">Brown Union</a></cite>
A new Brown Student Union, formed in 1973 to coordinate extracurricular functions and provide student services, had among its responsibilities the Film Society, Lecture Board, Concert Agency, Cultural Activities Board, and Big Mother Coffee House.<cite><a href="Brown Union.html">Brown Union</a></cite>
The Brown University Glacier, named by Dora Keen in honor of her father, William Williams Keen 1859, is the main source of the Harvard Glacier which flows from the Chugach Mountains in Alaska into College Fjord at the northwest extremity of Prince William Sound.<cite><a href="Brown University Glacier.html">Brown University Glacier</a></cite>
Miss Keen, as leader of an expedition, started to make the first exploration of this glacier on August 21, 1914.<cite><a href="Brown University Glacier.html">Brown University Glacier</a></cite>
Another glacier was named for Brown in 1913.<cite><a href="Brown University Glacier.html">Brown University Glacier</a></cite>
"<a href="Brunonia.html">Brunonia</a>" planet is the name given in 1954, by Dr. S. Arend of the Royal Observatory in Belgium, to a planet originally discovered in 1948.<cite><a href="Brown University Glacier.html">Brown University Glacier</a></cite>
Its official designation is "1570 <a href="Brunonia.html">Brunonia</a> – 1948TX."<cite><a href="Brown University Glacier.html">Brown University Glacier</a></cite>
... Its astronomical history dates back to the transit of Venus in 1769, observed by Prof. Benjamin West.<cite><a href="Brown University Glacier.html">Brown University Glacier</a></cite>
On a research cruise to the South Pacific in December-January 1990-91, Brown geologists participated in the discovery of several underwater volcanoes, among them one they named the "Carberry Seamount," a very small seamount difficult to detect by ordinary means, a quality which Professor Donald Forsyth pointed out also applies to Josiah Carberry.<cite><a href="Brown University Glacier.html">Brown University Glacier</a></cite>
The Brown University Press dates from the publication of the first volumes of the "Brown University Studies" series in 1932.<cite><a href="Brown University Press.html">Brown University Press</a></cite>
David Jonah, Librarian of the University and one of a three-man committee to select works to be published, ran the Press out of his office from about 1957 to 1963, when a full-time staff became necessary.<cite><a href="Brown University Press.html">Brown University Press</a></cite>
The first Brown University Press "Catalog of Books in Print" in 1958 listed 33 titles, many in series, as "Brown University Studies," "Brown University Papers," and "Colver Lectures."<cite><a href="Brown University Press.html">Brown University Press</a></cite>
In June 1964 the Brown University Press was elected to full membership in the Association of American University Presses.<cite><a href="Brown University Press.html">Brown University Press</a></cite>
Under the direction of a Bicentennial Publication Committee, a series of volumes, "Bicentennial publications: Studies in the Field of General Scholarship," was published between 1962 and 1970.<cite><a href="Brown University Press.html">Brown University Press</a></cite>
One book which the Brown University Press did "not" publish was "Psychoceramics" by Josiah Carberry (Brown University Press, 1945), which was cited in an article by Nicholas Vanserg in "American Scientist" in June 1958.<cite><a href="Brown University Press.html">Brown University Press</a></cite>
In 1981 the Brown Press, having published only four books in the preceding five years and facing annual deficits, elected to merge with seven other university publishers in the University Press of New England, which had been founded ten years earlier at Dartmouth.<cite><a href="Brown University Press.html">Brown University Press</a></cite>

S.S. Brown Victory was an armed cargo ship, named for the University and commissioned February 23, 1945 at the Oregon Shipbuilding yards.<cite><a href="Brown Victory.html">Brown Victory</a></cite>
Naval Reserve Officers Training Corps in November 1940.<cite><a href="Brunavian.html">Brunavian</a></cite>
The first issue of the "new series" of a printed "Brunavian" with photographs in October 1943 announced that the magazine was designed to keep the men informed, to develop "esprit de corps" and to generally serve a "happy crew."<cite><a href="Brunavian.html">Brunavian</a></cite>
Publication continued until 1945.<cite><a href="Brunavian.html">Brunavian</a></cite>
In 1948/49 a mimeographed newspaper of the Naval ROTC Unit called "Fairway" was issued.<cite><a href="Brunavian.html">Brunavian</a></cite>
The next year the title of "Brunavian" was resumed, and as such it continued until 1953.<cite><a href="Brunavian.html">Brunavian</a></cite>
One more revival of the "Brunavian" was attempted and at least two issues appeared in November and December of 1955.<cite><a href="Brunavian.html">Brunavian</a></cite>
The first edition, which appeared in 1909 was a small brown suede covered volume.<cite><a href="Brun Mael.html">Brun Mael</a></cite>
Margaret B. Stillwell ’09 was the editor of the first "Brun Mael," which contained this little "Prologue," in script within a frame supported by winged cherubs: In the aftermath of the World War there was no "Brun Mael" published in 1919.<cite><a href="Brun Mael.html">Brun Mael</a></cite>
The photographs of the seniors grew from a little over an inch (accompanied by much text describing the student) to a whole new format in 1968, when large photographs depicted the individual graduates in poses of their choice, which were taken inside and outside, in sunshine and in shade, and occasionally in the rain.<cite><a href="Brun Mael.html">Brun Mael</a></cite>
The final "Brun Mael" in 1970 had a mirrored cover with the phrase "I FIND (ME printed in reverse) ONLY HERE ."<cite><a href="Brun Mael.html">Brun Mael</a></cite>
After the merger of <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a> with Brown University in 1971 the "<a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a>" was the yearbook for both men and women students.<cite><a href="Brun Mael.html">Brun Mael</a></cite>
"Brunonia," "a magazine published by the men and women students of Brown University and published with the cooperation of the <a href="English.html">English</a> department" began with a <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> issue in 1946.<cite><a href="Brunonia.html">Brunonia</a></cite>
The last issue of "Brunonia" came out in the spring of 1960, after which the magazine changed its name to "<a href="Brown Review.html">Brown Review</a>" and decided to devote itself entirely to literary areas, giving up pictorial and humorous endeavors.<cite><a href="Brunonia.html">Brunonia</a></cite>
The "Brunonian," the first student publication, appeared in July 1829.<cite><a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a></cite>
The "Literary Subaltern," noticing the "Brunonian" in its pages of July 17, 1829, said, "The work evinces talent, but it is evidently written by individuals who are unpracticed in the field of letters," and urged these writers not to become discouraged, but to practice their writing.<cite><a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a></cite>
It was a literary magazine, intended to be a monthly, but its appearances at longer intervals came to an end in March 1831 after only twelve issues.<cite><a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a></cite>
The "Brunonian" was revived in 1868, first as a quarterly, increasing to six numbers in 1870, appearing every third Saturday in 1874, and eventually becoming biweekly in 1879.<cite><a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a></cite>
In 1874 the "Brunonian," failing financially, changed its appearance.<cite><a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a></cite>
A volume entitled "Brown Verse," containing selections from verse published in the "Brunonian," was compiled and published by the Brunonian Board of 1893-94.<cite><a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a></cite>
The "Brunonian" merged with the "<a href="Brown Magazine.html">Brown Magazine</a>" in 1899, retaining the name "Brunonian," and was from that time a literary monthly, leaving news reporting to the "Brown Daily Herald," which had begun in 1891.<cite><a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a></cite>
In October 1914 the "Brunonian" tried to change its image by dropping the old departments and adding humor, art, and travel articles.<cite><a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a></cite>
The magazine died a natural death after its February 1918 issue, and its place was taken in February 1920 by the "<a href="Brown Jug.html">Brown Jug</a>."<cite><a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a></cite>
The title, "Brunonian," was used from time to time by other publications, including a rival publication to the "<a href="Brown Paper.html">Brown Paper</a>" in 1866, a publication of Delta Upsilon in the late 1930s, a publication of Alpha Delta Phi in 1963, and the only issue of "a university publication prepared for all Brown alumni in military service" in August 1944.<cite><a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a></cite>
Bryant College was for many years a neighbor of Brown University, its site being the present "East <a href="Campus.html">Campus</a>," which Brown purchased in 1969 when Bryant acquired a new campus in Smithfield on land given by Earl S. Tupper.<cite><a href="Bryant College.html">Bryant College</a></cite>
In 1949 when Bryant was reincorporated as a tax-exempt, non-profit institution, its charter included a provision that the college with all its assets was to be offered to Brown University on January 2, 1960 or on the death of its president, Henry Loeb Jacobs, should that occur earlier.<cite><a href="Bryant College.html">Bryant College</a></cite>
Desiring to perpetuate the college, which had then grown into an institution of 3000 students and thirteen buildings, he reincorporated it as an educational institution under the management of trustees with the expectation that after his death the opportunity would be tendered to Brown "to carry on and operate Bryant College of Business Administration as an integral part of Brown University with such courses of instruction and studies as Brown University may from time to time determine and under the same or similar name and in any event with the word ‘Bryant’ as part of such name."<cite><a href="Bryant College.html">Bryant College</a></cite>
In 1956 Brown declined the proposal when the Bryant trustees asked for its cancellation, now that Bryant’s conditions had improved as a non-profit institution and its faculty members were becoming worried about the rapidly approaching radical change in 1960.<cite><a href="Bryant College.html">Bryant College</a></cite>
Brown purchased Bryant’s East Side campus in 1969 for five million dollars, thereby adding over ten acres of land and 26 buildings adjacent to the Brown campus.<cite><a href="Bryant College.html">Bryant College</a></cite>
Bryant’s administration building at 154 Hope Street, which had been named Taft for its first owner Robert W. Taft, was renamed King House in 1974 in honor of Lida Shaw King, former dean of <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a>.<cite><a href="Bryant College.html">Bryant College</a></cite>
Kilcup Hall on Hope Street was built in 1961 as a classroom building.<cite><a href="Bryant College.html">Bryant College</a></cite>
In 1974 it became the Brown-Fox Point Day care center, a bilingual facility for children of Brown students and staff and other community families.<cite><a href="Bryant College.html">Bryant College</a></cite>
By 1972 the back section of the building had been removed and converted into a parking area.<cite><a href="Bryant College.html">Bryant College</a></cite>
Appleby Hall at 100 Charles Field kept its name until 1988 when it was renamed Barbour Hall for <a href="President.html">President</a> Clarence Barbour.<cite><a href="Bryant College.html">Bryant College</a></cite>
Gardner Hall, a dormitory built on Power Street in 1960, was renamed Perkins Hall in 1974 in honor of Judge Fred B. Perkins ’19.<cite><a href="Bryant College.html">Bryant College</a></cite>
Jacobs Hall on Young Orchard Avenue, built in 1956, was renamed Theodore Francis Green Hall in honor of Senator Green 1887 in 1974.<cite><a href="Bryant College.html">Bryant College</a></cite>
The Bryant dormitories on Young Orchard Avenue, Carroll Hall, Allen Hall, Salisbury Hall, and Stowell Hall were removed to make way for the new apartment-type dormitories in 1973.<cite><a href="Bryant College.html">Bryant College</a></cite>
The name, East <a href="Campus.html">Campus</a>, was made official in June 1971.<cite><a href="Bryant College.html">Bryant College</a></cite>
In their senior year Liman and Bartis conceived the idea of a nationwide association of college television stations, and in July 1988, with the assistance of Brown’s Development Office, they were able to receive a three-year grant of $300,000 from CBS to start the National Association of College Broadcasters with headquarters at Brown.<cite><a href="BTV.html">BTV</a></cite>
In November 1988 NCAB held its first national conference at Brown with Walter Cronkhite as keynote speaker.<cite><a href="BTV.html">BTV</a></cite>
Subsequent conferences have featured Ted Turner ’60, Morley Safer of "60 Minutes" and Robert Pittman of MTV in 1989.<cite><a href="BTV.html">BTV</a></cite>
Harold Stephen Bucklin (1886-1967), professor of political science and sociology, was born in Pawtucket, Rhode Island on November 4, 1886.<cite><a href="Bucklin, Harold S..html">Bucklin, Harold S.</a></cite>
Harold S. Bucklin graduated from Brown in 1910.<cite><a href="Bucklin, Harold S..html">Bucklin, Harold S.</a></cite>
While Harold S. Bucklin was an undergraduate, he was also principal of the Evening Grammar School in Pawtucket from 1908 to 1910.<cite><a href="Bucklin, Harold S..html">Bucklin, Harold S.</a></cite>
From 1910 to 1913 Harold S. Bucklin taught school in Ironwood, Michigan, after which he was resident and playground director at the Henry Street Settlement in New York while he was a graduate student at the New York School of Social Work, where he received a master of arts degree in 1915.<cite><a href="Bucklin, Harold S..html">Bucklin, Harold S.</a></cite>
Harold S. Bucklin came back to Brown as instructor in social science in 1915 and earned his Ph.D. degree in 1918.<cite><a href="Bucklin, Harold S..html">Bucklin, Harold S.</a></cite>
Harold S. Bucklin was named assistant professor in 1918, associate professor of social science in 1926.<cite><a href="Bucklin, Harold S..html">Bucklin, Harold S.</a></cite>
In 1923-24 in connection with the Brown-in-China program as professor of sociology at Shanghai College, Harold S. Bucklin directed a social settlement center and helped college students conduct a survey of a Chinese village.<cite><a href="Bucklin, Harold S..html">Bucklin, Harold S.</a></cite>
Harold S. Bucklin was involved with many of the social institutions in Rhode Island and served as chairman of the Americanization Commission in 1919 and member of the Children’s Law Commission in 1926 and of the Juvenile Court Commission in 1938.<cite><a href="Bucklin, Harold S..html">Bucklin, Harold S.</a></cite>
In 1922 Harold S. Bucklin published a series of articles surveying the institutions dealing with disadvantaged children.<cite><a href="Bucklin, Harold S..html">Bucklin, Harold S.</a></cite>
Harold S. Bucklin's title was changed to associate professor of sociology in 1929, and full professor in 1949.<cite><a href="Bucklin, Harold S..html">Bucklin, Harold S.</a></cite>
Harold S. Bucklin was chairman of Sociology within the Department of Political Science and Sociology in 1946, and from 1947 to 1948 chairman of the separate Department of Sociology.<cite><a href="Bucklin, Harold S..html">Bucklin, Harold S.</a></cite>
Harold S. Bucklin retired in 1951.<cite><a href="Bucklin, Harold S..html">Bucklin, Harold S.</a></cite>
Harold S. Bucklin died on September 29, 1967, while visiting his daughter in Elyria, Ohio.<cite><a href="Bucklin, Harold S..html">Bucklin, Harold S.</a></cite>
Hermon Carey Bumpus (1862-1943), professor of comparative anatomy at Brown and later Director of the American Museum of Natural History and President of Tufts College, was born in Buckfield, Maine, on May 5, 1862.<cite><a href="Bumpus, Hermon Carey.html">Bumpus, Hermon Carey</a></cite>
In 1866 the family moved to Massachusetts, and Bumpus attended a number of different schools as they moved around in the vicinity of Boston.<cite><a href="Bumpus, Hermon Carey.html">Bumpus, Hermon Carey</a></cite>
The principal’s daughter, however, took an interest in Hermon and tutored him in languages, so that he was able to enter Brown in 1879, probably assisted in his admission by Deacon Joseph C. Hartshorn, his father’s friend, who was also a member of the Brown Corporation.<cite><a href="Bumpus, Hermon Carey.html">Bumpus, Hermon Carey</a></cite>
Hermon Carey Bumpus spent the summer after his graduation in 1884 in Annisquam on Cape Ann, Massachusetts, studying at Alpheus Hyatt’s new biological laboratory there.<cite><a href="Bumpus, Hermon Carey.html">Bumpus, Hermon Carey</a></cite>
In 1886 Olivet College in Michigan established a department of biology and Bumpus was offered the professorship.<cite><a href="Bumpus, Hermon Carey.html">Bumpus, Hermon Carey</a></cite>
Hermon Carey Bumpus left in 1889.<cite><a href="Bumpus, Hermon Carey.html">Bumpus, Hermon Carey</a></cite>
Bumpus had also become involved with the Marine Biological Laboratory which had been opened at Woods Hole, Massachusetts in 1888 as a graduate institution where biologists could continue their research work during the summer.<cite><a href="Bumpus, Hermon Carey.html">Bumpus, Hermon Carey</a></cite>
In 1889 Bumpus started a summer training school there for students interested in becoming biologists.<cite><a href="Bumpus, Hermon Carey.html">Bumpus, Hermon Carey</a></cite>
In 1890 Bumpus came back to Brown, this time as assistant professor of zoology.<cite><a href="Bumpus, Hermon Carey.html">Bumpus, Hermon Carey</a></cite>
In 1892 Hermon Carey Bumpus was named professor of comparative anatomy.<cite><a href="Bumpus, Hermon Carey.html">Bumpus, Hermon Carey</a></cite>
Tristam Burges (1770-1853), professor of oratory and belles-lettres, was born in Rochester, Massachusetts, on February 26, 1770.<cite><a href="Burges, Tristam.html">Burges, Tristam</a></cite>
His father was a farmer who joined the revolutionary army in 1775, but was forced by illness to return home, where Tristam Burges turned his efforts to raising men and collecting clothing for the army.<cite><a href="Burges, Tristam.html">Burges, Tristam</a></cite>
In April 1791 at the age of twenty-one Tristam Burges entered the academy run by <a href="Williams, William.html">William Williams</a> 1769 in Wrentham, Massachusetts.<cite><a href="Burges, Tristam.html">Burges, Tristam</a></cite>
In September 1793 Burges arrived in Providence and was admitted "after patient examination" (in the words of his biographer, Henry L. Bowen) to Rhode Island College.<cite><a href="Burges, Tristam.html">Burges, Tristam</a></cite>
In 1798 Tristam Burges opened a "morning school" and a "day school" for young ladies in an "elegant and pleasantly situated room adjacent to and directly in front of Hacker’s Hall," on South Main Street.<cite><a href="Burges, Tristam.html">Burges, Tristam</a></cite>
His ticket won him two thousand dollars and opportunity to read law full time until Tristam Burges was admitted to the bar in Rhode Island in 1799 at the age of twenty-nine.<cite><a href="Burges, Tristam.html">Burges, Tristam</a></cite>
In 1811 Tristam Burges was elected a Representative from Providence to the General Assembly of Rhode Island.<cite><a href="Burges, Tristam.html">Burges, Tristam</a></cite>
In 1817 Tristam Burges was appointed Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Rhode Island, but was removed after one year when the democratic party came into power.<cite><a href="Burges, Tristam.html">Burges, Tristam</a></cite>
Tristam Burges was elected to the U.S. House of Representatives in 1825.<cite><a href="Burges, Tristam.html">Burges, Tristam</a></cite>
In 1815 Tristam Burges was named professor of oratory and belles letters at Brown.<cite><a href="Burges, Tristam.html">Burges, Tristam</a></cite>
Tristam Burges began a course of lectures in 1821.<cite><a href="Burges, Tristam.html">Burges, Tristam</a></cite>
In a letter to the Corporation in 1826, Tristam Burges explained and defended his method, "I commenced the instruction, by a course of Lectures on Rhetorick.<cite><a href="Burges, Tristam.html">Burges, Tristam</a></cite>
Tristam Burges had been a very popular member of the college, and the "Providence Journal" of September 30, 1830, commented on Wayland’s decision, "the public however entertained a different opinion.<cite><a href="Burges, Tristam.html">Burges, Tristam</a></cite>
Burges was also a prominent member and long-time president of the Federal Adelphi, and on the occasion of the society’s last literary exercises in 1831 delivered an eloquent address.<cite><a href="Burges, Tristam.html">Burges, Tristam</a></cite>
Tristam Burges was an unsuccessful Whig candidate for governor in 1836.<cite><a href="Burges, Tristam.html">Burges, Tristam</a></cite>
Tristam Burges died at Watchemoket Farm (now in East Providence) on October 13, 1853.<cite><a href="Burges, Tristam.html">Burges, Tristam</a></cite>
Millar Burrows (1889-1980), professor of Biblical literature, was born in Cincinnati on October 26, 1889.<cite><a href="Burrows, Millar.html">Burrows, Millar</a></cite>
Millar Burrows graduated from Cornell University in 1912.<cite><a href="Burrows, Millar.html">Burrows, Millar</a></cite>
Millar Burrows received his divinity degree from Union Theological Seminary in 1915 and the same year was ordained a minister in the Presbyterian Church.<cite><a href="Burrows, Millar.html">Burrows, Millar</a></cite>
Millar Burrows was a rural pastor in Texas until 1919, and taught at Tusculum College in Greenville, Tennessee.<cite><a href="Burrows, Millar.html">Burrows, Millar</a></cite>
Millar Burrows came to Brown as assistant professor of Biblical literature and history of religions after receiving his doctorate from Yale in 1925.<cite><a href="Burrows, Millar.html">Burrows, Millar</a></cite>
Promoted to professor, Millar Burrows served as department chairman before leaving in 1934 to become Winkley Professor of Biblical theology in the Yale Divinity School.<cite><a href="Burrows, Millar.html">Burrows, Millar</a></cite>
Millar Burrows was chairman of the Department of Near Eastern Languages and literatures at Yale Graduate School from 1950 until his retirement in 1958.<cite><a href="Burrows, Millar.html">Burrows, Millar</a></cite>
In 1931-32 Millar Burrows was on leave of absence from Brown to serve as director of the American School of Oriental Research in Jerusalem.<cite><a href="Burrows, Millar.html">Burrows, Millar</a></cite>
Millar Burrows was again director of the school in 1947-48, but was away on a trip to Baghdad when some ancient scrolls found in a cave were brought to the school.<cite><a href="Burrows, Millar.html">Burrows, Millar</a></cite>
On his return Millar Burrows was shown the manuscripts, which came to be known as the Dead Sea Scrolls, and, after that devoted himself to the study of the scrolls, on which he became an authority, publishing "The Dead Sea Scrolls" in 1955, and "More Light on the Dead Sea Scrolls" in 1958.<cite><a href="Burrows, Millar.html">Burrows, Millar</a></cite>
When Burrows visited Brown in 1956 to lecture on the Dead Sea Scrolls, his lecture was so popular that it had to be rescheduled from Lower Manning to Upper Manning and finally to a very crowded Sayles Hall.<cite><a href="Burrows, Millar.html">Burrows, Millar</a></cite>
Millar Burrows received an honorary degree from Brown in 1961.<cite><a href="Burrows, Millar.html">Burrows, Millar</a></cite>
Millar Burrows died in 1980.<cite><a href="Burrows, Millar.html">Burrows, Millar</a></cite>
The Cabinet at 68 Waterman Street, presently the home of the Graphic Services department, is a two-story stucco Greek revival building designed by James C. Bucklin and built in 1844 as the "Cabinet" of the Rhode Island Historical Society, the name of which is carved in stone above the entrance.<cite><a href="Cabinet.html">Cabinet</a></cite>
A three-story addition, of which Stone and Carpenter were the architects, was built in 1891.<cite><a href="Cabinet.html">Cabinet</a></cite>
Brown acquired the building in 1942, and used it for the newly established Program of Advanced Instruction and Research in Mechanics, which later became the Division of Applied <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a>.<cite><a href="Cabinet.html">Cabinet</a></cite>
The building was used in 1947 for the Stenographic Bureau and the inventory and purchasing departments.<cite><a href="Cabinet.html">Cabinet</a></cite>
The Photo Lab moved in in 1975.<cite><a href="Cabinet.html">Cabinet</a></cite>
It was first published in December 1865 as an alternative to the "<a href="Brown Paper.html">Brown Paper</a>," which was the annual publication of the secret societies.<cite><a href="Caduceus.html">Caduceus</a></cite>
After a lapse of three years, another issue of the "Caduceus" appeared in December 1868.<cite><a href="Caduceus.html">Caduceus</a></cite>
In 1870 the "Caduceus" appeared in magazine form with a literary department added.<cite><a href="Caduceus.html">Caduceus</a></cite>
The issue of 1871 and the final issue in 1872 were published by Delta Upsilon and Wayland Literary Societies.<cite><a href="Caduceus.html">Caduceus</a></cite>
The Caesar Augustus statue, the gift of Moses Brown Ives Goddard 1854, was unveiled on the opening day of the college year, September 19, 1906.<cite><a href="Caesar Augustus.html">Caesar Augustus</a></cite>
In September 1952 the statue was removed to a new home in front of the <a href="Sharpe Refectory.html">Sharpe Refectory</a>, and there Caesar Augustus still stands, unfortunately having been relieved of his right arm, which had already been replaced after being broken off during the hurricane of 1938.<cite><a href="Caesar Augustus.html">Caesar Augustus</a></cite>
The Calendar of the college year was described in the early laws in 1783 in terms of the three vacations which were scheduled from September 6 to October 20, from December 24 to January 10, and from April 21 to June 1.<cite><a href="Calendar.html">Calendar</a></cite>
The Laws of 1803 changed the dates of vacation to allow four weeks after <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a>, which occurred the first Wednesday in September, six weeks beginning the last Wednesday in December, and three weeks beginning the first Wednesday in May.<cite><a href="Calendar.html">Calendar</a></cite>
In 1807, in order to provide students with more time in the winter when they might earn money teaching in the district schools, the winter vacation was lengthened to eight weeks and the spring vacation was shortened to two weeks and began the third Wednesday of May.<cite><a href="Calendar.html">Calendar</a></cite>
<a href="President.html">President</a> Wayland shortened the winter vacation to six weeks in 1827.<cite><a href="Calendar.html">Calendar</a></cite>
1832-33 was the last year that there was a vacation after <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a>.<cite><a href="Calendar.html">Calendar</a></cite>
The Laws of 1850, which introduced the "new system," called for two terms instead of three.<cite><a href="Calendar.html">Calendar</a></cite>
In 1853 the date of <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> was changed back to September by popular demand, but the two term calendar remained the same.<cite><a href="Calendar.html">Calendar</a></cite>
After <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> was moved to the last Wednesday in June in 1870, the calendar was changed in 1871 so that the first semester ended in mid-January and the second began on February 9 after a three week recess, ending just before <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a>.<cite><a href="Calendar.html">Calendar</a></cite>
In 1875 <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> was changed to the third Wednesday in June, and another change in the calendar took place.<cite><a href="Calendar.html">Calendar</a></cite>
In 1891-92 the two semester year was replaced by three terms, beginning in early September, late December, and late March.<cite><a href="Calendar.html">Calendar</a></cite>
In September 1911 there was a return to the two-term system, in which the first semester ended in February.<cite><a href="Calendar.html">Calendar</a></cite>
In 1919 there was a summer session to enable students whose work was interrupted by the war to make up time.<cite><a href="Calendar.html">Calendar</a></cite>
Year-round operation began in 1942 with a summer semester added as the University pursued an accelerated program adapted to the education of members of the armed services during the Second World War.<cite><a href="Calendar.html">Calendar</a></cite>
The three-semester year ended in June 1947.<cite><a href="Calendar.html">Calendar</a></cite>
In 1948 two summer sessions with an enrollment of 964 in the first and 837 in the second were held to alleviate problems of crowded laboratories during the year and the desire of the veterans to make up for lost time in completing their education.<cite><a href="Calendar.html">Calendar</a></cite>
In November of 1981 the <a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a> voted to change the calendar beginning with the 1983-84 academic year.<cite><a href="Calendar.html">Calendar</a></cite>
Previous proposals had been defeated in 1974 and 1977, but polls had shown the a majority of the students wanted to have first-semester examinations scheduled before Christmas.<cite><a href="Calendar.html">Calendar</a></cite>
In 1984 the Office of Summer Studies was established under Professor Reginald Archambault.<cite><a href="Calendar.html">Calendar</a></cite>
The Cammarian Club was organized in 1893 as a senior society.<cite><a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a></cite>
The club was self-perpetuating and the first public notice of an election of members was in 1897 when fifteen juniors were "tapped" as they left chapel to signify their selection as members of the next year’s club.<cite><a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a></cite>
In 1899 the Cammarian Club came to the rescue in mediating the altercation which resulted after the local firemen arrived at a bonfire after the Princeton baseball game and had their hose destroyed by the students.<cite><a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a></cite>
A Cammarian Club alumni group met in Boston in 1901, and had further meetings in New York and Providence.<cite><a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a></cite>
In 1907 the club, in an effort to strengthen class spirit, decreed that freshmen would wear brown caps from the opening of college until May 30.<cite><a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a></cite>
In 1909 it passed rules to protect the site of the freshman banquet from damage by the sophomores.<cite><a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a></cite>
The Cammarian Club also took on fraternity rushing, and recommended a delayed rushing season to give the freshmen and the fraternities more time to become acquainted, and in 1915 established an Interfraternity Governing Board for enforcing regulations.<cite><a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a></cite>
In 1910 the Cammarian Club announced that it would no longer be self-perpetuating, and that members would each year be elected by students in the three upper classes from nominations by the previous club.<cite><a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a></cite>
The 1915 Club, the first chosen by popular election, amended the Constitution to provide for the election of its members by the three upper classes, established a blanket tax to support athletics, publications, and debating, and limited the offices one person could hold.<cite><a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a></cite>
<a href="World War I.html">World War I</a> reduced the Cammarian Club of 1918 to five members.<cite><a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a></cite>
In 1920 the Club established "Druids," a forerunner of the Vigilance Committee, to instill college spirit, but discontinued this group for failure to do so.<cite><a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a></cite>
In 1921 the Club adopted a special hat by which members could be identified.<cite><a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a></cite>
First worn on October 20, 1921, it was a regulation white ‘varsity hat with a one-inch brown silk corded band with a narrow white stripe through the center.<cite><a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a></cite>
In the 1930s a new style of hat sported a red lobster as decoration.<cite><a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a></cite>
<a href="President.html">President</a> Faunce lauded the Cammarian Club in his annual report for 1925, "We are fortunate in having every year in the Cammarian Club men of good character and high standing who may be safely trusted by <a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a> and by students to deal wisely with the many phases of college life in which both are concerned.<cite><a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a></cite>
In 1931 there was another change in the method of electing new members at the urging of the "Brown Daily Herald."<cite><a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a></cite>
The 1931 Club abolished class officers and replaced them with class marshals.<cite><a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a></cite>
By 1937-38, the office of senior marshal was abolished and replaced with the usual class officers.<cite><a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a></cite>
In 1949-50 the Cammarian Club ceased to be a senior society and was composed of 26 representatives of all of the undergraduate classes.<cite><a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a></cite>
In 1968 members were elected from both Brown and <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a>.<cite><a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a></cite>
In 1971 the Cammarian Club, recognizing that its role as intermediary between the students and the administration was no longer necessary now that students were allowed to sit on various University committees, voted itself out of existence.<cite><a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a></cite>
The Campus first occupied in 1770 was an eight-acre piece of land, composed of two adjacent lots, one purchased from John and Moses Brown and the other from Oliver Bowen.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
College Street was laid out in 1772.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
In 1771 <a href="President.html">President</a> James Manning purchased a plot of land for his garden, which extended in back of the northerly of the two original lots to what is now Hope Street.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
The land first occupied by Manning’s garden passed through several hands before being acquired by the University in 1854.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
The next addition to the campus was the lot of land acquired for the building of <a href="Hope College.html">Hope College</a> in 1822.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
In 1803 a row of Lombardy poplars were planted by Ezekiel Robbins between the College edifice and the president’s house.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
In 1840, after the building of <a href="Rhode Island Hall.html">Rhode Island Hall</a>, gravel walks were laid out and the poplars were removed and replaced by elms.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
The campus in the 1870s is well described in "The Old Back Campus at Brown" by Walter Lee Munro 1879.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
The "back campus" of that time became the Middle Campus (renamed in 1947 the "College Green") and was described by Munro:  "Sprague Hall," referred to above, was the privy, named, it has been said, for Governor William Sprague of Rhode Island, possibly because of unfulfilled hopes that he would present a building to the University.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
Located at the rear of <a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a> toward <a href="Slater Hall.html">Slater Hall</a>, the privy was in the late 1960s the object of an anthropological dig by some of Professor James F. Deetz’s students, who found bits of eighteenth-century pottery there.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
The lower campus, transformed through the efforts of Professor Samuel Stillman Greene from swamp to ball field in the spring of 1880 and named <a href="Lincoln Field.html">Lincoln Field</a>, was the site of athletic events until the advent of <a href="Andrews Field.html">Andrews Field</a> in 1899.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
The old South well was abandoned in the summer of 1880, and the pump which was near the old president’s house on the front campus was removed.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
In 1915 a crop of buckwheat was raised on the middle campus and plowed in to benefit both the trees and the lawn about to be seeded there.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
In 1913 about 225 feet of tunnel, six feet high, was constructed to connect almost all the buildings.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
Around the turn of the century it was decided that there should be a plan for the future development of the campus, and in 1901 architect Frederick Law Olmsted made a survey of <a href="Lincoln Field.html">Lincoln Field</a> and prepared plans for its grading and the locations of future buildings.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
In 1920 <a href="President.html">President</a> Faunce affirmed the University’s decision that buildings should conform to the Colonial or Georgian architecture, "which not only reminds us of the age in which the University was founded, but is far better than the Gothic to give the generous lighting needed in modern libraries and laboratories."<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
General plans for the expansion of the University were prepared by Paul Cret in 1922, and the East Side Development Company was organized to purchase property to the south of the campus, where the <a href="Wriston Quadrangle.html">Wriston Quadrangle</a> was later situated.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
With an eye to expansion the University began to add to its real estate holdings in the 1920s, acquiring in 1922-23 the Coats estate at 13 Brown Street, the Pearce lot at the corner of Brook and Manning Streets, estates at 201 and 205 Bowen Street, two lots on Cushing Street which Stephen O. Metcalf presented to the Women’s College, and the block bounded by Brook, Williams, Power and Thayer Streets, which was to be used for tennis courts.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
In the spectacular hurricane of September 21, 1938, when downtown Providence was flooded, Brown, with four hundred freshmen on campus for Freshman Week, suffered only minor damage.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
At about the time of the renovation of <a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a> in 1940, <a href="President.html">President</a> Wriston approached Mary Elizabeth Sharpe, whose beautifully landscaped home at 84 Prospect Street (now <a href="Rochambeau House.html">Rochambeau House</a>) he admired, and asked her help with new planting plans.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
The building of the two quadrangles in the 1950s, a number of sizable buildings in the 1960s and early 70s, and the expansion of the campus beyond Hope Street with the purchase of the <a href="Bryant College.html">Bryant College</a> campus in 1969, caused aesthetic concern and resentment among local residents, particularly the Providence Preservation Society, which had been monitoring Brown’s encroachment of the the historic East Side since the building of the quadrangles.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
A landmark disappeared from the Brown campus in the fall of 1969 when the house once occupied by Howard Phillips Lovecraft, writer of weird tales, at 66 College Street was moved to 65 Prospect Street.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
A master plan setting guidelines for ten years of growth of the physical plant of the University was drawn up by Sasaki, Walker and Associates, Inc. in 1963.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
In a five-year plan written by the Office of Institutional Research in 1974, the University affirmed its intention of non-expansion of land area and its policy of intensifying usage of already acquired property.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
The elms on the campus, which had given to the <a href="Class Day.html">Class Day</a> exercises the name of "Under the Elms," were stricken by Dutch Elm disease about 1970.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
On the east side of <a href="Carrie Tower.html">Carrie Tower</a> two stone benches, the gift of the Class of 1924, flank the brick walk to the door of the tower.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
At its class reunion in 1981 the Class of 1926 dedicated its class memorial, a spot in back of <a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a> with redwood benches among the trees and shrubs which surround a bronze plaque inscribed, "The Happiest Moments of Life’s Fleeting Hours ... Class of 1926."<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
The walks on either side of <a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a> were named the "Swearer Walkways" at a surprise gathering on the Middle Campus on November 9, 1988, to which an unsuspecting <a href="President.html">President</a> Howard Swearer, soon to leave Brown, and his wife, Janet, were led by the Brown <a href="Bear.html">Bear</a> and a portion of the Brown Band.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
In the spring of 1990 there were added stone benches flanking the walkway and inscribed "Sede, viator, et recreare, dum recordaris Swearers, Howard and Jan." The Manning Walk, which joins the Geo-Chem building with the CIT building and the Sciences <a href="Library.html">Library</a>, was laid out in the spring of 1990.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
The Pembroke Campus began with the acquisition in 1895 of land on Meeting Street from the estate of John Wilson Smith.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
On this land <a href="Pembroke Hall.html">Pembroke Hall</a> was erected in 1897 and <a href="Sayles Gymnasium.html">Sayles Gymnasium</a> in 1907.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
The Class of 1900 erected a gate on the south side of Cushing Street near Sayles Gym in memory of their classmate Josephine Scholfield, who died in September 1900.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
In addition to the land acquired from Stephen O. Metcalf, in 1915 more land on Cushing Street was added by the purchase of houses, three of which were torn done, one at 123 Cushing Street fitted for rental, and one at 98 Cushing Street turned into a cooperative dormitory for the Women’s College.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
The Pembroke athletic field was acquired through the bequest of Charles T. Aldrich 1877 and Henry L. Aldrich 1876 of their estate which occupied the block bordered by Meeting, Hope, Cushing and Brook Streets.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
The Aldrich residence was torn down and the field was in use in the fall of 1936.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
The G1940 for future development to the north of <a href="Alumnae Hall.html">Alumnae Hall</a>.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
The <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a> property was extended to the east, and the dormitory quadrangle of <a href="Champlin and Morriss Halls.html">Champlin and Morriss Halls</a> and <a href="Emery and Woolley Halls.html">Emery and Woolley Halls</a> were built in the early 1960s and <a href="New Pembroke.html">New Pembroke</a> was built on Thayer Street in 1974.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
The East Campus was the former campus of <a href="Bryant College.html">Bryant College</a>, which was purchased in 1969.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
View of the COLLEGE in Providence, together with the PRESIDENT’S HOUSE &amp; GARDENS," which was drawn by David Leonard 1792 and engraved by Samuel Hill of Boston.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
Leonard depicted the College at the time when he was a student, as it would have appeared to George Washington when he visited in 1790.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
Shown are the College Edifice (now <a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a>) with its original cupola and balustrade and two lightning rods, the president’s two-story house standing near the present location of <a href="Carrie Tower.html">Carrie Tower</a>, the College well, and the stone wall which is probably the one which the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> records for 1777 note was built by <a href="President.html">President</a> Manning.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
In a lithograph from the 1820s the campus which now included <a href="Hope College.html">Hope College</a> and <a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a> is shown from the northwest.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
The back of the president’s house is shown, along with the stone wall on the north side of the campus and the Lombardy poplars planted in 1803.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
The company’s first lithographs appeared about 1828.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
An engraving of the campus in the 1850s, depicting <a href="Hope College.html">Hope College</a>, <a href="Manning Hall.html">Manning Hall</a>, <a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a>, and <a href="Rhode Island Hall.html">Rhode Island Hall</a> surrounded by a wooden fence, by J. C. Thompson, delineator, and F. O. Freeman, engraver, was printed by Wilson and Daniels, printers in Boston.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
Of this print William A. Mowry 1858 wrote to <a href="President.html">President</a> Faunce in 1914, "In 1857 to 1860 and after I was the editor and publisher of ‘The R. I. Schoolmaster,’ I had the steel engraving of four buildings made at a cost of $50.00 and published it with a historical sketch of the College in ... the Schoolmaster for Jan. 1858....<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
In 1908 the firm of Woodbury-Carlton of Worcester, Massachusetts, made a view of the University from a wash drawing done by John C. Woodbury, founder of the firm.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
The view appeared as a tail piece in "Memories of Brown," published in 1909, where the name of the firm was incorrectly given as "Woodbury-Clayton."<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
The wash drawing was given to the University by Woodbury’s son in 1947.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
Artist Richard Rummel of New York made an etching in 1908, which was very similar to and may have been copied from the Woodbury drawing.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
The "Appleby Etchings" were a set of five etchings by a young Scottish etcher, Wilfred C. Appleby, commissioned and published by Tilden-Thurber Company in 1927.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
One by Clarissa Daggett done in November 1799 is of <a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a> only.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
Abigail Adams Hobart, whose brother, Aaron was in the Class of 1805, completed in June 1802, in the tenth year of her age, a sampler which depicts <a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a> (which is identified as "Providence College"), the president’s house and two other buildings.<cite><a href="Campus.html">Campus</a></cite>
1929- ?<cite><a href="Carberry, Josiah S..html">Carberry, Josiah S.</a></cite>
), legendary professor of psychoceramics (the study of cracked pots) since 1929, was born on a bulletin board in University Hall.<cite><a href="Carberry, Josiah S..html">Carberry, Josiah S.</a></cite>
"Classical Weekly" published Carberry’s contribution, "Another Catullus to Another Lesbia," in 1934, and an article in "American Scientist" included his book, "Psychoceramics" (Brown University Press, 1945, 1313p.)<cite><a href="Carberry, Josiah S..html">Carberry, Josiah S.</a></cite>
Josiah S. Carberry was listed among the cast in Trinity Square Playhouse’s production of "Desire Under the Elms," and attended the University’s bicentennial celebration as a delegate of Burleigh College (est.1664).<cite><a href="Carberry, Josiah S..html">Carberry, Josiah S.</a></cite>
On Friday, May 13, 1955, an anonymous gift of $101.01 was received by the University from Professor Carberry to establish the Josiah S. Carberry Fund in memory of his "future late wife."<cite><a href="Carberry, Josiah S..html">Carberry, Josiah S.</a></cite>
Professor Carberry has been the subject of articles in a number of periodicals, including the "New York Times," which proclaimed him "The World’s Greatest Traveler" on the front page of its Sunday travel section in 1974, and in "Yankee" magazine, where he was "The Absent-Bodied Professor" in 1975.<cite><a href="Carberry, Josiah S..html">Carberry, Josiah S.</a></cite>
A recent honor which came to Professor Carberry was the award to him of an Ig Noble Prize at the First Annual Ig Noble Prize Ceremony on October 3, 1991.<cite><a href="Carberry, Josiah S..html">Carberry, Josiah S.</a></cite>
At this event sponsored by M.I.T. and the "Journal of Irreproducible Results," Carberry, the 1991 Ig Nobel Interdisciplinary Research Prize laureate, was cited as "bold explorer and eclectic seeker of knowledge, for his pioneering work in the field of psychoceramics, the study of cracked pots."<cite><a href="Carberry, Josiah S..html">Carberry, Josiah S.</a></cite>
Leonard Carmichael (1898-1973), professor of psychology, was born in Philadelphia on November 9, 1898.<cite><a href="Carmichael, Leonard.html">Carmichael, Leonard</a></cite>
Leonard Carmichael received his bachelor of science degree from Tufts College in 1921.<cite><a href="Carmichael, Leonard.html">Carmichael, Leonard</a></cite>
Leonard Carmichael was an assistant in the department of biology at Tufts during his senior year and continued as an instructor while he pursued his graduate education in psychology at Harvard, receiving his Ph.D. degree in 1924.<cite><a href="Carmichael, Leonard.html">Carmichael, Leonard</a></cite>
Leonard Carmichael studied in Berlin with a Sheldon Travelling Fellowship, then taught psychology at Princeton as an instructor from 1924 to 1926 and as assistant professor in 1926-27.<cite><a href="Carmichael, Leonard.html">Carmichael, Leonard</a></cite>
Leonard Carmichael came to Brown from Princeton as assistant professor in 1927 at the invitation of Vice-President <a href="Mead, Albert D..html">Albert D. Mead</a>.<cite><a href="Carmichael, Leonard.html">Carmichael, Leonard</a></cite>
