Leonard Carmichael left Brown in 1936 to become chairman of the Department of Psychology and dean of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences at the University of Rochester.<cite><a href="Carmichael, Leonard.html">Carmichael, Leonard</a></cite>
In 1938, at the age of 39, Leonard Carmichael became the seventh president of Tufts College.<cite><a href="Carmichael, Leonard.html">Carmichael, Leonard</a></cite>
In 1953 Leonard Carmichael became the seventh secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, which he guided through eleven years of expansion and renovation which enhanced its image as a modern institution.<cite><a href="Carmichael, Leonard.html">Carmichael, Leonard</a></cite>
Leonard Carmichael retired in 1964.<cite><a href="Carmichael, Leonard.html">Carmichael, Leonard</a></cite>
Leonard Carmichael died on September 16, 1973, in Washington.<cite><a href="Carmichael, Leonard.html">Carmichael, Leonard</a></cite>
Carrie Tower was erected in 1904, a gift of Paul Bajnotti of Turin, Italy, and a memorial to his wife, born Caroline Mathilde Brown, granddaughter of Nicholas Brown 1786, for whom the University is named, and daughter of Nicholas Brown 1811.<cite><a href="Carrie Tower.html">Carrie Tower</a></cite>
She died in Palermo in 1892 after sixteen years of marriage to Bajnotti, who also erected a fountain in her memory in Burnside Park in Providence.<cite><a href="Carrie Tower.html">Carrie Tower</a></cite>
A strange occurrence in 1950 caused the clock to run erratically.<cite><a href="Carrie Tower.html">Carrie Tower</a></cite>
"Casements," a literary magazine which first appeared in January 1923, was, as its foreword announced, born of "the conviction that undergraduates have things to say," and carried the motto, "To Youth’s glimpses – the time of the most vivid feeling of Truth and Beauty."<cite><a href="Casements.html">Casements</a></cite>
The January 1924 issue was highly publicized when newspapers carried a story that the sale of the magazine had been stopped by the city soliciter of Providence, after it was pronounced "obscene and unfit for public reading."<cite><a href="Casements.html">Casements</a></cite>
The January 1925 issue proclaimed that ""Casements does not apologize for being late ... somewhat less richly clad, but triumphant over divers (sic) vicissitudes."<cite><a href="Casements.html">Casements</a></cite>
Robert Pierce Casey (1897-1959), professor of Biblical literature, was born in Dorchester, Massachusetts, on December 3, 1897.<cite><a href="Casey, Robert P..html">Casey, Robert P.</a></cite>
Robert P. Casey graduated from Harvard in 1919 and received a bachelor of sacred theology degree from Harvard Divinity School in 1922.<cite><a href="Casey, Robert P..html">Casey, Robert P.</a></cite>
With a Sheldon Fellowship for study abroad awarded by Harvard, Robert P. Casey spent the next two years at Jesus College of the University of Cambridge, and in 1924 was the first American to receive a Ph.D. degree in theology from Cambridge.<cite><a href="Casey, Robert P..html">Casey, Robert P.</a></cite>
In 1926 Robert P. Casey was named professor of the history and philosophy of religions at Cincinnati.<cite><a href="Casey, Robert P..html">Casey, Robert P.</a></cite>
In 1934 Robert P. Casey was appointed professor of Biblical literature and history of religion and chairman of the Department of Biblical Literature at Brown.<cite><a href="Casey, Robert P..html">Casey, Robert P.</a></cite>
Robert P. Casey was a member of the Van Expedition, sponsored by the Museum of the University of Pennsylvania and the Brown Department of Biblical Literature, in 1938 and 1939 to excavate the ancient city of Van in Turkish Armenia.<cite><a href="Casey, Robert P..html">Casey, Robert P.</a></cite>
Robert P. Casey served as honorary curate at St. Stephen’s Church in Providence from 1939 to 1946 and was ordained to the Episcopal priesthood in 1940.<cite><a href="Casey, Robert P..html">Casey, Robert P.</a></cite>
Robert P. Casey left Brown in 1950, when he was elected to a lectureship in Sidney Sussex College in Cambridge.<cite><a href="Casey, Robert P..html">Casey, Robert P.</a></cite>
"The Church Times," a publication of the Church of England, in June 1956 included an appreciation of Casey, which read in part, "The undergraduates who frequent the rooms of the Dean of Sidney Sussex College are introduced to an atmosphere of learning and urbanity, and acquire a remarkable knowledge of dogmatic and ascetic theology, together with a sound devotional practice and good taste in literature, art, and the diverse characters and customs of many nations.<cite><a href="Casey, Robert P..html">Casey, Robert P.</a></cite>
Robert P. Casey died in Norfolk, England, in April 1959.<cite><a href="Casey, Robert P..html">Casey, Robert P.</a></cite>
Alexis Caswell (1799-1877), sixth president of Brown University, was born in Taunton, Massachusetts, on January 29, 1799, with his twin brother Alvaris.<cite><a href="Caswell, Alexis.html">Caswell, Alexis</a></cite>
Alexis Caswell studied at Taunton Academy and graduated first in the class of 1822 at Brown.<cite><a href="Caswell, Alexis.html">Caswell, Alexis</a></cite>
In 1827 Alexis Caswell was ordained and installed as minister of a Baptist church in Halifax, Nova Scotia.<cite><a href="Caswell, Alexis.html">Caswell, Alexis</a></cite>
Alexis Caswell was professor of mathematics and natural philosophy from 1828 to 1850, professor of mathematics and astronomy from 1850 to 1855, and professor of natural philosophy and astronomy from 1855 to 1863.<cite><a href="Caswell, Alexis.html">Caswell, Alexis</a></cite>
Alexis Caswell was involved in the creation of the museum of natural history and the raising of the library fund of $25,000 in 1831.<cite><a href="Caswell, Alexis.html">Caswell, Alexis</a></cite>
Alexis Caswell served as president "pro tempore" of the University in 1840-41 while President <a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Francis Wayland</a> traveled in Europe, and was appointed regent of the University to assist the president from 1852 to 1855.<cite><a href="Caswell, Alexis.html">Caswell, Alexis</a></cite>
When Wayland resigned in 1855, some expected that Caswell, then the senior member of the faculty, would succeed him, but it was decided that a new president from outside the University would be an advantage, and <a href="Sears, Barnas.html">Barnas Sears</a> was chosen.<cite><a href="Caswell, Alexis.html">Caswell, Alexis</a></cite>
Caswell continued his teaching, spending the year 1860-61 visiting observatories and attending meetings of scientific societies.<cite><a href="Caswell, Alexis.html">Caswell, Alexis</a></cite>
In 1863 Alexis Caswell retired and became president of the National Exchange Bank and the American Screw Company in Providence.<cite><a href="Caswell, Alexis.html">Caswell, Alexis</a></cite>
In 1868, after both Martin B. Anderson and <a href="Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman.html">Ezekiel Gilman Robinson</a> had declined the offer of the presidency of Brown University, Caswell was persuaded to accept the office.<cite><a href="Caswell, Alexis.html">Caswell, Alexis</a></cite>
The enrollment increased from 186 in 1868 to 224 in 1872.<cite><a href="Caswell, Alexis.html">Caswell, Alexis</a></cite>
Caswell revived the alumni association by inviting the alumni to meet with him on the day before Commencement in 1868.<cite><a href="Caswell, Alexis.html">Caswell, Alexis</a></cite>
After that, annual meetings were held and led to a permanent association in 1872.<cite><a href="Caswell, Alexis.html">Caswell, Alexis</a></cite>
In September 1868 an Advisory and Executive Committee was created and empowered "to give to the President the assistance of their counsel when it is desired by him ... to act on occasions of emergency ... to see that the Laws of the Corporation are carried into effect by the officers, and observed by the students."<cite><a href="Caswell, Alexis.html">Caswell, Alexis</a></cite>
Caswell resigned in 1872 at the age of 73, having, in the words of Professor <a href="Lincoln, John Larkin.html">John Larkin Lincoln</a>, "administered the Presidential office in a spirit of manly independence, and stood firmly, at whatever cost of personal convenience and personal interest, to the responsibilities which devolved upon him."<cite><a href="Caswell, Alexis.html">Caswell, Alexis</a></cite>
Beginning in 1831 Caswell made regular meteorological observations for Providence, and his "Meteorological Register; Providence, R.I." from 1831 to 1860 was published in volume 12 of "Smithsonian Contributions to Knowledge."<cite><a href="Caswell, Alexis.html">Caswell, Alexis</a></cite>
Alexis Caswell continued his observations until 1876.<cite><a href="Caswell, Alexis.html">Caswell, Alexis</a></cite>
In 1858 Alexis Caswell delivered a course of lectures at the Smithsonian Institution.<cite><a href="Caswell, Alexis.html">Caswell, Alexis</a></cite>
Alexis Caswell was named a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences in 1858.<cite><a href="Caswell, Alexis.html">Caswell, Alexis</a></cite>
When the National Academy of Science was created in 1863, Caswell was one the fifty members chosen.<cite><a href="Caswell, Alexis.html">Caswell, Alexis</a></cite>
Alexis Caswell was vice-president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science in 1855, and at the meeting in 1858 presided in the absence of the president and vice-president.<cite><a href="Caswell, Alexis.html">Caswell, Alexis</a></cite>
From 1875 until his death Alexis Caswell was president of Rhode Island Hospital.<cite><a href="Caswell, Alexis.html">Caswell, Alexis</a></cite>
Alexis Caswell died in Providence on January 8, 1877.<cite><a href="Caswell, Alexis.html">Caswell, Alexis</a></cite>
Caswell Hall was erected in 1903 on <a href="Lincoln Field.html">Lincoln Field</a> along Thayer Street.<cite><a href="Caswell Hall.html">Caswell Hall</a></cite>
Nov. Anglorum, ab Anno 1769, ad Annum 1772, alicujus Gradus Laurea donati sunt," which was a list of baccalaureate and honorary graduates.<cite><a href="Catalogues.html">Catalogues</a></cite>
The College was closed during the <a href="Revolutionary War.html">Revolutionary War</a>, so there was no catalogue until 1786, after which a new edition was published every three years.<cite><a href="Catalogues.html">Catalogues</a></cite>
In 1798 it took a new format as a pamphlet.<cite><a href="Catalogues.html">Catalogues</a></cite>
The triennial catalogue continued to appear until it was superseded in 1895 by the first <a href="English.html">English</a> catalogue of officers and students, the "Historical Catalogue of Brown University ...<cite><a href="Catalogues.html">Catalogues</a></cite>
1764-1894."<cite><a href="Catalogues.html">Catalogues</a></cite>
This valuable work contained the names of the faculty from the beginning of the college listed by rank and then in order of appointment, and lists of graduates for the classes of 1769 through 1894, with biographical sketches.<cite><a href="Catalogues.html">Catalogues</a></cite>
Subsequent Historical Catalogues were published at ten year intervals until 1934.<cite><a href="Catalogues.html">Catalogues</a></cite>
The 1904 edition included for the first time the names of those who had attended but had not graduated.<cite><a href="Catalogues.html">Catalogues</a></cite>
In 1924 the "Historical Catalogue" was issued in two volumes, one for the Men’s College and one for the Women’s, on the grounds that in 1924 an alumna had to buy a book which contained a thousand names of her fellow alumnae, in most of whom she was interested, but also six thousand men in whom she was not, and "vice versa."<cite><a href="Catalogues.html">Catalogues</a></cite>
The 1934 edition was the last of the historical catalogues published at ten year intervals, as none could be printed during <a href="World War II.html">World War II</a>.<cite><a href="Catalogues.html">Catalogues</a></cite>
The next edition, and the last to bear the title "Historical Catalogue," was printed in 1950.<cite><a href="Catalogues.html">Catalogues</a></cite>
The Catalogue was superseded by the "Brown University Alumni Directory," published in 1964 by the University, and published commercially in 1979, 1984, and 1989.<cite><a href="Catalogues.html">Catalogues</a></cite>
The first "Catalogue Of the Officers and Students of Rhode-Island College" was a broadside list dated October 1800, which listed Chancellor Jabez Bowen, <a href="President.html">President</a> Jonathan Maxcy, two Professors, David Howell and Asa Messer, and three tutors, one of whom, Calvin Park, was also the librarian, followed by the names of the members of the four classes with their places of residence.<cite><a href="Catalogues.html">Catalogues</a></cite>
The "Catalogue" became a pamphlet publication in 1820.<cite><a href="Catalogues.html">Catalogues</a></cite>
Information about admission, courses, and expense was added in 1824.<cite><a href="Catalogues.html">Catalogues</a></cite>
In 1852 the Catalogue was issued as a small duodecimo instead of the usual octavo.<cite><a href="Catalogues.html">Catalogues</a></cite>
As the annual catalogue evolved, separate catalogues were printed for <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a> from 1927-28 to 1957-58, and for the <a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a> from 1927-28 to 1970-71.<cite><a href="Catalogues.html">Catalogues</a></cite>
Biennial catalogues replaced the annual catalogues since the 1966-68 edition, with the exception of one single year catalogue in 1970-71, and the latest catalogue is for the year 1991-94.<cite><a href="Catalogues.html">Catalogues</a></cite>
The Centennial celebration was held on September 6, 1864, one day before <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a>, with formal exercises in the <a href="First Baptist Church.html">First Baptist Church</a>.<cite><a href="Centennial celebration.html">Centennial celebration</a></cite>
<a href="President.html">President</a> Barnas Sears delivered an historical discourse (57 printed pages) and the Central Glee Club sang an ode written for the occasion by Bishop George Burgess 1826.<cite><a href="Centennial celebration.html">Centennial celebration</a></cite>
After the exercises seven hundred alumni and guests attended a dinner in a large tent on the campus, and heard speeches by ex-president Wayland and Professor Goldwin Smith of Oxford University, and a poem by Charles Thurber 1827.<cite><a href="Centennial celebration.html">Centennial celebration</a></cite>
General Ambrose E. Burnside’s remarks were followed by a centennial poem by John Hay 1858, read in his absence by Professor James B. Angell 1849, which began:  George William Curtis, honorary alumnus, responded to the sentiment, "The Adopted Sons of the University," and Professor Caswell 1822 responded to "The Memory of the Founders and Benefactors of the University" by contributing $1000 toward endowment of a professorship as a memorial of the occasion.<cite><a href="Centennial celebration.html">Centennial celebration</a></cite>
Several addresses, because of the lateness of the hour, were rescheduled to the commencement dinner the next day, including a 120-line poem by Mark Antony DeWolfe Howe 1828.<cite><a href="Centennial celebration.html">Centennial celebration</a></cite>
The Center for Alcohol and Addiction Studies was established in 1982 by <a href="President.html">President</a> Swearer, who declared its goal to be a "collaborative research program which encourages the use of multidisciplinary approaches to problems related to the use of alcohol and other drugs."<cite><a href="Center for Alcohol and Addiction Studies.html">Center for Alcohol and Addiction Studies</a></cite>
Since 1985 the national offices of AMERSA (Association for Medical <a href="Education.html">Education</a> and Research in Substance Abuse, established in 1976) have been located at Brown.<cite><a href="Center for Alcohol and Addiction Studies.html">Center for Alcohol and Addiction Studies</a></cite>
The Brown University Program in Alcohol and Other Drug Abuse Prevention, funded by the U.S. Department of <a href="Education.html">Education</a>, was coordinated by Jerri Husch from 1989-1991.<cite><a href="Center for Alcohol and Addiction Studies.html">Center for Alcohol and Addiction Studies</a></cite>
The Center for Energy Studies was started in 1976 to coordinate the various types of energy research going on at Brown and to encourage communication leading to new research and programs.<cite><a href="Center for Energy Studies.html">Center for Energy Studies</a></cite>
The Center is last mentioned in the University catalogue for 1983-85, and was dissolved during that time.<cite><a href="Center for Energy Studies.html">Center for Energy Studies</a></cite>
The Center for Environmental Studies was established in May 1978.<cite><a href="Center for Environmental Studies.html">Center for Environmental Studies</a></cite>
With the assistance of a $221,000 grant from the Richard King Mellon Foundation in 1981, the Center created the Urban Environment Laboratory in the old Lucian Sharpe Carriage House at 135 Angell Street, turning it into a model house to show what can be accomplished in an urban environment with a solar greenhouse, insulation, water-conserving plumbing, and a recycling facility.<cite><a href="Center for Environmental Studies.html">Center for Environmental Studies</a></cite>
Eleven summer interns renovated the building in the summer of 1982.<cite><a href="Center for Environmental Studies.html">Center for Environmental Studies</a></cite>
In 1990 a program called "Brown is Green" was established under a committee of twelve administrators, professors, and students to encourage at Brown the acceptance of responsibility by individuals for the proper use of natural resources.<cite><a href="Center for Environmental Studies.html">Center for Environmental Studies</a></cite>
The Center for Foreign Policy Development was established in 1981, with Mark Garrison, former director of the State Department’s Office of Soviet Union Affairs, as director.<cite><a href="Center for Foreign Policy Development.html">Center for Foreign Policy Development</a></cite>
On November 17, 1983, fifty years to the day from the resumption of diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union, the Center, with the World Affairs Council of Rhode Island, the Council for International Studies at Brown, and the Rhode Island Committee for the Humanities, sponsored a lecture by George Kennan.<cite><a href="Center for Foreign Policy Development.html">Center for Foreign Policy Development</a></cite>
In July 1988 twenty-six delegates from Brown traveled to Moscow for a conference on mutual security, and in November 1989 a second conference on mutual security was held at Brown.<cite><a href="Center for Foreign Policy Development.html">Center for Foreign Policy Development</a></cite>
One of the visiting scholars, spending the first semester of 1991-92 at the Center, was Sergei Khrushchev, son of former leader of the Soviet Union, Nikita Khrushchev<cite><a href="Center for Foreign Policy Development.html">Center for Foreign Policy Development</a></cite>
The Center for Information Technology opened in June of 1988.<cite><a href="Center for Information Technology.html">Center for Information Technology</a></cite>
The "groundbreaking" for the CIT on October 11, 1986 involved no digging.<cite><a href="Center for Information Technology.html">Center for Information Technology</a></cite>
The dedication of the building as the Thomas J. Watson, Sr., Center for Information Technology took place October 7-8, 1988.<cite><a href="Center for Information Technology.html">Center for Information Technology</a></cite>
The Center for Latin American Studies was established in November 1984 to foster teaching and research on Latin America, using faculty from various departments who have taught or studied in Latin America.<cite><a href="Center for Latin American Studies.html">Center for Latin American Studies</a></cite>
The Center is one of thirteen federally supported Latin American Resource Centers, and with the University of Connecticut and the University of Massachusetts-Amherst forms a consortium, which has organized several conferences, including "Venezuela at the End of the Century/Venezuela: Sociedad y Cultura al Dinal del Siglo" in 1991.<cite><a href="Center for Latin American Studies.html">Center for Latin American Studies</a></cite>
The Center for Law and Liberal <a href="Education.html">Education</a> was formed in 1977.<cite><a href="Center for Law and Liberal Education.html">Center for Law and Liberal Education</a></cite>
To mark the first anniversary of the Center in December 1977, Anthony Lewis spoke on "Law in a Civilized Society," and commented on the future of the Center, "It will help to make law, as a way of looking at society, a more pervasive part of our civilization."<cite><a href="Center for Law and Liberal Education.html">Center for Law and Liberal Education</a></cite>
The Center for Modern Culture and Media was established in 1987, with Professor of <a href="English.html">English</a> Robert Scholes as director.<cite><a href="Center for Modern Culture and Media.html">Center for Modern Culture and Media</a></cite>
In 1991, the Center was renamed the Malcolm S. Forbes, Jr. Center for Modern Culture and Media, in consideration of a two million dollar endowment from the Forbes Foundation on August 19, which would have been the seventy-second birthday of Mr. Forbes, received through Forbes’s son Timothy ’76, who had concentrated in semiotics.<cite><a href="Center for Modern Culture and Media.html">Center for Modern Culture and Media</a></cite>
The program in Modern Literature and Society was founded by Professors Roger Henkle and Lewis Perry Curtis and initiated in 1980 under co-directors Curtis and Professor Duncan Smith, who served as chairpersons of the Executive Committee in charge of the program.<cite><a href="Center for Modern Culture and Media.html">Center for Modern Culture and Media</a></cite>
The scope of the program was described in the University catalogue for 1985-87:  The first undergraduate concentration in the country in Semiotics, the study of signs and systems of communication, was established by the Department of <a href="English.html">English</a> in 1974 in response to student interest.<cite><a href="Center for Modern Culture and Media.html">Center for Modern Culture and Media</a></cite>
There were four concentrators in 1974.<cite><a href="Center for Modern Culture and Media.html">Center for Modern Culture and Media</a></cite>
The number had risen to seventy when the interdisciplinary Center for Research in Semiotics under the direction of Professor of Slavic Languages Thomas Winner began in 1979.<cite><a href="Center for Modern Culture and Media.html">Center for Modern Culture and Media</a></cite>
The Center for Old World Archaeology and <a href="Art.html">Art</a> was founded in 1978 to bring together the scholars with this common interest from the Departments of <a href="Classics.html">Classics</a>, <a href="Art.html">Art</a>, <a href="History.html">History</a>, <a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a>, and <a href="Egyptology.html">Egyptology</a>.<cite><a href="Center for Old World Archaeology and Art.html">Center for Old World Archaeology and Art</a></cite>
In 1982 the Center undertook field work in Sicily with the excavation of a site of the Castelluccian Culture at la Muculufa.<cite><a href="Center for Old World Archaeology and Art.html">Center for Old World Archaeology and Art</a></cite>
The Center for the Comparative Study of Development was established in 1983 to facilitate research and teaching in the problems of socioeconomic development, with Morris D. Morris, Henry R. Luce Professor of the Comparative Study of Development, as director.<cite><a href="Center for the Comparative Study of Development.html">Center for the Comparative Study of Development</a></cite>
Dietrich Rueschemeyer was named director in 1989.<cite><a href="Center for the Comparative Study of Development.html">Center for the Comparative Study of Development</a></cite>
The Center for the study of race and ethnicity in America was established in July 1988 with professor of philosophy John Ladd as acting director, in response to a proposal which evolved from discussions among Ladd, professor of sociology Martin Martel and associate professor of history Rhett Jones.<cite><a href="Center for the Study of Race and Ethnicity in America.html">Center for the Study of Race and Ethnicity in America</a></cite>
Arnold Buffum Chace (1845-1932), eleventh chancellor of the University, was born in Valley Falls, Rhode Island, on November 10, 1845.<cite><a href="Chace, Arnold Buffum.html">Chace, Arnold Buffum</a></cite>
Arnold Buffum Chace graduated from Brown in 1866.<cite><a href="Chace, Arnold Buffum.html">Chace, Arnold Buffum</a></cite>
Arnold Buffum Chace was an instructor in chemistry at Brown in 1868-69 while he branched out in his scientific studies by attending lectures in biology at Harvard.<cite><a href="Chace, Arnold Buffum.html">Chace, Arnold Buffum</a></cite>
In the 1890s Arnold Buffum Chace was a regular visitor of Henry Parker Manning’s classes in higher mathematics at Brown.<cite><a href="Chace, Arnold Buffum.html">Chace, Arnold Buffum</a></cite>
In 1910 Chace and his wife (the aforementioned schoolgirl artist Lite) visited Egypt and were much impressed with Egyptian civilization.<cite><a href="Chace, Arnold Buffum.html">Chace, Arnold Buffum</a></cite>
Chace then paid for a fine edition of the work, which was sponsored by the Mathematical Association of America and dedicated to the memory of Mrs. Chace, who had died in 1924.<cite><a href="Chace, Arnold Buffum.html">Chace, Arnold Buffum</a></cite>
The first volume of Arnold Buffum Chace's "Rhind Mathematical Papyrus" was printed in 1927, the second in 1929.<cite><a href="Chace, Arnold Buffum.html">Chace, Arnold Buffum</a></cite>
Arnold Buffum Chace died in Providence on February 28, 1932.<cite><a href="Chace, Arnold Buffum.html">Chace, Arnold Buffum</a></cite>
George Ide Chace (1808-1885), professor of many subjects and president "ad interim" in 1867-68, was born on February 19, 1808 in Lancaster, Massachusetts, where he lived on a farm.<cite><a href="Chace, George Ide.html">Chace, George Ide</a></cite>
George Ide Chace entered Brown in 1827 as a sophomore and graduated in 1830, at which time he delivered a Commencement address on "The Results of Improvements in the Science of Education."<cite><a href="Chace, George Ide.html">Chace, George Ide</a></cite>
George Ide Chace was appointed adjunct professor of mathematics and natural philosophy in 1833, and professor of chemistry in 1834.<cite><a href="Chace, George Ide.html">Chace, George Ide</a></cite>
President <a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Francis Wayland</a>, who had been teaching a physiology course, sent Chace to Philadelphia to attend lectures, after which he was appointed professor of chemistry, physiology, and geology in 1836.<cite><a href="Chace, George Ide.html">Chace, George Ide</a></cite>
In the summer of 1836 George Ide Chace traveled through Virginia and Kentucky to acquire geological specimens.<cite><a href="Chace, George Ide.html">Chace, George Ide</a></cite>
In 1853 George Ide Chace gave a series of lectures to a class of 330 manufacturing jewelers of Providence and was rewarded by a gift of a silver pitcher engraved with scenes of Rhode Island Hall, the laboratory, and jewelers at work.<cite><a href="Chace, George Ide.html">Chace, George Ide</a></cite>
George Ide Chace became professor of chemistry and physiology in 1859, professor of geology and physical geography in 1864, and professor of chemistry and geology in 1865.<cite><a href="Chace, George Ide.html">Chace, George Ide</a></cite>
George Ide Chace served as president "ad interim" for six months after the resignation of President <a href="Sears, Barnas.html">Barnas Sears</a> in 1867, adding the teaching of metaphysics and ethics to his regular classes, and was thought by many to be the best choice to succeed Sears.<cite><a href="Chace, George Ide.html">Chace, George Ide</a></cite>
When <a href="Caswell, Alexis.html">Alexis Caswell</a> became president in 1868, Chace was named professor of moral and intellectual philosophy, courses which had usually been taught by the president.<cite><a href="Chace, George Ide.html">Chace, George Ide</a></cite>
His courses in physiology and in intellectual philosophy recognized the relationship between physiology and psychology, and in 1848 George Ide Chace published an article, "On the dependence of the mental powers upon the bodily organization."<cite><a href="Chace, George Ide.html">Chace, George Ide</a></cite>
James B. Angell 1849 said of Chace, "He was one of the few men who could talk well while conducting an experiment."<cite><a href="Chace, George Ide.html">Chace, George Ide</a></cite>
In 1869 Chace began a tradition of inviting to his home on Benefit Street all the members of his senior class in mental philosophy in groups of four or five for a social evening.<cite><a href="Chace, George Ide.html">Chace, George Ide</a></cite>
After his resignation from teaching in 1871, Chace traveled to Europe, and then returned and added to his civic responsibilities.<cite><a href="Chace, George Ide.html">Chace, George Ide</a></cite>
George Ide Chace was a trustee of Butler Hospital and Rhode Island Hospital, and from 1874 to 1883 was chairman of the State Board of Charities and Corrections, directing the state institutions in Cranston.<cite><a href="Chace, George Ide.html">Chace, George Ide</a></cite>
George Ide Chace died in Providence on April 29, 1885.<cite><a href="Chace, George Ide.html">Chace, George Ide</a></cite>
<a href="Bronson, Walter C..html">Walter C. Bronson</a> 1887 wrote of Chace: Another legacy was a free bed for Brown University at Rhode Island Hospital.<cite><a href="Chace, George Ide.html">Chace, George Ide</a></cite>
Zechariah Chafee, Jr. (1885-1957), University Professor at Harvard University and champion of civil liberties, was born in Providence on December 7, 1885.<cite><a href="Chafee, Zechariah Ã07.html">Chafee, Zechariah Ã07</a></cite>
His father, Zechariah Chafee 1880, was president of Builders Iron Foundry and a long-time trustee and fellow of the University.<cite><a href="Chafee, Zechariah Ã07.html">Chafee, Zechariah Ã07</a></cite>
Zechariah, Jr. graduated from Brown in 1907 and worked for a few years in his father’s business before entering Harvard Law School, where he received his LL.B. degree in 1913.<cite><a href="Chafee, Zechariah Ã07.html">Chafee, Zechariah Ã07</a></cite>
After three years with the law firm of Tillinghast and Collins in Providence, Zechariah Ã07 Chafee began his teaching career at Harvard in 1916 as assistant professor of law, and became full professor in 1919, Langdell Professor of Law in 1938, and University Professor in 1950.<cite><a href="Chafee, Zechariah Ã07.html">Chafee, Zechariah Ã07</a></cite>
One bit of law that he did learn is apparent in a letter to Librarian David A. Jonah, written by Chafee in 1952 when he presented his college essays to the Archives of the University, which contained this comment: "I blush now to think of the use that I made of some sort of encyclopedia of criticism, which was possessed by the old polygonal library.<cite><a href="Chafee, Zechariah Ã07.html">Chafee, Zechariah Ã07</a></cite>
In 1952 at a Senate subcommittee meeting, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy named Chafee a person "dangerous" to the United States.<cite><a href="Chafee, Zechariah Ã07.html">Chafee, Zechariah Ã07</a></cite>
Zechariah Ã07 Chafee's publications included "Freedom of Speech" in 1920, "Free Speech in the United States" in 1941, and "Government and Mass Communications" in 1947.<cite><a href="Chafee, Zechariah Ã07.html">Chafee, Zechariah Ã07</a></cite>
Zechariah Ã07 Chafee's last book was "The Blessings of Liberty" in 1956.<cite><a href="Chafee, Zechariah Ã07.html">Chafee, Zechariah Ã07</a></cite>
Zechariah Ã07 Chafee retired in July 1956, and died in Boston on February 8, 1957.<cite><a href="Chafee, Zechariah Ã07.html">Chafee, Zechariah Ã07</a></cite>
Robert Foster Chambers (1887-1947), professor of chemistry, was born in Providence on October 8, 1887.<cite><a href="Chambers, Robert F..html">Chambers, Robert F.</a></cite>
Robert F. Chambers received a bachelor of philosophy degree in 1909, a master of science in 1910, and a master of arts and Ph.D. in 1912, all from Brown, specializing in the study of organic chemistry under Professor John E. Bucher.<cite><a href="Chambers, Robert F..html">Chambers, Robert F.</a></cite>
Robert F. Chambers became assistant in chemistry at Brown in 1914-15, and was promoted to instructor in 1915, assistant professor in 1916, and associate professor in 1922.<cite><a href="Chambers, Robert F..html">Chambers, Robert F.</a></cite>
Robert F. Chambers was appointed chairman of the chemistry department in 1929 and named Newport Rogers professor of chemistry in 1932.<cite><a href="Chambers, Robert F..html">Chambers, Robert F.</a></cite>
Robert F. Chambers died in Providence on November 17, 1947, having been stricken shortly after presiding at a meeting at the University.<cite><a href="Chambers, Robert F..html">Chambers, Robert F.</a></cite>
Champlin and Morriss Halls, the first two units in a planned dormitory and dining quadrangle for <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a>, were dedicated on October 28, 1960.<cite><a href="Champlin and Morriss Halls.html">Champlin and Morriss Halls</a></cite>
Morriss Hall was named for Margaret S. Morriss, dean of the Women’s College and <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a> from 1923 to 1950.<cite><a href="Champlin and Morriss Halls.html">Champlin and Morriss Halls</a></cite>
The first, Stephen Hopkins (1764-1785) was one of the original incorporators of the College, several times Governor of Rhode Island, a delegate to the Continental Congress and a signer of the Declaration of Independence.<cite><a href="Chancellors.html">Chancellors</a></cite>
Jabez Bowen (1785-1815) was a Chief Justice of the Rhode Island Supreme Court.<cite><a href="Chancellors.html">Chancellors</a></cite>
Alexander Viets Griswold (1815-1828) was Episcopal Bishop of the Diocese of Eastern Massachusetts.<cite><a href="Chancellors.html">Chancellors</a></cite>
Samuel Willard Bridgham 1794 (1828-1840) was the first graduate to be named Chancellor.<cite><a href="Chancellors.html">Chancellors</a></cite>
John Brown Francis 1818 (1841-1854) was Governor of Rhode Island and a United States Senator.<cite><a href="Chancellors.html">Chancellors</a></cite>
Samuel Boyd Tobey (1854-1867) was a physician and a Quaker.<cite><a href="Chancellors.html">Chancellors</a></cite>
William Patten 1818 (1867-1873), Benjamin F. Thomas 1830 (1874-1878) and Thomas Durfee 1846 (1879-1888) were all lawyers.<cite><a href="Chancellors.html">Chancellors</a></cite>
Colonel William Goddard 1846 (1888-1907) was a Providence manufacturer and merchant and an officer in the <a href="Civil War.html">Civil War</a>.<cite><a href="Chancellors.html">Chancellors</a></cite>
Arnold Buffum Chace 1866 (1907-1932) was a cotton manufacturer and Henry D. Sharpe 1894 (1932-1952) was president of Brown and Sharpe Manufacturing Company.<cite><a href="Chancellors.html">Chancellors</a></cite>
Harold B. Tanner ’09 (1952-1964) was a lawyer, H. Stanford McLeod ’16 (1964-1968) an investment banker, and Charles C. Tillinghast, Jr. ’32 (1968-1979) among other things president of Trans World Airlines.<cite><a href="Chancellors.html">Chancellors</a></cite>
Richard Salomon ’32 (1979-1988) was chief executive officer of Lanvin-Charles of the Ritz from 1936 to 1971 and chairman of the board of the New York Public <a href="Library.html">Library</a> from 1977 to 1988.<cite><a href="Chancellors.html">Chancellors</a></cite>
Way ’51, chancellor since 1988, is chairman of IBJ Schroder Bank and Trust Company.<cite><a href="Chancellors.html">Chancellors</a></cite>
The Vice-Chancellors of the University have been Donald G. Millar ’19 (1964-1968), Alfred H. Joslin ’35 (1968-1969), Foster B. Davis ’39 (1969-1979), Thomas J. Watson, Jr. ’37 (1979-1985), Henry D. Sharpe, Jr. ’45 (1985-1988) and Artemis A. W. Joukowsky ’55, since 1988.<cite><a href="Chancellors.html">Chancellors</a></cite>
The Laws of 1783 state: "On the ringing of the Bell for morning and evening prayers, all the members of the College shall immediately, without unnecessary noise repair to the hall, and behave with decency, during the time of the exercises.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
After 1834 the chapel was on the second floor of <a href="Manning Hall.html">Manning Hall</a>.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
In 1869 the rule regarding attendance at chapel every morning applied to all residing in the college or living within a mile, but allowed certain students within that radius who had no recitation after prayers to be excused.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
Compulsory chapel attendance on Sunday was abolished by <a href="President.html">President</a> Robinson soon after his arrival in 1872, and later he changed another rule, that students should attend public worship twice on Sunday, by announcing that "once was enough."<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
In 1890 the chapel was improved by "lady friends of the University," who furnished an organ and a carpet around the pulpit.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
By September 1892 there were too many students to attend chapel at once, and chapel attendance was made optional for the two upper classes.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
<a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a>, with a new organ installed in 1903, was eventually used.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
In 1906 Gene Wilder Ware ’06, who had been college organist as a student, became director of chapel music.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
From 1910 to 1931 he was organist and director.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
When <a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a> was in turn outgrown by the student body in 1923, only two of the classes could be accommodated at one time, and <a href="President.html">President</a> Faunce noted, "No longer can any officer or speaker on any occasion address the entire student body at once."<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
In 1911 a change was made, so that the women had regular chapel with gowned choir and seniors in procession on four days a week, but on Wednesday morning the service was replaced by a mass meeting of Student Government.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
In 1912, Blanche N. Davis succeeded Hamilton MacDougall and Lacey Baker as chapel director.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
She established a vested chapel choir in 1922, and also gave monthly organ recitals for the students and provided musical accompaniment as needed for other productions of the Women’s College.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
In 1927 the auditorium of <a href="Alumnae Hall.html">Alumnae Hall</a> provided a new home for the chapel exercises.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
Retiring in 1938 after 26 years as chapel director, Miss Davis recalled the early days of daily religious chapel services, when the women students were forbidden to bring books into the chapel or to talk above the top landing of <a href="Pembroke Hall.html">Pembroke Hall</a>, and the change to once a week exercises, the subjects of which went so far afield as a demonstration of fire apparatus.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
Chapel attendance became less popular, especially in the 1920s.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
S. J. Perelman ’25, in later life a well-known humorist, wrote in a letter to the "Brown Daily Herald:"  A committee on chapel services was appointed by <a href="President.html">President</a> Faunce in 1926 to improve the quality of chapel services.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
In 1927 daily attendance by all students was replaced by a plan in which three groups of students attended two mornings per week.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
In 1929 the "Brown Daily Herald," which advocated voluntary chapel in preference to compulsory chapel, recommended that the chapel services be reduced to three per week on consecutive days, in hope of a better planned program, so that students might be spared boring speakers or a pre-breakfast organ recital with no speaker at all.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
In 1930 <a href="President.html">President</a> Barbour cut chapel to two days a week, to be attended by freshmen and sophomores on Wednesday and by juniors and seniors on Thursday.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
In 1946, with the influx of students after the war, chapel was held three times a week with each student attending once.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
In 1958 each class met once a week in <a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a>, and women students met once a week in <a href="Alumnae Hall.html">Alumnae Hall</a>.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
The renovation of Manning Chapel in 1959 and its rededication for the purpose of voluntary worship brought about the reconsideration of compulsory chapel.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
The expected change was voted by the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> on May 30, 1959.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
When compulsory chapel ended in September 1959, it was replaced by a new program of bi-weekly College Convocations of a more secular character.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
Compulsory attendance at the convocations was discontinued for all but freshmen at Brown at the beginning of 1968-69, and in November 1968 the taking of attendance at Pembroke covocations was ended.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
The title of Chaplain was created in 1942 for Dr. Arthur L. Washburn, who for some years had been performing the duties of the office.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
He gave up his parish and began to teach modern languages at Brown in 1929.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
He became a Resident Counsellor in 1935 and Chaplain in 1942.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
When Washburn retired in 1947, his place was assumed by William J. Robbins, a Baptist minister, who joined the faculty of the Department of Biblical Literature and became its chairman in 1950.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
The Office of the Chaplain was created in 1952, and in July of that year Edgar C. Reckard, a Presbyterian minister, was appointed chaplain and assistant professor in the Department of <a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a>.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
Reckard was succeeded in 1958 by Charles A. Baldwin, a 1950 graduate of Illinois College with a Bachelor of Divinity degree from Yale, who came to Providence as assistant minister of Central Congregational Church.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
At the rededication in 1959 of Manning Chapel on the second floor of <a href="Manning Hall.html">Manning Hall</a>, Chancellor Harold Tanner announced that compulsory chapel would be discontinued in the fall of 1959.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
In 1954 Bishop John S. Higgins appointed Rev. Samuel Wylie the first full-time Episcopal chaplain to Brown and other local colleges, forming the Episcopal College Church.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
With his office at St. Stephen’s Church Reverend Wylie served until 1958, and was followed by Canon Crocker from 1959 to 1969, and Rev. Sheldon Flory from 1970 to 1974.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
In 1971 the Episcopal College Church merged with the Protestant congregation of Manning Chapel to form the University Church, which continued the services in St. Stephen’s.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
A difference over the ecumenical nature of the services caused the removal of the services to Manning Chapel in April 1974.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
Reverend David Ames became the new Episcopal chaplain in 1974 and brought the University Church back to St. Stephen’s in 1975, where it remained until 1980.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
Catholic priests Edward Mullen and Daniel Kehew served as chaplains before 1967, when Father Howard V. O’Shea became the first full-time Catholic chaplain.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
In 1975 Miriam Wolcott was the first laywoman to be a full-time Catholic chaplain in Rhode Island.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
Later Catholic chaplains were Rev. David Inman, who came in 1976 and Rev. Richard Perry since 1991.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
Sister of Mercy Mary Lomax came to supply the Catholic chaplaincy in 1983, while David Inman was acting director of student activities.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
Gwen Hofmann became a Catholic lay chaplain in 1989.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
Nancy Simons, who was director of religious activities at Pembroke, became assistant chaplain in 1965.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
Other chaplains who were appointed with special interest in women’s issues were Beverly Edwards, who was appointed a lay chaplain in 1969 and was ordained a minister of the United Church of Christ in 1976, Rabbi Cathy Felix appointed assistant chaplain in 1980, and Flora A. Keshgegian, an Episcopal priest, who was named associate chaplain in 1984.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
Julius Scott, an ordained minister of the Methodist Church, came to Brown in 1963 as executive secretary of the Brown Christian Association, became assistant chaplain in 1965, and was acting chaplain during Chaplain Baldwin’s leave of absence in 1965-66, and left in 1967 to become assistant director of the Southern Fellowships Fund for Negro colleges.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
Rev. Bennett Owens was acting chaplain of the Episcopal College Church during Canon Crocker’s leave in 1965-66.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
Richard A. Dannenfelser, a Presbyterian minister, became assistant chaplain in 1967 and associate chaplain in 1970.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
After he was terminated in 1980, when the staff of the Chaplain’s Office was reduced, he worked for a brief time in the office of the dean of student life.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
In 1971 Rabbi Richard Marker became an additional Jewish chaplain with his appointment financed by Brown, National Hillel, and the Jewish Federation in Providence.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
He was succeeded by Rabbi Alan C. Flam, who became director of Hillel and assistant chaplain in 1982.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
The first chaplain for minority students was Geoffrey Black, appointed in 1974.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
In 1968 Reverend Herbert O. Edwards, then an assistant in the <a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a> department, had informally served as a chaplain for black students.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
Later minority chaplains were Reverend Darryl Smaw, a Baptist minister appointed in 1978, and Daphne Wiggins, also a Baptist minister, from 1985 to 1991.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
In 1983 a report on the chaplaincy concluded that the position of coordinating chaplain should be established and supported by the University, and that the University seek funding for chaplains with special responsibilities.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
Chaplain Baldwin’s successor, Janet Cooper Nelson, ordained in the United Church of Christ, was appointed in 1990, becoming the first woman University Chaplain in the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a>.<cite><a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a></cite>
Charles Value Chapin (1856-1941), professor of physiology, was born in Providence on January 17, 1856.<cite><a href="Chapin, Charles V..html">Chapin, Charles V.</a></cite>
After graduation from Brown in 1876, Charles V. Chapin prepared for the study of medicine with Dr. G. D. Wilcox, a homeopathic physician in Providence.<cite><a href="Chapin, Charles V..html">Chapin, Charles V.</a></cite>
In 1877 Charles V. Chapin went to New York to study at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, and then at Bellevue Hospital Medical College, New York University, where he received his M.D. degree in 1879.<cite><a href="Chapin, Charles V..html">Chapin, Charles V.</a></cite>
Charles V. Chapin was house physician at Bellevue in 1879-80.<cite><a href="Chapin, Charles V..html">Chapin, Charles V.</a></cite>
In 1884 Charles V. Chapin was appointed superintendent of health in Providence, a post he held for forty-eight years.<cite><a href="Chapin, Charles V..html">Chapin, Charles V.</a></cite>
Meanwhile Charles V. Chapin was instructor in physiology at Brown from 1882 to 1886 and professor from 1886 to 1895, city registrar of Providence from 1889 to 1932, lecturer at Harvard Medical School in 1909, at Harvard-M.I.T. School for health officers from 1913 to 1922, and at Harvard School of Hygiene from 1923 to 1931.<cite><a href="Chapin, Charles V..html">Chapin, Charles V.</a></cite>
Charles V. Chapin began his teaching of the course in physiology at Brown in 1882 with a class of juniors.<cite><a href="Chapin, Charles V..html">Chapin, Charles V.</a></cite>
In 1885 the course was shortened to two hours per week and offered to sophomores, whose lack of preparation made Charles V. Chapin's teaching difficult.<cite><a href="Chapin, Charles V..html">Chapin, Charles V.</a></cite>
In 1889 the course was restored to the junior year, and after <a href="Delabarre, Edmund B..html">Edmund B. Delabarre</a> began to teach psychology in 1892, Chapin was able to drop the teaching of the nervous system.<cite><a href="Chapin, Charles V..html">Chapin, Charles V.</a></cite>
His title in 1892 was "Professor of Physiology and Director of Physical Culture" and Charles V. Chapin reported on gymnastics and sports.<cite><a href="Chapin, Charles V..html">Chapin, Charles V.</a></cite>
Charles V. Chapin was ill in 1892-93, and after his return, the physical culture title was dropped.<cite><a href="Chapin, Charles V..html">Chapin, Charles V.</a></cite>
Charles V. Chapin was named the first honorary member of Delta Omega Society, the honorary hygiene association, in 1927.<cite><a href="Chapin, Charles V..html">Chapin, Charles V.</a></cite>
Charles V. Chapin was awarded the Marcellus Hartley Gold Medal by the National Academy of Sciences in 1928, at the time one of eight men in the world to receive this medal.<cite><a href="Chapin, Charles V..html">Chapin, Charles V.</a></cite>
In 1930 Charles V. Chapin was the first recipient of the Sedgwick Memorial Medal, awarded by the American Public Health Association for distinguished service in public health work.<cite><a href="Chapin, Charles V..html">Chapin, Charles V.</a></cite>
Charles V. Chapin received the Susan Colver Rosenberger Medal in 1935.<cite><a href="Chapin, Charles V..html">Chapin, Charles V.</a></cite>
First, in lifting Providence from a condition of well nigh medieval squalor in 1884 – to the hygienic and sanitary perfection of today – and second, in the founding of our City Hospital and its later organization, in which Charles V. Chapin played so important part."<cite><a href="Chapin, Charles V..html">Chapin, Charles V.</a></cite>
In 1931 the Providence City Hospital was renamed Charles V. Chapin Hospital.<cite><a href="Chapin, Charles V..html">Chapin, Charles V.</a></cite>
Dr. Chapin died in Providence on January 31, 1941.<cite><a href="Chapin, Charles V..html">Chapin, Charles V.</a></cite>
The Charter under which Brown University is governed was laid before the General Assembly at its meeting in East Greenwich beginning on the last Monday in February in 1764.<cite><a href="Charter.html">Charter</a></cite>
The "Act for the Establishment of College or University within this Colony" was passed by the House of Magistrates on March 2, 1764, and the Upper House concurred on March 3.<cite><a href="Charter.html">Charter</a></cite>
The act was signed and sealed by the Governor, Samuel Ward, and the Secretary, Edward Thurston, at Newport on October 24, 1765.<cite><a href="Charter.html">Charter</a></cite>
The events which led to the granting of the Charter began in July 1763 when James Manning presented a plan for a college to a group of gentlemen in Newport.<cite><a href="Charter.html">Charter</a></cite>
This was done at the session of August 1763, at which time a copy was given by Capt.<cite><a href="Charter.html">Charter</a></cite>
The preamble to the Charter of 1764 sets forth the purposes of the institution:  One provision of the Charter, that of tax exemption for the faculty, became controversial in later years, was amended in 1863 and was gradually phased out after 1965.<cite><a href="Charter.html">Charter</a></cite>
In 1772 at a town meeting in Providence, it was decided that the term "all taxes" applied only to taxes due to the Colony and the town tax was collected from the president and one professor for the next two years.<cite><a href="Charter.html">Charter</a></cite>
In 1774 the assessors, one of whom was Joseph Brown, chose not to assess the president and professor, which action raised much dissent, but was sustained and continued to be followed.<cite><a href="Charter.html">Charter</a></cite>
The House passed an act on February 9, 1863, limiting the tax exemption to amounts up to $10,000, and the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> voted its compliance on February 11.<cite><a href="Charter.html">Charter</a></cite>
In June 1965 the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> set about the elimination of the $10,000 exemption by voting that "as a condition of appointment all who are appointed <a href="President.html">President</a> or full Professor effective July 1, 1966 or thereafter shall waive their right to Charter exemption from taxes on their property."<cite><a href="Charter.html">Charter</a></cite>
An attempt in the 1890s to tax real estate in downtown Providence, which was owned and rented for business by the University, was settled by a Supreme Court in 1897 that "the provision of the Charter in question is in full force and operation, and that the tax assessed upon the property ... was wholly illegal and void."<cite><a href="Charter.html">Charter</a></cite>
The subject came up again in 1944, when the tax assessors decided that the fraternity houses deeded to the University should be taxed as well as those which were still the property of the fraternities.<cite><a href="Charter.html">Charter</a></cite>
There was also a feeling that the University was beginning to hoard property, which led <a href="President.html">President</a> Wriston to explain that, despite the 1897 ruling, Brown had adopted a policy of not acquiring property as a real estate investment and of selling donated property not required for future construction at the earliest opportunity.<cite><a href="Charter.html">Charter</a></cite>
In 1909 a committee of nine unanimously recommended that changes should be made, but after referring the matter to the law committee and considering the legal problems, a majority of five supported pursuing changes in the Charter, while the a minority of four recommended waiting.<cite><a href="Charter.html">Charter</a></cite>
In 1915 a second such committee recommended "that no action be taken at the present time."<cite><a href="Charter.html">Charter</a></cite>
A third committee was appointed in 1924, with the result that an amendment to the Charter in 1926 provided that the number of trustees be increased from 36 to 42 and that there be no denominational requirement for the additional trustees.<cite><a href="Charter.html">Charter</a></cite>
Finally, in 1942, the third and latest amendment to the Charter stated that, "no denominational qualification shall be required to make any person eligible to hold the office of Trustee, Fellow, <a href="President.html">President</a>, Professor, Tutor, or other office in Brown University."<cite><a href="Charter.html">Charter</a></cite>
The manuscript of the original Act signed by the Clerk of Magistrates on March 2, 1764 and by the Secretary of the Upper House on March 3, is preserved in the State House.<cite><a href="Charter.html">Charter</a></cite>
On November 12, 1765 a committee of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> authorized that a copy of the Charter on parchment be made and deposited with the president and also that a tin box to keep it in be procured.<cite><a href="Charter.html">Charter</a></cite>
This Charter was later placed in a bank vault, which unfortunately was flooded during the hurricane of September 21, 1938.<cite><a href="Charter.html">Charter</a></cite>
Herman Burleigh Chase (1913-1984), professor of biology, was born in New Hampton, New Hampshire, on May 7, 1913.<cite><a href="Chase, Herman B..html">Chase, Herman B.</a></cite>
Herman B. Chase graduated from the New Hampton School in 1930 and from Dartmouth College in 1934.<cite><a href="Chase, Herman B..html">Chase, Herman B.</a></cite>
Herman B. Chase earned his Ph.D. degree at the University of Chicago in 1938.<cite><a href="Chase, Herman B..html">Chase, Herman B.</a></cite>
From 1938 to 1948 Herman B. Chase taught at the University of Illinois.<cite><a href="Chase, Herman B..html">Chase, Herman B.</a></cite>
In 1948 Herman B. Chase came to Brown as associate professor of biology.<cite><a href="Chase, Herman B..html">Chase, Herman B.</a></cite>
Herman B. Chase was promoted to professor in 1952 and given the title of Robert P. Brown Professor of Biology in 1960.<cite><a href="Chase, Herman B..html">Chase, Herman B.</a></cite>
Herman B. Chase was chairman of the Department of Biology from 1963 to 1965, and when the department became the Division of Biological and Medical Sciences, he served as Director of Biology from 1965 to 1967.<cite><a href="Chase, Herman B..html">Chase, Herman B.</a></cite>
In 1967 Herman B. Chase was named Director of the Institute for Health Sciences.<cite><a href="Chase, Herman B..html">Chase, Herman B.</a></cite>
After retiring in 1978 Herman B. Chase went back to New Hampton and for five years was chairman of the science department at the Sant Bani Ashram School.<cite><a href="Chase, Herman B..html">Chase, Herman B.</a></cite>
Herman B. Chase died on April 23, 1984 in New Hampton.<cite><a href="Chase, Herman B..html">Chase, Herman B.</a></cite>
Cheering for athletic teams and the need for a cheerleader was mentioned in the "<a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a>" in 1884, which noted, "The sympathy and approval of a college rung out in a ‘three-times-three’ does much in any inter-collegiate competition, to nerve the representatives of that college for a victorious struggle," and went on to suggest, "Is there any good reason why our men should not sit together and cheer together instead of dividing into four or five small groups, each keeping different time from the others?<cite><a href="Cheering.html">Cheering</a></cite>
Cheers were included in the student handbook for 1898-99, introduced because "On numerous occasions the college man is called upon to join in, or perhaps lead the cheering."<cite><a href="Cheering.html">Cheering</a></cite>
Before the football game with Dartmouth in November 1901, the <a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a>, fearing that Brown would be outcheered on its own field, held the first pre-game pep rally.<cite><a href="Cheering.html">Cheering</a></cite>
The Celebration Committee of the <a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a> took charge of the cheerleaders, and in 1911 introduced tryouts for members of the junior class.<cite><a href="Cheering.html">Cheering</a></cite>
The 1919 "<a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a>" pictured three varsity cheerleaders, wearing white v-necked sweaters and neckties.<cite><a href="Cheering.html">Cheering</a></cite>
The cheering squad grew from five in 1936 to seven in 1938 to nine in 1938, while adding acrobatices to their performance.<cite><a href="Cheering.html">Cheering</a></cite>
In the 1970s women joined the previously all male cheerleading squad.<cite><a href="Cheering.html">Cheering</a></cite>
Chemistry was taught at Brown for the first time in 1811, when Dr. William C. Bowen was engaged to lecture to the medical students, which he did until 1813.<cite><a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a></cite>
In 1817 John D’Wolf was appointed professor of chemistry.<cite><a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a></cite>
He had studied at Brown with the Class of 1806 and later studied with Dr. Robert Hare of Philadelphia.<cite><a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a></cite>
He continued to teach until the demise of the medical school in 1827.<cite><a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a></cite>
Chemistry was listed as a subject taught in the second term of senior year in the annual catalogue of 1828.<cite><a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a></cite>
The 1829-30 catalogue stated that the senior class "have used the treatise of Brande for a text-book," and the 1830-31 catalogue announced that the seniors had studied chemistry, among other subjects, under Professor Caswell, professor of mathematics and natural philosophy, using the treatise of Dr. Turner, and observing "experimental illustrations, twice or thrice a week, as the subject might demand."<cite><a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a></cite>
In 1833-34 George Ide Chace was appointed adjunct professor of mathematics and natural philosophy, and the next year professor of chemistry.<cite><a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a></cite>
In 1836 his title included also geology and physiology.<cite><a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a></cite>
When <a href="Rhode Island Hall.html">Rhode Island Hall</a> was built in 1840 to accommstudies, the first chemical laboratory was housed in the basement.<cite><a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a></cite>
In 1840-41 Chace gave lectures on chemistry which were open to the public in <a href="Rhode Island Hall.html">Rhode Island Hall</a>.<cite><a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a></cite>
The Newport Rogers Professorship of Chemistry was founded by a bequest of William Sanford Rogers in 1872.<cite><a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a></cite>
The first to hold this professorship was John Howard Appleton 1863, who was the founder and moving spirit of modern chemistry at Brown from 1865 until his retirement in 1914.<cite><a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a></cite>
Research in chemistry at Brown owes its start to the arrival of John C. Bucher in 1901.<cite><a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a></cite>
The first Ph.D. in chemistry was awarded in 1903.<cite><a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a></cite>
In 1910, when more students were taking chemistry, which was voluntary, than any other course except required <a href="English.html">English</a> and mathematics, a laboratory for beginners was opened to relieve laboratory space needed for advanced students.<cite><a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a></cite>
Bucher left Brown in 1918.<cite><a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a></cite>
The <a href="Metcalf Chemical Laboratory.html">Metcalf Chemical Laboratory</a> was built in 1922, a gift of Jesse H. Metcalf.<cite><a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a></cite>
The appointment of Dr. Charles A. Kraus as professor of chemistry and director of laboratories in 1924 brought a vigorous and dynamic leader to the department.<cite><a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a></cite>
In 1938 the <a href="Metcalf Research Laboratory.html">Metcalf Research Laboratory</a>, another gift from Mr. Metcalf, was built to Kraus’s specifications, with one exception – his idea that the top floor be used for dormitory space for graduate students did not appeal to <a href="President.html">President</a> Wriston and got his veto.<cite><a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a></cite>
After Professor Paul C. Cross became chairman in 1947, he recruited Professors James S. Coles, Robert H. Cole, and Donald F. Hornig, who had worked at the Woods Hole Oceanograhic Institution or at <a href="Los.html">Los</a> Alamos during the war.<cite><a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a></cite>
In 1952, Professor Coles left to become first president of Bowdoin College and then in 1968 president of the Research <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a>.<cite><a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a></cite>
In 1957 Professor Hornig left for Princeton.<cite><a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a></cite>
Professor Julian H. Gibbs arrived in 1960 and became an enthusiastic and active advocate for physical biochemistry at Brown.<cite><a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a></cite>
In 1979 he became president of Amherst College.<cite><a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a></cite>
He moved to M.I.T. in 1966 and to Stanford in 1979.<cite><a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a></cite>
In 1973 Professor Clapp and in 1974 Professor John O. Edwards received the Manufacturing Chemists Award for excellence in teaching chemistry, and in 1974 Professor Cole received the Irving Langmuir Prize, this country’s highest award in chemical physics, for his work in dielectrics.<cite><a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a></cite>
The problem was solved with the construction of the GeoChem building into which the departments of chemistry and geological sciences moved in 1982.<cite><a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a></cite>
The Child Study Center was established in 1967, as a result of a study begun ten years earlier, when Brown participated in the National Collaborative Project, which until 1974 collected information on 50,000 children from birth to the age of eight.<cite><a href="Child Study Center.html">Child Study Center</a></cite>
Churchill House at 155 Angell Street was built for the Rhode Island Women’s Club in 1907 and named for Elizabeth Kittredge Churchill, founder of the Club.<cite><a href="Churchill House.html">Churchill House</a></cite>
Later occupied by Katherine Gibbs School, the building was acquired by Brown in 1970.<cite><a href="Churchill House.html">Churchill House</a></cite>
In 1972 the Afro-American Society, the <a href="Afro-American Studies.html">Afro-American Studies</a> Program, and the Graduate Minority Association moved into the building.<cite><a href="Churchill House.html">Churchill House</a></cite>
William Farr Church (1912-1977), professor of history, was born in Monmouth, Illinois, on December 13, 1912.<cite><a href="Church, William F..html">Church, William F.</a></cite>
William F. Church graduated from Allegheny College in 1934 and earned his master’s degree in 1935 and his Ph.D. in 1939, both from Harvard.<cite><a href="Church, William F..html">Church, William F.</a></cite>
William F. Church served as instructor in history at Gettysburg College in 1940-41 and at the University of Kentucky in 1941-42.<cite><a href="Church, William F..html">Church, William F.</a></cite>
After army duty in World War II, William F. Church came to Brown as assistant professor of history in 1947 and was promoted to associate professor in 1948 and professor in 1951.<cite><a href="Church, William F..html">Church, William F.</a></cite>
In 1960 William F. Church was named Munro, Goodwin, Wilkinson Professor of History.<cite><a href="Church, William F..html">Church, William F.</a></cite>
Church, who specialized in French political thought and was known as "one of the handful of Richelieu scholars in the world," published "Constitutional Thought in Sixteenth Century France" in 1941, "The Greatness of Louis XIV: Myth or Reality?" in 1959, and "Richelieu and Reason of State" in 1973.<cite><a href="Church, William F..html">Church, William F.</a></cite>
William F. Church was ill for some time before his death on November 4, 1977, in Rumford, Rhode Island.<cite><a href="Church, William F..html">Church, William F.</a></cite>
A Civic <a href="Convocation.html">Convocation</a> was held on February 3, 1955 "to recognize the continuing and rewarding associations between the community and the University."<cite><a href="Civic Convocation.html">Civic Convocation</a></cite>
Excerpts from the diary of Henry S. Burrage 1861 recorded the events at Brown occasioned by the attack on Fort Sumter on April 12, 1861:  On the day before <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> in 1866 a tablet in memory of the twenty-one Union Brown men who died in the war was dedicated.<cite><a href="Civil War.html">Civil War</a></cite>
Leallyn Burr Clapp (1913-1988), professor of chemistry, was born in Paris, Illinois, on October 13, 1913.<cite><a href="Clapp, Leallyn B..html">Clapp, Leallyn B.</a></cite>
Leallyn B. Clapp graduated in 1935 from Eastern Illinois Teachers College, where he had majored in physics.<cite><a href="Clapp, Leallyn B..html">Clapp, Leallyn B.</a></cite>
Leallyn B. Clapp taught mathematics at Paris High School for three years while he saved money for graduate school at the University of Illinois where he earned a master’s degree in 1939 and a Ph.D. in 1941.<cite><a href="Clapp, Leallyn B..html">Clapp, Leallyn B.</a></cite>
Arriving at Brown in 1941 as instructor in chemistry, Leallyn B. Clapp taught year-round during the war for five years.<cite><a href="Clapp, Leallyn B..html">Clapp, Leallyn B.</a></cite>
Leallyn B. Clapp was promoted to assistant professor in 1945, associate professor in 1949, and professor in 1956.<cite><a href="Clapp, Leallyn B..html">Clapp, Leallyn B.</a></cite>
In 1947, at the urging of his department chairman, Paul Cross, Clapp was instrumental in revolutionizing the teaching of chemistry at Brown, when he began teaching organic chemistry to freshmen.<cite><a href="Clapp, Leallyn B..html">Clapp, Leallyn B.</a></cite>
In 1959 Leallyn B. Clapp became involved in an experiment called the Chemical Bond Approach, and was on leave in the fall of that year to work at Earlham College in Richmond, where he edited the first two editions of CBA, which was intended to revolutionize the teaching of chemistry in the secondary schools with a new approach which encouraged students to learn from their experiments in the laboratory and to think like chemists.<cite><a href="Clapp, Leallyn B..html">Clapp, Leallyn B.</a></cite>
Clapp was awarded the Manufacturing Chemists Association College Chemistry Teacher Award in 1973 and the American Chemical Society Award in Chemical Education in 1976.<cite><a href="Clapp, Leallyn B..html">Clapp, Leallyn B.</a></cite>
The Department of Chemistry held a symposium in Leallyn B. Clapp's name on the art of chemistry teaching in October 1982.<cite><a href="Clapp, Leallyn B..html">Clapp, Leallyn B.</a></cite>
Leallyn B. Clapp suffered a massive heart attack on November 28, 1988, and died while lecturing in Metcalf Auditorium.<cite><a href="Clapp, Leallyn B..html">Clapp, Leallyn B.</a></cite>
Benjamin Franklin Clarke (1831-1908), professor of mathematics and engineering, was born in Newport, Maine, on July 14, 1831.<cite><a href="Clarke, Benjamin Franklin.html">Clarke, Benjamin Franklin</a></cite>
Benjamin Franklin Clarke took a course at Bridgewater (Massachusetts) State Normal School, from which he graduated in 1855, to prepare himself for teaching.<cite><a href="Clarke, Benjamin Franklin.html">Clarke, Benjamin Franklin</a></cite>
Benjamin Franklin Clarke graduated in 1863 at the age of 32.<cite><a href="Clarke, Benjamin Franklin.html">Clarke, Benjamin Franklin</a></cite>
Benjamin Franklin Clarke was instructor in mathematics at Brown from 1863 to 1868, when he revived instruction in civil engineering and was appointed professor of mathematics and civil engineering.<cite><a href="Clarke, Benjamin Franklin.html">Clarke, Benjamin Franklin</a></cite>
In 1893 Benjamin Franklin Clarke was named professer of mechanical engineering.<cite><a href="Clarke, Benjamin Franklin.html">Clarke, Benjamin Franklin</a></cite>
In 1896-97 Clarke served as president "pro tempore" while President Andrews was in Europe.<cite><a href="Clarke, Benjamin Franklin.html">Clarke, Benjamin Franklin</a></cite>
After a leave of absence during which Benjamin Franklin Clarke traveled with his family through most of Europe and Egypt and Palestine, he served as president "ad interim" after the resignation of Andrews until President Faunce took office in 1899.<cite><a href="Clarke, Benjamin Franklin.html">Clarke, Benjamin Franklin</a></cite>
Clarke retired in 1904.<cite><a href="Clarke, Benjamin Franklin.html">Clarke, Benjamin Franklin</a></cite>
At the 1907 Commencement the Class of 1897 presented Benjamin Franklin Clarke's portrait by Frank W. Benson to the University.<cite><a href="Clarke, Benjamin Franklin.html">Clarke, Benjamin Franklin</a></cite>
Benjamin Franklin Clarke died of pneumonia in Providence on December 29, 1908, less than a week after the death of his wife.<cite><a href="Clarke, Benjamin Franklin.html">Clarke, Benjamin Franklin</a></cite>
Class Day was celebrated at Brown for the first time in 1856, although such a day had long been part of the life of other institutions.<cite><a href="Class Day.html">Class Day</a></cite>
The first Class Day was held on June 12, 1856, four weeks before the close of term.<cite><a href="Class Day.html">Class Day</a></cite>
Beginning in 1858 there were printed programs for Class Day.<cite><a href="Class Day.html">Class Day</a></cite>
In 1863 a Class Tree exercise was added to the festivities.<cite><a href="Class Day.html">Class Day</a></cite>
In 1866 began the custom of a promenade concert on the College Green before the class supper.<cite><a href="Class Day.html">Class Day</a></cite>
On Class Day 1867 the class in a difference of opinion was divided into those who attended the class supper and those who went for a boat cruise.<cite><a href="Class Day.html">Class Day</a></cite>
In 1868, the first year of <a href="President.html">President</a> Caswell’s administration, there was a levee at his house after the morning exercises, followed by addresses by Caswell and interim president George Ide Chace.<cite><a href="Class Day.html">Class Day</a></cite>
In 1878 a group of seniors held a reception in <a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a> and <a href="Manning Hall.html">Manning Hall</a>.<cite><a href="Class Day.html">Class Day</a></cite>
In 1882, a reception with dancing was held in the new <a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a>, and by 1886 the senior reception had become a dance.<cite><a href="Class Day.html">Class Day</a></cite>
Until 1867 Class Day was held on a Thursday in June, far from <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> which was held in the fall.<cite><a href="Class Day.html">Class Day</a></cite>
In 1870 <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> was moved to the last Wednesday in June.<cite><a href="Class Day.html">Class Day</a></cite>
Beginning in 1904 Class Day was held on Monday.<cite><a href="Class Day.html">Class Day</a></cite>
In 1897 the afternoon exercises on the front campus, consisting of the band concert, the addresses, the planting of the class tree, and the smoking of class pipes, became known as the "Under the Elms" exercises.<cite><a href="Class Day.html">Class Day</a></cite>
In 1915 there was concern that Class Day was turning into a fraternity day with seniors missing exercises to prepare for receptions in off-campus fraternity houses.<cite><a href="Class Day.html">Class Day</a></cite>
In 1928 the senior class was forced to give up the traditional midnight march down the hill to the class supper, as no establishment was available to serve them.<cite><a href="Class Day.html">Class Day</a></cite>
Class Day reverted to some old-time traditions in 1933.<cite><a href="Class Day.html">Class Day</a></cite>
In connection with the winter <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> in February 1943, the exercises and the dance took place in <a href="Alumnae Hall.html">Alumnae Hall</a>.<cite><a href="Class Day.html">Class Day</a></cite>
The last Class Day was held in 1961, when only about 125 seniors out of a class of 447 attended.<cite><a href="Class Day.html">Class Day</a></cite>
There had been a growing lack of interest for several years and the Class of 1962 was asked whether to continue Class Day.<cite><a href="Class Day.html">Class Day</a></cite>
No dance was held in 1970, to the dismay of many alumni.<cite><a href="Class Day.html">Class Day</a></cite>
When the dance was resumed in 1971, the seniors had lost interest, and the Alumni Office took over the running of the dance, at which seniors constituted only 15 per cent of the 4,200 attendance.<cite><a href="Class Day.html">Class Day</a></cite>
Classics was the mainstay of the course of studies, at least for the first two years, as set forth in the Laws of 1783, which prescribed, "for the first year in Latin, Virgil, Cicero’s Orations and Horace, all in usum Delphini.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
Asa Messer was professor of learned languages from 1790 to 1796 before he became president, and presumably continued in that capacity until Calvin Park was named to that professorship in 1804.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
Park’s title was changed in 1811 to professor of moral philosophy and metaphysics, but he also probably continued his usual instruction in languages, since no replacement was appointed until he left the University in 1825.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
Romeo Elton was professor of Latin and Greek languages and literature from 1825 to 1843, with Horatio Balch Hackett as adjunct professor from 1835 to 1838.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
James Robinson Boise taught Greek from 1843 to 1852, with the exception of 1850-51, when Hiram H. Perry served as lecturer.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
The two classics professors of long standing in the nineteenth century were John Larkin Lincoln, who taught Latin from 1844 until 1891, and Albert Harkness, who taught Greek from 1855 to 1892.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
Required courses in Greek ended in the sophomore year, but in 1856 an elective course in Greek was added in the junior year.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
In 1871 and again in 1876 seniors requested an elective course, which became a regular course in 1878.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
When Albert Harkness was granted a leave of absence to spend the year 1870-71 in Europe, two instructors were hired, William Carey Poland 1868 to teach Greek to the freshman and sophomore classes, and Alonzo Williams 1870 to teach Greek and Latin to the freshman class.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
In the second term of 1890-91 Thomas Chase, former president of Haverford College, taught Greek courses for seniors and juniors.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
The Class of 1888 as seniors donated funds for the acquisition of a collection of casts from Greek and Roman sculpture which was placed in a room on the first floor of <a href="Manning Hall.html">Manning Hall</a>.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
The Classical Seminary in <a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a> opened in 1891-92 with a library of books suited to advanced students.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
