Charles E. Bennett was professor of classical philology and instructor in Sanskrit in 1891-92.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
Professor Lincoln died in 1891, and Professor Albert Granger Harkness 1879 (son the professor of Greek) took over the instruction in Latin, which he continued until 1923.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
Professor Albert Harkness retired in 1892 and was replaced by James Irving Manatt, who was professor of Greek literature and history from 1892 to 1915.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
A coeducational Classical Club met at Professor Manatt’s house in the 1890s.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
There, in the spring of 1894, a cast of both men and women students preformed Sophocles’ "Antigone."<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
On November 31, 1897, a performance in Greek of "The Return of Odysseus" at <a href="Pembroke Hall.html">Pembroke Hall</a> included a hymn to Apollo, which had been discovered at Delphi by Professor Manatt.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
Francis Greenleaf Allinson was associate professor of Greek and classical philology from 1895 to 1898, after which he was the David Benedict Professor of Greek literature and history from 1898 to 1927.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
The first Ph.D. degree in Latin was earned in 1895 by Charles E. Dennis 1888, the first in Greek in 1899 by Frederick E. Whitaker 1888.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
In 1915 a Greek play, a modern version of Aristophanes’ "The Frogs" was performed by the <a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a>.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
In 1923, after the death of Albert Granger Harkness, the separate departments of Greek literature and history and Latin literature and history were joined together as Greek and Latin classics under Professor Allinson with Latin instruction by Associate Professor John F. Greene.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
In 1927 Kendall K. Smith, who had taught Greek at Brown since 1915, became head of Classics, a position which was assumed by Benjamin C. Clough after Smith’s death in 1929.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
In 1928 the department moved from lower Manning to the third floor of <a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a>.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
Charles Arthur Lynch and Charles Alexander Robinson, Jr. both arrived as instructors in 1927, and Herbert N. Couch came as assistant professor in 1930.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
The Latin or Greek requirement for the Bachelor of Arts degree was removed by vote of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> in 1934.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
The name of the department was changed in 1945 from Department of Greek and Latin Classics to Department of Classics.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
In 1948 the department presented the first of its very popular Latin Christmas Carol Services.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
Charles Alexander Robinson headed Brown’s first excavation program in Corinth in the summer of 1959.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
Later expeditions led by Professor R. Ross Holloway excavated a site in Athens in 1965 and commenced the excavation of Satrianum in Lucania in 1966.<cite><a href="Classics.html">Classics</a></cite>
The Class of 1887 Gate was designed by Hoppin and Ely and built by Norcross Brothers on Waterman Street in 1903.<cite><a href="Class of 1887 Gate.html">Class of 1887 Gate</a></cite>
The verse beside the gate was written by Theodore Francis Green 1887.<cite><a href="Class of 1887 Gate.html">Class of 1887 Gate</a></cite>
"Cleavage," subtitled "the Brown undergraduate journal of women’s studies," began as a project conceived by a collective of six undergraduate women in the fall of 1986 as a forum for art and scholarly works by Brown students in the area of women’s studies.<cite><a href="Cleavage.html">Cleavage</a></cite>
Clinton Harvey Currier (1876-1943), professor of mathematics and astronomy, was born in Manchester, New Hampshire, on January 1, 1876.<cite><a href="Clinton Harvey Currier.html">Clinton Harvey Currier</a></cite>
’He earned a bachelor of philosophy degree in 1898 and a master of arts in 1899 at Brown.<cite><a href="Clinton Harvey Currier.html">Clinton Harvey Currier</a></cite>
He became an instructor in mathematics at Brown in 1899, and was promoted to assistant professor in 1916 and associate professor in 1928.<cite><a href="Clinton Harvey Currier.html">Clinton Harvey Currier</a></cite>
He also taught astronomy from 1914 to 1932.<cite><a href="Clinton Harvey Currier.html">Clinton Harvey Currier</a></cite>
He was an instructor in mathematics at the <a href="Rhode Island School of Design.html">Rhode Island School of Design</a> from 1903 to 1909.<cite><a href="Clinton Harvey Currier.html">Clinton Harvey Currier</a></cite>
He was director of <a href="Ladd Observatory.html">Ladd Observatory</a> from 1921 to 1931, and wrote a monthly column on astronomy for the "Providence Journal.<cite><a href="Clinton Harvey Currier.html">Clinton Harvey Currier</a></cite>
"He organized volunteer groups in Rhode Island to observe the total eclipse in January 1925.<cite><a href="Clinton Harvey Currier.html">Clinton Harvey Currier</a></cite>
He was co-author of a textbook entitled "A Course in General <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a> "published in 1928.<cite><a href="Clinton Harvey Currier.html">Clinton Harvey Currier</a></cite>
Mason in 1930, Currier took over his duties in connection with admissions and advising the freshman class.<cite><a href="Clinton Harvey Currier.html">Clinton Harvey Currier</a></cite>
He became ill and took a leave of absence in 1931 in an attempt to regain his health.<cite><a href="Clinton Harvey Currier.html">Clinton Harvey Currier</a></cite>
He returned, but became ill again in 1936 and retired in 1938.<cite><a href="Clinton Harvey Currier.html">Clinton Harvey Currier</a></cite>
He died on January 5, 1943, in Providence.<cite><a href="Clinton Harvey Currier.html">Clinton Harvey Currier</a></cite>
"Clio," subtitled "A journal of history," appeared in the fall of 1974, announcing that "CLIO is an autonomous organization affiliated with the <a href="History.html">History</a> Department of Brown University and the Brown University <a href="History.html">History</a> Society," committed to the publication of outstanding and controversial works of historical scholarship by Brown undergraduates.<cite><a href="Clio.html">Clio</a></cite>
The winter 1980 issue appeared in a new larger format with one more article added to the usual four.<cite><a href="Clio.html">Clio</a></cite>
Benjamin Crocker Clough (1889-1975), professor of English and classics, was born in Tisbury on the island of Martha’s Vineyard on November 19, 1889.<cite><a href="Clough, Benjamin C..html">Clough, Benjamin C.</a></cite>
Benjamin C. Clough went "off island" to continue his education at Harvard, where he received his A.B. degree in 1911, his A.M. in 1918, and his Ph.D. in 1921 for a study of the writings of John Donne.<cite><a href="Clough, Benjamin C..html">Clough, Benjamin C.</a></cite>
Benjamin C. Clough served as assistant in the English Department at Brown from 1913 to 1915, instructor from 1915 to 1917 and again from 1920 to 1922, and was promoted to assistant professor in 1922.<cite><a href="Clough, Benjamin C..html">Clough, Benjamin C.</a></cite>
Benjamin C. Clough left the English Department for Classics in 1924 as assistant professor of Greek and Latin classics, and became associate professor in 1926, head of the Classics Department in 1929, and David Benedict professor in 1930.<cite><a href="Clough, Benjamin C..html">Clough, Benjamin C.</a></cite>
Benjamin C. Clough published "The American Imagination at Work," an anthology of folk tales, and "Tall Tales and Folk Tales," both in 1947.<cite><a href="Clough, Benjamin C..html">Clough, Benjamin C.</a></cite>
Benjamin C. Clough retired in 1949.<cite><a href="Clough, Benjamin C..html">Clough, Benjamin C.</a></cite>
Benjamin C. Clough died on August 30, 1975 in Smithfield, Rhode Island.<cite><a href="Clough, Benjamin C..html">Clough, Benjamin C.</a></cite>
Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences became a department in 1986, with Sheila Blumstein as its first chairperson.<cite><a href="Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences.html">Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences</a></cite>
Formerly collaboration between the Department of Cognitive Sciences and the Center for Neural Sciences had been fostered by the Institute for Cognitive and Neural Research, which was created in May 1981.<cite><a href="Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences.html">Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences</a></cite>
The Center for Cognitive Science was established in 1977 under the direction of Richard Millward, professor of psychology, with funding from the Sloan Foundation.<cite><a href="Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences.html">Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences</a></cite>
The Center for Neural Studies began in 1973 to study animal central nervous systems and the human brain.<cite><a href="Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences.html">Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences</a></cite>
In 1978 it became the Center for Neural Sciences, with faculty members from the Departments of <a href="Psychology.html">Psychology</a>, Linguistics, <a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a>, <a href="Physics.html">Physics</a>, Applied <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a>, and Biomedical Science, to facilitate interdisciplinary research projects.<cite><a href="Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences.html">Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences</a></cite>
Linguistics became important at Brown with the appointment of Hans Kurath as professor of German in 1930.<cite><a href="Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences.html">Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences</a></cite>
The headquarters of the Atlas moved to Brown in 1932, and six volumes of the New England Atlas were published with the imprint of the University.<cite><a href="Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences.html">Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences</a></cite>
The staff of the Linguistic Atlas held a series of conferences at Brown in the summer of 1934.<cite><a href="Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences.html">Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences</a></cite>
Kurath was chairman of the German Department from 1931 to 1941, and chairman of the Division of <a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a> from 1941 until his resignation in 1946 to become professor of <a href="English.html">English</a> and editor of the Middle <a href="English.html">English</a> Dictionary at the University of Michigan.<cite><a href="Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences.html">Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences</a></cite>
An undergraduate honors concentration program in linguistics was introduced in 1957.<cite><a href="Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences.html">Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences</a></cite>
The Department of Linguistics was established in 1960, and offered master’s and Ph.D. degrees.<cite><a href="Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences.html">Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences</a></cite>
In 1959 Professor Henry Kucera was working on comparing the phonological structures of several languages.<cite><a href="Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences.html">Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences</a></cite>
When the computing center opened in 1960 Kucera taught a course in computational linguistics.<cite><a href="Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences.html">Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences</a></cite>
W. Nelson Francis, whose field was the structure and history of the <a href="English.html">English</a> language, joined the department in 1962 and was appointed chairman in 1968.<cite><a href="Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences.html">Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences</a></cite>
In 1962 five Egyptian teachers of <a href="English.html">English</a> came to Brown for two years of graduate study as part of a program, financed by the Rockefeller Foundation and the State Department, in which Brown, Cornell and the University of Texas cooperated to improve the teaching of <a href="English.html">English</a> in the United Arab Republic.<cite><a href="Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences.html">Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences</a></cite>
In 1965 Brown joined with the University of Texas and Cornell University in a project supported by the Ford Foundation to establish a modern language laboratory in Cairo to improve the teaching of <a href="English.html">English</a>.<cite><a href="Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences.html">Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences</a></cite>
Also in 1965 the Brown-Tougaloo Language Project was begun under the direction of W. Nelson Francis with support from the Rockefeller Foundation.<cite><a href="Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences.html">Cognitive and Linguistic Sciences</a></cite>
The Colgate Hoyt Pool was built in 1903 adjoining the Lyman Gymnasium at an estimated cost of $35,000, a welcome gift of Colgate Hoyt, whose sons attended Brown.<cite><a href="Colgate Hoyt Pool.html">Colgate Hoyt Pool</a></cite>
The pool was opened on March 2, 1903, at which time Colgate Hoyt, Jr. ’05 was the first to jump from the diving board into the water.<cite><a href="Colgate Hoyt Pool.html">Colgate Hoyt Pool</a></cite>
In 1947 a major reconstruction in the pool was provided by an anonymous donor.<cite><a href="Colgate Hoyt Pool.html">Colgate Hoyt Pool</a></cite>
The pool was still inadequate and, after much waiting, a new pool was built in 1973.<cite><a href="Colgate Hoyt Pool.html">Colgate Hoyt Pool</a></cite>
The space occupied by the pool was transformed into the Ashamu Dance Studio in 1979.<cite><a href="Colgate Hoyt Pool.html">Colgate Hoyt Pool</a></cite>
Rosalie Littell Colie (1924-1972), professor of comparative literature and first woman department chairman, was born in New York City in 1924.<cite><a href="Colie, Rosalie L..html">Colie, Rosalie L.</a></cite>
Rosalie L. Colie received a bachelor of arts degree from Vassar College in 1944, a master of arts from Columbia in 1946 and a Ph.D. in English and history from Columbia in 1950.<cite><a href="Colie, Rosalie L..html">Colie, Rosalie L.</a></cite>
Rosalie L. Colie was an instructor at Douglass College in 1948-49, and an assistant and associate professor at Barnard College and Columbia from 1949 to 1961.<cite><a href="Colie, Rosalie L..html">Colie, Rosalie L.</a></cite>
Rosalie L. Colie was associate professor at Wesleyan College from 1961 to 1963, professor at the University of Iowa from 1963 to 1966, visiting professor at Yale in 1966-67 and visiting research professor at Oxford University in 1967-68.<cite><a href="Colie, Rosalie L..html">Colie, Rosalie L.</a></cite>
After a year at the University of Toronto Rosalie L. Colie came to Brown in 1969 as professor of English and comparative literature, and was the first to hold the <a href="Lewis, Nancy Duke.html">Nancy Duke Lewis</a> Professorship, the first professorship at Brown endowed for women, which had been established in 1967.<cite><a href="Colie, Rosalie L..html">Colie, Rosalie L.</a></cite>
In January 1972 Rosalie L. Colie received the first appointment of a woman to the chairmanship of an academic department at Brown, the Department of Comparative Literature.<cite><a href="Colie, Rosalie L..html">Colie, Rosalie L.</a></cite>
This occurred only months before Rosalie L. Colie's brilliant academic career was cut short by her untimely death on July 7, 1972, in an accident in which her canoe overturned in the Lieutenant River in Old Lyme, Connecticut.<cite><a href="Colie, Rosalie L..html">Colie, Rosalie L.</a></cite>
Rosalie L. Colie's published works included "Some Thankfulness to Constantine: A Study of English Influence upon the Work of Constantine Huygens" in 1956, "Light and Enlightenment: A Study of the Cambridge Platonists and the Dutch Arminians" in 1957, and "Paradoxia Epidemica" in 1966.<cite><a href="Colie, Rosalie L..html">Colie, Rosalie L.</a></cite>
College and University presidents who have been educated at Brown include nine of the presidents of Brown: Jonathan Maxcy 1787, who was also the president of Union College and the University of South Carolina; Asa Messer 1790; Barnas Sears 1825, who had formerly been the president of Newton Theological Seminary; Alexis Caswell 1822; Ezekiel Gilman Robinson 1838, who had been president of Rochester Theological Seminary; Elisha Benjamin Andrews 1870, who had been president of Denison University and was later chancellor of the University of Nebraska; William Herbert Perry Faunce 1880; and Clarence Augustus Barbour 1888, who had also been president of Rochester Theological Seminary.<cite><a href="College and University Presidents.html">College and University Presidents</a></cite>
Six graduates have been president of Colby College; Jeremiah Chaplin 1799, Rufus Babcock 1821, Eliphaz Fay 1821, James Tifft Champlin 1834, Charles Lincoln White 1887, and Benaiah Longley Whitman 1887.<cite><a href="College and University Presidents.html">College and University Presidents</a></cite>
Abiel Bolles 1808 and Jasper Adams 1815 were president of the College of Charleston.<cite><a href="College and University Presidents.html">College and University Presidents</a></cite>
Two presidents of the University of Vermont have been Brown alumni, Willard Preston 1806 and James Burrill Angell 1849.<cite><a href="College and University Presidents.html">College and University Presidents</a></cite>
Willbur Fisk 1815 was president of Wesleyan University.<cite><a href="College and University Presidents.html">College and University Presidents</a></cite>
Horace Mann 1819 was the first president of Antioch College.<cite><a href="College and University Presidents.html">College and University Presidents</a></cite>
George Whitefield Samson 1839 and Benaiah Longley Whitman 1887 were both president of Columbian College (George Washington University).<cite><a href="College and University Presidents.html">College and University Presidents</a></cite>
Justin Rolph Loomis 1835 was president of the University at Lewisburg (Bucknell University).<cite><a href="College and University Presidents.html">College and University Presidents</a></cite>
Edward Hicks Magill 1852 was president of Swarthmore College.<cite><a href="College and University Presidents.html">College and University Presidents</a></cite>
Benjamin Ide Wheeler 1876 was president of the University of California.<cite><a href="College and University Presidents.html">College and University Presidents</a></cite>
Inman Page 1877, one of first black graduates, was president of Lincoln University, Oklahoma Agricultural and Normal University, Western Baptist College, and Roger Williams University.<cite><a href="College and University Presidents.html">College and University Presidents</a></cite>
Hermon Carey Bumpus 1884 was president of Tufts College.<cite><a href="College and University Presidents.html">College and University Presidents</a></cite>
Alexander Meiklejohn 1893 was president of Amherst College.<cite><a href="College and University Presidents.html">College and University Presidents</a></cite>
The Class of 1894 had three college presidents among its graduates.<cite><a href="College and University Presidents.html">College and University Presidents</a></cite>
John Hope 1894 was president of Morehouse College and Atlanta University; John William Beverly 1894 was president of Alabama State Normal School; and Mary Emma Woolley 1894 was president of Mount Holyoke College.<cite><a href="College and University Presidents.html">College and University Presidents</a></cite>
Presidents of Rhode Island colleges have been John Lincoln Alger 1890 of Rhode Island College of <a href="Education.html">Education</a>, and Frank Newman ’46 of the University of Rhode Island.<cite><a href="College and University Presidents.html">College and University Presidents</a></cite>
Brown men who were college presidents in foreign countries are Josiah Nelson Cushing 1862 of the Baptist College in Rangoon, Albert Arnold Bennett 1872 of the Baptist Theological Seminary of Japan, Wilbur Brown Parshley 1886 of Yokohama Theological Seminary, and Francois Jacobus de Villiers of Dower College, South Africa.<cite><a href="College and University Presidents.html">College and University Presidents</a></cite>
The  College Color, brown, the obvious choice as it would appear today, was not adopted until after 1866, when the "<a href="Brown Paper.html">Brown Paper</a>" reported on the question of choosing a college color, "the general opinion seems to be that "brown" should be adopted ...<cite><a href="College color.html">College color</a></cite>
The color brown, of course, has dominated the athletic uniforms for years, and indeed might be considered more "sober" than the first known uniform of a Brown team, that of the crew in 1859, which was described as "gray check pants; salmon silk shirts; blue skull caps."<cite><a href="College color.html">College color</a></cite>
In 1925 the University submitted a swatch of brown material to the Textile Color Card Association of the United States, Inc. to ascertain its exact shade (which proved to be Tobacco), and at that time the University colors were recorded by the Association, apparently mistakenly, as brown and white.<cite><a href="College color.html">College color</a></cite>
In 1947 the brightening up of the football uniforms by the addition of gold brought forth letters of both approval and disapproval to the "Alumni Monthly."<cite><a href="College color.html">College color</a></cite>
In December 1952, after the subject of the drabness of the Brown academic hoods, black lined with brown, came to attention, <a href="President.html">President</a> Wriston appointed Vice-<a href="President.html">President</a> Bruce Bigelow a "Committee of one to pick official colors for Brown University and to put it over."<cite><a href="College color.html">College color</a></cite>
On the recommendation of this committee, on April 9, 1954, the Advisory and Executive Committee of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> voted, "That the University adopt as the standard colors for the lining of all its academic hoods, seal brown with a single chevron of cardinal red similar to the red in the cross of the University coat-of arms."<cite><a href="College color.html">College color</a></cite>
In 1967, the colors, official or not, were noted for the first time in the football media guide as "seal brown and cardinal."<cite><a href="College color.html">College color</a></cite>
The "College Hill Independent," a weekly newspaper published by students of Brown University and the <a href="Rhode Island School of Design.html">Rhode Island School of Design</a>, made its first appearance on February 1, 1990.<cite><a href="College Hill Independent.html">College Hill Independent</a></cite>
In 1953-54 Jane Baltzell ’55, Thomas McCormick ’54, Judith Thorsen ’55, and Caleb Woodhouse ’54 ended the eight game winning streak of the University of Minnesota, and went on to defeat Michigan, Georgetown, Ohio State, Trinity, and Maryland, and to lose to Smith College in their seventh match.<cite><a href="College Quiz Bowl.html">College Quiz Bowl</a></cite>
In January 1968 Northwestern and Brown were invited to participate in a tenth-anniversary rematch, from which Brown returned with the victory and $10,000 in scholarship money.<cite><a href="College Quiz Bowl.html">College Quiz Bowl</a></cite>
John Reeves, an Englishman, was a provider of fruit and confections on the campus, who came to Providence as a boy around 1804, and after a life of many vicissitudes on sailing ships and adventures as a servant in China, came back to Providence in the late 1850s.<cite><a href="College servants.html">College servants</a></cite>
For about twenty years in his well-known stove-pipe hat he presided over a three-level tin box filled with confections from the catering business of Lewis H. Humphrey, the proprietor of the City Hotel, and only gave up his post on the chapel steps in 1878, at an estimated age of ninety.<cite><a href="College servants.html">College servants</a></cite>
He began selling food on the chapel steps in 1884, having paid five dollars to a former peddler named Asberry Neal, who had been in the business for seven years and was now leaving town, for the opportunity to replace him.<cite><a href="College servants.html">College servants</a></cite>
Captain "Cap" Cameron, the Scotsman, was the night patrol from about 1904.<cite><a href="College servants.html">College servants</a></cite>
He was joined in 1919 by Sergeant Briggs, the daytime officer who came to Brown after 27 years with the Providence police.<cite><a href="College servants.html">College servants</a></cite>
Bernard Hand, who came from Ireland and served in the Providence Police Department from 1902 to 1939, was the friendly campus policeman at Brown from 1939 to 1949, who "had a way with boys" and kept them out of trouble.<cite><a href="College servants.html">College servants</a></cite>
Nelson Lambert, "Nels" of <a href="Faunce House.html">Faunce House</a>, was born in Guadaloupe in 1885, worked in ships traveling to Japan and China, Australia, and Europe, and lived and worked for a time in New Caledonia and Tahiti.<cite><a href="College servants.html">College servants</a></cite>
He came to Providence, and several generations of alumni had fond memories of him as the janitor at <a href="Faunce House.html">Faunce House</a> from 1909 (when it was still Rockefeller Hall) until his retirement in 1952.<cite><a href="College servants.html">College servants</a></cite>
The College Venture Program began in 1974 as a pilot program financed by the Braitmayer Foundation to help students who needed or wanted to drop out of college temporarily.<cite><a href="College Venture Program.html">College Venture Program</a></cite>
After the pilot program was incorporated as a non-profit organization and Susan Stroud was named director, the operation moved to Brown University in 1978 at her request.<cite><a href="College Venture Program.html">College Venture Program</a></cite>
Theodore Collier (1874-1963), professor of history, was born in Montville, New Jersey, on July 9, 1874.<cite><a href="Collier, Theodore.html">Collier, Theodore</a></cite>
Theodore Collier received a bachelor’s degree in 1894 and a master’s degree in 1897, both from Hamilton College.<cite><a href="Collier, Theodore.html">Collier, Theodore</a></cite>
Theodore Collier studied at Union Theological Seminary from 1899 to 1902 and at the Universities of Berlin and Marburg in 1903-04.<cite><a href="Collier, Theodore.html">Collier, Theodore</a></cite>
Theodore Collier earned his Ph.D. degree from Cornell in 1907.<cite><a href="Collier, Theodore.html">Collier, Theodore</a></cite>
Theodore Collier was at Williams College from 1905 to 1911 as instructor and later assistant professor of history, and came to Brown in 1911 as associate professor.<cite><a href="Collier, Theodore.html">Collier, Theodore</a></cite>
Theodore Collier was professor of European history from 1917 to 1923, professor of history and international relations from 1923 to 1944, and head of the Department of History from 1917 to 1939.<cite><a href="Collier, Theodore.html">Collier, Theodore</a></cite>
Theodore Collier served with the Y.M.C.A overseas service in France in 1918-19.<cite><a href="Collier, Theodore.html">Collier, Theodore</a></cite>
Theodore Collier also taught at summer sessions at Middlebury College, Clark University and Columbia University, and during the academic year 1924-25 was a visiting professor at Constantinople College.<cite><a href="Collier, Theodore.html">Collier, Theodore</a></cite>
From the time of his arrival at Brown until 1918 his name was listed among the faculty as "Theodore Frelinghuysen Collier."<cite><a href="Collier, Theodore.html">Collier, Theodore</a></cite>
In the early 1930s Theodore Collier traveled in Europe, observing political, economic, and social conditions, and frequently lectured on these topics.<cite><a href="Collier, Theodore.html">Collier, Theodore</a></cite>
When Theodore Collier retired from Brown in 1944 at the age of 70, he said that what he would miss most was "the direct contact and association with young minds which is the great delight and reward of a teacher’s life."<cite><a href="Collier, Theodore.html">Collier, Theodore</a></cite>
In 1945 Theodore Collier became a professor of business at Rollins College in Florida, remaining in that position until 1952.<cite><a href="Collier, Theodore.html">Collier, Theodore</a></cite>
Theodore Collier died on April 9, 1963 in Tryon, North Carolina.<cite><a href="Collier, Theodore.html">Collier, Theodore</a></cite>
James Franklin Collins (1863-1940), professor of botany, was born in North Anson, Maine, on December 29, 1863.<cite><a href="Collins, James Franklin.html">Collins, James Franklin</a></cite>
James Franklin Collins went to work at an early age for the Gorham Manufacturing Company, where he was employed from 1879 to 1898.<cite><a href="Collins, James Franklin.html">Collins, James Franklin</a></cite>
James Franklin Collins never attended college, but in 1894 he was placed in charge of the Olney Herbarium at Brown on the recommendation of Bailey.<cite><a href="Collins, James Franklin.html">Collins, James Franklin</a></cite>
In 1896 James Franklin Collins was awarded an honorary bachelor of philosophy degree, and in 1899 he was appointed instructor in botany.<cite><a href="Collins, James Franklin.html">Collins, James Franklin</a></cite>
In 1905 James Franklin Collins was named assistant professor of botany and the next year became acting head of the department after Bailey’s retirement.<cite><a href="Collins, James Franklin.html">Collins, James Franklin</a></cite>
After four summers spent investigating the chestnut blight for the U.S. Department of Agriculture James Franklin Collins resigned his professorship in 1911 to become forest pathologist in the Providence bureau of the Department’s Office of Forest Pathologist, which had its headquarters in University Hall.<cite><a href="Collins, James Franklin.html">Collins, James Franklin</a></cite>
A pamphlet which James Franklin Collins wrote in 1907 advocating flexible wood or sawdust rather than concrete fillings for injured trees sold 200,000 copies and won him the wrath of commercial tree surgery companies.<cite><a href="Collins, James Franklin.html">Collins, James Franklin</a></cite>
James Franklin Collins had begun contributing to the "Botanical Gazette" in 1886 and wrote 122 books and articles on botanical subjects.<cite><a href="Collins, James Franklin.html">Collins, James Franklin</a></cite>
Collins retired from his government position in 1934 at the age of seventy.<cite><a href="Collins, James Franklin.html">Collins, James Franklin</a></cite>
James Franklin Collins died in Cranston, Rhode Island, on November 14, 1940.<cite><a href="Collins, James Franklin.html">Collins, James Franklin</a></cite>
Stephen Sheldon Colvin (1869-1923), professor of educational psychology, was born in Phenix, Rhode Island, on March 29, 1869.<cite><a href="Colvin, Stephen S..html">Colvin, Stephen S.</a></cite>
Stephen S. Colvin prepared for college at Worcester Academy and graduated from Brown with a bachelor of philosophy degree in 1891.<cite><a href="Colvin, Stephen S..html">Colvin, Stephen S.</a></cite>
Stephen S. Colvin was awarded a master of arts degree upon examination in 1894.<cite><a href="Colvin, Stephen S..html">Colvin, Stephen S.</a></cite>
During these years of study Stephen S. Colvin also reported for the "Providence Journal" and the "Evening Telegram" and taught rhetoric at Brown from 1892 until 1895, when he went to study at the Universities of Berlin and Strasburg.<cite><a href="Colvin, Stephen S..html">Colvin, Stephen S.</a></cite>
Stephen S. Colvin's thesis for his Ph.D. at Strasburg in 1897 was "Schopenhauer’s Doctrine of the Thing-in-Itself and his Attempt to Relate it to the World of Phenomena."<cite><a href="Colvin, Stephen S..html">Colvin, Stephen S.</a></cite>
Stephen S. Colvin taught English at Worcester Academy from 1897 to 1901, and continued his studies under G. Stanley Hall at Clark University, becoming interested in educational psychology.<cite><a href="Colvin, Stephen S..html">Colvin, Stephen S.</a></cite>
From 1901 to 1903 Stephen S. Colvin was assistant professor of psychology at the University of Illinois.<cite><a href="Colvin, Stephen S..html">Colvin, Stephen S.</a></cite>
When Stephen S. Colvin came back to Brown in 1912 he was the first professor of educational psychology.<cite><a href="Colvin, Stephen S..html">Colvin, Stephen S.</a></cite>
In 1919 Stephen S. Colvin was also named director of the School of Education.<cite><a href="Colvin, Stephen S..html">Colvin, Stephen S.</a></cite>
Stephen S. Colvin published "The Learning Process" in 1911, "Human Behavior" with William C. Bagley in 1913, and "Introduction to High School Teaching," an extensively used teacher-training text-book, in 1917.<cite><a href="Colvin, Stephen S..html">Colvin, Stephen S.</a></cite>
Colvin left Brown in 1923 to become professor of education at Teachers College, Columbia, where he had taught during the summer.<cite><a href="Colvin, Stephen S..html">Colvin, Stephen S.</a></cite>
Stephen S. Colvin died suddenly from a heart ailment on July 15, 1923 in New York City.<cite><a href="Colvin, Stephen S..html">Colvin, Stephen S.</a></cite>
Commencement was first held on September 7, 1769 at the Baptist Church in Warren.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
In 1770 the college moved to Providence, where the next five Commencements were held in Mr. Snow’s Meeting House.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
There was no Commencement in 1775 by request of the students, who were deeply affected by the battles of Lexington and Concord.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
In 1776 Commencement was held for the first time in the First Baptist Meeting House.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
The college was closed from December 1776 to May 1782, and no Commencements were held, although degrees were granted in 1777 and 1782.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
The first Commencement after the Revolution was held in 1783, but again the next two years there were no students ready for graduation.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
Annual Commencements began again in the Baptist Church in 1786, and their traditional conviviality returned to the point that in 1790 the College asked the General Assembly to have the Sheriff of the County of Providence attend future Commencements "to preserve the peace, good order, and decorum," which he still does.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
In 1787 it was decreed that the assignment of the Salutatory oration should be made by the <a href="President.html">President</a>, the assignment of the valedictory and intermediate orations by the class, and that of the Syllogistic and Forensic Disputes by the president and tutors.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
Since 1776 all but two Commencements have been celebrated in the First Baptist Meeting House.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
In 1804 Commencement was held in the First Congregational Church to accommodate the seniors who wished to "have the benifit (sic) of the Organ."<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
In 1832 Commencement was again held in the First Congregational Church while the Meeting House was being repaired  The Commencement of 1835 was poorly attended, as twenty-one members of the class, protesting the distribution of the speaking "parts," refused to receive their diplomas, leaving only three graduates.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
Commencement in 1836 was much better, even outshining Harvard’s, according to the description in Benjamin Waterhouse’s diary: "September 7th.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
The traditional day for Commencement was the first Wednesday in September, but was changed in 1851 and 1852 to the second Wednesday in July, a change which proved unpopular enough for the date to be returned to September in 1853.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
The "Providence Journal" reported in 1853 that it was now "quite possible to remain out of the city until after Commencement, a thing that was never thought of before," and in 1860 the "Journal" did not carry its usual announcement, "This being Commencement, no paper will be issued from this office to-morrow."<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
The time of Commencement was changed in 1870 to the last Wednesday in June, and again in 1875 to the third Wednesday in June.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
In 1928, in another change designed to increase alumni attendance by scheduling the activities around a weekend, Commencement began to be held on the third Monday in June, preceded by <a href="Class Day.html">Class Day</a> on Friday, class reunions on Saturday, Baccaulaureate on Sunday, and followed by the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> meeting on Tuesday.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
In 1950 the annual Commencement was moved to the first Monday in June, where it remained until the latest change of date to the last Monday in May, when Memorial Day is also celebrated.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
In 1887-88 the annual catalogue announced a plan for the selection of the speakers, in which a number of students, up to three-fifths of the class, were appointed by rank to submit orations.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
In 1891-92 it was decided that every member of the graduating class was entitled to submit an oration.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
From 1895 to 1936 the winner of the Gaston Prize was entitled to be a speaker at Commencement.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
In 1932 it was voted that the names of the graduates would no longer be written in Latin on their diplomas.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
Another change in diplomas occured in 1940, when a new six by eight inch diploma in a leather folder with the Latin phrases printed replaced the traditional 19 by 15 inch scroll-like diploma with the words in script.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
In 1942 Commencement was held in May, and during the war years, up until 1946, Commencement was held three times a year, in June, October, and February, as students graduated under the accelerated program.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
At a winter Commencement held in February 1943 the graduates assembled at the <a href="Rhode Island School of Design.html">Rhode Island School of Design</a> building opposite the <a href="First Baptist Church.html">First Baptist Church</a> and marched across the street through the snow.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
After the war Commencement exercises were held at the end of first semester in 1949-50 in the <a href="Faunce House.html">Faunce House</a> Theater and in 1950-51 in <a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a> to accommodate graduates finishing their courses in midyear.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
The awarding of degrees on the College Green began in 1947.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
The first occasion when weather interfered with the outdoor exercises was 1969, when rain caused a change of site to <a href="Meehan Auditorium.html">Meehan Auditorium</a>.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
"An Hour with the <a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a>" was added to the Commencement activities in 1956 and featured talks by two faculty members each year.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
The Commencement of 1970 was different, coming after a spring when student strikes protested the invasion of Cambodia and the killing of four Kent State students by National Guard troops during a protest.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
There were other changes in the 1970 Commencement.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
The person most honored by the seniors was Professor Barrett Hazeltine, who was cited in 1972 and every year after that, until 1977, when he was declared the first member of the "Senior Class Hall of Fame," for persons who received the citation five times.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
The Commencement Forums began in 1970 following the student strike in May.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
At the 1973 Commencement for the first time both of the student orators were women, Mary E. Moore and Suzanne Nolan.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
The Pops Concert was first held on the Pembroke <a href="Campus.html">Campus</a> on the Saturday of the Commencement Weekend in 1965 to celebrate the closing of Brown’s bicentennial year.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
A major change in 1978 involved the traditional line of march.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
In 1984 the date was changed once more, this time to the last Monday in May, which is also the observance of Memorial Day.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
In 1987 the procession was accompanied for the first time by the playing of bag pipes.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
When Henry V. A. Joslin 1867 was chief marshal for 27 years in 1916, his aides presented him with a loving cup in honor of his long and efficient services.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
Rose 1881 took his place from 1917 to 1931, when he was relieved of the post at his own request.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
The first woman to serve as chief marshal was Doris Brown Reed ’27, who led the procession in 1977.<cite><a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a></cite>
The menu, as prescribed by the Laws of 1783, provided a main meal which varied to include during each week two meals of salt beef or pork, two meals of fresh meat, one meal of soup and fragments, one meal of boiled meat, and one meal of fish, accompanied by "good small Beer or Cyder."<cite><a href="Commons.html">Commons</a></cite>
That this ideal behavior did not prevail is evident from a letter written by George W. Keely 1824 to his father in June 1820:<cite><a href="Commons.html">Commons</a></cite>
Comparative Literature began as an honors program for undergraduates in 1961, added a master of arts program in 1963, and admitted Ph.D. candidates in 1965.<cite><a href="Comparative Literature.html">Comparative Literature</a></cite>
In 1967 the Department of Comparative Literature was established with Professor Juan López-Morillas as chairman.<cite><a href="Comparative Literature.html">Comparative Literature</a></cite>
Computer Science came to Brown in 1956 under the wing of the Applied <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a> Division, when an IBM card-programmed calculator (CPC) which could be fed 150 punched cards a minute was installed.<cite><a href="Computer Science.html">Computer Science</a></cite>
In the fall of 1956 the applied mathematics course in practical analysis considered the history, theory and use of high-speed computers, and students in economics were introduced to the accounting and statistical applications of the computer.<cite><a href="Computer Science.html">Computer Science</a></cite>
In January 1958 a new IBM650 Data Processing System (the only one of its kind between Hartford and Boston) was installed in the Applied <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a> building.<cite><a href="Computer Science.html">Computer Science</a></cite>
The <a href="Computing Laboratory.html">Computing Laboratory</a> on George Street with its IBM7070 computer opened in 1961.<cite><a href="Computer Science.html">Computer Science</a></cite>
Since 1965 faculty members specializing in computer science, Andries van Dam, John Savage and Peter Wegner, were hired to develop the computer science program, and in 1975 there was a Program in Computer Science under the direction of the computer science faculty.<cite><a href="Computer Science.html">Computer Science</a></cite>
The Department of Computer Science was established in 1979.<cite><a href="Computer Science.html">Computer Science</a></cite>
In 1979 the department moved into <a href="Kassar House.html">Kassar House</a>, to which were added in 1982 the Gould Laboratory and the Foxboro Auditorium, the first electronic workstation-based classroom.<cite><a href="Computer Science.html">Computer Science</a></cite>
Also in 1982 the department was awarded a three million dollar five-year National Science Foundation grant to provide workstations and staff.<cite><a href="Computer Science.html">Computer Science</a></cite>
The new five-story Thomas J. Watson, Sr. <a href="Center for Information Technology.html">Center for Information Technology</a> was opened in 1988.<cite><a href="Computer Science.html">Computer Science</a></cite>
TheComputing Laboratory at 180 George Street, a gift of the widow and son of Thomas J. Watson, Sr., was dedicated in his memory on January 12, 1961.<cite><a href="Computing Laboratory.html">Computing Laboratory</a></cite>
The IBM7070 computer which it was built to house, the first of this system installed on the Eastern seaboard, was acquired through a grant from the National Science Foundation and the generosity of the IBM <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a>.<cite><a href="Computing Laboratory.html">Computing Laboratory</a></cite>
After the opening of the <a href="Center for Information Technology.html">Center for Information Technology</a> in 1988, the Computing Laboratory building was reassigned for the use of the Applied <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a> Division.<cite><a href="Computing Laboratory.html">Computing Laboratory</a></cite>
The words on the plaque placed in the Brown University Computing Laboratory in 1987 are, "given by Thomas J. Watson, Jr. ’37, son, and Jeannette K. Watson, wife, in honor of Thomas J. Watson, Sr., who, from the days of the punched card tabulators to the first years of the computer era, led IBM, as chairman, to the creation of machines that would attack the great problems of science and mathematics previously out of the reach of human capability."<cite><a href="Computing Laboratory.html">Computing Laboratory</a></cite>
"Confrontation" was a periodical which appeared for only two issues in 1967.<cite><a href="Confrontation.html">Confrontation</a></cite>
A Convocation entitled "Man’s Contracting World in an Expanding Universe" was held from October 21 to 23, 1959, in <a href="Marvel Gymnasium.html">Marvel Gymnasium</a>.<cite><a href="Convocation.html">Convocation</a></cite>
The house was built by George H. Corliss during the years 1875 to 1882.<cite><a href="Corliss-Brackett House.html">Corliss-Brackett House</a></cite>
He was born in Easton, New York, in 1817.<cite><a href="Corliss-Brackett House.html">Corliss-Brackett House</a></cite>
He came to Providence in 1844, hoping to get financial backing for his newly invented sewing machine (for which he had received his first patent on December 27, 1843) and to acquire some machine shop experience.<cite><a href="Corliss-Brackett House.html">Corliss-Brackett House</a></cite>
Corliss became president of the firm which employed him and by 1848 had invented a fuel-saving cut-off that revolutionized the steam engine.<cite><a href="Corliss-Brackett House.html">Corliss-Brackett House</a></cite>
In 1876 his famed "Centennial Engine," 776 tons, 40 feet high on a platform 56 feet in diameter, was transported on seventy-one flat cars to Philadelphia to provide the power for the fourteen-acre Machinery Hall at the country’s Centennial Exposition.<cite><a href="Corliss-Brackett House.html">Corliss-Brackett House</a></cite>
He gave the house to Brown in 1955, with a life tenancy for himself.<cite><a href="Corliss-Brackett House.html">Corliss-Brackett House</a></cite>
The house was renovated for use by the admission office in 1973.<cite><a href="Corliss-Brackett House.html">Corliss-Brackett House</a></cite>
The Corporation created by the <a href="Charter.html">Charter</a> in 1764 consisted of two branches, the Trustees and the Fellows.<cite><a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a></cite>
An Executive Board, composed of conservative members and entrusted with some of the functions which the <a href="Charter.html">Charter</a> had reserved for the Board of Fellows, was created in 1850.<cite><a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a></cite>
In 1863 the University also created a committee of public lands to be responsible for the agricultural lands assigned to the University as a result of the Morrill Act in 1862.<cite><a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a></cite>
The <a href="Charter.html">Charter</a> was amended in 1926 to add six trustees, to be chosen without regard to religious affiliation, bringing the number of trustees to 42.<cite><a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a></cite>
In 1942 another amendment removed all denominational requirements for Corporation members.<cite><a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a></cite>
In 1927 Nettie Goodale Murdock ’95 and Magel Wilder ’19 addressed a letter to the Corporation suggesting that women should be represented.<cite><a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a></cite>
The Corporation replied on October 21, 1927 that "the time had not arrived for the election of a woman to membership."<cite><a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a></cite>
At the Corporation meeting in June 1928 it was voted to add an alumna to the Executive Committee of the Women’s College.<cite><a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a></cite>
The first woman member of the Corporation was Anna Canada Swain ’11, who was chosen as a term trustee in 1949.<cite><a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a></cite>
In 1965 for the first time a Pembroke alumna was nominated for a membership on the Board of Trustees under a new agreement between the <a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a> and the Pembroke <a href="Alumnae Association.html">Alumnae Association</a>.<cite><a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a></cite>
The method of fulfilling this ratio after the initial four women were elected was the provision that after 1970 two alumni would be elected each year and one alumnae would be elected in four out of every five years.<cite><a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a></cite>
The first elected alumna trustee was Elizabeth Goodale Kenyon ’39 in 1965.<cite><a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a></cite>
Appointed to the Board of Fellows in 1969 were first woman member, Doris Brown Reed ’27, who had been a term trustee since 1963, the first African-American member, Jay Saunders Redding ’28, and the first Jewish member, Alfred Joslin H. ’35  Although the <a href="Charter.html">Charter</a> provided that a trustee or fellow may hold his office "during life or until resignation," the Corporation has chosen to impose some limitations on the length of terms.<cite><a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a></cite>
Until 1981 the Fellows were elected for life.<cite><a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a></cite>
Since 1981 they have been elected for eleven year terms and are eligible for reelection.<cite><a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a></cite>
The Secretaries of the Corporation have been Thomas Eyres from 1764 to 1776; Thomas Arnold 1771 from 1776 to 1780; David Howell from 1780 to 1806; Samuel Eddy 1787 from 1806 to 1829; Nathan Bourne Crocker from 1829 to 1837; Theron Metcalf 1805 from 1837 to 1843; William Giles Goddard 1812 from 1843 to 1846; Nathan Bourne Crocker from 1846 to 1853; John Kingsbury 1826 from 1853 to 1874; Samuel Lunt Caldwell from 1875 to 1889; Thomas D. Anderson 1874 from 1890 to 1924; Hermon Carey Bumpus 1884 from 1924 to 1937; Albert L. Scott 1900 from 1937 to 1945; Fred B. Perkins ’19 from 1945 to 1963; John Nicholas Brown from 1963 to 1972; Alfred H. Joslin ’35 from 1972 to 1982; Ruth Burt Ekstrom  ’53 from 1982 to 1988; and Henry D. Sharpe, Jr. ’45 since 1988.<cite><a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a></cite>
The cricket club he formed fielded a team of six seniors, four juniors, and a sophomore in 1957.<cite><a href="Cricket.html">Cricket</a></cite>
The short-lived cricket experiment ended with the departure of Chorley in 1957.<cite><a href="Cricket.html">Cricket</a></cite>
An earlier brief encounter had taken place in 1862, when the Brown "Paper "announced, "We are glad to record the appearance among us of a new game ...<cite><a href="Cricket.html">Cricket</a></cite>
The Crucible was a club formed in 1910 at the Women’s College to discuss "serious problems of interest to college women."<cite><a href="Crucible.html">Crucible</a></cite>
The club came to be viewed as too exclusive, even by the members, who voted in 1917 to reorganize as a subcommittee of the College Forum and relinquished their separate existence in 1918.<cite><a href="Crucible.html">Crucible</a></cite>
Public speaking was of utmost importance as students in college were often preparing themselves for the ministry or the law, and the Laws of 1783 saw to it that the students were not lacking in practice:  By a vote of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> in 1830 students could be admitted to the "partial course" without registering to study for a degree.<cite><a href="Curriculum.html">Curriculum</a></cite>
By 1846 there were 72 special students enrolled, at which time an attempt was made to attract more students by introducing "The <a href="English.html">English</a> and Scientific Course," which could be taken for one or for two years.<cite><a href="Curriculum.html">Curriculum</a></cite>
Between 1846 and 1849 22 students had entered the course.<cite><a href="Curriculum.html">Curriculum</a></cite>
On March 28, 1850 <a href="President.html">President</a> Francis Wayland presented his famous "Report to the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> of Brown University on Changes in the System of Collegiate <a href="Education.html">Education</a>.<cite><a href="Curriculum.html">Curriculum</a></cite>
After 1855 the examinations were dropped.<cite><a href="Curriculum.html">Curriculum</a></cite>
Barnas Sears, who succeeded Wayland as president, noted in his annual report of 1856 that "the character &amp; reputation of the University are injuriously affected by the low standard of scholarship required for the degrees of A.M. &amp; A.B.... We are now literally receiving the refuse of other colleges.<cite><a href="Curriculum.html">Curriculum</a></cite>
In 1857 the "old system" was to a certain extent resumed.<cite><a href="Curriculum.html">Curriculum</a></cite>
<a href="President.html">President</a> Ezekiel Gilman Robinson, arriving in 1872, found the curriculum inadequate to meet the needs of the time and the community.<cite><a href="Curriculum.html">Curriculum</a></cite>
The school Robinson envisioned was not established at Brown, but the founding of the <a href="Rhode Island School of Design.html">Rhode Island School of Design</a> in 1877 provided some of the subjects, and there were new offerings in physiology, botany, and astronomy at Brown.<cite><a href="Curriculum.html">Curriculum</a></cite>
The minimum passing mark was raised from 25 to 50 per cent in 1875, and holders of scholarships were expected to achieve a grade of 75 per cent.<cite><a href="Curriculum.html">Curriculum</a></cite>
With the advent of the Bachelor of Science degree in 1891, the course of instruction for the Bachelor of Arts degree was altered so that after a freshman year filled with required studies (Greek, Latin, French, and mathematics) chosen for the disciplinary value, the required courses for sophomore, junior, and senior years were limited to subjects (<a href="English.html">English</a>, German, history, and philosophy) "the pursuit of which is deemed necessary for all students who are to be recommended for a collegiate degree.<cite><a href="Curriculum.html">Curriculum</a></cite>
Changes were made in the curriculum for students entering in 1902 or thereafter.<cite><a href="Curriculum.html">Curriculum</a></cite>
As <a href="President.html">President</a> Faunce wrote in his annual report in 1917, "It is obvious that one of the by-products of the Great War is to be a more urgent insistence that all study hereafter shall be focused directly on equipment for life."<cite><a href="Curriculum.html">Curriculum</a></cite>
For students entering in 1919 or thereafter a concentration requirement for the degrees of Bachelor of Arts and Bachelor of <a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a> was introduced.<cite><a href="Curriculum.html">Curriculum</a></cite>
The next major curricular revision occurred in 1937.<cite><a href="Curriculum.html">Curriculum</a></cite>
"Vagabonding" was informally developed in 1939 to allow students to drop in and hear lectures of interest in courses in which they were not registered.<cite><a href="Curriculum.html">Curriculum</a></cite>
In 1939 he recommended a four-course plan.<cite><a href="Curriculum.html">Curriculum</a></cite>
On December 12, 1941 a Division of National Defense Training Courses was established with Professors Walter Hunter and Edwin Kretzmann in charge.<cite><a href="Curriculum.html">Curriculum</a></cite>
The "New Curriculum" of 1947 had two main functions – to give every student a stock of basic knowledge and to teach the student to think in different ways.<cite><a href="Curriculum.html">Curriculum</a></cite>
When the first comprehensive examinations were given in the spring of 1940, a considerable number of seniors received an "unsatisfactory" grade, which did not prevent them from receiving their degrees, and six failed the examinations and did not graduate.<cite><a href="Curriculum.html">Curriculum</a></cite>
Collaborative research at Brown got a boost in 1988 from a $750,000 grant from the Ford Foundation, which, when matched by $1.5 million from Brown, would be used to interest more students, especially minority students, in academic careers to meet the impending shortage of new college teachers, and to bring new ideas into Brown’s curriculum.<cite><a href="Curriculum.html">Curriculum</a></cite>
In November 1984 this group of students and faculty began to meet with the administration to try to find solutions to the racial issues which finally brought about the protests in the spring of 1985, which were led by two of the four minority students in the Spectrum group.<cite><a href="Curriculum.html">Curriculum</a></cite>
With the passage of time the "New Curriculum" of 1969 has become known as the "Brown Curriculum."<cite><a href="Curriculum.html">Curriculum</a></cite>
In 1988 the faculty voted to change the number of courses required for graduation from 28 to thirty.<cite><a href="Curriculum.html">Curriculum</a></cite>
When the number of courses was reduced in 1969, it was expected that students would continue to take 32 courses.<cite><a href="Curriculum.html">Curriculum</a></cite>
<a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> Sheila Blumstein’s report, "The Brown Curriculum Twenty Years Later, "presented in February 1990, found the 1969 New Curriculum a success.<cite><a href="Curriculum.html">Curriculum</a></cite>
Lindsay Todd Damon (1871-1940), professor of English, was born in Brookline, Massachusetts, on November 8, 1871.<cite><a href="Damon, Lindsay Todd.html">Damon, Lindsay Todd</a></cite>
Lindsay Todd Damon graduated in 1894 from Harvard, where he remained as assistant in English from 1894 to 1896.<cite><a href="Damon, Lindsay Todd.html">Damon, Lindsay Todd</a></cite>
After a year as instructor in English at Brown, Lindsay Todd Damon held the same position at the University of Chicago until 1901, when he returned to Brown as associate professor of rhetoric.<cite><a href="Damon, Lindsay Todd.html">Damon, Lindsay Todd</a></cite>
Lindsay Todd Damon became professor of English in 1905 and succeeded to head of the English Department in 1927 on the retirement of Professor <a href="Bronson, Walter C..html">Walter C. Bronson</a>.<cite><a href="Damon, Lindsay Todd.html">Damon, Lindsay Todd</a></cite>
Damon retired in 1936.<cite><a href="Damon, Lindsay Todd.html">Damon, Lindsay Todd</a></cite>
Lindsay Todd Damon died on May 6, 1940 in the Hyde Park Hotel in New York City.<cite><a href="Damon, Lindsay Todd.html">Damon, Lindsay Todd</a></cite>
S(amuel) Foster Damon (1893-1971), professor of English, was born in Newton, Massachusetts, on February 12, 1893.<cite><a href="Damon, Samuel Foster.html">Damon, Samuel Foster</a></cite>
In 1914 Samuel Foster Damon graduated from Harvard, where he majored in music and was captain of the fencing team for two years.<cite><a href="Damon, Samuel Foster.html">Damon, Samuel Foster</a></cite>
After the war Samuel Foster Damon was an instructor in the English Department at Harvard and earned a master of arts degree in 1926.<cite><a href="Damon, Samuel Foster.html">Damon, Samuel Foster</a></cite>
Damon was to become one of the world’s leading authorities on Blake, publishing "A New Page in Blake’s Milton" in 1925, "Blake’s Grave" in 1963, "A Blake Dictionary" in 1965, and two texts to accompany Blake’s illustrations for the Book of Job, "The Doctrine of Job" in 1950, and "Blake’s Job" in 1966.<cite><a href="Damon, Samuel Foster.html">Damon, Samuel Foster</a></cite>
Samuel Foster Damon traveled to London in 1955 to be the guest of honor at the annual William Blake dinner.<cite><a href="Damon, Samuel Foster.html">Damon, Samuel Foster</a></cite>
He came to Brown in 1927, where he joined his cousin, <a href="Damon, Lindsay Todd.html">Lindsay Todd Damon</a>, in the English Department as assistant professor.<cite><a href="Damon, Samuel Foster.html">Damon, Samuel Foster</a></cite>
Samuel Foster Damon was promoted to associate professor in 1930, and professor in 1936.<cite><a href="Damon, Samuel Foster.html">Damon, Samuel Foster</a></cite>
Samuel Foster Damon's play, "The Witch of Dogtown," which won the Russel Crouse award, was produced in Gloucester, Massachusetts, in 1955.<cite><a href="Damon, Samuel Foster.html">Damon, Samuel Foster</a></cite>
Under the pseudonym "Samuel Nomad" he published in 1964 a book of 66 sonnets (from beyond the grave) entitled "Nightmare Cemetery."<cite><a href="Damon, Samuel Foster.html">Damon, Samuel Foster</a></cite>
Samuel Foster Damon also wrote published in 1971 "The Moulton Tragedy, a heroic poem with lyrics," which he had been writing since 1928 and of which a number of excerpts had been printed since the 1930s in "Poetry" magazine and other periodicals.<cite><a href="Damon, Samuel Foster.html">Damon, Samuel Foster</a></cite>
In 1968 the University published "William Blake: Essays for S. Foster Damon," and celebrated his seventy-fifth birthday with a two-day festival in 1968, during which Damon read from his poems, a music professor played Damon’s compositions, and students performed parts of Damon’s play, "Witch of Dogtown," and a seminar on Blake was held.<cite><a href="Damon, Samuel Foster.html">Damon, Samuel Foster</a></cite>
He also received an honorary Litt.D. degree from Brown in 1968, awarded with a citation which began: Damon died on December 25, 1971 in Smithfield, Rhode Island.<cite><a href="Damon, Samuel Foster.html">Damon, Samuel Foster</a></cite>
The Dante bust in front of the John Hay <a href="Library.html">Library</a>, the work of sculptor Pablo S. Abbate, was unveiled on December 9, 1921 at ceremonies attended by General Diaz of Italy.<cite><a href="Dante.html">Dante</a></cite>
On November 5, 1921 Brown had observed the anniversary of Dante’s death with exercises in <a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a>.<cite><a href="Dante.html">Dante</a></cite>
The Rhode Island Grand Lodge, Sons of Italy had earlier established in August 1921 four scholarships at Brown to be known as the Dante scholarships and awarded to young men who had made good progress in the study of Italian.<cite><a href="Dante.html">Dante</a></cite>
Nathaniel French Davis (1847-1921), professor of mathematics, was born in Laconia, New Hampshire, on June 11, 1847.<cite><a href="Davis, Nathaniel F..html">Davis, Nathaniel F.</a></cite>
Nathaniel F. Davis entered Brown from Williston Academy in Easthampton, New York, and graduated in 1870.<cite><a href="Davis, Nathaniel F..html">Davis, Nathaniel F.</a></cite>
In 1874 Nathaniel F. Davis returned to Brown as instructor in mathematics, and was promoted to assistant professor in 1879, associate professor in 1889, and professor of pure mathematics in 1890.<cite><a href="Davis, Nathaniel F..html">Davis, Nathaniel F.</a></cite>
Nathaniel F. Davis studied at the University of Göttingen in 1892-93.<cite><a href="Davis, Nathaniel F..html">Davis, Nathaniel F.</a></cite>
Nathaniel F. Davis retired in 1915, and died on May 17, 1921 in Cambridge, Massachusetts.<cite><a href="Davis, Nathaniel F..html">Davis, Nathaniel F.</a></cite>
James Quayle Dealey (1861-1937), professor of social and political science, was born in Manchester, England, on August 13, 1861.<cite><a href="Dealey, James Q..html">Dealey, James Q.</a></cite>
At the age of 17 James Q. Dealey joined two older brothers employed by the "Galveston News," and worked in various capacities at the newspaper until 1884, when he decided to resume his education.<cite><a href="Dealey, James Q..html">Dealey, James Q.</a></cite>
James Q. Dealey prepared at Cook Academy in Montour Falls, New York, and graduated from Brown in 1890.<cite><a href="Dealey, James Q..html">Dealey, James Q.</a></cite>
The next year James Q. Dealey was professor of languages and history at Denton Normal College in Texas, and from 1891 to 1893 he taught Latin at Vermont Academy.<cite><a href="Dealey, James Q..html">Dealey, James Q.</a></cite>
James Q. Dealey received his master’s degree from Brown in 1893 for study in Greek and German, and became an instructor in Latin at Brown.<cite><a href="Dealey, James Q..html">Dealey, James Q.</a></cite>
Changing his field to political and social studies, James Q. Dealey earned his Ph.D. from Brown in 1895, after which he was appointed assistant professor of social and political science.<cite><a href="Dealey, James Q..html">Dealey, James Q.</a></cite>
James Q. Dealey was promoted to associate professor in 1898 and full professor in 1910.<cite><a href="Dealey, James Q..html">Dealey, James Q.</a></cite>
James Q. Dealey was chairman of the Department of Political and Social Science from 1910 until his retirement in 1928.<cite><a href="Dealey, James Q..html">Dealey, James Q.</a></cite>
James Q. Dealey also served as lecturer at the Naval War College from 1916 to 1928, and during the first World War was the liaison officer between the University and the War Department.<cite><a href="Dealey, James Q..html">Dealey, James Q.</a></cite>
In 1921-22, in connection with Brown-in-China, James Q. Dealey spent a semester teaching at Shanghai College.<cite><a href="Dealey, James Q..html">Dealey, James Q.</a></cite>
In 1905 James Q. Dealey published "Textbook of Sociology" with <a href="Ward, Lester F..html">Lester Ward</a>, whom he helped to bring to Brown in 1906.<cite><a href="Dealey, James Q..html">Dealey, James Q.</a></cite>
James Q. Dealey also published "The Development of the States" in 1909, "The Family in its Sociological Aspects" in 1912, "Growth of the State Constitutions" in 1915, "State and Government" in 1921, "Foreign Policies of the United States" in 1926, and "Political Situations in Rhode Island" in 1928.<cite><a href="Dealey, James Q..html">Dealey, James Q.</a></cite>
In 1928 James Q. Dealey retired and returned to Texas, where he became editor-in-chief of the "Dallas News," of which his brother George was president.<cite><a href="Dealey, James Q..html">Dealey, James Q.</a></cite>
James Q. Dealey remained in that capacity until his sudden death on January 22, 1937, which occurred while he was at his desk conferring with his brother.<cite><a href="Dealey, James Q..html">Dealey, James Q.</a></cite>
The Dean of the University was an office established by the Advisory and Executive Committee in December 1899 to relieve the president of routine and disciplinary work.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
The first dean was Winslow Upton, who resigned in 1901 for health reasons.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
Alexander Meiklejohn was dean from 1901 to 1912, and concerned himself with scholastic achievement, attendance, athletic activities, and social life of the students.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
Otis Randall, who followed Meiklejohn, was dean until 1930.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
After a year as acting dean in 1929-1930, Samuel T. Arnold was given the title of Dean of Undergraduates.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
In 1937 his title was changed to Dean of the College.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
There was no Dean of the University until 1946, when Arnold assumed that office.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
Robert W. Kenny was Dean of the College from 1947 to 1952.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
In 1949 Arnold was named <a href="Provost.html">Provost</a> and there was no Dean of the University.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
In the 1950s and 60s the deanery at Brown became known as a training ground for college presidents.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
The five Deans of the College who became college presidents were: James Stacy Coles, acting dean of the College for one year when he became president of Bowdoin College in 1952; Brown president Barnaby Keeney, acting dean in 1952-53 and dean from 1953 to 1955; K. Roald Bergethon, acting dean in 1955-56 and dean from 1956 to 1958, who went to Lafayette College; Charles H. Watts II ’47, dean from 1958 to 1962, who became president of Bucknell; and Robert W. Morse, dean from 1962 to 1964, who became president of Case Western Reserve University.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
In 1964 the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> created the post of Dean of the University again and Merton P. Stoltz was named to the office.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
In 1965 at a junior convocation <a href="President.html">President</a> Barnaby Keeney in a speech on campus communication had occasion to discuss the function of deans.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
Robert O. Schulze was the Dean of the College from 1964 to 1968, followed by F. Donald Eckelmann from 1968 to 1971.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
The position of Dean of the College was reestablished in 1974 with Thomas F. Bechtel, who had been Dean of Counseling, as acting dean, followed by Walter Massey from 1975 to 1979, Harriet Sheridan from 1979 to 1987, Sheila Blumstein from 1987 to 1997, Nancy Dunbar from 1998 through December 2000, and Paul Armstrong from January 2001 through June 2006.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
Katherine Bergeron served as dean from July 2006 through December 2013, when she became president of Connecticut College.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
[Updated October 17, 2013]  Maurice Glicksman occupied two deanships at the same time.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
An engineer and physicist who had been on the faculty since 1969 and had served as chairman of the <a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a> Policy Group, he was appointed Dean of the <a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a> in 1974, and in 1975 was also named Acting Dean of the <a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a> and Academic Affairs, succeeding Jacqueline A. Mattfeld, who had held that position since 1974, and had previously been Dean of Academic Affairs from 1971 to 1974.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
Glicksman served in both capacities until he was named <a href="Provost.html">Provost</a> and Dean of the <a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a> in 1978.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
John Quinn was Dean of the <a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a> from 1986 to 1989, followed by Thomas J. Anton in 1990-1991, and Bryan E. Shepp since 1991.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
The office of Dean of Freshmen was created in 1922 and held by William Russell Burwell from 1922 to 1926, and Kenneth O. Mason from 1926 until his death in 1930.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
The office of Dean of Students was held by Bruce M. Bigelow from 1943 to 1946, Robert W. Kenny from 1946 to 1947, Edward R. Durgin to 1952 to 1962, and John M. Robinson from 1979 to 1988.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
James E. Dougherty was Dean of Student Affairs between 1970 and 1975.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
The office of Dean of Student Life was created in 1979 and held by Eric Widmer until 1988.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
John M. Robinson, who became Dean of Students in 1979, was Dean of Student Life from 1988 to 1990.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
Eric Widmer was acting dean from January to December of 1991, when Robin L. Rose was appointed.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
Louis Franklin Snow was named first Dean of the Women’s College in 1892 and served until 1900, when Anne Crosby Emery was appointed.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
She resigned in 1905 to marry Professor Francis Greenleaf Allinson.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
Lida Shaw King, was dean from 1905 to 1922, and resigned because of illness.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
Anne Crosby Emery Allinson was acting dean in 1920-1921 and again in 1922-1923.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
In 1923 Margaret Shove Morriss was named Dean of the Women’s College.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
After the College was renamed in 1928 she was Dean of <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a>.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
Nancy Duke Lewis, who was acting dean in 1949-1950, succeeded Miss Morriss in 1950.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
Robert W. Kenny was acting dean during Miss Lewis’ illness in 1960-61, and Rosemary Pierrel was dean from 1961 until the office was discontinued in 1971, when <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a> was merged with Brown University.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
Carl Barus, the first Dean of the Graduate Department from 1903 to 1926, was succeeded in that position for one year by Roland G. D. Richardson, who was then the Dean of the <a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a> until 1949.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
From 1947 to 1949 Curt J. Ducasse was acting dean.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
The Deans of the <a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a> since that time have been Barnaby C. Keeney from 1949 to 1953, Robert Bruce Lindsay from 1954 to 1966, Michael J. Brennan from 1966 to 1974, Maurice Glicksman from 1974 to 1976, and Ernest S. Frerichs from 1976 to 1982.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
Edmund S. Morgan was acting dean in 1951-1952, and Donald F. Hornig in 1952-1953.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
The title of the office was changed in 1983 to Dean of the <a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a> and Research, and has been held by Mark B. Schupack from 1983 to 1986 and by Phillip J. Stiles since 1986.<cite><a href="Dean.html">Dean</a></cite>
At the first <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> in 1769 the subject of the "Disputatio forensica" was "Whether, British America can under her present Circumstances consistent with good Policy, effect to become an independent State?"<cite><a href="Debating.html">Debating</a></cite>
The first of these organizations was the Misokosmian Society in 1794, which changed its name to <a href="Philermenian Society.html">Philermenian Society</a> in 1798.<cite><a href="Debating.html">Debating</a></cite>
The <a href="United Brothers.html">United Brothers</a> Society was formed in 1806.<cite><a href="Debating.html">Debating</a></cite>
A third organization, the <a href="Franklin Society.html">Franklin Society</a>, existed from 1824 to 1834.<cite><a href="Debating.html">Debating</a></cite>
The two earlier ones were active until about 1860.<cite><a href="Debating.html">Debating</a></cite>
Modern interest in debate began in 1898 when the Brown Debating Union was formed to conduct debates with Dartmouth.<cite><a href="Debating.html">Debating</a></cite>
The Brown-Dartmouth annual debates between that time and 1905 were won 4 times by Brown and 4 times by Dartmouth.<cite><a href="Debating.html">Debating</a></cite>
In 1906 the Triangular League of Dartmouth, Williams and Brown was established.<cite><a href="Debating.html">Debating</a></cite>
Debating was introduced into the Women’s College on April 5, 1906, when the senior and juniors debated the question, "Resolved, That elaborate scenic accessories are detrimental to pure dramatic art," was won by the juniors for the negative, and the question debated by the sophomores and the freshman, "Resolved, That women of independent means are justified in holding income-yielding positions," was decided in favor of the sophomores for the affirmative.<cite><a href="Debating.html">Debating</a></cite>
In 1909 a New England Oratorical League was formed by representatives Amherst, Bowdoin, Brown, Wesleyan, and Williams, and the same year a Brown chapter of Delta Sigma Rho, national forensic society, was established.<cite><a href="Debating.html">Debating</a></cite>
In 1911 a new club, the Brown Forum, was formed under the auspices of the Debating Union to foster interest in public discussion, and initially admitted any student who had taken part in a varsity, class, or prize debate.<cite><a href="Debating.html">Debating</a></cite>
In 1921-22 the Brown team defeated Wesleyan, Dartmouth, and Williams, but lost its debate with the women of Vassar College.<cite><a href="Debating.html">Debating</a></cite>
The 1926 team displayed its versatility by winning its first debate with Princeton (Brown in favor of the Volstead Act), and going on to defeat Amherst the next week (Brown against the Volstead Act), but when this popular subject came up in the first debate between the men and women of Brown in 1928, the Women’s College team defeated the University team, having defended the affirmative side of the subject, "Resolved: that the Volstead Act be modified to permit the use of light wines and beers."<cite><a href="Debating.html">Debating</a></cite>
Brown won the championship of the Eastern Intercollegiate League in 1929.<cite><a href="Debating.html">Debating</a></cite>
Debating gained renewed popularity in the 1930s.<cite><a href="Debating.html">Debating</a></cite>
Professor Henry B. Huntington introduced a course in debating in 1937.<cite><a href="Debating.html">Debating</a></cite>
Pembroke, admitted into the Eastern Intercollegiate Debate League in 1936-37, won five of six league debates that year and won second place at the League’s convention.<cite><a href="Debating.html">Debating</a></cite>
By 1940 interest in debating waned, and the Debating Society merged with the International Relations Club.<cite><a href="Debating.html">Debating</a></cite>
