After a lapse during <a href="World War II.html">World War II</a>, debating was revived in October 1946, when a group of ten members without a coach practiced in the fall and won their first debate against the University of Connecticut on Friday the thirteenth of December.<cite><a href="Debating.html">Debating</a></cite>
The next year the team entered competition with the other "<a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a>" colleges (the Ivy Group had only begun in 1945) for the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> Cup.<cite><a href="Debating.html">Debating</a></cite>
Robert Renwick of the <a href="English.html">English</a> Department took over coaching the team in 1948.<cite><a href="Debating.html">Debating</a></cite>
In 1952-53 the Union started to sponsor an intramural debating tournament.<cite><a href="Debating.html">Debating</a></cite>
In October 1954 an audience of about eleven hundred watched Brown, taking the negative side of "The United States should extend diplomatic relations to Communist China," overcome Oxford University by a 4-1 decision.<cite><a href="Debating.html">Debating</a></cite>
In November 1957 teams from 42 schools from ten states and Canada came to Brown for a debate on "Open Shop for the Labor Union."<cite><a href="Debating.html">Debating</a></cite>
Debating was a student activity until 1970, when it became a team connected to the <a href="English.html">English</a> Department, which it remained for about ten years.<cite><a href="Debating.html">Debating</a></cite>
Coached by Barbara Tannenbaum, the team placed fourth in a national debating tournament in 1972.<cite><a href="Debating.html">Debating</a></cite>
There was also a competitive speaking team, which was formed in 1982 with Barbara Duley ’77 as coach, which sent five members to the Competitive Speech National Tournament at Georgia Southern College.<cite><a href="Debating.html">Debating</a></cite>
Degrees were conferred for the first time in 1769, when seven Bachelor of Arts degrees were granted to students who had completed the prescribed course, along with twenty-one honorary Master of Arts degrees.<cite><a href="Degrees.html">Degrees</a></cite>
In 1772 six of the seven graduates of 1769 were awarded Master of Arts degrees.<cite><a href="Degrees.html">Degrees</a></cite>
The Bachelor of Arts degree continued to be the only earned degree until the advent of Francis Wayland’s "New System" in 1850, which inaugurated the Bachelor of <a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a> for those who desired to prepare themselves for the professions, but were unable to pursue a full course of liberal education.<cite><a href="Degrees.html">Degrees</a></cite>
The first Ph.B. degree was awarded to Thomas Tefft in 1851.<cite><a href="Degrees.html">Degrees</a></cite>
In 1857 the undergraduate Master of Arts degree was dropped, and the Bachelor of Arts was once more a four-year degree.<cite><a href="Degrees.html">Degrees</a></cite>
The Bachelor of <a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a> degree came under fire in <a href="President.html">President</a> Robinson’s report for 1875.<cite><a href="Degrees.html">Degrees</a></cite>
After 1876 requirements for the Bachelor of <a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a> degree were altered to include four years of study and some knowledge of Latin.<cite><a href="Degrees.html">Degrees</a></cite>
In 1911 further changes required students for the Ph.B. degree to take a course in classical civilization and a course in general biology and to choose a "major" at the end of the sophomore year.<cite><a href="Degrees.html">Degrees</a></cite>
Members of the Class of 1938 were the last to receive the Ph.B. degree.<cite><a href="Degrees.html">Degrees</a></cite>
The first earned graduate Master of Arts degrees were awarded to Austen K. DeBlois and George Grafton Wilson 1886 in 1888.<cite><a href="Degrees.html">Degrees</a></cite>
The same two gentlemen received the first Doctor of <a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a> degree awarded by Brown in 1889.<cite><a href="Degrees.html">Degrees</a></cite>
A course leading to the degree of Bachelor of Science was drawn up in 1891, and the Sc.B. degree was awarded for the first time in 1897 to three candidates.<cite><a href="Degrees.html">Degrees</a></cite>
The first degree of Civil Engineer was awarded in 1892, and the first degree of Mechanical Engineer in 1896.<cite><a href="Degrees.html">Degrees</a></cite>
After 1905 the C.E.<cite><a href="Degrees.html">Degrees</a></cite>
The Master of Science degree was first awarded in 1905 to Warren A. Clough 1904 and George B. Obear.<cite><a href="Degrees.html">Degrees</a></cite>
With the establishment of the School of <a href="Education.html">Education</a> in 1916, the degree of Bachelor of <a href="Education.html">Education</a> was introduced.<cite><a href="Degrees.html">Degrees</a></cite>
The degree of Bachelor of <a href="Education.html">Education</a> was discontinued in 1929, with the provision that the degree would be awarded to candidates already enrolled.<cite><a href="Degrees.html">Degrees</a></cite>
For a short time in the 1920s Brown awarded a Master of Business Administration degree.<cite><a href="Degrees.html">Degrees</a></cite>
Two students earned their M.B.A. degree in 1923, one in 1924, and two in 1925, after which the degree was discontinued.<cite><a href="Degrees.html">Degrees</a></cite>
Degrees with distinction were awarded for the first time in June of 1925, when 27 bachelors’ degrees "cum laude," eighteen "magna cum laude," and five "summa cum laude," conferred honor upon fifteen per cent of the graduating class.<cite><a href="Degrees.html">Degrees</a></cite>
The Master of Arts in Teaching degree was introduced in 1957.<cite><a href="Degrees.html">Degrees</a></cite>
Three degrees of Doctor of Arts in Creative Writing were awarded under an experimental program in 1975.<cite><a href="Degrees.html">Degrees</a></cite>
The Master of Fine Arts degree has been conferred since 1990.<cite><a href="Degrees.html">Degrees</a></cite>
The degrees conferred by the University from its beginning are summarized in a recent "Catalogue," "As of May 1991, there were enrolled the names of 78,056 graduates, both men and women.<cite><a href="Degrees.html">Degrees</a></cite>
Edmund Burke Delabarre (1863-1945), professor of psychology, was born in Dover, Maine, on September 25, 1863.<cite><a href="Delabarre, Edmund B..html">Delabarre, Edmund B.</a></cite>
Edmund B. Delabarre prepared for college at Mowry and Goff’s School in Providence and entered Brown in 1882.<cite><a href="Delabarre, Edmund B..html">Delabarre, Edmund B.</a></cite>
Edmund B. Delabarre left after his freshman year, as his family’s move to Conway, Massachusetts made it more practical for him to attend Amherst College, where he graduated in 1883.<cite><a href="Delabarre, Edmund B..html">Delabarre, Edmund B.</a></cite>
Appointed associate professor of psychology in 1891 and promoted to full professor in 1896, Edmund B. Delabarre was Brown’s first professor of that subject.<cite><a href="Delabarre, Edmund B..html">Delabarre, Edmund B.</a></cite>
In 1896-97 Edmund B. Delabarre was director of Harvard’s Psychological Laboratory during the absence of Professor Muensterberg.<cite><a href="Delabarre, Edmund B..html">Delabarre, Edmund B.</a></cite>
His work was described in the memorial minute of the Faculty in 1945:  Edmund B. Delabarre was one of the first to use ink blots to encourage mental imagery.<cite><a href="Delabarre, Edmund B..html">Delabarre, Edmund B.</a></cite>
The rock, at the edge of the Taunton River, was submerged by tides much of the time, but Delabarre managed to photograph it in different degrees of light until he was able to make out the date of 1511 which had been obscured by Indian markings of a later time.<cite><a href="Delabarre, Edmund B..html">Delabarre, Edmund B.</a></cite>
Edmund B. Delabarre's investigations led to the the discovery of two Portugese brothers, Gaspar Cortereal, who explored the coast of Newfoundland in 1501 and did not return to Portugal, and his brother Miguel Cortereal, who set out the next year to search for him and also did not return.<cite><a href="Delabarre, Edmund B..html">Delabarre, Edmund B.</a></cite>
Further study of the photographs revealed a clear M followed by the less distinct letters IGU, and more letters from which Edmund B. Delabarre pieced together an inscription which read "Miguel Cortereal 1511 V Dei hic dux ind."<cite><a href="Delabarre, Edmund B..html">Delabarre, Edmund B.</a></cite>
This supported an Indian tradition recorded by Reverend John Danforth in 1680 that men from a strange land had come up the river at an earlier time and had slain their sachem.<cite><a href="Delabarre, Edmund B..html">Delabarre, Edmund B.</a></cite>
In 1929 Delabarre published a book, "Dighton Rock," which described his interpretation and cited others.<cite><a href="Delabarre, Edmund B..html">Delabarre, Edmund B.</a></cite>
Edmund B. Delabarre also published "Report of the Brown-Harvard Expedition to Nachvak, Labrador, in the Year 1900," an account of a journey he made in the company of Reginald A. Daly, instructor in geology at Harvard and four Harvard undergraduates, with observations of botany, ornithology, and geology in Labrador.<cite><a href="Delabarre, Edmund B..html">Delabarre, Edmund B.</a></cite>
Delabarre retired in 1932.<cite><a href="Delabarre, Edmund B..html">Delabarre, Edmund B.</a></cite>
Edmund B. Delabarre died in Providence on March 16, 1945.<cite><a href="Delabarre, Edmund B..html">Delabarre, Edmund B.</a></cite>
Gordon Rohde Dewart (1920-1974), professor of French and associate dean of academic affairs, was born in LaCrosse, Wisconsin, on July 4, 1920.<cite><a href="Dewart, Gordon R..html">Dewart, Gordon R.</a></cite>
After graduation from Amherst College in 1941, Gordon R. Dewart served in the U.S. Navy until 1946.<cite><a href="Dewart, Gordon R..html">Dewart, Gordon R.</a></cite>
Gordon R. Dewart received his master’s degree in 1947 and his Ph.D. in 1953, both from Princeton.<cite><a href="Dewart, Gordon R..html">Dewart, Gordon R.</a></cite>
Gordon R. Dewart came to Brown as instructor in French in 1948 and was promoted to assistant professor in 1953 and associate professor in 1970.<cite><a href="Dewart, Gordon R..html">Dewart, Gordon R.</a></cite>
Gordon R. Dewart was named assistant dean of the college in 1962, associate dean in 1964, and associate dean of academic affairs in 1971.<cite><a href="Dewart, Gordon R..html">Dewart, Gordon R.</a></cite>
Gordon R. Dewart died suddenly in Providence, after being stricken at the University Club, on April 20, 1974.<cite><a href="Dewart, Gordon R..html">Dewart, Gordon R.</a></cite>
Jeremiah Lewis Diman (1831-1881), professor of history and political economy, was born in Bristol on May 1, 1831.<cite><a href="Diman, Jeremiah Lewis.html">Diman, Jeremiah Lewis</a></cite>
Jeremiah Lewis Diman graduated from Brown University in 1851 and went on to study theology and philosophy, first with a clergyman in Newport, then at Andover Theological Seminary, and later in Germany.<cite><a href="Diman, Jeremiah Lewis.html">Diman, Jeremiah Lewis</a></cite>
Jeremiah Lewis Diman graduated from Andover in 1856 and was a pastor of Congregational churches in Fall River and Brookline, Massachusetts.<cite><a href="Diman, Jeremiah Lewis.html">Diman, Jeremiah Lewis</a></cite>
In 1864 Jeremiah Lewis Diman was appointed professor of history and political economy at Brown.<cite><a href="Diman, Jeremiah Lewis.html">Diman, Jeremiah Lewis</a></cite>
In 1879 Jeremiah Lewis Diman delivered twenty lectures at Johns Hopkins University, and in 1880 he delivered twelve lectures on theism at the Lowell Institute in Boston.<cite><a href="Diman, Jeremiah Lewis.html">Diman, Jeremiah Lewis</a></cite>
Jeremiah Lewis Diman declined offers of professorships elsewhere, remaining at Brown until his death on May 17, 1881 after an illness of less than a week.<cite><a href="Diman, Jeremiah Lewis.html">Diman, Jeremiah Lewis</a></cite>
Robert P. Brown 1871 in "Memories of Brown" quotes this description of Diman, "Professor Diman is a Unitarian, who hires a pew in Saint Stephen’s Episcopal Church, preaches mostly in orthodox Congregational pulpits, is in warm sympathy with the faith of the liberal Jews, and teaches Catholicism in a Baptist College."<cite><a href="Diman, Jeremiah Lewis.html">Diman, Jeremiah Lewis</a></cite>
His son, John Byron Diman 1885, was ordained in the Episcopal Church and founded St. George’s School in Middletown.<cite><a href="Diman, Jeremiah Lewis.html">Diman, Jeremiah Lewis</a></cite>
He resigned as headmaster of the school in 1916, became a Catholic priest, changed his name to J. Hugh Diman, and established the Portsmouth Priory School.<cite><a href="Diman, Jeremiah Lewis.html">Diman, Jeremiah Lewis</a></cite>
He was also the founder in 1912 of the Diman Vocational School in Fall River, Massachusetts.<cite><a href="Diman, Jeremiah Lewis.html">Diman, Jeremiah Lewis</a></cite>
George Elliot Downing (1904-1977), professor of art, was born in Marquette, Michigan, on June 19, 1904.<cite><a href="Downing, George E..html">Downing, George E.</a></cite>
George E. Downing graduated from the University of Chicago in 1925, intending to study medicine.<cite><a href="Downing, George E..html">Downing, George E.</a></cite>
However, George E. Downing chose to earn a master’s degree in art history from Harvard in 1928.<cite><a href="Downing, George E..html">Downing, George E.</a></cite>
George E. Downing was an instructor at the University of Chicago from 1926 to 1931, and in 1930 went abroad to study Romanesque architecture.<cite><a href="Downing, George E..html">Downing, George E.</a></cite>
When George E. Downing came to Brown as assistant professor of art in 1932, he was the second member of the art department and resided on the second floor of a house above the Art Department quarters.<cite><a href="Downing, George E..html">Downing, George E.</a></cite>
In 1946 George E. Downing earned his doctorate at Harvard and was promoted to associate professor.<cite><a href="Downing, George E..html">Downing, George E.</a></cite>
George E. Downing became a full professor in 1953.<cite><a href="Downing, George E..html">Downing, George E.</a></cite>
George E. Downing was chairman of the Art Department from 1949 to 1963.<cite><a href="Downing, George E..html">Downing, George E.</a></cite>
Downing retired from teaching in 1969, and was working on a book, "Modern Art and Modern Thought," at the time of his death in Providence on May 8, 1977.<cite><a href="Downing, George E..html">Downing, George E.</a></cite>
The earliest known reference to a play performed by students is in the 1757 edition of Thomas Otway’s works in the College <a href="Library.html">Library</a> where a note in the hand of Nicholas Brown 1786 at the beginning of "The Cheats of Scapin," reads, "Acted in the Hall in Providencè as a Farce to the ‘Revengè’ April: 1785 With Great Applause."<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
The volume also contains the names of the actors, all members of the classes of 1786 through 1788, in what seems to have been an afterpiece to the performance of Edward Young’s play, "The Revenge."<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
Later annotations of the names of student actors indicate that "The Cheats of Scapin" was also performed sometime in 1791-92 and again by the Class of 1805 in the third term of 1803.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
The program for the sophomore-junior exhibition on August 22, 1804 announced the performance of a one-act comedy for four actors, "The Miser Outwitted."<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
Years later, in 1931, the Harris Collection of American <a href="Poetry.html">Poetry</a> and Plays acquired a copy of a play entitled "The Miser" by Samuel Randall of the class of 1804.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
This play, published in 1812 in Warren, appears to be a revision of "The Miser Outwitted" with three more acts and seven more characters.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
The Thalian Dramatic Society was noted in the "<a href="Brown Paper.html">Brown Paper</a>" in 1866, but was never heard from again.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
Hammer and Tongs, producer of skits and light operettas for the benefit of athletics, began in 1867, and after a brief hiatus in 1892 and 1893 when the Brown Operatic Club took its place, revived for a few years, and was replaced by Sock and Buskin, the Brown dramatic society, in 1901.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
Komians, the Women’s College dramatic society, also began in 1901, and the two societies went their separate ways for more than thirty years in which the men played women’s parts in their plays, and the women played men’s parts in theirs.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
In November 1929 more than twenty delegates from other colleges attended the first conference of the New England College Dramatic Societies, which was held at Brown.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
In 1939 a Student Dramatic Committee was set up to work with the newly appointed Committee on Dramatic Productions.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
In the 1920s the vaudeville group staged some very popular and irreverent St. Patrick’s Day shows (which were not necessarily held on St. Patrick’s Day).<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
The 1924 show was "The Plastered Duchess," a burlesque on "The Duchess of Padua," which had recently been staged by Sock and Buskin.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
Leslie Allen Jones ’26, who held scenic artist positions with various theaters throughout the country and offered volunteer assistance to dramatics at Brown in the 1930s, was appointed instructor in <a href="English.html">English</a> and technical director of theatre at Brown in 1942.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
Janice Van De Water (later Mrs. Sevellon Brown), who joined the <a href="English.html">English</a> Department in 1940, became a member of the <a href="Faunce House.html">Faunce House</a> Theatre staff in 1942.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
Also, for a few years, <a href="English.html">English</a> 23-24, a course in play production introduced in 1946, held annual performances in the <a href="Faunce House.html">Faunce House</a> Theatre.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
This course, the basic course in acting and directing, became <a href="Theatre Arts.html">Theatre Arts</a> 23-24 in 1978, when the Department of <a href="Theatre Arts.html">Theatre Arts</a> was established.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
Production Workshop was formed in 1959-60 as an independent organization, controlled by students.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
The 1966 <a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a> described the work of Production Workshop as a supplement to Sock and Buskin:  The Brown Summer Theatre was started in 1969.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
John Lucas took over as producer in 1971, and served in that capacity until 1974.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
Lucas became the Summer Theatre’s full time director in 1978.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
<a href="Theatre Arts.html">Theatre Arts</a> became a concentration within the <a href="English.html">English</a> Department in 1969.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
The Department of <a href="Theatre Arts.html">Theatre Arts</a>, with Professor James O. Barnhill as chairman, was created in 1978, at the time when <a href="Lyman Hall.html">Lyman Hall</a> was being remodeled into a theatre.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
In the fall of 1981 the theatre arts programs at Brown, Providence College and Rhode Island College combined to present the first Shakespeare festival in Rhode Island, entitled "Trilogy of Kings."<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
Brownbrokers was formed in 1935 when some students decided to stage an original music revue.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
"Something Bruin’" opened on May 10, 1935 with 23 original numbers.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
"Road to Bruin," the 1936 production parodied the college athletic and publicity departments.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
"Man about Brown," which played to standing room only audiences in 1937, parodied everything from Gypsy Rose Lee to Roosevelt’s attempt to pack the Supreme Court.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
"Curriculi-Curricula," produced in 1938, was described by "Variety" as the best college show in the country, and was favorably viewed in dress rehearsal by George M. Cohan, who was made an honorary member of Brownbrokers.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
In 1941 "Life" magazine photographer Eric Schall said that "Run for your Life," based on the magazine, was the best college show he had ever seen.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
The annual musical was omitted in 1943 because of the war, but Brownbrokers returned in 1944 with "Scuttlebutt," a navy show, for which some of the performers wore their own uniforms for costumes.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
The shows produced in 1956, "Barney ’n Me," and in 1957, "Fiddle-De-Dee," had books and lyrics by future Oscar-winner Alfred F. Uhry ’58.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
The 1958 production, "Down to Earth," was the first written entirely by Pembroke students.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
In 1964 the Brownbrokers took "Statutory Scrape," which was about the theft of the Statue of Liberty, on the road for a repeat performance at the Brown Club of New York.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
The annual productions of shows written by students continued, with the exception of the year 1962, when Sock and Buskin produced "Bus Stop" in the slot usually reserved for the Brownbrokers show.<cite><a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a></cite>
Solomon Drowne (1753-1834), professor in the early Brown University Medical School, was born on North Main Street in Providence on March 11, 1753.<cite><a href="Drowne, Solomon.html">Drowne, Solomon</a></cite>
Solomon Drowne began his studies in 1769 with Charles Thompson 1769, and according to his diary was examined for entrance to Rhode Island College on June 30, 1770.<cite><a href="Drowne, Solomon.html">Drowne, Solomon</a></cite>
Solomon Drowne graduated in 1773.<cite><a href="Drowne, Solomon.html">Drowne, Solomon</a></cite>
A year after his graduation, in September 1774, Drowne began the study of medicine at the College of Philadelphia.<cite><a href="Drowne, Solomon.html">Drowne, Solomon</a></cite>
Solomon Drowne was in the army from 1776 to 1780, and had a narrow escape on July 3, 1776, when he remained to gather medical supplies until moments before the arrival of the British in New York City.<cite><a href="Drowne, Solomon.html">Drowne, Solomon</a></cite>
In 1780 Solomon Drowne took part in a cruise on the private sloop of war "Hope," which was owned by Joseph Nightingale and John Innis Clarke, and kept a detailed diary of this adventure.<cite><a href="Drowne, Solomon.html">Drowne, Solomon</a></cite>
On his return to Providence in 1785 Solomon Drowne began his practice of medicine.<cite><a href="Drowne, Solomon.html">Drowne, Solomon</a></cite>
In 1788 Solomon Drowne traveled to Ohio to join other veterans of the Revolution in the settling of Marietta.<cite><a href="Drowne, Solomon.html">Drowne, Solomon</a></cite>
Among the inhabitants was James Mitchell Varnum 1769, who died during the first year there.<cite><a href="Drowne, Solomon.html">Drowne, Solomon</a></cite>
Several months later Solomon Drowne delivered, on April 7, 1789, the address at the first anniversary of the settlement of Marietta.<cite><a href="Drowne, Solomon.html">Drowne, Solomon</a></cite>
Solomon Drowne came back to Providence in 1792, but soon moved on to Union, Pennsylvania, and Morgantown, West Virginia.<cite><a href="Drowne, Solomon.html">Drowne, Solomon</a></cite>
In 1801 Solomon Drowne returned once more to Rhode Island, ready to settle down.<cite><a href="Drowne, Solomon.html">Drowne, Solomon</a></cite>
Solomon Drowne's old friend <a href="Foster, Theodore.html">Theodore Foster</a> 1770 had returned from two terms in the Senate and retired to the town of Foster, which had been named for him when it was separated from Scituate in 1781.<cite><a href="Drowne, Solomon.html">Drowne, Solomon</a></cite>
When medical lectures were introduced to Brown University in 1811, Drowne was appointed professor of materia medica and botany.<cite><a href="Drowne, Solomon.html">Drowne, Solomon</a></cite>
Solomon Drowne was in demand as an orator, his best known addresses being a eulogy on the death of <a href="Washington, George.html">George Washington</a> and his "Oration in Aid of the Cause of the Greeks" delivered by invitation of the people of Providence in the First Baptist Church on February 23, 1824.<cite><a href="Drowne, Solomon.html">Drowne, Solomon</a></cite>
In collaboration with his son William Solomon Drowne wrote "The Compendium of Agriculture or the Farmer’s Guide," which was published in 1824.<cite><a href="Drowne, Solomon.html">Drowne, Solomon</a></cite>
Before this could be accomplished, Solomon Drowne died in Foster on February 5, 1834.<cite><a href="Drowne, Solomon.html">Drowne, Solomon</a></cite>
Curt John Ducasse (1881-1969), was born in Angouleme, France, on July 7, 1881.<cite><a href="Ducasse, Curt J..html">Ducasse, Curt J.</a></cite>
In 1900 Curt J. Ducasse left his first position in a Paris business house to work for a dry goods firm in Mexico City.<cite><a href="Ducasse, Curt J..html">Ducasse, Curt J.</a></cite>
In 1906 in Seattle, while Curt J. Ducasse was secretary to an engineer involved in railroad construction, he decided to study philosophy.<cite><a href="Ducasse, Curt J..html">Ducasse, Curt J.</a></cite>
Curt J. Ducasse received his bachelor and master of arts degrees from the University of Washington in 1908 and 1909, taught there for one year, then went to Harvard as a University Scholar in 1910 and received his Ph.D. degree in 1912.<cite><a href="Ducasse, Curt J..html">Ducasse, Curt J.</a></cite>
After returning from a long train trip to read an article at a meeting of the Western Division of the American Philosophical Association in Chicago in April 1924, Curt J. Ducasse decided to organize the Pacific Division of the Association.<cite><a href="Ducasse, Curt J..html">Ducasse, Curt J.</a></cite>
In 1926 Curt J. Ducasse came to Brown as associate professor of philosophy.<cite><a href="Ducasse, Curt J..html">Ducasse, Curt J.</a></cite>
Curt J. Ducasse was made full professor in 1929 and was head of the Philosophy Department from 1930 to 1951.<cite><a href="Ducasse, Curt J..html">Ducasse, Curt J.</a></cite>
Curt J. Ducasse was acting dean of the Graduate School from 1947 to 1949.<cite><a href="Ducasse, Curt J..html">Ducasse, Curt J.</a></cite>
Curt J. Ducasse retired in 1951, having reached the compulsory retirement age, but was asked to teach part-time.<cite><a href="Ducasse, Curt J..html">Ducasse, Curt J.</a></cite>
Curt J. Ducasse retired from part-time teaching at Brown in 1958, after which he accepted a part-time teaching position at New York University, He was the author of "The Philosophy of Art" in 1930, "Nature, Mind and Death" in 1951, and "A Critical Examination of the Belief in a Life after Death" in 1961, and numerous articles and other books.<cite><a href="Ducasse, Curt J..html">Ducasse, Curt J.</a></cite>
Chichibu died in 1954 at the age of 22, and was buried in the back yard of the Ducasse home with a marker of blue (the color of Chichibu’s eyes) on the gravesite.<cite><a href="Ducasse, Curt J..html">Ducasse, Curt J.</a></cite>
Ducasse died on September 3, 1969 at the age of 88.<cite><a href="Ducasse, Curt J..html">Ducasse, Curt J.</a></cite>
Robinson Potter Dunn(1825-1867), professor of rhetoric and English literature, was born in Newport on May 31, 1825, the son of a physician.<cite><a href="Dunn, Robinson P..html">Dunn, Robinson P.</a></cite>
After graduation as valedictorian of his class at Brown in 1843, Robinson P. Dunn took charge of the library and taught French during the absence of Professor Charles Coffin Jewett.<cite><a href="Dunn, Robinson P..html">Dunn, Robinson P.</a></cite>
Robinson P. Dunn would have entered Princeton Theological School in the fall of 1845, but remained at Brown because of the delay of Jewett’s return from Europe.<cite><a href="Dunn, Robinson P..html">Dunn, Robinson P.</a></cite>
Robinson P. Dunn did not lose any time, however, as he began the studies of his theological course, keeping up with his class and receiving weekly bulletins from his collegemate William F. Hansell 1845, who was taking the course.<cite><a href="Dunn, Robinson P..html">Dunn, Robinson P.</a></cite>
Robinson P. Dunn went to Princeton in December of 1845, graduated in 1848, was ordained a Presbyterian clergyman and was paster of the First Church in Camden, New Jersey, from 1848 to 1851.<cite><a href="Dunn, Robinson P..html">Dunn, Robinson P.</a></cite>
In 1851 Robinson P. Dunn exchanged his pulpit with misgivings for the professorship of rhetoric and English literature at Brown.<cite><a href="Dunn, Robinson P..html">Dunn, Robinson P.</a></cite>
His colleague on the faculty, James B. Angell recalled, Adoniram Brown Judson 1859 remembered,<b.ockquote>"Robinson P. Dunn was an elegant and refined gentleman, whose influence on the students and Faculty was doubtless most excellent.<cite><a href="Dunn, Robinson P..html">Dunn, Robinson P.</a></cite>
Dust was a short-lived student publication of two issues only in January and May of 1934, described in the first issue as "an experiment printed by the editors under the tutelage of E. A. Johnson Printing Company.<cite><a href="Dust.html">Dust</a></cite>
John D’Wolf (1786-1862), professor of chemistry, was born in Bristol on February 26, 1786.<cite><a href="D’Wolf, John.html">D’Wolf, John</a></cite>
John D’Wolf's early studies were under the instruction of Abner Alden 1787 and President Eleazar Wheelock of Dartmouth College.<cite><a href="D’Wolf, John.html">D’Wolf, John</a></cite>
John D’Wolf was a member of the Class of 1806 at Brown, but did not graduate, although he is said to have nearly completed the course.<cite><a href="D’Wolf, John.html">D’Wolf, John</a></cite>
John D’Wolf was given an honorary A.M. degree in 1813.<cite><a href="D’Wolf, John.html">D’Wolf, John</a></cite>
John D’Wolf was appointed professor of chemistry in 1817 in association with the Medical School in the position left vacant since 1813 when it was resigned by Dr. William C. Bowen.<cite><a href="D’Wolf, John.html">D’Wolf, John</a></cite>
Park 1826 wrote of him: On August 12, 1826, D’Wolf wrote a long letter to his classmate and member of the Corporation, David Benedict, criticizing the College for its low admission requirements and elementary courses, recommending the teaching of political economy and an option between the modern and ancient languages, and suggesting that Benedict go to the College to check on the performance of the instructors.<cite><a href="D’Wolf, John.html">D’Wolf, John</a></cite>
John D’Wolf resigned his position in 1834, being unable to comply with a requirement of residency in the college, and became professor of chemistry at the Medical School at Woodstock, Vermont.<cite><a href="D’Wolf, John.html">D’Wolf, John</a></cite>
In 1840 John D’Wolf was appointed professor of chemistry at the McDowell Medical College in St. Louis, where he taught until 1844, still returning to Bristol in the summers.<cite><a href="D’Wolf, John.html">D’Wolf, John</a></cite>
After that John D’Wolf engaged in farming near Bristol, and in his later years moved back into the town and died there on February 23, 1862.<cite><a href="D’Wolf, John.html">D’Wolf, John</a></cite>
East Asian Studies became a separate department directed by James Wrenn and Jerome Grieder in 1987.<cite><a href="East Asian Studies.html">East Asian Studies</a></cite>
In the fall of 1965 an East Asia Language and Area Center was established in connection with the Department of <a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a>, and Professsor Lea E. Williams was named director.<cite><a href="East Asian Studies.html">East Asian Studies</a></cite>
Chinese courses had begun in 1962 in the Department of Linguistics, instructed by James Wrenn, who was joined in 1965 by David Lattimore, and in 1975 by Chieh-fang Ou Lee.<cite><a href="East Asian Studies.html">East Asian Studies</a></cite>
Student interest led to the creation of a Department of Asian <a href="History.html">History</a> in 1969 with a staff composed of chairman Lea Williams and professors Jerome Grieder and Eric Widmer, all of them formerly members of the <a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a> faculty.<cite><a href="East Asian Studies.html">East Asian Studies</a></cite>
The Asian <a href="History.html">History</a> Department was absorbed by the Department of <a href="History.html">History</a> in 1976.<cite><a href="East Asian Studies.html">East Asian Studies</a></cite>
Japanese history was introduced in the <a href="History.html">History</a> Department in 1979, when James McClain joined the department.<cite><a href="East Asian Studies.html">East Asian Studies</a></cite>
In 1987 the East Asian Language and Area Center was restructured as the foundation of the Department of East Asian Studies.<cite><a href="East Asian Studies.html">East Asian Studies</a></cite>
Japanese courses were added in the Department of Linguistics in 1979 and were taught by Steve Rabson.<cite><a href="East Asian Studies.html">East Asian Studies</a></cite>
Kikuko Yamashita joined the Japanese staff in 1981.<cite><a href="East Asian Studies.html">East Asian Studies</a></cite>
Classes in Hindi were started in 1983 by Lecturer Robert Hueckstedt, and ended in 1988.<cite><a href="East Asian Studies.html">East Asian Studies</a></cite>
Classes in Korean were started by Visiting Lecturer Yeon Lee Choi in 1987.<cite><a href="East Asian Studies.html">East Asian Studies</a></cite>
Lecturer Andrew Kim replaced Ms. Choi in 1988.<cite><a href="East Asian Studies.html">East Asian Studies</a></cite>
East Building was part of a double house of Meeting Street, which was pressed into service as a recitation hall for the women students in 1913, with three classrooms "of such a size that no words of the professor’s melt in distance before they reach the farthermost student."<cite><a href="East Building.html">East Building</a></cite>
Student opinion dismissed the building in the "Students’ Handbook" for 1917 as "another one, which is glorified by the name of East Building, but it is a bit of college etiquette not to speak of that."<cite><a href="East Building.html">East Building</a></cite>
The second half of the building was renovated in 1923.<cite><a href="East Building.html">East Building</a></cite>
In 1935 the building was still in service and had been treated to fresh paint in bright colors.<cite><a href="East Building.html">East Building</a></cite>
It was torn down in 1952 along with the nearby East House.<cite><a href="East Building.html">East Building</a></cite>
Economics was introduced as "political economy" by Francis Wayland in 1828.<cite><a href="Economics.html">Economics</a></cite>
William Gammell taught history and political economy from 1850 to 1864, followed by J. Lewis Diman from 1864 to 1881.<cite><a href="Economics.html">Economics</a></cite>
Henry Brayton Gardner was appointed associate professor of political economy in 1888, and a separate Department of Political Economy was first listed in the catalogue in 1889.<cite><a href="Economics.html">Economics</a></cite>
The change of name to Department of Economics took place in 1906.<cite><a href="Economics.html">Economics</a></cite>
When Professor Diman reported on his class in political economy in 1869, he stated that "Instruction has been by lectures, and has included a general introduction to the study with an examination of the laws of Production, Exchange, Distribution and Consumption.<cite><a href="Economics.html">Economics</a></cite>
In the twentieth century students were beginning to ask for business courses, and in 1916 the University responded, first, by the presentation of a series of lectures sponsored by Edgar L. Marston on South American business and trade, and, second, by entering into cooperation with the National Bank as one of a group of selected universities invited to recommend each year three seniors and three juniors or sophomores to be trained by the bank for future service in its foreign branches.<cite><a href="Economics.html">Economics</a></cite>
In the 1920s the department grew through the addition of faculty members James P. Adams in 1921, Hugh B. Killough, Harry E. Miller, and James H. Shoemaker in 1924, Albert F. Hinrichs in 1926, George E. Bigge in 1927, Williams Adams Brown in 1928, and Chelcie C. Bosland in 1929.<cite><a href="Economics.html">Economics</a></cite>
The Brown Bureau of Business Research was formed in 1921 by the Providence Chamber of Commerce and the Brown Department of Economics for the purpose of effecting a close business contact between Rhode Island business and the department.<cite><a href="Economics.html">Economics</a></cite>
In 1924 the Bureau inaugurated its official publication, "Brown Business Service," subtitled "Analyses of Economic Conditions in Southeastern New England," for distribution of timely information to the business community monthly from September to July.<cite><a href="Economics.html">Economics</a></cite>
In 1927-28 the Bureau cooperated with the Division of Industrial and Municipal Research at M.I.T. in the industrial survey of metropolitan Providence.<cite><a href="Economics.html">Economics</a></cite>
The Bureau continued as an agency of the University until 1939.<cite><a href="Economics.html">Economics</a></cite>
In 1932 a grant was received from the Rockefeller Foundation for a study of the international gold standard under the direction of William Adams Brown and Carel J. Smit, who came to Brown from Amsterdam in 1932.<cite><a href="Economics.html">Economics</a></cite>
A textbook, "Introduction to War Economics," written by members of the Department of Economics and edited by Professor Alfred C. Neal, was published in 1942.<cite><a href="Economics.html">Economics</a></cite>
The authors, who began to write the book before the United States’ declaration of war on December 8, 1941, rushed to finish it in early January, and in six months 7,000 copies had been sold and were in use in more than one hundred universitites and colleges.<cite><a href="Economics.html">Economics</a></cite>
Philip Taft, who became a noted labor historian, joined the faculty in 1937, and was chairman from 1949 to 1953.<cite><a href="Economics.html">Economics</a></cite>
In 1952 Brown entered into cooperation with a newly appointed Business Executives’ Research Committee from the community to study the economic problems of Rhode Island with grants from the nationwide Committee for Economic Development and the Ford Foundation’s Fund for Adult <a href="Education.html">Education</a>.<cite><a href="Economics.html">Economics</a></cite>
These studies were conducted by Professor Merton P. Stoltz, who had joined the department in 1940.<cite><a href="Economics.html">Economics</a></cite>
Professor Stoltz later served as chairman from 1957 to 1964, and went on to become <a href="Provost.html">Provost</a> and acting <a href="President.html">President</a> of Brown.<cite><a href="Economics.html">Economics</a></cite>
In the 1950s the department grew through the addition of faculty members George H. Borts in 1950, Jerome L. Stein in 1953, Michael J. Brennan in 1957, Phillip D. Cagan in 1958, and Martin J. Beckmann and Mark B. Schupack in 1959.<cite><a href="Economics.html">Economics</a></cite>
In 1958 the department received a grant from the Ford Foundation to study regional economic development in the United States.<cite><a href="Economics.html">Economics</a></cite>
In 1963 the department received a grant from the Ford Foundation to study the economics of aging.<cite><a href="Economics.html">Economics</a></cite>
In the 1960s the department grew through the addition of faculty members Herschel I. Grossman in 1964, James A. Hanson and Harl E. Ryder in 1965, Benjamin Chinitz in 1966, and Ryuzu Sato in 1967.<cite><a href="Economics.html">Economics</a></cite>
New faculty members in the 1970s included Allan Feldman in 1971, J. Vernon Henderson and William Poole in 1974, and in the 1980s Louis Putterman in 1980, Rajiv Vohra in 1983, Oded Galor and Robert Moffitt in 1984, Peter Garber in 1985, Talbot Page in 1986, Anthony Lancaster in 1987, and Mark Pitt in 1989.<cite><a href="Economics.html">Economics</a></cite>
From 1968 to 1980 the department housed the editorial offices of the "American Economic Review," the main publication of the American Economic Association.<cite><a href="Economics.html">Economics</a></cite>
The "Editor" was published for the first time in the spring of 1958 and sold for 25 cents.<cite><a href="Editor.html">Editor</a></cite>
There were only two more issues, the final one printed in the summer of 1959.<cite><a href="Editor.html">Editor</a></cite>
Education as a subject of study began in 1851 with the appointment of Samuel Stillman Greene to the new chair of Didactics which had been created as part of <a href="President.html">President</a> Wayland’s New System and described in the Laws of 1850-51: In 1851 Greene also became superintendent of schools in Providence.<cite><a href="Education.html">Education</a></cite>
In 1853-54 the course was discontinued and did not reappear until 1893 when Walter B. Jacobs became instructor in pedagogy.<cite><a href="Education.html">Education</a></cite>
In 1901 his title was changed to professor of the theory and practice of education.<cite><a href="Education.html">Education</a></cite>
He was assisted by Charles E. Dennis, instructor in pedagogy, from 1897 to 1901.<cite><a href="Education.html">Education</a></cite>
The Brown University Teachers Association was established in 1903 to provide an opportunity for teachers among the Brown alumni and other teachers to meet annually at the University.<cite><a href="Education.html">Education</a></cite>
In 1912 Stephen S. Colvin 1891, who had been teaching at the University of Illinois, was appointed to the newly created chair of Educational <a href="Psychology.html">Psychology</a>.<cite><a href="Education.html">Education</a></cite>
At the October 1916 meeting of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> a School of Education was established to promote graduate study by teachers and cooperation between Brown and the Rhode Island State Normal School and other institutions and to provide undergraduate work leading to a Bachelor of Education degree after two years of college work.<cite><a href="Education.html">Education</a></cite>
Colvin was director of the School of Education from 1918 to 1923, Jacobs from 1923 to 1927, and C. Emanuel Ekstrom, who had joined the department in 1919, from 1927 until 1931.<cite><a href="Education.html">Education</a></cite>
In 1929 the Board of Fellows voted to discontinue the Bachelor of Education degree, but allowed those already enrolled to receive the degree.<cite><a href="Education.html">Education</a></cite>
On hundred and eighteen Bachelor of Education degrees were awarded between 1920 to 1934, and some students continued their study and received the Bachelor of <a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a> degree.<cite><a href="Education.html">Education</a></cite>
Andrew H. MacPhail, professor of educational psychology since 1921, became director of educational measurement in 1934.<cite><a href="Education.html">Education</a></cite>
Frances E. Dunn became director in 1957.<cite><a href="Education.html">Education</a></cite>
In 1957, with a grant from the Fund for the Advancement of Education, Brown was able to institute a new program leading to the degree of Master of Arts in Teaching.<cite><a href="Education.html">Education</a></cite>
In 1958 a National Science Foundation grant enabled the University to establish summer institutes for teachers under the direction of Professor Elmer R. Smith.<cite><a href="Education.html">Education</a></cite>
In 1959 the Ford Foundation awarded Brown a grant of $1,047,000 to begin the program which was called The Brown Plan for Teacher Education, also under the direction of Smith.<cite><a href="Education.html">Education</a></cite>
One of the first projects of the Plan was a curriculum revision program for the public school system of Warren, Rhode Island in 1959-60.<cite><a href="Education.html">Education</a></cite>
New additions to the faculty of the department were Roberta Kellogg in 1957, Reginald Archambault in 1965, and Herman Eschenbacher in 1967.<cite><a href="Education.html">Education</a></cite>
Theodore R. Sizer, former dean of the Harvard <a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a> of Education, came to Brown as chairman of the department in 1984, bringing with him a new emphasis on secondary education.<cite><a href="Education.html">Education</a></cite>
His book, "Horace’s Compromise: The Dilemma of the American High School," led to the Brown-based Coalition of Essential Schools, a school and university partnership, which by 1990 had grown to include 65 private and public schools, in which innovations in teaching methods have been made possible by grants from thirty private and corporate foundations.<cite><a href="Education.html">Education</a></cite>
The Institute for Secondary Education was formed in 1985 with the goals of linking Brown to neighboring schools, providing programs for secondary school teachers, creating a forum for teachers and school administrators, and promoting the Coalition of Essential Schools.<cite><a href="Education.html">Education</a></cite>
The Center for the Advancement of College Teaching, with Harriet Sheridan as director, was established in 1987 to prepare graduate students as teaching assistants and teaching fellows for professional careers.<cite><a href="Education.html">Education</a></cite>
The department was housed in Sharpe House from 1960 until the fall of 1975, when it moved into the former <a href="Alumni House.html">Alumni House</a> at 159 George Street, which was renamed Meiklejohn House in honor of <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> Alexander Meiklejohn 1893.<cite><a href="Education.html">Education</a></cite>
The department moved again in 1991 to the former Barus Lab.<cite><a href="Education.html">Education</a></cite>
Morgan Edwards (1722-1795), prime mover in the founding of Brown University, was born in Wales on May 9, 1722, of Episcopalian parents.<cite><a href="Edwards, Morgan.html">Edwards, Morgan</a></cite>
On June 1, 1757 Morgan Edwards was ordained pastor of a Baptist church in Cork, Ireland.<cite><a href="Edwards, Morgan.html">Edwards, Morgan</a></cite>
Morgan Edwards arrived in Philadelphia on May 23, 1761, having been entreated to take the place of Reverend Jenkin Jones, recently deceased, as pastor of the First Church of Philadelphia, which was composed mostly of Welsh people.<cite><a href="Edwards, Morgan.html">Edwards, Morgan</a></cite>
It was Morgan Edwards, who, as Moderator of the annual meeting of the Philadelphia Association on October 12, 1762, made the motion for the establishment of a Baptist college, for which cooperation was pledged by some of his colleagues, but not by all – in his own words from his "Materials for a History of the Baptists of Rhode Island," "The first mover for it in 1762 was laughed at as the projector of a thing impossible.<cite><a href="Edwards, Morgan.html">Edwards, Morgan</a></cite>
In February 1767 Edwards left for England and Ireland to solicit funds for the college.<cite><a href="Edwards, Morgan.html">Edwards, Morgan</a></cite>
Morgan Edwards wrote to President Manning on April 26, 1768, "My patience, my feet and my assurance are much impaired.<cite><a href="Edwards, Morgan.html">Edwards, Morgan</a></cite>
Morgan Edwards's wife, formerly Mary Nunn of Cork, Ireland, died in 1769.<cite><a href="Edwards, Morgan.html">Edwards, Morgan</a></cite>
Edwards now recalled a dream he had fifteen years earlier and became convinced that he would die the next year – so convinced, in fact, that he preached and printed a sermon entitled "A New Year’s Gift; a sermon preached in this house, January 1, 1770, from these words, "This year thou shalt die.""<cite><a href="Edwards, Morgan.html">Edwards, Morgan</a></cite>
Morgan Edwards moved to Newark, Delaware, in 1772.<cite><a href="Edwards, Morgan.html">Edwards, Morgan</a></cite>
At the start of the Revolutionary War Morgan Edwards was loyal to the king, but on August 7, 1775 signed a recantation of his statements.<cite><a href="Edwards, Morgan.html">Edwards, Morgan</a></cite>
His son, William Edwards 1776, who as a pupil in Manning’s Latin School had been allowed to pronounce a piece from Homer at the 1770 Commencement, became a colonel in the English army and later drowned on his way to Cork from Bristol, England.<cite><a href="Edwards, Morgan.html">Edwards, Morgan</a></cite>
Another son, Joshua, at the age of eighteen served in the American Navy in 1782 as surgeon’s mate on the "Duc de Lauzon."<cite><a href="Edwards, Morgan.html">Edwards, Morgan</a></cite>
In 1780 Morgan Edwards moved to the property of his third wife, the widow of a wealthy proprietor in Delaware.<cite><a href="Edwards, Morgan.html">Edwards, Morgan</a></cite>
Morgan Edwards died at Pencader, Newcastle County, Delaware, on January 28, 1795.<cite><a href="Edwards, Morgan.html">Edwards, Morgan</a></cite>
Egyptology was established as a department of study in 1948 through the will of Theodora Wilbour, who had died in 1947, leaving $750,000 to start the department and endow a chair in Egyptology in memory of her father, Charles Edwin Wilbour 1854.<cite><a href="Egyptology.html">Egyptology</a></cite>
In 1854 he went to work for the "New York Herald Tribune."<cite><a href="Egyptology.html">Egyptology</a></cite>
When the Tweed ring was smashed in 1871, Wilbour and his family sailed for France.<cite><a href="Egyptology.html">Egyptology</a></cite>
In 1880 he began his visits to Egypt, and in 1886 acquired his own sailing dahabiyeh, named "The Seven Hathors," in which he and his family sailed on the Nile in the winters.<cite><a href="Egyptology.html">Egyptology</a></cite>
He died in 1897.<cite><a href="Egyptology.html">Egyptology</a></cite>
In 1951 Parker instituted a visiting scholar program, which in the next ten years brought scholars from England, Egypt, Israel, France, and Belgium to Brown.<cite><a href="Egyptology.html">Egyptology</a></cite>
In 1952 Ricardó Caminos, who had studied under Parker in Chicago, became the second member of the Egyptology faculty.<cite><a href="Egyptology.html">Egyptology</a></cite>
Caroline Nestman Peck, who received the first graduate degree in Egyptology in 1958, was the third.<cite><a href="Egyptology.html">Egyptology</a></cite>
Richard H. Pierce ’57 received the second graduate degree in 1963.<cite><a href="Egyptology.html">Egyptology</a></cite>
Caminos became chairman of the department in 1972, when Parker retired, and was in turn succeeded by Leonard H. Lesko in 1981.<cite><a href="Egyptology.html">Egyptology</a></cite>
Claus Emanuel Ekstrom (1892-1981), professor of education, was born in Falkenberg, Sweden, on November 5, 1892.<cite><a href="Ekstrom, Claus Emanuel.html">Ekstrom, Claus Emanuel</a></cite>
Claus Emanuel Ekstrom attended Classical High School in Providence and graduated from Brown in 1916.<cite><a href="Ekstrom, Claus Emanuel.html">Ekstrom, Claus Emanuel</a></cite>
Claus Emanuel Ekstrom did graduate work at Columbia University Teachers College from 1919 to 1922.<cite><a href="Ekstrom, Claus Emanuel.html">Ekstrom, Claus Emanuel</a></cite>
Claus Emanuel Ekstrom was appointed instructor in education at Brown in 1919 and promoted to assistant professor in 1923 and associate professor in 1931.<cite><a href="Ekstrom, Claus Emanuel.html">Ekstrom, Claus Emanuel</a></cite>
In 1927 Claus Emanuel Ekstrom was named acting director of the School of Education.<cite><a href="Ekstrom, Claus Emanuel.html">Ekstrom, Claus Emanuel</a></cite>
Claus Emanuel Ekstrom became Director of University Extension in 1931.<cite><a href="Ekstrom, Claus Emanuel.html">Ekstrom, Claus Emanuel</a></cite>
Claus Emanuel Ekstrom took a strong interest in opposing legalized gambling in Rhode Island in the 1930s as being "detrimental to business and social and political welfare," maintaining that the state’s gain from taxation would come mainly from persons in the lower wage brackets, who could least afford to lose even a small amount of their earnings.<cite><a href="Ekstrom, Claus Emanuel.html">Ekstrom, Claus Emanuel</a></cite>
Claus Emanuel Ekstrom helped organize "Majblommen," the Swedish-American anti-tuberculosis association in the United States in 1922, and for his work in anti-tuberculosis education was awarded the first class medal, Royal Order of Vasa, by King Gustaf V of Sweden.<cite><a href="Ekstrom, Claus Emanuel.html">Ekstrom, Claus Emanuel</a></cite>
Claus Emanuel Ekstrom retired from Brown in 1957.<cite><a href="Ekstrom, Claus Emanuel.html">Ekstrom, Claus Emanuel</a></cite>
Claus Emanuel Ekstrom died on November 22, 1981 in Middletown, Rhode Island.<cite><a href="Ekstrom, Claus Emanuel.html">Ekstrom, Claus Emanuel</a></cite>
Elizabethans was an association founded by women students in October 1930, probably prompted by the formation of the <a href="Erasmians.html">Erasmians</a>, as the constitution of that organization has been kept in the records of the Elizabethans.<cite><a href="Elizabethans.html">Elizabethans</a></cite>
Romeo Elton (1790-1870), professor of Latin and Greek, was born in Burlington, Connecticut, in 1790, His father was a farmer, and in early life Romeo Elton, of frail constitution and gentle disposition, engaged in agricultural pursuits for which he was not particulary suited.<cite><a href="Elton, Romeo.html">Elton, Romeo</a></cite>
Romeo Elton entered Brown University in 1810 and graduated in 1813.<cite><a href="Elton, Romeo.html">Elton, Romeo</a></cite>
Romeo Elton was ordained in 1817 and became minister of the Second Baptist church in Newport.<cite><a href="Elton, Romeo.html">Elton, Romeo</a></cite>
In 1825 Romeo Elton was appointed professor of Latin and Greek at Brown, but did not begin teaching immediately, as President Messer recommended that he first spend two years studying in Europe at his own expense.<cite><a href="Elton, Romeo.html">Elton, Romeo</a></cite>
Romeo Elton taught until 1843.<cite><a href="Elton, Romeo.html">Elton, Romeo</a></cite>
Charles T. Congdon 1841 wrote in his "Reminiscences:"  Living abroad was what appealed to Elton.<cite><a href="Elton, Romeo.html">Elton, Romeo</a></cite>
Romeo Elton moved to Exeter in England in 1845 and remained there until 1867, at which time he moved to Bath.<cite><a href="Elton, Romeo.html">Elton, Romeo</a></cite>
During this time Romeo Elton made only one visit to the United States in 1852.<cite><a href="Elton, Romeo.html">Elton, Romeo</a></cite>
In 1869 Romeo Elton returned and spent the last few months of his life in Newport and Boston.<cite><a href="Elton, Romeo.html">Elton, Romeo</a></cite>
Romeo Elton died at the Parker House in Boston on February 5, 1870.<cite><a href="Elton, Romeo.html">Elton, Romeo</a></cite>
Romeo Elton published a memoir of Roger Williams in 1853.<cite><a href="Elton, Romeo.html">Elton, Romeo</a></cite>
Emery and Woolley Halls were built in 1963 to house 227 students on the Pembroke <a href="Campus.html">Campus</a>.<cite><a href="Emery and Woolley Halls.html">Emery and Woolley Halls</a></cite>
The dormitories were named for Anne Crosby Emery Allinson, second dean of <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a>, and Mary Emma Woolley, one of the first two women graduates in 1894, who became president of Mount Holyoke College.<cite><a href="Emery and Woolley Halls.html">Emery and Woolley Halls</a></cite>
Engineering was part of Francis Wayland’s new curriculum of 1850.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
Norton left early in 1852 at the request of the Executive Board for not complying with the requirement of calling to see if students were in their rooms during study hours.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
At Brown he was replaced by Frederick Hesse, who was named as instructor in drawing and civil engineering, and by Rev. Henry Day, professor of natural philosophy and civil engineering from 1852 to 1854.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
Samuel Stillman Greene, who had been serving as professor of didactics, became professor of mathematics and civil engineering from 1855 to 1864.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
Among the early engineering graduates were Alexander Lyman Holley 1851, who made substantial improvements in the Bessemer steel-making process, and Robert H. Thurston 1859, pioneer in engineering education at Stevens Institute of Technology and Sibley College of Mechanical Engineering at Cornell and first president of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
Benjamin F. Clarke revived the study of civil engineering in 1868 and was appointed professor of mathematics and civil engineering.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
In 1893 Clarke’s title was changed to professor of mechanical engineering, an appointment he held until 1908.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
In 1874 Nathaniel F. Davis helped with the instruction in drawing.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
In 1886 all courses in drawing were taken over by Otis E. Randall, newly appointed instructor of mathematics and civil engineering.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
Randall was made assistant professor of mathematics and civil engineering in 1891, advanced the next year to associate professor of mechanical drawing, and was from 1892 to 1930 professor of applied mathematics.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
Until 1882 a room in <a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a> was used for drawing.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
Then a room on the top floor of <a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a> was used until 1884, when the central portion of the top floor of the newly renovated <a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a> was fitted up for drafting.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
By 1893 there were so many students of drawing that they worked in the east end of <a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a>, in the <a href="Psychology.html">Psychology</a> Laboratory, and even in the boxing room of the Gymnasium.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
Brown offered its first course leading to an engineering degree in 1891.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
Ernest H. Brownell 1888 (Sc.B., M.I.T. 1890) was named instructor in civil engineering.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
Edward C. Burnham 1886 (Sc.B., M.I.T. 1890), appointed instructor in mechanical drawing and engineering in 1892, developed a course in mechanical engineering.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
The first degree of Civil Engineer was awarded in 1892 to Frank E. Winsor 1892.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
William H. Kenerson 1896 was the first to earn the Mechanical Engineer degree in 1896.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
After 1905 the C.E.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
In 1894 a four-year course in architecture began and six new courses in freehand drawing were offered, making use of the second story of <a href="Manning Hall.html">Manning Hall</a>, which had been adapted for a drawing room.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
In 1895 the engineering workshops moved to the basement of the new <a href="Wilson Hall.html">Wilson Hall</a>, and the addition to the Chemical Laboratory (<a href="Rogers Hall.html">Rogers Hall</a>) provided drafting rooms.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
William D. Mount was assistant professor of mechanical engineering for one year in 1893-94.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
John E. Hill was appointed instructor in 1894 and served as professor of civil engineering until 1934.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
Kenerson was assistant in mathematics and drawing until 1901, when he became assistant professor of drawing and engineering.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
From 1906 he was associated with the teaching of mechanical engineering.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
The new Engineering Building was built on <a href="Lincoln Field.html">Lincoln Field</a> in 1903.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
For three weeks in 1905 a million-dollar pump invented by a retired Italian officer was placed at Brown for the Engineering Department to test.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
By 1907 interest in engineering courses had grown to the extent that fifty to sixty per cent of the class entering that year were candidates for the bachelor of science degree.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
Additions to the department in the early part of the twentieth century were Arthur H. Blanchard, who taught civil engineering from 1899 to 1910, Ansel Brooks, who taught mechanical drawing from 1903 to 1920, and Leighton T. Bohl, who taught civil engineering from 1913 to 1955.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
The Engineering Council, established in 1912, was composed of the three Engineering Departments, Civil, Mechanical and Electrical, and also the Departments of <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a>, Mechanics and Mechanical Drawing, <a href="Physics.html">Physics</a>, and <a href="Astronomy.html">Astronomy</a>.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
In 1914-15 in connection with the 150th anniversary a major exhibition was held in the Engineering Building, tracing the development of the steam engine (with models of Watts and Corliss engines and a steam turbine), the development of the internal combustion engine (with the Brayton engine purchased by Professor Blake in 1871 and engines lent by the Cadillac and Packard Motor Companies), and the development of the telephone, to which Professors Blake and Pierce contributed so much by developing useable receivers.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
In 1916 the separate Departments of Civil, Mechanical, and Electrical Engineering were combined into one Division of Engineering with a common core of basic engineering courses.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
In 1918 the Emergency Fleet <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> requested the assistance of engineering students on a sea trial of the S. S. Coyote, a wooden ship being outfitted at Field’s Point.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
More space was found for Engineering in 1925, when the <a href="President.html">President</a>’s report announced, "The new Engineering Laboratory includes both a new one-story structure, in the rear of <a href="Brunonia.html">Brunonia</a> Hall, and the renovated stone building adjacent, which the University has owned for some years.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
Another revolutionary change in engineering education at Brown took place in the 1950s, when the engineering curriculum became firmly based on the in-depth study of mathematics, the physical sciences, and the engineering sciences common to all branches of engineering.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
Paul F. Maeder received the first Ph.D. in engineering in 1951.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
Tau Beta Pi, the national engineering honor society founded at Lehigh University in 1885, established Rhode Island Alpha at Brown on February 12, 1954, at which time 128 alumni members were initiated.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
At the dedication of <a href="Prince Engineering Laboratory.html">Prince Engineering Laboratory</a> in 1962, Professor Paul Symonds explained the philosophy of engineering education at Brown: An experimental program, "Technology and Society," begun in the fall of 1972, designed to introduce engineering technology to students not specializing in engineering, was developed with a grant from the Westinghouse Educational Foundation.<cite><a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a></cite>
The Laws of 1774 required that each evening two students would "pronounce on the Stage," and the seniors and juniors would write a weekly "Dispute" on assigned topics.<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
When Nicholas Brown contributed the $5,000 which changed the name of the College in 1804, he specified that the money should be used to establish a Professorship of Oratory and Belles Letters (sic), a hope which his uncle John Brown had expressed in a letter the previous year.<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
Tristam Burges 1796 was named to the professorship in 1815.<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
In 1821 he began a course of lectures.<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
After that, as Burges complained in a letter written in 1826, the whole of the work had been assigned to him and had become a burden, although "The young men are, some times, considerate; &amp; do not "all" write; &amp; the two present Classes relieve me, in a more creditable manner; that is by writing very correctly."<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
Burges was soon relieved of his burden, after the arrival of Francis Wayland as president in 1827.<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
William Giles Goddard was professor of belles lettres from 1834 until his resignation in 1842.<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
William Gammell, assistant professor of belles lettres from 1835, was named professor of rhetoric in 1837.<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
Gammell switched to teaching history in 1850, and Robinson P. Dunn took over instruction in rhetoric and English literature until 1867.<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
Timothy Whiting Bancroft became professor of rhetoric and English literature in 1868.<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
Instruction in logic was part of the responsibility of the professor of rhetoric and English literature until 1874 when it was removed to the Department of <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a>.<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
In 1873-74 Bancroft introduced the reading of Chaucer with early English pronunciation and recommended the establishment of a professorship of Anglo-Saxon and early English, "a department now generally maintained in our leading colleges."<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
An editorial in the "<a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a>" of February 24, 1883 complained of the poor provision for instruction in the English Department, "One sadly overworked mortal is compelled to give instruction in composition and rhetoric, including argumentation, Anglo-Saxon language and literature, with the development of the English language, English literature, Chaucer and Shakspere, to say nothing of being obliged to wade through four hundred sophomore essays, and to writhe beneath an indefinite number of junior orations."<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
<a href="President.html">President</a> Robinson, recommending in his 1883 report that the duties of the department should be divided between a professor of rhetoric and a professor of English literature, wrote, "the most radical defect to-day in our American colleges is a want of due attention to rhetorical studies, understanding by these studies not only practice in the arts of composition and of speech ... but also that correctness of literary taste, that knowledge of English literature and that appreciation of its riches, without which facility and skill in the use of our tongue are never attainable."<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
Lorenzo Sears became associate professor of rhetoric in 1890, associate professor of rhetoric and oratory in 1892, and associate professor of American literature in 1895, at which time Hammond Lamont took over rhetoric and oratory.<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
In 1891 Louis F. Snow, instructor in elocution, was allowed to offer a special elective in Shakespeare for seniors.<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
John Matthews Manly was associate professor of English language and literature in 1891-92, and changed his position to associate professor of English language in 1892, when Walter C. Bronson began to teach English literature.<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
In 1895-96 the English Department under Professor Bronson offered a new Introductory Course in English Literature, taught by three faculty members.<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
<a href="Thomas Crosby.html">Thomas Crosby</a> succeeded Lamont in 1901, with the title of assistant professor of English and public speaking.<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
Albert K. Potter joined the department in 1898, George W. Benedict in 1899, Lindsay Todd Damon in 1901, and Henry B. Huntington in 1902.<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
William T. Hastings became an assistant in English after his graduation in 1903 and, except for two years of graduate study at Harvard, was a member of the department until 1952.<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
Benjamin C. Clough, better known as a professor of classics, first taught in the English Department from 1913 to 1924.<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
Ralph L. Blanchard arrived in 1915, and Benjamin W. Brown was appointed in 1921 to teach drama, public speaking, and playwriting.<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
Major changes in the English Department took place in 1927.<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
Other additions to the faculty of the English Department in the 1920s and their specialties were Robert W. Kenny (18th century), Leicester Bradner (16th century and Elizabethan drama) in 1926, and I. J. Kapstein (novel, composition, the romantic movement) in 1927.<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
In the 1930s and 40s the faculty was increased by the arrival of Clarence M. Webster (17th century) in 1936, Robert Gale Noyes (English novel) in 1937, Randall Stewart (American literature) in 1938, Janice O.<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
Van De Water (play writing and production) in 1940, Andrew J. Sabol (Renaissance literature) in 1941, Leslie Allen Jones (play production) in 1942, Charles H. Philbrick (poetry) and Elmer Blistein (Shakespeare and comedy) in 1946, and Edward Bloom (18th century and literary criticism) in 1947.<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
Jay Saunders Redding came as visiting professor in 1949-50 and gave the first course in Afro-American literature.<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
The English Department of the 1940s was recalled by Mark Spilka ’49 in his address to <a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a> in 1974: Later additions to the faculty were Albert D. Van Nostrand in 1951, James O. Barnhill in 1953, Hyatt H. Waggoner and Barbara K. Lewalski in 1956, R. Verlin Cassill, John C. B. Hawkes, and David Krause in 1958, Charles H. Nichols in 1960, David H. Hirsch in 1961, James E. Schevill and John Shroeder in 1968, Michael S. Harper and Robert E. Scholes in 1970.<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
Courses in film criticism were initiated by Mark Spilka about 1968, and in the fall semester of 1970-71 Maurice Rapf, New York film writer and director was a visiting instructor in the art of film making.<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
In November 1991 a festival of contemporary African writing organized by Professor Robert Coover and the Program in Creative Writing brought eighteen African writers from eleven countries to Brown.<cite><a href="English.html">English</a></cite>
Enrollment in 1765 consisted of one student, William Rogers from Newport, who entered on the third of September, one day before the second annual meeting of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a>.<cite><a href="Enrollment.html">Enrollment</a></cite>
No other student enrolled until June 20, 1766, when Richard Stites, young brother-in-law of <a href="President.html">President</a> Manning, became the second student.<cite><a href="Enrollment.html">Enrollment</a></cite>
A "matriculation roll" in the hand of James Manning lists 29 students who arrived between 1765 and 1769.<cite><a href="Enrollment.html">Enrollment</a></cite>
In 1770 there were twenty students and by 1775 enrollment had increased to 41.<cite><a href="Enrollment.html">Enrollment</a></cite>
The College was closed from 1776 to 1782.<cite><a href="Enrollment.html">Enrollment</a></cite>
In 1783 there were only twelve, but then there began a steady growth to 23 in 1784, 68 in 1789, 83 in 1793, and 100 in 1798.<cite><a href="Enrollment.html">Enrollment</a></cite>
The first printed "Catalogue of the Officers and Students" in 1800 listed the names and abodes of 107 students, of whom 74 were from Massachusetts, 22 from Rhode Island, four from South Carolina, four from Connecticut, two from Virginia, and one from New York.<cite><a href="Enrollment.html">Enrollment</a></cite>
The 152 students, fifty of them freshmen, who enrolled in 1821, called for the building of a new dormitory, and <a href="Hope College.html">Hope College</a> was built the following year.<cite><a href="Enrollment.html">Enrollment</a></cite>
Enrollment fluctuated from 98 in 1828, to 196 in 1836, back down to 140 in 1845.<cite><a href="Enrollment.html">Enrollment</a></cite>
In 1851 there were 225 students, including 55 in the select course and three resident graduates.<cite><a href="Enrollment.html">Enrollment</a></cite>
The total enrollment in 1890 was 352 from 25 states and three foreign countries.<cite><a href="Enrollment.html">Enrollment</a></cite>
By 1901, counting 176 women students and 94 graduate students the number had risen to 920.<cite><a href="Enrollment.html">Enrollment</a></cite>
At the end of the 1920s, when the student body had increased to over 2000, there was still some concern by alumni that students from Providence were going elsewhere.<cite><a href="Enrollment.html">Enrollment</a></cite>
After the second World War the restriction on the size of the University set by "The Policy in Force" in 1929 (1200 undergraduate men, 500 undergraduate women, 300 graduate students) was removed by the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> and, while no new limits were set, there was a general understanding that the number of students in the College would be about 2,000 and the number in <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a> would be between 750 and 800.<cite><a href="Enrollment.html">Enrollment</a></cite>
The demand for higher education after the war brought 822 students into the freshman class in the fall of 1946.<cite><a href="Enrollment.html">Enrollment</a></cite>
In the first semester of 1948-40 there were 3,261 undergraduate men with the veterans absorbed into the College, and 906 women at <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a>.<cite><a href="Enrollment.html">Enrollment</a></cite>
After the veterans had graduated, the male enrollment dropped to 2,077 in 1951.<cite><a href="Enrollment.html">Enrollment</a></cite>
In 1974 the report of the Committee on Plans and Resources recommended that undergraduate registration be limited to 5,150.<cite><a href="Enrollment.html">Enrollment</a></cite>
In 1972 the total enrollment topped 6,000 with 4,879 undergraduates, 40 percent of them women, and 1,357 graduate students.<cite><a href="Enrollment.html">Enrollment</a></cite>
In 1978 for the first time there were more women than men in the freshman class.<cite><a href="Enrollment.html">Enrollment</a></cite>
In September 1991 there were 5,864 undergraduates, 3,009 men and 2,855 women, almost evenly divided among the four classes, and 816 men and 563 women in the <a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a>.<cite><a href="Enrollment.html">Enrollment</a></cite>
Erasmians was an organization founded in 1930 by Professor Robert P. Casey.<cite><a href="Erasmians.html">Erasmians</a></cite>
As restated in the 1935 "<a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a>," the purpose of the members was to "form a miniature parliament ... to give training in unprepared speech," which they did until <a href="World War II.html">World War II</a> interrupted such activities.<cite><a href="Erasmians.html">Erasmians</a></cite>
The Erickson Athletic Complex is the name given in 1988 to the former <a href="Aldrich-Dexter Field.html">Aldrich-Dexter Field</a> on Hope Street in honor of Wendell R. Erickson ’19, a catcher on the baseball team, whose six million dollar bequest to the University would be used in part for the maintenance of athletic facilities.<cite><a href="Erickson Athletic Complex.html">Erickson Athletic Complex</a></cite>
Four structures together with the playing fields make up the athletic complex: <a href="Meehan Auditorium.html">Meehan Auditorium</a>, the ice rink built in 1961, <a href="Smith Swimming Center.html">Smith Swimming Center</a>, built in 1973, <a href="Olney-Margolies Athletic Center.html">Olney-Margolies Athletic Center</a>, built in 1981, and <a href="Pizzitola Sports Center.html">Pizzitola Sports Center</a>, completed in 1989.<cite><a href="Erickson Athletic Complex.html">Erickson Athletic Complex</a></cite>
Walter Goodnow Everett (1860-1937), professor of philosophy, was born in Rowe, Massachusetts, on August 21, 1860.<cite><a href="Everett, Walter G..html">Everett, Walter G.</a></cite>
Walter G. Everett graduated from Brown in 1885, after which he was a private tutor in Providence for four years.<cite><a href="Everett, Walter G..html">Everett, Walter G.</a></cite>
In 1889 Walter G. Everett became instructor in Greek and Latin at Brown, but changed his subject when he was named associate professor of philosophy in 1894.<cite><a href="Everett, Walter G..html">Everett, Walter G.</a></cite>
Walter G. Everett earned his Ph.D. degree at Brown in 1895, and then studied at the Universities of Berlin and Strasburg the following year.<cite><a href="Everett, Walter G..html">Everett, Walter G.</a></cite>
Walter G. Everett was head of the Philosophy Department from 1896 to 1930, and served as acting president while President Faunce made a trip around the world in 1912-13.<cite><a href="Everett, Walter G..html">Everett, Walter G.</a></cite>
