Walter G. Everett became internationally known for his book, "Moral Values," which was published in 1918, published in England in 1920, and translated into Japanese in 1929 at the request of the Imperial University of Tokyo.<cite><a href="Everett, Walter G..html">Everett, Walter G.</a></cite>
Walter G. Everett was appointed a delegate of the American Philosophical Association to the Allied Congress of Philosophy in Paris in 1921, and was president of the Association in 1922.<cite><a href="Everett, Walter G..html">Everett, Walter G.</a></cite>
At the last meeting of Everett’s famous course in Ethics in 1930, the students in the class presented him with a leather-bound illuminated testimonial, which read:<cite><a href="Everett, Walter G..html">Everett, Walter G.</a></cite>
The <a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a> Club was formed after the acquisition in 1922 of the house at 13 Brown Street.<cite><a href="Faculty Club.html">Faculty Club</a></cite>
<a href="President.html">President</a> Faunce, in his annual report in October 1922, pointed out the desire of the University to improve the "mutual acquaintance which is the prerequisite of intellectual understanding and cooperation."<cite><a href="Faculty Club.html">Faculty Club</a></cite>
In 1938 the <a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a> Club moved to the house at 1 Megee Street, the former home of Zachariah Allen 1813, designed by Alfred Stone and built in 1864, which had become the home of William Ely 1878.<cite><a href="Faculty Club.html">Faculty Club</a></cite>
In 1944 the Board of Governors admitted women to the main dining room.<cite><a href="Faculty Club.html">Faculty Club</a></cite>
In 1957 a new room in the basement was opened as a self-service lunchroom and later in the afternoon as an informal cocktail lounge, for which the principal ingredients were stored by faculty members in rented lockers.<cite><a href="Faculty Club.html">Faculty Club</a></cite>
In 1975 improvements were made to the building in the form of four new dining rooms.<cite><a href="Faculty Club.html">Faculty Club</a></cite>
The basement room, now named the "<a href="Brown Jug.html">Brown Jug</a>," was decorated with memorabilia of the 1920s, and also with a Class D liquor license obtained in December 1975.<cite><a href="Faculty Club.html">Faculty Club</a></cite>
A major renovation of the <a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a> Club was undertaken in 1980, when a one-story wing to the north and east, designed by Ira Rakatansky, was added, providing a main dining room for 100.<cite><a href="Faculty Club.html">Faculty Club</a></cite>
Faculty of one (<a href="President.html">President</a> James Manning) was enough to instruct a student body of one (William Rogers) in 1765.<cite><a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a></cite>
In 1768 the faculty was doubled by the appointment of David Howell, a 1766 graduate of New Jersey College (Princeton) as a tutor.<cite><a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a></cite>
The faculty was enlarged in 1784 by the appointment of Joseph Brown as professor of natural philosophy and Benjamin Waterhouse as professor of natural history, both of whom, according to <a href="President.html">President</a> Manning, "engaged to give Lectures in their respective Branches, without any Expence to the College, while destitute of an Endowment."<cite><a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a></cite>
Benjamin West lectured in mathematics and astronomy and Perez Fobes in natural philosophy from 1786 to 1798 when Asa Messer took over in these subjects.<cite><a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a></cite>
A professor of learned languages, Calvin Park, was engaged in 1804.<cite><a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a></cite>
Medical lectures were first offered in 1811 and it was necessary to procure professors in botany, chemistry, and medical subjects.<cite><a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a></cite>
In 1815, Tristam Burges was appointed to fill the first endowed professorship, that of Oratory and Belles Lettres, established by Nicholas Brown 1786 in 1804.<cite><a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a></cite>
When <a href="President.html">President</a> Wayland arrived in 1827, determined to take control of a student body which had become unruly, he revived a former rule that required the officers of instruction to visit the students’ rooms and added to it that the officers must "occupy rooms in College, during the hours appointed to study."<cite><a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a></cite>
The tutors were dismissed in 1846 to save funds, but two years later the senior professors were complaining about the added work and their own inadequate salaries.<cite><a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a></cite>
After <a href="President.html">President</a> Wayland’s New System with its curricular changes was introduced in 1850, the professors were given a choice of salaries, $1,200 per year or $500 per year augmented by fees based on the number of students in their classes.<cite><a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a></cite>
In 1856 the New System was abandoned and the professors’ salaries were set at $1,200.<cite><a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a></cite>
<a href="President.html">President</a> Ezekiel Gilman Robinson, arriving in 1872, was responsible for adding professorships in the sciences and modern languages.<cite><a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a></cite>
In Robinson’s last year, 1888-1889, there were fourteen professors, two assistant professors, and six instructors.<cite><a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a></cite>
In the nineteenth century the University drew its faculty from its own graduates, but in 1914 Walter C. Bronson pointed out in his "<a href="History.html">History</a> of Brown University" that the faculty "have had healthful diversity of training: fifty-four per cent of the teachers of professorial rank hold first degrees from colleges other than Brown, and sixty-five per cent have studied at two or more institutions; fifty-six per cent are Doctors of <a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a>."<cite><a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a></cite>
The admission of women students in 1891 brought about the appointment of the first women faculty members, hired to teach those courses which could not be taught to young ladies by a male professor, namely, biology, hygiene, and physical education.<cite><a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a></cite>
Lida Shaw King, the third dean, had the title of assistant professor of classical philology from 1905 to 1909 and professor of classical literature and archaeology from 1909 to 1922.<cite><a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a></cite>
Margaret S. Morriss, succeeding <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> King, was named associate professor of American history in 1923 and promoted to professor in 1932.<cite><a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a></cite>
The women’s biology course continued to be taught by women, but Magel C. Wilder ’19, who became an instructor in biology at the Women’s College in 1921 and was named assistant professor in 1930, also taught men students.<cite><a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a></cite>
At the time of her death in 1947, <a href="President.html">President</a> Wriston said, "So far as I can determine she is the first woman, other than administrative officers, to be appointed a full-time teacher in the University faculty, without having her work limited to <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a>, instructing both men and women.<cite><a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a></cite>
Tenure was reserved for full professors until 1940, when 36 associate professors and seven assistant professors were given the same privilege.<cite><a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a></cite>
In 1969 the first Faculty Policy Group was elected.<cite><a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a></cite>
In the 1970s a large majority of the faculty was still male, when Louise Lamphere, an assistant professor of anthropology who had not been granted tenure in 1974, brought a class-action suit against Brown University, charging sex discrimination in hiring, promotion, renewal of contracts, and granting of tenure.<cite><a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a></cite>
The case was settled out of court in September 1977.<cite><a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a></cite>
In 1977, as required by the federal government, Brown developed an Affirmative Action Plan to increase the number of women and minority members of the faculty.<cite><a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a></cite>
In 1979 there were 64 women (30 tenured, 34 non-tenured) and 35 minority faculty members (25 tenured, 10 non-tenured) out of a total 376 tenured and 113 non-tenured faculty membership.<cite><a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a></cite>
In 1989 Brown’s request that the consent decree be terminated was denied by Judge Raymond Pettine, who ordered the University to grant tenure to thirteen more women by 1991.<cite><a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a></cite>
Since 1973 tenure has not been granted to hospital-based faculty of the Medical School, for whom senior appointments are for five years and are renewable and appointments as assistant professor are limited to nine years.<cite><a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a></cite>
Harrison (Harry) Edward Farnsworth (1896-1989), professor of physics, was born in Ripon, Wisconsin, on March 24, 1896.<cite><a href="Farnsworth, Harrison E..html">Farnsworth, Harrison E.</a></cite>
Harrison E. Farnsworth graduated from Ripon College in 1918 and earned his A.M. and Ph.D. degrees from the University of Wisconsin in 1921 and 1922.<cite><a href="Farnsworth, Harrison E..html">Farnsworth, Harrison E.</a></cite>
Harrison E. Farnsworth's first published paper in 1922 reported that some secondary electrons were reflected without loss of energy, an observation which was at first criticized, but later confirmed.<cite><a href="Farnsworth, Harrison E..html">Farnsworth, Harrison E.</a></cite>
Harrison E. Farnsworth taught at the University of Pittsburgh in 1918-19, was a teaching assistant and research fellow at the University of Wisconsin from 1919 to 1924 and associate professor at the University of Maine from 1924 until 1926, when he came to Brown as assistant professor of physics.<cite><a href="Farnsworth, Harrison E..html">Farnsworth, Harrison E.</a></cite>
Harrison E. Farnsworth was promoted to associate professor in 1929 and professor in 1946.<cite><a href="Farnsworth, Harrison E..html">Farnsworth, Harrison E.</a></cite>
In 1960 Harrison E. Farnsworth was designated a research professor and in 1963 was named the Annette L. R. Barstow University Professor.<cite><a href="Farnsworth, Harrison E..html">Farnsworth, Harrison E.</a></cite>
Harrison E. Farnsworth was chairman of the Department of Physics in 1942-43 and a member of the executive committee of the department from 1954 to 1956.<cite><a href="Farnsworth, Harrison E..html">Farnsworth, Harrison E.</a></cite>
In 1941 Harrison E. Farnsworth was on leave to work on a war project at M.I.T.<cite><a href="Farnsworth, Harrison E..html">Farnsworth, Harrison E.</a></cite>
Harrison E. Farnsworth retired in 1970 and moved to Tucson, Arizona, where he set up a laboratory at the University of Arizona, which he later moved to his home, so that he continued his research almost until his death in Tucson on November 14, 1989.<cite><a href="Farnsworth, Harrison E..html">Farnsworth, Harrison E.</a></cite>
Faunce House was originally named Rockefeller Hall when the west end of the present building was erected in 1904.<cite><a href="Faunce House.html">Faunce House</a></cite>
This came about after John D. Rockefeller, Jr. 1897 wrote to the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> on January 6, 1902, "My father stands ready to erect, furnish and give to the corporation of Brown University, free of expense, a building to be devoted primarily to the social and religious uses of the students of the university.<cite><a href="Faunce House.html">Faunce House</a></cite>
Inscribed in stone on the north side of the building are quotations in French:<br />   "Il se faut entr’aide<br />   C’est la loi de nature"<br /> and in Latin:<br />   "Vivat, Floreat, Crescat, <a href="Brunonia.html">Brunonia</a>"  The new building was dedicated on January 20, 1904, and provided on the first floor a large reading room, a central room for the exhibition of college trophies, and a smoking room.<cite><a href="Faunce House.html">Faunce House</a></cite>
At <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> 1930, John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gave $600,000 for the enlargement of Rockefeller Hall, requesting that the building be renamed Faunce House as a memorial to <a href="President.html">President</a> Faunce who had died in January.<cite><a href="Faunce House.html">Faunce House</a></cite>
The Faunce Memorial Room, a room furnished in a manner to invite meditation and containing a portrait of <a href="President.html">President</a> Faunce, was dedicated after the <a href="Baccalaureate.html">Baccalaureate</a> service in 1934 with a ceremony at which Faunce’s voice was heard from a phonograph record.<cite><a href="Faunce House.html">Faunce House</a></cite>
The sun-dial on the south wall of Faunce House was a gift from Delta Phi in 1938 in observance of the centennial of the Brown chapter.<cite><a href="Faunce House.html">Faunce House</a></cite>
The Blue Room was installed during the summer of 1939, during <a href="President.html">President</a> Wriston’s absence.<cite><a href="Faunce House.html">Faunce House</a></cite>
In 1969 the central section of the first floor was redecorated and promptly dubbed the "Airport Lounge" by students in honor of its style of furniture.<cite><a href="Faunce House.html">Faunce House</a></cite>
In 1977 the lounge was greatly expanded by removing walls to make a room sixty by forty feet.<cite><a href="Faunce House.html">Faunce House</a></cite>
In the early 1980s changes began to return the building to its purpose as a student center, as Faunce House underwent a major renovation, designed by architects Goody, Clancy and Associates.<cite><a href="Faunce House.html">Faunce House</a></cite>
The renovated building was rededicated on May 26, 1989.<cite><a href="Faunce House.html">Faunce House</a></cite>
William Herbert Perry Faunce (1859-1930), ninth president of Brown University, was born in Worcester, Massachusetts, on January 15, 1859, the son of Reverend Daniel W. Faunce, a graduate of Amherst College and Newton Theological Institution and Mary Parkhurst Perry of Bristol.<cite><a href="Faunce, William H. P..html">Faunce, William H. P.</a></cite>
After high school in Concord, New Hampshire, William H. P. Faunce entered Brown in 1876.<cite><a href="Faunce, William H. P..html">Faunce, William H. P.</a></cite>
On January 12, 1879 during the week of his twentieth birthday he wrote a twenty-page letter to his father, full of memories of past problems and uncertainty about the future:  When the beloved president known to students as "Prexy" and "Willie Horse Power Faunce" retired in 1929 at the age of seventy, the Corporation wanted to provide a residence for him, and $40,000 was contributed by five friends to acquire the house at 41 Lloyd Avenue where he lived until his death on January 31, 1930.<cite><a href="Faunce, William H. P..html">Faunce, William H. P.</a></cite>
This happened in 1790.<cite><a href="Federal Adelphi.html">Federal Adelphi</a></cite>
The applicants resolved to form their own society, but the death of <a href="President.html">President</a> Manning and the unsettled condition of the college intervened and it was not until 1797, when Jonathan Maxcy, who had been president "pro tem" for five years, was appointed president, that the formation of the society was actively taken up again.<cite><a href="Federal Adelphi.html">Federal Adelphi</a></cite>
"Old Citizen," writing in the "Providence Journal" on July 2, 1851, recalled the festivities on the day after <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a>: In 1831 Tristam Burges 1796, resigning after many years as president of the Federal Adelphi, delivered an eloquent address.<cite><a href="Federal Adelphi.html">Federal Adelphi</a></cite>
After 1835 the meetings of the Federal Adelphi ceased.<cite><a href="Federal Adelphi.html">Federal Adelphi</a></cite>
The Alan Shawn Feinstein World Hunger Program was inaugurated on February 26, 1985, at a convocation on world hunger held in <a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a>, at which James Grant, executive director of the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF), was the keynote speaker.<cite><a href="Feinstein World Hunger Program.html">Feinstein World Hunger Program</a></cite>
In October 1986, as part of World Hunger Week, the first national Alan Shawn Feinstein World Hunger Program Awards were presented to Ahangamage Tudor Ariyaratne, founder of the Sarvodaya Shramadan rural development movement in Sri Lanka, and Achola Pala Okeyo from Kenya, representing the International Centre of Insect Physiology and Ecology.<cite><a href="Feinstein World Hunger Program.html">Feinstein World Hunger Program</a></cite>
The first annual Hunger Briefing and Research Exchange held at Brown in 1988 featured Kates’s "The Hunger Report," which concluded that current programs could be expected to effect the end of a significant portion of world hunger.<cite><a href="Feinstein World Hunger Program.html">Feinstein World Hunger Program</a></cite>
The 1990 awards were presented to the Bangladesh Rural Advancement Committee, the Women’s Organization (WARMI) of Independencia, Peru, and Harvard professor Amartya Sen.<cite><a href="Feinstein World Hunger Program.html">Feinstein World Hunger Program</a></cite>
In 1991 the awards honored the people of Iringa, Tanzania for a nutritional program for children, Nevin S. Scrimshaw for organizing a World Hunger Program at United Nations University, and Patricia Young for the observation of World Food Day.<cite><a href="Feinstein World Hunger Program.html">Feinstein World Hunger Program</a></cite>
The Fence around the campus was erected on 1903 after the building of the <a href="Van Wickle Gates.html">Van Wickle Gates</a>.<cite><a href="Fence.html">Fence</a></cite>
The 1786 section was not a gift of the long-departed class, but was given in honor of the class of Nicholas Brown.<cite><a href="Fence.html">Fence</a></cite>
The gates in the fence are the 1872 Gate on Prospect Street, the Robinson Gate on Waterman Street, a gift of the Class of 1884 dedicated at <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> 1904 in memory of <a href="President.html">President</a> Ezekiel Gilman Robinson, and the <a href="Class of 1887 Gate.html">Class of 1887 Gate</a> on Waterman Street.<cite><a href="Fence.html">Fence</a></cite>
The gates on George Street are the <a href="John Nicholas Brown Gate.html">John Nicholas Brown Gate</a>, given in 1903 by his widow, the William Goddard Memorial Gate, given by Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin in 1911 in memory of her father, Chancellor William Goddard 1846, and the Psi Upsilon gate, dedicated by the fraternity at the time of its centennial in 1940.<cite><a href="Fence.html">Fence</a></cite>
The Class of 1923 bought its section in 1956, paying $2750, the estimated cost of adding a new section at that time.<cite><a href="Fence.html">Fence</a></cite>
The Classes of 1907, 1924, 1929, and 1934 had their numerals added in 1964, and the Class of 1932 numerals were added to 1992.<cite><a href="Fence.html">Fence</a></cite>
Fencing was an activity assigned to the senior class in the physical education program devised in the 1890s after the building of Lyman Gymnasium.<cite><a href="Fencing.html">Fencing</a></cite>
In December 1932 Fred Avis ’35 recruited and coached a team of his fellow students and arranged two informal engagements, which resulted in two victories for Brown, 12-5 against a Y.M.C.A. team and 9-0 against Rhode Island State College.<cite><a href="Fencing.html">Fencing</a></cite>
The fencing team had winning seasons in 1934 and 1935, but by 1936 the varsity team was reduced to five members, who had to double up in order to have three contenders on each of the sabre, epee, and foils.<cite><a href="Fencing.html">Fencing</a></cite>
In 1937 the schedule was expanded to include opponents beyond the Providence and Boston areas, and ended with a 6-3 record.<cite><a href="Fencing.html">Fencing</a></cite>
The team had an instructor, Antone Sobocinski, from 1939 until 1942, and was first in the New England tournament in 1940 and third in 1941.<cite><a href="Fencing.html">Fencing</a></cite>
Fencing ceased in 1943 and was resumed in 1946 with Sobocinski as coach.<cite><a href="Fencing.html">Fencing</a></cite>
In 1963 the men’s Fencing Club under faculty advisor William Silvert for the first time in years scheduled matches with clubs from other New England colleges.<cite><a href="Fencing.html">Fencing</a></cite>
The Fencing Club was reestablished in the fall of 1971 through the efforts of Professor Duncan Smith, who borrowed equipment from the Pembroke Fencing Club and attracted eighteen students, eight of whom were still involved by November and being coached by Smith and a special student and sabre fencer, Chuck Dillon.<cite><a href="Fencing.html">Fencing</a></cite>
In 1972-73 the number of students interested in fencing had increased to more than eighty.<cite><a href="Fencing.html">Fencing</a></cite>
In 1973 the new club participated in its first meet, winning a scrimmage against Southeastern Massachusetts University.<cite><a href="Fencing.html">Fencing</a></cite>
In 1973-74 Brown entered the New England Intercollegiate Fencing League, finished with a 5-4 record and placed fifth in the regionals.<cite><a href="Fencing.html">Fencing</a></cite>
Fencing became a coed sport in 1973-74, and the next year the team had twelve men and ten women.<cite><a href="Fencing.html">Fencing</a></cite>
Brown was fourth in the New Englands in 1976, had a 7-4 dual meet record and came in fourth in the New Englands in 1977-78, and the next year had a 7-3 dual meet record and took third place in the New Englands.<cite><a href="Fencing.html">Fencing</a></cite>
In 1980, the first year that women’s fencing was a varsity (though unfunded) sport, Chris Golde ’82 finished second in the New England tournament.<cite><a href="Fencing.html">Fencing</a></cite>
In 1986 Brown hosted the New England Championships at Marvel Gym.<cite><a href="Fencing.html">Fencing</a></cite>
Elliot Lilien, an outstanding high school fencing coach, succeeded Duncan Smith as coach in 1986.<cite><a href="Fencing.html">Fencing</a></cite>
In the 1990-91 season the men finished 18-10 and the women 15-9.<cite><a href="Fencing.html">Fencing</a></cite>
William Leopold Fichter (1892-1985), professor of Spanish language and literature, was born in New York City on January 5, 1892.<cite><a href="Fichter, William L..html">Fichter, William L.</a></cite>
William L. Fichter received his Sc.B., A.M., and Ph.D. degrees, all from Columbia, in 1914, 1918, and 1926.<cite><a href="Fichter, William L..html">Fichter, William L.</a></cite>
William L. Fichter taught at the High School of Commerce in New York City from 1914 to 1917, at the United States Naval Academy from 1917 to 1922, at Girard College from 1922 to 1925, and at the University of Minnesota from 1925 to 1928.<cite><a href="Fichter, William L..html">Fichter, William L.</a></cite>
William L. Fichter came to Brown as associate professor of Spanish language and literature in 1928, and became full professor in 1938.<cite><a href="Fichter, William L..html">Fichter, William L.</a></cite>
William L. Fichter spent his sabbatic leaves in 1940-41 and 1947-48 studying Spanish and Indian civilizations in Mexico and Guatemala, and was visiting lecturer at Harvard in 1952-53.<cite><a href="Fichter, William L..html">Fichter, William L.</a></cite>
William L. Fichter retired in 1962, and the next year was visiting Andrew Mellon Professor of Romance Languages at the University of Pittsburgh.<cite><a href="Fichter, William L..html">Fichter, William L.</a></cite>
In 1977 William L. Fichter received from the King of Spain the decoration of the Order of Alfonso X, el Sabio (the Learned) in a ceremony in the Hispanic House at Brown.<cite><a href="Fichter, William L..html">Fichter, William L.</a></cite>
William L. Fichter died on March 9, 1985 at the age of 93.<cite><a href="Fichter, William L..html">Fichter, William L.</a></cite>
Field <a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a> was played by women students in as early as 1905, when the women were allowed to use the <a href="Metcalf Botanical Garden.html">Metcalf Botanical Garden</a> for outdoor sports.<cite><a href="Field Hockey.html">Field Hockey</a></cite>
The sport received a new impetus when Bessie Rudd arrived in 1930.<cite><a href="Field Hockey.html">Field Hockey</a></cite>
There Constance Applebee, who brought hockey from England to the United States in 1901, operated a hockey camp for many years.<cite><a href="Field Hockey.html">Field Hockey</a></cite>
In 1933 she started a Providence <a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a> Club, which became a member of the U.S. <a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a> Association.<cite><a href="Field Hockey.html">Field Hockey</a></cite>
In the fall of 1933 one hundred students came out for hockey competition between the classes.<cite><a href="Field Hockey.html">Field Hockey</a></cite>
From the 1930s into the 1950s Pembroke played against Rhode Island State, Jackson, Radcliffe, Wheaton, Mount Holyoke, and others, and took part in the annual Wellesley Play Day (afterwards the Wellesley Sports Day).<cite><a href="Field Hockey.html">Field Hockey</a></cite>
In 1960, Bessie Rudd’s last season of coaching, Pembroke finished 5-1, losing only to the Bouvé School, which specialized in physical education.<cite><a href="Field Hockey.html">Field Hockey</a></cite>
After Miss Rudd, field hockey was coached by Sarah Phillips from 1961 to 1968, Joan Taylor from 1969 to 1971, and Jan Lutz in 1972.<cite><a href="Field Hockey.html">Field Hockey</a></cite>
Interest in field hockey had waned, but picked up in the fall of 1973, when 38 women came out for practice and no games had been scheduled.<cite><a href="Field Hockey.html">Field Hockey</a></cite>
After four years without a victory, the 1973 team, coached by Marge Anderson, wife of football coach John Anderson, finished 7-4-2 after a slow start and won three games in the New England All-College Tourney.<cite><a href="Field Hockey.html">Field Hockey</a></cite>
Debbie Field coached in 1974.<cite><a href="Field Hockey.html">Field Hockey</a></cite>
The team had a successful 6-2-1 season in 1975, the first year with Dale Philippi as a regular coach.<cite><a href="Field Hockey.html">Field Hockey</a></cite>
Julie Dickson coached from 1979 to 1983 with a record of 16-42-12.<cite><a href="Field Hockey.html">Field Hockey</a></cite>
Wendy Anderson’s first team in 1984 won a share of the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> title with Dartmouth.<cite><a href="Field Hockey.html">Field Hockey</a></cite>
After placing second in the next three years, the 1989 team with a record of 11-5-1 overall, set a new record for most wins in a season, won another Ivy title, and also won its first ECAC championship.<cite><a href="Field Hockey.html">Field Hockey</a></cite>
The 1991 season ended with a four-way tie for the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> championship shared with with Cornell, Harvard, and Princeton, and a loss in triple overtime to Princeton in the first round of the ECAC tournament.<cite><a href="Field Hockey.html">Field Hockey</a></cite>
Wendy Anderson’s record from 1984 to 1991 was 54-49-17.<cite><a href="Field Hockey.html">Field Hockey</a></cite>
Lauren Becker was a three-time All-Ivy choice from 1984 to 1986.<cite><a href="Field Hockey.html">Field Hockey</a></cite>
Charles Thompson 1769 received fourteen pounds from a legacy left by the widow of John Hobbs of the Philadelphia Association for the education of pious youths for the ministry.<cite><a href="Financial aid.html">Financial aid</a></cite>
In 1792 the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> authorized the president to employ one of the students to ring the bell and to allow him tuition and room rent.<cite><a href="Financial aid.html">Financial aid</a></cite>
Students from South Carolina came to the College in the 1790s with the support of Reverend Richard Furman.<cite><a href="Financial aid.html">Financial aid</a></cite>
In the 1830s the Northern Baptist Association provided scholarship aid for students.<cite><a href="Financial aid.html">Financial aid</a></cite>
The first scholarships provided by the University were established in 1858.<cite><a href="Financial aid.html">Financial aid</a></cite>
The will of Nicholas Brown 1786, who died in 1841, had instructed that half of the net income from certain properties should be made available to the University and that these funds be used, with the advice of the Warren <a href="Education.html">Education</a> Society, to aid "deserving young men in obtaining their education while members of said University."<cite><a href="Financial aid.html">Financial aid</a></cite>
<a href="President.html">President</a> Wayland, who was believer in the efficacy of prizes in the cultivation of scholarship, chose to use a portion of the money, as was announced in the annual catalogue of 1842, for the award of "premiums, either in money or books, to such competitors as may by examination prove themselves most meritorious."<cite><a href="Financial aid.html">Financial aid</a></cite>
After a while, fewer students were competing for the premiums (in small classes they could often predict who would win, anyway), and in 1858 under <a href="President.html">President</a> Sears the funds for the University Premiums were converted into eleven scholarships, each the income of $1000.<cite><a href="Financial aid.html">Financial aid</a></cite>
In 1859 Reverend Horace T. Love was appointed a joint agent of Brown University and Colby College to collect subscriptions for scholarships and other objects.<cite><a href="Financial aid.html">Financial aid</a></cite>
From his collections until 1863 and the efforts of <a href="President.html">President</a> Sears, by the end of Sears’s administration $259,000 had been subscribed.<cite><a href="Financial aid.html">Financial aid</a></cite>
In September 1860, Miss Lydia Carpenter, a member of the <a href="First Baptist Church.html">First Baptist Church</a> of Pawtucket, who had been baptized by Reverend David Benedict 1806, added four thousand dollars to a thousand which she had donated to the University in 1858 to establish a fund "to be called the AID FUND, which is to be applied to help deserving students, who may need aid after their admission into Brown University."<cite><a href="Financial aid.html">Financial aid</a></cite>
In 1869 45 students were aided by scholarships and nine by the aid fund, for a total of $3270, and two students were beneficiaries of the agricultural land fund.<cite><a href="Financial aid.html">Financial aid</a></cite>
In 1871, when tuition was raised from $50 to $75, the faculty was authorized to extend abatement of tuition amounting to $25 to up to two-fifths of the students.<cite><a href="Financial aid.html">Financial aid</a></cite>
In 1872 there were 52 scholarships available, fourteen of them assigned by the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a>, the remainder by donors or their representatives, and in addition five students were receiving free rooms for keeping the rolls of attendance at chapel.<cite><a href="Financial aid.html">Financial aid</a></cite>
The Rand Fund, established by a gift of one hundred dollars from Professor Albert E. Rand in 1913-14, was increased by other contributions and put at the disposal of the dean of undergraduates as an emergency loan fund for students who needed aid for a short time.<cite><a href="Financial aid.html">Financial aid</a></cite>
A student loan fund, established in 1926-27, authorized a committee to lend annually through a local trust company up to $50,000.<cite><a href="Financial aid.html">Financial aid</a></cite>
After weathering the strain of the Depression, when students were unable to repay loans and the Society had to raise an extra $750, the Society turned its fund over to the University in 1941.<cite><a href="Financial aid.html">Financial aid</a></cite>
The federal loan program of the National Defense <a href="Education.html">Education</a> Act provided aid to students, but Brown withdrew from the program in 1961 in opposition to the requirement that a student applying for a loan sign a disclaimer affidavit stating that he did not belong to or support any association which believed in the overthrow of the government of the United States.<cite><a href="Financial aid.html">Financial aid</a></cite>
Financial need is determined by a system of needs analysis developed in 1954 by the College Scholarship Service of the College Entrance Examination Board, which was later made law by Congress.<cite><a href="Financial aid.html">Financial aid</a></cite>
When the Class of 1993 entered in 1989, an unexpected 38 percent of its members were awarded financial aid and accounted for an excess $1.2 million in the University budget.<cite><a href="Financial aid.html">Financial aid</a></cite>
Students on Financial Aid (SOFA) is an organization which evolved in 1988 from a discussion group which had been meeting regularly in the chaplain’s office.<cite><a href="Financial aid.html">Financial aid</a></cite>
The First Baptist Church, which has been the scene of Brown commencements since 1776, was the first Baptist Church in America.<cite><a href="First Baptist Church.html">First Baptist Church</a></cite>
When Roger Williams was banished from Massachusetts for his religious and political beliefs, he came in 1636 with five others to a place he named Providence.<cite><a href="First Baptist Church.html">First Baptist Church</a></cite>
Joined by other Separatists, he became the first pastor of the group of about twelve persons which constituted the Church in 1638.<cite><a href="First Baptist Church.html">First Baptist Church</a></cite>
In 1771, after the removal of the College to Providence, <a href="President.html">President</a> James Manning became pastor of the church, continuing until 1791.<cite><a href="First Baptist Church.html">First Baptist Church</a></cite>
Other Brown presidents who served as pastor were Jonathan Maxcy, who served for one year, 1791-1792, resigning when he became president of the college, and Francis Wayland, who was acting pastor from March 1857 to June 1858.<cite><a href="First Baptist Church.html">First Baptist Church</a></cite>
It was during his ministry that the Society resolved in February 1774 to build a meeting-house "for the publick Worship of Almighty GOD; and also for holding <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> in."<cite><a href="First Baptist Church.html">First Baptist Church</a></cite>
The building cost 7000 pounds, of which 2000 pounds was raised by a state-authorized lottery.<cite><a href="First Baptist Church.html">First Baptist Church</a></cite>
The meeting house was dedicated on May 28, 1775.<cite><a href="First Baptist Church.html">First Baptist Church</a></cite>
Since 1776 all Commencements have been held there, except for those of 1804 and 1832.<cite><a href="First Baptist Church.html">First Baptist Church</a></cite>
A Flag for the University was designed by Henry L. P. Beckwith ’58 and carried for the first time at the inauguration of <a href="President.html">President</a> Swearer in 1977.<cite><a href="Flag.html">Flag</a></cite>
An earlier flag which was designed by Theodore Francis Green 1887 to be carried at the inauguration of <a href="President.html">President</a> Barbour in 1929 was made of brown silk with a white shield in the center on which a brown bear rampant displays a flashing red tongue.<cite><a href="Flag.html">Flag</a></cite>
In 1964 a bicentennial flag bearing the bicentennial emblem, which was sewn by Shirley Morrison ’64, was flown each day beneath the American flag on the College Green.<cite><a href="Flag.html">Flag</a></cite>
In the 1938 hurricane it was blown down and its top was broken off.<cite><a href="Flagpole.html">Flagpole</a></cite>
When it was raised again, it was placed on a base erected by the American Hellenic Educational Progressive Association as a memorial to Samuel Gridley Howe 1821, who was surgeon-in-chief of the Greek fleet during the Greek War of Independence, 1820-1829.<cite><a href="Flagpole.html">Flagpole</a></cite>
The marble and bronze base was dedicated on June 4, 1941.<cite><a href="Flagpole.html">Flagpole</a></cite>
Flat Top was a particularly unattractive building which was erected on the lower campus between the <a href="Lincoln Field Building.html">Lincoln Field Building</a> and the <a href="Metcalf Research Laboratory.html">Metcalf Research Laboratory</a> in 1946 for use as a temporary cafeteria building.<cite><a href="Flat Top.html">Flat Top</a></cite>
It remained in this unsatisfactory location, where cashiers sometimes had to wear boots when the floors were flooded, until 1951, when the shortage of dining facilities was ended with the opening of <a href="Sharpe Refectory.html">Sharpe Refectory</a>.<cite><a href="Flat Top.html">Flat Top</a></cite>
A Flying Club called the Brown University Aero Club was first organized in January 1928 by about thirty students who had an interest in aviation, and was assisted in its formation by Joseph K. Barber, a registered pilot.<cite><a href="Flying Club.html">Flying Club</a></cite>
The Glider Club was formed in the fall of 1930, and its first year acquired part ownership in a hangar and two gliders.<cite><a href="Flying Club.html">Flying Club</a></cite>
The Brown Aviation Club with about 25 <a href="Charter.html">Charter</a> members was organized in 1931, at which time the members made it clear that they were not connected with the University Glider Club.<cite><a href="Flying Club.html">Flying Club</a></cite>
Flying instruction became available from another source in the fall of 1939, when a Civil Aeronautics Authority program of pilot training courses was introduced.<cite><a href="Flying Club.html">Flying Club</a></cite>
After the end of <a href="World War II.html">World War II</a>, flying was a popular hobby, and a new Flying Club was organized in 1946.<cite><a href="Flying Club.html">Flying Club</a></cite>
In 1948 a non-profit student corporation of the Club members named Air Brown Inc. purchased a Taylorcraft plane after raising the $400 down payment from twenty members, each of whom contributed twenty dollars.<cite><a href="Flying Club.html">Flying Club</a></cite>
In 1948, when students from Rhode Island State College painted the bear in front of Marvel Gym blue prior to the traditional Brown-Rhode Island football game and Brown students were threatened with expulsion if they entered the Rhode Island State campus in retaliation, flyers from Brown, with their own plane and four others which had been rented, bombarded the campus of Rhode Island State College in Kingston with 20,000 leaflets.<cite><a href="Flying Club.html">Flying Club</a></cite>
The "<a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a>" in 1951, noting that the club now had two planes, mentioned a fringe benefit for members, who were allowed to "have use of the planes at their convenience ...<cite><a href="Flying Club.html">Flying Club</a></cite>
In 1951 the Brown club won seven events in a Cape Cod meet sponsored by Harvard.<cite><a href="Flying Club.html">Flying Club</a></cite>
Interest in flying seems to have waned after 1953, and the Flying Club no longer appeared in the "<a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a>"  A new Glider Club was formed in 1969 with Professor Boris Rotman as its instructor and Vincent Simmon ’72 as its first president.<cite><a href="Flying Club.html">Flying Club</a></cite>
The first flight by the club was made on May 27, 1969, at a small grass airfield called Coventry Park, where a car-winch was used for launching the glider.<cite><a href="Flying Club.html">Flying Club</a></cite>
In 1974 the club acquired a new glider with better performance, and moved to North Central Airport in Lincoln, Rhode Island.<cite><a href="Flying Club.html">Flying Club</a></cite>
Between twelve and fifteen students took the course, which was offered again in 1975.<cite><a href="Flying Club.html">Flying Club</a></cite>
In 1979 the Glider Club joined forces with a club at M.I.T., enabling it to share the M.I.T. gliders and a plane for launching.<cite><a href="Flying Club.html">Flying Club</a></cite>
Interest in gliding declined at Brown, and when the Brown glider was destroyed in a windstorm at the Mansfield Airport in April 1980, the Brown Soaring Club invested the insurance money in a plane instead of a new glider.<cite><a href="Flying Club.html">Flying Club</a></cite>
Perez Fobes (1742-1812), professor of natural philosophy and vice-president of the College in 1786, was born in Bridgewater, Massachusetts, on September 21, 1742, one of twelve children.<cite><a href="Fobes, Perez.html">Fobes, Perez</a></cite>
Perez Fobes taught school and graduated from Harvard in 1762.<cite><a href="Fobes, Perez.html">Fobes, Perez</a></cite>
Perez Fobes was licensed to preach, and on November 19, 1766 was ordained as pastor of a Congregational church in Raynham, Massachusetts, where he remained for the rest of his life.<cite><a href="Fobes, Perez.html">Fobes, Perez</a></cite>
When President Manning was elected representative to Congress, Fobes was appointed to oversee the College from June 1 to September 1, 1786.<cite><a href="Fobes, Perez.html">Fobes, Perez</a></cite>
Later in the year Perez Fobes was named professor of natural philosophy, replacing Joseph Brown, who had died in 1785.<cite><a href="Fobes, Perez.html">Fobes, Perez</a></cite>
On August 1, 1791, four days after the death of Manning, Fobes was requested by the Corporation to "attend the College from this time ’till Commencement to supervise the instruction of the Students &amp; perform prayers &amp;c." The efficacy of his prayer is recorded in "The Ministry of Taunton" by Samuel Hopkins Emery: Fobes allowed the College the benefit of the scientific apparatus which he owned while he was a professor, and on resigning in 1798 left behind the instruments, for the use of which the College paid him fifty dollars a year.<cite><a href="Fobes, Perez.html">Fobes, Perez</a></cite>
In 1796 Perez Fobes was placed in charge of Bristol Academy in Massachusetts, where he encouraged students to come to the College.<cite><a href="Fobes, Perez.html">Fobes, Perez</a></cite>
Perez Fobes died on February 23, 1812.<cite><a href="Fobes, Perez.html">Fobes, Perez</a></cite>
1 was a mimeographed "magazine of experiment ... devoted frankly to creative talent" which came out in December 1931 and sold for fifteen cents.<cite><a href="Folio.html">Folio</a></cite>
The sport, banned by <a href="President.html">President</a> Sears in 1862, became very popular with all the classes when it was reinstated in 1866, and then reverted to its former status as a freshman-sophomore encounter.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
In 1874 a football association was formed, but Brown did not play an intercollegiate game until invited by Amherst College in 1878.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
On November 12, 1878 (nine years to the day after Rutgers and Princeton played the first intercollegiate game) Brown arrived at Amherst fitted out with white canvas uniforms and brown stockings, which they had obtained two days before the game for a fifty-dollar down payment and Brown Football Association <a href="President.html">President</a> George Malcom’s watch as security for the balance.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
There they found the Amherst team more up-to-date in jersey uniforms, which Brown captain Alfred U. Eddy 1879 recalls, enabled them "to dash up and down the field without encumbrance, and when our men got hold of an opposing runner, the jersey stretched and he either pulled away completely or added four or five yards to his journey."<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
Brown played one intercollegiate game in 1880, which Yale won with a score of five tries and eight goals to nothing.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
In 1886 a league was formed by Amherst, Brown, Dartmouth, M.I.T., and Stevens Institute, but the league games did not begin.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
There were no games between 1886 and 1889, when Brown might have made use of a student named John Heisman 1891, who stayed for only two years.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
An important development in Brown football was the arrival of John Lindsey 1892 from Fall River.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
With Lindsey as captain-coach, Brown played four games in 1889, defeating the Pawtucket <a href="Cricket.html">Cricket</a> Club and Tufts and losing to M.I.T. and the Boston Athletic Association.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
The 1890 team recorded two victories (Tufts and Harvard freshmen), fives losses (Fall River, Pawtucket, Boston Athletic Assocition, Trinity, and Wesleyan), and one tie (M.I.T.).<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
The 1891 team, suffering from injuries and a shortage of substitutes, finished its season 4-6.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
Brown was beginning to take football seriously and acquired a coach, Mr. Howland, in 1892, a year marked by a victory over Wesleyan, 6-0, on a touchdown scored by freshman fullback Edward North Robinson 1896 (future Brown coach) with only ten seconds to play.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
A contested game in the annals of football was Brown’s meeting with M.I.T. in New Bedford on November 9, 1892.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
For the next three years Brown had three different coaches, and successful seasons with the playing of William Burr Hopkins 1897, Charles D. Millard 1897, William F. Donovan 1897, and 140-pound Charles McCarthy 1896, who scored Brown’s first touchdown against Harvard (although Brown lost the game).<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
On November 9, 1895, the Brown team scored against Yale for the first time in a game which ended in a 6-6 tie.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
F. D. Stidham 1891 later provided a bronze plaque for the gymnasium to commemorate this near victory.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
The 1896 team featured John "Daff" Gammons 1898, Dave Fultz 1898, Brown’s first Walter Camp All-American, and also John D. Rockefeller, Jr. 1897 as manager.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
Brown defeated the Carlisle Indians, 18-14, in 1898 at the <a href="Polo.html">Polo</a> Grounds in New York in a game called because of darkness just after Gammons’ winning touchdown.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
Edward North Robinson replaced Wallace Moyle as coach in 1898, beginning his first of three coaching stints at Brown.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
In 1899 Willis Richardson 1899 kicked Brown’s first field goal and made Walter Camp’s second All-American team for the second time.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
Between 1900 and 1919 Brown had seventeen winning seasons with Robinson as coach, relieved by J.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
A. Gammons in 1902, David Fultz in 1903, and Gammons again in 1908 and 1909.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
In 1906 John Mayhew ’09 became the first Brown player to make Walter Camp’s first All-American team.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
In 1908 John Hartigan ’10 threw Brown’s first touchdown pass to Frank "Spike" Dennie ’09.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
An historic moment in Brown football was the first victory over Yale in 1910, 21-0.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
In 1912 a spot on Camp’s first team went to George "Kid" Crowther ’13, nicknamed for his small size, 130 pounds, which did not prevent him from making a dazzling 48-yard run for a touchdown in the Harvard game that year, after the Harvard coach had suggested that the small player should be removed from the game for his own safety.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
Perhaps the most memorable moment in Brown football history is the 1915 team’s appearance in what is referred to as the first "annual" Rose Bowl game.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
The word "annual" is important here, as the "first" such game was played by Michigan and Stanford in 1902.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
Brown did not have a really outstanding season in 1915, ending with a 5-3-1 record.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
The new star who flashed across the field that year was Fritz Pollard ’19, the first black to make Camp’s All-American backfield, but the decisive play was Captain Buzz Andrews’ ’16 first and only field goal of his career, which clinched a 3-0 victory over Yale and the invitation to the Tournament of Roses Association Game (which became known as the Rose Bowl Game in 1923).<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
On January 1, 1916, Brown was defeated by Washington State College, 14-0, in a heavy rainstorm which hampered Pollard’s performance.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
The 1916 team, one of Brown’s best and the first to beat Harvard, won its first eight games, then lost to Colgate in the final game.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
Coach Robinson’s teams of the early 1920s managed to win more games than they lost, but they were losing the important ones.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
In 1926 Robinson was replaced by DeOrmond "Tuss" McLaughry from Amherst, who was to lead Brown into a new era of football.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
An all home game schedule was arranged for the season of 1925, the first played in the new stadium on Elmgrove Avenue.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
In the middle of the 1926 season the "Iron Men" came into being when the same eleven men played against Yale for sixty minutes and a 7-0 win.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
The 1928 team lost only to Yale.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
The 1932 team continued to defeat previously undefeated teams until the very last game of the season, which Colgate won, 21-0.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
Brown renewed football relations with Princeton and Syracuse in 1930 and with Harvard in 1932.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
Between 1878 and 1932 Brown’s powerful teams won 254, lost 158, and tied 23.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
After 1932 Brown teams met with less success.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
Although the seasons from 1932 through the war years were not outstanding, some of the players were, such as Irving "Shine" Hall ’39, John McLaughry ’40, Dick High ’42, who scored the winning touchdowns against Yale in 1940 and 1941, Bob Margarita ’44, who set a single-game rushing record against Columbia in 1942, and Daniel "Doc" Savage ’44.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
On April 18, 1942, in a game which was announced as Brown’s "first regularly scheduled spring game" Brown defeated the Coast Guard Academy, 19-6.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
The 1948 team was the best since 1932, winning seven of nine games (the two losses were to Harvard and Yale).<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
The 1949 team, with the help of Joe Paterno ’50, was even better, losing only to Princeton and finishing the season with a spectacular victory over Colgate, coming from behind to score three touchdowns in the last four minutes for a final score of 41-26.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
After <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> play began in 1956, Brown was outclassed.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
In 1959 John McLaughry ’40, son of coach Tuss McLaughry, came back to Brown as football coach, after a successful coaching career which included three years at Union College and nine at Amherst, an overall coaching record of 61-29-5 and an undefeated season at each college.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
In the 1963 season John Parry ’65 captured six Ivy and five Brown pass-receiving records.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
Leonard Jardine began coaching in 1967 and compiled a record of 9-44-1 before John Anderson took over as coach in 1973.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
In 1971 <a href="President.html">President</a> Hornig had made a statement that football like anything else at Brown should be first-class.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
In 1971 and 1972 Brown lost eighteen of nineteen games.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
The Anderson years were better, as his teams finished 4-3-1 in 1973, 5-4 in 1974 and 6-2-1 in 1975.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
In 1976, with an 8-1 overall record and 6-1 in the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a>, Brown shared its first (and to date only) Ivy title with Yale.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
In 1983 the Brown team was invited to play Penn State by coach Joe Paterno.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
John Rosenberg was named coach in 1984 and had three winning seasons from 1984 to 1987, including a second place in the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> in 1987, before a losing streak of fourteen games in the 1988 and 1989 seasons, which was finally broken by Brown’s defeat of Cornell on October 19, 1989.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
At the end of the 1989 season, Rosenberg resigned and was replaced by Michael Kwiatowski.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
The coaches and their records (assuming that the early coaches were there for the whole season, which may or may not have been so) were: Mr. Howland (4-5-1) in 1892; William Odlin (6-3-0) in 1893; Mr. Norton (10-5-0) in 1894; Wallace Moyle (18-15-2) from 1895 to 1897; Edward North Robinson (140-82-12) in his three times as coach from 1898 to 1901, from 1904 to 1907, and from 1910 to 1925; John A. Gammons (17-10-2) in 1902, 1908, and 1909; David Fultz (5-4-1) in 1903; DeOrmond "Tuss" McLaughry (76-58-5) from 1926 to 1940; J. Neil "Skip" Stahley (14-11-0) from 1941 to 1943; Charles A.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
"Rip" Engle (28-20-4) from 1943 to 1949, when he left for Penn State and took Joe Paterno with him; Gregory "Gus" Zitrides (1-8-0) in 1950; Alva E. Kelley (31-39-2) from 1951 to 1958; John J. McLaughry (17-51-3) from 1959 to 1966; Len Jardine (9-44-1) from 1967 to 1973; John Anderson (60-39-3) from 1973 to 1983; and John Rosenberg (23-33-3) from 1984 to 1989.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
While mention of Mr. Howland in the "Brown Daily Herald" in 1892 does not include his first name, there is noted as an umpire at games that year a Howland identified as "Harvard" or "Yale ’91" (identified as Charles P. Howland, Yale 1891, who received an advanced degree from Harvard a few years later).<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
Mr. Norton, who played football at Dartmouth and also coached there has been identified of Joseph M. Norton, Dartmouth 1892, who began teaching at the Friends’ School in Providence in 1895.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
Wallace Moyle, Yale 1891, also played for Yale and coached the Dartmouth team.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
Edward North Robinson was coach three separate times, during the seasons of 1898 to 1901, 1904 to 1907, and 1910 to 1925, a total of 23 years.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
For two years after his graduation in 1896, he coached the University of Nebraska football team before returning to Brown to coach from 1898 to 1901.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
In 1902 he coached the University of Maine to a state championship, and in 1903 coached Exeter.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
In 1904 he returned to Brown for three more seasons, but in June 1907 read in the paper that he was not being rehired.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
Left without a coaching job that year, he was coach at Tufts in 1909, and the next year was once more at Brown, remaining this time until 1925.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
Again relieved of his job along with assistant coach Reginald W. P. Brown, he coached the Boston University team from 1926 to 1928 and the Providence Steamrollers from 1931 to 1934.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
Brown men who have been elected to the Football Hall of Fame are John W. Heisman 1891, DeOrmond McLaughry, Frederick D. Pollard ’19, Edward North Robinson 1896, and Wallace Wade ’17.<cite><a href="Football.html">Football</a></cite>
Foreign study programs began in 1932 with "Junior Year Abroad," which offered students interested in French or German language and literature an opportunity to spend the third undergraduate year studying in Paris or Munich under the auspices of an American Director.<cite><a href="Foreign study programs.html">Foreign study programs</a></cite>
In the mid-1960s Brown, as a member of the Intercollegiate Center for Classical Studies in Rome, allowed students to spend their junior year at the Center, which was staffed by classical philologists from cooperating institutions.<cite><a href="Foreign study programs.html">Foreign study programs</a></cite>
The German Exchange Program began on September 14, 1979 when <a href="President.html">President</a> Swearer and Wolfgang Brauer, rector of William Pieck University in Rostock in the German Democratic Republic, signed an agreement establishing the first scholarly exchange between an American and an East German university.<cite><a href="Foreign study programs.html">Foreign study programs</a></cite>
In 1971 an agreement had been made to exchange books and periodicals.<cite><a href="Foreign study programs.html">Foreign study programs</a></cite>
Duncan Smith had been a visiting professor at William Pieck and Hans-Joachim Bernard of that university had come to Brown in the spring of 1978.<cite><a href="Foreign study programs.html">Foreign study programs</a></cite>
In 1982 the University entered into a formal agreement with Nanjing University in China for the exchange of faculty and students.<cite><a href="Foreign study programs.html">Foreign study programs</a></cite>
Sam Walter Foss (1858-1911), librarian and poet, was born in Candia, New Hampshire, on June 19, 1858.<cite><a href="Foss, Sam Walter.html">Foss, Sam Walter</a></cite>
Sam Walter Foss graduated from Brown in 1882, and was considered one of Brown’s illustrious graduates (his name is on the mace), although his name is not often recognized today.<cite><a href="Foss, Sam Walter.html">Foss, Sam Walter</a></cite>
At Brown Sam Walter Foss was chosen class poet in 1882.<cite><a href="Foss, Sam Walter.html">Foss, Sam Walter</a></cite>
In 1887 Sam Walter Foss was editor of the "Yankee Blade," a literary weekly in Boston.<cite><a href="Foss, Sam Walter.html">Foss, Sam Walter</a></cite>
Public Library from 1898 until Sam Walter Foss's death on February 26, 1911 in Cambridge, Massachusetts.<cite><a href="Foss, Sam Walter.html">Foss, Sam Walter</a></cite>
Theodore Foster (1752-1828), early graduate and one of the first two United States Senators from Rhode Island, was born on April 29, 1752 in Brookfield, Massachusetts.<cite><a href="Foster, Theodore.html">Foster, Theodore</a></cite>
Theodore graduated from Rhode Island College in September 1770 at the second Commencement, which was held in Mr. Snow’s meeting house in Providence, as the college had moved from Warren earlier that year.<cite><a href="Foster, Theodore.html">Foster, Theodore</a></cite>
On July 9 he had written of the move in a letter: After his graduation Foster became an attorney and served as Providence Town Clerk from 1775 to 1787, as Secretary of the Rhode Island Council of War from 1776 to 1781, and as Representative to the General Assembly from 1776 to 1782.<cite><a href="Foster, Theodore.html">Foster, Theodore</a></cite>
In 1790 Theodore Foster was elected to the United States Senate.<cite><a href="Foster, Theodore.html">Foster, Theodore</a></cite>
In 1800 he was joined in the Senate by his brother, Dwight Foster 1774.<cite><a href="Foster, Theodore.html">Foster, Theodore</a></cite>
The event which made Foster’s name memorable was the division of the town of Scituate into two towns in 1781, probably to secure greater representation of the area in the General Assembly.<cite><a href="Foster, Theodore.html">Foster, Theodore</a></cite>
In 1799 he purchased land in Foster, and in 1801 his old friend <a href="Drowne, Solomon.html">Solomon Drowne</a> 1773 purchased an adjoining farm, and the two of them settled in the country in search of a quiet and studious life.<cite><a href="Foster, Theodore.html">Foster, Theodore</a></cite>
Foster kept a law office near his farm, and traveled to Providence as representative of the town of Foster in the General Assembly from 1812 to 1816.<cite><a href="Foster, Theodore.html">Foster, Theodore</a></cite>
He secured a charter for the Hartford Turnpike, which went through Foster, in 1803, and established the Foster Society Library in 1806.<cite><a href="Foster, Theodore.html">Foster, Theodore</a></cite>
In 1815 Theodore Foster secured postal service for his town.<cite><a href="Foster, Theodore.html">Foster, Theodore</a></cite>
In 1820 Theodore Foster moved back to Providence, apparently having had enough tranquility and desiring the bustling activity that had so rattled his youthful mind as a student.<cite><a href="Foster, Theodore.html">Foster, Theodore</a></cite>
Theodore Foster died on Providence on January 13, 1828.<cite><a href="Foster, Theodore.html">Foster, Theodore</a></cite>
The Association had in 1756 established the first Baptist Latin Grammar School, <a href="Hopewell Academy.html">Hopewell Academy</a>, in New Jersey.<cite><a href="Founding.html">Founding</a></cite>
In 1762, the design of establishing a college was promoted, with the Reverend Morgan Edwards, moderator of the Association a prime mover of the project, and Rhode Island was selected as a likely site, since the colony had been settled by Baptists, was still largely governed by Baptists, and had no college.<cite><a href="Founding.html">Founding</a></cite>
Accordingly, James Manning, a graduate of New Jersey College (Princeton) in 1762, visited Newport in July 1763, where he met with "about 15 gentlemen of the same denomination" at the home of Deputy Governor John Gardner.<cite><a href="Founding.html">Founding</a></cite>
The plan for a college was immediately accepted and a <a href="Charter.html">Charter</a> was presented to the August 1763 General Assembly in Newport.<cite><a href="Founding.html">Founding</a></cite>
After postponement a different charter was presented at subsequent sessions and granted at the session in East Greenwich on March 2 and 3, 1764.<cite><a href="Founding.html">Founding</a></cite>
At the first meeting of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> September 5, 1764 there were present eleven of the twelve Fellows and nineteen of the 36 Trustees.<cite><a href="Founding.html">Founding</a></cite>
The second meeting of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> was held one year later, on September 5, 1765.<cite><a href="Founding.html">Founding</a></cite>
Henry Thatcher Fowler (1867-1948), professor of biblical literature, was born in Fishkill, New York, on March 4, 1867.<cite><a href="Fowler, Henry T..html">Fowler, Henry T.</a></cite>
Henry T. Fowler graduated from Yale in 1890 and received his Ph.D., also at Yale, in 1896.<cite><a href="Fowler, Henry T..html">Fowler, Henry T.</a></cite>
Henry T. Fowler taught at Norwich Academy in 1891-92, was general secretary of the Y.M.C.A. at Yale from 1892 to 1894, and assistant in biblical literature at Yale in 1895-96.<cite><a href="Fowler, Henry T..html">Fowler, Henry T.</a></cite>
Henry T. Fowler taught at Knox College from 1896 until 1901, when he came to Brown as professor of biblical literature and history.<cite><a href="Fowler, Henry T..html">Fowler, Henry T.</a></cite>
Henry T. Fowler was chairman of that department until 1932, after which he taught on a part time basis until his retirement in 1934.<cite><a href="Fowler, Henry T..html">Fowler, Henry T.</a></cite>
Henry T. Fowler traveled and studied in the Holy Land during the academic years 1912-13, 1921-22, and 1928-29.<cite><a href="Fowler, Henry T..html">Fowler, Henry T.</a></cite>
A recognized scholar in his field, Henry T. Fowler was the author of a number of books, among them "The Prophets as Statesmen and Preachers," published in 1904 and translated into Portuguese in 1924, "The Origin and Growth of the Hebrew Religion" in 1916, translated into Chinese in 1925, and "The History and Literature of the New Testament" in 1925.<cite><a href="Fowler, Henry T..html">Fowler, Henry T.</a></cite>
Henry T. Fowler died on January 28, 1948.<cite><a href="Fowler, Henry T..html">Fowler, Henry T.</a></cite>
The Franklin Society was organized in 1824, a year when such a large class entered that the two existing literary debating societies, the <a href="Philermenian Society.html">Philermenian Society</a> and the <a href="United Brothers.html">United Brothers</a> Society could not accommodate enough of the entering students.<cite><a href="Franklin Society.html">Franklin Society</a></cite>
Ten years after its establishment, in 1834, the Franklin Society was dissolved, its library of several hundred volumes was turned over to the College <a href="Library.html">Library</a>, and in 1847 its members were elected in equal proportions into the two older societies.<cite><a href="Franklin Society.html">Franklin Society</a></cite>
Fraternities began to appear in the 1830s and were not greeted with enthusiasm by the authorities.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Alpha Delta Phi established a chapter in 1836, followed by Delta Phi in 1838 and Psi Upsilon in 1840.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In 1844 the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> voted, "That this <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> disapproves of the establishment of Secret Societies by the Undergraduates of this University or of their participation therein and that the <a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a> of the University be requested to adopt such measures as they may deem advisable for the suppression of said secret societies."<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Beta Theta Pi established a chapter in 1847, Delta Kappa Epsilon in 1850, Zeta Psi in 1852, and Theta Delta Chi in 1853.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Librarian Reuben Guild registered his disapproval of fraternities in a letter written in 1852, in which he stated, "Secret Societies ... originate with the Devil, all of them."<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In October 1903 the <a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a> called for organized rushing regulations and arranged a meeting of fraternity representatives with the dean.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
At another meeting in 1908 the Club suggested a delayed rushing season to allow both the freshmen and the fraternities more time to make their choices.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
An interfraternity council, composed of one representative from each fraternity, was appointed in 1913 to propose new rushing rules.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The Interfraternity Governing Board was established by the <a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a> in 1915.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
By the 1930s almost all of the fraternities had purchased their own houses.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
<a href="President.html">President</a> Wriston, a firm believer in the fraternity system, initiated late in 1943 a proposal to the fraternities that the sixteen fraternities whose houses were being leased should make a gift, debt-free, of the houses to the University, which would then maintain the buildings, collect the room rent, and run the dining rooms.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The fraternities continued to occupy their houses until the early 1950s when they acquired new quarters in the <a href="Wriston Quadrangle.html">Wriston Quadrangle</a>, which had been built to house the fraternities and the independent dormitories together.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In 1949 fraternities came under fire from "<a href="Brunonia.html">Brunonia</a>," which, pointing out that 90% of the elective offices were held by fraternity men, who accounted for only 30% of the students, also commented, "The fraternity man is the campus leader and the campus idiot."<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
For other reasons the life of fraternities at Brown was endangered in 1949 after several incidents on the evening of March 4, which was pledge night for the fraternities.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In December 1961 the <a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a> passed a resolution calling on the fraternities to remove all membership restrictions based on race or religion, and gave the seven fraternities with such restrictions two years to comply.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In a new agreement between the University and the fraternities drawn up in 1980, the fraternities relinquished their exclusive use of private dining rooms in the Refectory and residential fraternities were required to maintain a membership of 24 to qualify for a permanent campus house with lounge space.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The society called "Oudens" of the Class of 1864 is believed to have been such an organization.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In 1908 "<a href="Bear Facts.html">Bear Facts</a>," noted, "The Kasa is the non-secret fraternal organization; admission is by invitation or application."<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The Hill Club for non-fraternity men was organized in December 1914, and was represented by two members on the Interfraternity Council.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In February 1923 with the blessing of the <a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a> a group of non-fraternity men formed a new club, which began as the Bruno Club, changed its name to the <a href="Bear.html">Bear</a> Cubs, and finally to the <a href="Bear.html">Bear</a> Club in the first month of its existence.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In 1927-28 the <a href="Bear.html">Bear</a> Club asked permission to become a local fraternity under the name of Tau Delta Epsilon, and the next year affiliated with the national fraternity Sigma Phi Sigma.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In 1928 <a href="President.html">President</a> Faunce reported "urgent demands during the year for permission to organize a Jewish fraternity, also an Italian fraternity," and stated, "we do not want at Brown any fraternity organized on the basis of race or religion."<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The Jewish students who wanted to form a fraternity went ahead and secretly joined Pi Lambda Phi during the Christmas vacation of 1928-29.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
When it became known in April 1929 that they had formed a local chapter of Pi Lambda Phi, they were obliged to resign as a Brown chapter, but continued to keep their membership in the national fraternity.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
A photograph of the members and the list of members, all but one of whom had Italian surnames, appeared in the 1929 "<a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a>."<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
New resolutions of the Brown <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> in May 1929 allowed Pi Lambda Phi to form a Brown chapter.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The first of these was Alpha Gamma chapter of Alpha Phi Alpha, which was established in 1921 and became inactive before the second World War.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Brown students were involved in forming a chapter of another black fraternity in 1947, when Paris Sterrett, who was executive director of a settlement house in Providence (now the John Hope Center) and a member of Omega Psi Phi sought George Lima ’48 and Charles Bentley ’44 as pledges with the intention of establishing a chapter at Brown.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
On June 27, 1947 Theta Epsilon chapter of Omega Psi Phi with two pledges from Providence College had the required membership of five persons for an undergraduate chapter.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
By the mid-1950s Theta Epsilon had become a graduate chapter, and Archie Williams ’56 found himself the only undergraduate member, while black students at Brown were pledging to black fraternities centered in Boston.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
A chance to rejuvenate the Brown chapter came with the initiation in 1957 of Wallace Terry ’59, Arthur Lamb ’59, Wortham Baskerville ’58, and Joel Stokes ’58.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In 1959 seven new members were added, among them Richard Nurse ’61.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
After 1962 Omega Psi Phi was dormant until 1970, when a new group of pledges seemed to assure the continuance of an undergraduate chapter, and a separate graduate chapter, Sigma Nu, was formed.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
After another period of inactivity, Omega Psi Phi was back again in the late 1970s, and Alpha Phi Alpha was reactivated.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In November 1989 La Unidad Latina, Lambda Upsilon Lambda Fraternity established Zeta chapter at Brown, "in the Latin tradition, and spirit of pride, dignity and quality."<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Alpha Delta Phi (<a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a> chapter) was established in 1836, the first fraternity at Brown and the only one until the appearance of Delta Phi two years later.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
When Delta Phi began to pledge freshmen, Alpha Delta Phi, rather than seek their members from among the freshmen or from upper classes already picked over by Delta Phi, chose to cease the initiation of new members after January 1839, and went out of existence at <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> in 1841, when all its members had graduated.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The fraternity was dormant until April 1851 when it acquired the membership of Beta Theta Pi.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Meetings were held in the "Arnold Block" until 1904, when the chapter purchased a house at 54 College Street.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The decision in 1973 to admit women to the Brown chapter of Alpha Delta Phi did not have the blessing of the national organization.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Alpha Tau Omega was established in September 1894.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In 1920 the chapter acquired a house at 43-45 George Street.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In January 1938 the chapter voted to discontinue itself after a series of misfortunes which included foreclosure of its mortgage, the pledging of few freshmen, and damage to the heating system in an attempted theft of the house’s oil burner during Christmas vacation.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The fraternity moved to 58 College Street, and the University purchased the house, which was used by the <a href="English.html">English</a> Department, and the chapter became inactive in 1940.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Beta Theta Pi (Kappa chapter) was established in 1849.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In 1851 the Brown chapter and the Williams chapter, the only eastern chapters of Beta Theta Pi, withdrew from the national fraternity and became chapters of Alpha Delta Phi.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In March 1880 Kappa chapter was reestablished at Brown by initiating forty members of the local Phi Kappa Alpha society.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In 1907 Beta Theta Pi acquired a house at 41 George Street, which had been the home and school of Mrs. Mary Balch.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The Brown chapter disappeared in 1971.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Chi Psi (Lambda chapter) existed at Brown from 1860 to 1871, at which time it had only two members.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Delta Kappa Epsilon (Upsilon chapter) was established in 1850.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
After these room were destroyed by fire in 1889, the chapter moved to a school house on Benefit Street, then to <a href="Caswell Hall.html">Caswell Hall</a> in 1903, to temporary quarters on North Main Street, and in 1907 into the house at 65 College Street, which the chapter had acquired in 1905.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In 1928 William T. Aldrich designed a three-story brick chapter house, which was not built.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In December of 1964 the Brown chapter was dissolved as a result of a hazing incident in which a pledge collapsed.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Delta Phi (Beta chapter) was established in 1838, when an application of Jonas D. Sleeper 1840 and Edwin C. Larned 1840 for a chapter at Brown was granted by the first chapter at Union College, which had not approved any other extension of the fraternity since its founding in 1827.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The Brown chapter flourished until 1854, when it ended abruptly, after a number of its members left college as a result of their involvement in the dissemination of a mock program at the junior exhibition.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The chapter remained inactive until 1868, when fourteen members were initiated.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In 1876 Delta Phi decided not to initiate any more members for a few years and was once more inactive until it was revived in 1881 through the efforts of Franklin E. Brooks 1883.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
A fiftieth anniversary symposium was held at the Narragansett Hotel in 1888.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
