In 1920 Delta Phi, which had been living in North <a href="Slater Hall.html">Slater Hall</a>, purchased the Dorrance mansion on 2 Prospect Street.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Delta Phi left the national fraternity in 1966, partly because of a disagreement over lifetime national dues, and continued as Delta Phi Omega until its reaffiliation with Delta Phi in 1983.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Delta Psi had ten student members at Brown in 1852.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In April 1853 the national fraternity revoked the charter of the Brown chapter and dismissed the remaining eight members (the two who had left college remained on the rolls of the fraternity).<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
One hundred fifty years later, in 1983, Delta Psi was reestablished at Brown as a coed literary fraternity, and was housed in King House, known to the fraternity as St. Anthony Hall, the name traditionally given to the chapter houses of Delta Psi on other campuses.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Delta Tau Delta (Beta chapter) was established in 1896.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In 1907 Delta Tau Delta purchased a house at 94 Angell Street.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
That house was razed and replaced by Howard P. Lovecraft’s house, which was moved to the lot from its former location on College Street in 1969.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The chapter left the national fraternity in 1969 and continued as Delta Tau.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In 1981, the local fraternity Delta Tau was evicted from South Wayland Hall on charges of vandalism.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In 1985 the fraternity, reaffiliated with Delta Tau Delta, had built up its membership and regained housing in the <a href="Wriston Quadrangle.html">Wriston Quadrangle</a>.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Delta Upsilon (Brown chapter) began as Gamma Nu in 1860, when several members of the classes of 1863 and 1864, observing the decline of the literary societies at Brown, sought permission to form a new society to provide opportunities for extemporaneous speaking and debate.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The founding members intended the society to consist of freshmen and sophomores only, but in 1863 membership was extended to all classes.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In 1866 it reverted to a freshman-sophomore society.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
On May 22, 1868, the Gamma Nu society joined Delta Upsilon fraternity, which was also a non-secret society.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In 1865 Gamma Nu published the first issue of the "<a href="Caduceus.html">Caduceus</a>" as an alternative to the "<a href="Brown Paper.html">Brown Paper</a>," which was the organ of the secret societies.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In 1919 the chapter bought a house at 80 Waterman Street, which is now <a href="Walter Hall.html">Walter Hall</a>.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The chapter left the national fraternity in 1967 and continued as Kappa Delta Upsilon, then reaffiliated with Delta Upsilon in 1986, and in 1991 became for the second time Kappa Delta Upsilon.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Kappa Sigma (Beta Alpha chapter) was installed on February 22, 1898, at the Narragansett Hotel, and rooms for the society were secured in the Banigan Building.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The chapter later lived at 127 Angell Street and in <a href="Hope College.html">Hope College</a>, and in 1927 acquired a house at 49 Angell Street, which was later razed for the construction of <a href="Rhode Island School of Design.html">Rhode Island School of Design</a> dormitories.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The chapter left the national fraternity and took the name of Toad Hall in 1969, reaffiliated with Kappa Sigma in 1983, and again became a local fraternity, Chi Kappa Sigma, in 1990.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Lambda Chi Alpha (Iota Zeta chapter) was established in 1912, drawing its membership from a local fraternity which had been formed in 1908.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Lambda Chi Alpha lived in <a href="Hope College.html">Hope College</a>, at 411 Brook Street, and at 57 Waterman Street before 1936 when the house became University property.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In 1938 the fraternity had a house at 32 George Street.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The chapter became inactive in 1970.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Phi Delta Theta (Rhode Island Alpha chapter) owed its beginning in February 1889 to some members of the senior class who got together to thwart the plans of several fraternities who expected to gain all the offices of the senior class for themselves.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The chapter lived in <a href="Brunonia.html">Brunonia</a> Hall and moved to 62 College Street in 1920.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In about 1964 Phi Delta Theta became a local fraternity, Phi Delta Beta, after being instructed by the University to drop its national ties because of a discriminatory clause in the national constitution.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
After being reaffiliated in 1983 with Phi Delta Theta, the chapter lost its housing in the <a href="Wriston Quadrangle.html">Wriston Quadrangle</a> in 1985 because of vandalism, and the University ceased to recognize its charter.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Phi Gamma Delta (Pi Rho chapter) was established in 1902.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In the spring of 1901, Amos L. Taylor ’01 and Berton L. Maxfield ’01, who had both been invited to join fraternities but had found the expense too great, approached <a href="President.html">President</a> Faunce for permission to form a local fraternity which they hope to affiliated with Phi Gamma Delta.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Pi Phi was organized in April 1901, and announced to the College on <a href="Class Day.html">Class Day</a>.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
After acceptance by Phi Gamma Delta, Pi Rho chapter was installed on May 16, 1902.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
By 1909 the chapter had acquired the use of all the rooms in South <a href="Hope College.html">Hope College</a>.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The members began negotiations to purchase the house at 56 Waterman Street in 1916, and were finally able to occupy it after the end of the World War.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The chapter became inactive in 1968.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Phi Kappa was founded in September 1889 as a fraternity for Catholic students by thirteen men (all but two of the Catholic students at Brown), who would not have been welcome in the established fraternities.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
At first it met in Room 3, <a href="Hope College.html">Hope College</a>, the room of three of the members, moving in the spring of 1890 to a room in the Wayland Building on North Main Street.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In 1892 M. Joseph Harson ’84, a Providence merchant, invited the members to meet at his home, where a plan to extend membership to alumni was devised.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Upon discovering that a national fraternity named Phi Kappa Sigma already existed, the local fraternity changed its name in 1900 to Phi Kappa and in 1902 received a charter from the state of Rhode Island which enabled it to establish chapters at other colleges.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The earliest members had intended to form a society, rather than a full-fledged fraternity, and until 1900, when it was instituted as Phi Kappa, the organization was not recognized by inclusion in the "<a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a>" with the other fraternities.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Phi Kappa had its location in <a href="Caswell Hall.html">Caswell Hall</a>, at 109 George Street, and at 279 Benefit Street, before settling at 426 Brook Street from 1922 until the chapter became inactive in 1929.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The national Phi Kappa, which had grown to more than thirty chapters, merged with the national Theta Kappa Phi in 1959 to form Phi Kappa Theta.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Phi Kappa Psi (Rhode Island Alpha chapter) was established in 1902.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In 1923 Phi Kappa Psi acquired a house at 108 Waterman Street.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The chapter was suspended in 1978, was later revitalized as Phi Psi, and reaffiliated with Phi Kappa Psi in 1984.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Phi Sigma Kappa (Upsilon chapter) was established in 1906.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The chapter became inactive in 1939.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Pi Lambda Phi (Phi chapter) was established on September 28, 1929.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The reversal of the University’s decision in May 1929 allowed the establishment of a Brown chapter.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In 1963 Phi chapter, which a year earlier had narrowly defeated a motion to become a local fraternity, unanimously voted to secede from the national fraternity and to continue its existence as Alpha Pi Lambda until about 1970.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Psi Upsilon (Sigma chapter) was established in 1840, the third fraternity at Brown, The early members met of <a href="President.html">President</a> Wayland’s objection to the secrecy of the organization by electing him to honorary membership.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Many of the members of Psi Upsilon were Rhode Island residents, and, according to an article in the "<a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a>" in 1892, "For more than half a century the Sigma has annually recruited from the best families in Rhode Island."<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In 1893 Psi Upsilon became the first fraternity to have its own house.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
It was finally razed in 1972 from the lot in front of the Sciences <a href="Library.html">Library</a>.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The chapter disbanded in 1964.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
It had been unable to meet the requirements of academic average and membership set forth in the Housing Report of 1962, had been fined by the Interfraternity Council for rushing practices, and had lost ten members who were suspended for a disorder at the house in the spring of 1963.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The chapter was revived in 1985 with both men and women members.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Sigma Chi (Beta Nu chapter) began as Kappa chapter of Chi Phi with six charter members in 1872, and became Beta Nu chapter of Sigma Chi in 1914.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Its members lived in Middle <a href="Hope College.html">Hope College</a>, and in 1919 Sigma Chi purchased a house at 96 Waterman Street.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Sigma Chi changed its name to Swyndlestock in 1966 after severing ties with the national fraternity when the University interpreted a membership clause in the national constitution as discriminatory.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The new name was inspired by the name of a tavern in the town of Oxford in England, in which a riot with town and gown implications in 1335 brought the University under the royal protection of King Edward III.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The chapter reaffiliated with Sigma Chi in 1973.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Sigma Nu (Delta Lambda chapter) was established in 1912 by members of the local society of Sigma Delta Kappa.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
After living at 110 and 104 Waterman Street, in 1923 Sigma Nu purchased a house at 23 Charles Field Street.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Sigma Nu, after trying for several years to persuade the national fraternity to drop discriminatory membership clauses from its constitution, became an independent local fraternity named Lambda Sigma Nu in 1964, and changed its name to <a href="Casements.html">Casements</a> in 1970.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Sigma Phi began at Brown as a non-secret society, founded by the members of the classes of 1873 and 1874 in 1870 and established as a chapter in 1872.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The society published the "Photeinian," a literary annual which appeared only twice, in 1873 and 1874.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The 1874 issue of the "Photeinian" described the society further, "Sigma Phi is preeminently a working society.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Sigma Phi Epsilon (Rhode Island Alpha chapter) existed at Brown from 1912 to 1919, living in South <a href="Caswell Hall.html">Caswell Hall</a> and North <a href="Hope College.html">Hope College</a>.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Sigma Phi Sigma (Sigma chapter) was established in 1929, when the local fraternity, Tau Delta Epsilon, formed by members of <a href="Bear.html">Bear</a> Club a year earlier, affiliated with the national fraternity.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In 1935 the affiliation was dropped and the fraternity once more became the local Tau Delta Epsilon.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Theta Delta Chi (Zeta chapter) was established in November 1853.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Five of the nine active and eight graduate members who fought in the <a href="Civil War.html">Civil War</a> were killed, but John Hay 1858, secretary to Abraham Lincoln was able to save the life of his Confederate fraternity brother Clarence Bate ’58.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
After the war, according to an article by Lucien E. Taylor 1895 in the "<a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a>," "the Charge survived, under discouraging circumstances till 1879, when preferring non-existence to a lower standard, it surrendered its charter."<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
The fraternity was reinstated at Brown in 1887.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In 1909 Theta Delta Chi moved into a house which had been purchased by the University and leased to the fraternity.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
They moved from 81 Waterman Street to 36 Prospect Street, before purchasing the house at 50 Waterman Street from George S. Baker in 1925.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
After Theta Delta Chi’s charter was revoked by the University in 1985, the members continued to meet off-campus and initiate new brothers.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
It was founded at Wesleyan University in 1870, and Beta Upsilon chapter was established at Brown in 1900.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Whatever the reason, the only members of Theta Nu Epsilon who were listed in the "<a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a>" belonged to the classes of 1903 and 1904.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
While the names of active members appeared in scrambled letters and symbols, as if to preserve their anonymity, the real names of the Class of 1903 members were revealed after their sophomore year.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Zeta Psi (Epsilon chapter) was established on April 21, 1852.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
After occupying rooms in <a href="Slater Hall.html">Slater Hall</a>, in 1917 Zeta Psi purchased a house at 48 College Street.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
In 1960 the building was needed for rehearsal rooms and studios for the Department of <a href="Music.html">Music</a>.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
When the <a href="Music.html">Music</a> Department found new quarters on Young Orchard Avenue in 1979, the <a href="Classics.html">Classics</a> Department moved into 48 College Street, which was renamed Macfarlane House in honor of Kilgore Macfarlane, Jr. ’23.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Zeta Psi began to initiate women members in 1983, and in 1986 withdrew from the national fraternity to become Zeta Delta Xi.<cite><a href="Fraternities.html">Fraternities</a></cite>
Freshman caps were first worn in 1907, when the <a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a>, in an attempt to strengthen class spirit, ruled that freshmen would wear brown Eton caps from the beginning of the year until May 30.<cite><a href="Freshman caps.html">Freshman caps</a></cite>
In 1908 the style was improved so that the new cap would "fit closely about the head without the bulge in front, but will be larger than the small skull cap used last year, thus ensuring more adequate protection for the head during inclement weather.<cite><a href="Freshman caps.html">Freshman caps</a></cite>
In 1915 the <a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a> was criticized by the "Brown Daily Herald" for abolishing freshman caps in January and reinstating them in March.<cite><a href="Freshman caps.html">Freshman caps</a></cite>
In May 1928 the <a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a> once again abolished the caps, after the investigation of a local merchant who had undertaken to manufacture the caps and sell them as a lower price than the University’s supplier and was selling them to purchasers who were not Brown men.<cite><a href="Freshman caps.html">Freshman caps</a></cite>
For one year freshmen were required to wear black ties, after which the wearing of the caps was revived in 1929.<cite><a href="Freshman caps.html">Freshman caps</a></cite>
It was revived in the fall of 1947.<cite><a href="Freshman caps.html">Freshman caps</a></cite>
The "beanies" survived through the class of 1975, mainly because of the $2.75 charge per cap which, with the sale of outing tickets, helped support Freshman Week.<cite><a href="Freshman caps.html">Freshman caps</a></cite>
With the arrival of the class of 1976, the sale of caps was dropped and each student was assessed five dollars for Freshman Week.<cite><a href="Freshman caps.html">Freshman caps</a></cite>
Fund-raising for the College began at the first meeting of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> in 1765, when the members present subscribed $1,992.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
In November 1766 Morgan Edwards was authorized to go to Europe to solicit benefactions and returned in 1768, having collected about $4,300.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
Hezekiah Smith was sent to the South in 1769 and 1770 and collected about $1,700.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
Again in 1774 the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> planned another solicitation, appointing David Howell to go to Europe and William Rogers to the South.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
One popular way of raising money was a lottery, and an item in the "Newport Mercury" for September 28 to October 5, 1767 announced that the General Assembly of the Colony of Rhode Island had approved a lottery to raise 150 pounds lawful money "to be applied toward finishing the Parsonage House belonging to the Baptist Church in Warren, and rendering it commodious for the Reception of the Pupils who are, or shall be, placed there for a liberal <a href="Education.html">Education</a>."<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
Another lottery for the benefit of the College held in 1798 paid out $8,000 and brought in $33,548.50.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
<a href="President.html">President</a> Manning thought about an international lottery in 1772 when he wrote to an <a href="English.html">English</a> friend to inquire if a lottery to raise one or two thousand pounds would meet with encouragement in England.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
The <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> decided instead to return to soliciting funds in England, and began by awarding degrees to a number of <a href="English.html">English</a> clergymen in 1773 and 1774.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
After <a href="President.html">President</a> Francis Wayland complained of the inadequacy of the library, the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> in 1831 undertook a bold plan to raise $25,000 for the purchase of books and scientific apparatus.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
The campaign brought in $19,437.50, which was put at interest until it grew to $25,000, which was then invested, and by 1839 supplied an income for books and apparatus.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
In 1836 a committee of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> was appointed to raise funds for a building for instruction in the sciences.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
In March 1839 Nicholas Brown 1786 announced that he would subscribe $10,000 for the science building and a new president’s house, provided the same amount should be subscribed before May 1.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
<a href="President.html">President</a> Wayland’s New System of instruction, approved by the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> in March 1850 to be instituted as soon as $125,000 should be raised, began another fund raising campaign.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
In June 1901 <a href="President.html">President</a> Faunce announced the success of a two million dollar endowment campaign, which included half a million for the endowment of the John Carter Brown <a href="Library.html">Library</a>, $150,000 for a new library building, a contribution of $250,000 from John D. Rockefeller, Jr. 1897, and contributions from about 2,500 subscribers, many of them not wealthy.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
A successful million dollar endowment fund in 1912, aided by a contribution of $150,000 from the General <a href="Education.html">Education</a> Board, was distributed as follows: $200,000 for the Women’s College, $225,000 for the pension fund, $50,000 for the <a href="Library.html">Library</a>, and $525,000 for the general funds.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
In 1914 the Loyalty Fund was established to provide an annual fund from the alumni in place of larger endowment campaigns.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
The Endowment and Development Fund of 1919 raised about $3,725,000, aided by an issue of "Brown <a href="Bear.html">Bear</a> Bonds" ranging from "Baby-<a href="Bear.html">Bear</a> Common" at five dollars to "Brown <a href="Bear.html">Bear</a>–summa cum laude" at five thousand.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
The Brown University Council was established in 1936 with the purpose of increasing the financial resources of the University through a continuous cultivation of interest among alumni and friends.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
Chancellor Henry D. Sharpe 1894 was appointed General Chairman.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
As a result of these efforts, involving reductions amounting to more the $200,000, the University operated virtually without a deficit for the two years, 1932-33 and 1933-34.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
In June 1946 a Housing and Development Campaign was launched with G. Edward Buxton ’02 as chairman, its purpose to provide badly needed housing in the form of a new dormitory for <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a> and a quadrangle with dormitories for men students, fraternity houses, and a refectory.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
A Bicentennial Development Program, designed to raised thirty million dollars by 1964 through growth in annual giving and bequests, was approved by the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> in October 1956.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
In June 1959 a major fund drive to raise fifteen million dollars was launched with Thomas J. Watson, Jr. ’37 as chairman, and continued through 1960 and the first part of 1961.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
In 1960 the Ford Foundation announced a Special Program in <a href="Education.html">Education</a>, designed to offer challenge grants to a few institutions with no restrictions, dispensed on the basis of the presentation by their presidents of plans for five and ten year permanent improvements projected for the colleges.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
In June 1961 Brown was the sixth recipient of such a grant of $7.5 million, if fifteen million could be raised in three years.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
On June 25, 1964, only a few days before the end of the fund raising period, the bell on <a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a> was rung and the announcement made that $15,400,000 in matching funds were on hand.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
The success of the campaign brought to the University in December 1964 a second Ford Foundation challenge grant, this time for five million dollars to be met by ten million raised by the University by June 30, 1967.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
Fortunately for Brown the period of the challenge was retroactive to July 1, 1964, allowing an already received grant of two million from the James Foundation to be counted toward the matching funds.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
The Program for the Seventies was formally announced in November 1969, pursuing a ten year goal of $92 million, which proved to be elusive.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
The financial crisis of the 1970s called for new strategy in fund-raising.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
In 1974 Richard Salomon ’32 assisted the annual Brown Fund with a challenge grant of $500,000, which matched increases in donors’ gifts and gifts from those who had not subscribed the year before.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
The record-breaking years for the Brown Fund in 1974-75 and 1975-76 won for Brown the U. S. Steel Alumni Giving Incentive Award.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
In 1976 Brown Giving Clubs were established to encourage annual donations of certain amounts, the Century Club ($100-$499), the 1764 Associates ($500-$999), the Manning Fellows ($1,000-$4,999), and the Nicholas Brown Society for donors of an annual gift of $5,000, commemorating the gift of $5,000 given by Nicholas Brown 1786, which changed the name of Rhode Island College to Brown University.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
"The Campaign for Brown," launched in 1978, had as its five-year goal $158 million for endowment, current use, renovation of the John Hay <a href="Library.html">Library</a> and a number of departmental buildings, and new facilities for chemistry and geology.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
In 1984 "The New Priorities," another fund raising program (it was not called a campaign) sought to raise fifty million dollars in two years for endowment and current expenses.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
In 1986 the Brown Annual Fund began to emphasize reunion giving, with the result that the fund revenues rose from $5.3 million to $10.5 million in the next five years.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
The three-year fund-raising drive which began in from 1986 through 1989 was named "The Challenge Years."<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
The present campaign, named "The Rising Generation," words taken from the University <a href="Charter.html">Charter</a>, which aspired to form the rising generation to virtue, knowledge, and useful literature, began in April 1992.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
The goal of the campaign is to reendow the University by raising $450 million by the end of 1995, for the support of the following areas: $110 million for faculty endowment and graduate fellowships, $40 million for undergraduate scholarships, $25 million for the libraries, $90 million for academic support (programs, centers, institutes, curriculum), $15 million for national outreach initiatives, $50 million for the School of Medicine, $10 million for athletics endowment, $55 million for new and renovated facilities, and $55 million for the Brown Annual Fund.<cite><a href="Fund-raising.html">Fund-raising</a></cite>
William Gammell (1812-1889), professor of rhetoric, history and political economy, was born in Medfield, Massachusetts, on February 10, 1812, the son of a Baptist clergyman who was also a trustee of the University.<cite><a href="Gammell, William.html">Gammell, William</a></cite>
After graduating from Brown in 1831, Gammell was principal of an academy in South Reading, Massachusetts, for a year before he returned to Brown as a tutor.<cite><a href="Gammell, William.html">Gammell, William</a></cite>
William Gammell became assistant professor of belles-lettres in 1835 and professor of rhetoric in 1837.<cite><a href="Gammell, William.html">Gammell, William</a></cite>
In 1843 William Gammell began to teach a course in history, and was appointed to the chair of history and political economy in 1850.<cite><a href="Gammell, William.html">Gammell, William</a></cite>
William Gammell resigned in 1864.<cite><a href="Gammell, William.html">Gammell, William</a></cite>
William Gammell was involved in the founding of Rhode Island Hospital and delivered the opening address on October 1, 1868.<cite><a href="Gammell, William.html">Gammell, William</a></cite>
William Gammell died in Providence on April 3, 1889, and left to the University a bequest of $10,000 for the purchase of books relating to United States history.<cite><a href="Gammell, William.html">Gammell, William</a></cite>
Henry Brayton Gardner (1863-1939), professor of economics, was born in Providence on March 26, 1863.<cite><a href="Gardner, Henry B..html">Gardner, Henry B.</a></cite>
Henry B. Gardner studied at the University Grammar School and graduated from Brown in 1884.<cite><a href="Gardner, Henry B..html">Gardner, Henry B.</a></cite>
Henry B. Gardner received his Ph.D. degree from John Hopkins University in 1890.<cite><a href="Gardner, Henry B..html">Gardner, Henry B.</a></cite>
Meanwhile Henry B. Gardner was instructor of political economy at Brown from 1888 to 1890.<cite><a href="Gardner, Henry B..html">Gardner, Henry B.</a></cite>
Henry B. Gardner became associate professor in 1890 and full professor in 1898, after a year’s study in Germany.<cite><a href="Gardner, Henry B..html">Gardner, Henry B.</a></cite>
In 1919 Henry B. Gardner became the first Eastman Professor of Political Economy.<cite><a href="Gardner, Henry B..html">Gardner, Henry B.</a></cite>
Henry B. Gardner was head of the department of economics until he retired in 1928.<cite><a href="Gardner, Henry B..html">Gardner, Henry B.</a></cite>
Henry B. Gardner died in Providence on April 22, 1939.<cite><a href="Gardner, Henry B..html">Gardner, Henry B.</a></cite>
The arrangement which led to the acquisition of the house was made by George W. Gardner 1894, his wife, Jessie Barker Gardner 1896, and their friend since college days, Vice-<a href="President.html">President</a> Albert D. Mead.<cite><a href="Gardner House.html">Gardner House</a></cite>
The house on George Street, an elegant three-story brick Federal house built by mason Joseph Haile in 1806, was acquired by the University and the use of it given to the Gardners, who contributed to its restoration and gave the Orchard Avenue house to Brown.<cite><a href="Gardner House.html">Gardner House</a></cite>
On April 14, 1935 the Gardners held an informal house-warming, at which Albert Mead dedicated the Henry Ames Barker room in memory of Mrs. Gardner’s brother "to all the interests, civic and artistic, that filled his life," and communicated her wish that the room would serve as a meeting place for groups in the college or city who wish to carry on this work.<cite><a href="Gardner House.html">Gardner House</a></cite>
Henry Ames Barker 1893 was the author, with A. E. Thomas 1894, of a play, "In Colony Times," for the sesquicentennial celebration of the University in 1914.<cite><a href="Gardner House.html">Gardner House</a></cite>
The house is used as lodging for guests of the University, and for many years Mabelle Chappell 1933 served as resident hostess.<cite><a href="Gardner House.html">Gardner House</a></cite>
The four and one-half story brick building with chimney-like stacks at each end was built in 1982 at a cost of approximately 17 million dollars.<cite><a href="Geology-Chemistry Research Building.html">Geology-Chemistry Research Building</a></cite>
A sculpture in the lobby of the building by Robert Scofield was dedicated in 1983 by the <a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a> Department to the memory of Professor William T. King.<cite><a href="Geology-Chemistry Research Building.html">Geology-Chemistry Research Building</a></cite>
Geology was recognized as a separate study when George Ide Chace was appointed professor of chemistry, physiology, and geology in 1836.<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
Edward L. Pierce 1850 recalled "the excursion to Cumberland and vicinity, taken annually by the class in geology, in which he (Chace) explained rare specimens gathered from the mines, - the day closing with an entertainment at his house."<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
The popularity of geology as a study was shown when the class of 1871, by some circumstance deprived of the usual course in junior year, contrived to have Professor Chace deliver a series of lectures for them.<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
Alpheus Spring Packard became professor of zoology and geology in 1878 and was succeeded at his death in 1905 by Charles Wilson Brown, who set up a separate Department of Geology in the basement of <a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a>.<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
There also in 1912 the work of the State Natural Resources Survey, of which Professor Brown was the director, was carried on.<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
The department had only two chairmen in its first 55 years, Professor Brown from its beginning in 1905, and from 1941 to 1960 Alonzo Quinn, who had joined the department in 1929.<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
A student organization called "Pick and Hammer Club" existed in the 1930s to conduct field trips and bring prominent speakers in the field of geology to the campus.<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
Oceanography was introduced at Brown in 1949 and taught by Visiting Professor Raymond B. Montgomery until 1954.<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
F. Donald Eckelmann came in 1957 and became chairman in 1961.<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
By 1960 other young faculty, Léo Laporte, Bruno Giletti, and Thomas Mutch, had been recruited.<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
William Chapple and Richard Yund came in 1961.<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
The first Ph.D. in the Geology Department was awarded in 1964.<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
Robley Matthews joined the staff in 1964, David G. Harkrider in 1965, Michael J. Chinnery in 1966, and John Imbrie in 1967.<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
Paul C. Hess, and John F. Hermance came in 1968.<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
In the middle 1960s the department acquired a new name.<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
The department needed a new building, and architect I. M. Pei was hired in 1964 to design one, but it was not built.<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
By the time the new <a href="Geology-Chemistry Research Building.html">Geology-Chemistry Research Building</a> was occupied in 1982 there were eighteen faculty members, about fifty graduate students and several postdoctoral fellows.<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
In 1974 the Henry L. and Grace Doherty Charitable Foundation offered $500,000 for a chair of oceanography, provided the University would raise $250,000.<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
By 1976 the funds were in hand and John Imbrie was the first Doherty Professor of Oceanography, and upon his retirement in 1990 was succeeded by Warren Prell.<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
In the spring of 1986 Professor Prell, led a scientific team composed mostly of members of the department on a cruise aboard the Research Vessel Robert D. Conrad to search for evidence of past changes in the Indian Ocean monsoon climate system.<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
Since 1990 Professor Donald Forsyth has led three research cruises to map the seafloor in the Pacific Ocean near Easter Island.<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
In the spring of 1981 the Brown Regional Planetary Data Center was opened at the Sciences <a href="Library.html">Library</a> and dedicated to the memory of Thomas A. Mutch, who formed Brown’s planetary geology group of faculty members and graduate students who study the surfaces of planets.<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
Mutch wrote a book on the geology of Mars and oversaw the imaging team for the Viking I and II missions to Mars in 1976.<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
The Planetary Data Center moved into <a href="Lincoln Field Building.html">Lincoln Field Building</a> in 1984, and Associate Professor Peter Schultz assumed the directorship that year.<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
Since 1984, Associate Professsor Carle Pieters has been the Science Manager of the Reflective Experiment Laboratory (RELAB), a multi-user NASA facility at Brown RELAB was rededicated in 1992 after major renovations.<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
Brown has been involved in an informal exchange with the Soviet Union since Professor James Head went to Moscow in 1973 to a space science meeting.<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
In 1985 a five-year agreement for scientific cooperation was signed by Brown and the USSR’s Vernadsky Institute of Geochemistry and Analytic <a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a>.<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
The institutions collaborate on research and since 1984 have held twice yearly "microsymposia," attended by scientists from both countries at Brown in the spring and in the Soviet Union in late summer.<cite><a href="Geology.html">Geology</a></cite>
Robert Hudson George (1889-1979), professor of history, was born in Brookline, Massachusetts, on December 25, 1889.<cite><a href="George, Robert H..html">George, Robert H.</a></cite>
After graduation from Amherst College in 1911, Robert H. George earned his master of arts degree in 1913 and his Ph.D. in 1916, both from Harvard where he was instructor and tutor.<cite><a href="George, Robert H..html">George, Robert H.</a></cite>
Robert H. George was an instructor at Harvard from 1914 to 1916 and at Yale in 1916-17.<cite><a href="George, Robert H..html">George, Robert H.</a></cite>
Robert H. George was a captain in the infantry in the First World War and a member of the American Commission to Negotiate Peace in 1919.<cite><a href="George, Robert H..html">George, Robert H.</a></cite>
Robert H. George returned to Yale as assistant professor from 1919 to 1922, and in 1922-23 was associate professor at Union College.<cite><a href="George, Robert H..html">George, Robert H.</a></cite>
Robert H. George came to Brown as associate professor in 1923 and was promoted to full professor in 1939.<cite><a href="George, Robert H..html">George, Robert H.</a></cite>
Robert H. George was named the first Munro-Goodwin-Wilkinson Professor in 1946.<cite><a href="George, Robert H..html">George, Robert H.</a></cite>
During a sabbatical leave in 1931-32 Robert H. George visited England in search of documents to further his research on James II with the help of a grant from the Social Science Research Council.<cite><a href="George, Robert H..html">George, Robert H.</a></cite>
George was a popular professor, known for his History D1 survey course and for "his deep resounding voice, his interesting lectures, his pleasing personality," noted in the "Pembroke Record" in 1946.<cite><a href="George, Robert H..html">George, Robert H.</a></cite>
Robert H. George's alma mater conferred an honorary L.H.D. degree upon him in 1954 with these words, "In the classroom you are a lecturer of rare artistry.<cite><a href="George, Robert H..html">George, Robert H.</a></cite>
After his retirement from Brown in 1960, Robert H. George continued his work on the reign of James II and also compiled information and wrote articles on Brown University in the Civil War.<cite><a href="George, Robert H..html">George, Robert H.</a></cite>
Robert H. George moved to his summer home in Jaffrey, New Hampshire, where he died on October 12, 1979.<cite><a href="George, Robert H..html">George, Robert H.</a></cite>
Both George and his wife had celebrated their 89th birthday on Christmas Day in 1978.<cite><a href="George, Robert H..html">George, Robert H.</a></cite>
The Gerontology Center was established in 1985.<cite><a href="Gerontology Center.html">Gerontology Center</a></cite>
Julian Howard Gibbs (1924-1983), professor of chemistry, was born in Greenfield, Massachusetts, on June 24, 1924.<cite><a href="Gibbs, Julian H..html">Gibbs, Julian H.</a></cite>
Julian H. Gibbs graduated from Amherst in 1947 and earned his master’s and Ph.D. degrees in 1949 and 1950 from Princeton.<cite><a href="Gibbs, Julian H..html">Gibbs, Julian H.</a></cite>
After that Julian H. Gibbs worked for eight years in research and industry at General Electric Company and American Viscose Corporation before coming to Brown in 1960 as associate professor of chemistry.<cite><a href="Gibbs, Julian H..html">Gibbs, Julian H.</a></cite>
Julian H. Gibbs was named a full professor in 1963.<cite><a href="Gibbs, Julian H..html">Gibbs, Julian H.</a></cite>
Julian H. Gibbs was chairman of the Chemistry Department from 1964 to 1972.<cite><a href="Gibbs, Julian H..html">Gibbs, Julian H.</a></cite>
In 1979 Julian H. Gibbs accepted the presidency of Amherst.<cite><a href="Gibbs, Julian H..html">Gibbs, Julian H.</a></cite>
When Brown conferred an honorary degree upon him in 1981, the citation observed, "We feel sure that you will not lose your love for research on basic problems, especially as carried out in your floating laboratory on Narragansett Bay."<cite><a href="Gibbs, Julian H..html">Gibbs, Julian H.</a></cite>
Julian H. Gibbs did continue his chemical research while he was president, and in 1967 won the High Polymer Prize of the American Physical Society.<cite><a href="Gibbs, Julian H..html">Gibbs, Julian H.</a></cite>
Julian H. Gibbs died suddenly in Springfield, Massachusetts on February 20, 1983, after being stricken while skiing.<cite><a href="Gibbs, Julian H..html">Gibbs, Julian H.</a></cite>
Giddings House, the home of the <a href="Anthropology.html">Anthropology</a> Department on Hope Street named for J. Louis Giddings, was acquired in 1969 with the purchase of the <a href="Bryant College.html">Bryant College</a> campus.<cite><a href="Giddings House.html">Giddings House</a></cite>
Bryant had purchased the building in 1961 for use as a library and had added a wing in 1962.<cite><a href="Giddings House.html">Giddings House</a></cite>
J(ames) Louis Giddings (1909-1964), professor of anthropology, was born in Caldwell, Texas on April 10, 1909.<cite><a href="Giddings, James Louis.html">Giddings, James Louis</a></cite>
James Louis Giddings received his bachelor of science degree in engineering from the University of Alaska in 1932, his M.A. in anthropology from the University of Arizona in 1941, and his Ph.D. from the University of Pennsylvania in 1951.<cite><a href="Giddings, James Louis.html">Giddings, James Louis</a></cite>
From 1932 to 1937 James Louis Giddings worked as an assistant engineer with the Fairbanks Exploration Department of U.S.<cite><a href="Giddings, James Louis.html">Giddings, James Louis</a></cite>
James Louis Giddings began working with the Eskimos in 1934 and later excavated archaeological sites at Cape Denbigh and on the Seward Peninsula.<cite><a href="Giddings, James Louis.html">Giddings, James Louis</a></cite>
From 1940 until 1951 (with three years off for service in World War II) James Louis Giddings taught at the University of Alaska, where he was director of archaeological research and museum curator from 1938 to 1949.<cite><a href="Giddings, James Louis.html">Giddings, James Louis</a></cite>
James Louis Giddings was assistant curator of the American section of the Museum and assistant professor of anthropology at the University of Pennsylvania, before being brought to Brown in 1956 to take charge of the recently acquired Haffenreffer Museum of the American Indian, and develop it into a teaching and research center and also a museum for the public.<cite><a href="Giddings, James Louis.html">Giddings, James Louis</a></cite>
James Louis Giddings was promoted to professor of anthropology in 1959.<cite><a href="Giddings, James Louis.html">Giddings, James Louis</a></cite>
After 1956 James Louis Giddings concentrated on the area around Kotzebue Sound where he made important archaeological discoveries.<cite><a href="Giddings, James Louis.html">Giddings, James Louis</a></cite>
James Louis Giddings's last expedition to Alaska was in the summer of 1964.<cite><a href="Giddings, James Louis.html">Giddings, James Louis</a></cite>
James Louis Giddings died in Pawtucket, Rhode Island, on December 9, 1964 of injuries suffered in an automobile accident November 3.<cite><a href="Giddings, James Louis.html">Giddings, James Louis</a></cite>
In 1966 a previously unnamed 10,180 foot peak about eighty-five miles from Fairbanks, Alaska, was given the name Mount Giddings by the U. S. Department of the Interior to honor "the leading Alaskan archaeologist at the time of his death."<cite><a href="Giddings, James Louis.html">Giddings, James Louis</a></cite>
Ray Edwin Gilman (1887-1975), professor of mathematics, was born in Lansing, Kansas, on June 19, 1887.<cite><a href="Gilman, Ray E..html">Gilman, Ray E.</a></cite>
After graduation in 1911, Ray E. Gilman was assistant in mathematics at Kansas State College for a year and then instructor and fellow in mathematics at Princeton, where he received a Ph.D. degree in 1916.<cite><a href="Gilman, Ray E..html">Gilman, Ray E.</a></cite>
After the war Ray E. Gilman worked briefly for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company until Professor R. G. D. Richardson brought him to Brown as assistant professor in 1919.<cite><a href="Gilman, Ray E..html">Gilman, Ray E.</a></cite>
Ray E. Gilman became associate professor in 1932 and full professor in 1949.<cite><a href="Gilman, Ray E..html">Gilman, Ray E.</a></cite>
In 1952-53 Ray E. Gilman was scientific warfare advisor to the Joint Chiefs of Staff.<cite><a href="Gilman, Ray E..html">Gilman, Ray E.</a></cite>
Ray E. Gilman retired from Brown in 1954, but continued his teaching from 1954 to 1959 at Washington College in Maryland.<cite><a href="Gilman, Ray E..html">Gilman, Ray E.</a></cite>
Ray E. Gilman died in Providence on January 26, 1975.<cite><a href="Gilman, Ray E..html">Gilman, Ray E.</a></cite>
William Giles Goddard (1794-1846), professor of moral philosophy and belles-lettres, was born in Johnston, Rhode Island, on January 2, 1794.<cite><a href="Goddard, William Giles.html">Goddard, William Giles</a></cite>
William Giles Goddard graduated from Brown in 1812 and began the study of law in Worcester, Massachusetts.<cite><a href="Goddard, William Giles.html">Goddard, William Giles</a></cite>
William Giles Goddard turned to newspaper editing as associate editor of the "Worcester Spy," and in 1813 became the proprietor and editor of the "Rhode Island American."<cite><a href="Goddard, William Giles.html">Goddard, William Giles</a></cite>
In 1825 William Giles Goddard was appointed professor of moral philosophy and metaphysics.<cite><a href="Goddard, William Giles.html">Goddard, William Giles</a></cite>
William Giles Goddard was appointed professor of belles-lettres in 1834.<cite><a href="Goddard, William Giles.html">Goddard, William Giles</a></cite>
William Giles Goddard took a more active interest than any of his colleagues in the Dorr Rebellion in 1842, at which time, according to President Wayland, "His essays for the daily press, during this period alone, would fill a moderately sized volume."<cite><a href="Goddard, William Giles.html">Goddard, William Giles</a></cite>
William Giles Goddard resigned in 1842 because of his health and died in Providence on February 16, 1846.<cite><a href="Goddard, William Giles.html">Goddard, William Giles</a></cite>
Wayland wrote further of him: Professor Goddard’s sons were Thomas Poynton Ives Goddard 1846, <a href="Goddard, William.html">William Goddard</a> 1846, Moses Brown Ives Goddard 1854, <a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Francis Wayland</a> Goddard 1855, and Robert Hale Ives Goddard 1858.<cite><a href="Goddard, William Giles.html">Goddard, William Giles</a></cite>
William Goddard (1825-1907), tenth chancellor of the University, was born at Potowomut Neck in Warwick on Christmas Day in 1825, the son of <a href="Goddard, William Giles.html">William Giles Goddard</a> and Charlotte Rhoda Ives.<cite><a href="Goddard, William.html">Goddard, William</a></cite>
After graduation from Brown University in 1846, William Goddard went to Europe, and during the Revolution of 1848 he carried secret dispatches from Paris to Rome.<cite><a href="Goddard, William.html">Goddard, William</a></cite>
William Goddard was elected to the Common Council from the Second Ward in 1852 and was reelected three more times.<cite><a href="Goddard, William.html">Goddard, William</a></cite>
In 1857 William Goddard was named a trustee of Brown University.<cite><a href="Goddard, William.html">Goddard, William</a></cite>
William Goddard retired from military service in 1862.<cite><a href="Goddard, William.html">Goddard, William</a></cite>
From 1875 to 1900 William Goddard was president of the Providence Institution for Savings, a job for which he received no salary.<cite><a href="Goddard, William.html">Goddard, William</a></cite>
William Goddard was Chancellor of Brown from 1888 until his death in Providence on September 20, 1907.<cite><a href="Goddard, William.html">Goddard, William</a></cite>
Golf became accessible to Brown students in October 1901, when a change in the constitution of the Metacomet Club in East Providence provided that members of the newly formed Brown Golf Club would be admitted to the Metacomet Club without further recommendation.<cite><a href="Golf.html">Golf</a></cite>
In 1903 Brown won the New England intercollegiate golf tournament at the Wannamoisett Club, defeating Amherst and M.I.T.<cite><a href="Golf.html">Golf</a></cite>
Golf became a recognized sport in 1920, and over the years had a few highly successful seasons, which occurred in 1931, 1941, 1949, 1955, 1956, 1968, 1971, 1972, and 1975.<cite><a href="Golf.html">Golf</a></cite>
The 1969 and 1975 teams were undefeated.<cite><a href="Golf.html">Golf</a></cite>
After taking time off from college and improving his strength by working as a lumberjack, he returned to play with the 1928 team and finish second in the Intercollegiate tournament that year.<cite><a href="Golf.html">Golf</a></cite>
In its best season in seven years the golf team in 1982 finished fourth in the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> and fourth of twelve teams in the New England Championships.<cite><a href="Golf.html">Golf</a></cite>
Funding for golf as a varsity sport was withdrawn in 1991 as part of the University’s budget reduction.<cite><a href="Golf.html">Golf</a></cite>
Among the golf coaches have been Frank S. Souchak from 1942 to 1943, Charles A. Engle in 1943 and again from 1947 to 1950, Ralph Anderton from 1951 to 1961, L. Stanley Ward from 1961 to 1963, J. Allen Soares from 1963 to 1970, Mike Koval in 1970-71, Jack Ferreira in 1971-71, Richard L. Toomey from 1972 to 1979, Jay Riley from 1979 to 1982, Paul Butler from 1982 to 1988, and Chris Humm, whose four-year record since 1988 is 24-16.<cite><a href="Golf.html">Golf</a></cite>
Leland Matthew Goodrich (1899-1990), professor of political science, was born in Lewiston, Maine, on September 1, 1899.<cite><a href="Goodrich, Leland M..html">Goodrich, Leland M.</a></cite>
Leland M. Goodrich graduated from Bowdoin College in 1920 and earned his master of arts degree in 1921 and his Ph.D. in 1925, both from Harvard.<cite><a href="Goodrich, Leland M..html">Goodrich, Leland M.</a></cite>
While studying for his doctorate Leland M. Goodrich taught at Brown in 1922-23, and during the next two years studied in Brussels, Paris, and the Hague on a fellowship of the Commission for the Relief of Belgium.<cite><a href="Goodrich, Leland M..html">Goodrich, Leland M.</a></cite>
Leland M. Goodrich taught at Lafayette College in 1925-26 and returned to Brown as assistant professor of political science in 1926.<cite><a href="Goodrich, Leland M..html">Goodrich, Leland M.</a></cite>
Leland M. Goodrich was named associate professor in 1931 and professor in 1946.<cite><a href="Goodrich, Leland M..html">Goodrich, Leland M.</a></cite>
Leland M. Goodrich was a lecturer at the Naval War College from 1928 to 1939.<cite><a href="Goodrich, Leland M..html">Goodrich, Leland M.</a></cite>
Leland M. Goodrich studied in Geneva during a leave of absence in 1936 and during World War II was on leave to be director of the World Peace Foundation in Boston from 1942 to 1946.<cite><a href="Goodrich, Leland M..html">Goodrich, Leland M.</a></cite>
Leland M. Goodrich was a member of the international secretariat for the United Nations Conference on International Organization in San Francisco in 1945.<cite><a href="Goodrich, Leland M..html">Goodrich, Leland M.</a></cite>
Leland M. Goodrich took a leave of absence in 1948 and was appointed chairman of the Political Science Department in 1949.<cite><a href="Goodrich, Leland M..html">Goodrich, Leland M.</a></cite>
When Leland M. Goodrich left Brown on 1950 to become professor of international organization and American foreign relations at Columbia University School of International Affairs, where he had been a visiting professor for two years, President Wriston approved the appointment, which "taking him as it does near the United Nations headquarters, will allow him to continue his distinguished work with that organization in the field of foreign affairs."<cite><a href="Goodrich, Leland M..html">Goodrich, Leland M.</a></cite>
Leland M. Goodrich's book, "The United Nations," was one of seventy "controversial" volumes removed from a United States exhibition in Moscow in 1959, and was later one of 37 of these books allowed to be returned to the exhibit.<cite><a href="Goodrich, Leland M..html">Goodrich, Leland M.</a></cite>
Leland M. Goodrich was also the author of "The United Nations in a Changing World" in 1974.<cite><a href="Goodrich, Leland M..html">Goodrich, Leland M.</a></cite>
Leland M. Goodrich died on November 16, 1990.<cite><a href="Goodrich, Leland M..html">Goodrich, Leland M.</a></cite>
Lewis Hall Gordon (1905-1990), professor of Italian, was born in Trenton, New Jersey, on December 23, 1905.<cite><a href="Gordon, Lewis H..html">Gordon, Lewis H.</a></cite>
Lewis H. Gordon graduated in 1927 from Princeton, where he received his master of arts degree the next year.<cite><a href="Gordon, Lewis H..html">Gordon, Lewis H.</a></cite>
Lewis H. Gordon earned his Ph.D. at Cornell in 1945.<cite><a href="Gordon, Lewis H..html">Gordon, Lewis H.</a></cite>
Lewis H. Gordon taught romance languages at Hamilton College from 1929 until 1943, when he became acting associate professor at Cornell, serving as the head of the Italian division of the Army Specialized Training Program for Languages.<cite><a href="Gordon, Lewis H..html">Gordon, Lewis H.</a></cite>
In 1946 Lewis H. Gordon came to Brown as visiting associate professor of romance languages and literatures.<cite><a href="Gordon, Lewis H..html">Gordon, Lewis H.</a></cite>
Lewis H. Gordon was named associate professor in 1947, professor of Italian in 1955, and professor of Italian and French in 1960.<cite><a href="Gordon, Lewis H..html">Gordon, Lewis H.</a></cite>
In 1954 Lewis H. Gordon was elected president of the American Association of Teachers of Italian.<cite><a href="Gordon, Lewis H..html">Gordon, Lewis H.</a></cite>
Lewis H. Gordon retired in 1970.<cite><a href="Gordon, Lewis H..html">Gordon, Lewis H.</a></cite>
Lewis H. Gordon died on November 11, 1990, in Providence.<cite><a href="Gordon, Lewis H..html">Gordon, Lewis H.</a></cite>
Frederic Poole Gorham (1871-1933), professor of bacteriology, was born in Providence on April 29, 1871.<cite><a href="Gorham, Frederic P..html">Gorham, Frederic P.</a></cite>
Frederic P. Gorham graduated from Brown in 1893 and earned a master of arts degree in 1894.<cite><a href="Gorham, Frederic P..html">Gorham, Frederic P.</a></cite>
Frederic P. Gorham was named instructor in biology at Brown in 1893, assistant professor in 1899, and associate professor in 1901.<cite><a href="Gorham, Frederic P..html">Gorham, Frederic P.</a></cite>
In 1913 Frederic P. Gorham established bacteriology as a study at Brown, and was appointed professor of bacteriology.<cite><a href="Gorham, Frederic P..html">Gorham, Frederic P.</a></cite>
Frederic P. Gorham was also head of the Biology Department from 1928 until his death.<cite><a href="Gorham, Frederic P..html">Gorham, Frederic P.</a></cite>
In 1899 the Providence Department of Health appointed him as its bacteriologist, an office in which Frederic P. Gorham continued until it was removed to the <a href="Chapin, Charles V..html">Charles V. Chapin</a> Hospital in 1933.<cite><a href="Gorham, Frederic P..html">Gorham, Frederic P.</a></cite>
Frederic P. Gorham became biologist and bacteriologist for the Rhode Island Shellfish Commission in 1913, and deputy milk inspector for the city of Providence in 1914.<cite><a href="Gorham, Frederic P..html">Gorham, Frederic P.</a></cite>
From 1925 to 1931 Frederic P. Gorham was a member of the city park commission.<cite><a href="Gorham, Frederic P..html">Gorham, Frederic P.</a></cite>
Frederic P. Gorham was voted an honorary Doctor of Science degree in 1933, and, in his acknowledgment written in January, referred to this award as "an honor that I had never even dreamed would come to me," adding, "I shall certainly be present, Deo volente, to receive the degree at the coming Commencement."<cite><a href="Gorham, Frederic P..html">Gorham, Frederic P.</a></cite>
Unfortunately, two weeks before Commencement, on June 4, 1933, Gorham died after being stricken with a sudden heart attack in the garden of his summer home at Glocester.<cite><a href="Gorham, Frederic P..html">Gorham, Frederic P.</a></cite>
The Graduate Center, built in 1968, was composed of four six-story dormitory towers around a central four-story commons building.<cite><a href="Graduate Center.html">Graduate Center</a></cite>
The dedication of the Center, at which Margaret Mead was the principal speaker, was held on October 12, 1968.<cite><a href="Graduate Center.html">Graduate Center</a></cite>
The <a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a> convocation began in 1926, when, because of the large number of degree recipients, it was decided to hold separate exercises for the awarding of advanced degrees on Tuesday, the day after <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a>.<cite><a href="Graduate School Convocation.html">Graduate School Convocation</a></cite>
In 1928 the ceremony was scheduled for the Saturday preceding <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a>.<cite><a href="Graduate School Convocation.html">Graduate School Convocation</a></cite>
In 1958 the time of the <a href="Convocation.html">Convocation</a> was changed to take place in <a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a> at the same time as the <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> exercises in the First Baptist Meeting House.<cite><a href="Graduate School Convocation.html">Graduate School Convocation</a></cite>
In 1989 the site of the <a href="Convocation.html">Convocation</a> was changed to <a href="Lincoln Field.html">Lincoln Field</a>.<cite><a href="Graduate School Convocation.html">Graduate School Convocation</a></cite>
In 1978, to commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of the <a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a>, citations "for distinguished contributions to society through scholarship or related professional activity" were awarded to alumni of the <a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a> for the first time.<cite><a href="Graduate School Convocation.html">Graduate School Convocation</a></cite>
A three day convocation, "On the Future of Knowledge," was held on October 29-31, 1989, honoring one hundred years of Ph.D. degrees granted by the University.<cite><a href="Graduate School Convocation.html">Graduate School Convocation</a></cite>
The Graduate School started in 1927, succeeding the Graduate Department which had been in existence since 1903.<cite><a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a></cite>
Through the years alumni had desired graduate instruction and in the late 1870s faculty members had accommodated them.<cite><a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a></cite>
Robinson himself had stayed on in a rented room in the college after his graduation in 1838 in order to study German with Professor Horatio B. Hackett.<cite><a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a></cite>
Starting in 1859-60, most of the annual catalogues carried a list of graduates in residence, although there were no advanced degrees.<cite><a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a></cite>
Robinson, in his 1881 report, noted, "Individual graduates ... are every year proposing to remain and continue their studies in one direction of another; but the number is not large enough, nor the studies proposed to be pursued of a kind, to warrant at present the organization of a special department."<cite><a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a></cite>
His own post-graduate lectures given in 1878-79 and 1879-80 had been replaced the next year by a course of lectures on a variety of subjects, also open to the public, taught by six faculty members.<cite><a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a></cite>
In 1887 study for the degrees of Master of Arts and Doctor of <a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a> was instituted.<cite><a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a></cite>
The first graduate degrees were awarded to Austen K. DeBlois and George Grafton Wilson 1886, both of whom received the Master of Arts degree in 1888 and the Doctor of <a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a> degree in 1889, DeBlois in philosophy and psychology and Wilson in history and political science.<cite><a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a></cite>
Wilson taught political and social science at Brown from 1891 to 1910, when he became professor of international law at Harvard.<cite><a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a></cite>
In 1889 <a href="President.html">President</a> Andrews appointed a committee on graduate students, consisting of Alonzo Williams, Alpheus Spring Packard, and Albert G. Harkness.<cite><a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a></cite>
Also through the efforts of Professor Williams the first graduate fellowship was established in 1891 by the Rhode Island Department of Grand Army of the Republic with a fund of $10,000, the income of which was available to assist a graduate student, preferably the descendant of a Union veteran of the <a href="Civil War.html">Civil War</a>.<cite><a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a></cite>
In 1903 Carl Barus was appointed dean of the newly established Graduate Department.<cite><a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a></cite>
He ran the department out of his office in <a href="Wilson Hall.html">Wilson Hall</a> aided by what Professor R. Bruce Lindsay 1920 described as "a stack of forms with slots for the insertion of names, courses and dates.<cite><a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a></cite>
The Master of Science degree was added in 1904.<cite><a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a></cite>
Work in absentia was abolished in 1908.<cite><a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a></cite>
The State of Rhode Island began in 1912-13 to grant graduate scholarships in education to teachers in service.<cite><a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a></cite>
Over one hundred doctorates were awarded during Barus’ administration from 1903 to 1926, in the latter half of which many were in chemistry and biology.<cite><a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a></cite>
In 1917-18 new rules governing graduate education provided that the major department be responsible for seeing that candidates for the master’s degree submit a substantial thesis on an approved topic.<cite><a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a></cite>
After it became apparent that few departments were requiring the thesis, a Graduate Council consisting of four members and the <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> was established in 1922 to help with the administration of graduate work.<cite><a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a></cite>
Barus retired in 1926.<cite><a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a></cite>
Between 1888 and 1926 the number of degrees conferred amounted to 132 Ph.D. degrees, 1,001 Master of Arts degrees, 98 Master of Science degrees, and 5 Master of Business Administration degrees.<cite><a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a></cite>
In 1927 the Graduate School, with Roland G. D. Richardson as dean, replaced the Graduate Department.<cite><a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a></cite>
Richardson encouraged doctoral programs in mathematics and physics, especially by the establishment of the Graduate Division of Applied <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a> in 1941.<cite><a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a></cite>
Three hundred and sixty Ph.D degrees were awarded between 1930 to 1950, an annual average of eighteen, compared to four per year during Barus’ time.<cite><a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a></cite>
Following <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> Richardson, the deans of the Graduate School have been Barnaby C. Keeney from 1949 to 1953, Robert Bruce Lindsay from 1954 to 1966, Michael J. Brennan from 1966 to 1974, Maurice Glicksman from 1974 to 1976, Ernest S. Frerichs from 1976 to 1982, Mark B. Schupack from 1983 to 1986, and Phillip J. Stiles (as <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> of the Graduate School and <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> of Research) since 1986.<cite><a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a></cite>
Acting deans were Curt J. Ducasse from 1947 to 1949, Edmund S. Morgan in 1951-52, and Donald F. Hornig in 1953-54.<cite><a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a></cite>
The total enrollment of the Graduate School in September 1991 was 1379, composed of 816 men and 563 women, of whom 1316 are full-time and 73 were part-time students.<cite><a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a></cite>
Albert Gorton Greene (1802-1867), Brown graduate in 1820, was born on February 10, 1802 in Providence.<cite><a href="Greene, Albert Gorton.html">Greene, Albert Gorton</a></cite>
After graduation from Brown Albert Gorton Greene studied law in the office of John Whipple, passed the bar in 1823, and began the practice of law.<cite><a href="Greene, Albert Gorton.html">Greene, Albert Gorton</a></cite>
In 1832, on formation of the city government of Providence, Albert Gorton Greene was named clerk of the city council and also of the municipal court.<cite><a href="Greene, Albert Gorton.html">Greene, Albert Gorton</a></cite>
Albert Gorton Greene held the first office until the year before his death, and the second office until 1857, when he was appointed judge of the court, an office he held until his death in Cleveland on January 3, 1867.<cite><a href="Greene, Albert Gorton.html">Greene, Albert Gorton</a></cite>
Albert Gorton Greene was a leader in Providence literary circles, a friend of Mrs. Sarah Helen Whitman, a book collector, and editor of "The Literary Journal and Weekly Register of Science and the Arts" during the one year of its existence in 1833-34.<cite><a href="Greene, Albert Gorton.html">Greene, Albert Gorton</a></cite>
<a href="Washington, George.html">George Washington</a> Greene (1811-1883), instructor in modern languages, was born in East Greenwich, Rhode Island, on April 8, 1811.<cite><a href="Greene, George W..html">Greene, George W.</a></cite>
In 1825, at the age of fourteen, George W. Greene entered Brown.<cite><a href="Greene, George W..html">Greene, George W.</a></cite>
George W. Greene lived abroad for twenty years, except for several visits home, during one of which in 1834 he was principal of Kent Academy in East Greenwich.<cite><a href="Greene, George W..html">Greene, George W.</a></cite>
From 1837 to 1845 George W. Greene was United States Consul at Rome.<cite><a href="Greene, George W..html">Greene, George W.</a></cite>
Greene wrote, beginning in 1835, a number of essays on Italian literature and history for the "North American Review."<cite><a href="Greene, George W..html">Greene, George W.</a></cite>
After his return to the United States, George W. Greene was appointed in the spring of 1848 instructor in modern languages at Brown, a position he occupied until 1852.<cite><a href="Greene, George W..html">Greene, George W.</a></cite>
In 1850-51 and 1851-52 courses in Italian and Spanish were offered.<cite><a href="Greene, George W..html">Greene, George W.</a></cite>
<a href="Angell, James Burrill.html">James Burrill Angell</a> 1849, wrote in "Memories of Brown" of Greene’s arrival to take the place of Charles Coffin Jewett, the librarian, who had been teaching modern languages: In 1852 he moved to New York City and devoted his time to study and writing, and was especially occupied with working on the biography of his much admired grandfather, General Nathanael Greene.<cite><a href="Greene, George W..html">Greene, George W.</a></cite>
The first volume of "The Life of Nathanael Greene," was published in 1867, followed by the second and third volumes in 1871.<cite><a href="Greene, George W..html">Greene, George W.</a></cite>
In 1872 Greene became a non-resident professor of American history at Cornell University for a year, and may be said to have held the first chair in American history in the country.<cite><a href="Greene, George W..html">Greene, George W.</a></cite>
George W. Greene retired to his writing, and died in East Greenwich on February 2, 1883.<cite><a href="Greene, George W..html">Greene, George W.</a></cite>
John Francis Greene (1868-1933), professor of classics, was born in Seekonk, Massachusetts, on April 13, 1868.<cite><a href="Greene, John F..html">Greene, John F.</a></cite>
John F. Greene graduated from Brown in 1891 and the next fall was made an instructor in Greek, which he taught until 1894, when he asked to be assigned to the teaching of Latin.<cite><a href="Greene, John F..html">Greene, John F.</a></cite>
John F. Greene received his master’s degree from Brown in 1901 and was named assistant professor of Roman literature and history in 1911.<cite><a href="Greene, John F..html">Greene, John F.</a></cite>
The Providence "Evening Bulletin" editorial the day after John F. Greene's death on February 7, 1933, read,<cite><a href="Greene, John F..html">Greene, John F.</a></cite>
Samuel Stillman Greene (1810-1883), professor of didactics, mathematics, natural history, astronomy and logic, was born in Belchertown, Massachusetts, on May 3, 1810.<cite><a href="Greene, Samuel Stillman.html">Greene, Samuel Stillman</a></cite>
Samuel Stillman Greene entered Brown in the fall of 1833 at the age of twenty-three and found himself ill prepared for college, but he used his vacation to catch up and graduated with the highest honors of his class in 1837.<cite><a href="Greene, Samuel Stillman.html">Greene, Samuel Stillman</a></cite>
Samuel Stillman Greene's resignation was accepted in August 22, 1840, "with regret that the state of his health obliged him to resign."<cite><a href="Greene, Samuel Stillman.html">Greene, Samuel Stillman</a></cite>
From 1842 to 1849 Samuel Stillman Greene taught in the public schools of Boston, and then took on another newly created office, that of agent of the Massachusetts Board of Education.<cite><a href="Greene, Samuel Stillman.html">Greene, Samuel Stillman</a></cite>
In 1851 Samuel Stillman Greene succeeded Nathan Bishop 1837 as superintendent of schools in Providence, and was at the same time appointed professor of didactics at Brown.<cite><a href="Greene, Samuel Stillman.html">Greene, Samuel Stillman</a></cite>
In 1852 Samuel Stillman Greene and others opened a private normal school in Providence, which the next year received the support of the city, and in 1854 became the Rhode Island Normal School (later Rhode Island College of Education and then Rhode Island College).<cite><a href="Greene, Samuel Stillman.html">Greene, Samuel Stillman</a></cite>
The teaching of didactics ceased in 1854.<cite><a href="Greene, Samuel Stillman.html">Greene, Samuel Stillman</a></cite>
The versatile Greene went on to serve as professor of mathematics and civil engineering from 1855 to 1864, and professor of natural philosophy and astronomy from 1864 to 1883, with a change of title to professor of mathematics and astronomy in 1875.<cite><a href="Greene, Samuel Stillman.html">Greene, Samuel Stillman</a></cite>
Meanwhile Samuel Stillman Greene edited a number of grammar textbooks, including "Analysis and Classification of English Sentences" in 1848, and in the same year a simplified "The First Lessons in Grammar."<cite><a href="Greene, Samuel Stillman.html">Greene, Samuel Stillman</a></cite>
There followed "The Introduction to the Study of English Grammar in 1856 and" "A Grammar of the English Language" in 1860, these two being part of a series which ended with the "Analysis."<cite><a href="Greene, Samuel Stillman.html">Greene, Samuel Stillman</a></cite>
Samuel Stillman Greene was a member of the school committee of Providence for eighteen years, president of the Rhode Island Institution of Instruction from 1856 to 1860, president of the National Teachers’ Association in 1864-65 and president of the American Institute of Instruction in 1869-70.<cite><a href="Greene, Samuel Stillman.html">Greene, Samuel Stillman</a></cite>
Samuel Stillman Greene continued his connection with Worcester Academy as trustee from 1852 until his death, and is credited with the rescue of the Academy from a proposal to close and turn its endowment over to the Newton Theological Institution, and also with the relocation of the school to a better location in 1869.<cite><a href="Greene, Samuel Stillman.html">Greene, Samuel Stillman</a></cite>
He had three sons, Frank Bartlett Greene 1872, the son of his first wife, and John Stimson Greene 1882 and Samuel Stuart Greene 1883, the sons of his second.<cite><a href="Greene, Samuel Stillman.html">Greene, Samuel Stillman</a></cite>
The two younger sons were members of the baseball team at Brown, and thus it was that in 1880 Professor Greene undertook the supervision of the laying out of Lincoln Field as a baseball field, investing his time, money, and manual labor.<cite><a href="Greene, Samuel Stillman.html">Greene, Samuel Stillman</a></cite>
His death on January 22, 1883 was sudden, occurring two days after Samuel Stillman Greene was stricken with paralysis while on his way to class.<cite><a href="Greene, Samuel Stillman.html">Greene, Samuel Stillman</a></cite>
Theodore Francis Green (1867-1966), was born in Providence on October 2, 1867, the son of Arnold Green 1858.<cite><a href="Green, Theodore Francis.html">Green, Theodore Francis</a></cite>
Theodore Francis Green entered Brown at fifteen and graduated in 1887.<cite><a href="Green, Theodore Francis.html">Green, Theodore Francis</a></cite>
He joined his father’s law firm, and after 1906 headed the law firm of Green, Hinckley and Allen until 1923, and after that the firm of Green, Curran and Hart.<cite><a href="Green, Theodore Francis.html">Green, Theodore Francis</a></cite>
Theodore Francis Green was an instructor in Roman law at Brown from 1894 to 1897.<cite><a href="Green, Theodore Francis.html">Green, Theodore Francis</a></cite>
In 1932, at the age of 65, instead of retiring, Green was elected Governor of Rhode Island on the Democratic ticket.<cite><a href="Green, Theodore Francis.html">Green, Theodore Francis</a></cite>
In 1907 Theodore Francis Green had been elected to the Rhode Island House of Representatives, but his bids for higher office were unsuccessful.<cite><a href="Green, Theodore Francis.html">Green, Theodore Francis</a></cite>
Theodore Francis Green was defeated for election as Governor in 1912, as Congressman in 1918, and as Governor again in 1930.<cite><a href="Green, Theodore Francis.html">Green, Theodore Francis</a></cite>
Theodore Francis Green finally came into office along with Franklin D. Roosevelt’s Democratic sweep in 1932.<cite><a href="Green, Theodore Francis.html">Green, Theodore Francis</a></cite>
Theodore Francis Green was elected to the United States Senate in 1936 and remained there until 1961.<cite><a href="Green, Theodore Francis.html">Green, Theodore Francis</a></cite>
Theodore Francis Green served on the Foreign Relations Committee from 1937 to 1947 and from 1949 to 1959, and in 1957 at age 89 achieved his fondest wish of becoming chairman of the committee.<cite><a href="Green, Theodore Francis.html">Green, Theodore Francis</a></cite>
