Theodore Francis Green voluntarily resigned the chairmanship in 1959.<cite><a href="Green, Theodore Francis.html">Green, Theodore Francis</a></cite>
In 1957, after Theodore Francis Green had worn his academic gown for more than fifty years, he was presented with a new one.<cite><a href="Green, Theodore Francis.html">Green, Theodore Francis</a></cite>
Theodore Francis Green was on the building committee for Rockefeller Hall and was chairman of the Brown Union from 1903 to 1907.<cite><a href="Green, Theodore Francis.html">Green, Theodore Francis</a></cite>
Theodore Francis Green introduced the bear as the mascot of the University and composed the verse of the Class of 1887 Gate.<cite><a href="Green, Theodore Francis.html">Green, Theodore Francis</a></cite>
Theodore Francis Green served 66 years on the Corporation, as a trustee from 1900 to 1929 and as a fellow from that time until his death on May 19, 1966 in Providence.<cite><a href="Green, Theodore Francis.html">Green, Theodore Francis</a></cite>
Vartan Gregorian, sixteenth president of Brown University, was unanimously elected at a special meeting of the Corporation on August 31, 1988.<cite><a href="Gregorian, Vartan.html">Gregorian, Vartan</a></cite>
Born in Tabriz, Iran, on April 8, 1934, Vartan Gregorian attended an Armenian-Russian school until he was fifteen, when he left Tabriz with fifty dollars and a letter of introduction from a French vice consul and entered the Collège Arménien in Beirut, Lebanon.<cite><a href="Gregorian, Vartan.html">Gregorian, Vartan</a></cite>
In 1955 Vartan Gregorian received a degree in Armenian studies.<cite><a href="Gregorian, Vartan.html">Gregorian, Vartan</a></cite>
Vartan Gregorian earned his Ph.D. degree at Stanford in 1964, writing a dissertation on "Traditionalism and Modernism in Islam."<cite><a href="Gregorian, Vartan.html">Gregorian, Vartan</a></cite>
Vartan Gregorian taught at San Francisco State University from 1960 to 1968.<cite><a href="Gregorian, Vartan.html">Gregorian, Vartan</a></cite>
Vartan Gregorian won the Danforth Foundation’s Harbison Award for Distinguished Teaching in 1968, and in the same year became professor of history at the University of Texas at Austin.<cite><a href="Gregorian, Vartan.html">Gregorian, Vartan</a></cite>
In 1972 Vartan Gregorian was named Tarzian Professor of Armenian and Caucasian History at the University of Pennsylvania.<cite><a href="Gregorian, Vartan.html">Gregorian, Vartan</a></cite>
The next year Vartan Gregorian was named faculty assistant to the president and provost, and served until 1980, when he resigned.<cite><a href="Gregorian, Vartan.html">Gregorian, Vartan</a></cite>
When Gregorian was awarded an honorary degree at Brown’s 1984 Commencement, the citation observed, "The lions who guard the steps of the Library are named ‘Patience’ and ‘Fortitude,’ but when we consider your accomplishments, it is the courage of the lions that we are more apt to remember.<cite><a href="Gregorian, Vartan.html">Gregorian, Vartan</a></cite>
Vartan Gregorian was able to combine teaching with his presidency of the Library, receiving appointments in 1984 as University Professor of History at the New School for Social Research and as professor of history and Near Eastern studies at New York University.<cite><a href="Gregorian, Vartan.html">Gregorian, Vartan</a></cite>
Vartan Gregorian accepted the presidency of Brown in 1988, arrived on campus in January 1989, and was formally inaugurated on April 9.<cite><a href="Gregorian, Vartan.html">Gregorian, Vartan</a></cite>
The Grimshaw-Gudewicz Medical Building, a six-story wing of the Bio-Medical Center, was dedicated on April 20-21, 1990, at exercises which included an inaugural lecture, "From Ionic Currents to Molecules," by William A. Catterall ’68, and a keynote address by Louis W. Sullivan, U. S. Secretary of Health and Human Services.<cite><a href="Grimshaw-Gudewicz Medical Building.html">Grimshaw-Gudewicz Medical Building</a></cite>
The first "Brown University <a href="Calendar.html">Calendar</a>" appeared in October 1913, with an announcement that it would be published every Friday during the college year.<cite><a href="GSJ George Street Journal.html">GSJ George Street Journal</a></cite>
The Publicity Committee announced in October 1915 that publication would be temporarily suspended.<cite><a href="GSJ George Street Journal.html">GSJ George Street Journal</a></cite>
Two weeks later the "<a href="Calendar.html">Calendar</a>" began to be issued as a supplement to the "Brown Daily Herald" on Saturdays during term time, an arrangement which continued until June 1917.<cite><a href="GSJ George Street Journal.html">GSJ George Street Journal</a></cite>
Another calendar, which began in September 1930 as the "Brown University Weekly <a href="Calendar.html">Calendar</a>," changed its name abruptly in December 1932 to "Brown University Weekly Bulletin," and continued under that title, even after it had changed to biweekly publication and adopted a newspaper format in January 1976.<cite><a href="GSJ George Street Journal.html">GSJ George Street Journal</a></cite>
Since September 1980, the paper has been called "The George Street Journal," a name connected with the location of its publisher, the Brown News Bureau, which was selected after a naming contest announced the previous December had brought forth nearly a hundred suggestions.<cite><a href="GSJ George Street Journal.html">GSJ George Street Journal</a></cite>
Publication of the "George Street Journal," suspended in September 1991 for budgetary reasons, was resumed one year later, this time as a weekly paper.<cite><a href="GSJ George Street Journal.html">GSJ George Street Journal</a></cite>
Reuben Aldridge Guild (1822-1899), librarian of the University from 1848 to 1893, was born in Dedham, Massachusetts, on May 4, 1822, one of a family of eleven children.<cite><a href="Guild, Reuben A..html">Guild, Reuben A.</a></cite>
Reuben A. Guild was brought up as a Unitarian, but in April 1840 he was baptized by the Reverend Baron Stow and received as a member of the Baldwin Place Baptist Church in Boston.<cite><a href="Guild, Reuben A..html">Guild, Reuben A.</a></cite>
On his graduation from Brown in 1847, Reuben A. Guild became assistant librarian, and in March 1848 succeeded his former teacher, Charles Coffin Jewett, as librarian.<cite><a href="Guild, Reuben A..html">Guild, Reuben A.</a></cite>
That position Reuben A. Guild held until 1893, and his obituary notes that he was absent on only three occasions.<cite><a href="Guild, Reuben A..html">Guild, Reuben A.</a></cite>
These were a convalescence from a sprained ankle suffered from a fall from a ladder in the library in 1857, a few days of absence when his son died in 1876, and a visit to England and Scotland in 1877 when Reuben A. Guild attended the International Conference of Librarians in London.<cite><a href="Guild, Reuben A..html">Guild, Reuben A.</a></cite>
Reuben A. Guild was instrumental with Charles B. Norton in calling the first librarians’ convention, which met in New York in September of 1853.<cite><a href="Guild, Reuben A..html">Guild, Reuben A.</a></cite>
Reuben A. Guild was the historian of Brown University, keeping scrapbooks of clippings about the University beginning in 1851, and publishing "The Life, Times and Correspondence of <a href="Manning, James.html">James Manning</a>, and the Early History of Brown University" in 1864, "History of Brown University with Illustrative Documents" in 1867, and "The Early History of Brown University" in 1897.<cite><a href="Guild, Reuben A..html">Guild, Reuben A.</a></cite>
This last named work was to have been the first of a two volume set, the second to be an update of Reuben A. Guild's 1867 "History."<cite><a href="Guild, Reuben A..html">Guild, Reuben A.</a></cite>
Reuben A. Guild spent his time after his retirement in 1893 in writing.<cite><a href="Guild, Reuben A..html">Guild, Reuben A.</a></cite>
Reuben A. Guild died in Providence on May 13, 1899, at the age of 77.<cite><a href="Guild, Reuben A..html">Guild, Reuben A.</a></cite>
Gymnastics became important in 1891, when Lyman Gymnasium was built and Dr. Fred E. Parker was appointed director of physical culture.<cite><a href="Gymnastics.html">Gymnastics</a></cite>
A demonstration of physical training by six hundred students in Infantry Hall on March 3, 1898 was the first of the annual gymnastic demonstrations.<cite><a href="Gymnastics.html">Gymnastics</a></cite>
In 1914 a varsity gym team coached by Lucien Joseph Gay was successful in its two meets with Harvard and Haverford.<cite><a href="Gymnastics.html">Gymnastics</a></cite>
The next year the team lost to Harvard and Yale, defeated Dartmouth (in the first athletic contest since Brown and Dartmouth severed athletic relations in 1907).<cite><a href="Gymnastics.html">Gymnastics</a></cite>
In 1916 Hincks coached the team through a longer season of three losses and four wins, team captain Ernest Mattison ’16 amassed fifteen first places during the season, and Brown was second in the intercollegiate meet at Philadelphia.<cite><a href="Gymnastics.html">Gymnastics</a></cite>
The gym team disappeared after the season of 1917, during which it defeated Harvard and Haverford and tied with Dartmouth.<cite><a href="Gymnastics.html">Gymnastics</a></cite>
Jackie Court has coached women’s gymnastics since from 1970.<cite><a href="Gymnastics.html">Gymnastics</a></cite>
The team had its first winning season, 6-4, in 1979 and a better season, 10-1, in 1980, followed by an undefeated season in nine dual meets in 1980-81.<cite><a href="Gymnastics.html">Gymnastics</a></cite>
The team finished third in the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> in 1986 and 1988.<cite><a href="Gymnastics.html">Gymnastics</a></cite>
In 1990 Brown hosted the Ivy tournament and won the championship with a school-record 175.80, .05 of a point ahead of Yale.<cite><a href="Gymnastics.html">Gymnastics</a></cite>
Funding for women’s gymnastics as a varsity sport was withdrawn in 1991 as part of the University’s budget reduction.<cite><a href="Gymnastics.html">Gymnastics</a></cite>
Horatio Balch Hackett (1808-1875), professor of Hebrew and classical literature, was born in Salisbury, Massachusetts, on December 27, 1808.<cite><a href="Hackett, Horatio B..html">Hackett, Horatio B.</a></cite>
Horatio B. Hackett graduated from Phillips Academy, Andover, and Amherst College, where he was a tutor in 1831-32.<cite><a href="Hackett, Horatio B..html">Hackett, Horatio B.</a></cite>
After graduation from Andover Theological Seminary, Horatio B. Hackett taught at Mount Hope College in Baltimore in 1834-35.<cite><a href="Hackett, Horatio B..html">Hackett, Horatio B.</a></cite>
Horatio B. Hackett was appointed adjunct professor of Latin and Greek at Brown in 1835, and was professor of Hebrew and classical literature from 1837 to 1839.<cite><a href="Hackett, Horatio B..html">Hackett, Horatio B.</a></cite>
Charles T. Congdon 1841 remembered Hackett: When Hackett left Brown in 1839 to become professor of Biblical literature at Newton Theological Institution, <a href="Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman.html">Ezekiel Gilman Robinson</a> 1838 went along to continue his studies with him.<cite><a href="Hackett, Horatio B..html">Hackett, Horatio B.</a></cite>
Hackett continued to teach at Newton until 1868.<cite><a href="Hackett, Horatio B..html">Hackett, Horatio B.</a></cite>
In 1870, at the request of Robinson, then president of Rochester Theological Institution, Hackett returned to teaching as professor of Biblical literature and New Testament exegesis.<cite><a href="Hackett, Horatio B..html">Hackett, Horatio B.</a></cite>
After a trip to the East in 1852, Horatio B. Hackett published "Illustrations of Scripture, suggested by a Tour through the Holy Land."<cite><a href="Hackett, Horatio B..html">Hackett, Horatio B.</a></cite>
In 1858-59 Horatio B. Hackett spent six months in Athens, sponsored by the American Bible Union.<cite><a href="Hackett, Horatio B..html">Hackett, Horatio B.</a></cite>
Horatio B. Hackett contributed thirty articles to William Smith’s "Dictionary of the Bible," published in England in 1861-63, and in 1866 began an American edition of Smith’s "Dictionary," which was published between 1867 and 1870.<cite><a href="Hackett, Horatio B..html">Hackett, Horatio B.</a></cite>
Horatio B. Hackett continued to teach at Rochester, and only a few weeks after his final trip abroad, he died suddenly on November 2, 1875, having just met with one of his classes.<cite><a href="Hackett, Horatio B..html">Hackett, Horatio B.</a></cite>
The Haffenreffer Museum of the American Indian was acquired in December 1955 as part of the property in Bristol, which was given to the University by the Haffenreffer family.<cite><a href="Haffenreffer Museum.html">Haffenreffer Museum</a></cite>
In 1917, when Rudolph F. Haffenreffer II purchased the Bristol estate called Mount Hope, where King Philip lived and died, he found arrowheads and other Indian artifacts on his land and began to collect them.<cite><a href="Haffenreffer Museum.html">Haffenreffer Museum</a></cite>
He then began to acquire more of these objects from other places, and in 1928 built a museum to house his outstanding collection of Indian objects from North, Central, and South America.<cite><a href="Haffenreffer Museum.html">Haffenreffer Museum</a></cite>
After Haffenreffer’s death in 1954, his widow and sons decided to give the 500-acre estate with the museum to Brown.<cite><a href="Haffenreffer Museum.html">Haffenreffer Museum</a></cite>
When Giddings died in 1964, his widow, Ruth Warner Giddings, stayed on as administrator of the museum.<cite><a href="Haffenreffer Museum.html">Haffenreffer Museum</a></cite>
In 1968 Alex F. Ricciardelli, an authority on the North American Indian and a former student of Giddings, was appointed curator.<cite><a href="Haffenreffer Museum.html">Haffenreffer Museum</a></cite>
<a href="Anthropology.html">Anthropology</a> professor Jane Dwyer was director of the museum from 1971 until her death in 1982.<cite><a href="Haffenreffer Museum.html">Haffenreffer Museum</a></cite>
Shepard Krech III has been director since 1988.<cite><a href="Haffenreffer Museum.html">Haffenreffer Museum</a></cite>
Albert Harkness (1822-1907), professor of Greek languages and literature, was born in Mendon, Massachusetts, on October 6, 1822.<cite><a href="Harkness, Albert 1842.html">Harkness, Albert 1842</a></cite>
Albert 1842 Harkness graduated from Brown in 1842, the valedictorian of his class.<cite><a href="Harkness, Albert 1842.html">Harkness, Albert 1842</a></cite>
From 1853 to 1855 Albert 1842 Harkness was in Germany, studying in Berlin, Bonn, and Göttingen.<cite><a href="Harkness, Albert 1842.html">Harkness, Albert 1842</a></cite>
Albert 1842 Harkness's Ph.D. degree was earned in Bonn in 1854.<cite><a href="Harkness, Albert 1842.html">Harkness, Albert 1842</a></cite>
From 1855 until his retirement in 1892 Albert 1842 Harkness was Professor of Greek at Brown.<cite><a href="Harkness, Albert 1842.html">Harkness, Albert 1842</a></cite>
Albert 1842 Harkness travelled to Europe again in 1870-71 and 1883-84 during leaves of absence.<cite><a href="Harkness, Albert 1842.html">Harkness, Albert 1842</a></cite>
Albert 1842 Harkness published "A First Greek Book" in 1860.<cite><a href="Harkness, Albert 1842.html">Harkness, Albert 1842</a></cite>
Albert 1842 Harkness taught Greek at Brown, but maintained his early devotion to Latin and published fourteen Latin textbooks between 1851 and 1905.<cite><a href="Harkness, Albert 1842.html">Harkness, Albert 1842</a></cite>
At his death on May 27, 1907, the "Brown Alumni Monthly" printed these lines about him: A bronze bust of Harkness modeled by William Manatt of Providence six months before Harkness’s death was given to Brown by his widow in 1909.<cite><a href="Harkness, Albert 1842.html">Harkness, Albert 1842</a></cite>
Albert Granger Harkness (1856-1923), professor of classics, was born in Providence on November 19, 1856, the son the Professor <a href="Harkness, Albert 1842.html">Albert Harkness</a> 1842.<cite><a href="Harkness, Albert Granger.html">Harkness, Albert Granger</a></cite>
Albert Granger Harkness studied at the University Grammar School and entered Brown in 1874, but because of illness did not graduate until 1879.<cite><a href="Harkness, Albert Granger.html">Harkness, Albert Granger</a></cite>
Albert Granger Harkness taught classics at the Peddie School until 1881, then studied Latin and Greek philology at the Universities of Berlin, Leipzig, and Bonn.<cite><a href="Harkness, Albert Granger.html">Harkness, Albert Granger</a></cite>
Albert Granger Harkness was professor of Latin and German at Madison University (now Colgate) from 1883 to 1889, when he returned to Brown as associate professor of Latin.<cite><a href="Harkness, Albert Granger.html">Harkness, Albert Granger</a></cite>
Albert Granger Harkness became professor of Roman literature and history in 1893.<cite><a href="Harkness, Albert Granger.html">Harkness, Albert Granger</a></cite>
In 1902-03 Albert Granger Harkness was resident professor at the American School for Classical Studies in Rome.<cite><a href="Harkness, Albert Granger.html">Harkness, Albert Granger</a></cite>
Albert Granger Harkness died in Providence on January 29, 1923.<cite><a href="Harkness, Albert Granger.html">Harkness, Albert Granger</a></cite>
William Thomson Hastings (1881-1969), professor of English, was born in Feeding Hills, Massachusetts, on December 1, 1881.<cite><a href="Hastings, William T..html">Hastings, William T.</a></cite>
He entered Brown in 1899, following the footsteps of his father, Judson W. Hastings 1876, who had not planned to go to college at all, but had been persuaded by his principal at Suffield Academy, who was E. Benjamin Andrews 1870, later president of Brown.<cite><a href="Hastings, William T..html">Hastings, William T.</a></cite>
William Hastings graduated in 1903, and immediately began what was to be his life-long teaching career at Brown, being appointed assistant in English in 1903, instructor in 1907, assistant professor in 1912, associate professor in 1923, professor in 1935, and chairman of the Department of English from 1937 to 1949.<cite><a href="Hastings, William T..html">Hastings, William T.</a></cite>
William T. Hastings earned a master of arts degree at Brown in 1905 and a second master of arts degree at Harvard in 1907.<cite><a href="Hastings, William T..html">Hastings, William T.</a></cite>
His two years of study at Harvard were the only time that William T. Hastings was away from Brown in the 53 years from his arrival as a student in 1899 until his retirement in 1952.<cite><a href="Hastings, William T..html">Hastings, William T.</a></cite>
Elected to Phi Beta Kappa in 1902, William T. Hastings was secretary of Rhode Island Alpha from 1920 to 1951, vice-president from 1951 to 1953, president from 1953 to 1955, and chapter historian until his death.<cite><a href="Hastings, William T..html">Hastings, William T.</a></cite>
William T. Hastings served on the Senate of the United Chapters of Phi Beta Kappa, and was national vice-president from 1952 to 1955, national president from 1955 to 1958, and national historian until his death.<cite><a href="Hastings, William T..html">Hastings, William T.</a></cite>
William T. Hastings's last book, published in 1965, was "Phi Beta Kappa as a Secret Society."<cite><a href="Hastings, William T..html">Hastings, William T.</a></cite>
In 1948 William T. Hastings attracted attention by being the faculty member who was willing to introduce presidential candidate Henry Wallace when he came to speak on the campus.<cite><a href="Hastings, William T..html">Hastings, William T.</a></cite>
Hastings died in Providence on December 18, 1969.<cite><a href="Hastings, William T..html">Hastings, William T.</a></cite>
John (Milton) Hay (1838-1905), secretary to President Abraham Lincoln and Secretary of State of the United States, was born on October 8, 1838 in a small brick house in Salem, Indiana.<cite><a href="Hay, John.html">Hay, John</a></cite>
The oldest son died in 1840.<cite><a href="Hay, John.html">Hay, John</a></cite>
When Augustus died in 1904, John Hay wrote to Theodore Roosevelt, "My brother was my first friend and my best.<cite><a href="Hay, John.html">Hay, John</a></cite>
The Hay boys studied at the private school of the Reverend Stephen Childs, an Episcopal clergyman, and in 1851 John went to an academy at Pittsfield in Pike County, where he met an older student, John G. Nicolay, who would influence his later career.<cite><a href="Hay, John.html">Hay, John</a></cite>
In 1852 John Hay went to the college at Springfield, and in 1855 was sent to Brown, where his grandfather David Augustus Leonard had graduated in 1792.<cite><a href="Hay, John.html">Hay, John</a></cite>
John Hay was admitted to advanced standing and could have finished college in 1857, but finding himself behind the juniors in some studies, he wrote home, "I do not know whether I can finish the course, with justice, in two years.<cite><a href="Hay, John.html">Hay, John</a></cite>
As Class Poet, John Hay read his poem, "Erato," at Class Day on June 10, 1858, and captivated his audience.<cite><a href="Hay, John.html">Hay, John</a></cite>
Early in 1864 Hay was named Assistant Adjutant-general in the army and detailed to the White House with the successive ranks of major, lieutenant colonel, and colonel.<cite><a href="Hay, John.html">Hay, John</a></cite>
In March 1865 John Hay was appointed secretary to the American legation in Paris, where he remained until 1867.<cite><a href="Hay, John.html">Hay, John</a></cite>
In 1867 John Hay went to Vienna as chargé d’affaires, and in 1869 he became secretary of legation in Madrid.<cite><a href="Hay, John.html">Hay, John</a></cite>
Returning to the United States in 1870, John Hay went to work for Whitelaw Reid as editorial writer and night editor for the "New York Tribune."<cite><a href="Hay, John.html">Hay, John</a></cite>
His marriage in 1874 to Clara L. Stone, daughter of wealthy Amasa Stone of Cleveland, changed his life as John Hay moved to Cleveland and conducted the financial affairs of his father-in-law and was able to resume his writing.<cite><a href="Hay, John.html">Hay, John</a></cite>
In 1878 John Hay became Assistant Secretary of State and moved back to Washington.<cite><a href="Hay, John.html">Hay, John</a></cite>
Hay served as editor of the "Tribune" in 1881 while Whitelaw Reid was in Europe; then, having decided to give up politics, he began his own travels.<cite><a href="Hay, John.html">Hay, John</a></cite>
After his friend William McKinley was elected president, John Hay was appointed ambassador to Great Britain in 1897.<cite><a href="Hay, John.html">Hay, John</a></cite>
In September 1898 John Hay was back in Washington to become Secretary of State.<cite><a href="Hay, John.html">Hay, John</a></cite>
The events of the next few years – the end of the Spanish-American War, the "Open Door" policy in China, the Boxer Rebellion, the Russo-Japanese War, the Alaska boundary treaty, and the Panama Canal treaty – all took their toll, and Hay, who had been in ill health for most of this time, died at his summer home on the shore of Lake Sunapee in New Hampshire on July 1, 1905.<cite><a href="Hay, John.html">Hay, John</a></cite>
The new library at Brown built in 1910 was at the request of Andrew Carnegie named the John Hay Library.<cite><a href="Hay, John.html">Hay, John</a></cite>
James Blaine Hedges (1891-1965), professor of history, was born in Bowling Green, Missouri, on November 19, 1891.<cite><a href="Hedges, James B..html">Hedges, James B.</a></cite>
James B. Hedges earned a bachelor of arts degree at the University of Missouri in 1915 and a master’s in 1916.<cite><a href="Hedges, James B..html">Hedges, James B.</a></cite>
James B. Hedges taught at the University of Oklahoma and Mills College while he studied under Frederick Jackson Turner at Harvard for his Ph.D., which he earned in 1924.<cite><a href="Hedges, James B..html">Hedges, James B.</a></cite>
James B. Hedges taught at Clark University before coming to Brown in 1930.<cite><a href="Hedges, James B..html">Hedges, James B.</a></cite>
James B. Hedges was appointed George L. Littlefield Professor of American History in 1931 and was chairman of the History Department twice, from 1938 to 1952 and from 1958 to 1960.<cite><a href="Hedges, James B..html">Hedges, James B.</a></cite>
James B. Hedges retired in 1962, but was still teaching a course in the spring of 1965.<cite><a href="Hedges, James B..html">Hedges, James B.</a></cite>
James B. Hedges died on October 13, 1965 in Providence.<cite><a href="Hedges, James B..html">Hedges, James B.</a></cite>
Ray Lorenzo Heffner, thirteenth president of Brown University, was born in Durham, North Carolina, on May 7, 1925.<cite><a href="Heffner, Ray L..html">Heffner, Ray L.</a></cite>
Ray L. Heffner graduated in 1948.<cite><a href="Heffner, Ray L..html">Heffner, Ray L.</a></cite>
Ray L. Heffner earned his master’s at degree at Yale in 1950.<cite><a href="Heffner, Ray L..html">Heffner, Ray L.</a></cite>
With the help of a Yale College Fellowship and later a Sterling Fellowship, Ray L. Heffner received his Ph.D. degree in 1953.<cite><a href="Heffner, Ray L..html">Heffner, Ray L.</a></cite>
Ray L. Heffner was promoted to assistant professor in 1956 and associate professor in 1960.<cite><a href="Heffner, Ray L..html">Heffner, Ray L.</a></cite>
Ray L. Heffner resigned in January 1963 to become Vice-President for Instruction and Dean of the Faculties at the State University of Iowa.<cite><a href="Heffner, Ray L..html">Heffner, Ray L.</a></cite>
In June 1964 Ray L. Heffner returned to Indiana as full professor and Vice-President and Dean of the Faculties.<cite><a href="Heffner, Ray L..html">Heffner, Ray L.</a></cite>
In 1966 Ray L. Heffner accepted the presidency of Brown University, and when he was inaugurated on October 15, he had already greeted the students at the opening convocation with words of optimism about the new medical program, the Graduate Center about to be constructed, Pembroke College’s approaching 75th anniversary, and the projected Sciences Library.<cite><a href="Heffner, Ray L..html">Heffner, Ray L.</a></cite>
On May 9, 1969 Heffner presented his resignation, stating, "I have simply reached the conclusion that I do not enjoy being a university president."<cite><a href="Heffner, Ray L..html">Heffner, Ray L.</a></cite>
Hegeman Hall, was built at the corner of George and Thayer Streets in 1926 with $250,000 provided by the John R. Hegeman Foundation.<cite><a href="Hegeman Hall.html">Hegeman Hall</a></cite>
The building shared its day of dedication of October 13, 1926 with <a href="Marston Hall.html">Marston Hall</a>.<cite><a href="Hegeman Hall.html">Hegeman Hall</a></cite>
.up .bd Hellcoal Press issued the first of the "Hellcoal Press Pamphlet Series" in March 1968, a pamphlet of four poems by visiting professor Edouard Roditi and Richard <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> Rosen.<cite><a href="Hellcoal Press.html">Hellcoal Press</a></cite>
The pamphlet series continued until 1973.<cite><a href="Hellcoal Press.html">Hellcoal Press</a></cite>
The press also printed individual pamphlets of selected poetry and fiction, including "Pound," poems written at a poetry workshop at <a href="Tougaloo College.html">Tougaloo College</a> in 1968.<cite><a href="Hellcoal Press.html">Hellcoal Press</a></cite>
In addition "Hellcoal Annual" appeared in 1971, "Hellcoal First Edition Series" in 1972, "Hellcoal Playbook Series" in 1973, and "Hellcoal Review," a continuation of the "Hellcoal Annual" in 1978.<cite><a href="Hellcoal Press.html">Hellcoal Press</a></cite>
Herbert Newell Couch (1899-1959), professor of classics, was born in Laurel, Ontario, on December 4, 1899.<cite><a href="Herbert Newell Couch.html">Herbert Newell Couch</a></cite>
He graduated from the University of Toronto in 1924, and received his master’s degree in 1926 and his Ph.D. in 1927, both from Johns Hopkins University.<cite><a href="Herbert Newell Couch.html">Herbert Newell Couch</a></cite>
In 1927-28 he studied at the American Academy in Rome and at the American School of Classical Studies in Athens.<cite><a href="Herbert Newell Couch.html">Herbert Newell Couch</a></cite>
From 1928 to 1930 he was an associate in classics at the University of Illinois.<cite><a href="Herbert Newell Couch.html">Herbert Newell Couch</a></cite>
He came to Brown in 1930 as assistant professor of classics, and was promoted to associate professor in 1938 and professor in 1945.<cite><a href="Herbert Newell Couch.html">Herbert Newell Couch</a></cite>
He served as chairman of the Department of <a href="Classics.html">Classics</a> from 1948 to 1959.<cite><a href="Herbert Newell Couch.html">Herbert Newell Couch</a></cite>
He published "Classical Civilization: Greece "in 1940, and "Beauty and Parting, "translations from the Greek poets, illustrated with his own sketches, in 1945.<cite><a href="Herbert Newell Couch.html">Herbert Newell Couch</a></cite>
His last book, "Cicero on the "<a href="Art.html">Art</a> "of Growing Old, "written while on sabbatical in 1958, was published after his death from a heart attack on June 6, 1959 in Providence.<cite><a href="Herbert Newell Couch.html">Herbert Newell Couch</a></cite>
Mayo Dyer Hersey (1886-1978), professor of engineering, was born in Pawtuxet Neck, Rhode Island, on August 30, 1886.<cite><a href="Hersey, Mayo D..html">Hersey, Mayo D.</a></cite>
Mayo D. Hersey graduated from Colorado College with a bachelor of arts degree in 1907, and earned a bachelor of science degree in mechanical engineering from M.I.T. and a master of arts degree in physics and mathematics from Olivet College, both in 1910.<cite><a href="Hersey, Mayo D..html">Hersey, Mayo D.</a></cite>
From 1910 to 1920 Mayo D. Hersey was a physicist at the National Bureau of Standards, and from 1922 to 1926 chief of the physical laboratory of the U.S. Bureau of Mines in Pittsburgh.<cite><a href="Hersey, Mayo D..html">Hersey, Mayo D.</a></cite>
Mayo D. Hersey also taught at M.I.T. from 1910 to 1922.<cite><a href="Hersey, Mayo D..html">Hersey, Mayo D.</a></cite>
Mayo D. Hersey was a lecturer and research associate at Brown from 1934 to 1936, the first year by invitation and the second under a subsidy from the Standard Oil Development Company.<cite><a href="Hersey, Mayo D..html">Hersey, Mayo D.</a></cite>
For fifteen years Mayo D. Hersey was employed by the National Bureau of Standards, and he also served as a consultant to the Manhattan Project at Columbia during World War II and worked for the Naval Engineering Experiment Station at Annapolis from 1947 to 1957.<cite><a href="Hersey, Mayo D..html">Hersey, Mayo D.</a></cite>
After retirement from government service in 1957 Mayo D. Hersey returned to Brown as visiting professor in engineering.<cite><a href="Hersey, Mayo D..html">Hersey, Mayo D.</a></cite>
In 1965 he was the first recipient of the Mayo D. Hersey award, which continued to be given annually by the American Society of Engineers for "outstanding and continued contributions to the field of lubrication science and engineering."<cite><a href="Hersey, Mayo D..html">Hersey, Mayo D.</a></cite>
Mayo D. Hersey was awarded the American Society of Mechanical Engineers Medal for 1967.<cite><a href="Hersey, Mayo D..html">Hersey, Mayo D.</a></cite>
In 1974, in recognition of his life’s work in tribology and its significance in alleviating the energy shortage, Mayo D. Hersey was awarded a gold medal by a group of British engineering societies.<cite><a href="Hersey, Mayo D..html">Hersey, Mayo D.</a></cite>
Mayo D. Hersey died on September 5, 1978 in Providence.<cite><a href="Hersey, Mayo D..html">Hersey, Mayo D.</a></cite>
John Edward Hill (1864-1934), professor of engineering, was born in New York City on November 9, 1864.<cite><a href="Hill, John E..html">Hill, John E.</a></cite>
John E. Hill received a bachelor of science degree in 1884, a civil engineering degree in 1887, and a master of science degree in 1892, all from Rutgers.<cite><a href="Hill, John E..html">Hill, John E.</a></cite>
John E. Hill received a master of civil engineering degree from Cornell in 1895.<cite><a href="Hill, John E..html">Hill, John E.</a></cite>
John E. Hill began teaching at Cornell in 1890 as instructor in civil engineering.<cite><a href="Hill, John E..html">Hill, John E.</a></cite>
John E. Hill came to Brown in 1894 as instructor in charge of the civil engineering courses, which were being placed in a separate department.<cite><a href="Hill, John E..html">Hill, John E.</a></cite>
John E. Hill was promoted to associate professor in 1895 and to full professor in 1898.<cite><a href="Hill, John E..html">Hill, John E.</a></cite>
In 1905-06 John E. Hill was on leave to work for a New York firm on preliminary studies for the sewage disposal plant in Baltimore.<cite><a href="Hill, John E..html">Hill, John E.</a></cite>
John E. Hill's only book, "Shades and Shadows and Perspectives," was published in 1896.<cite><a href="Hill, John E..html">Hill, John E.</a></cite>
At the time of his death in Providence on November 22, 1934, John E. Hill was the oldest active member of the faculty.<cite><a href="Hill, John E..html">Hill, John E.</a></cite>
Nathaniel Peter Hill (1832-1900), professor of chemistry, was born in Montgomery, New York, on February 18, 1832.<cite><a href="Hill, Nathaniel P..html">Hill, Nathaniel P.</a></cite>
When Nathaniel P. Hill entered Brown in 1853, he had already been managing a farm after the death of his father.<cite><a href="Hill, Nathaniel P..html">Hill, Nathaniel P.</a></cite>
Although Nathaniel P. Hill did not graduate, he was appointed instructor in chemistry applied to the arts in 1858 and professor of chemistry in 1859.<cite><a href="Hill, Nathaniel P..html">Hill, Nathaniel P.</a></cite>
Nathaniel P. Hill worked to secure funds for the chemistry laboratory, which was built in 1862.<cite><a href="Hill, Nathaniel P..html">Hill, Nathaniel P.</a></cite>
Nathaniel P. Hill resigned in 1864 and, after studying mining in Colorado and Europe for three years, he organized the Boston and Colorado Smelting Company in 1867.<cite><a href="Hill, Nathaniel P..html">Hill, Nathaniel P.</a></cite>
Nathaniel P. Hill was mayor of Black Hawk, Colorado, in 1871, a member of the Colorado territorial council in 1872 and 1873, and United States Senator from Colorado from 1879 to 1885.<cite><a href="Hill, Nathaniel P..html">Hill, Nathaniel P.</a></cite>
Brown awarded him a master of arts degree by special vote in 1894.<cite><a href="Hill, Nathaniel P..html">Hill, Nathaniel P.</a></cite>
Nathaniel P. Hill died in Denver on May 22, 1900.<cite><a href="Hill, Nathaniel P..html">Hill, Nathaniel P.</a></cite>
Albert Ford Hinrichs (1899-1978), professor of economics, was born in Brooklyn, New York, on September 20, 1899.<cite><a href="Hinrichs, Albert F..html">Hinrichs, Albert F.</a></cite>
Albert F. Hinrichs attended Cornell University from 1916 to 1920, but received all his degrees from Columbia, the bachelor of arts in 1921, master of arts in 1922, and Ph.D. in 1923.<cite><a href="Hinrichs, Albert F..html">Hinrichs, Albert F.</a></cite>
Albert F. Hinrichs taught at Columbia, and was director of research in the New York State Bureau of Housing and Regional Planning from 1924 to 1926.<cite><a href="Hinrichs, Albert F..html">Hinrichs, Albert F.</a></cite>
Albert F. Hinrichs was assistant professor of economics at Brown from 1926 to 1930, and associate professor from 1930 to 1935.<cite><a href="Hinrichs, Albert F..html">Hinrichs, Albert F.</a></cite>
In the summer of 1930 Albert F. Hinrichs was a member of the first team of American economists to visit the USSR.<cite><a href="Hinrichs, Albert F..html">Hinrichs, Albert F.</a></cite>
In 1932-33 Albert F. Hinrichs traveled to Germany, Austria, Switzerland, Spain, Italy, and the USSR, studying economic conditions.<cite><a href="Hinrichs, Albert F..html">Hinrichs, Albert F.</a></cite>
In September 1934 Hinrichs submitted a provisional resignation to Brown University.<cite><a href="Hinrichs, Albert F..html">Hinrichs, Albert F.</a></cite>
In April 1935 Albert F. Hinrichs was attacked in a confidential bulletin (dutifully reported by the "Providence Journal)" to the Rhode Island Textile Association, warning its members to "treat him as an enemy" in his investigations for his department in Rhode Island.<cite><a href="Hinrichs, Albert F..html">Hinrichs, Albert F.</a></cite>
Albert F. Hinrichs resigned from Brown and remained with the Bureau of Labor Statistics, and from 1948 to 1953 was with the Division of Finance and Fiscal Policy.<cite><a href="Hinrichs, Albert F..html">Hinrichs, Albert F.</a></cite>
Albert F. Hinrichs's later assignments included a post with the Institute of Public and Business Administration at the University of Karachi, principal statistical advisor to the government of Pakistan, professor at Syracuse University, and chief of the statistical advisors to the government of the Republic of China in 1965.<cite><a href="Hinrichs, Albert F..html">Hinrichs, Albert F.</a></cite>
Albert F. Hinrichs died on October 12, 1978 in Washington.<cite><a href="Hinrichs, Albert F..html">Hinrichs, Albert F.</a></cite>
The Laws of 1783 do mention "Bolingbroke on History" as one of the books to be studied in the senior year.<cite><a href="History.html">History</a></cite>
William Gammell, professor of rhetoric, instructed the junior class in modern history in the third term of 1843-44, in accordance with a vote of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> in September 1843, using as a textbook Smythe’s "Lectures on Modern History," which he reported to be satisfactory for the course, although "requiring of the student a vast amount of collateral reading of history."<cite><a href="History.html">History</a></cite>
In 1845-46 he added recitations in history for the senior class, and in the second term of 1847-48 "read lectures on American history to the senior class."<cite><a href="History.html">History</a></cite>
In the second term of 1850-51 there was a newly created chair of history and political economy held by Gammell.<cite><a href="History.html">History</a></cite>
James Burrill Angell 1849 commented on Gammell’s teaching, "His course in history was fuller than that at any other college except Harvard.<cite><a href="History.html">History</a></cite>
Gammell, retiring in 1864, was succeeded by a former pupil, Jeremiah Lewis Diman.<cite><a href="History.html">History</a></cite>
Barnas Sears taught history at the end of the 1863-64 academic year.<cite><a href="History.html">History</a></cite>
In 1871 Diman’s annual report mentioned the increased attention being given to the history of Political Opinion, and in 1872 he announced that the class was responding to a new method of reading widely instead of being confined to a single text and of writing every four weeks an "elaborate historical essay."<cite><a href="History.html">History</a></cite>
In 1877-78 Diman added an elective course for seniors in the history of architecture.<cite><a href="History.html">History</a></cite>
Diman died suddenly at the beginning of the second term of 1880-81.<cite><a href="History.html">History</a></cite>
For the next two years William C. Russell was acting professor of history and political economy, until Elisha Benjamin Andrews was appointed to the professorship in 1882.<cite><a href="History.html">History</a></cite>
John Franklin Jameson was professor of history from 1888 to 1901.<cite><a href="History.html">History</a></cite>
In 1889-90 the Brown University Historical and Economic Association gave two series of public lectures in <a href="Manning Hall.html">Manning Hall</a>, presenting such speakers as Woodrow Wilson, Francis Wayland 1846, and Edward Everett Hale.<cite><a href="History.html">History</a></cite>
In 1891-92 Jameson introduced a new course of practical exercises in American history, in which students did independent work on selected topics, using original materials in local libraries.<cite><a href="History.html">History</a></cite>
Wilfred Harold Munro 1870 was associate professor of history from 1891 to 1899 and professor of European history from 1899 to 1911.<cite><a href="History.html">History</a></cite>
Theodore Collier was associate professor of European history from 1911 to 1917, professor from 1917 to 1923, and professor of history and international relations after 1923.<cite><a href="History.html">History</a></cite>
William MacDonald was professor of American history from 1901 to 1917.<cite><a href="History.html">History</a></cite>
The professors who joined the department in the 1920s and 1930s and their fields were Robert H. George, <a href="English.html">English</a> history, in 1923, Chester Hugo Kirby, modern European history, in 1927, James B. Hedges, American history and economic life, and Sinclair W. Armstrong, modern European history, in 1930. and Carl Bridenbaugh, American colonial history, in 1938.<cite><a href="History.html">History</a></cite>
Hans Rothfels, as visiting professor, taught seventeenth and eighteenth century European history from 1940 to 1946.<cite><a href="History.html">History</a></cite>
Irving A. Leonard was professor of Hispanic civilization from 1940 to 1942, and Edmundo O’Gorman was visiting professor of Latin American history in 1942-43.<cite><a href="History.html">History</a></cite>
After <a href="World War II.html">World War II</a>, the History Department was strengthened by the arrival of several new professors, Edmund S. Morgan in 1946 to teach American colonial history and American social and intellectual history, Barnaby C. Keeney in 1946 as professor of medieval history, and William F. Church in 1947 as professor of seventeenth and eighteenth century European history.<cite><a href="History.html">History</a></cite>
In the next twenty years a distinguished faculty was assembled to teach a much wider range of history, especially when funding received in the late 1960s permitted the department to expand its curriculum, which had been limited to European and American history.<cite><a href="History.html">History</a></cite>
Added to the department faculty were: in 1958, William G. McLoughlin, formerly of the <a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a> Department (American religious and cultural history in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries); in 1959, Donald G. Rohr (nineteenth century German social and intellectual history); in 1964, John L. Thomas (<a href="Civil War.html">Civil War</a> and Reconstruction); in 1965, Bryce Lyon (the Middle Ages); in 1966, Stephen R. Graubard, who had been a visiting professor the year before (Modern British and French history) and Anthony Mohlo (Renaissance and Reformation); in 1968, A.<cite><a href="History.html">History</a></cite>
Hunter Dupree (history of science and technology), Abbott Gleason (Russian history), Barry D. Karl (recent United States history), R. Burr Litchfield (French and Italian economic and social history in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries), Norman Rich (German political and diplomatic history since 1850), and David Underdown (<a href="English.html">English</a> politics in the seventeenth century); in 1970, Howard P. Chudacoff (nineteenth and twentieth century United States urban history), Charles E. Neu (foreign relations of the United States in the late nineteenth and twentieth centuries), Robert C. Padden (the expansion of Europe and Comparative American colonial societies) and Gordon S. Wood (American colonial history); and in 1973, Lewis Perry Curtis (modern British history) and James T. Patterson (American history).<cite><a href="History.html">History</a></cite>
Women professors first joined the department in the 1970s, although Margaret S. Morriss, who was <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> of the Women’s College was given the title of Associate Professor of History in 1923.<cite><a href="History.html">History</a></cite>
Mary Gluck (intellectual history) came in 1978, Naomi Lamoreux (American economic history) in 1979, and Joan Richards (history of science) in 1981.<cite><a href="History.html">History</a></cite>
Patricia Herlihy joined the department as a tenured professor of Russian history in 1986, along with her husband, David Herlihy, who was a professor of medieval history.<cite><a href="History.html">History</a></cite>
<a href="History.html">History</a> of <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a> was established as a department at Brown on January 7, 1947.<cite><a href="History of Mathematics.html">History of Mathematics</a></cite>
Otto Neugebauer, who had come to Brown as professor of mathematics in 1939, was named chairman of the department he had helped to create.<cite><a href="History of Mathematics.html">History of Mathematics</a></cite>
On a visit to the Oriental Institute in Chicago in 1941 he had met Abraham Sachs and had arranged a fellowship to bring Sachs to Brown, where the two scholars, Neugebauer with his mathematical training, and Sachs with his knowledge of ancient languages, combined to publish "Mathematical Cuneiform Texts" in 1945.<cite><a href="History of Mathematics.html">History of Mathematics</a></cite>
In 1953 Sachs received a grant to study astronomical cuneiform tablets in the British Museum, and his work enabled Neugebauer to publish "Astronomical Cuneiform Tests" in 1955, while Sachs published "Late Babylonian Astronomical and Related Texts."<cite><a href="History of Mathematics.html">History of Mathematics</a></cite>
Gerald Toomer came to Brown as a special student in 1959 and joined the department in 1963 to pursue his interests in "the history of mathematics in antiquity and the transmission of these systems through Arabic into medieval Europe."<cite><a href="History of Mathematics.html">History of Mathematics</a></cite>
David Pingree joined the department in 1971.<cite><a href="History of Mathematics.html">History of Mathematics</a></cite>
Sachs became chairman of the department in 1965, Toomer in 1980, and Pingree in 1986.<cite><a href="History of Mathematics.html">History of Mathematics</a></cite>
Following the death of Professor Pingree in November 2005, the department was disbanded.<cite><a href="History of Mathematics.html">History of Mathematics</a></cite>
Its remaining member, Alice Slotsky, a visiting associate professor who taught Akkadian language from 1999 through 2007, was moved temporarily to the <a href="Classics.html">Classics</a> Department in 2006-07.<cite><a href="History of Mathematics.html">History of Mathematics</a></cite>
In the summer of 2007, the Brown University <a href="Library.html">Library</a> acquired Pingree’s personal library, which it now maintains as The Pingree Collection.<cite><a href="History of Mathematics.html">History of Mathematics</a></cite>
Hockey came to the United States in 1895, having been brought here by a group of collegians who had learned the game in Canada.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
Before that time ice polo, which was played with short sticks with rounded ends and a rubber ball, was popular in the United States and had been enjoyed informally by the colleges for several years, and at Brown was taken up in the winter of 1894 by a team which within a week won three games.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
On February 22 a team lead by Malcolm Chace 1896 and Alexander Meiklejohn 1893 (who had already graduated) played two twenty-minute halves against the Cambridge <a href="Polo.html">Polo</a> Team, composed of mostly of Harvard men and considered the champion amateur team of Massachusetts, at the Ten Mile River and won 4-0.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
In the summer of 1894 some American and Canadian tennis players who met at a tournament in Niagara Falls were comparing the Canadian game of ice hockey with the American game of ice polo.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
A series of games was arranged, to be held in Montreal, Ottawa, Kingston, and Toronto during the Christmas vacation of 1894-95.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
The United States team members included Brown men Byron Watson 1897, William Jones 1896, George Matteson 1896, and Alexander Meiklejohn 1893, then a graduate student, Yale men A. C. Foote and Malcolm Chace (who had transferred from Brown to Yale in 1894), F. H. Clarkson of Harvard, and Billy Larned of Columbia.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
In 1896 Harvard defeated Brown 5-4 in ice polo on Spy Pond in Arlington, and the next winter Harvard won again 5-0 in Roger Williams Park.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
On January 19, 1898, on Franklin Field in Boston, the first game of intercollegiate ice hockey in the United States was played by Harvard and Brown.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
Members of the Brown team were Jesse Pevear 1899, Irving Hunt 1899, Charles Cooke 1899, Horace Day ’01, Harris Bucklin ’00, Robert Steere ’01, and Albert Barrows 1898.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
On the occasion of the Brown hockey team’s visit to Harvard’s new Donald C. Watson Rink in 1957, the Brown Club of Boston presented a plaque which commemorated the first game and generously omitted the score.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
In 1901 the Brown team, although twice defeated by Harvard, won all of its league games against Yale, Princeton, Columbia, and the University of Pennsylvania, before losing the two final games for the league championship to Yale.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
Brown’s early success in hockey was short-lived, and the team lost sixteen straight games from 1904 to 1906.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
A report of the renewal of hockey at Brown in the "Boston American" in January 1923, which announced a new Brown team with Quentin Reynolds ’24 as coach, was only a rumor.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
In 1925 the Rhode Island Auditorium, the first indoor artificial ice rink in the area, was built on North Main Street in Providence, sparking a renewed interest in hockey as the Rhode Island Reds competed in the Canadian-American Hockey League.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
Brown students organized class teams which played each other in the new arena, and regained official recognition from the University in 1926, when James H. Gardner, the coach of the Reds, was hired to coach the new Brown team.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
The 1926-27 team lost its first two games, but ended the season with a 4-4 record.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
Jean Dubuc, a former major league baseball pitcher, then general manager of the Reds, coached in 1927-28 (4-8) and 1928-29 (8-5), and was followed in 1929 by Tom Taylor who later became Athletic Director at Brown.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
Taylor’s first two teams, which boasted such players as Philip Lingham ’30, Westcott Moulton ’31, G. Edward Crane ’31, and Alden R. Walls ’31, won eight, lost three, and tied one in 1929-30, and in 1930-31 had a 9-1 record, losing only to Dartmouth.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
Tom’s brother, Bobby Taylor, who played for the Reds, coached for two years before Tom took over again in 1933.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
Another team to remember was that of 1935-36, which, although beset with injuries, managed a season of seven wins and five losses.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
<a href="Art.html">Art</a> Lesieur, who also played for the Reds, coached in 1938-39, but the next year hockey was discontinued again for financial reasons.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
In 1946 an informal team coached by Mazzeo, having been denied the use of the college name, played under the name of "Providence Clippers."<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
Hockey became an officially recognized sport in 1947-48 with Westcott E. S. Moulton 1931, former star player for Brown, as coach.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
In its first official season since 1939, the team won five of its thirteen games.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
The 1948-49 team finished with a 7-7 record.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
One event of the 1948-49 season which gained national attention was Whiston’s face mask.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
In 1949-50 Brown won the Pentagonal league championship with a 7-2 record in league play, losing to Dartmouth and Yale, but did not fare well in the national championship series in Colorado, with losses to Michigan, Colorado College, Boston College, and Boston University.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
Whiston’s awards included first string tournament goalie, most valuable tournament player, All-<a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> first string goalie, first goalie on the Player’s All-Star Hockey Team in 1949-50 and second in 1950-51.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
Brown was second in the Pentagonal league in 1951-52 behind Yale, and lost to Boston University in the New England Playoffs.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
In 1954-55 Whiston coached the team to a 9-8-1 record.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
Whiston’s three-season record from 1952 to 1954 was 28-27-1.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
The opening of <a href="Meehan Auditorium.html">Meehan Auditorium</a> in 1962 greatly improved Brown’s hockey prospects.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
In January 1965 at an invitational tournament held at <a href="Meehan Auditorium.html">Meehan Auditorium</a>, in which the East was represented by Brown and Providence College and the West by Michigan State and Colorado College, Brown was the winner of its own tournament, defeating Michigan 6-2, and Colorado 6-5 in overtime.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
The 1964-65 team, led by All-American Bob Gaudreau ’66, Terry Chapman ’65 and Leon Bryant ’65, won the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> championship and played in the NCAAs in <a href="Meehan Auditorium.html">Meehan Auditorium</a>, losing to Michigan Tech, 0-4, and North Dakota, 5-9.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
The next <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> championship came in 1976 after a thirteen game winning streak, which ended with a 10-4 defeat of Yale and, in the final game of the season, an overtime 8-7 score against Dartmouth.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
In Soares’s final game on February 6, 1974, the team received eleven penalties, injured three Harvard players, and lost the game 6-1, all of which resulted in the replacement of Soares by freshman coach Dick Toomey.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
Coach Toomey’s record from 1974 to 1978 was 73-44-2.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
Goalie Kevin McCabe’s ’77 career record of 43-20 from 1974 to 1977 still stands.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
In December of 1985 the Brown team became the first American hockey team to visit the People’s Republic of China, under the auspices of People to People, an organization which arranges international exchanges of students and athletes.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
Robert Gaudet became coach in 1988.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
His 1990-91 team, after a seven-game winning streak, took the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> title.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
Hockey coaches at Brown have been James H. Gardner in 1926-27, Jean Dubuc from 1927 to 1929, Thomas W. Taylor from 1929 to 1932, Robert Taylor from 1931 to 1933, Thomas W. Taylor again from 1933 to 1938, and Arthur J. Lesieur in 1938-39.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
After seven years of no hockey at Brown and an informal team in 1946-47, the coaches were Westcott E. S. Moulton from 1947 to 1952, Donald Whiston from 1952 to 1955, James Fullerton from 1955 to 1970, J. Allan Soares from 1970 to 1974, Richard Toomey from 1974 to 1978, Paul Schilling from 1978 to 1982, Herbert Hammond from 1982 to 1988, and Bob Gaudet, whose four-year record frow 1988 to 1992 was 15-19-6.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
Women’s ice hockey started at Brown in 1964.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
The Pembroke team, coached by Jerry Crane ’68, lost to the Walpole Brooms by a score of 1-4 in February 1966.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
Two weeks later, on March 6, 1966, an improved Pembroke team lost, 1-2, in a rematch with the Brooms, in a sudden death overtime after the Pembroke goalie was pulled.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
Barbara Jacobskind ’67, who had assisted Sarah Phillips, coached the women players between 1968 and 1970 with help from the men’s hockey team.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
The Pandas ventured into international competition in January 1968 in Kingston, Ontario, where they were overcome, 1-10, by an amateur Canadian team, the Humberside Omegas, and in a second game by the Golden Gals of Queen’s University, 1-4.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
In the Second Annual Loyola University Invitational Hockey Tournament for Women, held in Montreal in January 1970, the Pandas outshot Loyola’s team 30-0 and won 8-0.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
McGill came to Brown to play in 1971.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
In 1972 the Pandas, with Tom Garland ’74 as coach, entered and won the Loyola Invitational Tournament by defeating Cornell 2-1 in overtime and Loyola 5-4 in double overtime, after Susie Barnes ’72 scored the tying goal with only three seconds left in regulation play.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
Marcia Hoffer ’71 coached with Tom Garland in 1972-73.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
In 1974 a team from John Abbott College of Quebec visited Brown, and was twice defeated by the Pandas.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
Steve Shea coached the women’s team from 1973 to 1989 with a record of 120-130-10.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
The Pandas tied with Cornell for the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> championship in 1981 and won it outright in 1985.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
Amy Crafts ’81 was a four-time All-Ivy selection from 1979 to 1982.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
In their first ECAC tournament in 1985 the Pandas lost to the University of New Hampshire in the first round, while Mardie Corcoran ’86 was named ECAC player of the year.<cite><a href="Hockey.html">Hockey</a></cite>
Alexander Lyman Holley (1832-1882), engineer and inventor, was born in Lakeville, Connecticut, on July 20, 1832.<cite><a href="Holley, Alexander Lyman.html">Holley, Alexander Lyman</a></cite>
Alexander Lyman Holley's early fondness for mechanics and his distaste for classical studies made him an ideal applicant to Brown in 1850, just when President <a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Francis Wayland</a>’s new curriculum was introduced, replacing some of the courses in ancient languages with electives including engineering.<cite><a href="Holley, Alexander Lyman.html">Holley, Alexander Lyman</a></cite>
Before entering college Alexander Lyman Holley wrote "An Essay on Pen and Pocket Cutlery," which appeared in the "American Railroad Journal" in 1850.<cite><a href="Holley, Alexander Lyman.html">Holley, Alexander Lyman</a></cite>
Alexander Lyman Holley's oration at the Brown Commencement of 1853 was entitled "The Natural Motors."<cite><a href="Holley, Alexander Lyman.html">Holley, Alexander Lyman</a></cite>
While still an undergraduate Alexander Lyman Holley invented a steam engine cutoff which he described in an article in "Appleton’s Mechanics’ Magazine and Engineers’ Journal" for July 1852.<cite><a href="Holley, Alexander Lyman.html">Holley, Alexander Lyman</a></cite>
In 1857, at the age of twenty-six, Alexander Lyman Holley gave up his paper and went with Colburn to Europe to study European railroads with a view to improving American railways and published a report on this subject.<cite><a href="Holley, Alexander Lyman.html">Holley, Alexander Lyman</a></cite>
Alexander Lyman Holley was engaged as a writer on engineering subjects by Henry J. Raymond, editor of the "New York Times," and contributed about 300 articles to the paper between 1858 and 1875.<cite><a href="Holley, Alexander Lyman.html">Holley, Alexander Lyman</a></cite>
In 1862 Alexander Lyman Holley was sent to Europe to learn about steel armored naval vessels.<cite><a href="Holley, Alexander Lyman.html">Holley, Alexander Lyman</a></cite>
Alexander Lyman Holley published his findings in a valuable text book, "Ordnance and Armament," in 1864.<cite><a href="Holley, Alexander Lyman.html">Holley, Alexander Lyman</a></cite>
Alexander Lyman Holley was able to make improvements in Henry Bessemer’s steel-making process developed several years earlier, and in 1865 was successfully producing steel in Troy, New York.<cite><a href="Holley, Alexander Lyman.html">Holley, Alexander Lyman</a></cite>
Alexander Lyman Holley died on January 20, 1882 in Brooklyn.<cite><a href="Holley, Alexander Lyman.html">Holley, Alexander Lyman</a></cite>
Homecoming for the alumni in the fall was first held in 1935, in response to an expressed need for a time when all alumni could come back to the campus.<cite><a href="Homecoming.html">Homecoming</a></cite>
The idea served its purpose as 800 alumni from the Class of 1867 up to the Class of 1935 congregated at the homecoming dinner.<cite><a href="Homecoming.html">Homecoming</a></cite>
At the second annual Homecoming in 1936 the classroom experience was transferred to Friday morning.<cite><a href="Homecoming.html">Homecoming</a></cite>
In the 1960s Homecoming became a one-day event centering on the football game.<cite><a href="Homecoming.html">Homecoming</a></cite>
Since 1971 the Athletic Hall of Fame has been an added attraction on Friday evening.<cite><a href="Homecoming.html">Homecoming</a></cite>
Honorary degrees were awarded at the first <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> in 1769 "at their own request" to ten gentlemen graduated at other colleges and to eleven others who were recommended for literary merit.<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
Rev. John Ryland of England assisted in identifying prospective honorees by sending lists of names of British clergymen and noted in a communication to James Manning in 1773, "For me to ask any of those gentlemen I nominated in my letter, whether he would please to accept of a degree from your College, would spoil all the honor and delicacy of conferring it.<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
In 1784 the first Doctor of Laws degree was conferred upon Stephen Hopkins, and in 1786 the first Doctor of Divinity degree upon Rev. Samuel Jones.<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
In 1806 an honorary Bachelor of Medicine, apparently the only one ever, was awarded to John McKie.<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
The first honorary Doctor of Medicine degree was conferred upon Solomon Drowne in 1804.<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
During the life of the Medical School, from 1811 to 1828, twenty-two honorary M.D. degrees were conferred.<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
Adoniram Judson 1807 did not even want the honorary Doctor of Divinity degree awarded to him in 1823 and refused to use the title "Doctor."<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
In 1900 the Board of Fellows decreed that recipients of honorary degrees should be present to accept their degrees at the University.<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
Herbert Hoover was in Belgium in 1916 and was unable to be present when his degree was awarded.<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
Reverend Joseph Taylor 1898 was in Chengtu Sze, China, in 1918, when he received an unexpected letter a few days after <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> informing him that he had been awarded an honorary D.D. degree.<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
In 1950 exceptional arrangements were made for the award of an honorary Master of Arts degree to John F. Aiso ’31, who was the highest ranking Japanese-American in the United States Army during <a href="World War II.html">World War II</a>.<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
<a href="President.html">President</a> Wriston, on a visit to the <a href="Los.html">Los</a> Angeles Brown Club meeting on February 14, 1950, called a convocation and presented the degree.<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
At <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> in 1956 <a href="President.html">President</a> Keeney read the name of John Howard Benson, who was to have received an honorary LL.D. degree, but had died in February.<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
Also in 1900 the practice of pronouncing citations on the awarding of honorary degrees was begun by <a href="President.html">President</a> Faunce.<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
His citations were printed in a little book in 1925.<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
Other occasions have been anniversary celebrations, building dedications, special institutes or convocations, or, occasionally the visit of a distinguished person, such as Marshal Ferdinand Foch, who was honored on November 13, 1921.<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
In 1910 the degree of Doctor of Laws was conferred upon Johann Heinrich von Bernstorff, the German ambassador to the United States, "representing the great people to whom we owe in large measure our science, our music, our philosophy, who by chivalrous courtesy and skillful administration is hastening the time of the parliament of man, the federation of the world."<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
At the war-time <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> in 1918, <a href="President.html">President</a> Faunce read the resolution of the Board of Fellows, annulling the earlier action conferring the degree, because, "while he was Ambassador of the Imperial German Government to the United States and while the nations were still at peace, he was guilty of conduct dishonorable alike in a gentleman and a diplomat."<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
The first time that the recipients of honorary degrees were announced in advance of <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> was in 1963, when it was decided that spectators would like to be able to identify them in the procession.<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
In 1969, when an honorary degree was awarded to Henry Kissinger, Special Assistant to <a href="President.html">President</a> Nixon, three-quarters of the graduating class and some of the faculty turned their backs on him in protest of the Vietnam war.<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
The suggestion of a faculty member in 1970 that Brown give an honorary degree to controversial trial lawyer William Kunstler caused another dispute on the campus.<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
As a compromise, the Class of 1970 decided to give its own "honors," which were awarded, mostly "in absentia" to Shirley Chisholm, Ramsey Clark, David Deldlinger, Charles Evers, Roswell Johnson, Robert Lowell, Ralph Nader, Milton Stanzler, Mikis Theodorakis, and Tom Wicker.<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
After 1970 a faculty-student committee was formed for the purpose of suggesting a list of honorees.<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
A reception similar to Kissinger’s greeted Harold Brown, Secretary of Defense, in 1977, when 150 seniors turned their backs as his honorary degree was awarded.<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
Since 1982, Bachelor of <a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a> degrees, "honoris causa," have been awarded from time to time to selected alumni who attended Brown, but did not receive degrees.<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
Six presidents of the United States have received honorary degrees from Brown, although only one of them, George Washington, was in office at the time of the award in 1790.<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
The others were John Adams in 1787, Thomas Jefferson in 1797, Woodrow Wilson in 1903, Herbert Hoover in 1916, and Lyndon Johnson in 1960, all of whom received their degrees before election, and William Howard Taft who received his in 1914 after leaving office.<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
In 1934 Evans asked permission to speak and intoned a short verse, "In this grave presence to record my name/... Like him who in the desert’s awful frame/ Notches his Cockney initials on the Sphinx."<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
Cosby made a few remarks in 1985, but the most unusual acceptance of an honorary degree came from Yale historian Jack H. Hexter.<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
<a href="President.html">President</a> Barnaby C. Keeney, conferring the honorary Litt.D. degree in 1964 and choosing this moment to call to mind a joke among Hexter’s acquaintances about his middle initial which stood for nothing, announced, "Jack "Hernando" Hexter."<cite><a href="Honorary degrees.html">Honorary degrees</a></cite>
Hope College was built in 1822 through the munificence of Nicholas Brown.<cite><a href="Hope College.html">Hope College</a></cite>
In 1821 a committee of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> had been appointed to consider erecting another building and was authorized to select a suitable site and solicit donations.<cite><a href="Hope College.html">Hope College</a></cite>
On January 13, 1823 the committee reported that a lot had been purchased from Nathan Waterman, on which an "elegant brick building ... in length one hundred and twenty feet, width forty feet, four stories high, and containing forty-eight rooms," had been erected.<cite><a href="Hope College.html">Hope College</a></cite>
Once, when the bill went unpaid, the Providence Gas Company removed the meter, and there was no gas until a ball player, crawling under Hope College to retrieve a ball (there was no cellar until 1890) discovered how easy it was to reconnect the severed gas pipes with a rubber hose.<cite><a href="Hope College.html">Hope College</a></cite>
In 1904 showers were installed and the rent was raised.<cite><a href="Hope College.html">Hope College</a></cite>
Hope College was reconstructed in 1959 and rededicated at <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> that year.<cite><a href="Hope College.html">Hope College</a></cite>
John Hope (1868-1936), president of Morehouse College and Atlanta University, was born in Augusta, Georgia, on June 2, 1868, the son of a Scottish father and a black mother.<cite><a href="Hope, John.html">Hope, John</a></cite>
In 1881, when John became thirteen years old and finished eighth grade, he left school and took a job at Lexius Henson’s Ladies’ and Gentlemen’s Restaurant to help support the family, beginning as a wine steward and progressing to keeping the restaurant’s books and selecting and purchasing food.<cite><a href="Hope, John.html">Hope, John</a></cite>
In September 1890 John Hope, twenty-two years old, arrived at Brown and moved into Number 45 Hope College with Frank Trimble, a brilliant black student from Tennessee, the son of a Baptist minister.<cite><a href="Hope, John.html">Hope, John</a></cite>
John Hope wrote for the "Brown Daily Herald" from its beginning in 1891.<cite><a href="Hope, John.html">Hope, John</a></cite>
Desperate for money to pay his debts and continue his education, Hope went to Chicago in 1893, hoping for a job at the World’s Fair, but settling for employment at the Hotel Lexington.<cite><a href="Hope, John.html">Hope, John</a></cite>
His brother, Thomas Hope 1900, who received a bequest from a rich uncle of the same name, had an easier time financially.<cite><a href="Hope, John.html">Hope, John</a></cite>
On Class Day, June 15, 1894, John Hope delivered the class oration, in which he invited his classmates "to observe on this occasion, if we never have before, that to have been at Brown University is to have drunk in the unpretentious, unobtrusive, yet all pervading idea of liberty and brotherhood; and to have acquired a breadth of culture which means the erasure of all lines, be they of race, or sect, or class, and recognizes no claim other than that which highest manhood makes."<cite><a href="Hope, John.html">Hope, John</a></cite>
In 1906 John Hope became president of Morehouse College, which at the time had twenty-one students.<cite><a href="Hope, John.html">Hope, John</a></cite>
At the end of his administration in 1931 there were 359 students and John Hope had begun what was to be a successful campaign to raise $300,000 in endowment to meet a matching offer of that amount from the General Education Board.<cite><a href="Hope, John.html">Hope, John</a></cite>
In 1929 Hope became president of Atlanta University, which had been formed by the affiliation of Atlanta University, Morehouse College for men and Spelman College for women.<cite><a href="Hope, John.html">Hope, John</a></cite>
John Hope died of pneumonia on February 20, 1936.<cite><a href="Hope, John.html">Hope, John</a></cite>
It was the first educational institution sponsored by the Baptists in the American colonies, and was founded in 1756 by Rev. Isaac Eaton under the auspices of the Philadelphia and Charleston Association.<cite><a href="Hopewell Academy.html">Hopewell Academy</a></cite>
Although the academy lasted only until 1767, many Baptist ministers, as well as some who entered other professions, received the rudiments of an education there.<cite><a href="Hopewell Academy.html">Hopewell Academy</a></cite>
Stephen Hopkins (1707-1785), first chancellor of the College, was born in Providence on March 7, 1707.<cite><a href="Hopkins, Stephen.html">Hopkins, Stephen</a></cite>
Stephen Hopkins moved to Scituate as a child and engaged in farming there until he returned to live in Providence in 1742.<cite><a href="Hopkins, Stephen.html">Hopkins, Stephen</a></cite>
Stephen Hopkins began his life of public service in Scituate in 1730 at the age of 23, when he was chosen Town Moderator when Scituate was set off from Providence.<cite><a href="Hopkins, Stephen.html">Hopkins, Stephen</a></cite>
Stephen Hopkins served as town clerk from 1732 to 1741 and president of the town council from 1735 to 1742.<cite><a href="Hopkins, Stephen.html">Hopkins, Stephen</a></cite>
Stephen Hopkins was a member of the Rhode Island House of Representatives from 1732 to 1752 and from 1770 to 1775.<cite><a href="Hopkins, Stephen.html">Hopkins, Stephen</a></cite>
Stephen Hopkins was chief justice of the court of common pleas and chief justice of the Rhode Island Supreme Court, and was elected nine times as governor of Rhode Island between 1755 and 1768.<cite><a href="Hopkins, Stephen.html">Hopkins, Stephen</a></cite>
Hopkins was a delegate to the Colonial Congress in Albany in 1754, the Colonial Congress in Boston in 1757, a member of the Continental Congress from 1774 to 1776, and a signer of the Declaration of Independence.<cite><a href="Hopkins, Stephen.html">Hopkins, Stephen</a></cite>
Horace Mann House at 47-49 George Street was built by Seth Adams as a rental property in 1854.<cite><a href="Horace Mann House.html">Horace Mann House</a></cite>
The house was bought after Adams’ death by Daniel Berkeley Updike and was at one time occupied by Nicholas Brown 1811, American consul in Rome and father of two daughters whose memorials are <a href="Carrie Tower.html">Carrie Tower</a> and the <a href="Annmary Brown Memorial.html">Annmary Brown Memorial</a>.<cite><a href="Horace Mann House.html">Horace Mann House</a></cite>
The University purchased the building from the the estate of Willard S. Achorn in 1938.<cite><a href="Horace Mann House.html">Horace Mann House</a></cite>
It was used as a dormitory and was called Megee House until 1940 when it was named for Horace Mann 1819.<cite><a href="Horace Mann House.html">Horace Mann House</a></cite>
Donald Frederick Hornig, fourteenth president of Brown University, was born in Milwaukee on March 17, 1920.<cite><a href="Hornig, Donald F..html">Hornig, Donald F.</a></cite>
Donald F. Hornig graduated from Harvard in 1940 and earned his Ph.D. in chemistry there in 1943.<cite><a href="Hornig, Donald F..html">Hornig, Donald F.</a></cite>
After this experience Donald F. Hornig came to Brown as assistant professor in 1946, and was promoted to associate professor in 1949.<cite><a href="Hornig, Donald F..html">Hornig, Donald F.</a></cite>
Donald F. Hornig was director of the Metcalf Research Laboratory from 1949 to 1957.<cite><a href="Hornig, Donald F..html">Hornig, Donald F.</a></cite>
Donald F. Hornig was associate dean of the Graduate School in 1951-52 and acting dean in 1952-53.<cite><a href="Hornig, Donald F..html">Hornig, Donald F.</a></cite>
Donald F. Hornig was promoted to full professor in 1951, when he was only 31 years old.<cite><a href="Hornig, Donald F..html">Hornig, Donald F.</a></cite>
In 1957 Donald F. Hornig left for Princeton where he became chairman of the Department of Chemistry and the first to hold the Donner Chair of Science.<cite><a href="Hornig, Donald F..html">Hornig, Donald F.</a></cite>
Donald F. Hornig became a member of the Space Science Board of the National Academy of Sciences in 1959.<cite><a href="Hornig, Donald F..html">Hornig, Donald F.</a></cite>
President Eisenhower appointed him to Donald F. Hornig's Science Advisory Committee in 1960.<cite><a href="Hornig, Donald F..html">Hornig, Donald F.</a></cite>
In 1969-70 Donald F. Hornig was professor of chemistry at the University of Rochester and vice-president of Eastman Kodak Company.<cite><a href="Hornig, Donald F..html">Hornig, Donald F.</a></cite>
When Donald F. Hornig accepted the presidency of Brown in March of 1970, he said, "My father has told me my decision is distinctly irrational.<cite><a href="Hornig, Donald F..html">Hornig, Donald F.</a></cite>
Donald F. Hornig accepted the challenge of the years ahead at his inauguration on October 4, 1970, with these words, "If the private university is to continue as an important social and intellectual force, it must remain firmly in the storm center.<cite><a href="Hornig, Donald F..html">Hornig, Donald F.</a></cite>
Important events during Hornig’s administration were the merger of Brown and Pembroke into a fully coeducational institution in 1971 and the development of a full M.D. degree-granting medical program.<cite><a href="Hornig, Donald F..html">Hornig, Donald F.</a></cite>
Donald F. Hornig sent telegrams to President Nixon, protesting the invasion of Cambodia in 1970 and the bombing of North Vietnam in 1972.<cite><a href="Hornig, Donald F..html">Hornig, Donald F.</a></cite>
Donald F. Hornig suffered a heart attack at his desk on May 24, 1972.<cite><a href="Hornig, Donald F..html">Hornig, Donald F.</a></cite>
