At a news conference held on the day after the ending of the occupation of University Hall by minority students in the spring of 1975, Hornig said, "A generation has grown up believing that anything was possible if you set your mind to it.<cite><a href="Hornig, Donald F..html">Hornig, Donald F.</a></cite>
The worsening financial crisis required severe measures, and in February 1975 Hornig sent to the faculty a "white paper," which recommended selective cutbacks, including a reduction in the size of the faculty by about 15 per cent (75 people) in the next few years.<cite><a href="Hornig, Donald F..html">Hornig, Donald F.</a></cite>
On July 14, 1975, Hornig tendered his resignation and announced his intention of leaving office at the end of June 1976.<cite><a href="Hornig, Donald F..html">Hornig, Donald F.</a></cite>
A symposium honoring Hornig on his 70th birthday was held at Brown on March 17, 1990.<cite><a href="Hornig, Donald F..html">Hornig, Donald F.</a></cite>
Howard Terrace on Meeting Street was dedicated on May 9, 1954, in honor of Edith Lockwood Danielson Howard and her mother, Sarah L. Danielson, both of whom had done much for the College.<cite><a href="Howard Terrace.html">Howard Terrace</a></cite>
Funds for the project were raised by the Rhode Island Society for the Collegiate <a href="Education.html">Education</a> of Women, of which Mrs. Howard had been president from 1922 to 1942.<cite><a href="Howard Terrace.html">Howard Terrace</a></cite>
Mary Elizabeth Sharpe directed the landscaping after the removal of East House and the <a href="East Building.html">East Building</a> from the site in 1952.<cite><a href="Howard Terrace.html">Howard Terrace</a></cite>
David Howell (1747-1824), first professor at the College, was born in Morristown, New Jersey, on January 1, 1747.<cite><a href="Howell, David.html">Howell, David</a></cite>
Before his graduation in 1766, David Howell received a letter from Manning, suggesting that he come to Rhode Island to teach school.<cite><a href="Howell, David.html">Howell, David</a></cite>
In 1768 David Howell was appointed a tutor at the College to assist Manning at a "Salary of Seventy two Pounds Lawful Money," and was "authorized to collect the Tuition Money as it became due as part of his Salary."<cite><a href="Howell, David.html">Howell, David</a></cite>
In 1769 David Howell was appointed professor of mathematics and natural philosophy.<cite><a href="Howell, David.html">Howell, David</a></cite>
David Howell's teaching career ended when college exercises were suspended in 1776 because of the Revolutionary War.<cite><a href="Howell, David.html">Howell, David</a></cite>
In 1779 David Howell resigned, writing to the Corporation, "Having at length given over all hopes of a revival of classical instruction in this College during the continuance of the war, and not feeling disposed so far to take advantage of public munificence as to continue to avail myself of the emoluments of an office without discharging its duties, I have thought fit, not without weighty deliberation, to resign the professorship."<cite><a href="Howell, David.html">Howell, David</a></cite>
In 1793 Howell was appointed professor of law with the duties of taking care of the law books and lecturing at least once a year.<cite><a href="Howell, David.html">Howell, David</a></cite>
David Howell continued his interest in the College, being a member of the Board of Fellows from 1773 to 1824 and secretary of the Corporation from 1780 to 1806.<cite><a href="Howell, David.html">Howell, David</a></cite>
Upon the death of <a href="Manning, James.html">James Manning</a>, Howell served as president "ad interim" until the election of <a href="Maxcy, Jonathan.html">Jonathan Maxcy</a> in 1792.<cite><a href="Howell, David.html">Howell, David</a></cite>
David Howell had been admitted to the bar in 1768.<cite><a href="Howell, David.html">Howell, David</a></cite>
David Howell was a member of the Continental Congress from 1782 to 1785, associate justice of the supreme court of Rhode Island from 1786 to 1787, attorney general in 1789, and judge of the Rhode Island district court from 1812 until his death on July 30, 1824.<cite><a href="Howell, David.html">Howell, David</a></cite>
Howell House at 155 Thayer Street was the third building on the campus to bear the name of the first professor, David Howell, and was the home of the Department of <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a>, which moved there in 1961.<cite><a href="Howell House.html">Howell House</a></cite>
In 1971 the name, Howell House, was applied to the whole house.<cite><a href="Howell House.html">Howell House</a></cite>
A George Street dormitory which had been named Maxcy House (and was renamed Howell House in 1894 after <a href="Maxcy Hall.html">Maxcy Hall</a> was built) was torn down for the building of the John Carter Brown <a href="Library.html">Library</a>.<cite><a href="Howell House.html">Howell House</a></cite>
Samuel Gridley Howe (1801-1876) was born in Boston on November 10, 1801.<cite><a href="Howe, Samuel Gridley.html">Howe, Samuel Gridley</a></cite>
For his offences Samuel Gridley Howe was rusticated, sent to the care of the Reverend Josephus Wheaton of Holliston, Massachusetts, to keep up his studies away from the distractions of college life from mid-March to the first of August 1819, after which he was allowed to return to college.<cite><a href="Howe, Samuel Gridley.html">Howe, Samuel Gridley</a></cite>
After graduation from Brown, Howe went to Harvard and received his M.D. degree in 1824.<cite><a href="Howe, Samuel Gridley.html">Howe, Samuel Gridley</a></cite>
The Greek War of Independence had started in 1821, and Howe, fresh out out Medical School and inspired by Lord Byron, took some fencing lessons and offered himself as surgeon/soldier to the Greek cause.<cite><a href="Howe, Samuel Gridley.html">Howe, Samuel Gridley</a></cite>
Samuel Gridley Howe did not meet Byron, who was ill and died in April 1825.<cite><a href="Howe, Samuel Gridley.html">Howe, Samuel Gridley</a></cite>
He did manage to purchase Byron’s blue-plumed helmet, which occupied a place of honor in the Howe household and was eventually returned to Greece by his daughter, Maud Howe Elliott, in 1926.<cite><a href="Howe, Samuel Gridley.html">Howe, Samuel Gridley</a></cite>
Samuel Gridley Howe returned to America in 1828 to undertake a lecture tour to raise supplies of food and clothing for the Greeks and returned to distribute them, giving them away to the feeble, but requiring the able-bodied to work for them.<cite><a href="Howe, Samuel Gridley.html">Howe, Samuel Gridley</a></cite>
In 1831 Samuel Gridley Howe returned to the United States and was engaged to head the New England Institution for the Education of the Blind which had been chartered two years earlier.<cite><a href="Howe, Samuel Gridley.html">Howe, Samuel Gridley</a></cite>
On his return to Boston in 1832 Samuel Gridley Howe took two blind students into his father’s house and began to instruct them with the aid of his sister.<cite><a href="Howe, Samuel Gridley.html">Howe, Samuel Gridley</a></cite>
The next year Colonel Thomas Handasyd Perkins gave Samuel Gridley Howe's mansion for the school, and in 1839 it was renamed the Perkins Institution for the Blind in his honor.<cite><a href="Howe, Samuel Gridley.html">Howe, Samuel Gridley</a></cite>
Samuel Gridley Howe then turned his attention to the mentally deficient, and in 1848 persuaded the Massachusetts legislature to appropriate "a sum not exceeding $2500 for the purpose of teaching ten idiotic children," selected by the Governor and Council.<cite><a href="Howe, Samuel Gridley.html">Howe, Samuel Gridley</a></cite>
Samuel Gridley Howe was later on the commission to observe the condition of freedmen in the South and the commission sent to Santo Domingo in 1867.<cite><a href="Howe, Samuel Gridley.html">Howe, Samuel Gridley</a></cite>
Samuel Gridley Howe went to Crete with supplies during the insurrection against Turkey in 1871.<cite><a href="Howe, Samuel Gridley.html">Howe, Samuel Gridley</a></cite>
One of Howe’s last communications from Theodore Parker was a Latin epitaph (written when Howe was fifty-seven, so that his age of 77 at death was a conjecture), which translated reads: Howe was 74 when he died in Boston on January 9, 1876.<cite><a href="Howe, Samuel Gridley.html">Howe, Samuel Gridley</a></cite>
On June 4, 1941 a marble and bronze base for the flagpole on the Middle Campus was dedicated as a memorial to him, a gift of the American Hellenic Educational and Progressive Association.<cite><a href="Howe, Samuel Gridley.html">Howe, Samuel Gridley</a></cite>
"Hubris" appeared in 1961, with the expectation of being published "quarterly" by St. David’s Press, with this editorial note: One of the "questions" of the time was an article entitled "The Cuban Achievement," in the first and only issue of the magazine.<cite><a href="Hubris.html">Hubris</a></cite>
Charles Evans Hughes, (1862-1948), Secretary of State and the only Brown man to run for President of the United States, was born in Glens Falls, New York on April 11, 1862, the son of Reverend David C. Hughes, a Baptist clergyman who was born in Wales.<cite><a href="Hughes, Charles Evans 1881.html">Hughes, Charles Evans 1881</a></cite>
Charles Evans 1881 Hughes entered Brown in 1878 after two years at Colgate.<cite><a href="Hughes, Charles Evans 1881.html">Hughes, Charles Evans 1881</a></cite>
Proud of his enterprise, Charles Evans 1881 Hughes wrote to his father, on February 11, 1880:<cite><a href="Hughes, Charles Evans 1881.html">Hughes, Charles Evans 1881</a></cite>
Charles Herman Hunkins (1869-1931), professor of romance languages, was born in Ipswich, Massachusetts, on December 30, 1869.<cite><a href="Hunkins, Charles H..html">Hunkins, Charles H.</a></cite>
At Dummer Academy Charles H. Hunkins was taught by Asa Clinton Crowell 1886.<cite><a href="Hunkins, Charles H..html">Hunkins, Charles H.</a></cite>
Charles H. Hunkins graduated from Dartmouth in 1895.<cite><a href="Hunkins, Charles H..html">Hunkins, Charles H.</a></cite>
After five years as a private tutor Charles H. Hunkins studied and taught in Paris from 1901 to 1903, when he came to Brown as instructor in French.<cite><a href="Hunkins, Charles H..html">Hunkins, Charles H.</a></cite>
Charles H. Hunkins was promoted to assistant professor of Romance languages and literatures in 1911 and associate professor in 1920.<cite><a href="Hunkins, Charles H..html">Hunkins, Charles H.</a></cite>
Charles H. Hunkins loved France, and in 1917, before the United States entered the first World War, he became an ambulance driver with the American Field Service attached to the Second French Army.<cite><a href="Hunkins, Charles H..html">Hunkins, Charles H.</a></cite>
In 1918 Charles H. Hunkins served as American censor at the Bureau de la Presse in Paris.<cite><a href="Hunkins, Charles H..html">Hunkins, Charles H.</a></cite>
Charles H. Hunkins's book, "Favorite French Poems," published in 1924, was used in many classrooms.<cite><a href="Hunkins, Charles H..html">Hunkins, Charles H.</a></cite>
In June 1931 Charles H. Hunkins went back to France on sabbatic leave.<cite><a href="Hunkins, Charles H..html">Hunkins, Charles H.</a></cite>
Before his expected return Charles H. Hunkins died on December 30, 1931 in Ipswich.<cite><a href="Hunkins, Charles H..html">Hunkins, Charles H.</a></cite>
Hunter Laboratory of <a href="Psychology.html">Psychology</a>, named for Walter S. Hunter, chairman of the psychology department from 1936 to 1954, was dedicated on November 1, 1958.<cite><a href="Hunter Laboratory.html">Hunter Laboratory</a></cite>
The building had been made possible through a gift of John D. Rockefeller, Jr. in 1955 and a federal grant of $400,000 from the United States Public Health Service.<cite><a href="Hunter Laboratory.html">Hunter Laboratory</a></cite>
The 228-seat lecture room on the ground floor was named the Leonard Carmichael Auditorium in honor of the department chairman from 1927 to 1936, and the seminar room on the second floor was named in honor of Professor Edmund Burke Delabarre, who founded Brown’s psychology laboratory in 1892.<cite><a href="Hunter Laboratory.html">Hunter Laboratory</a></cite>
Walter Samuel Hunter (1889-1954), professor of psychology, was born in Decatur, Illinois, on March 22, 1889.<cite><a href="Hunter, Walter S..html">Hunter, Walter S.</a></cite>
In 1901, after the death of his mother, he and his brother were taken by their father to live on his grandfather’s farm in Saginaw, Texas, where Walter attended a two-room school until 1905, when he was admitted to the Preparatory School of the Polytechnic College in Fort Worth.<cite><a href="Hunter, Walter S..html">Hunter, Walter S.</a></cite>
On graduation from the University of Texas in 1910, Walter S. Hunter was awarded a scholarship for study at the University of Chicago.<cite><a href="Hunter, Walter S..html">Hunter, Walter S.</a></cite>
Walter S. Hunter's dissertation for his doctorate in 1912 was "Delayed Reaction in Animals and Children."<cite><a href="Hunter, Walter S..html">Hunter, Walter S.</a></cite>
Hunter became an instructor at the University of Texas in 1912, adjunct professor at the University of Kansas in 1916, and the first G. Stanley Hall Professor of Genetic Psychology at Clark University in 1925.<cite><a href="Hunter, Walter S..html">Hunter, Walter S.</a></cite>
In 1936 Walter S. Hunter came to Brown to replace <a href="Carmichael, Leonard.html">Leonard Carmichael</a>.<cite><a href="Hunter, Walter S..html">Hunter, Walter S.</a></cite>
Also in 1936 Hunter was appointed Chairman of the Division of Anthropology and Psychology of the National Research Council.<cite><a href="Hunter, Walter S..html">Hunter, Walter S.</a></cite>
Walter S. Hunter received the Presidential Medal of Merit in 1948.<cite><a href="Hunter, Walter S..html">Hunter, Walter S.</a></cite>
Walter S. Hunter was editor of "Psychological Index" from 1926 to its termination in 1936, and editor of "Psychological Abstracts" from 1926 until 1946, when he resigned because he thought twenty years was long enough for a single editor.<cite><a href="Hunter, Walter S..html">Hunter, Walter S.</a></cite>
Walter S. Hunter resigned the chairmanship of the Psychology Department on his 65th birthday in March 1954.<cite><a href="Hunter, Walter S..html">Hunter, Walter S.</a></cite>
A few months later after returning from a trip Walter S. Hunter suffered a sudden coronary occlusion and died in Providence on August 3, 1954.<cite><a href="Hunter, Walter S..html">Hunter, Walter S.</a></cite>
Remembering him at the dedication of the Hunter Laboratory of Psychology in 1958, <a href="Carmichael, Leonard.html">Leonard Carmichael</a> said, "Dr. Hunter early became one of the leading exponents of an enlightened objective and behavioristic psychology that has now come to be almost synonymous with scientific psychology in this country."<cite><a href="Hunter, Walter S..html">Hunter, Walter S.</a></cite>
Henry Barrett Huntington (1875-1965), professor of English, was born in Malden, Massachusetts, on January 17, 1875.<cite><a href="Huntington, Henry B..html">Huntington, Henry B.</a></cite>
Henry B. Huntington prepared for college at St. Paul’s School in Concord, New Hampshire, and graduated from Harvard in 1897.<cite><a href="Huntington, Henry B..html">Huntington, Henry B.</a></cite>
Henry B. Huntington taught at Dartmouth and Harvard before coming to Brown in 1902 as assistant professor of English.<cite><a href="Huntington, Henry B..html">Huntington, Henry B.</a></cite>
Henry B. Huntington was promoted to associate professor in 1910 and professor in 1929.<cite><a href="Huntington, Henry B..html">Huntington, Henry B.</a></cite>
With George Pierce Baker Henry B. Huntington wrote "Principles of Argumentation," published in 1925.<cite><a href="Huntington, Henry B..html">Huntington, Henry B.</a></cite>
Henry B. Huntington died in Providence on October 14, 1965 at the age of ninety.<cite><a href="Huntington, Henry B..html">Huntington, Henry B.</a></cite>
Sponsored by the Brown Club of New York and the <a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a>, the first awards in 1985 were presented to Richard B. Salomon ’32, and Malcolm Forbes.<cite><a href="Independent Award.html">Independent Award</a></cite>
The awards were presented in 1986 to Thomas J. Watson, Jr. ’37 and Kathryn Sullivan, the first American woman to walk in space, in 1987 to Vernon Alden ’45 and Joseph Paterno ’50, in 1988 to Artemis A. W. Joukowsky ’55, businessman H. Ross Perot, and former president Howard Swearer, in 1989 to <a href="President.html">President</a> Gregorian and Federal Reserve Chairman Paul A. Volcker, in 1990 to Charles C. Tillinghast ’32 and Robert Edward "Ted" Turner ’60, and in 1991 to Apple Computer president Stephen P. Jobs, Marvin Bower ’25, and Nancy L. Buc ’65.<cite><a href="Independent Award.html">Independent Award</a></cite>
An Infirmary was first opened in 1923 in Room 104, Metcalf Laboratory.<cite><a href="Infirmary.html">Infirmary</a></cite>
In the early days of the University sick students were sometimes cared for at the homes of local residents, and in 1872 Charles S. Bradley 1838 had paid for a free bed for Brown University at Rhode Island Hospital.<cite><a href="Infirmary.html">Infirmary</a></cite>
In the fall of 1925 the infirmary moved to a small wooden house at 10 Manning Street between <a href="Marston Hall.html">Marston Hall</a> and the Psi Upsilon house, which housed the offices of Dr. Burgess and Dr. Wilfred Pickles ’18, and provided seven beds where ill students could be kept under observation by a trained nurse at all times.<cite><a href="Infirmary.html">Infirmary</a></cite>
In 1929 the Division of University Health, consisting of three physicians, a graduate nurse in charge of the infirmary and a graduate nurse in charge of the Pembroke infirmary, was organized under the Department of <a href="Biology.html">Biology</a>.<cite><a href="Infirmary.html">Infirmary</a></cite>
In 1939 <a href="Andrews House.html">Andrews House</a> replaced the Manning Street infirmary.<cite><a href="Infirmary.html">Infirmary</a></cite>
The Rhode Island Society for the Collegiate <a href="Education.html">Education</a> of Women equipped an infirmary for the women students in 1922 in <a href="Metcalf Hall.html">Metcalf Hall</a>.<cite><a href="Infirmary.html">Infirmary</a></cite>
In 1939-40 Sarah Doyle House, originally called Bowen House, on the Pembroke campus was opened as a student health center.<cite><a href="Infirmary.html">Infirmary</a></cite>
Doyle House was removed from its location on Bowen Street during the winter of 1945-46 to make room for the construction of <a href="Andrews Hall.html">Andrews Hall</a>.<cite><a href="Infirmary.html">Infirmary</a></cite>
When Champlin Hall was opened in 1960, the Pembroke Health Center was installed on its first floor.<cite><a href="Infirmary.html">Infirmary</a></cite>
Inner-City Teachers of Science (ICTOS) was initiated in 1970 by a group of faculty members from <a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a>, <a href="Biology.html">Biology</a>, <a href="Education.html">Education</a> and <a href="Physics.html">Physics</a>, who met to discuss problems in the education of high school teachers of science.<cite><a href="Inner-City Teachers of Science.html">Inner-City Teachers of Science</a></cite>
The Institute for International Studies was established in September 1986.<cite><a href="Institute for International Studies.html">Institute for International Studies</a></cite>
Swearer announced the preliminary plans for the Institute at the 1985 Opening <a href="Convocation.html">Convocation</a>.<cite><a href="Institute for International Studies.html">Institute for International Studies</a></cite>
Earlier, in 1979, a Council for International Studies had been formed to represent and better coordinate the interests and activities of international studies programs on campus.<cite><a href="Institute for International Studies.html">Institute for International Studies</a></cite>
When the Institute was officially inaugurated on September 25 and 26, 1986, Senator J. William Fulbright made the principal address and received an honorary LL.D. degree, former <a href="President.html">President</a> Jimmy Carter addressed a public meeting on the Green, and two forums were held with Cyrus Vance, Daniel Yankelovich, and Harrison Salisbury among the participants.<cite><a href="Institute for International Studies.html">Institute for International Studies</a></cite>
The Institute was formally dedicated as the Thomas J. Watson, Jr. Institute for International Studies on May 25, 1991, at which time former Soviet foreign minister Eduard Shevardnadze delivered an addresss on international affairs.<cite><a href="Institute for International Studies.html">Institute for International Studies</a></cite>
The Institute for Research in Information and Scholarship (IRIS) was established at Brown in 1983 as a self-supporting institution with William Shipp as director, its goal the finding of new ways for computing technology to help scholars in their daily work.<cite><a href="Institute for Research in Information and Scholarship.html">Institute for Research in Information and Scholarship</a></cite>
In 1986-87 the new technology was applied to two courses, George Landow’s "<a href="English.html">English</a> Literature from 1700 to the Present," and Peter Heywood’s "Plant Cell <a href="Biology.html">Biology</a>."<cite><a href="Institute for Research in Information and Scholarship.html">Institute for Research in Information and Scholarship</a></cite>
"Ishmael," a literary periodical containing fiction, poetry, and graphics was first published by Big Fish Productions in the spring of 1971.<cite><a href="Ishmael.html">Ishmael</a></cite>
Volume 2, appearing in 1972-73, was identified as "the cooperative literary-arts magazine of Brown University and the <a href="Rhode Island School of Design.html">Rhode Island School of Design</a>."<cite><a href="Ishmael.html">Ishmael</a></cite>
"Ishmael" continued publication until 1980.<cite><a href="Ishmael.html">Ishmael</a></cite>
"Issues" came out for the first time on January 4, 1971, a fourteen page journal featuring the new curriculum and resistance to the Vietnam war and including an article by William Stringfellow and a sermon by Daniel Berrigan.<cite><a href="Issues.html">Issues</a></cite>
The November 1972 issue carried the subtitle "The <a href="Brown Review.html">Brown Review</a>," included letters from readers, and introduced departments into its table of contents.<cite><a href="Issues.html">Issues</a></cite>
The magazine appeared irregularly at first, until its editors announced in 1976 that it would "emerge in September as a monthly magazine publishing research, ideas, and creative work from every part of the University."<cite><a href="Issues.html">Issues</a></cite>
In April 1978 "Issues" assumed a tabloid format and a new subtitle, "The Weekly Magazine," as it switched from monthly to weekly publication.<cite><a href="Issues.html">Issues</a></cite>
In October 1978, the magazine was once again a monthly.<cite><a href="Issues.html">Issues</a></cite>
In 1988 "Issues" changed its interest from literary and social commentary to include investigative reporting of the University administration, and in 1989 the administration was surprised and displeased to see confidential material and private communications printed in the magazine, but, after finding no proof that reporters had used unethical methods of obtaining their information, continued to provide financial support.<cite><a href="Issues.html">Issues</a></cite>
In 1897 <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> Louis F. Snow sent to Cambridge, England for a slip of ivy for the seniors to plant beside the newly built <a href="Pembroke Hall.html">Pembroke Hall</a>.<cite><a href="Ivy Day.html">Ivy Day</a></cite>
The next year, the planting of the class ivy on June 13, 1898 was referred to as "a time-honored tradition."<cite><a href="Ivy Day.html">Ivy Day</a></cite>
The program for the Ivy Day exercises at three o’clock on June 19, 1900 listed six speakers, three senior women, one junior, <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> Snow and Acting <a href="President.html">President</a> Benjamin F. Clarke, and included the words to "Pembroke Song" by senior Alice M. Tallman.<cite><a href="Ivy Day.html">Ivy Day</a></cite>
In 1902 the ivy chain was introduced, carried by lines of undergraduates in white dresses, followed by the seniors in caps and gowns.<cite><a href="Ivy Day.html">Ivy Day</a></cite>
The Class of 1918 gave up its Ivy Day exercises in order to use the funds saved for war work.<cite><a href="Ivy Day.html">Ivy Day</a></cite>
In 1927 the senior reception in the evening became the Ivy Night Dance.<cite><a href="Ivy Day.html">Ivy Day</a></cite>
In 1928 Ivy Day and Ivy Night festivities were moved to the new <a href="Alumnae Hall.html">Alumnae Hall</a>.<cite><a href="Ivy Day.html">Ivy Day</a></cite>
The carrying of the ivy chain ended in 1942.<cite><a href="Ivy Day.html">Ivy Day</a></cite>
The Ivy Night dance continued until the late 1960s to be the last dance of the year at <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a>.<cite><a href="Ivy Day.html">Ivy Day</a></cite>
It began in November 1945 with a formal statement by the presidents of the eight colleges of their intention to continue intercollegiate football "in such a way as to maintain the value of the game while keeping it in fitting proportion to the main purposes of academic life."<cite><a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a></cite>
The "Ivy" designation was introduced in the 1930s by sportswriters Stanley Woodward and Caswell Adams and others to describe loosely, and not necessarily in a complimentary manner, the athletic teams of the oldest colleges in the East.<cite><a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a></cite>
In February 1935, Associated Press sports editor Alan Gould wrote, "The so-called ‘Ivy League’ which is in the process of formation among a group of the older Eastern universities now seems to have welcomed Brown into the fold and automatically assumed the proportions of a Big Eight’".<cite><a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a></cite>
In December 1936 the editors of the student newspapers of seven of the eight colleges printed a joint editorial proposing "an Ivy League in fact, not just the one in the minds of sportswriters."<cite><a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a></cite>
However, in the minds of the presidents and athletic directors of the colleges, the differences in the identities of the individual colleges were too great to overcome until the agreement of 1945.<cite><a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a></cite>
A new agreement adopted in July 1952 called for the creation of a Presidents’ Policy Committee.<cite><a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a></cite>
The effect of the agreement was felt when Brown was compelled in 1952 to report a violation of the agreement and to declare fourteen football players ineligible, when it became known that they had not reported receiving unofficial donations toward their tuition from a group of alumni.<cite><a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a></cite>
Beginning in the fall of 1953 all the colleges in the Group were required to play each of the others at least once every five years.<cite><a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a></cite>
In February 1954 the Ivy Group announced that beginning in 1956 the eight colleges would set up schedules for yearly games with the other seven.<cite><a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a></cite>
The agreement signed in 1954 stated, "The Group affirm their conviction that under proper conditions, intercollegiate competition in organized athletics offers desirable development and recreation for players and a healthy focus of collegiate loyalty.<cite><a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a></cite>
Walter Ballou Jacobs (1861-1932), professor of education, was born in Providence on May 5, 1861.<cite><a href="Jacobs, Walter B..html">Jacobs, Walter B.</a></cite>
After graduation from Brown in 1882, Walter B. Jacobs studied for a year at Union Theological School.<cite><a href="Jacobs, Walter B..html">Jacobs, Walter B.</a></cite>
Walter B. Jacobs taught in the classical department of Providence High School from 1883 to 1898, when he was made principal of the new Hope Street High School, a post he held until 1901.<cite><a href="Jacobs, Walter B..html">Jacobs, Walter B.</a></cite>
While Walter B. Jacobs was teaching in the public schools, he was also instructor in pedagogy at Brown from 1893 to 1895 and associate professor from 1895 to 1901.<cite><a href="Jacobs, Walter B..html">Jacobs, Walter B.</a></cite>
As early as 1895 Walter B. Jacobs introduced the idea of practice teaching for graduate students in secondary schools under actual classroom conditions.<cite><a href="Jacobs, Walter B..html">Jacobs, Walter B.</a></cite>
Walter B. Jacobs undertook the reorganization of university extension courses in 1906, and with only four courses attracted 500 registrations.<cite><a href="Jacobs, Walter B..html">Jacobs, Walter B.</a></cite>
Walter B. Jacobs was director of university extension from 1915 until 1931, by which time the registration had climbed to 3400 persons in nearly sixty courses.<cite><a href="Jacobs, Walter B..html">Jacobs, Walter B.</a></cite>
Walter B. Jacobs was director of the School of Education from 1923 to 1927.<cite><a href="Jacobs, Walter B..html">Jacobs, Walter B.</a></cite>
Walter B. Jacobs died in Plattsburgh, New York on June 23, 1932.<cite><a href="Jacobs, Walter B..html">Jacobs, Walter B.</a></cite>
John Franklin Jameson (1859-1937), professor of history, was born in Somerville, Massachusetts, on September 19, 1859.<cite><a href="Jameson, John Franklin.html">Jameson, John Franklin</a></cite>
After graduation in 1879, unable to finance graduate study in Germany as he had hoped, he taught Latin and history in the high school in Worcester, Massachusetts, and then went on to the newly founded Johns Hopkins University to study with Herbert B. Adams and to earn the first doctorate in history from that institution in 1882.<cite><a href="Jameson, John Franklin.html">Jameson, John Franklin</a></cite>
He remained at Johns Hopkins until 1888, teaching history and a new graduate course in historical criticism.<cite><a href="Jameson, John Franklin.html">Jameson, John Franklin</a></cite>
In 1888 John Franklin Jameson came to Brown as professor of history.<cite><a href="Jameson, John Franklin.html">Jameson, John Franklin</a></cite>
In 1891 John Franklin Jameson started the Historical Seminary for graduate students and upperclassmen.<cite><a href="Jameson, John Franklin.html">Jameson, John Franklin</a></cite>
Jameson was active in the American Historical Association from the time of its founding in 1884 and was president of the association in 1907.<cite><a href="Jameson, John Franklin.html">Jameson, John Franklin</a></cite>
In 1895 John Franklin Jameson took part in the founding of the "American Historical Review," and served as its editor from its beginning until 1928 with the exception of 1901 to 1905.<cite><a href="Jameson, John Franklin.html">Jameson, John Franklin</a></cite>
In 1895-96 John Franklin Jameson became the first chairman of the Association of the Historical Manuscripts Commission.<cite><a href="Jameson, John Franklin.html">Jameson, John Franklin</a></cite>
In 1899 John Franklin Jameson delivered at Barnard College a series of lectures which were published as "The American Revolution Considered as a Social Movement" in 1926.<cite><a href="Jameson, John Franklin.html">Jameson, John Franklin</a></cite>
Jameson, through his authorship of an "Open Letter ... to the Corporation of Brown University by Members of the Faculty" on July 31, 1897, initiated a protest by faculty, alumni, and academic persons throughout the country, whose petitions were instrumental in convincing the Corporation to request the withdrawal of his resignation.<cite><a href="Jameson, John Franklin.html">Jameson, John Franklin</a></cite>
When William Rainey Harper offered him the chairmanship of the department of history, Jameson left Brown in 1901 for the University of Chicago, where he remained until 1905.<cite><a href="Jameson, John Franklin.html">Jameson, John Franklin</a></cite>
After the Carnegie Institution of Washington was established in 1902, Jameson approached its director, Daniel Coit Gilman, with a plan which resulted in the establishment of the Institution’s Bureau of Historical Research in 1903.<cite><a href="Jameson, John Franklin.html">Jameson, John Franklin</a></cite>
Another campaign, launched by John Franklin Jameson's article, "Gaps in the Published Records of United States History," in 1906, led to the establishment of the National Historical Records Commission.<cite><a href="Jameson, John Franklin.html">Jameson, John Franklin</a></cite>
John Franklin Jameson participated in the organization in 1919 of the American Council of Learned Societies, and later took part in planning the monumental "Dictionary of American Biography."<cite><a href="Jameson, John Franklin.html">Jameson, John Franklin</a></cite>
In 1927 John Franklin Jameson was named to the newly created chair of American history in the Library of Congress and also chief of the Library’s Manuscript Division.<cite><a href="Jameson, John Franklin.html">Jameson, John Franklin</a></cite>
John Franklin Jameson died in Washington on September 28, 1937.<cite><a href="Jameson, John Franklin.html">Jameson, John Franklin</a></cite>
John Whipple Potter Jenks (1819-1894), director of Brown’s museum of natural history, was born in West Boylston, Massachusetts, on May 1, 1819.<cite><a href="Jenks, John Whipple Potter.html">Jenks, John Whipple Potter</a></cite>
John Whipple Potter Jenks graduated in 1838 and taught in Georgia for a few years.<cite><a href="Jenks, John Whipple Potter.html">Jenks, John Whipple Potter</a></cite>
In 1848, with financial help from his father-in-law, Jenks took over the failing Peirce Academy, which had been founded by his wife’s grandfather, and made it into a outstanding school.<cite><a href="Jenks, John Whipple Potter.html">Jenks, John Whipple Potter</a></cite>
John Whipple Potter Jenks was principal of the academy from 1848 to 1871.<cite><a href="Jenks, John Whipple Potter.html">Jenks, John Whipple Potter</a></cite>
In 1872 John Whipple Potter Jenks came to Brown as curator of the museum, bringing some of his own collections with him.<cite><a href="Jenks, John Whipple Potter.html">Jenks, John Whipple Potter</a></cite>
According to Walter Lee Munro 1879, "What he (Jenks) didn’t know about agriculture would fill a library, but his colleagues knew even less, so, as under the conditions of the land grant for educational purposes from the Federal Government, it was necessary to have a course in agriculture, Professor Jenks was selected to fill the chair."<cite><a href="Jenks, John Whipple Potter.html">Jenks, John Whipple Potter</a></cite>
John Whipple Potter Jenks stayed on the job until his death on September 26, 1894, the particulars of which are described by Walter Lee Munro 1879:<cite><a href="Jenks, John Whipple Potter.html">Jenks, John Whipple Potter</a></cite>
Charles Coffin Jewett (1816-1868), librarian and professor of modern languages, was born in Lebanon, Maine, on August 12, 1816.<cite><a href="Jewett, Charles C..html">Jewett, Charles C.</a></cite>
Charles C. Jewett studied at the Latin School in Salem, Massachusetts, and entered Dartmouth College in 1831.<cite><a href="Jewett, Charles C..html">Jewett, Charles C.</a></cite>
In his sophomore year Charles C. Jewett transferred to Brown, and with other members of the "conscientious class" of 1835, declined to receive his degree in that year, because of the method of distribution of Commencement parts.<cite><a href="Jewett, Charles C..html">Jewett, Charles C.</a></cite>
Charles C. Jewett did accept the degree in 1838.<cite><a href="Jewett, Charles C..html">Jewett, Charles C.</a></cite>
Charles C. Jewett graduated from Andover in 1840, and, intending to be a missionary in the East, was about to embark for foreign study and research, but he missed his ship’s sailing and settled for taking charge of Day’s Academy in Wrentham, Massachusetts, for a year.<cite><a href="Jewett, Charles C..html">Jewett, Charles C.</a></cite>
In 1841 the Joint Library Committee at Brown employed him "to make out a new and improved Catalogue of the University Library, and superintend the printing of the same; and that during the period in which Charles C. Jewett shall be so occupied, he be charged with the ordinary duties of Librarian."<cite><a href="Jewett, Charles C..html">Jewett, Charles C.</a></cite>
The catalogue, when completed in 1843, received favorable notice in the "North American Review" and other publications.<cite><a href="Jewett, Charles C..html">Jewett, Charles C.</a></cite>
Jewett was appointed professor of modern languages and literature, and, in the fall of 1843, was sent to Europe to buy books for the library.<cite><a href="Jewett, Charles C..html">Jewett, Charles C.</a></cite>
Returning in 1845, having bought seven thousand books in French, German, and Italian, and visited the principal libraries of Europe, Charles C. Jewett took up his duties as librarian and professor of modern languages.<cite><a href="Jewett, Charles C..html">Jewett, Charles C.</a></cite>
Jewett’s reputation also won for him appointment as assistant secretary and librarian of the newly founded Smithsonian Institution in 1848.<cite><a href="Jewett, Charles C..html">Jewett, Charles C.</a></cite>
In 1851 the Institution published "Notices of Public Libraries in the United States of America," and Jewett began plans for a compilation of a union catalogue of American libraries and for a method of stereotyped plates (an anticipation of Library of Congress printed cards) for individual titles, from which catalogues of various libraries could be printed.<cite><a href="Jewett, Charles C..html">Jewett, Charles C.</a></cite>
The result of this disagreement was Jewett’s dismissal in July of 1854.<cite><a href="Jewett, Charles C..html">Jewett, Charles C.</a></cite>
At the "Librarian’s Convention" of 1853, Jewett was chosen to preside, and, in opening the proceedings, observed, "We meet for the purpose of seeking mutual instruction and encouragement in the discharge of the quiet and unostentatious labors of our vocation, for which each at his separate post finds perhaps but little sympathy, for which each when at home must derive enthusiasm only from within himself and from the silent masters of his daily communion."<cite><a href="Jewett, Charles C..html">Jewett, Charles C.</a></cite>
True to his vocation, Jewett turned down a college presidency and in 1854 accepted the opportunity to purchase and arrange the books needed for the new Boston Public Library.<cite><a href="Jewett, Charles C..html">Jewett, Charles C.</a></cite>
When the library opened in 1858, Charles C. Jewett was selected as superintendent.<cite><a href="Jewett, Charles C..html">Jewett, Charles C.</a></cite>
Charles C. Jewett's labors were abruptly ended by his sudden death on January 9, 1868 in Braintree, Massachusetts.<cite><a href="Jewett, Charles C..html">Jewett, Charles C.</a></cite>
The <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a>, to clear up any doubt of the intention of the charter, voted on September 6, 1770, "That the Children of Jews may be admitted into this Institution and intirely (sic) enjoy the freedom of their own Religion, without any Constraint or Imposition whatever."<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
The Laws of 1783 prescribed that a student might not "deny the being of a God, the Existence of Virtue and Vice; or that the Books of the old and new Testament are of divine authority," adding "Young gentlemen of the Hebrew nation are to be excepted from this Law, in so far as it relates to the New Testament and its authenticity."<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
Nevertheless, no Jewish student seems to have entered or even applied for over a century, when Israel Strauss of the class of 1894 became Brown’s first known Jewish student.<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
In his reminiscences of Andrews written in 1935, Strauss wrote:  Graduating at the same time as Strauss was Jacob Hayman, who came from Russia and entered Brown as a senior in 1893 after first studying at the University of Vermont.<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
The first of these, the Menorah Society, was dedicated on January 6, 1915 in the <a href="Brown Union.html">Brown Union</a>.<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
The society originated at Harvard in 1906 with sixteen members.<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
The Women’s College had a Menorah Society in 1919.<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
In November 1927 a conference of Eastern and Northeastern Menorah Societies was held at Brown.<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
The Menorah Society disappeared about 1932.<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
In 1916 fifteen students formed a chapter of Phi Epsilon Pi, which was allowed to exist without being recognized as a fraternity and was disbanded in 1919.<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
About 1918 several students formed a small social group which they called the B.G.S.<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
This club, which met at Temple Beth-El, had in 1921 a membership of 75, of whom twenty were Brown students.<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
During the academic year 1918-19 there was established a fraternity named Alpha Sigma Omicron, which met weekly and held initiations and dances, but was not recognized by, nor in fact known to the University administration.<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
On January 1, 1923, at a banquet at the Town House in New York City, a group of Jewish alumni of Brown living in Boston, Providence, and New York formed a fraternal organization, also Alpha Sigma Omicron, the purpose of which was to maintain the interest of its members in the activities of the University and to help further its interests.<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
In 1928 a movement to establish a Jewish fraternity was noted in <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> Otis E. Randall’s report for that year, "we do not want at Brown any fraternity organized on the basis of race or religion.<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
During the Christmas vacation in 1928 nine students went to New York, without informing the administration, and were secretly initiated into the national fraternity Pi Lambda Phi, a non-sectarian fraternity with primarily Jewish members, at the New York University chapter house.<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
The "New York Times," reporting on the incident on April 30, 1929, noted, "The resignations are said to have followed a conference held recently between officials of the University and counsel for the Jewish Fraternity, including Arthur Garfield Hays of New York, at which the university was threatened with prosecution if it persisted in its opposition to the formation of a Jewish Fraternity at Brown."<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
A application for a charter for the Lambda Psi Club, a social club to which Jewish students would be admitted, submitted on March 1, 1929, was deferred while the matter of Pi Lambda Phi was under consideration.<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
A new Tower Club was formed in 1937 by 25 Jewish students who met in <a href="Faunce House.html">Faunce House</a> for the purpose of forming a new fraternal organization.<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
It was dissolved in 1969.<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
The Hillel Foundation of Brown University was established in 1947 after a conference between Dr. Abram L. Sachar, National Hillel Director, and the administration of the University.<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
The first president of the Brown chapter was Melvin Feldman 1945.<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
A newsletter, "Hillel on the Hill," began publication in October 1947.<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
The first issue of a yearbook, "The Hillel Scroll," was published in 1953.<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
In October 1963 the Samuel Rapaporte Jr. Hillel House was opened at 80 Brown Street and named for a Providence benefactor.<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
The chalet-style building, designed by Stone and Carpenter and built in 1878, was first used by Mrs. Caroline Alden, who opened a school for training kindergarten teachers in the Froebel method.<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
In 1971, when Jewish students accounted for twenty-five per cent of the enrollment, Brown appointed the first university-sponsored Jewish chaplain in the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a>.<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
About 1973 a Jewish women’s prayer group was formed at Brown and conducted a women’s service at Hillel every Saturday.<cite><a href="Jews.html">Jews</a></cite>
The John Carter Brown <a href="Library.html">Library</a> houses a collection of Americana which John Carter Brown 1816 began to collect in 1846 when he purchased a small collection of American books from his brother, Nicholas Brown 1811, who was leaving for Rome where he was to be United States Consul General.<cite><a href="John Carter Brown Library.html">John Carter Brown Library</a></cite>
John Carter Brown had already begun to buy books on travel and history in his student days, and in 1841 had inherited the family library from his father.<cite><a href="John Carter Brown Library.html">John Carter Brown Library</a></cite>
He decided to collect books printed before 1801, which, at the time, was a relatively recent date.<cite><a href="John Carter Brown Library.html">John Carter Brown Library</a></cite>
He enlisted the aid of Henry Stevens "of Vermont," a recent Yale graduate and law student, who was willing to travel to Europe in 1845 to buy rare books for Brown and other clients.<cite><a href="John Carter Brown Library.html">John Carter Brown Library</a></cite>
In the next two years his purchases had enlarged Brown’s collection by 1500 titles, many of them from the library of Henri Ternaux-Compans.<cite><a href="John Carter Brown Library.html">John Carter Brown Library</a></cite>
The importance of Mr. Brown’s private collection is attested by this entry in "The Librarian’s Manual" in 1858: "These two <a href="Catalogues.html">Catalogues</a>, (Rich’s Bibliotheca and Supplement), although they contain two thousand five hundred and twenty-three articles, are far from being complete.<cite><a href="John Carter Brown Library.html">John Carter Brown Library</a></cite>
A merchant in Providence, well known to the amateurs of this class of books, has in his own private collection three thousand two hundred and thirty-one early works upon America, published between the years 1700 and 1800, of which one thousand five hundred and twelve are not mentioned by Rich.<cite><a href="John Carter Brown Library.html">John Carter Brown Library</a></cite>
He has also one thousand one hundred and seventy-four works published "previous" to the year 1700, of which five hundred and nine are not mentioned by Ternaux; thus making four thousand four hundred and five separate works relating to America and published previous to the year 1800, of which two thousand and twenty-one were unknown to the eminent American bibliographers, whose catalogues are described in this list."<cite><a href="John Carter Brown Library.html">John Carter Brown Library</a></cite>
In 1865 Bartlett prepared an edition of fifty copies of the first part of "A Catalogue of Books relating to North and South America in the <a href="Library.html">Library</a> of John Carter Brown, of Providence, R.I.," which included selected titles of works printed between 1493 and 1600.<cite><a href="John Carter Brown Library.html">John Carter Brown Library</a></cite>
The second part, for the years 1601 to 1700, was published in 1866, and the third part, from 1701 to 1800, in 1870 and 1871.<cite><a href="John Carter Brown Library.html">John Carter Brown Library</a></cite>
An updated new catalogue with the same subdivisions was issued by his widow between 1875 and 1882.<cite><a href="John Carter Brown Library.html">John Carter Brown Library</a></cite>
After the death of John Carter Brown in 1874, the second printed catalogue of his books, which now numbered about 7,000, was printed in the years 1875 to 1882.<cite><a href="John Carter Brown Library.html">John Carter Brown Library</a></cite>
One of her two sons, Harold Brown 1886, was more interested in his collection of books on the liturgy of the Church of England and the history of that church in America.<cite><a href="John Carter Brown Library.html">John Carter Brown Library</a></cite>
The older son, John Nicholas Brown 1885, inherited his father’s interest in Americana, and it was to him that his mother deeded the collection in 1898.<cite><a href="John Carter Brown Library.html">John Carter Brown Library</a></cite>
John Nicholas had already hired George Parker Winship in 1895 to catalogue the library, and he was also planning to erect a building for the library, when he died on May 1, 1900.<cite><a href="John Carter Brown Library.html">John Carter Brown Library</a></cite>
The trustees chose Brown University, and the bequest was received in September 1901.<cite><a href="John Carter Brown Library.html">John Carter Brown Library</a></cite>
Under an agreement between the trustees of the estate and the University in 1902, the library is owned by the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a>, but has been operated as a semi-autonomous institution with its own administration and funding, under a committee of management.<cite><a href="John Carter Brown Library.html">John Carter Brown Library</a></cite>
At the dedication on May 17, 1904, a procession marched through the <a href="John Nicholas Brown Gate.html">John Nicholas Brown Gate</a>, opened for the first time, and four-year-old John Nicholas Brown presented the keys to the library to <a href="President.html">President</a> Faunce.<cite><a href="John Carter Brown Library.html">John Carter Brown Library</a></cite>
Winship came to the campus with the <a href="Library.html">Library</a>, and by the time of his retirement in 1915, the collection had grown to 30,000 volumes.<cite><a href="John Carter Brown Library.html">John Carter Brown Library</a></cite>
Burrage remained only until 1917, and the library was under the care of Worthington C. Ford, until the appointment of Lawrence C. Wroth in 1923.<cite><a href="John Carter Brown Library.html">John Carter Brown Library</a></cite>
Wroth was librarian until 1957 and was followed by Thomas R. Adams from 1957 to 1983 and Norman Fiering since 1983.<cite><a href="John Carter Brown Library.html">John Carter Brown Library</a></cite>
In the 1980s, the John Carter Brown <a href="Library.html">Library</a> became a center for advanced research in the humanities, and started a fellowship program with stipends for scholars from around the world, who come to do research for several months.<cite><a href="John Carter Brown Library.html">John Carter Brown Library</a></cite>
In the summer of 1989 construction began on a four-level annex at the rear of the building, designed by the Washington firm of Hartman-Cox.<cite><a href="John Carter Brown Library.html">John Carter Brown Library</a></cite>
The John Hay <a href="Library.html">Library</a> was opened in 1910.<cite><a href="John Hay Library.html">John Hay Library</a></cite>
The new library was named for John Hay 1858 at the request of Andrew Carnegie, who contributed half of the $300,000 cost of the building.<cite><a href="John Hay Library.html">John Hay Library</a></cite>
At the dedication of the library on November 11, 1910, eight hundred graduates and guests moved in procession to <a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a> to hear the principal addresses, by James B. Angell 1849 on "Mr. Hay as an Undergraduate," and Elihu Root, Senator from New York, on "Mr. Hay as a Diplomat."<cite><a href="John Hay Library.html">John Hay Library</a></cite>
With room for 300,000 volumes, the building was expected to last for generations, but by 1930 the demand for space for library operations had become so critical that windows were installed in the first floor coat room to provide work space for the clerical staff and new stacks were installed in the top floor exhibition room.<cite><a href="John Hay Library.html">John Hay Library</a></cite>
A bequest of $100,000 for an addition to the library was made by Webster Knight 1876, who died in 1933.<cite><a href="John Hay Library.html">John Hay Library</a></cite>
Architect’s plans were drawn up for a marble addition about the same size as the original building, but what the University was able to afford in 1939 was a new wing, which added seating for 140 readers in two reading rooms, study carrells for fifty students, and stack space for 150,000 volumes.<cite><a href="John Hay Library.html">John Hay Library</a></cite>
Guild 1847.<cite><a href="John Hay Library.html">John Hay Library</a></cite>
When the main library was removed to the new John D. Rockefeller, Jr. <a href="Library.html">Library</a> in 1964, the John Hay <a href="Library.html">Library</a> retained the special collections and provided temporary quarters for the Physical Sciences <a href="Library.html">Library</a> until the Sciences <a href="Library.html">Library</a> was built.<cite><a href="John Hay Library.html">John Hay Library</a></cite>
The John Hay <a href="Library.html">Library</a> was completely renovated under the direction of Shepley, Bulfinch, Richardson and Abbott, and was rededicated on September 21, 1981.<cite><a href="John Hay Library.html">John Hay Library</a></cite>
On December 9, 1903, her son, four-year-old John Nicholas Brown (later Secretary of the Brown <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a>), dressed in a coat of white fur, with a large white hat and golden curls, took part in the cornerstone laying with a trowel of ivory and silver and added much to the spirit of the occasion by spontaneously turning to the students, shouting "Rah, rah, rah, Brown!"<cite><a href="John Nicholas Brown Gate.html">John Nicholas Brown Gate</a></cite>
The gate was opened for the first time to admit the procession at the dedication of the John Carter Brown <a href="Library.html">Library</a> on May 17, 1904.<cite><a href="John Nicholas Brown Gate.html">John Nicholas Brown Gate</a></cite>
Albert Bushnell Johnson (1869-1941), professor of romance languages and literature, was born in Fairton, New Jersey, on January 20, 1869.<cite><a href="Johnson, Albert Bushnell.html">Johnson, Albert Bushnell</a></cite>
Albert Bushnell Johnson graduated from Brown in 1891 and received his master’s degree in 1892.<cite><a href="Johnson, Albert Bushnell.html">Johnson, Albert Bushnell</a></cite>
From 1892 to 1898 Albert Bushnell Johnson was instructor in French and Spanish.<cite><a href="Johnson, Albert Bushnell.html">Johnson, Albert Bushnell</a></cite>
Albert Bushnell Johnson was named assistant professor in 1899 and associate professor in 1903.<cite><a href="Johnson, Albert Bushnell.html">Johnson, Albert Bushnell</a></cite>
Albert Bushnell Johnson studied Spanish and Portuguese in South America in 1924, and had thought of offering courses in business Portuguese.<cite><a href="Johnson, Albert Bushnell.html">Johnson, Albert Bushnell</a></cite>
Albert Bushnell Johnson spent his entire teaching career at Brown, retiring in 1934.<cite><a href="Johnson, Albert Bushnell.html">Johnson, Albert Bushnell</a></cite>
Albert Bushnell Johnson died on February 21, 1941 in Sarasota, Florida.<cite><a href="Johnson, Albert Bushnell.html">Johnson, Albert Bushnell</a></cite>
Samuel Jones (1735-1814), prominent member of the Philadelphia Association instrumental in the founding of the College, was born in 1735 and educated at Hopewell Academy.<cite><a href="Jones, Samuel.html">Jones, Samuel</a></cite>
Samuel Jones died on February 7, 1814.<cite><a href="Jones, Samuel.html">Jones, Samuel</a></cite>
Adoniram Judson (1788-1850), the first foreign missionary from America, was born in Malden, Massachusetts, on August 9, 1788, the son of a Congregational minister.<cite><a href="Judson, Adoniram.html">Judson, Adoniram</a></cite>
Adoniram Judson entered Brown at sixteen and he graduated in 1807 as valedictorian of his class.<cite><a href="Judson, Adoniram.html">Judson, Adoniram</a></cite>
In college Adoniram Judson came under the influence of a free-thinking upperclassman, Jacob Eames 1806, and chose to deliver at Commencement "An Oration of Free Enquiry."<cite><a href="Judson, Adoniram.html">Judson, Adoniram</a></cite>
Adoniram Judson closed his school in August of 1808 and set out on a tour of the northern states.<cite><a href="Judson, Adoniram.html">Judson, Adoniram</a></cite>
Adoniram Judson was determined to become a missionary, and in January 1811 embarked for England to gain the help of the London Missionary Society.<cite><a href="Judson, Adoniram.html">Judson, Adoniram</a></cite>
Back in the United States, Adoniram Judson married Ann Hasseltine on February 5, 1812, and the next day was ordained at Salem with his fellow missionaries, Samuel Newell, Samuel Nott, Gordon Hall and Luther Rice.<cite><a href="Judson, Adoniram.html">Judson, Adoniram</a></cite>
The Judsons were expelled from Calcutta by the British East India Company and traveled to Rangoon, arriving in July of 1813.<cite><a href="Judson, Adoniram.html">Judson, Adoniram</a></cite>
Six years after Adoniram Judson's arrival, the first Christian service in the Burmese language was held in April 1819 and the first Burman convert was baptized in June.<cite><a href="Judson, Adoniram.html">Judson, Adoniram</a></cite>
In 1823 the Judsons and Dr. Price, who had joined the mission, left Rangoon for Ava, where the missionaries had been given land by the King.<cite><a href="Judson, Adoniram.html">Judson, Adoniram</a></cite>
Mrs. Judson and one remaining child died in 1826.<cite><a href="Judson, Adoniram.html">Judson, Adoniram</a></cite>
In 1835 Judson completed his translation of the Bible into Burmese, and he married Sarah Hall Boardman, widow of missionary George Dana Boardman.<cite><a href="Judson, Adoniram.html">Judson, Adoniram</a></cite>
Judson, now living in Maulmein, began work on a Burmese-English dictionary, which he interrupted in 1845 in order to take his wife on a trip to the United States for her health.<cite><a href="Judson, Adoniram.html">Judson, Adoniram</a></cite>
In November 1845 Adoniram Judson visited Brown, where he met with the members of the Philermenian Society and the Society for Missionary Inquiry.<cite><a href="Judson, Adoniram.html">Judson, Adoniram</a></cite>
Adoniram Judson had been awarded an honorary Doctor of Divinity of degree by the University in 1823, but refused to use that title.<cite><a href="Judson, Adoniram.html">Judson, Adoniram</a></cite>
In June 1846, Adoniram Judson married Emily Chubbuck, a poetess who used the name of Fanny Forester, with whom he returned to Rangoon and then to Maulmein.<cite><a href="Judson, Adoniram.html">Judson, Adoniram</a></cite>
On April 3, 1850 Adoniram Judson was carried aboard the "Aristide Marie," following directions of his doctor that a long sea voyage was the only hope of regaining his health.<cite><a href="Judson, Adoniram.html">Judson, Adoniram</a></cite>
Four sons and a stepson came to Brown University; Adoniram Brown Judson 1859, a physician, Elnathan Judson 1859, a journalist, Edward Judson 1862, a Baptist clergyman, Henry Hall Judson 1864, who left Brown for Williams College, and George Dana Boardman 1852, a Baptist minister.<cite><a href="Judson, Adoniram.html">Judson, Adoniram</a></cite>
Judson House was the name given in 1946 to the building at 117-119 George Street in honor of Adoniram Judson 1807.<cite><a href="Judson House.html">Judson House</a></cite>
In 1954 the house at 62 College Street was named Judson House.<cite><a href="Judson House.html">Judson House</a></cite>
The sophomores were no longer included after the spring of 1820 in what now became the "Junior Exhibition."<cite><a href="Junior and Senior Exhibitions.html">Junior and Senior Exhibitions</a></cite>
Originally held in the chapel, after 1806 these presentations often took place in the Town House, which stood at the southwest corner of Benefit and College Streets.<cite><a href="Junior and Senior Exhibitions.html">Junior and Senior Exhibitions</a></cite>
It was built for the First Congregational Church in 1723 and served as the Town House from 1795 to 1860, when it was torn down.<cite><a href="Junior and Senior Exhibitions.html">Junior and Senior Exhibitions</a></cite>
The end of the senior exhibitions was noted in an obituary of the Senior Exhibition which appeared in the first "<a href="Brown Paper.html">Brown Paper</a>" in November 1857, with these lines: In 1870 the "<a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a>" called for an end to the "obsolete custom," by which the exhibition speakers were obliged to appear in a gown in which "the speaker can make no gesture with grace, nor even stand at ease."<cite><a href="Junior and Senior Exhibitions.html">Junior and Senior Exhibitions</a></cite>
The last junior exhibition was held in 1882.<cite><a href="Junior and Senior Exhibitions.html">Junior and Senior Exhibitions</a></cite>
The next year the appointed members of the Class of 1884, protesting the current practice of appointing the speakers, which, according to the "<a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a>," was based "almost entirely according to the marks obtained in "all" the studies during the entire previous course, slightly modified by particular excellence in speaking and writing," asked to be excused from speaking.<cite><a href="Junior and Senior Exhibitions.html">Junior and Senior Exhibitions</a></cite>
Junior Burials of textbooks began in the 1850s, the earliest known program being for the year 1853.<cite><a href="Junior Burials.html">Junior Burials</a></cite>
Such a burial is nicely described in the diary of William Dearth 1855: Before the cremations ended in the 1880s, the students had turned their condemnation to their teachers as well as to the textbook authors.<cite><a href="Junior Burials.html">Junior Burials</a></cite>
On the other hand, when the junior class announced early in 1872 its plan to cremate <a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a> as a change from the usual victims, the professor of chemistry, John Howard Appleton, was upset by this choice, because he feared injury to the reputation of the department and his text-book.<cite><a href="Junior Burials.html">Junior Burials</a></cite>
In 1883 the juniors chose to bury the marking system, a decision for which they were commended by the "<a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a>" for continuing the tradition of the burial without the "former offensive features" which disturbed the faculty.<cite><a href="Junior Burials.html">Junior Burials</a></cite>
In 1885 the Junior Burial was replaced by a pow-wow at Messer Field, at which the main event was the mock wedding of Captain John Smith and Pocahontas.<cite><a href="Junior Burials.html">Junior Burials</a></cite>
Junior week was first held in 1901.<cite><a href="Junior Week.html">Junior Week</a></cite>
The events that were announced on the program were a concert by the Glee, Banjo, and Mandolin Clubs and an informal dance on Monday, April 8; a reception for the junior class and a theatre party at Keith’s Opera House on Tuesday, April 9, and on Wednesday, April 10, a special chapel service, a baseball game with Andover, and the junior promenade, which had first been held in 1898.<cite><a href="Junior Week.html">Junior Week</a></cite>
The 1909 Junior Week was especially exciting.<cite><a href="Junior Week.html">Junior Week</a></cite>
In 1918 Junior Week began on Thursday with a baseball game between the staffs of the "Brown Daily Herald" and the "<a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a>," followed by a tea dance, a Sock and Buskin performance, and dancing at the <a href="Brown Union.html">Brown Union</a>.<cite><a href="Junior Week.html">Junior Week</a></cite>
Another activity of the junior class was the "Junior Cruise," on Narragansett Bay, a rowdy affair which prompted Donald Jackson ’09 to compose a song: Junior Week, which in the beginning started on Monday, began on Wednesday from 1905 until 1910, then on Thursday until 1928, and after that on Friday, as all the activities moved to the weekend.<cite><a href="Junior Week.html">Junior Week</a></cite>
In 1928 the prom was moved from <a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a> to the new Gymnasium.<cite><a href="Junior Week.html">Junior Week</a></cite>
The prom was broadcast from the Gym in 1932 by the ten radio stations of the Yankee Network.<cite><a href="Junior Week.html">Junior Week</a></cite>
In 1935 the prom again changed location to the Biltmore Hotel.<cite><a href="Junior Week.html">Junior Week</a></cite>
After <a href="World War II.html">World War II</a> the junior prom, sponsored by the class and the <a href="Brown Key.html">Brown Key</a>, was revived in 1948.<cite><a href="Junior Week.html">Junior Week</a></cite>
The J. Walter Wilson Laboratory was dedicated on October 5, 1962, when the cornerstone bearing the expired date 1961 was laid under rainy skies.<cite><a href="J. Walter Wilson Laboratory.html">J. Walter Wilson Laboratory</a></cite>
The building was enlarged in 1983, when the two million dollar Sol Koffler wing, named for its donor, the founder of the American Luggage Works, added 10,000 square feet of space.<cite><a href="J. Walter Wilson Laboratory.html">J. Walter Wilson Laboratory</a></cite>
(Israel James) Kapstein (1904-1983), professor of English, was born in Fall River, Massachusetts, on January 16, 1904.<cite><a href="Kapstein, I. J..html">Kapstein, I. J.</a></cite>
I. J. Kapstein lived in Boston before moving to Providence in 1916.<cite><a href="Kapstein, I. J..html">Kapstein, I. J.</a></cite>
After graduation in 1926 Kapstein, with a literary career in mind, moved to New York and worked for Alfred Knopf, publisher, where he was assigned to the textbook department.<cite><a href="Kapstein, I. J..html">Kapstein, I. J.</a></cite>
In 1928 I. J. Kapstein was brought back to Brown by invitation of Professor <a href="Benedict, George W..html">George W. Benedict</a> as an instructor in English, and earned his master’s degree in 1929 and his Ph.D. in 1931.<cite><a href="Kapstein, I. J..html">Kapstein, I. J.</a></cite>
In 1937 I. J. Kapstein's story, "Song the Summer Evening Sings," was published in "Story" magazine.<cite><a href="Kapstein, I. J..html">Kapstein, I. J.</a></cite>
I. J. Kapstein's 1941 novel, "Something of a Hero," made the best-seller list.<cite><a href="Kapstein, I. J..html">Kapstein, I. J.</a></cite>
I. J. Kapstein collaborated with Rabbi William Braude on a translation of "Peskta de-Rab Kahana: R. Kahana’s Compilation of Discourses for Sabbaths and Festal Days," which was awarded the 1976 National Jewish Book Award.<cite><a href="Kapstein, I. J..html">Kapstein, I. J.</a></cite>
In August 1960 I. J. Kapstein was sent by the State Department to Vietnam where he taught American literature at the University of Saigon until the following April.<cite><a href="Kapstein, I. J..html">Kapstein, I. J.</a></cite>
When the Graduate Center was opened in 1968, a honey locust tree was planted in his honor, a gift of Sol B. Korn ’65 as a tribute to his "friend and counselor," crediting Kapstein, with whom he had never taken a course, as being the person who encouraged him when he thought of dropping out of college.<cite><a href="Kapstein, I. J..html">Kapstein, I. J.</a></cite>
In 1982 a former student, Marvyn Carton ’38, established the Israel J. Kapstein Professorship.<cite><a href="Kapstein, I. J..html">Kapstein, I. J.</a></cite>
Kapstein retired in 1969.<cite><a href="Kapstein, I. J..html">Kapstein, I. J.</a></cite>
I. J. Kapstein died in Providence on August 5, 1983.<cite><a href="Kapstein, I. J..html">Kapstein, I. J.</a></cite>
The three-story house was built in 1884 by Nancy Bishop, sister-in-law of the wife of General Ambrose Burnside.<cite><a href="Kassar House.html">Kassar House</a></cite>
It was bought in 1920 by Frank Hinckley and in 1930 by William Viall.<cite><a href="Kassar House.html">Kassar House</a></cite>
Brown acquired the building in 1977 from Richmond Viall, and named it Edward W. Kassar House in recognition of funds given in 1982 by Raymond E. Kassar ’48.<cite><a href="Kassar House.html">Kassar House</a></cite>
The Gould Laboratory, a brick addition to Kassar House was built in 1982 to provide a much needed computer science laboratory including the Foxboro Auditorium with tiers of worktables and computers for classroom instruction in computer science.<cite><a href="Kassar House.html">Kassar House</a></cite>
In 1990 the two existing sections were integrated into a new <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a> Building designed by William Kite Architects, and Gould Laboratory, no longer a laboratory, became Gould Annex.<cite><a href="Kassar House.html">Kassar House</a></cite>
Barnaby Conrad Keeney (1914-1980), twelfth president of Brown University, was born in Halfway, Oregon, on October 17, 1914.<cite><a href="Keeney, Barnaby C..html">Keeney, Barnaby C.</a></cite>
After graduation from Hartford High School, Keeney went to the University of North Carolina where he participated in track, majored in history, and graduated at the top of his class in 1936.<cite><a href="Keeney, Barnaby C..html">Keeney, Barnaby C.</a></cite>
Barnaby C. Keeney went on to Harvard, where he earned his master’s degree in 1937 and his Ph.D. in 1939 and taught until 1941.<cite><a href="Keeney, Barnaby C..html">Keeney, Barnaby C.</a></cite>
After the war Barnaby C. Keeney studied for a year in Europe with a John Simon Guggenheim Post Service Fellowship, then came to Brown in 1946 as assistant professor of history.<cite><a href="Keeney, Barnaby C..html">Keeney, Barnaby C.</a></cite>
Barnaby C. Keeney became Dean of the Graduate School in 1949, when he was only 34, and in 1951 he was promoted to full professor.<cite><a href="Keeney, Barnaby C..html">Keeney, Barnaby C.</a></cite>
Barnaby C. Keeney took a leave of absence in 1951 to work for the Central Intelligence Agency.<cite><a href="Keeney, Barnaby C..html">Keeney, Barnaby C.</a></cite>
Barnaby C. Keeney returned to the deanship of the Graduate School and in 1952 added the position of Acting Dean of the College to his duties.<cite><a href="Keeney, Barnaby C..html">Keeney, Barnaby C.</a></cite>
In 1953 Barnaby C. Keeney became Dean of the College, and two years later was chosen to succeed <a href="Wriston, Henry M..html">Henry Wriston</a> as president of Brown.<cite><a href="Keeney, Barnaby C..html">Keeney, Barnaby C.</a></cite>
New buildings were added: the West Quadrangle in 1957, Hunter Laboratory for psychology in 1958, the Computing Laboratory in 1961, Prince Engineering Laboratory in 1962, the J. Walter Wilson Biology Laboratory in 1962; Meehan Auditorium in 1961; the <a href="Rockefeller, John D., Jr..html">John D. Rockefeller</a>, Jr. Library in 1963, the Barus and Holley Building in 1963, and on the Pembroke Campus, two dormitory complexes, Champlin and Morriss Halls and Emery and Woolley Halls.<cite><a href="Keeney, Barnaby C..html">Keeney, Barnaby C.</a></cite>
In 1970 Barnaby C. Keeney became chief executive officer of the Consortium of Universities of Washington, D.C., and in June 1971 he became the first president of Claremont Graduate School.<cite><a href="Keeney, Barnaby C..html">Keeney, Barnaby C.</a></cite>
Barnaby C. Keeney retired in 1976 and came back to live in Little Compton.<cite><a href="Keeney, Barnaby C..html">Keeney, Barnaby C.</a></cite>
Barnaby C. Keeney died on June 18, 1980 in Providence.<cite><a href="Keeney, Barnaby C..html">Keeney, Barnaby C.</a></cite>
In 1978 it was revealed that Keeney had worked for the Central Intelligence Agency while he was president of Brown.<cite><a href="Keeney, Barnaby C..html">Keeney, Barnaby C.</a></cite>
The Keeney Quadrangle, known at first as the West Quadrangle, was opened in 1957.<cite><a href="Keeney Quadrangle.html">Keeney Quadrangle</a></cite>
Construction had begun in December 1955, and Barnaby Keeney said in his speech at the laying of the cornerstone (which he identified as "my first cornerstone"), that this quadrangle was designed "to provide a dignified and happy home for the independents," the <a href="Wriston Quadrangle.html">Wriston Quadrangle</a> having already taken care of fraternity housing.<cite><a href="Keeney Quadrangle.html">Keeney Quadrangle</a></cite>
The quadrangle was named Keeney Quadrangle at exercises held on the Saturday before <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> in 1982.<cite><a href="Keeney Quadrangle.html">Keeney Quadrangle</a></cite>
<a href="Williams, William.html">William Williams</a> Keen (1837-1932), eminent surgeon, member of the class of 1859 and long-term member of the Corporation, was born in Philadelphia on January 19, 1837.<cite><a href="Keen, William Williams.html">Keen, William Williams</a></cite>
At Commencement in 1859 William Williams Keen was valedictorian of his class and delivered an oration on "The Scholar’s Sentiment of Veneration for the Past."<cite><a href="Keen, William Williams.html">Keen, William Williams</a></cite>
William Williams Keen remained at Brown for an extra year to prepare for his medical studies and entered Jefferson Medical College in Philadelphia in 1860.<cite><a href="Keen, William Williams.html">Keen, William Williams</a></cite>
William Williams Keen had his practical training in surgery with Brinton, who recommended him as surgeon for the Fifth Massachusetts Regiment in July 1861.<cite><a href="Keen, William Williams.html">Keen, William Williams</a></cite>
William Williams Keen cared for the wounded at the Battle of Bull Run and was discharged soon afterward when the enlistment of his regiment expired in September 1861.<cite><a href="Keen, William Williams.html">Keen, William Williams</a></cite>
William Williams Keen finished his course at Jefferson Medical College and received his M.D. degree in March of 1862.<cite><a href="Keen, William Williams.html">Keen, William Williams</a></cite>
In May 1863 William Williams Keen was sent to Philadelphia to be resident surgeon in special wards in the Christian Street Hospital devoted to the treatment of injuries and diseases of the nerves.<cite><a href="Keen, William Williams.html">Keen, William Williams</a></cite>
There William Williams Keen was associated with Dr. S. Weir Mitchell and Dr. George R. Morehouse, with whom he wrote "Gunshot Wounds and Other Injuries of Nerves," published in 1864.<cite><a href="Keen, William Williams.html">Keen, William Williams</a></cite>
In 1864 William Williams Keen went to Europe and studied in Paris and Berlin.<cite><a href="Keen, William Williams.html">Keen, William Williams</a></cite>
William Williams Keen returned in 1866 to lecture at Jefferson Medical College and to conduct the Philadelphia School of Anatomy.<cite><a href="Keen, William Williams.html">Keen, William Williams</a></cite>
Dr. Wilfred Pickles ’18, in a biographical sketch in the "Rhode Island Medical Journal" in January 1927, when Keen was ninety, noted that "after five years in practice, in the month of June, he saw a total of seven patients, of whom three were charity cases, two disappeared and paid him nothing, and the other two paid him one dollar each."<cite><a href="Keen, William Williams.html">Keen, William Williams</a></cite>
When Joseph Lister came to Philadelphia in 1876, Keen heard his views on antisepsis in surgery and was one of the first American surgeons to adopt Lister’s system.<cite><a href="Keen, William Williams.html">Keen, William Williams</a></cite>
Keen was professor of artistic anatomy at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts from 1876 to 1890, professor of surgery at the Women’s Medical College from 1884 to 1889, and professor of surgery at Jefferson Medical College from 1889 to 1907.<cite><a href="Keen, William Williams.html">Keen, William Williams</a></cite>
William Williams Keen was said to have performed the first successful operation for brain tumor in 1887, and in 1893 he assisted Dr. Joseph D. Bryant in operating on President Grover Cleveland.<cite><a href="Keen, William Williams.html">Keen, William Williams</a></cite>
The story of the operation became known in 1917, after which Keen wrote a little book, "The Surgical Operations on President Cleveland in 1893."<cite><a href="Keen, William Williams.html">Keen, William Williams</a></cite>
He also wrote many medical articles and, with Dr. J. William White, edited the first surgical textbook in the English language in 1892.<cite><a href="Keen, William Williams.html">Keen, William Williams</a></cite>
William Williams Keen published "Animal Experimentation and Medical Progress" in 1914, and "I Believe in God and in Evolution" in 1921.<cite><a href="Keen, William Williams.html">Keen, William Williams</a></cite>
William Williams Keen began his monumental "Surgery," which contained articles by about a hundred American and British authors, in 1905 and issued the eighth and final volume in 1921.<cite><a href="Keen, William Williams.html">Keen, William Williams</a></cite>
William Williams Keen retired in 1907.<cite><a href="Keen, William Williams.html">Keen, William Williams</a></cite>
In 1908 William Williams Keen became president of the American Philosophical Society.<cite><a href="Keen, William Williams.html">Keen, William Williams</a></cite>
William Williams Keen was a trustee of Brown from 1873 to 1895 and a fellow from 1895 to 1932.<cite><a href="Keen, William Williams.html">Keen, William Williams</a></cite>
William Williams Keen was awarded the Susan Colver Rosenberger medal in 1925.<cite><a href="Keen, William Williams.html">Keen, William Williams</a></cite>
William Williams Keen died on June 7, 1932.<cite><a href="Keen, William Williams.html">Keen, William Williams</a></cite>
Hunter Kellenberger (1904-1975), professor of French and chairman of the Modern Languages Division, was born in Newark, Ohio, on February 14, 1904.<cite><a href="Kellenberger, Hunter.html">Kellenberger, Hunter</a></cite>
Hunter Kellenberger graduated from Kenyon College in 1925 and received his M.A. and Ph.D. degrees from Princeton in 1928 and 1931.<cite><a href="Kellenberger, Hunter.html">Kellenberger, Hunter</a></cite>
Hunter Kellenberger was master in Latin and Greek at the DeVeau School from 1925 to 1927, and master in French at the Northwood School from 1931 to 1933.<cite><a href="Kellenberger, Hunter.html">Kellenberger, Hunter</a></cite>
In 1933-34 Hunter Kellenberger was Traveling Fellow of the American Council of Learned Societies.<cite><a href="Kellenberger, Hunter.html">Kellenberger, Hunter</a></cite>
Hunter Kellenberger taught at Princeton before coming to Brown in 1938 as assistant professor of French.<cite><a href="Kellenberger, Hunter.html">Kellenberger, Hunter</a></cite>
Hunter Kellenberger was promoted to associate professor in 1946 and professor in 1947.<cite><a href="Kellenberger, Hunter.html">Kellenberger, Hunter</a></cite>
