Hunter Kellenberger was chairman of the Division of Modern Languages from 1946 until 1960, when the division was divided into separate departments, after which he was chairman of the Department of French Studies from 1960 to 1964 and chairman of the new Council on Languages and Literature from 1960 to 1963.<cite><a href="Kellenberger, Hunter.html">Kellenberger, Hunter</a></cite>
Hunter Kellenberger published "The Influence of Accentuation on French Word Order" in 1932, and contributed the chapter on "Modern Languages" in the "Case for Basic Education," published in 1958.<cite><a href="Kellenberger, Hunter.html">Kellenberger, Hunter</a></cite>
Hunter Kellenberger was chairman of the first Northeast Conference on the Teaching of Foreign Languages, which was held at Brown in 1954.<cite><a href="Kellenberger, Hunter.html">Kellenberger, Hunter</a></cite>
Hunter Kellenberger retired in 1971 and died on April 12, 1975 in Providence.<cite><a href="Kellenberger, Hunter.html">Kellenberger, Hunter</a></cite>
William Herbert Kenerson (1873-1966), was born in Fall River, Massachusetts, on December 9, 1873.<cite><a href="Kenerson, William H..html">Kenerson, William H.</a></cite>
In 1896 William H. Kenerson was awarded the first M.E.<cite><a href="Kenerson, William H..html">Kenerson, William H.</a></cite>
William H. Kenerson earned a master of arts degree from Harvard in 1906.<cite><a href="Kenerson, William H..html">Kenerson, William H.</a></cite>
When the separate Department of Civil and Mechanical Engineering and the course in electrical engineering were merged in a single division of engineering in 1916, Kenerson was named chairman, which he remained for twenty-five years.<cite><a href="Kenerson, William H..html">Kenerson, William H.</a></cite>
After retirement in 1941 William H. Kenerson became executive secretary of the Division of Engineering and Industrial Research of the National Research Council, and was later appointed executive secretary of the Council and also of the National Academy of Sciences, the first to hold both positions at the same time.<cite><a href="Kenerson, William H..html">Kenerson, William H.</a></cite>
William H. Kenerson died in Providence on September 22, 1966, at the age of 92.<cite><a href="Kenerson, William H..html">Kenerson, William H.</a></cite>
Robert Webb "Pat" Kenny (1902-1983), professor of English, was born in Somerville, Massachusetts, on February 10, 1902.<cite><a href="Kenny, Robert W..html">Kenny, Robert W.</a></cite>
Having chosen Brown, Kenny stayed for the rest of his life except for two years, 1927 to 1929, as instructor in English at Northeastern University, one year, 1934-1935, as an exchange professor at the American College in Sofia, Bulgaria, and two stints of military service during World War II and the Korean conflict.<cite><a href="Kenny, Robert W..html">Kenny, Robert W.</a></cite>
Robert W. Kenny graduated in 1925 and earned his master’s in 1926 and his Ph.D. in 1934.<cite><a href="Kenny, Robert W..html">Kenny, Robert W.</a></cite>
Robert W. Kenny returned as associate professor in 1928, and was named full professor in 1951.<cite><a href="Kenny, Robert W..html">Kenny, Robert W.</a></cite>
Robert W. Kenny was recalled to active duty from 1951 to 1953.<cite><a href="Kenny, Robert W..html">Kenny, Robert W.</a></cite>
In 1960 Robert W. Kenny retired from the Army Reserve with the rank of brigadier general and commander of the 76th division.<cite><a href="Kenny, Robert W..html">Kenny, Robert W.</a></cite>
Robert W. Kenny was appointed dean of students in 1946, then dean of the college from 1947 to 1951 and acting dean of Pembroke in 1961 after the retirement of <a href="Lewis, Nancy Duke.html">Nancy Duke Lewis</a>.<cite><a href="Kenny, Robert W..html">Kenny, Robert W.</a></cite>
Robert W. Kenny retired in 1971.<cite><a href="Kenny, Robert W..html">Kenny, Robert W.</a></cite>
Robert W. Kenny died in Providence on June 12, 1983.<cite><a href="Kenny, Robert W..html">Kenny, Robert W.</a></cite>
When the University conferred an honorary degree upon him in 1975, the citation noted, "Few men have borne more titles, worn more hats, than you.<cite><a href="Kenny, Robert W..html">Kenny, Robert W.</a></cite>
Hugh Baxter Killough (1892-1976), professor of economics, was born in Waco, Texas, on December 30, 1892.<cite><a href="Killough, Hugh B..html">Killough, Hugh B.</a></cite>
Hugh B. Killough graduated from Texas A and M in 1916, and after service as a lieutenant in the Air Service during World War I, he earned a master of science degree from the University of Wisconsin in 1920.<cite><a href="Killough, Hugh B..html">Killough, Hugh B.</a></cite>
Hugh B. Killough taught briefly at the University of Minnesota and was an economist with Michigan State College extension service before earning a Ph.D. degree at Columbia in 1925.<cite><a href="Killough, Hugh B..html">Killough, Hugh B.</a></cite>
Hugh B. Killough became assistant professor of economics at Brown in 1924, and was promoted to associate professor in 1927 and professor in 1931.<cite><a href="Killough, Hugh B..html">Killough, Hugh B.</a></cite>
Hugh B. Killough wrote two books, "Raw Materials of Industrialism" in 1929 and "Economics of International Trade" in 1948, with his wife, who was a professor of economics at Wellesley College.<cite><a href="Killough, Hugh B..html">Killough, Hugh B.</a></cite>
In 1943-44 Hugh B. Killough was an economist with the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.<cite><a href="Killough, Hugh B..html">Killough, Hugh B.</a></cite>
From 1944 to 1946 Hugh B. Killough was chief of the Employment and Occupational Outlook Branch of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.<cite><a href="Killough, Hugh B..html">Killough, Hugh B.</a></cite>
In 1950-51 Hugh B. Killough was an economist with the Economic Cooperation Administration in Taiwan, and in 1952 he conducted a study of economic and political conditions in Indonesia.<cite><a href="Killough, Hugh B..html">Killough, Hugh B.</a></cite>
Hugh B. Killough was chairman of the Department of Economics from 1953 to 1957 and retired in 1959.<cite><a href="Killough, Hugh B..html">Killough, Hugh B.</a></cite>
Hugh B. Killough died on December 13, 1976 in Stuart, Florida.<cite><a href="Killough, Hugh B..html">Killough, Hugh B.</a></cite>
Lida Shaw King (1868-1932), third dean of the Women’s College, was born in Boston on September 15, 1868.<cite><a href="King, Lida Shaw.html">King, Lida Shaw</a></cite>
She was the daughter of the Reverend Henry Melville King, pastor of the First Baptist Church in Providence from 1891 to 1906, and was descended through her paternal grandmother from John Alden of Plymouth and the Mayflower.<cite><a href="King, Lida Shaw.html">King, Lida Shaw</a></cite>
Lida Shaw King graduated from Vassar College in 1890, and received a master of arts degree from Brown in 1894, the first year that any degrees were awarded to women.<cite><a href="King, Lida Shaw.html">King, Lida Shaw</a></cite>
Lida Shaw King returned to Vassar for more graduate study and taught classical subjects there from 1894 to 1897.<cite><a href="King, Lida Shaw.html">King, Lida Shaw</a></cite>
In 1897-98 Lida Shaw King was a graduate student at Radcliffe College.<cite><a href="King, Lida Shaw.html">King, Lida Shaw</a></cite>
Between 1898 and 1902 Lida Shaw King was at the Packer Collegiate Institute, first as a teacher of ancient languages and later as director of the Department of Latin and Greek.<cite><a href="King, Lida Shaw.html">King, Lida Shaw</a></cite>
Lida Shaw King studied at the American School of Archaeology in Athens as a Bryn Mawr Fellow in 1899 and again as the Agnes Hoppin Memorial Fellow in 1900.<cite><a href="King, Lida Shaw.html">King, Lida Shaw</a></cite>
Lida Shaw King and fellow student Ida Thallon were the first women to excavate on the mainland of Greece, and their work at the Nymph’s Cave at Vari resulted in an article, "Vases, Terra-Cotta Statuettes, Bronzes and Miscellaneous Objects Found in the Cave at Vari," which appeared in the "Journal of the Archaeological Institute" in 1903.<cite><a href="King, Lida Shaw.html">King, Lida Shaw</a></cite>
Lida Shaw King was inaugurated as third dean of the Women’s College on October 25, 1905, following the resignation of Anne Crosby Emery.<cite><a href="King, Lida Shaw.html">King, Lida Shaw</a></cite>
Lida Shaw King's title was changed in 1909 to professor of classical literature and archaeology.<cite><a href="King, Lida Shaw.html">King, Lida Shaw</a></cite>
In "Topics of the Month" in the June 1909 "Brown Alumni Monthly" it was recorded: Lida Shaw King had considerable success in raising the separate funds of the college from $66,031 in 1905 to $358,971 in 1921.<cite><a href="King, Lida Shaw.html">King, Lida Shaw</a></cite>
Enrollment increased from 196 in 1905 to 420 in 1922.<cite><a href="King, Lida Shaw.html">King, Lida Shaw</a></cite>
The Lida Shaw King Decennial Fund "for the entertainment of guests, and the maintenance of the social and cultural side of college life," established by the Rhode Island Society for the Collegiate Education of Women had become available in 1919-20.<cite><a href="King, Lida Shaw.html">King, Lida Shaw</a></cite>
During Lida Shaw King's absence from the College in 1920-21 former dean Anne Crosby Emery Allinson returned as acting dean.<cite><a href="King, Lida Shaw.html">King, Lida Shaw</a></cite>
In 1922 Miss King resigned.<cite><a href="King, Lida Shaw.html">King, Lida Shaw</a></cite>
Reports that Lida Shaw King planned to return to Greece to continue her studies concealed the unfortunate illness which continued until her death in Providence on January 10, 1932.<cite><a href="King, Lida Shaw.html">King, Lida Shaw</a></cite>
Of her resignation in 1922, President Faunce said in his annual report, "Lida Shaw King plans to return to Greece to pursue her favorite studies in classical archaeology."<cite><a href="King, Lida Shaw.html">King, Lida Shaw</a></cite>
John Kingsbury (1801-1874), secretary of the Corporation and school principal, was born in South Coventry, Connecticut, on May 26, 1801.<cite><a href="Kingsbury, John.html">Kingsbury, John</a></cite>
When he entered Brown in 1822, Kingsbury had already been teaching in district schools for five years while working on his father’s farm.<cite><a href="Kingsbury, John.html">Kingsbury, John</a></cite>
John Kingsbury continued teaching to make ends meet while he studied, and after graduating in 1826 he conducted with G. A. Dewitt the private Providence high school.<cite><a href="Kingsbury, John.html">Kingsbury, John</a></cite>
In 1828 John Kingsbury opened a department for girls, which became the Young Ladies’ High School, at which the students learned not the usual feminine accomplishments, but Latin, mathematics and science.<cite><a href="Kingsbury, John.html">Kingsbury, John</a></cite>
In 1848 the building, which was old-fashioned and poorly ventilated, was replaced by a new school house designed by <a href="Tefft, Thomas A..html">Thomas A. Tefft</a> 1851 (who was then a freshman at Brown), built at the same location.<cite><a href="Kingsbury, John.html">Kingsbury, John</a></cite>
This building was to become in 1892 the first home of the Women’s College at 235 Benefit Street.<cite><a href="Kingsbury, John.html">Kingsbury, John</a></cite>
In 1830 Kingsbury was among the founding members of the American Institute of Instruction, of which he was later vice-president for many years and president in 1856 and 1857.<cite><a href="Kingsbury, John.html">Kingsbury, John</a></cite>
John Kingsbury was also president of the Rhode Island Institute of Instruction from its inception in 1845 until 1856.<cite><a href="Kingsbury, John.html">Kingsbury, John</a></cite>
John Kingsbury was named a trustee of the University in 1844, served on the committee to raise $125,000 for President Wayland’s "New System" in 1850, was appointed a fellow of the University in 1853 and at the same time appointed Secretary of the Corporation.<cite><a href="Kingsbury, John.html">Kingsbury, John</a></cite>
John Kingsbury retired from his position at the Young Ladies’ High School in 1858, and was commissioner of public instruction in Rhode Island until 1859.<cite><a href="Kingsbury, John.html">Kingsbury, John</a></cite>
From that date until 1874 John Kingsbury was president of the Washington Insurance Company.<cite><a href="Kingsbury, John.html">Kingsbury, John</a></cite>
John Kingsbury died in Providence on December 21, 1874.<cite><a href="Kingsbury, John.html">Kingsbury, John</a></cite>
Chester Hugo Kirby (1899-1975), professor of history, was born in Sioux Falls, South Dakota, on September 12, 1899.<cite><a href="Kirby, Chester H..html">Kirby, Chester H.</a></cite>
Chester H. Kirby received his A.B. degree in 1921 and his A.M. in 1923, both from the State University of Iowa, and went on the receive a second A.M. degree in 1924 and a Ph.D. in 1929 from Harvard.<cite><a href="Kirby, Chester H..html">Kirby, Chester H.</a></cite>
Chester H. Kirby came to Brown as instructor in history in 1927, and was promoted to assistant professor in 1932, associate professor in 1945, and professor in 1950.<cite><a href="Kirby, Chester H..html">Kirby, Chester H.</a></cite>
Chester H. Kirby's book, "The English Country Gentleman, a Study of Nineteenth Century Types" was published in 1937.<cite><a href="Kirby, Chester H..html">Kirby, Chester H.</a></cite>
Chester H. Kirby retired in 1964 and died on March 5, 1975 at his home in Thetford, Vermont.<cite><a href="Kirby, Chester H..html">Kirby, Chester H.</a></cite>
Paul Norman Kistler (1894-1962), professor of engineering, was born in Steelton, Pennsylvania, on July 20, 1894.<cite><a href="Kistler, Paul N..html">Kistler, Paul N.</a></cite>
Paul N. Kistler received the degree of bachelor of science in mechanical engineering from Pennsylvania State College in 1920, and the master of science in mechanical engineering from Lehigh University in 1924.<cite><a href="Kistler, Paul N..html">Kistler, Paul N.</a></cite>
Paul N. Kistler worked for Bethlehem Steel Company and Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania before coming to Brown as assistant professor of engineering in 1926.<cite><a href="Kistler, Paul N..html">Kistler, Paul N.</a></cite>
Paul N. Kistler was named associate professor in 1935.<cite><a href="Kistler, Paul N..html">Kistler, Paul N.</a></cite>
From 1945 until his retirement in 1960 Paul N. Kistler was professor of mechanical engineering.<cite><a href="Kistler, Paul N..html">Kistler, Paul N.</a></cite>
Paul N. Kistler was also called upon by the State of Rhode Island in 1936 to travel to Canton, Ohio, to inspect the new voting machines ordered for the state.<cite><a href="Kistler, Paul N..html">Kistler, Paul N.</a></cite>
Paul N. Kistler retired in 1960, and died two years later on November 17, 1962 in Providence.<cite><a href="Kistler, Paul N..html">Kistler, Paul N.</a></cite>
Harry Lyman Koopman (1860-1937), librarian from 1893 to 1930, was born in Freeport, Maine, on July 1, 1860.<cite><a href="Koopman, Harry Lyman.html">Koopman, Harry Lyman</a></cite>
Harry Lyman Koopman graduated from Colby College in 1880.<cite><a href="Koopman, Harry Lyman.html">Koopman, Harry Lyman</a></cite>
In 1881, after a brief teaching experience, Harry Lyman Koopman went to work at the Astor Library.<cite><a href="Koopman, Harry Lyman.html">Koopman, Harry Lyman</a></cite>
In 1883 Harry Lyman Koopman became a cataloger at Cornell University, a job he subsequently held at Columbia, Rutgers and the University of Vermont.<cite><a href="Koopman, Harry Lyman.html">Koopman, Harry Lyman</a></cite>
In 1893 Harry Lyman Koopman received a master of arts degree from Harvard and was appointed Librarian of Brown University, a position from which he retired thirty-seven years later.<cite><a href="Koopman, Harry Lyman.html">Koopman, Harry Lyman</a></cite>
During Harry Lyman Koopman's tenure, the size of the library grew from 80,000 to 400,000, and the <a href="Hay, John.html">John Hay</a> Library was built in 1910.<cite><a href="Koopman, Harry Lyman.html">Koopman, Harry Lyman</a></cite>
Well known in the library world, Koopman was elected president of the American Library Association in 1928.<cite><a href="Koopman, Harry Lyman.html">Koopman, Harry Lyman</a></cite>
Harry Lyman Koopman was opposed to censorship, and, in 1929, delivered an outspoken commentary on the policy of the Customs Department in barring works by such authors as Rousseau, Balzac and Bocaccio: "Every college in the country will have to ‘shut up shop’ if this continues.<cite><a href="Koopman, Harry Lyman.html">Koopman, Harry Lyman</a></cite>
Harry Lyman Koopman wrote his first published poem in 1875, and later contributed prose and poetry to the college monthly at Columbia.<cite><a href="Koopman, Harry Lyman.html">Koopman, Harry Lyman</a></cite>
Harry Lyman Koopman's first book, an ode to Farragut entitled "The Great Admiral," was published in 1883.<cite><a href="Koopman, Harry Lyman.html">Koopman, Harry Lyman</a></cite>
Harry Lyman Koopman's other books of poetry included "Morrow Songs" in 1898, "At the Gates of the Century" in 1905, "The Librarian and the Desert" in 1908, and "Hesperia, an American National Poem" in two volumes, 1919-1924.<cite><a href="Koopman, Harry Lyman.html">Koopman, Harry Lyman</a></cite>
In 1895 Harry Lyman Koopman published the "Historical Catalogue of Brown University."<cite><a href="Koopman, Harry Lyman.html">Koopman, Harry Lyman</a></cite>
Harry Lyman Koopman was associate editor of the "Brown Alumni Monthly" from 1906 to 1917.<cite><a href="Koopman, Harry Lyman.html">Koopman, Harry Lyman</a></cite>
Harry Lyman Koopman was named professor of bibliography in 1908.<cite><a href="Koopman, Harry Lyman.html">Koopman, Harry Lyman</a></cite>
In October 1930 Harry Lyman Koopman began to write a regular column, "Planets and Stars," for the "Providence Journal."<cite><a href="Koopman, Harry Lyman.html">Koopman, Harry Lyman</a></cite>
Harry Lyman Koopman died on December 28, 1937.<cite><a href="Koopman, Harry Lyman.html">Koopman, Harry Lyman</a></cite>
Harry Lyman Koopman's last "Planets and Stars" column was published posthumously on January 1, 1938.<cite><a href="Koopman, Harry Lyman.html">Koopman, Harry Lyman</a></cite>
Edward T. Kornhauser (1925-1988), professor of engineering, was born in Louisville, Kentucky, on June 30, 1925.<cite><a href="Kornhauser, Edward T..html">Kornhauser, Edward T.</a></cite>
Edward T. Kornhauser served in the Navy during World War II, then received his bachelor of electrical engineering degree from Cornell in 1945, and his master of science and Ph.D. degrees, both from Harvard, in 1947 and 1949.<cite><a href="Kornhauser, Edward T..html">Kornhauser, Edward T.</a></cite>
Edward T. Kornhauser came to Brown as assistant professor of physics in 1951, and was assistant professor of engineering in 1955-56, after which he became associate professor of engineering in 1956, and professor in 1963.<cite><a href="Kornhauser, Edward T..html">Kornhauser, Edward T.</a></cite>
In 1959-60 Edward T. Kornhauser was a visiting lecturer and NATO Fellow at the University of Bristol in England.<cite><a href="Kornhauser, Edward T..html">Kornhauser, Edward T.</a></cite>
Edward T. Kornhauser died in Providence on November 17, 1988.<cite><a href="Kornhauser, Edward T..html">Kornhauser, Edward T.</a></cite>
Charles August Kraus (1875-1967), professor of chemistry, was born in Knightsville, Indiana, on August 15, 1875.<cite><a href="Kraus, Charles A..html">Kraus, Charles A.</a></cite>
In 1893 Charles A. Kraus went to the University of Kansas, where he studied electrical engineering and took his only formal chemistry course in his freshman year.<cite><a href="Kraus, Charles A..html">Kraus, Charles A.</a></cite>
Charles A. Kraus graduated from the University of Kansas in 1898, a year late in graduating because of a course he had declined to take.<cite><a href="Kraus, Charles A..html">Kraus, Charles A.</a></cite>
Charles A. Kraus did work in physics at John Hopkins in 1899-1900 and at the University of Kansas in 1900-01, and became instructor in physics at the University of California in 1901, remaining until 1904.<cite><a href="Kraus, Charles A..html">Kraus, Charles A.</a></cite>
From 1904 to 1908 Charles A. Kraus was a research assistant in physical chemistry at M.I.T., where he received his Ph.D. degree in 1908, after which he was a research associate until 1912, and associate professor of physical chemical research from 1912 to 1914.<cite><a href="Kraus, Charles A..html">Kraus, Charles A.</a></cite>
Charles A. Kraus became professor of chemistry and director of the chemical laboratory at Clark University in 1914.<cite><a href="Kraus, Charles A..html">Kraus, Charles A.</a></cite>
In 1923-24 Charles A. Kraus was a lecturer at Brown and the following year became professor of chemistry and director of the chemical laboratories.<cite><a href="Kraus, Charles A..html">Kraus, Charles A.</a></cite>
Charles A. Kraus was awarded the William H. Nichols Medal of the New York section of the American Chemical Society in 1924, the Theodore William Richards Medal of the Chicago section in 1935 and the Northeastern section in 1936, the Willard Gibbs Medal of the Chicago section in 1935, the Franklin Medal in 1938 and the Priestly Medal in 1950.<cite><a href="Kraus, Charles A..html">Kraus, Charles A.</a></cite>
In 1948 Charles A. Kraus was awarded the Navy Distinguished Public Service Award, the highest honor which the Navy can confer upon a civilian.<cite><a href="Kraus, Charles A..html">Kraus, Charles A.</a></cite>
A portrait of Kraus by William Dacey was dedicated in 1950 and hangs in the auditorium of the Metcalf Research Laboratory.<cite><a href="Kraus, Charles A..html">Kraus, Charles A.</a></cite>
His retirement in 1946 made very little difference in his life style, on which Charles A. Kraus commented, "you do your work, but you don’t get paid for it."<cite><a href="Kraus, Charles A..html">Kraus, Charles A.</a></cite>
Charles A. Kraus's last research paper was published in 1967.<cite><a href="Kraus, Charles A..html">Kraus, Charles A.</a></cite>
Kraus died on June 27, 1967 in East Providence at the age of 91.<cite><a href="Kraus, Charles A..html">Kraus, Charles A.</a></cite>
Reinhard Kuhn (1930-1980), professor of French, was born in Berlin, Germany, on September 6, 1930.<cite><a href="Kuhn, Reinhard.html">Kuhn, Reinhard</a></cite>
Reinhard Kuhn received his bachelor of arts degree in 1952, his master of arts in 1954, and his Ph.D. in 1957, all from Princeton.<cite><a href="Kuhn, Reinhard.html">Kuhn, Reinhard</a></cite>
Reinhard Kuhn served in the Army from 1954 to 1956.<cite><a href="Kuhn, Reinhard.html">Kuhn, Reinhard</a></cite>
Reinhard Kuhn was assistant professor and later associate professor of French at the University of Kansas between 1959 and 1963, and professor of French at the University of Buffalo in 1963-64.<cite><a href="Kuhn, Reinhard.html">Kuhn, Reinhard</a></cite>
Reinhard Kuhn came to Brown in 1964 as professor of French.<cite><a href="Kuhn, Reinhard.html">Kuhn, Reinhard</a></cite>
Reinhard Kuhn was chairman of the Department of French Studies from 1967 to 1977.<cite><a href="Kuhn, Reinhard.html">Kuhn, Reinhard</a></cite>
As a young man, Reinhard Kuhn made a trip through the Midwest where, driving through what he described as "endless miles of grain fields and farmlands in the shimmering summer heat," he felt "a tremendous lassitude, a deepening sense of numbness, of disconnection from reality ..." This condition led to his continuing interest in "boredom," until, after collecting notes on the subject for years, he published a book on the subject entitled "The Demon of Noontide: Ennui in Western Literature" in 1977.<cite><a href="Kuhn, Reinhard.html">Kuhn, Reinhard</a></cite>
Reinhard Kuhn died of "Legionnaire’s Disease" in Boston on November 7, 1980.<cite><a href="Kuhn, Reinhard.html">Kuhn, Reinhard</a></cite>
At Commencement of 1981 Reinhard Kuhn was awarded a posthumous senior citation.<cite><a href="Kuhn, Reinhard.html">Kuhn, Reinhard</a></cite>
Lacrosse gained varsity standing in 1926 after two years of informal play, with a team, coached by freshman football and basketball coach Ben Beck, which played five games for one win, three losses, and one tie.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
John Frederick Powers, a hockey coach from Boston, who coached in 1927, was followed by Allen E. Reed from Harvard in 1928, D. Alex Wieland in 1929, and A. Barr Snively from 1930 to 1932.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
In 1930 the team played a combined Oxford-Cambridge team which won, 6-0.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
In 1931 the Athletic Council declared lacrosse a major sport.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
After a few losing seasons, the team had four winning seasons from 1930 through 1933, before a decline which lasted until the sport was dropped in 1937 during the Depression.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
Henry Letoile began coaching in 1933.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
The 1938 "<a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a>," while noting that there were promising players in the Classes of 1940 and 1941, announced, "Lacrosse has been abandoned."<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
Lacrosse was revived by an informal team without University recognition which competed in 1949 under the name of the Narragansett Lacrosse Club with Don Miller ’49 as coach and captain.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
In 1950 the lacrosse team was coached by senior Alexander "Tim" Colahan ’50.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
"<a href="Bear Facts.html">Bear Facts</a>," in September 1955 described the status of lacrosse, "The Brown Lacrosse Club is one of the most active groups on the campus.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
Continuing informally, lacrosse was coached in 1959 and 1960 by Terry Reardon of the Providence Reds.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
Lacrosse was recognized as a club sport in 1961, and after two successful seasons under coach Cliff Stevenson, was once again accorded varsity status in 1963.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
In 1964 the Brown lacrosse team had three All-Americans, Thomas H. Draper ’64, Michael T. Healy ’64, and William A. Lemire ’64.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
Stevenson, who coached from 1961 to 1982 and who once described lacrosse as "mayhem with a crooked stick," had a 20-year record of 188-100-0, with eight New England championships, six of them between 1962 and 1972, and shared the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> title with Cornell in 1969.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
His teams reached the NCAA quarterfinals three times, in 1971, 1973, and 1976.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
The 1973 team, spurred on by Stevenson’s promise to buy watches for the players if they won the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> championship, finished 6-0 in the league, 10-2 overall, and won the New England championship, but was defeated by Maryland, 7-16, in the NCAA quarterfinals.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
The Brown team also lost to Maryland, 8-17, in the 1976 quarterfinals.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
Dom Starsia ’74, who never saw a lacrosse game before he came to Brown, was All-American in 1973 and 1974, and in his senior year captain of his team in both the North-South All-Star and the New England All-Star games.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
He succeeded Stevenson as coach in 1982.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
His 1985 team won the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> championship and lost to North Carolina, 14-16, in the quarterfinals of the NCAA tournament.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
Bill Aliber ’83 made the All-Ivy team three times from 1981 to 1983, as did Darren Lowe ’92 from 1990 to 1992.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
Brown made the quarterfinals three more times, in 1990, 1991, and 1992.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
The team was eliminated, 12-20, by Syracuse in 1990.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
The season of 1991, Brown’s finest, which included an undefeated regular season and the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> title, ended when Brown’s second seeded team was eliminated in the NCAA quarterfinals, losing, 13-16, to the University of Maryland before 3,600 spectators at Stevenson Field.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
The 1992 team lost to North Carolina,10-16, in the quarterfinals.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
Peter Lasagna began coaching in 1992.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
Women students took up lacrosse in 1934 when Bessie Rudd acquired 24 lacrosse sticks, and made arrangements to pay for them in two installments.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
After a few intramural games a team played Wheaton College on May 14, 1934, and lost, 0-11.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
Women’s lacrosse began in earnest in 1974 with Dale Philippi as coach.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
Candis Russell coached from 1981 to 1987, and Wendy Anderson from 1988 to 1992.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
Among the best seasons for women’s lacrosse were 1977 with 8-0-2, in 1978 with 10-4, in 1986 with 8-4, and 1989 with 10-4.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
The team went to two ECAC playoffs, in 1989 and 1991.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
The 1991 team was ranked among the top ten nationally and played in the ECAC tournament, and two players, Suzanne Bailey ’91 and Monique Kapitulik ’91 were named to the All-American first team.<cite><a href="Lacrosse.html">Lacrosse</a></cite>
Ladd Observatory was opened on October 21, 1891.<cite><a href="Ladd Observatory.html">Ladd Observatory</a></cite>
When Winslow Upton came to Brown as professor of astronomy in 1884, it was understood that the University would build an observatory.<cite><a href="Ladd Observatory.html">Ladd Observatory</a></cite>
At the dedication, Ladd recalled, "Becoming a resident of Rhode Island, my attention was drawn to Brown University, and my interest aroused in it; and when, at the Alumni dinner of 1889, in reply to a question as to what the university most needed, I was informed ‘an observatory,’ and, as circumstances seemed fitting, I determined to make the promise, which was at that time announced."<cite><a href="Ladd Observatory.html">Ladd Observatory</a></cite>
Construction began in May 1890 of a 43 by 27 foot building of brick and stone with a dome 21 feet in diameter made of copper sheets on a steel framework.<cite><a href="Ladd Observatory.html">Ladd Observatory</a></cite>
In 1893 the University purchased two lots which extended the eastern boundary of the property.<cite><a href="Ladd Observatory.html">Ladd Observatory</a></cite>
From 1893 to 1973 Ladd Observatory provided time signals, first to the Rhode Island Electric Protective Company, which distributed them throughout the state, then in 1906 to the local fire stations.<cite><a href="Ladd Observatory.html">Ladd Observatory</a></cite>
The transit observations were discontinued in November 1916 and began again after the war in 1919.<cite><a href="Ladd Observatory.html">Ladd Observatory</a></cite>
In 1944 the Observatory began to test the Civil Defense air raid signals at the fire stations every day at noon.<cite><a href="Ladd Observatory.html">Ladd Observatory</a></cite>
Alexis Caswell had begun these records in 1831 and kept them for 45 years.<cite><a href="Ladd Observatory.html">Ladd Observatory</a></cite>
The records were kept by the City Engineer after 1876, the observatory after 1890, and the United States Weather Bureau beginning in 1904.<cite><a href="Ladd Observatory.html">Ladd Observatory</a></cite>
After the death of Upton in 1914, the observatory came under the direction of professors of mathematics R. G. D. Richardson from 1914 to 1921, and Clinton H. Currier from 1921 to 1931.<cite><a href="Ladd Observatory.html">Ladd Observatory</a></cite>
Professor of astronomy Charles H. Smiley took charge for the next forty years, and on his retirement the observatory became the responsibility of the <a href="Physics.html">Physics</a> Department, and was directed by Phillip J. Stiles from 1970 to 1986 and by Hendrik J. Gerritsen from 1986 to 1989.<cite><a href="Ladd Observatory.html">Ladd Observatory</a></cite>
David M. Targan became director in 1989.<cite><a href="Ladd Observatory.html">Ladd Observatory</a></cite>
When Ladd Observatory celebrated its one hundredth anniversary on October 21, 1991, a tent adjoining the building was once more required to hold the visitors.<cite><a href="Ladd Observatory.html">Ladd Observatory</a></cite>
Courtney Langdon (1861-1924), professor of modern languages, was born in Rome on January 18, 1861, the son of William Chauncy Langdon, an Episcopal clergyman, who was at that time chaplain of the American delegation in Rome.<cite><a href="Langdon, Courtney.html">Langdon, Courtney</a></cite>
The family lived in Florence and Genoa before returning to the United States in 1873.<cite><a href="Langdon, Courtney.html">Langdon, Courtney</a></cite>
Langdon studied at Harvard from 1878 to 1881, and between 1881 and 1890 he taught German and romance languages in various places including Lehigh and Cornell Universities.<cite><a href="Langdon, Courtney.html">Langdon, Courtney</a></cite>
Courtney Langdon came to Brown as assistant professor of modern languages in 1890, was awarded an honorary bachelor of arts degree in 1891, promoted to associate professor in 1892 and professor in 1898.<cite><a href="Langdon, Courtney.html">Langdon, Courtney</a></cite>
The three volumes of Courtney Langdon's translation of Dante’s "Divina Commedia" into English blank verse were published between 1918 and 1921.<cite><a href="Langdon, Courtney.html">Langdon, Courtney</a></cite>
Courtney Langdon also wrote a book of poems, "Sonnets on the War," which was published in 1917.<cite><a href="Langdon, Courtney.html">Langdon, Courtney</a></cite>
George W. Potter ’21 wrote of him in the "Providence Journal:" Langdon died in Providence on November 19, 1924.<cite><a href="Langdon, Courtney.html">Langdon, Courtney</a></cite>
Waldo Gifford Leland (1879-1966), historian, was born in Newton, Massachusetts, on July 17, 1879.<cite><a href="Leland, Waldo G..html">Leland, Waldo G.</a></cite>
Waldo G. Leland graduated from Brown in 1900.<cite><a href="Leland, Waldo G..html">Leland, Waldo G.</a></cite>
In 1903, while Waldo G. Leland was a doctoral candidate at Harvard, he went to Washington to assist his former history professor, J. Franklin Jameson, then Director of Historical Research for the Carnegie Institution of Washington, in the first major inventory of American historical documents.<cite><a href="Leland, Waldo G..html">Leland, Waldo G.</a></cite>
Although some government offices were not enthusiastic about opening their files to Leland, he published in 1904 a "Guide to the Archives of the Government of the United States in Washington," the first comprehensive listing.<cite><a href="Leland, Waldo G..html">Leland, Waldo G.</a></cite>
Leland and Jameson paved the way for the establishment of the National Archives, even though this event did not take place until 1934.<cite><a href="Leland, Waldo G..html">Leland, Waldo G.</a></cite>
Waldo G. Leland was the first president of the Society of American Archivists in 1940-41.<cite><a href="Leland, Waldo G..html">Leland, Waldo G.</a></cite>
Leland was also one of the principal organizers and president from 1927 to 1946 of the American Council of Learned Societies.<cite><a href="Leland, Waldo G..html">Leland, Waldo G.</a></cite>
Waldo G. Leland was a member of the Brown Board of Fellows from 1933 to 1964.<cite><a href="Leland, Waldo G..html">Leland, Waldo G.</a></cite>
Waldo G. Leland died in Washington on October 9, 1966.<cite><a href="Leland, Waldo G..html">Leland, Waldo G.</a></cite>
Nancy Duke Lewis (1910-1961), Dean of Pembroke College from 1950 to 1960, was born in Lexington, Kentucky on November 1, 1910.<cite><a href="Lewis, Nancy Duke.html">Lewis, Nancy Duke</a></cite>
Nancy Duke Lewis held an administrative position at the Women’s College of the University of North Carolina before coming to Pembroke to be social director of the college and also to teach mathematics in 1943.<cite><a href="Lewis, Nancy Duke.html">Lewis, Nancy Duke</a></cite>
Nancy Duke Lewis continued as social director until 1946, also serving as assistant dean from 1944 to 1947.<cite><a href="Lewis, Nancy Duke.html">Lewis, Nancy Duke</a></cite>
Nancy Duke Lewis was Dean of Students at Pembroke from 1947 to 1949 and acting dean in 1949-50.<cite><a href="Lewis, Nancy Duke.html">Lewis, Nancy Duke</a></cite>
Nancy Duke Lewis had given up teaching in 1948 to devote her time to administration.<cite><a href="Lewis, Nancy Duke.html">Lewis, Nancy Duke</a></cite>
In 1949 Nancy Duke Lewis received a travel grant from the Carnegie Corporation to visit colleges throughout the country, studying their administrative and academic organizations, the first such grant which the Carnegie Corporation had awarded to a woman.<cite><a href="Lewis, Nancy Duke.html">Lewis, Nancy Duke</a></cite>
Nancy Duke Lewis succeeded Margaret S. Morriss as Dean of Pembroke College in 1950.<cite><a href="Lewis, Nancy Duke.html">Lewis, Nancy Duke</a></cite>
In 1960 Nancy Duke Lewis was elected Chairman of the American Conference of Academic Deans.<cite><a href="Lewis, Nancy Duke.html">Lewis, Nancy Duke</a></cite>
Professor <a href="Kenny, Robert W..html">Robert W. Kenny</a> took over Nancy Duke Lewis's duties as acting dean of Pembroke in 1960.<cite><a href="Lewis, Nancy Duke.html">Lewis, Nancy Duke</a></cite>
Dean Lewis died on July 31, 1961.<cite><a href="Lewis, Nancy Duke.html">Lewis, Nancy Duke</a></cite>
The "Liber Brunensis" for 1870 appeared in December 1869, superseding the "<a href="Brown Paper.html">Brown Paper</a>," an annual newspaper published by the secret societies.<cite><a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a></cite>
The 1890 volume included group photographs of publication boards, musical clubs and athletic teams.<cite><a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a></cite>
Individual photographs of seniors first appeared in the 1896 "Liber."<cite><a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a></cite>
Since 1857 seniors had been accustomed to purchase large leather-bound class albums into which they inserted photographs of individual classmates as well as campus views and group photographs.<cite><a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a></cite>
Even when the "Liber" began to include photographs, the class albums continued their existence until 1907.<cite><a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a></cite>
In 1895 the "Liber" included lists of women students in a section headed "Co-<a href="Education.html">Education</a>."<cite><a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a></cite>
The next year there were pictures of individual women graduates, and in 1897 lists of sorority members.<cite><a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a></cite>
From 1902 until 1907 the "Liber" contained class lists of women students and pages devoted to the sororities and other women’s organizations and teams.<cite><a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a></cite>
In 1908 the women’s pages disappeared, and in 1909 the Women’s College started its own annual, "<a href="Brun Mael.html">Brun Mael</a>," which was published until 1970, after which the "Liber Brunensis" became the yearbook of the coeducational institution brought about by the merger of Brown and Pembroke.<cite><a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a></cite>
The "Liber" of 1919 was the last to be published by a senior board of editors, who were representatives of their fraternities.<cite><a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a></cite>
The "Liber" has continued to be published annually, except when prevented by wartime conditions in 1944.<cite><a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a></cite>
A combined 1944-1945 book was issued the following year.<cite><a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a></cite>
The first known book in the library was a gift from its president, being Valentin Schindler’s "Lexicon Pentaglotten, Hebraicum, Chaldaicum, Syriacum ... Rabbinicum &amp; Arabicum, Hanoviae, 1612," which bore the inscription, "The gift of the Revd.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
James Manning to Rhode Island College June 17th, 1767."<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
Morgan Edwards, soliciting funds in England and Ireland in 1767 and 1768, was also given books for the library.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
James Manning, in a letter to Thomas Llewelyn, February 21, 1772, stated, "At present we have but about two hundred and fifty volumes and those not well chosen, being such as our friends could best spare."<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
Twenty-seven of these volumes had been received in 1771 from student Joseph Dolbeare Russell 1772, an assortment which included among their subjects philosophy, algebra, histories of Scotland and Iceland, and eight volumes of the "Spectator."<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
In 1772 the executors of John Gill, biblical commentator, of London, added to the library all his published works plus 52 volumes of other religious works.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
In 1776, when the British arrived in Newport and the College Edifice was needed for barracks, all the books in the College Library were removed to Wrentham, Massachusetts, to the home of William Williams 1769.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
There they remained until 1782, when the library, now returned to the College Edifice, was described by Manning in a letter to Samuel Stennett of London as "about five hundred volumes, most of which are both very ancient and very useless, as well as very ragged and unsightly."<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
The Laws of 1783 allowed a folio to be taken for four weeks, a quarto for three weeks, an octavo for two weeks, and a duodecimo for one week, and the size of the fine for not returning a book also depended on the size of the book.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
A letter of Asher Robbins written in 1843 recalls the library in 1782, but his estimate of its size is at variance with Manning’s catalogue.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
The "New Library" (now <a href="Robinson Hall.html">Robinson Hall</a>) was dedicated on February 16, 1878.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
Other floors could be visited with permission, and such was the care taken of the books that it was reported that "One book missing at the close of the year 1881-82, was afterwards found to have fallen behind others on the shelf where it belonged."<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
The new regulations adopted by the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> on June 20, 1878 permitted undergraduates to borrow up to three volumes for two weeks, provided that any student planning to leave Providence for more than one week return his books before his departure.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
In 1881 Rev. Josiah Nelson Cushing 1862 presented a collection of the sacred writings of the Buddhists written in the Pali language on palm leaves.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
In 1883 the library acquired books from the library of Joseph J. Cooke, who bequeathed to Brown, and to several other colleges, $5,000 to be spent at auction sales of his books.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
Part of the plan, which involved continuing the use of the old library for departmental libraries after the opening of the <a href="John Hay Library.html">John Hay Library</a> in 1910, was abandoned.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
On the continuing problem of cataloguing the books, even with the use of Library of Congress cards, <a href="President.html">President</a> Faunce commented in his annual report in 1916, "What if, after twenty years of minute and exhausting labor, a new and different system should seem advisable?<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
By 1929 space problems in the <a href="John Hay Library.html">John Hay Library</a> were so acute that duplicate and lesser used volumes were sent to the Tockwotten branch of the Providence Public Library for storage.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
When he arrived in 1937, there were seventeen departmental libraries housed in campus buildings other than the <a href="John Hay Library.html">John Hay Library</a>.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
A much needed addition was built on the <a href="John Hay Library.html">John Hay Library</a> in 1939, not the adjacent marble structure of equal size that had been designed, but a less costly brick wing providing two floors of reading space and six floors of stacks.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
In 1961 the library received a collection of 35,000 Chinese books from Dr. Charles Sidney Gardner of Harvard’s Yenching Institute.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
The <a href="Rockefeller Library.html">Rockefeller Library</a> with a capacity of 1,500,000 books was opened in 1964.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
In 1971 the <a href="Sciences Library.html">Sciences Library</a> with room for 450,000 volumes brought together the Biological <a href="Sciences Library.html">Sciences Library</a> and the Physical <a href="Sciences Library.html">Sciences Library</a>.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
In 1954 the library announced the acquisition of its millionth item, "De Homine Figuris et Latinate Donatus a Florentio Schuyl" by Descartes, printed in Leyden in 1662, a gift of Albert E. Lownes ’20, and its eight hundred thousandth book, "Compendium Pharmaceuticum," compiled by John Francis Coste, physician-in-chief of the French forces in America in the Revolution, given by the heirs of Solomon Drowne 1773.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
In 1988 the library designated as its two-millionth book a first-edition copy of Pavlov’s "Lectures on the Function of the Main Food-Digesting Glands," printed in St Petersburg in 1897.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
The art slide library and media services for the University community are administered by the University Library, as are the satellites installed in 1989 for the purpose of receiving television broadcasts from the Soviet Union, international satellites over the Atlantic Ocean, and United States and Canadian satellites.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
One of these is the Harris Collection of American <a href="Poetry.html">Poetry</a> and Plays, which was bequeathed to the University in 1884 by Senator Henry Bowen Anthony 1833.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
The author of "Old Grimes’ was Albert Gorton Greene 1820, whose collection was on his death purchased by Caleb Fiske Harris 1838, and on the death of Harris purchased by Henry Bowen Anthony 1835.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
The McLellan Lincoln Collection was the gift of John D. Rockefeller, Jr. 1897 in 1923.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
The Williams Table Collection is the name of the reassembled library of the College at the time of the <a href="Revolutionary War.html">Revolutionary War</a>, and takes its name from the table which William Williams 1769 used as a student and in which he later stored some of the books in the college library which were sent to his home in Wrentham, Massachusetts, for safekeeping during the Revolution.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
The table itself, bequeathed to the University by his daughter in 1867, stands in the <a href="John Hay Library.html">John Hay Library</a> near the collection.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
The first of the long-term librarians was Horatio Gates Bowen from 1824 to 1840, who was followed by Charles C. Jewett from 1842 to 1848, Reuben A.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
Guild from 1848 to 1893, Harry Lyman Koopman from 1893 to 1930, Henry B.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
Van Hoesen from 1930 to 1949, David A. Jonah from 1949 to 1974, Charles D. Churchwell from 1974 to 1979, C. James Schmidt from 1979 to 1982, and Merrily Taylor since 1982.<cite><a href="Library.html">Library</a></cite>
The <a href="Lincoln Field.html">Lincoln Field</a> Building was erected in 1903 as the <a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a> Building.<cite><a href="Lincoln Field Building.html">Lincoln Field Building</a></cite>
<a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a> acquired new quarters in the Barus-Holley Building, built in 1964.<cite><a href="Lincoln Field Building.html">Lincoln Field Building</a></cite>
Lincoln Field was laid out in the spring of 1880 under the supervision of Professor Samuel S. Greene, who had two sons on the college baseball team.<cite><a href="Lincoln Field.html">Lincoln Field</a></cite>
In 1894 a cinder track was built around the field, along with a short path of the same material for jumping and vaulting.<cite><a href="Lincoln Field.html">Lincoln Field</a></cite>
Lincoln Field was the site of athletic contests until <a href="Andrews Field.html">Andrews Field</a> on Camp Street took its place in 1899.<cite><a href="Lincoln Field.html">Lincoln Field</a></cite>
In 1985 the University hoped to receive funding from the Olin Foundation to erect a three-story building, which was required by the foundation to be visible from the main campus.<cite><a href="Lincoln Field.html">Lincoln Field</a></cite>
John Larkin Lincoln (1817-1891), professor of Latin, was born in Boston on February 23, 1817.<cite><a href="Lincoln, John Larkin.html">Lincoln, John Larkin</a></cite>
John Larkin Lincoln was baptized in the Federal Street Church on Sunday, October 7, 1832, and on Monday presented himself at Brown to be examined for admission.<cite><a href="Lincoln, John Larkin.html">Lincoln, John Larkin</a></cite>
John Larkin Lincoln joined the Society of Missionary Inquiry in May 1833 and noted in January 1834, "Commenced a practice of meeting with three of my classmates who are pious ... three times a week for religious conversation and prayer."<cite><a href="Lincoln, John Larkin.html">Lincoln, John Larkin</a></cite>
On May 26, 1833, John Larkin Lincoln recorded President Andrew Jackson’s visit to Providence, "He arrived in the morning and was welcomed cordially by the citizens, and was brought into the city in a barouche amidst the shouts of the spectators.<cite><a href="Lincoln, John Larkin.html">Lincoln, John Larkin</a></cite>
After graduation in 1836, Lincoln was at Columbian College (now <a href="Washington, George.html">George Washington</a> University), first as a teacher in the preparatory school and then as a tutor in the college.<cite><a href="Lincoln, John Larkin.html">Lincoln, John Larkin</a></cite>
In 1837 John Larkin Lincoln entered Newton Theological School to study for the ministry.<cite><a href="Lincoln, John Larkin.html">Lincoln, John Larkin</a></cite>
John Larkin Lincoln went to Europe in 1841 for two years of study in Germany followed by a year of travel in France and Italy.<cite><a href="Lincoln, John Larkin.html">Lincoln, John Larkin</a></cite>
In 1844 John Larkin Lincoln was named assistant professor of Latin at Brown.<cite><a href="Lincoln, John Larkin.html">Lincoln, John Larkin</a></cite>
The next year John Larkin Lincoln was promoted to professor, and, although presidencies of colleges were offered him, kept that position for the rest his days with the exception of three trips to Europe, one for his health in 1857, the next in the summer of 1878, and the last a year’s absence in 1887-88.<cite><a href="Lincoln, John Larkin.html">Lincoln, John Larkin</a></cite>
In addition to teaching John Larkin Lincoln was a member of the University library committee for 35 years, and edited the Annual Catalogue with President <a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Francis Wayland</a> until 1855 and after that time by himself until 1884.<cite><a href="Lincoln, John Larkin.html">Lincoln, John Larkin</a></cite>
From 1858 to 1867, while still teaching the senior class and furnishing a substitute for his other classes, he was the principal of a school for young ladies, formerly operated by <a href="Kingsbury, John.html">John Kingsbury</a> 1826.<cite><a href="Lincoln, John Larkin.html">Lincoln, John Larkin</a></cite>
The Lincoln School in Providence, established in 1884, was named for him at a later date by Mrs. Ames and principal Ednah Bowen, both of whom had been students at his school.<cite><a href="Lincoln, John Larkin.html">Lincoln, John Larkin</a></cite>
In 1890 a fund of $100,000 raised in John Larkin Lincoln's honor was added to the endowment with the provision that the income of the fund be used to give him his usual salary for the rest of his life.<cite><a href="Lincoln, John Larkin.html">Lincoln, John Larkin</a></cite>
John Larkin Lincoln died on October 17, 1891 in Providence.<cite><a href="Lincoln, John Larkin.html">Lincoln, John Larkin</a></cite>
The Lincoln Society was formed in 1947 with a membership of about twenty men committed to its purpose as a social organization to promote interracial and interreligious understanding on the campus and in the community.<cite><a href="Lincoln Society.html">Lincoln Society</a></cite>
In 1949 the Lincoln Society affiliated with the Student Committee on Educational Democracy, described in "<a href="Bear Facts.html">Bear Facts</a>" as "a loose federation of college organizations acting as ‘a clearing house for ideas.’" Its last year as a student organization was 1951-52.<cite><a href="Lincoln Society.html">Lincoln Society</a></cite>
R(obert) Bruce Lindsay (1900-1985), professor of physics, was born in New Bedford, Massachusetts, on January 1, 1900.<cite><a href="Lindsay, Robert Bruce.html">Lindsay, Robert Bruce</a></cite>
Robert Bruce Lindsay graduated from Brown in 1920, receiving both a bachelor of arts and a master of science degree that year.<cite><a href="Lindsay, Robert Bruce.html">Lindsay, Robert Bruce</a></cite>
In the 1922-23 academic year Robert Bruce Lindsay studied, as a Fellow of the American-Scandinavian Foundation, at the Institute of Theoretical Physics in Copenhagen under Niels Bohr (who won the Nobel prize that year) and H. A. Kramer.<cite><a href="Lindsay, Robert Bruce.html">Lindsay, Robert Bruce</a></cite>
Their translation was published by Gyldendal in 1923 with the title, "The Atom and the Bohr Theory of its Structure," and was published in the United States by Knopf in 1924.<cite><a href="Lindsay, Robert Bruce.html">Lindsay, Robert Bruce</a></cite>
The Lindsays used the approximately $125 they had received for the translation in traveling around Europe in the summer of 1923.<cite><a href="Lindsay, Robert Bruce.html">Lindsay, Robert Bruce</a></cite>
On his return, Lindsay completed his dissertation on the atomic models of the alkali metals, which he had begun in Copenhagen, and received his Ph.D. from M.I.T. in 1924.<cite><a href="Lindsay, Robert Bruce.html">Lindsay, Robert Bruce</a></cite>
Robert Bruce Lindsay went to Yale as instructor in physics in 1923 and was promoted to assistant professor in 1927.<cite><a href="Lindsay, Robert Bruce.html">Lindsay, Robert Bruce</a></cite>
Robert Bruce Lindsay came back to Brown in 1930 as associate professor of theoretical physics.<cite><a href="Lindsay, Robert Bruce.html">Lindsay, Robert Bruce</a></cite>
Robert Bruce Lindsay was named Hazard Professor of Physics in 1936 and chairman of the Physics Department in 1934, a post which he held until he became dean of the Graduate School in 1954.<cite><a href="Lindsay, Robert Bruce.html">Lindsay, Robert Bruce</a></cite>
Robert Bruce Lindsay published a number of textbooks, among them, "Acoustics – A Text on Theory and Applications" with G. W. Stewart in 1934, "Physical Mechanics" in 1933, "Foundations of Physics" with Henry Margenau in 1936, "Concepts and Methods of Theoretical Physics" in 1951 (with a Japanese translation published in 1957).<cite><a href="Lindsay, Robert Bruce.html">Lindsay, Robert Bruce</a></cite>
He also published "The Nature of Physics" in 1968, "Lord Rayleigh, The Man and His Work" in 1970, and "Julius Robert Mayer, Prophet of Energy" in 1973.<cite><a href="Lindsay, Robert Bruce.html">Lindsay, Robert Bruce</a></cite>
Robert Bruce Lindsay retired as dean of the Graduate School in 1966 and from teaching in 1970.<cite><a href="Lindsay, Robert Bruce.html">Lindsay, Robert Bruce</a></cite>
Robert Bruce Lindsay died on March 2, 1985 in Newport, Rhode Island.<cite><a href="Lindsay, Robert Bruce.html">Lindsay, Robert Bruce</a></cite>
List <a href="Art.html">Art</a> Building was completed in 1971, six years after the building project was launched by a donation by Mr. and Mrs. Albert List, private collectors and art patrons.<cite><a href="List Art Building.html">List Art Building</a></cite>
On the first floor are a large lecture room for 225 people and the David Winton Bell Gallery, a 2500 square foot exhibition area, the gift of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Bell and Lucy Bell Hartwell in memory of their son and brother.<cite><a href="List Art Building.html">List Art Building</a></cite>
On the top floor is a 4500 square foot painting studio with skylights.<cite><a href="List Art Building.html">List Art Building</a></cite>
The building, named the Albert and Vera List <a href="Art.html">Art</a> Building, was dedicated on October 8, 1971 at exercises at which art historian Kenneth Clark delivered an address.<cite><a href="List Art Building.html">List Art Building</a></cite>
The Literary Magazine of Brown University appeared in two issues only, in May 1967 and March 1968.<cite><a href="Literary Magazine of Brown University.html">Literary Magazine of Brown University</a></cite>
Littlefield Hall, a dormitory for 78 students adjoining <a href="Maxcy Hall.html">Maxcy Hall</a>, was built in 1925, at a cost of $150,000 provided by the George L. Littlefield General Fund.<cite><a href="Littlefield Hall.html">Littlefield Hall</a></cite>
James Manning, who had been sent to Newport in 1763 with the proposal for a Baptist college in the Colony, had settled in Warren and was soon appointed the first pastor of the new Baptist Church there, an offshoot of the church in Swansea, organized in November 1764.<cite><a href="Location.html">Location</a></cite>
There he conducted a Latin school and, after he was named president of the College in September 1765, students of the College met in the Warren parsonage along with the Latin school students.<cite><a href="Location.html">Location</a></cite>
In 1769, when a building for the College was considered, Warren was first agreed upon as the location.<cite><a href="Location.html">Location</a></cite>
The next contender as a site for the College was East Greenwich, but only a few days after its application, Moses Brown wrote to his brothers on October 23, 1769, that a conversation with Governor Darius Sessions had convinced him of the advantages of Providence as a site.<cite><a href="Location.html">Location</a></cite>
At the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> meeting, November 15, 1769, John Cole, Moses Brown, and Hezekiah Smith presented a memorial on behalf of the principal inhabitants of Providence to have the college located there.<cite><a href="Location.html">Location</a></cite>
In January 1770 the Browns bought it from the present owner, Samuel Fenner, and sold it to the College.<cite><a href="Location.html">Location</a></cite>
On February 23, 1770, according to the diary of Ezra Stiles, William Ellery visited him to discuss a charter for another college to be located at Newport, and a charter for the rival college was passed by the lower house of the General Assembly at the February session, but deferred by the upper house until the next session, when it was rejected.<cite><a href="Location.html">Location</a></cite>
"Los," subtitled "a magazine of poetry," was published by the graduate students of Brown University from March 1967 to the spring of 1970.<cite><a href="Los.html">Los</a></cite>
Lyman Hall was formerly Lyman Gymnasium, named for Daniel W. Lyman 1865, who bequeathed the University $50,000 in 1887 for a building which was to be named for him.<cite><a href="Lyman Hall.html">Lyman Hall</a></cite>
The subject was often brought up in the pages of the "<a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a>," and "King’s Pocket-book of Providence, R.I." in 1882 went so far as to list among its descriptions of existing buildings of Brown University: Lyman’s bequest with other contributions was sufficient to cover the $66,000 cost of building and equipping the gymnasium, which was completed in November 1891.<cite><a href="Lyman Hall.html">Lyman Hall</a></cite>
The opening celebration was the Gym Ball held on December 2, 1891, amid lavish decorations consisting of potted plants, and appropriate items such as fencing foils and boxing gloves arrayed on the rail around the running track.<cite><a href="Lyman Hall.html">Lyman Hall</a></cite>
During the second term of 1891-92 physical education was required of all students four times a week.<cite><a href="Lyman Hall.html">Lyman Hall</a></cite>
In 1901 the space cut for the tank, about sixty yards in length, was surrounded by a new running track, banked at the corners, for the track team.<cite><a href="Lyman Hall.html">Lyman Hall</a></cite>
In 1913 the basement area was floored over for track practice, and a small room in the southwest corner of the basement was equipped as a wrestling room.<cite><a href="Lyman Hall.html">Lyman Hall</a></cite>
In 1924 the increasing space problem of Lyman Gym was partially alleviated by installing a boxing room in <a href="Rogers Hall.html">Rogers Hall</a> with a temporary passage from the gymnasium to <a href="Rogers Hall.html">Rogers Hall</a> built over the new heating plant.<cite><a href="Lyman Hall.html">Lyman Hall</a></cite>
In 1928 a new gymnasium took the place of Lyman Gym, which continued to be used for handball and basketball.<cite><a href="Lyman Hall.html">Lyman Hall</a></cite>
In 1946, since all sports activities were centered at <a href="Marvel Gymnasium.html">Marvel Gymnasium</a>, the name of the building was changed from Lyman Gymnasium to Lyman Hall, and the Department of Naval Science moved in from its former quarters in <a href="Maxcy Hall.html">Maxcy Hall</a>.<cite><a href="Lyman Hall.html">Lyman Hall</a></cite>
In 1972, when Lyman Hall was vacated by the ROTC, a team from the architectural firm of Sasaki, Dawson, DeMay Associates of Watertown, Massachusetts, recommended that the building be renovated for an experimental theatre and that the adjoining <a href="Colgate Hoyt Pool.html">Colgate Hoyt Pool</a> be made into a dance studio.<cite><a href="Lyman Hall.html">Lyman Hall</a></cite>
Another part of the recommendation was that South Hall, purchased from <a href="Bryant College.html">Bryant College</a> in 1969, be renovated for the use of the <a href="Music.html">Music</a> Department.<cite><a href="Lyman Hall.html">Lyman Hall</a></cite>
In 1973 the Kresge Foundation offered a two-for-one challenge grant of $900,000 to match $1,800,000 to be raised by the University.<cite><a href="Lyman Hall.html">Lyman Hall</a></cite>
Marion Wolk, coordinator of the arts at Brown, organized the national committee for the performing arts fund, which under the leadership of Isabelle Russek Leeds, University trustee, met the goal in 1976.<cite><a href="Lyman Hall.html">Lyman Hall</a></cite>
Leslie Armstrong ’62 drew up plans based on the design of Sasaki, Dawson, DeMay, and construction was begun in 1977.<cite><a href="Lyman Hall.html">Lyman Hall</a></cite>
On April 21, 1979, both the Isabelle Russek Leeds Theatre, a gift of Mrs. Leeds and her family, and the Ashamu Dance Studio, a gift of Chief and Mrs. E.O.<cite><a href="Lyman Hall.html">Lyman Hall</a></cite>
Children of both donors, Amy Leeds 1974 and Samson Ashamu 1979, had studied at Brown.<cite><a href="Lyman Hall.html">Lyman Hall</a></cite>
The accompanying performances, workshops, and recitals went on for a week, and included a performance of "The Master," a play written by Professor James Schevill, directed by Professor John Emigh, and performed by Professor James O. Barnhill and Julia Roig 1980, a lecture by John Ford Noonan, a theatre arts workshop with Richard Foreman 1959, and the first class held in the new theatre, which was taught by Robert Bailey 1970.<cite><a href="Lyman Hall.html">Lyman Hall</a></cite>
Charles Arthur Lynch (1903-1963), professor of classics, was born in Providence on May 4, 1903.<cite><a href="Lynch, Charles Arthur.html">Lynch, Charles Arthur</a></cite>
Charles Arthur Lynch graduated from Classical High School and received his bachelor of arts degree from Harvard in 1926, a master’s degree from Brown in 1927 and another from Harvard in 1927, and his Ph.D. from Harvard in 1936.<cite><a href="Lynch, Charles Arthur.html">Lynch, Charles Arthur</a></cite>
Charles Arthur Lynch was instructor in Greek and Latin classics at Brown in 1927-28 and again in 1932, becoming assistant professor in 1935, associate professor in 1944, and professor in 1951.<cite><a href="Lynch, Charles Arthur.html">Lynch, Charles Arthur</a></cite>
With Professor <a href="Bradner, Leicester.html">Leicester Bradner</a> Charles Arthur Lynch translated "The Latin Epigrams of Thomas More," which was published by the University of Chicago Press in 1953, after which he was invited to become a member of the Thomas More Project at Yale University.<cite><a href="Lynch, Charles Arthur.html">Lynch, Charles Arthur</a></cite>
Charles Arthur Lynch was acting chairman of the department in the second semester of 1962-63, when illness caused him to stop teaching in April.<cite><a href="Lynch, Charles Arthur.html">Lynch, Charles Arthur</a></cite>
Charles Arthur Lynch died in Providence on July 16, 1963.<cite><a href="Lynch, Charles Arthur.html">Lynch, Charles Arthur</a></cite>
William Macdonald (1863-1938), professor of history, was born in Providence on July 31, 1863.<cite><a href="Macdonald, William.html">Macdonald, William</a></cite>
William Macdonald received a bachelor of arts degree from Harvard in 1892 and an honorary Ph.D. degree from Union College in 1895.<cite><a href="Macdonald, William.html">Macdonald, William</a></cite>
William Macdonald was professor of history and economics at Worcester Polytechnic Institute in 1892-93 and professor of history and political science at Bowdoin College from 1893 to 1901.<cite><a href="Macdonald, William.html">Macdonald, William</a></cite>
William Macdonald came to Brown in 1901 as professor of history and was named George L. Littlefield Professor of History in 1905.<cite><a href="Macdonald, William.html">Macdonald, William</a></cite>
William Macdonald was on sabbatical leave in France in 1917 when he resigned his professorship and became a special foreign correspondent for "The Nation" in Europe.<cite><a href="Macdonald, William.html">Macdonald, William</a></cite>
William Macdonald was a lecturer on government at the University of California in 1917-18, associate editor of "The Nation" from 1918 to 1920, and later editorial writer for "The Freeman," "Commercial and Financial Chronicle" and "The Nation."<cite><a href="Macdonald, William.html">Macdonald, William</a></cite>
From 1924 to 1926 William Macdonald was visiting lecturer at Yale.<cite><a href="Macdonald, William.html">Macdonald, William</a></cite>
A reviewer called a later work, "The Menace of Recovery" (1934) "the most sizzling attack which the New Deal has yet received," and had this to say, "Mr. Macdonald, who in long years of teaching acquired that accent of bland and monumental authority which only American professors and the leading writers of ‘The London Times’ and the Paris ‘Temps’ command, learned in his later years as a radical editor of ‘The Nation’ the rhetoric of denunciation.<cite><a href="Macdonald, William.html">Macdonald, William</a></cite>
MacDonald died on December 15, 1938 in New York City.<cite><a href="Macdonald, William.html">Macdonald, William</a></cite>
The Brown University mace, a gift of Mrs. George St. John Sheffield in 1928, is 44 inches long.<cite><a href="Mace.html">Mace</a></cite>
The name of Charles Evans Hughes 1881 was added at a later date.<cite><a href="Mace.html">Mace</a></cite>
The staff, two feet long and made of curly maple and silver-plate over bronze, has a caduceus of two snakes cast in silver on a maple rod, on which is engraved "<a href="Brown Medical Association.html">Brown Medical Association</a> / <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> Marching Staff / Given May 26, 1985."<cite><a href="Mace.html">Mace</a></cite>
Machado House at 87 Prospect Street was formerly the Ellen Dexter Sharpe House, a two-and-one-half story brick Elizabethan Revival house designed by Parker, Thomas and Rice, and built as the Sharpe family home in 1912.<cite><a href="Machado House.html">Machado House</a></cite>
The house, property of the <a href="Rhode Island School of Design.html">Rhode Island School of Design</a> after Miss Sharpe’s death in 1953, was purchased by Brown in 1955 and used as a small dormitory for women students.<cite><a href="Machado House.html">Machado House</a></cite>
An extension at the rear of the building was designed by Steven L. Lerner and added in 1975.<cite><a href="Machado House.html">Machado House</a></cite>
At a ceremony on November 10, 1989 the building was formally renamed Antonio Machado House in honor of the Spanish poet.<cite><a href="Machado House.html">Machado House</a></cite>
A bust of Machado by sculptor Pablo Serrano acquired by the University in 1967 was moved from the <a href="Annmary Brown Memorial.html">Annmary Brown Memorial</a> to the garden of the house.<cite><a href="Machado House.html">Machado House</a></cite>
Andrew Hamilton MacPhail (1891-1981), professor of educational psychology, was born in Lawrence, Massachusetts, on August 16, 1891.<cite><a href="MacPhail, Andrew H..html">MacPhail, Andrew H.</a></cite>
Andrew H. MacPhail received a bachelor of philosophy degree from Brown in 1913, and a master of arts in 1914.<cite><a href="MacPhail, Andrew H..html">MacPhail, Andrew H.</a></cite>
Andrew H. MacPhail was the principal of schools in Conway and Quincy, Massachusetts from 1914 to 1920, and assistant professor of psychology at the State Teachers College at Terre Haute, Indiana, in 1920-21.<cite><a href="MacPhail, Andrew H..html">MacPhail, Andrew H.</a></cite>
In 1921 Andrew H. MacPhail became a research assistant in educational psychology at Brown and earned his Ph.D. degree in 1923, at which time he was appointed instructor.<cite><a href="MacPhail, Andrew H..html">MacPhail, Andrew H.</a></cite>
Andrew H. MacPhail was promoted to assistant professor in 1924, associate professor in 1931, and was named director of educational measurement in 1934.<cite><a href="MacPhail, Andrew H..html">MacPhail, Andrew H.</a></cite>
Andrew H. MacPhail's first publication was an article in 1920 on the effect of the removal of tonsils and adenoids on a child’s school work.<cite><a href="MacPhail, Andrew H..html">MacPhail, Andrew H.</a></cite>
Andrew H. MacPhail retired in 1956 and died on January 2, 1981 in Holyoke, Massachusetts.<cite><a href="MacPhail, Andrew H..html">MacPhail, Andrew H.</a></cite>
Maddock Alumni Center occupies the former home of Chancellor William Goddard 1846.<cite><a href="Maddock Alumni Center.html">Maddock Alumni Center</a></cite>
When the house was built for Charlotte Ives Goddard in the 1830s the main entrance was on George Street with two-way steps on the sidewalk.<cite><a href="Maddock Alumni Center.html">Maddock Alumni Center</a></cite>
Before William Goddard returned to the house in 1882, he had a large addition, of which Stone and Carpenter were the architects, added at the south end.<cite><a href="Maddock Alumni Center.html">Maddock Alumni Center</a></cite>
After William Goddard died in 1907, the house was opened only when Mrs. Iselin visited.<cite><a href="Maddock Alumni Center.html">Maddock Alumni Center</a></cite>
<a href="President.html">President</a> Faunce, in a letter thanking her for her hospitality in 1928, broached the possibility of her leaving the house to Brown University.<cite><a href="Maddock Alumni Center.html">Maddock Alumni Center</a></cite>
In 1940 Mrs. Iselin deeded the house to Brown in memory of her father.<cite><a href="Maddock Alumni Center.html">Maddock Alumni Center</a></cite>
The house was turned over to the University in 1966.<cite><a href="Maddock Alumni Center.html">Maddock Alumni Center</a></cite>
Mrs. Iselin died in 1970 at the age of 102.<cite><a href="Maddock Alumni Center.html">Maddock Alumni Center</a></cite>
The center was dedicated on May 1, 1974 and named for Paul L. Maddock ’33, principal donor to the cost of the renovation.<cite><a href="Maddock Alumni Center.html">Maddock Alumni Center</a></cite>
Named rooms on the first floor are the Brian Room, gift of Joseph A. Brian ’47; the Lanpher Room, gift of family and friends of the late <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> Edgar J. Lanpher ’19; the Goldberger Room, gift of Herbert H. Goldberger ’39; the Heritage Room, gift of Paul Maddock ’33, and the Class of 1933 Room, gift of the class on its fortieth reunion.<cite><a href="Maddock Alumni Center.html">Maddock Alumni Center</a></cite>
James Irving Manatt (1845-1915), professor of Greek literature and history, was born in Millersburg, Ohio, on February 17, 1845.<cite><a href="Manatt, James Irving.html">Manatt, James Irving</a></cite>
In 1864 James Irving Manatt was a private in the 46th Iowa infantry.<cite><a href="Manatt, James Irving.html">Manatt, James Irving</a></cite>
James Irving Manatt graduated from Iowa (now Grinnell) College in 1869 and received his Ph.D. from Yale in 1873.<cite><a href="Manatt, James Irving.html">Manatt, James Irving</a></cite>
From 1874 to 1876 James Irving Manatt was professor of Greek at Denison College.<cite><a href="Manatt, James Irving.html">Manatt, James Irving</a></cite>
The next year James Irving Manatt studied in Leipzig, and was then professor of Greek at Marietta College from 1877 to 1884.<cite><a href="Manatt, James Irving.html">Manatt, James Irving</a></cite>
James Irving Manatt was chancellor of the University of Nebraska from 1884 to 1889, and United States Consul at Athens from 1889 to 1893.<cite><a href="Manatt, James Irving.html">Manatt, James Irving</a></cite>
In 1893 James Irving Manatt became professor of Greek literature and history at Brown, a position he held until his sudden death from pneumonia on February 14, 1915 in Providence.<cite><a href="Manatt, James Irving.html">Manatt, James Irving</a></cite>
Horace Mann (1796-1859), "Father of our Public Schools," was born in Franklin, Massachusetts, on May 4, 1796.<cite><a href="Mann, Horace.html">Mann, Horace</a></cite>
Horace Mann is listed as a freshman in the "Catalogue of Officers and Students of Brown University" in October 1814, but apparently left, probably because of illness, as the next year’s "Catalogue" includes his name as a sophomore with the note, "Left college since the catalogue of 1814."<cite><a href="Mann, Horace.html">Mann, Horace</a></cite>
Horace Mann reentered in 1816 and graduated in 1819 as valedictorian of his class.<cite><a href="Mann, Horace.html">Mann, Horace</a></cite>
Horace Mann studied law with J. J. Fiske of Wrentham during the summer of 1819, after which he was appointed tutor in Latin and Greek at Brown.<cite><a href="Mann, Horace.html">Mann, Horace</a></cite>
In 1821 Horace Mann entered the law school of Judge James Gould at Litchfield, Connecticut.<cite><a href="Mann, Horace.html">Mann, Horace</a></cite>
Horace Mann opened his law practice in Dedham, Massachusetts, in 1823.<cite><a href="Mann, Horace.html">Mann, Horace</a></cite>
In 1830 Horace Mann married Charlotte Messer, to whom he had been devoted since college days, when she was the ten-year-old daughter of President Messer.<cite><a href="Mann, Horace.html">Mann, Horace</a></cite>
Having been elected to the Massachusetts Senate in 1827, Horace Mann was involved with the passage of legislation creating the State Board of Education and the first state insane asylum in the United States.<cite><a href="Mann, Horace.html">Mann, Horace</a></cite>
In 1837 Horace Mann began ten years as Secretary of the Massachusetts Board of Education, during which he promoted the common schools and the proper training of teachers.<cite><a href="Mann, Horace.html">Mann, Horace</a></cite>
Horace Mann brought about the establishment of the first state normal school in the United States, which was opened on July 3, 1839 in Lexington.<cite><a href="Mann, Horace.html">Mann, Horace</a></cite>
In 1843 Horace Mann married Mary T. Peabody, one of "Peabody sisters of Salem."<cite><a href="Mann, Horace.html">Mann, Horace</a></cite>
In 1848 Horace Mann was elected to the House of Representatives to fill the term of John Quincy Adams, who had died in office.<cite><a href="Mann, Horace.html">Mann, Horace</a></cite>
In 1853 Horace Mann became the president of Antioch College in Yellow Springs, Ohio, a new "experimental college," which was non-sectarian and coeducational.<cite><a href="Mann, Horace.html">Mann, Horace</a></cite>
Horace Mann continued as president until 1859, when he delivered his last baccalaureate address, which included the often quoted words, "I beseech you to treasure up in your hears these my parting words; be ashamed to die until you have won some victory for humanity."<cite><a href="Mann, Horace.html">Mann, Horace</a></cite>
Horace Mann died in Yellow Springs on August 2, 1859.<cite><a href="Mann, Horace.html">Mann, Horace</a></cite>
Manning Hall was built in 1834 at the expense of Nicholas Brown and named at his request for <a href="President.html">President</a> Manning.<cite><a href="Manning Hall.html">Manning Hall</a></cite>
It is said to have cost $18,500, and is an exact model, though twice the size, of the temple of Diana-Propylea in Eleusis, the plan having been obtained from a work published in 1817, entitled "The Unedited Antiquities of Attica, comprising the Architectural Remains of Eleusis, Rhamnus, and Thericus."<cite><a href="Manning Hall.html">Manning Hall</a></cite>
At the dedication of the building on February 4, 1835, <a href="President.html">President</a> Wayland delivered a discourse on the "Dependence of Science upon Revealed Religion."<cite><a href="Manning Hall.html">Manning Hall</a></cite>
Albert Gorton Greene 1820 composed an ode for the occasion, as did George Burgess 1826.<cite><a href="Manning Hall.html">Manning Hall</a></cite>
Wayland’s address was published with appended notes by Professor William Gammell describing the new building:  In a somewhat contradictory account written by Providence architect John Hutchens Cady ’03 in 1934 for the hundredth anniversary of the building, he wrote, "Two influences doubtless, were instrumental in causing its architect, James C.
