Bucklin, to design this building in accordance with Greek traditions, namely his familiarity with that style, as exemplified by the Arcade which he had recently designed in collaboration with Russell Warren, and his desire to give the hall an academic appearance."<cite><a href="Manning Hall.html">Manning Hall</a></cite>
Reuben Guild described in his "<a href="History.html">History</a> of Brown University" in 1867 how the shelves of the library extended from the columns in the middle of the room to the walls forming ten alcoves, and how already extra shelves had been built in every available space.<cite><a href="Manning Hall.html">Manning Hall</a></cite>
Photographs of the library in the 1870s show piles of books on the floor around the columns.<cite><a href="Manning Hall.html">Manning Hall</a></cite>
In 1874 Albert G. Upham was paid twenty dollars to play the organ for the academic year.<cite><a href="Manning Hall.html">Manning Hall</a></cite>
The chapel was redecorated in 1857 with funds from Robert Hale Ives and the late Moses Brown Ives and a marble tablet in memory of Nicholas Brown was placed on the east wall.<cite><a href="Manning Hall.html">Manning Hall</a></cite>
There was no basement until the 1850s when one was excavated.<cite><a href="Manning Hall.html">Manning Hall</a></cite>
The building was heated by stoves which were replaced by the introduction of steam heat in 1886; gas was introduced into the building about 1873.<cite><a href="Manning Hall.html">Manning Hall</a></cite>
The library removed to the new library building (now <a href="Robinson Hall.html">Robinson Hall</a>) in 1878, and, after the renovation of <a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a> in 1883, the president’s lecture room was located in the lower floor of Manning Hall.<cite><a href="Manning Hall.html">Manning Hall</a></cite>
The chapel remained, but was also being used for more mundane purposes as <a href="President.html">President</a> Robinson noted in his report of 1886, "The other than religious uses to which Manning Hall is not infrequently given up have stocked it with associations that are by no means congenial with the spirit of devotion."<cite><a href="Manning Hall.html">Manning Hall</a></cite>
<a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a> services were held in <a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a> after 1894, when the upper floor of Manning became a room for architectural and freehand drawing.<cite><a href="Manning Hall.html">Manning Hall</a></cite>
On March 8, 1959 Manning <a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a> was rededicated to its original function.<cite><a href="Manning Hall.html">Manning Hall</a></cite>
The first service in the restored chapel was held on February 15, 1959, the occasion being the Universal Day of Prayer for Students.<cite><a href="Manning Hall.html">Manning Hall</a></cite>
Henry Parker Manning (1859-1956), professor of mathematics, was born in Woodstock, Connecticut, on October 3, 1859.<cite><a href="Manning, Henry P..html">Manning, Henry P.</a></cite>
In 1883 Henry P. Manning graduated from Brown, having won the Hartshorn premium for entrance mathematics, the Howell premium for the highest record in mathematics and natural philosophy, and a Carpenter premium for "ability, character and attainment."<cite><a href="Manning, Henry P..html">Manning, Henry P.</a></cite>
In 1889 Henry P. Manning entered Johns Hopkins University to study mathematics, astronomy and physics.<cite><a href="Manning, Henry P..html">Manning, Henry P.</a></cite>
When Henry P. Manning received his Ph.D. degree in 1891, his first printed paper had already appeared in the "American Journal of Mathematics."<cite><a href="Manning, Henry P..html">Manning, Henry P.</a></cite>
From 1893 to 1908 Manning offered courses in higher mathematics never previously available at Brown, courses with names like "Theory of functions: algebraic functions, Riemann surfaces, and Abelian functions," "Substitutions and transformation groups," and "Quaternions, non-Euclidean geometry, and hyperspace."<cite><a href="Manning, Henry P..html">Manning, Henry P.</a></cite>
After 1908 there were others in the department able to teach higher mathematics.<cite><a href="Manning, Henry P..html">Manning, Henry P.</a></cite>
Henry P. Manning's publications included "Non-Euclidean Geometry" in 1901, the first English language text in this subject, "Irrational Numbers and their Representation by Sequences and Series" in 1906, and "Geometry of Four Dimensions" in 1914.<cite><a href="Manning, Henry P..html">Manning, Henry P.</a></cite>
Henry P. Manning retired in 1930 and spent several years as associate editor of the "American Mathematical Monthly."<cite><a href="Manning, Henry P..html">Manning, Henry P.</a></cite>
Henry P. Manning died in Providence on January 11, 1956, at the age of 96.<cite><a href="Manning, Henry P..html">Manning, Henry P.</a></cite>
James Manning (1738-1791), first president of Brown University, was born October 22, 1738 in Piscataway, New Jersey, the son of James and Grace (Fitz-Randolph) Manning.<cite><a href="Manning, James.html">Manning, James</a></cite>
James Manning studied at the Latin Grammar School conducted by Isaac Eaton in Hopewell, New Jersey, and graduated second in a class of 21 from the College of New Jersey (Princeton University) in 1762.<cite><a href="Manning, James.html">Manning, James</a></cite>
James Manning was licensed to preach by the Scotch Plains Baptist Church, February 6, 1763, and ordained April 19, 1763.<cite><a href="Manning, James.html">Manning, James</a></cite>
James Manning married Margaret Stites on March 23, 1763.<cite><a href="Manning, James.html">Manning, James</a></cite>
The college was chartered March 3, 1764.<cite><a href="Manning, James.html">Manning, James</a></cite>
In April 1764 Manning opened a Latin school in Warren, Rhode Island, and became the first pastor of the Warren Baptist Church founded in November 1764.<cite><a href="Manning, James.html">Manning, James</a></cite>
In September 1765 James Manning was elected the first president of Rhode Island College.<cite><a href="Manning, James.html">Manning, James</a></cite>
Manning was the only professor until 1767, when the increase in students presented a need for an additional instructor.<cite><a href="Manning, James.html">Manning, James</a></cite>
<a href="Howell, David.html">David Howell</a>, a graduate of the College of New Jersey was engaged as a tutor and was appointed professor of natural philosophy in 1769.<cite><a href="Manning, James.html">Manning, James</a></cite>
In September 1769 the first Commencement was held.<cite><a href="Manning, James.html">Manning, James</a></cite>
The College Edifice was built in Providence in 1770, and Manning moved to Providence and lived in Benjamin Bowen’s house while the president’s house was being built.<cite><a href="Manning, James.html">Manning, James</a></cite>
The Revolutionary War soon interrupted the life of the College, when the Edifice was taken over from December 7, 1776 to May 27, 1782, and used as barracks and as a hospital by American and French troops, and left in dilapidated condition.<cite><a href="Manning, James.html">Manning, James</a></cite>
On April 29, 1779 he left Providence with Mrs. Manning, and traveled to Philadelphia, visiting relatives in New York and New Jersey, preaching in churches along the way, and returning to Providence on September 29, at which time he wrote in his journal, "Reached Providence at six o’clock, the road better than usual; being just five months to an hour absent from home."<cite><a href="Manning, James.html">Manning, James</a></cite>
<a href="Howell, David.html">David Howell</a> had resigned as professor in 1779, leaving the College with no faculty other than the president.<cite><a href="Manning, James.html">Manning, James</a></cite>
In 1783 John Brown offered to pay half the price of a "compleat Philosophical Apparatus &amp; Library," and the other half was quickly raised.<cite><a href="Manning, James.html">Manning, James</a></cite>
In 1784 two professors were appointed, Joseph Brown as professor of experimental philosophy, and <a href="Waterhouse, Benjamin.html">Benjamin Waterhouse</a> as professor of natural history, both of whom "engaged to give Lectures in their respective Branches, without any Expence to the College while destitute of an Endowment."<cite><a href="Manning, James.html">Manning, James</a></cite>
A Commencement was held in 1783 for six graduates, who had been students before the war or had studied privately with Manning, but it was not until 1786 that more students were ready for graduation.<cite><a href="Manning, James.html">Manning, James</a></cite>
The number of students increased steadily from twenty in 1784 to fifty in 1786.<cite><a href="Manning, James.html">Manning, James</a></cite>
In 1786 Manning was appointed by a unanimous resolution of the General Assembly to represent Rhode Island in the Congress of the Confederation.<cite><a href="Manning, James.html">Manning, James</a></cite>
James Manning explained his reasons for accepting the appointment in a letter to Reverend John Rippon in England on April 7, 1786, "Pray, don’t be alarmed should you hear that I am in Congress.<cite><a href="Manning, James.html">Manning, James</a></cite>
On November 12, 1785 he wrote to Reverend <a href="Jones, Samuel.html">Samuel Jones</a>, who was establishing a school in Kentucky: He also at times took boarders, among them two sons of Robert Carter of Nomony Hall in Virginia, who wrote to Manning in February 1786 of George and John Tasker Carter, "they to be Sent from Boston immediately upon their Arrival there to your College in Providence.<cite><a href="Manning, James.html">Manning, James</a></cite>
The Marcus Aurelius statue which stands at the rear of <a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a>, facing Thayer Street through the <a href="Soldiers Memorial Gate.html">Soldiers Memorial Gate</a>, was unveiled on June 1, 1908.<cite><a href="Marcus Aurelius.html">Marcus Aurelius</a></cite>
The equestrian statue, a copy of the one on Capitoline Hill in Rome, was presented by Col. Robert Hale Ives Goddard 1858 on behalf of his deceased brother Moses Brown Ives Goddard 1854.<cite><a href="Marcus Aurelius.html">Marcus Aurelius</a></cite>
William Learned Marcy (1786-1857), Secretary of State of the United States, was born in Sturbridge (the part which is now Southbridge), Massachusetts on December 12, 1786.<cite><a href="Marcy, William L..html">Marcy, William L.</a></cite>
The son of a farmer, William L. Marcy studied at Leicester Academy and graduated from Brown in 1808.<cite><a href="Marcy, William L..html">Marcy, William L.</a></cite>
In the War of 1812 William L. Marcy was a lieutenant in a military company which in October 1812 captured a company of Canadian militia at St. Regis.<cite><a href="Marcy, William L..html">Marcy, William L.</a></cite>
In 1816 William L. Marcy was appointed Recorder of Troy, an office from which he was removed in 1818 after he criticized Governor DeWitt Clinton’s administration in the Albany "Argus."<cite><a href="Marcy, William L..html">Marcy, William L.</a></cite>
Marcy was appointed Adjutant General of New York in 1821 and State Comptroller in 1823.<cite><a href="Marcy, William L..html">Marcy, William L.</a></cite>
In 1829 William L. Marcy was appointed a justice of the New York Supreme Court.<cite><a href="Marcy, William L..html">Marcy, William L.</a></cite>
Marcy’s expenses for this special circuit were paid by the state, and Marcy, like a good former Comptroller, accounted for every expenditure, including, to his later embarrassment this item: "For mending my pantaloons, 50 cents," which was dug up by his political opponents to ridicule him during his campaign for governor in 1832.<cite><a href="Marcy, William L..html">Marcy, William L.</a></cite>
William L. Marcy was elected to the United States Senate in 1831 and served until his resignation in 1833 to take office as Governor, just long enough to make another quotable faux pas.<cite><a href="Marcy, William L..html">Marcy, William L.</a></cite>
In 1840, Van Buren appointed Marcy one of the commissioners under the convention with Mexico for the adjustment of claims.<cite><a href="Marcy, William L..html">Marcy, William L.</a></cite>
In 1845, James K. Polk appointed him Secretary of War.<cite><a href="Marcy, William L..html">Marcy, William L.</a></cite>
Between 1849 and 1853, William L. Marcy held no public office, and spent his time on politics, reading, and playing whist with his political foe Thurlow Weed.<cite><a href="Marcy, William L..html">Marcy, William L.</a></cite>
William L. Marcy was a leading candidate for the Democratic nomination for president in 1852, but lost on the forty-ninth ballot to Franklin Pierce.<cite><a href="Marcy, William L..html">Marcy, William L.</a></cite>
Marcy negotiated the Canadian reciprocity treaty in 1854, sought the annexation of the Hawaiian Islands, promoted the abolition of the Danish Sound dues, urged the free navigation of international streams, and favored the annexation of Cuba if this could be accomplished without war.<cite><a href="Marcy, William L..html">Marcy, William L.</a></cite>
William L. Marcy also composed on June 1, 1853 a circular in which diplomatic representatives of the United States were encouraged to be received by foreign governments "as far as practicable ... in the simple dress of an American citizen."<cite><a href="Marcy, William L..html">Marcy, William L.</a></cite>
After leaving the Department of State in March 1857, Marcy planned a trip to Europe with Hamilton Fish.<cite><a href="Marcy, William L..html">Marcy, William L.</a></cite>
Mount Marcy, 5,343 feet high, the highest peak in the Adirondacks and the highest mountain in New York State, was named in 1836 by Professor Ebenezer Emmons of the New York Geological Survey in honor of Marcy, when he was governor of New York.<cite><a href="Marcy, William L..html">Marcy, William L.</a></cite>
Marston <a href="Boat House.html">Boat House</a> was dedicated on October 7, 1967.<cite><a href="Marston Boat House.html">Marston Boat House</a></cite>
The former plant of the Saltesea Packing Company at the foot of Gano Street just south of the Washington Bridge was purchased by the University in 1966 with funds given by Hunter S. Marston ’08.<cite><a href="Marston Boat House.html">Marston Boat House</a></cite>
In 1970 a 48 by 32 feet rowing tank to accommodate sixteen crew members at one time was erected adjacent to the boat house.<cite><a href="Marston Boat House.html">Marston Boat House</a></cite>
Marston Field House was provided in 1907 by Edgar L. Marston, father of Hunter S. Marston ’08, who was then manager of the track team.<cite><a href="Marston Field House.html">Marston Field House</a></cite>
The building, designed by Welles Bosworth of New York City, architect of the J. P. Morgan <a href="Library.html">Library</a>, is of Indiana limestone and has on either side of its main entrance the original seal of the College and the third and permanent seal adopted in 1834.<cite><a href="Marston Hall.html">Marston Hall</a></cite>
Webster Knight 1876 contributed $10,000 for furnishing the building.<cite><a href="Marston Hall.html">Marston Hall</a></cite>
A room on the second floor was named the Williams-Conant Seminary of German Literature, commemorating the library instituted by Alonzo Williams in 1890, to which Hezekiah Conant was the chief donor.<cite><a href="Marston Hall.html">Marston Hall</a></cite>
The building was dedicated on the same day as <a href="Hegeman Hall.html">Hegeman Hall</a>, October 13, 1926.<cite><a href="Marston Hall.html">Marston Hall</a></cite>
Frederick William Marvel (1869-1938), first director of intercollegiate athletics at Brown, was born in Rehoboth, Massachusetts, on Christmas Day 1869.<cite><a href="Marvel, Frederick W..html">Marvel, Frederick W.</a></cite>
Frederick W. Marvel graduated in 1894.<cite><a href="Marvel, Frederick W..html">Marvel, Frederick W.</a></cite>
Frederick W. Marvel was instructor in drawing and physical culture at Brown from 1894 to 1896, then became Director of Athletics and Professor of Physical Education at Wesleyan University for six years.<cite><a href="Marvel, Frederick W..html">Marvel, Frederick W.</a></cite>
Frederick W. Marvel came back to Brown in 1903 as Director of Physical Culture, a title which was soon changed to Director of Physical Education.<cite><a href="Marvel, Frederick W..html">Marvel, Frederick W.</a></cite>
When Frederick W. Marvel assumed his duties in 1903, Brown participated in three intercollegiate sports and had little in the way of equipment.<cite><a href="Marvel, Frederick W..html">Marvel, Frederick W.</a></cite>
Marvel had become known as the dean of college athletic directors, and in 1934 was elected to fellowship in the American Physical Education Association.<cite><a href="Marvel, Frederick W..html">Marvel, Frederick W.</a></cite>
Frederick W. Marvel died on August 21, 1938 in Richmond, Rhode Island.<cite><a href="Marvel, Frederick W..html">Marvel, Frederick W.</a></cite>
Marvel Gymnasium was built in 1927 on Elmgrove Avenue across the street from the <a href="Stadium.html">Stadium</a>, and adjacent to <a href="Aldrich Field.html">Aldrich Field</a>.<cite><a href="Marvel Gymnasium.html">Marvel Gymnasium</a></cite>
The opening of the gym on the scheduled date of September 1, 1927 was delayed by strikes.<cite><a href="Marvel Gymnasium.html">Marvel Gymnasium</a></cite>
It opened, unfinished, on December 16 with a basketball game against Harvard, and was actually completed in 1928.<cite><a href="Marvel Gymnasium.html">Marvel Gymnasium</a></cite>
Brown won the opening game, 33-30, and the first balls were thrown out, one to captain John Heffernan ’28 and one to the Harvard captain, by Henry L. Aldrich 1876 and Charles T. Aldrich 1877, whose generosity had made possible the acquisition of the site for the gymnasium and the adjacent playing fields.<cite><a href="Marvel Gymnasium.html">Marvel Gymnasium</a></cite>
At first known as the Brown Gymnasium, the building was rededicated at the fourth annual Alumni Day dinner in the gymnasium on October 7, 1938, by Vice-president James P. Adams as a memorial to the recently deceased Frederick Marvel, which "for as long as it shall endure ... shall be known as the Frederick William Marvel Gymnasium in memory of a loyal son of Brown who gave a lifetime in her service."<cite><a href="Marvel Gymnasium.html">Marvel Gymnasium</a></cite>
Marvel Gym celebrated its fiftieth anniversary in December 1977.<cite><a href="Marvel Gymnasium.html">Marvel Gymnasium</a></cite>
With the opening of the <a href="Pizzitola Sports Center.html">Pizzitola Sports Center</a> in 1989, Marvel Gym had outlived its usefulness and closed its doors in February 1989.<cite><a href="Marvel Gymnasium.html">Marvel Gymnasium</a></cite>
The Materials Research Laboratory, devoted to the study of the capabilities of existing materials and the search for new types of materials, was established in 1962.<cite><a href="Materials Research Laboratory.html">Materials Research Laboratory</a></cite>
The Advanced Research Projects Agency of the Defense Department (ARPA) entered a $3.5 million contract with Brown in 1961 for materials research to be conducted by the Departments of <a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a> and <a href="Physics.html">Physics</a> and the Divisions of Applied <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a> and <a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a>.<cite><a href="Materials Research Laboratory.html">Materials Research Laboratory</a></cite>
In 1969 Heller became director of the Laboratory with physics professor Charles Elbaum as associate director.<cite><a href="Materials Research Laboratory.html">Materials Research Laboratory</a></cite>
In 1967 ARPA initiated a program which brought together twelve major universities in a cooperative search for new materials with "super-properties."<cite><a href="Materials Research Laboratory.html">Materials Research Laboratory</a></cite>
In 1973 the National Science Foundation took over funding of the laboratory and directed the definition of specific targets of its research.<cite><a href="Materials Research Laboratory.html">Materials Research Laboratory</a></cite>
In 1977 the laboratory was awarded a three-year $4.72 million grant from the National Science Foundation to explore the development of lightweight high-strength metals resistant to corrosion and extreme temperatures, and electronic materials for lasers and solar cells.<cite><a href="Materials Research Laboratory.html">Materials Research Laboratory</a></cite>
The Laws of 1783 required that the applicant for admission shall have "learned the rules of ... Vulgar Arithmetic."<cite><a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a></cite>
In 1828 the annual catalogue noted that an entering student "must be well acquainted with ... Colburn’s Algebra, as far as Quadratick Equations."<cite><a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a></cite>
According to the Laws of 1793, students were exposed to "Fennings Arithmetic, Hammonds Algebra, Stones Euclid, Martins Trigonometry, Loves Surveying, Wilsons Navigation," but not until the third year of their studies, the first two having been occupied largely by the <a href="Classics.html">Classics</a>, rhetoric, and oratory.<cite><a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a></cite>
The professors of mathematics during the first hundred years included Benjamin West, who lectured from 1786 to 1798, Asa Messer whose title was professor of mathematics and natural philosophy from 1799 to 1802 and who continued to teach after becoming president in 1802, Jasper Adams from 1819 to 1824, Alva Woods from 1824 to 1828, Alexis Caswell from 1828 to 1863, and Samuel Stillman Greene from 1855 to 1864.<cite><a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a></cite>
Immediately after his graduation in 1863, Benjamin F. Clarke became instructor in mathematics, advancing to professor of mathematics and civil engineering in 1868.<cite><a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a></cite>
Nathaniel French Davis 1870 returned to Brown in 1874 as instructor in mathematics and remained until 1915, being named professor of pure mathematics in 1890.<cite><a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a></cite>
In 1874-75 the study of logic was removed from the professorship of rhetoric and was joined to mathematics.<cite><a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a></cite>
Henry Parker Manning 1883 introduced previously unavailable courses in higher mathematics at Brown, when he returned after earning his Ph.D. degree at Johns Hopkins in 1891.<cite><a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a></cite>
Clinton Currier 1898, who began as an instructor in 1899, added astronomy to his teaching duties in 1914.<cite><a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a></cite>
In 1907 Professor Roland G. D. Richardson came to Brown from Nova Scotia by way of Yale.<cite><a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a></cite>
He was chairman of the department from 1914 to 1942, and secretary of the American Mathematical Society from 1921 to 1940.<cite><a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a></cite>
Appointments during Richardson’s chairmanship included Raymond C. Archibald, also from Nova Scotia, in 1907, C. Raymond Adams ’18 in 1918, Ray E. Gilman in 1919, and Albert A. Bennett ’10 in 1927.<cite><a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a></cite>
Jacob D. Tamarkin came from Russia in 1927 and taught until 1946.<cite><a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a></cite>
Between 1933 and 1935 Hans Lewy and Otto Szasz taught at Brown under the provision of the Emergency Committee in Aid of Displaced German Scholars.<cite><a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a></cite>
George Polya from Hungary was a visiting professor from 1940 to 1942.<cite><a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a></cite>
<a href="President.html">President</a> Wriston announced in his annual report in June 1939:  In the summer of 1941 a Program of Advanced Instruction and Research in Mechanics was organized by Professor Richardson with the support of the U.S. Office of <a href="Education.html">Education</a> and the Carnegie Foundation.<cite><a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a></cite>
Professor C. Raymond Adams was chairman of the Department of Mathematics from 1942 to 1960.<cite><a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a></cite>
New additions to the faculty were Bjarni Jonsson and Herbert Federer in 1946, Frank M. Stewart in 1947, and E.H. Lee in 1948.<cite><a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a></cite>
A program leading to the Bachelor of Science degree in Mathematics was initiated in 1969 for students who wished to add more study in science to the pure mathematics program.<cite><a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a></cite>
The Mathematics Department moved in 1952 to the old Delta Kappa Epsilon house, which was renamed <a href="Howell House.html">Howell House</a>.<cite><a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a></cite>
The next move in 1961, necessitated by the impending razing of <a href="Howell House.html">Howell House</a> to make room for the Rockefeller <a href="Library.html">Library</a>, was to 155 Thayer Street, where the department occupied half a house which was given the name of <a href="Howell House.html">Howell House</a>, the other half of which was already named <a href="Ames House.html">Ames House</a>.<cite><a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a></cite>
In time the Mathematics Department used the whole house, and was finally given a spacious home in <a href="Kassar House.html">Kassar House</a> with its new addition in 1990.<cite><a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a></cite>
Maxcy Hall was built in 1895 as the University’s answer to the need of more dormitory rooms and also more recitation rooms.<cite><a href="Maxcy Hall.html">Maxcy Hall</a></cite>
In 1907 the <a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a> Department was using the second floor.<cite><a href="Maxcy Hall.html">Maxcy Hall</a></cite>
In 1913 the Bureau of Plant Industry of the United States Department of Agriculture was given space for a branch laboratory for forest pathology.<cite><a href="Maxcy Hall.html">Maxcy Hall</a></cite>
In 1938, after the construction of the <a href="Metcalf Chemical Laboratory.html">Metcalf Chemical Laboratory</a>, the <a href="Botany.html">Botany</a> Department inherited <a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a>’s old quarters in <a href="Rogers Hall.html">Rogers Hall</a>, and Maxcy Hall was turned into a dormitory.<cite><a href="Maxcy Hall.html">Maxcy Hall</a></cite>
Maxcy Hall continued to be used as a dormitory until 1959.<cite><a href="Maxcy Hall.html">Maxcy Hall</a></cite>
Jonathan Maxcy (1768-1820), second president of Brown University, was born in Attleboro, Massachusetts on September 2, 1768.<cite><a href="Maxcy, Jonathan.html">Maxcy, Jonathan</a></cite>
Jonathan Maxcy entered the College from <a href="Williams, William.html">William Williams</a>’ Academy in Wrentham at the age of fifteen and graduated in 1787.<cite><a href="Maxcy, Jonathan.html">Maxcy, Jonathan</a></cite>
Jonathan Maxcy was baptized by President Manning in 1789, and licensed to preach by the First Baptist Church in Providence on April 1, 1790.<cite><a href="Maxcy, Jonathan.html">Maxcy, Jonathan</a></cite>
After Manning’s death on July 29, 1791, Jonathan Maxcy was requested by the Corporation at the annual meeting in September "as often as he conveniently can without interfering with his duties as Pastor of the Church he serves to attend &amp; accasionly (sic) Lecture on Sundays Morning &amp; Eveng.<cite><a href="Maxcy, Jonathan.html">Maxcy, Jonathan</a></cite>
On September 8, 1791, Jonathan Maxcy was ordained as pastor of the First Baptist Church, and on the same day elected a trustee of the College and appointed professor of divinity.<cite><a href="Maxcy, Jonathan.html">Maxcy, Jonathan</a></cite>
In September 1792 Jonathan Maxcy was elected president "pro tempore," being given a trial period because of his youth.<cite><a href="Maxcy, Jonathan.html">Maxcy, Jonathan</a></cite>
In September 1797 Jonathan Maxcy was formally elected president.<cite><a href="Maxcy, Jonathan.html">Maxcy, Jonathan</a></cite>
In 1802 Maxcy resigned to become president of Union College in Schenectady, New York, succeeding Reverend Jonathan Edwards.<cite><a href="Maxcy, Jonathan.html">Maxcy, Jonathan</a></cite>
Jonathan Maxcy died at Columbia on June 4, 1820.<cite><a href="Maxcy, Jonathan.html">Maxcy, Jonathan</a></cite>
The "<a href="Sepiad.html">Sepiad</a>" for May 1901 notes that the annual May Festival of the Young Women’s Christian Association had occurred from 4 to 10 on May 15.<cite><a href="May Day.html">May Day</a></cite>
The "<a href="Sepiad.html">Sepiad</a>" for June 1912 had the following account of May Day, which had been planned by the <a href="Brownies.html">Brownies</a>.<cite><a href="May Day.html">May Day</a></cite>
In 1914 every freshman presented her senior with a May basket.<cite><a href="May Day.html">May Day</a></cite>
May Day of 1915 was described as "the best organized May Stunt we have had," with three heralds in brown, wearing the bear rampant, leading a procession of "personages of every county and every class, from the fair Queen of the May to tinkers and sailors."<cite><a href="May Day.html">May Day</a></cite>
The next year there were Dutch children, a gypsy, and nymphs to perform before queen Margaret Corey ’16, the Komians presented scenes from "As You Like It," and the Class of 1918 was "conspicuous by its absence."<cite><a href="May Day.html">May Day</a></cite>
In 1918 the sophomore masque, which had been performed by that class since 1907, became part of May Day.<cite><a href="May Day.html">May Day</a></cite>
A combined celebration of <a href="Spring Day.html">Spring Day</a> and May Day was held in 1942.<cite><a href="May Day.html">May Day</a></cite>
In the fall of 1943 a Harvest Queen was crowned, for the benefit of seniors who were graduating in October or February under the accelerated system and would miss the traditional May Day.<cite><a href="May Day.html">May Day</a></cite>
The May Day festivities became part of the Mother-Daughter Weekend in the 1950s and were last held in 1967.<cite><a href="May Day.html">May Day</a></cite>
The McIntyre Medal was awarded for the first time in 1989, when <a href="President.html">President</a> Gregorian, presiding at his first <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a>, made an unscheduled announcement.<cite><a href="McIntyre Medal.html">McIntyre Medal</a></cite>
McIntyre had been assistant to six presidents since 1947.<cite><a href="McIntyre Medal.html">McIntyre Medal</a></cite>
In 1967 he became secretary to the Advisory and Executive Committee of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a>, and later became secretary of the Board of Fellows.<cite><a href="McIntyre Medal.html">McIntyre Medal</a></cite>
Albert Davis Mead (1869-1946), professor of biology and vice-president of Brown University, was born in Swanton, Vermont on April 15, 1869.<cite><a href="Mead, Albert D..html">Mead, Albert D.</a></cite>
Mead graduated from Middlebury College in 1890.<cite><a href="Mead, Albert D..html">Mead, Albert D.</a></cite>
There Albert D. Mead met Brown professor <a href="Bumpus, Hermon Carey.html">Hermon Carey Bumpus</a> and came back to Brown with him to receive an A.M. degree in 1891.<cite><a href="Mead, Albert D..html">Mead, Albert D.</a></cite>
Albert D. Mead went on to study at Clark University under C. O. Whitman, whom he followed to the University of Chicago in 1893.<cite><a href="Mead, Albert D..html">Mead, Albert D.</a></cite>
After earning his Ph.D. degree at Chicago in 1895, Mead returned to Brown as instructor in comparative anatomy.<cite><a href="Mead, Albert D..html">Mead, Albert D.</a></cite>
In 1900 Albert D. Mead was named professor of comparative anatomy and was named chairman of that department in 1901 on the resignation of Professor <a href="Bumpus, Hermon Carey.html">Hermon Carey Bumpus</a>.<cite><a href="Mead, Albert D..html">Mead, Albert D.</a></cite>
In 1905, after the death of Professor <a href="Packard, Alpheus S..html">Alpheus S. Packard</a>, Albert D. Mead became chairman of the reorganized Department of Biology and in 1908 his title was changed to professor of biology.<cite><a href="Mead, Albert D..html">Mead, Albert D.</a></cite>
Albert D. Mead married Ada Wing, who taught biology to women students from 1896 to 1901.<cite><a href="Mead, Albert D..html">Mead, Albert D.</a></cite>
In 1925 Mead was appointed vice-president of the University to assist President Faunce and continued in that position during the presidency of <a href="Barbour, Clarence A..html">Clarence Barbour</a>.<cite><a href="Mead, Albert D..html">Mead, Albert D.</a></cite>
Albert D. Mead retired in 1936 and died in Pasadena, California, on December 8, 1946.<cite><a href="Mead, Albert D..html">Mead, Albert D.</a></cite>
Medical <a href="Education.html">Education</a> began at Brown in 1811.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
The medical instruction which was given from that date until 1827 is often referred to as the "Medical School," but it was, in fact, not a separate school, and was called at the time of its existence the "Medical Department," or, more accurately, the "Medical Lectures in Brown University."<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
In the beginning, there were three professors, Solomon Drowne 1773, professor of materia medica and botany, William Ingalls, professor of anatomy and surgery, and William Corlis Bowen 1803, professor of chemistry.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
Ingalls had received a medical degree from Harvard in 1794, had a practice in Boston, and came to Providence to deliver his lectures.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
He resigned his position in 1816.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
Solomon Drowne, after service in the Revolution, had received a bachelor of medicine degree from the College of Philadelphia in 1781.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
He was also awarded the first medical degree from Brown University, an honorary doctor of medicine in 1804.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
William Bowen 1803, a fourth-generation physician in the Bowen family in America, had left Brown, graduated from Union College in 1803, and received his medical degree at Edinburgh in 1807.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
He resigned as professor of chemistry in 1813, and his death two years later was said to be from a respiratory disease brought on by chemical experimentation.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
Providence physician John Mathewson Eddy, to whom Brown awarded an honorary M.D. degree in 1815, was adjunct professor of anatomy and surgery from 1815 until his death in 1817.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
In 1815 Levi Wheaton 1782 was appointed professor of the theory and practice of physic.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
In 1782 he received his degree, which he had requested on the basis of his service and continuing education during the war.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
He studied medicine privately and was awarded an honorary M.D. by Brown in 1812.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
Usher Parsons was appointed adjunct professor of anatomy and surgery in 1822, and professor in 1823.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
He had studied medicine with Dr. John Warren of Boston, been a navy surgeon in the War of 1812, earned an M.D. degree at Harvard in 1818, and taught anatomy and surgery at Dartmouth from 1820 to 1822.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
When Francis Wayland arrived as president in 1827, he was determined to improve the discipline in the college, and convinced the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> to vote in March 1827 that thereafter no member of the faculty should receive his salary unless he occupied a room in the college and helped to preserve order among the students.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
The medical department was not blameless in the state of disruption into which the college has fallen, according to Usher Parsons’ son, Charles W. Parsons, in a paper read before the Rhode Island Historical Society in 1881: As the medical professors depended for their livelihood on their active medical practices, they were unable to comply with the condition of their employment at the college, and the medical school went out of existence.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
In a letter written on June 17, 1827, Wayland asked Usher Parsons to inform the New England medical community that medical courses at Brown had been suspended.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
In his annual report for 1911, <a href="President.html">President</a> Faunce justified his continuing resistance to entreaties to establish a medical school, when he wrote, "A medical school, if first-class, requires enormous expenditure; if not first-class, it is a public menace."<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
On June 19, 1944, the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> voted to establish a Department of Medical Sciences "for instruction and research in the medical sciences ... the importance of health and hygiene ... a better orientation for students who are preparing for the art and science of medicine ... opportunity for advanced study ... cooperation of the University with the Hospitals of the community in programs of post-graduate education."<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
A medical convocation was held in the <a href="Faunce House.html">Faunce House</a> Theatre on August 9, 1944, to inaugurate the new department.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
The Haffenreffer Fellowship was established by the R. F. Haffenreffer Family Foundation and was awarded to Dr. William J. Fisher in 1945-56 and to Dr. Michael DiMaio and Dr. Robert Lewis in 1947-48.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
In 1945 Dr. McDonald was given the title of Director of Health Services, and in 1947 Dr. Burgess’ title was changed to Professor of Medical Science.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
The department, however, quietly disappeared, and <a href="President.html">President</a> Wriston announced to the Advisory and Executive Committee on December 8, 1950, that the Department of Medical Science had been discontinued.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
In 1957 Brown was selected as one of fourteen child-study centers by the National Collaborative Study of Cerebral Palsy, Mental Retardation and Other Sensory and Psychological Defects.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
In the late 1950s, through the efforts of Professor J. Walter Wilson and Congressman John E. Fogarty, the Institute for Research in the Health Sciences was established at Brown with Glidden L. Brooks as director.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
From this Institute the concept of a medical school grew, and in 1960 <a href="President.html">President</a> Barnaby Keeney appointed a committee to consider the feasibility of a program in medical education.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
In 1963 the six-year program leading to the degree of Master of Medical Science was inaugurated with a grant of over a million dollars from the W. K. Kellogg Foundation.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
The medical graduates of the classes of 1969 through 1972 all transferred to the third year of conventional medical schools.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
In 1969 the University signed an agreement of affiliation with five local hospitals – Rhode Island Hospital, Roger Williams General Hospital, Miriam Hospital, Lying-In Hospital (now Women and Infants Hospital), and Memorial Hospital of Pawtucket (now Memorial Hospital of Rhode Island).<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
Professor Mac V. Edds became chairman of the new Division of Medicine, and in 1965 became Director of Medicine in the Division of Biological and Medical Sciences.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
In 1972 a program in medicine leading to the Doctor of Medicine degree was incorporated into the Division of <a href="Biology.html">Biology</a> and Medicine with provisional accreditation and an entering class of sixty.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
Full accreditation as a four-year medical school was granted in 1975, and 58 students (thirteen of whom were women) received their M.D. degree in June of that year.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
In 1976 an early identification admission program was initiated with the University of Rhode Island, Providence College, and <a href="Tougaloo College.html">Tougaloo College</a>.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
In 1980 an agreement was reached between the Brown Medical Program and Dartmouth Medical School, which did not have facilities for the clinical education of the number of students it wished to admit.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
In 1984 an extra large class of 75 was admitted of which 50.7 per cent were women and 34.2 per cent were minority students.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
The new Program in Liberal Medical <a href="Education.html">Education</a> (PLME), initiated in 1984-85, is an eight-year continuum beginning in the freshman year, which involves six years of pre-medical and other undergraduate courses and two years of clinical work.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
Regular admission of college graduates into the medical program was discontinued in 1986-87, after which students have been admitted as freshmen or as transfers from other medical schools at the beginning of the clinical years.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
The Center for Gerontology was established in 1980.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
The Centers for Alcohol Studies and for Health Care Research were established in 1983.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
The Division of <a href="Biology.html">Biology</a> and Medicine, which had been formed as a single department in 1968 was reorganized in 1985 into two administrative units, the Program in <a href="Biology.html">Biology</a> and the Program in Medicine.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
A family medicine residency program in conjunction with Memorial Hospital was initiated in 1975.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
In 1978 a new undergraduate concentration, Health and Society, open to premedical students and others, was created, with a curriculum in the three major areas of health behavior and the social conditions of illness, the organization of health services, and research methods as appled to health services.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
Pierre M. Galletti, who had been chairman of the Division of Biological and Medical Sciences since 1968, was named Vice-<a href="President.html">President</a> for <a href="Biology.html">Biology</a> and Medicine in 1972.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
Stanley M. Aronson was appointed <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> of Medical Affairs in 1973, and was <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> of Medicine from 1976 to 1981.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
David S. Greer was <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> of Medicine from 1981 to 1992.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
The International Health Institute was created in 1988 to coordinate efforts at the University to improve health services to the world’s population.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
In 1991 "U.S. News and World Report," in an article rating graduate programs in the United States, ranked Brown number one of 66 medical schools specializing in primary care.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
In October 1991 the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> voted to change the name of the Program in Medicine to the Brown University School of Medicine.<cite><a href="Medical education.html">Medical education</a></cite>
Meehan Auditorium was dedicated at the Brown-Princeton hockey game on January 6, 1962.<cite><a href="Meehan Auditorium.html">Meehan Auditorium</a></cite>
There are 2100 permanent seats painted brown, red and yellow, the colors in the Brown coat of arms.<cite><a href="Meehan Auditorium.html">Meehan Auditorium</a></cite>
Alexander Meiklejohn (1872-1964), professor of philosophy and dean of the college, was born in Rochdale, England, on February 1, 1872.<cite><a href="Meiklejohn, Alexander.html">Meiklejohn, Alexander</a></cite>
Alexander Meiklejohn graduated from Brown in 1893.<cite><a href="Meiklejohn, Alexander.html">Meiklejohn, Alexander</a></cite>
Alexander Meiklejohn earned his master’s degree in philosophy at Brown under the Scottish <a href="Seth, James.html">James Seth</a> in 1895 and followed Seth to Cornell to earn his Ph.D. in 1897.<cite><a href="Meiklejohn, Alexander.html">Meiklejohn, Alexander</a></cite>
Alexander Meiklejohn became instructor in philosophy at Brown in 1897 and was promoted to assistant professor in 1899.<cite><a href="Meiklejohn, Alexander.html">Meiklejohn, Alexander</a></cite>
Alexander Meiklejohn was promoted to professor of logic and metaphysics in 1903.<cite><a href="Meiklejohn, Alexander.html">Meiklejohn, Alexander</a></cite>
In 1901 Alexander Meiklejohn became the second Dean of the University, succeeding <a href="Upton, Winslow.html">Winslow Upton</a>, who had served in that capacity for fewer than two years.<cite><a href="Meiklejohn, Alexander.html">Meiklejohn, Alexander</a></cite>
As dean until 1912 Alexander Meiklejohn was involved with discipline, athletics, and social life.<cite><a href="Meiklejohn, Alexander.html">Meiklejohn, Alexander</a></cite>
In 1904 Alexander Meiklejohn had an opportunity to demonstrate standing by a principle.<cite><a href="Meiklejohn, Alexander.html">Meiklejohn, Alexander</a></cite>
In 1913 Alexander Meiklejohn became president of Amherst College.<cite><a href="Meiklejohn, Alexander.html">Meiklejohn, Alexander</a></cite>
When Alexander Meiklejohn resigned in 1923, eight faculty members left and thirteen students refused their diplomas.<cite><a href="Meiklejohn, Alexander.html">Meiklejohn, Alexander</a></cite>
Alexander Meiklejohn was offered the presidencies of other colleges, but went to the University of Wisconsin, where with some former colleagues and students he started the University’s Experimental College in 1928.<cite><a href="Meiklejohn, Alexander.html">Meiklejohn, Alexander</a></cite>
The experimental college inspired its students, but was an administrative failure and ended in 1932.<cite><a href="Meiklejohn, Alexander.html">Meiklejohn, Alexander</a></cite>
Meiklejohn continued to teach at Wisconsin until 1938.<cite><a href="Meiklejohn, Alexander.html">Meiklejohn, Alexander</a></cite>
His writings included "The Liberal College" in 1920, "Freedom and the College" in 1923, "The Experimental College" in 1930, "Free Speech and its Relation to Self-Government" in 1948, and "Political Freedom; the Constitutional Powers of the People" in 1960, Alexander Meiklejohn was a long-time member of the National Committee of the American Civil Liberties Union.<cite><a href="Meiklejohn, Alexander.html">Meiklejohn, Alexander</a></cite>
In 1945 Alexander Meiklejohn was a United States delegate to the charter meeting of USESCO in London.<cite><a href="Meiklejohn, Alexander.html">Meiklejohn, Alexander</a></cite>
He was able to come east to hear Justice William O. Douglas deliver the first Meiklejohn lecture at Brown in 1963.<cite><a href="Meiklejohn, Alexander.html">Meiklejohn, Alexander</a></cite>
Alexander Meiklejohn once told President Keeney that he considered the Rosenberger Medal which he was awarded in 1959 the highest honor of his life.<cite><a href="Meiklejohn, Alexander.html">Meiklejohn, Alexander</a></cite>
On December 6, 1963, Alexander Meiklejohn received from President Lyndon B. Johnson the Presidential Medal of Freedom, for which he had been selected by President John F. Kennedy.<cite><a href="Meiklejohn, Alexander.html">Meiklejohn, Alexander</a></cite>
Alexander Meiklejohn died in Berkeley, California, on December 17, 1964 at the age of 92.<cite><a href="Meiklejohn, Alexander.html">Meiklejohn, Alexander</a></cite>
Asa Messer (1769-1836), third president of Brown University, was born in Methuen, Massachusetts on May 31, 1769.<cite><a href="Messer, Asa.html">Messer, Asa</a></cite>
Asa Messer prepared for college under Reverend <a href="Smith, Hezekiah.html">Hezekiah Smith</a> of Haverhill, Massachusetts, came to Rhode Island College as a sophomore, and graduated in 1790.<cite><a href="Messer, Asa.html">Messer, Asa</a></cite>
Asa Messer was named tutor in the College in 1791, professor of learned languages in 1796, and professor of natural philosophy in 1799.<cite><a href="Messer, Asa.html">Messer, Asa</a></cite>
Asa Messer was also librarian from 1792 to 1799.<cite><a href="Messer, Asa.html">Messer, Asa</a></cite>
In 1802 Asa Messer succeeded <a href="Maxcy, Jonathan.html">Jonathan Maxcy</a> as president "pro tempore" for two years before being named president in 1804.<cite><a href="Messer, Asa.html">Messer, Asa</a></cite>
Asa Messer was licensed to preach by the First Baptist Church in Providence in 1792 and ordained in 1801, but was never a pastor.<cite><a href="Messer, Asa.html">Messer, Asa</a></cite>
In 1818 Asa Messer was appointed a justice of the state supreme court, but declined, finding the appointment incompatible with his college office.<cite><a href="Messer, Asa.html">Messer, Asa</a></cite>
Asa Messer patented two inventions, "Flume for a Mill" (1822) and "Water-wheel and Flume" (1824).<cite><a href="Messer, Asa.html">Messer, Asa</a></cite>
The style of Messer’s administration was described in "Brown University under the Presidency of Asa Messer, S.T.D., LL.D.," a pamphlet published anonymously in Boston in 1867, but known to be written by Silas Axtell Crane 1823.<cite><a href="Messer, Asa.html">Messer, Asa</a></cite>
The Metcalf Botanical Garden, occupying between thirteen and fourteen acres between Morris Avenue and Cypress Street was deeded to Brown in 1884 by Mrs. Almira T. Metcalf as a permanent memorial to her husband, Whiting Taft Metcalf, who had planted about half of the hundred trees on the site.<cite><a href="Metcalf Botanical Garden.html">Metcalf Botanical Garden</a></cite>
The only building on the grounds was a barn, the Metcalf home having burned in 1875.<cite><a href="Metcalf Botanical Garden.html">Metcalf Botanical Garden</a></cite>
In 1889 two and one-half additional acres adjoining the property were added, having been acquired by a mortgage foreclosure, and came to Brown through the efforts of former Chancellor William Goddard, who had purchased it either in his own name or as an agent of the University.<cite><a href="Metcalf Botanical Garden.html">Metcalf Botanical Garden</a></cite>
In 1897 an attempt by the heirs to recover the land on the grounds of non-compliance was not allowed by the court, and in 1908 Mrs. Metcalf’s daughter, Almira Pierce, unwillingly paid Brown $8,000 which she had held in trust "for the improvement of the ... Botanical Garden," and took this opportunity to protest the University’s inaction.<cite><a href="Metcalf Botanical Garden.html">Metcalf Botanical Garden</a></cite>
In 1900 the trees had been marked with labels and a fence built for the protection of the new nursery.<cite><a href="Metcalf Botanical Garden.html">Metcalf Botanical Garden</a></cite>
In 1903 the University School obtained permission to use part of the grounds for athletics, and a fence was installed to separate the rented pasture.<cite><a href="Metcalf Botanical Garden.html">Metcalf Botanical Garden</a></cite>
One such scheduled performance by Ben Greet’s "Everyman" company in June 1903 was "rained out" and staged in Infantry Hall.<cite><a href="Metcalf Botanical Garden.html">Metcalf Botanical Garden</a></cite>
Improvements in 1912 included a new fence and the planting of hedges around the grounds.<cite><a href="Metcalf Botanical Garden.html">Metcalf Botanical Garden</a></cite>
In 1917 the University purchased the Durfee land between Elmgrove and Cole Avenues, and then began negotiations with the heir of the donors of the botanical garden property, with a view to using the combined site for an athletic plant  The result was the removal of the restrictions on the use of the Metcalf Botanical Garden in consideration of the return of approximately one-third of the land to the heir, and the building of the <a href="Stadium.html">Stadium</a> on the lot.<cite><a href="Metcalf Botanical Garden.html">Metcalf Botanical Garden</a></cite>
Metcalf Chemical Laboratory was built in 1923 with a gift of $450,000 from Jesse Houghton Metcalf as a memorial to his father, Jesse Metcalf.<cite><a href="Metcalf Chemical Laboratory.html">Metcalf Chemical Laboratory</a></cite>
Professor James William McBain came from Bristol University in England to deliver the principal address at the dedication of the building on October 10, 1923.<cite><a href="Metcalf Chemical Laboratory.html">Metcalf Chemical Laboratory</a></cite>
Metcalf Hall, the second dormitory on the campus of the Women’s College, was built in 1919 on land which had been acquired by the gift of Stephen O. Metcalf.<cite><a href="Metcalf Hall.html">Metcalf Hall</a></cite>
Metcalf Research Laboratory was dedicated in December 1938 with a three-day symposium on intermolecular action sponsored by the Division of Physical and Inorganic <a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a> of the American Chemical Society.<cite><a href="Metcalf Research Laboratory.html">Metcalf Research Laboratory</a></cite>
Military <a href="Education.html">Education</a> was added to the curriculum in 1892 to fulfill the terms of the Morrill land-grant fund, which had been received in 1863.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
Lieutenant William J. Pardee was professor of military tactics from 1892 to 1895, and was succeeded by Lieutenant John Baxter in 1895-96 and Captain Cunliffe H. Murray from 1896 to 1898.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
The subject of military training came up again in 1916.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
The University’s Reserve Officers’ Training Corps was recognized by the War Department in 1917, and the entire student body was inducted into the Student Army Training Corps or the Naval Training Unit in October 1918.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
The Student Army Training Corps was disbanded in December 1918.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
When the Naval Training Unit was demobilized in 1918, the Department of Naval Science remained with its title changed to the Department of Nautical Science and new headquarters on the third floor of <a href="Maxcy Hall.html">Maxcy Hall</a>.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
First steps toward establishing a unit for air training under the Civil Aeronautics Authority began in 1939.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
In 1940 a quota of 30 students signed up for training with a technical instructor from M.I.T. and flying instruction by E. W. Wiggins Airways, Inc.  A Naval Reserve Officers Training Corps unit was established at Brown in the fall of 1940 with 110 members.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
Students who were admitted to the Corps under peace-time conditions before March 1943 took a four-year course in naval science and tactics which, together with a summer cruise, entitled them to a degree and a commission as Ensign in the Volunteer Naval Reserve or Second Lieutenant in the Marine Corps Reserve.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
Students in the Corps in March 1943 completed their program as Naval students, Class V-12, in the Naval Reserve.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
George H. Bowdey in 1941-42, Capt.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
Henry M. Briggs from 1942 to 1944, and Capt.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
Emanuel A. Lofquist in 1944-45,  After the war there were three types of officer-candidates: 1) regular NROTC students who were midshipmen in the Naval Reserve, were educated at government expense, and were required to serve on active duty after graduation; 2) contract students who as civilians entered a contract with the Navy, paid for their own education while receiving uniforms and a commuted ration (65 cents a day in 1946), and were required to accept a commission in the Naval or Marine Corps Reserve; 3) naval science students in excess of the quota of the NROTC unit, who were permitted to take naval science courses for credit and were eligible for the NROTC when vacancies occurred.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
Carl G. Gesen in 1945-46, Capt.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
Francis D. McCorkle from 1946 to 1948, Capt.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
Edward R. Durgin from 1948 to 1952, when he retired and became dean of students at Brown, Capt.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
Frederick W. Laing from 1952 to 1955, Capt.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
Charles M. Lyons from 1955 to 1959, Capt.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
Norman D. Johnson from 1959 to 1961, Col. William F. Lantz, USMC, from 1961 to 1963, Capt.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
Robert Brent from 1963 to 1969, and Capt.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
John P. Kane from 1969 until the end of the ROTC program in 1972.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
Air Force ROTC units were established at Brown and 61 other institutions on July 1, 1951.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
In September 1950 freshmen arrived for indoctrination under Colonel Bryan B. Harper, who was named Chairman of the Department of Air Science and Tactics.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
Other officers who headed the Air Science Department were Col. Gilbert E. Goodman from 1955 to 1957, Lt. Col. George W. Hutcheson from 1958 to 1960, Major Arthur E. Allen from 1960 to 1961, Lt. Col. William J. Grundmann from 1962 to 1966, Major Robert G. Liotta from 1966 to 1969, and Capt.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
Richard J. Manning from 1969 until the end of thr program.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
(Hap) Arnold, which began at the University of Cincinnati in 1947.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
A long-term debate on the future of ROTC began in 1967, when 35 members of the Brown Committee to abolish ROTC picketed the annual ROTC spring review at <a href="Meehan Auditorium.html">Meehan Auditorium</a>.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
In November 1967 the <a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a> passed a resolution stating that the ROTC program was not compatible with the academic integrity of the University.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
The annual review was picketed again in 1968.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
In 1968 the commissioning ceremony of the ROTC had been separated from the <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> exercises and held later in <a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a>, where an unscheduled appearance was made by Bob Hope, who had received an honorary degree at the <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> exercises.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
In March 1969 the faculty rejected by a vote of 115 to 55 a resolution calling for the end of all military education, but recommended that the ROTC units should not have departmental status, that instruction by these units should not earn academic credit, that their officers should not have faculty status, and that the programs should be considered extracurricular activities.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
The University entered into new agreements for phase-out periods for the two ROTC programs, which applied only to students enrolled as of July 1, 1969.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
Negotiations were reopened in 1971, and, since the stipulations of March 1969 were not being met, the faculty affirmed its action and ended the presence of the ROTC at Brown in 1971 for the Air Force unit and in 1972 for the Naval unit.<cite><a href="Military education.html">Military education</a></cite>
Carl Wallace Miller (1893-1975), professor of physics, was born in Somerville, Massachusetts, on March 28, 1893.<cite><a href="Miller, Carl W..html">Miller, Carl W.</a></cite>
Carl W. Miller graduated from Harvard in 1915, received a Sheldon Prize Fellowship with which he studied in Zurich and Paris in 1915-16, then returned to Harvard as an assistant in the Physics Department from 1916 to 1918, when he became an inspection supervisor of army ordnance.<cite><a href="Miller, Carl W..html">Miller, Carl W.</a></cite>
Carl W. Miller received a master of arts degree in 1922 and a Ph.D. in 1923, both from Harvard.<cite><a href="Miller, Carl W..html">Miller, Carl W.</a></cite>
Carl W. Miller taught at New York University from 1922 to 1924.<cite><a href="Miller, Carl W..html">Miller, Carl W.</a></cite>
Carl W. Miller came to Brown as assistant professor of physics in 1924, and was promoted to associate professor in 1929 and full professor in 1945.<cite><a href="Miller, Carl W..html">Miller, Carl W.</a></cite>
Carl W. Miller retired in 1955.<cite><a href="Miller, Carl W..html">Miller, Carl W.</a></cite>
Carl W. Miller was a member of the National Geographic Society eclipse expedition to Siam in 1948, and was a research associate in the Office of Naval Research Beavertail project at Yale from 1952 to 1954.<cite><a href="Miller, Carl W..html">Miller, Carl W.</a></cite>
Carl W. Miller published "Principles of Photographic Reproduction" in 1942, and "A Scientist’s Approach to Religion" in 1947.<cite><a href="Miller, Carl W..html">Miller, Carl W.</a></cite>
Carl W. Miller died on January 8, 1975.<cite><a href="Miller, Carl W..html">Miller, Carl W.</a></cite>
Miller Hall was built in 1910 to accommodate about fifty women students.<cite><a href="Miller Hall.html">Miller Hall</a></cite>
Harry Edward Miller (1897-1937), professor of economics, was born in Boston on October 10, 1897.<cite><a href="Miller, Harry E..html">Miller, Harry E.</a></cite>
Harry E. Miller graduated from Boston University in 1919 and earned his A.M. degree in 1920 and his Ph.D. in 1923, both from Harvard.<cite><a href="Miller, Harry E..html">Miller, Harry E.</a></cite>
Harry E. Miller was named associate professor on the Eastman Foundation in 1928 and Eastman Professor of Political Economy in 1930.<cite><a href="Miller, Harry E..html">Miller, Harry E.</a></cite>
Harry E. Miller taught courses in money and banking, public finance and economic theory, and published a book, "Banking Theories in the United States before 1860," in 1927.<cite><a href="Miller, Harry E..html">Miller, Harry E.</a></cite>
Harry E. Miller served on the Consumers Council of the National Emergency Council for Providence County during the Depression and was chairman of the special Rhode Island Commission on Liquor Legislation in 1931.<cite><a href="Miller, Harry E..html">Miller, Harry E.</a></cite>
In the spring of 1937 Miller took a leave of absence because of his health.<cite><a href="Miller, Harry E..html">Miller, Harry E.</a></cite>
Harry E. Miller died shortly after an operation in Boston on November 14, 1937.<cite><a href="Miller, Harry E..html">Miller, Harry E.</a></cite>

Matthew Cargill Mitchell (1888-1969), professor of political science, was born in Bellefontaine, Ohio, on July 15, 1888.<cite><a href="Mitchell, Matthew C..html">Mitchell, Matthew C.</a></cite>
Matthew C. Mitchell graduated from Geneva College in 1911, and taught high school in Twin Falls, Idaho, where he also became a school principal and superintendent of schools.<cite><a href="Mitchell, Matthew C..html">Mitchell, Matthew C.</a></cite>
After earning his Ph.D. at Harvard in 1926, Matthew C. Mitchell came to Brown as assistant professor of political science.<cite><a href="Mitchell, Matthew C..html">Mitchell, Matthew C.</a></cite>
Matthew C. Mitchell became chairman of the department in 1928, and was named associate professor in 1931 and professor in 1949.<cite><a href="Mitchell, Matthew C..html">Mitchell, Matthew C.</a></cite>
Matthew C. Mitchell retired in 1952.<cite><a href="Mitchell, Matthew C..html">Mitchell, Matthew C.</a></cite>
Matthew C. Mitchell served on many local boards, among them the Rhode Island Commission to Encourage Morality, the advisory council to the University of Rhode Island Bureau of Government Research and Governor’s Committee on State Goals, and was secretary of the Mayor’s Special Committee on Education in 1967.<cite><a href="Mitchell, Matthew C..html">Mitchell, Matthew C.</a></cite>
Matthew C. Mitchell died in Providence on April 16, 1969, after leaving a meeting of the Rhode Island Council of Churches.<cite><a href="Mitchell, Matthew C..html">Mitchell, Matthew C.</a></cite>
Philip Henry Mitchell (1893-1955), professor of biology, was born in Southbury, Connecticut, on December 13, 1893.<cite><a href="Mitchell, Philip H..html">Mitchell, Philip H.</a></cite>
Philip H. Mitchell received a Bachelor of Philosophy degree from Yale’s Sheffield Scientific School in 1904, and, after earning his Ph.D. at Yale in 1907, he came to Brown as instructor in physiology.<cite><a href="Mitchell, Philip H..html">Mitchell, Philip H.</a></cite>
Philip H. Mitchell was appointed assistant professor in 1911, associate professor in 1920, and professor in 1925.<cite><a href="Mitchell, Philip H..html">Mitchell, Philip H.</a></cite>
Philip H. Mitchell was chairman of the department from 1933 to 1944, and was named Robert P. Brown Professor of Biology in 1936.<cite><a href="Mitchell, Philip H..html">Mitchell, Philip H.</a></cite>
From 1911 to 1921 Philip H. Mitchell was involved in fisheries research at Woods Hole, first as research physiologist, and from 1917 to 1921 as research director of the Woods Hole Laboratory of the U.S. Bureau of Fisheries.<cite><a href="Mitchell, Philip H..html">Mitchell, Philip H.</a></cite>
As an investigator for the Connecticut State Board of Fisheries and Game in the 1920s Philip H. Mitchell studied the effect of pollution of the shad fisheries, and in the 1930s he did research on sea water at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute.<cite><a href="Mitchell, Philip H..html">Mitchell, Philip H.</a></cite>
Philip H. Mitchell retired in 1949, and died in Winter Park, Florida, on February 2, 1955.<cite><a href="Mitchell, Philip H..html">Mitchell, Philip H.</a></cite>
Robert McBurney Mitchell (1879-1956), professor of Germanic languages and literature, was born in Lake Mills, Wisconsin, on December 31, 1879.<cite><a href="Mitchell, Robert McBurney.html">Mitchell, Robert McBurney</a></cite>
Robert McBurney Mitchell graduated from the University of Chicago in 1903.<cite><a href="Mitchell, Robert McBurney.html">Mitchell, Robert McBurney</a></cite>
Robert McBurney Mitchell studied at the Universities of Berlin, Freiburg, and Munich, and taught for a year at Dartmouth before he came to Brown in 1907 as an instructor.<cite><a href="Mitchell, Robert McBurney.html">Mitchell, Robert McBurney</a></cite>
In 1914 Robert McBurney Mitchell received his Ph.D. degree from Brown and was promoted to assistant professor.<cite><a href="Mitchell, Robert McBurney.html">Mitchell, Robert McBurney</a></cite>
In 1938 Robert McBurney Mitchell was named full professor.<cite><a href="Mitchell, Robert McBurney.html">Mitchell, Robert McBurney</a></cite>
Robert McBurney Mitchell made a special adaptation of "Everyman" for a Sock and Buskin production in 1929 and prepared the text of Kleist’s "Prince Frederick of Homburg" for its first American performance by Sock and Buskin in 1935.<cite><a href="Mitchell, Robert McBurney.html">Mitchell, Robert McBurney</a></cite>
Robert McBurney Mitchell retired in 1947 and died on April 12, 1956 in Seattle, Washington.<cite><a href="Mitchell, Robert McBurney.html">Mitchell, Robert McBurney</a></cite>
French was first taught by David Howell, who came as a tutor in 1769 and remained until the College was closed by the <a href="Revolutionary War.html">Revolutionary War</a>.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
Solomon Drowne 1773 recorded in his diary on December 11, 1770 that he "began to learn French of Mr. David Howel ... four Evenings in a Week, and on the following two days purchased a French grammar and a French "Telemachus."<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
There was renewed interest in French in 1795 when the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> appointed a committee to arrange for a proper master to teach the French language.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
In 1827 the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> appointed a committee to consider establishing a course in modern languages, and the annual catalogue for 1827-28 mentions Hebrew or French as optional studies in the third term of the senior year.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
The 1836-37 catalog announced that "Instruction in French, German and Hebrew is also furnished to those who desire it, at the expense of the student."<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
A change occurred in 1842-43, when "By recent statute of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a>, regular instruction in the principal languages of modern Europe is furnished to the students at a moderate additional expense, in accordance with such arrangements as the <a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a> may adopt.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
Charles Coffin Jewett 1835 was professor of modern languages until 1848.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
After Jewett, the professor of modern languages were George Washington Greene 1828 from 1848 to 1852, and James B. Angell 1849 from 1852 to 1860.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
Jewett, who was also librarian of the college, was in Europe from 1843 to 1845 buying books for the library and improving his language skills.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
The modern languages were still not an important part of the curriculum in the 1840s.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
In 1850, when <a href="President.html">President</a> Francis Wayland’s New System introduced new degrees, the substitution of modern languages for the ancient languages was permitted.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
The University catalogue for 1850-51 described the courses in French, German, Italian, and Spanish, and added, "The course in each language is intended to be critical, grounding the student thoroughly in grammatical principles and accustoming him to the same rigorous analysis which is applied to the Latin and Greek, while at the same time he is prepared for writing and speaking by the constant use of oral and written exercises.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
William E. Jillson 1846 assisted as instructor in 1852-53.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
From the departure of Angell in 1860 until the arrival of Alonzo Williams the professorship of modern languages was vacant.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
German was taught by a native instructor in 1861-62, then by <a href="President.html">President</a> Barnas Sears until his retirement in 1866, after which German was added to the duties of John Larkin Lincoln, professor of Latin.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
When Alonzo Williams was appointed professor of modern languages in 1876, French began to be offered in the freshman year.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
In 1877 it was possible to start German in the junior year.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
Courses in Italian and Spanish were offered to seniors in 1885.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
By 1888 courses in French extended into the first half of the junior year, and German was offered in the last three years.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
In 1891 Alonzo Williams recommended that the department, which by this time included German, French, Italian, and Spanish languages and literatures, be split into two separate departments.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
In 1941 the Department of Romance Languages and Literatures and the Department of Germanic Languages and Literatures were reunited in the Division of Modern Languages.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
Hans Kurath was chairman of the department until 1946, when he was succeeded by Hunter Kellenberger.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
In the 1950s, in connection with the new I.C.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
In 1960 the Division of Modern Languages was replaced by five separate language and literature departments (French, German, Linguistics, Spanish and Italian, and Slavic languages) and a Modern Language Board consisting of the five chairmen and two coordinators.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
The five departments, joined in the late 1960s by <a href="Comparative Literature.html">Comparative Literature</a>, also entered into cooperation with <a href="Classics.html">Classics</a> and <a href="English.html">English</a> to form the Council for Languages and Literatures.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
This Council was disbanded by decision of the participating chairs in 1977.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
The Center for Language Studies was established in 1986. to facilitate contact and cooperation among foreign language faculty across individual department boundaries.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
Oriental languages were first introduced in the Department of Linguistics, Chinese in 1962, Japanese in 1979, and Hindi in 1983.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
Instruction in Korean began in 1987.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
Since 1987 the oriental languages have been taught by the Department of <a href="East Asian Studies.html">East Asian Studies</a>.<cite><a href="Modern Languages.html">Modern Languages</a></cite>
Margaret Shove Morriss (1884-1975), fourth dean of the Women’s College and of Pembroke College, was born in Baltimore on June 25, 1884.<cite><a href="Morriss, Margaret Shove.html">Morriss, Margaret Shove</a></cite>
Margaret Shove Morriss graduated from Goucher College in 1904 and earned her Ph.D. degree from Bryn Mawr in 1911.<cite><a href="Morriss, Margaret Shove.html">Morriss, Margaret Shove</a></cite>
Margaret Shove Morriss was promoted to associate professor in 1914.<cite><a href="Morriss, Margaret Shove.html">Morriss, Margaret Shove</a></cite>
Margaret Shove Morriss left Mount Holyoke from 1917 to 1919 to be recreational director for the Y.W.C.A.<cite><a href="Morriss, Margaret Shove.html">Morriss, Margaret Shove</a></cite>
Margaret Shove Morriss came to Brown as dean of the Women’s College with the recommendation of <a href="Woolley, Mary Emma.html">Mary Emma Woolley</a> 1894, president of Mt.<cite><a href="Morriss, Margaret Shove.html">Morriss, Margaret Shove</a></cite>
Miss Morris arrived in 1923 and set about making the Women’s College known.<cite><a href="Morriss, Margaret Shove.html">Morriss, Margaret Shove</a></cite>
Margaret Shove Morriss was associate professor of history until 1932, when she was promoted to professor.<cite><a href="Morriss, Margaret Shove.html">Morriss, Margaret Shove</a></cite>
Margaret Shove Morriss served as national president of the American Association of University Women from 1937 to 1944, and as president of the New England Association of Schools and Colleges in 1941.<cite><a href="Morriss, Margaret Shove.html">Morriss, Margaret Shove</a></cite>
In 1949-50 Margaret Shove Morriss took her first leave of absence to travel, and retired in 1950.<cite><a href="Morriss, Margaret Shove.html">Morriss, Margaret Shove</a></cite>
The Margaret S. Morris Scholarship was established in 1951 to be given every four years to an entering freshman.<cite><a href="Morriss, Margaret Shove.html">Morriss, Margaret Shove</a></cite>
The Connecticut division of the American Association of University Women established an international fellowship in Margaret Shove Morriss's named in 1965.<cite><a href="Morriss, Margaret Shove.html">Morriss, Margaret Shove</a></cite>
Morriss Hall on the Pembroke Campus was named for her in 1960.<cite><a href="Morriss, Margaret Shove.html">Morriss, Margaret Shove</a></cite>
Margaret Shove Morriss died in East Providence on January 22, 1975.<cite><a href="Morriss, Margaret Shove.html">Morriss, Margaret Shove</a></cite>
Wilfred Harold Munro (1849-1934), professor of history, was born in Bristol, Rhode Island, on August 20, 1849.<cite><a href="Munro, Wilfred H..html">Munro, Wilfred H.</a></cite>
Wilfred H. Munro attended Mowry and Goff’s English and Classical School and graduated from Brown in 1870.<cite><a href="Munro, Wilfred H..html">Munro, Wilfred H.</a></cite>
Wilfred H. Munro was captain of the Class of 1870 baseball team which defeated the New England champion Lowells of Boston, 22 to 19, in a game played on June 17, 1868.<cite><a href="Munro, Wilfred H..html">Munro, Wilfred H.</a></cite>
