A baseball feat of Munro’s, fondly recounted by his brother, Walter Lee Munro 1879 in "The Old Back Campus at Brown," took place on the ball field on what is now the Middle Campus, when Wilfred Munro hit a foul fly ball to right field and broke all eight panes of a window in University Hall.<cite><a href="Munro, Wilfred H..html">Munro, Wilfred H.</a></cite>
After college, Munro taught at De Veaux College in Niagara Falls, was associate principal of St. Mark’s School in Salt Lake City in 1871, spent some time in Central and South America, was principal of the Academic Institute in Le Roy, New York, from 1875 to 1879, and returned to De Veaux College as president from 1881 to 1889.<cite><a href="Munro, Wilfred H..html">Munro, Wilfred H.</a></cite>
Wilfred H. Munro resumed his study of history at Freiburg and Heidelburg in 1890 and 1891, and in 1891 began his teaching career at Brown as associate professor of history.<cite><a href="Munro, Wilfred H..html">Munro, Wilfred H.</a></cite>
Wilfred H. Munro's title was changed to professor of European history in 1899.<cite><a href="Munro, Wilfred H..html">Munro, Wilfred H.</a></cite>
His course on European history after 1815 was popular with the students, who called him "Pop" Munro.<cite><a href="Munro, Wilfred H..html">Munro, Wilfred H.</a></cite>
Wilfred H. Munro was appointed the first director of University Extension in 1890-91, and, as he was traveling in Europe at the time of his appointment, he was able to study methods used in England before he initiated the extension program, which he continued to direct until 1899.<cite><a href="Munro, Wilfred H..html">Munro, Wilfred H.</a></cite>
Wilfred H. Munro retired from teaching in 1911.<cite><a href="Munro, Wilfred H..html">Munro, Wilfred H.</a></cite>
Wilfred H. Munro published "History of Bristol, Rhode Island" in 1880, "Picturesque Rhode Island" in 1881, and another history of Bristol, "Tales of an Old Seaport" in 1917.<cite><a href="Munro, Wilfred H..html">Munro, Wilfred H.</a></cite>
Wilfred H. Munro died on August 9, 1934 in Providence.<cite><a href="Munro, Wilfred H..html">Munro, Wilfred H.</a></cite>
Mention of a college "museum" had been made as early as 1790, when George Washington was reported to have been entertained with a visit to the museum.<cite><a href="Museum of Natural History.html">Museum of Natural History</a></cite>
In 1795 the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> voted its thanks to Mr. Jones Welch of Boston for "a preserved bird called the Curlieu of Cayenne, and a Calabash curiously wrought by the natives of Cayenne, to be deposited in the Museum."<cite><a href="Museum of Natural History.html">Museum of Natural History</a></cite>
In 1829 a gift of items from the Sandwich Islands, including paddles, dresses, and a carved wooden image, was deposited in the museum by Captain John Jennings.<cite><a href="Museum of Natural History.html">Museum of Natural History</a></cite>
In his first report as president in 1869, Alexis Caswell expressed the need for a proper museum, but there was no money available for such purposes.<cite><a href="Museum of Natural History.html">Museum of Natural History</a></cite>
In 1871, a former student with an interest in natural history, John Whipple Potter Jenks 1838, on resigning as principal of Pierce Academy, offered his services in connection with the natural history collection.<cite><a href="Museum of Natural History.html">Museum of Natural History</a></cite>
In 1871 the family of the recently deceased Dr. William Blanding 1801 deposited his cabinet of minerals, shells, fossils, relics and coins, numbering 7,769, in the museum.<cite><a href="Museum of Natural History.html">Museum of Natural History</a></cite>
A collection of over a thousand insects was received from the Reverend David Weston 1859.<cite><a href="Museum of Natural History.html">Museum of Natural History</a></cite>
Jenks reported in 1873, "It is intended that the museum shall contain specimens illustrative of every branch taught in the institution ...<cite><a href="Museum of Natural History.html">Museum of Natural History</a></cite>
After the addition to <a href="Rhode Island Hall.html">Rhode Island Hall</a> in 1873 provided more room for the museum, Jenks, still without funds for the Museum, added a few cases paid for by donors, and, by soliciting ten dollars each from seventeen persons, was almost able to meet the cost of $190 for mounted skeletons of a horse and a buffalo acquired in 1875.<cite><a href="Museum of Natural History.html">Museum of Natural History</a></cite>
A fine walrus skin was obtained in 1878 as the parting gift of the senior class.<cite><a href="Museum of Natural History.html">Museum of Natural History</a></cite>
In 1882 Jenks offered to contribute two hundred dollars in each of the next five years.<cite><a href="Museum of Natural History.html">Museum of Natural History</a></cite>
In his annual report for 1892 <a href="President.html">President</a> Andrews noted, "The Old Museum of Natural <a href="History.html">History</a> now exists in two parts, the Jenks Museum of Zoology and the Museum of <a href="Anthropology.html">Anthropology</a>, either of which is more valuable for educational purposes than the whole was before."<cite><a href="Museum of Natural History.html">Museum of Natural History</a></cite>
However, after the death of Jenks in 1894, no more funds were appropriated for the curator or the assistant, and the Museum was no longer viewed as an asset.<cite><a href="Museum of Natural History.html">Museum of Natural History</a></cite>
In 1905 Professor Albert D. Mead repeated an appeal for $1,000 for the maintenance of the anatomical and zoological material used in teaching, while he conceded that "the reasonableness of spending money for the dusting and rearranging of the miscellaneous curios of a university junk shop for the gratification of a few straggling sightseers is, we readily admit, not obvious."<cite><a href="Museum of Natural History.html">Museum of Natural History</a></cite>
When the <a href="Biology.html">Biology</a> Department moved into <a href="Arnold Laboratory.html">Arnold Laboratory</a> in 1915, <a href="Rhode Island Hall.html">Rhode Island Hall</a> was assigned to other departments and the contents of the Museum were put into storage.<cite><a href="Museum of Natural History.html">Museum of Natural History</a></cite>
Musical Clubs at Brown have a history which dates back to 1775, when Andrew Law 1775 organized a singing group of fellow students.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
The diary of Williams Latham 1827 contains references to the Harmonic Society on November 24, 1826, "Harmonic Society got excused from singing in the <a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a> any more this term, and on March 25, 1827, "the Harmonic Society to Mr. Edes’s Meeting house, where with the use of the Organ we sung many tunes out of Bridgewater Collection to the gratification of Rev. Mr. Edes and some others."<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
A student band played at <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> in 1828.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
The "<a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a> Band" performed at the junior and senior exhibitions in 1837.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
There was a Brown student orchestra as early as 1858, according to a flyer advertising a concert on April 19, 1858, at the Town Hall of nearby Seekonk, with "a chorus of forty singers ... accompanied by the ORCHESTRA of Brown University."<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
The "<a href="Brown Paper.html">Brown Paper</a>," in its first issue in 1857 contained a roster of a Glee Club.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
A more formal Glee Club or Chorus came into being in 1868.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
At a concert performed in the Horse Guards Armory on June 14, 1869, the new Glee Club introduced the "<a href="Alma Mater.html">Alma Mater</a>," which had been written nine years earlier.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
In 1871 the club was an added attraction at the Junior Exhibition.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
Progress was reported in the "<a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a>" of July, 1871: Women students had their own musical organizations.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
In 1895-96 a glee club, which consisted of a double quartet, sang at the College.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
The women’s club sang at the <a href="Baccalaureate.html">Baccalaureate</a> in 1897, and after 1900 sang at chapel exercises.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
Other women’s clubs were the short-lived Choral Club in 1909 and the <a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a> Choir, established in 1909-10 under the direction of Professor Hamilton MacDougall, and directed by Blanche N. Davis from 1913 to 1938.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
In 1914 the women’s Glee Club presented the operetta, "Japanese Girl."<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
The Brown and Amherst clubs held a concert in Providence on the eve of the Brown-Amherst game in 1907.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
In 1910 Dr. Lacey-Baker, organist at Grace Church in Providence volunteered to coach the Glee Club in return for volunteers from the Club to sing with the church’s choir.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
In 1919 the Brown musical clubs took part in an "A.B.C."<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
In 1926 the Brown Glee Club participated for the first time in the Intercollegiate Glee Club contest in Jordan Hall with twelve other glee clubs.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
From 1949 to 1959 the Glee Club was under the direction of David Laurent.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
An <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> Musical Activities Council was formed in 1955, designed to create close ties among the eight universities by featuring joint concerts of three clubs each year in New York.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
In 1956 Brown was one of the three clubs participating with Yale and Cornell.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
Erich Kunzel became director of the Glee Club in 1959.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
In 1960 the club made a record of Brown songs.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
The Chorus became the first Brown performing arts group to represent the University abroad when it traveled to England for the 350th anniversary of the crossing of the Mayflower in 1970 and sang in thirteen <a href="English.html">English</a> cathedrals.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
In the summer of 1973 there was another trip to Czechoslovakia (where the Chorus, with Robert Molison as director, gave the first officially recognized American concert in Prague since the Russian invasion of 1968), Hungary, and Austria.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
In 1974 William Ermey replaced Robert Molison as director of the University Chorus and the Chamber Choir.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
Fifty-two members of the Brown Chorus traveled 20,000 miles in 1976 on a 24-day trip to India and Nepal sponsored by Friendship Ambassadors, Inc., a private foundation which promotes harmony between nations through music.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
In June 1979 the Brown Chorus became the first American college performing group to tour the People’s Republic of China, sponsored again by Friendship Ambassadors.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
Aaron Copland performed with the Chorus and the Wind Ensemble at a <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> concert in 1980.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
On April 12, 1987 the Chorus and Orchestra, sponsored by the Brown Club of New York, performed in a benefit concert in Carnegie Hall and raised $20,000 for financial aid.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
The Chorus and Orchestra made another appearance in Carnegie Hall with Dave Brubeck on February 18, 1990.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
The Bruinaires, a group organized in 1945 with Francis Madeira as one of its founders, performed as a featured ensemble of the Glee Club, of which all the "Bruinaires" were members, and also went on separate singing tours.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
The Pembroke Double Quartet, known as the PDQ’s, began about 1948, modeling themselves after the Double Quartet at Amherst.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
The "quartet" also increased in number (fifteen members were reported in 1963).<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
The Jabberwocks, a male double quartet, began in 1950.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
They wore grey flannel suits, white button-down oxford shirts, striped ties and white buck shoes, and travelled to out-of-town concerts in a 1928 Rolls Royce.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
The group turned coed in the early 1970s and then disappeared, to be revived in 1980 by Jack Dorer ’81 and Tom Dorer ’84, sons of John Dorer ’55, a member of the earlier group.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
In 1983 the Jabberwocks released a record called "Street Night."<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
The Chattertocks got their start in the fall of 1951 in the interdormitory group singing competition, when Nancy Tobin ’55 arranged for her dormitory, Sharpe House, to perform a skit imitating the Jabberwocks.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
From "a cappella" they branched out to guitar and piano accompaniment, returned to "a cappella" in 1982, and added choreography and comedy skits to their concerts.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
The Brown University Chorale accompanied the Brown University Brass Ensemble on a bicentennial tour of the Middle West during spring break in 1964.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
The High Jinks, a barbershop octet with bow ties, began in 1975.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
The Brown Derbies, a group which began in the early 1980s, adopted vests and derbies for a turn of the century look.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
The Higher Keys, a coed "a cappella" group, was formed in 1983.<cite><a href="Musical Clubs.html">Musical Clubs</a></cite>
Music was included in the Department of Fine Arts when it was first taught in 1895 by Joseph N. Ashton 1891, who had been appointed instructor of musical theory and history.<cite><a href="Music.html">Music</a></cite>
Ashton was promoted to associate professor in 1898, and in 1900 became director of chapel music.<cite><a href="Music.html">Music</a></cite>
During the first year of the <a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a> organ he conducted two series of concerts, before his resignation in 1904.<cite><a href="Music.html">Music</a></cite>
No classes in music are listed in the course announcement for the years 1904-05 through 1907-08.<cite><a href="Music.html">Music</a></cite>
In 1909-10 Arthur Ware Locke (Harvard 1894), who had taught at St. Paul’s School in Concord, New Hampshire, and had studied in Berlin and Paris, was was instructor in music, teaching the same course.<cite><a href="Music.html">Music</a></cite>
The next year Professor MacDougall returned, and until his departure in 1914 the music courses varying from year to year covered elementary and advanced harmony, the symphony, and the opera.<cite><a href="Music.html">Music</a></cite>
Edwin Ernest Wilde, who was also in charge of music at St. Stephen’s Church, was lecturer in music at Brown from 1914 to 1920.<cite><a href="Music.html">Music</a></cite>
Gene Wilder Ware ’06, who had been director of chapel music since 1906, became lecturer in music in 1920, and assistant professor of music in 1923.<cite><a href="Music.html">Music</a></cite>
The department occupied two first floor rooms in the dormitory at 36 Prospect Street in 1924.<cite><a href="Music.html">Music</a></cite>
In 1929 Brown entered into an affiliation with St. Dunstan’s College of Sacred Music, which made it unnecessary for Brown to give advanced courses in music and allowed students at St. Dunstan’s to take courses at Brown.<cite><a href="Music.html">Music</a></cite>
In 1930, for the first time Brown students were able to major in music, and for the first time in 1930-31 credit was given for work in applied music, as students who had already had training in singing or playing instruments upon examination were allowed to continue their training under an approved teacher.<cite><a href="Music.html">Music</a></cite>
Also, in 1930, Arlan Coolidge ’26 succeeded Gene Ware as professor of music.<cite><a href="Music.html">Music</a></cite>
He was named chairman of the department in 1939, a post he held until 1963.<cite><a href="Music.html">Music</a></cite>
In 1932 the student musical organizations were put under the direction of the department.<cite><a href="Music.html">Music</a></cite>
When St. Dunstan’s withdrew from work of college grade in 1932, the Music Department added a new course in elementary theory.<cite><a href="Music.html">Music</a></cite>
The department grew steadily with the arrival of William Dinneen in 1938, Francis K. C. Madeira in 1943, Edward B. Greene in 1946, Martin Fischer in 1947, Otto van Koppenhagen in 1949, Millard S. Thomson and Mildred Pansy in 1950, David Laurent in 1951, Ron Nelson in 1956, and Paul Nelson in 1964.<cite><a href="Music.html">Music</a></cite>
Professor Ron Nelson, a graduate of the Eastman School of Music at the University of Rochester, became chairman in 1963.<cite><a href="Music.html">Music</a></cite>
His cantata, "The Christmas Story," was first performed at Brown, and his "Triumphal Te Deum" became part of Brown’s annual Latin Carol Service in 1962.<cite><a href="Music.html">Music</a></cite>
When Professor Coolidge retired in 1967, the department offered thirty courses.<cite><a href="Music.html">Music</a></cite>
A new concentration in non-Western music was added in 1971.<cite><a href="Music.html">Music</a></cite>
In 1971, when enrollment in applied music had increased 300% in the preceding five years, students sought more space for the Music Department by staging a demonstration in <a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a>.<cite><a href="Music.html">Music</a></cite>
In 1973 1,400 undergraduates of the University’s 4,700 were taking courses in music.<cite><a href="Music.html">Music</a></cite>
A new wing on the building in 1988 added a music library.<cite><a href="Music.html">Music</a></cite>
Thomas Andrew "Tim" Mutch (1931-1980), professor of geological sciences, was born in Rochester, New York, on August 26, 1931.<cite><a href="Mutch, Thomas A..html">Mutch, Thomas A.</a></cite>
Thomas A. Mutch received an A.B. degree from Princeton in 1952, an M.S. from Rutgers in 1957, and a Ph.D. from Princeton in 1960.<cite><a href="Mutch, Thomas A..html">Mutch, Thomas A.</a></cite>
Thomas A. Mutch came to Brown as assistant professor in 1960, and was promoted to associate professor in 1965, and professor in 1970.<cite><a href="Mutch, Thomas A..html">Mutch, Thomas A.</a></cite>
Thomas A. Mutch was chairman of the Department of Geological Sciences from 1968 to 1971.<cite><a href="Mutch, Thomas A..html">Mutch, Thomas A.</a></cite>
His field was planetary geology, and Thomas A. Mutch published an important text, "Geology of the Moon," in 1970, and also "Geology of Mars" in 1976, and "The Martian Landscape" in 1978.<cite><a href="Mutch, Thomas A..html">Mutch, Thomas A.</a></cite>
In 1969 Thomas A. Mutch was chosen as a member of the team of NASA scientists planning a trip to Mars.<cite><a href="Mutch, Thomas A..html">Mutch, Thomas A.</a></cite>
Thomas A. Mutch participated in the design of the special camera mounted on Viking Lander I, which went into orbit around Mars in 1976 and dropped the lander craft which beamed to Earth the first photographs taken from the surface of Mars.<cite><a href="Mutch, Thomas A..html">Mutch, Thomas A.</a></cite>
Thomas A. Mutch received a NASA medal for scientific achievement in 1977.<cite><a href="Mutch, Thomas A..html">Mutch, Thomas A.</a></cite>
From 1972 to 1975 Thomas A. Mutch taught a Modes of Thought course called "Exploration."<cite><a href="Mutch, Thomas A..html">Mutch, Thomas A.</a></cite>
The course in which students read journals of explorers whetted the appetites for real exploration, and in 1978, after much planning and a preliminary climbing trail on Mount Olympus in Washington State, Mutch and 32 students and professors attempted the climb of Devistan, a 21,904 mountain in the Himalayas.<cite><a href="Mutch, Thomas A..html">Mutch, Thomas A.</a></cite>
In 1979 Mutch took a leave of absence to serve as associate administrator for space science at NASA.<cite><a href="Mutch, Thomas A..html">Mutch, Thomas A.</a></cite>
On October 5, 1980, while leading an expedition of six persons, including four Brown alumni, in climbing Mount Nun in the Himalayas, Thomas A. Mutch fell while descending from the summit.<cite><a href="Mutch, Thomas A..html">Mutch, Thomas A.</a></cite>
On October 22, 1980, the American Astronomical Society Eagle Award was bestowed upon him was awarded posthumously.<cite><a href="Mutch, Thomas A..html">Mutch, Thomas A.</a></cite>
On January 7, 1981, the Viking Lander 1 Spacecraft was named for him and a plaque prepared to be placed on the craft when the first manned mission lands on Mars was inscribed: "Thomas A. Mutch Memorial Station.<cite><a href="Mutch, Thomas A..html">Mutch, Thomas A.</a></cite>
The Name, Brown University, was adopted in 1804.<cite><a href="Name.html">Name</a></cite>
The <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> empowered by the <a href="Charter.html">Charter</a> in 1764 was "in Fact and Name to be known by the Name of Trustees, and Fellows of the College or University in the <a href="English.html">English</a> Colony of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations in New England in America the Trustees and Fellows at any time hereafter giving such more particular Name to the College in Honor of the greatest &amp; most distinguished Benefactor or otherwise as they shall think proper ..." Thus the college was known as Rhode Island College, and even sometimes casually referred to as Providence College.<cite><a href="Name.html">Name</a></cite>
<a href="President.html">President</a> Maxcy, in a letter to Richard Furman on October 26, 1795, wrote, "This College is still without a "name."<cite><a href="Name.html">Name</a></cite>
The <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> had passed a resolution at its meeting in September 1795 that a gift of $6,000 previous to the next <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> would entitle the donor to name the college, but no donor was forthcoming at this time.<cite><a href="Name.html">Name</a></cite>
Again in September 1803 the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> voted that a donation of $5,000 within a year would entitle the donor to name the college.<cite><a href="Name.html">Name</a></cite>
On September 6, 1804, Nicholas Brown 1786 donated $5,000 for the establishment of a "Professorship of Oratory &amp; Belles Letters (sic)," and the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> voted, "That this College be called and known in all future time by the Name of Brown University in Providence in the State of Rhode Island, and Providence Plantations."<cite><a href="Name.html">Name</a></cite>
Otto Neugebauer (1899-1990), professor of the history of mathematics, was born in Innsbruck in Tyrol on May 26, 1899.<cite><a href="Neugebauer, Otto.html">Neugebauer, Otto</a></cite>
Otto Neugebauer earned his Ph.D. degree at the University of Göttingen in 1926, with a dissertation on Egyptian fractions.<cite><a href="Neugebauer, Otto.html">Neugebauer, Otto</a></cite>
Otto Neugebauer was assistant professor at Göttingen from 1927 to 1933, and research professor at the University of Copenhagen from 1934 to 1939.<cite><a href="Neugebauer, Otto.html">Neugebauer, Otto</a></cite>
When the first publication of scientific cuneiform texts was happening, Neugebauer, realizing that the translators did not understand the mathematics involved, undertook the work himself, and between 1935 and 1938 published a three-volume edition of Babylonian mathematical texts.<cite><a href="Neugebauer, Otto.html">Neugebauer, Otto</a></cite>
Nazi interference with his work in Denmark led him to come to Brown in 1939 as professor of mathematics, bringing with him the journal which Otto Neugebauer was editing and would continue to edit at Brown, "Mathematical Reviews."<cite><a href="Neugebauer, Otto.html">Neugebauer, Otto</a></cite>
In 1941 Otto Neugebauer was able to bring Abraham Sachs to Brown with a fellowship from the Rockefeller Foundation, and together they published "Mathematical Cuneiform Texts."<cite><a href="Neugebauer, Otto.html">Neugebauer, Otto</a></cite>
In 1945 Neugebauer and Sachs published "Mathematical Cuneiform Texts."<cite><a href="Neugebauer, Otto.html">Neugebauer, Otto</a></cite>
Neugebauer was responsible for the founding of the History of Mathematics Department in 1947.<cite><a href="Neugebauer, Otto.html">Neugebauer, Otto</a></cite>
Otto Neugebauer's book, "The Exact Sciences in Antiquity," published in 1951, was awarded the Heineman Foundation Prize in 1952, the same year in which his "The Babylonian Method for the Computation of the Last Visibilities of Mercury" won the John F. Lewis Prize of the American Philosophical Society.<cite><a href="Neugebauer, Otto.html">Neugebauer, Otto</a></cite>
In 1961 Otto Neugebauer was awarded an American Council of Learned Societies prize as one of ten outstanding American university professors who were honored for "distinguished accomplishment in humanistic scholarship."<cite><a href="Neugebauer, Otto.html">Neugebauer, Otto</a></cite>
Otto Neugebauer was chairman of the History of Mathematics Department until 1965.<cite><a href="Neugebauer, Otto.html">Neugebauer, Otto</a></cite>
Otto Neugebauer retired in 1969.<cite><a href="Neugebauer, Otto.html">Neugebauer, Otto</a></cite>
In 1975 Otto Neugebauer published "A History of Ancient Mathematical Astronomy."<cite><a href="Neugebauer, Otto.html">Neugebauer, Otto</a></cite>
Otto Neugebauer died on February 19, 1990 in Princeton, New Jersey.<cite><a href="Neugebauer, Otto.html">Neugebauer, Otto</a></cite>
Since 1954 Otto Neugebauer had been associated with the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton.<cite><a href="Neugebauer, Otto.html">Neugebauer, Otto</a></cite>
On being elected to the American Academy of Science in 1977, Otto Neugebauer was cited as having had "more influence ... in the progress of mathematics in this century than any other individual."<cite><a href="Neugebauer, Otto.html">Neugebauer, Otto</a></cite>
New Pembroke, a new style of dormitory complex, was built in 1974.<cite><a href="New Pembroke.html">New Pembroke</a></cite>
The design was awarded first place from among 670 entries in a competition sponsored by the magazine "Progressive Architecture" in 1970, but construction was postponed when the city refused to grant a zoning exception.<cite><a href="New Pembroke.html">New Pembroke</a></cite>
Nicholson House at 71 George Street, was originally the home of Francis W. Goddard, built in 1878-79 and given to him by his mother, Charlotte Ives Goddard.<cite><a href="Nicholson House.html">Nicholson House</a></cite>
The University acquired ownership of the house in 1944, with an agreement that Mrs. Nicholson had the right to occupy it during her lifetime.<cite><a href="Nicholson House.html">Nicholson House</a></cite>
It was voted by the Advisory and Executive Committee in 1948 that the name of the building would be Nicholson House.<cite><a href="Nicholson House.html">Nicholson House</a></cite>
In 1963 the <a href="Brown University Press.html">Brown University Press</a> moved into Nicholson House, and was followed by other offices connected with University Relations.<cite><a href="Nicholson House.html">Nicholson House</a></cite>
Norwood House at 82 Waterman Street, a former boarding house which had been renovated for the use of the <a href="American Civilization.html">American Civilization</a> Program, was named in 1982 in recognition of the generosity of V. Lee Norwood ’53.<cite><a href="Norwood House.html">Norwood House</a></cite>
"Novel" first appeared in the fall of 1967, created by Edward Bloom, Park Honan, and Mark Spilka, all members of the <a href="English.html">English</a> Department, who recognized the need for an academic journal to encourage the study of fiction as a genre.<cite><a href="Novel.html">Novel</a></cite>
Honan, given a choice of available post office box numbers for the journal, chose "1984," and the title of the opening announcement by Spilka in the first issue was "On Box 1984."<cite><a href="Novel.html">Novel</a></cite>
When he moved to the University of Birmingham in 1968, Park Honan started a British branch of "Novel," and with David Lodge, set up a symposium on the Novel in which "nine very active British critics" participated at the Stratford Institute at Stratford-on-Avon on December 7 and 8, 1968.<cite><a href="Novel.html">Novel</a></cite>
In celebration of the tenth anniversary of the periodical, a conference was held as part of the festivities connected with the inauguration of <a href="President.html">President</a> Swearer in April of 1977.<cite><a href="Novel.html">Novel</a></cite>
Edward Bloom was succeeded as senior editor by Mark Spilka in 1987.<cite><a href="Novel.html">Novel</a></cite>
(Robert) Gale Noyes (1898-1961), professor of English was born in Norwich, Connecticut on September 1, 1898.<cite><a href="Noyes, Robert Gale.html">Noyes, Robert Gale</a></cite>
After graduation from Norwich Free Academy Robert Gale Noyes entered Brown and received both the bachelor of arts and master of arts degrees in 1921.<cite><a href="Noyes, Robert Gale.html">Noyes, Robert Gale</a></cite>
Robert Gale Noyes earned his Ph.D. at Harvard and became an assistant professor there before he returned to Brown in 1938 as associate professor of English.<cite><a href="Noyes, Robert Gale.html">Noyes, Robert Gale</a></cite>
Robert Gale Noyes was promoted to full professor in 1951.<cite><a href="Noyes, Robert Gale.html">Noyes, Robert Gale</a></cite>
Robert Gale Noyes published "Ben Jonson on the English Stage, 1660-1776" in 1935, "The Thespian Mirror" in 1953, and "The Neglected Muse" in 1958.<cite><a href="Noyes, Robert Gale.html">Noyes, Robert Gale</a></cite>
Robert Gale Noyes was ill during the academic year 1960-61 and died in Providence on March 25.<cite><a href="Noyes, Robert Gale.html">Noyes, Robert Gale</a></cite>
1961.<cite><a href="Noyes, Robert Gale.html">Noyes, Robert Gale</a></cite>
"Nucleus," "a little magazine," was first published in the winter of 1953.<cite><a href="Nucleus.html">Nucleus</a></cite>
Only three issues were printed, the last in the winter of 1954.<cite><a href="Nucleus.html">Nucleus</a></cite>
The Nursing program which began in 1931 was offered jointly by <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a> and the Rhode Island Hospital Training School for Nurses.<cite><a href="Nursing program.html">Nursing program</a></cite>
The suggestion for a program of this type first appeared in the report of the Survey Committee which studied the University and made recommendations in 1930.<cite><a href="Nursing program.html">Nursing program</a></cite>
Professor George Ide Chace was president of the Board of Trustees when the hospital’s nursing school was started in 1882.<cite><a href="Nursing program.html">Nursing program</a></cite>
Among the Brown biology professors who served on the board of trustees of the hospital were Professor Hermon Carey Bumpus from 1895 to 1901, and Professor Albert D. Mead, who succeeded him in 1901 and was president of the board in 1934.<cite><a href="Nursing program.html">Nursing program</a></cite>
Five students enrolled in the fall of 1931, before the program was formerly approved by the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> on January 8, 1932.<cite><a href="Nursing program.html">Nursing program</a></cite>
The first two students were graduated from the nursing school in 1935 and received their degrees in 1936.<cite><a href="Nursing program.html">Nursing program</a></cite>
In the 1938-39 <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a> catalogue the name of the program was changed from "A Course for the Training of Teachers of Nursing" to "A Course in Nursing <a href="Education.html">Education</a>."<cite><a href="Nursing program.html">Nursing program</a></cite>
Miss Skoogland initiated a review of the nursing program, addressing a questionnaire to the 45 graduates from 1936 to 1948, and a meeting of a "Special Committee on the Five Year Program" composed of University and hospital representatives was held on November 3, 1948.<cite><a href="Nursing program.html">Nursing program</a></cite>
The success of the nursing program was further thwarted when the National Nursing Accrediting Service visited in 1950 and accredited the hospital nursing school, but not the five-year program.<cite><a href="Nursing program.html">Nursing program</a></cite>
Later invitations to apply for accreditation in 1953 and 1957 were not pursued.<cite><a href="Nursing program.html">Nursing program</a></cite>
In 1959 a special committee, noting that the University of Rhode Island and Salve Regina College were offering four-year nursing programs and that the steps necessary for accreditation of the Pembroke program were not practical considering the small number of students, recommended that registration for the bachelor of science degree in nursing be discontinued with the class entering in 1960.<cite><a href="Nursing program.html">Nursing program</a></cite>
The last nursing diploma received by a Pembroke student was awarded in November 1963, and the last degree in nursing in June 1964.<cite><a href="Nursing program.html">Nursing program</a></cite>
The "Observer" was described as a "fortnightly publication by the students of Brown University with the cooperation of the <a href="English.html">English</a> Department and the approval of the Committee on Student Activities" when it first appeared on January 17, 1949.<cite><a href="Observer.html">Observer</a></cite>
The Olney-Margolies Athletic Center was dedicated on October 31, 1981.<cite><a href="Olney-Margolies Athletic Center.html">Olney-Margolies Athletic Center</a></cite>
Named for two principal donors, both members of the Class of 1936, Joseph Olney and Moe Price Margolies, it is sometimes called the "Joe-Moe Building."<cite><a href="Olney-Margolies Athletic Center.html">Olney-Margolies Athletic Center</a></cite>
At the dedication, honorary degrees were awarded to sportswriter Red Smith, featured speaker at the exercises, and famous Brown football player Fritz Pollard 1919, who was prevented by illness from attending.<cite><a href="Olney-Margolies Athletic Center.html">Olney-Margolies Athletic Center</a></cite>
Richard Olney (1835-1917), United States Attorney General and Secretary of State, was born in Oxford, Massachusetts, on September 15, 1835.<cite><a href="Olney, Richard.html">Olney, Richard</a></cite>
Richard Olney attended Leicester Academy and graduated from Brown in 1856 and from Harvard Law School in 1858.<cite><a href="Olney, Richard.html">Olney, Richard</a></cite>
Richard Olney joined the law firm of Benjamin F. Thomas of Boston, and married Thomas’ daughter in 1861.<cite><a href="Olney, Richard.html">Olney, Richard</a></cite>
Richard Olney was a Democrat and was elected to the state legislature in 1873, but was defeated for reelection and for other offices.<cite><a href="Olney, Richard.html">Olney, Richard</a></cite>
Thus Richard Olney was not well known when Cleveland appointed him Attorney General in 1893.<cite><a href="Olney, Richard.html">Olney, Richard</a></cite>
In 1895 Richard Olney was appointed Secretary of State, and remained in office until the end of the Cleveland administration.<cite><a href="Olney, Richard.html">Olney, Richard</a></cite>
The "Boston Transcript" assessed his record in 1897, "Mr. Olney’s methods were those of a strong and well-equipped lawyer; there was nothing of the politician in his administration of either cabinet office.<cite><a href="Olney, Richard.html">Olney, Richard</a></cite>
Richard Olney died on April 8, 1917, in Boston.<cite><a href="Olney, Richard.html">Olney, Richard</a></cite>

Lars Onsager, (1903-1976), instructor in chemistry, was born in Oslo on November 27, 1903.<cite><a href="Onsager, Lars.html">Onsager, Lars</a></cite>
Lars Onsager received a degree from the Norwegian Technical University in 1925 and studied at Zurich University before coming to the United States in 1928.<cite><a href="Onsager, Lars.html">Onsager, Lars</a></cite>
In that year, after a brief stint as associate in chemistry at Johns Hopkins University, Lars Onsager came to Brown as research instructor in chemistry and stayed until 1933.<cite><a href="Onsager, Lars.html">Onsager, Lars</a></cite>
In 1968 Lars Onsager won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry for work which he had done at Brown and had published in 1931.<cite><a href="Onsager, Lars.html">Onsager, Lars</a></cite>
Lars Onsager died on October 2, 1976 in Coral Gables, Florida.<cite><a href="Onsager, Lars.html">Onsager, Lars</a></cite>
The Orwig <a href="Music.html">Music</a> Center occupies a building at 1 Young Orchard Avenue, which was built about 1850 for Byron Sprague, son of manufacturer Amasa Sprague.<cite><a href="Orwig Music Center.html">Orwig Music Center</a></cite>
After the collapse of the Sprague business in 1873, the house passed into other hands and was eventually purchased by I. Gifford Ladd.<cite><a href="Orwig Music Center.html">Orwig Music Center</a></cite>
Later the building was the Hope Hospital, was sold to <a href="Bryant College.html">Bryant College</a> and named South Hall, and was acquired by Brown in 1969 with the purchase of the <a href="Bryant College.html">Bryant College</a> campus.<cite><a href="Orwig Music Center.html">Orwig Music Center</a></cite>
The music library in the new wing built in 1988 was named for Mrs. Orwig, and was dedicated on two days in May 1988 at exercises featuring a performance by the Charleston String Quartet and an address by Joseph B. Kerman, professor of music at the University of California.<cite><a href="Orwig Music Center.html">Orwig Music Center</a></cite>
Otis Smith Farm, a seventeen-acre farm with a brook, on Scott Road in Ashton, Rhode Island, twelve miles from the campus, was left to <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a> in 1964 by Lura Mae Thomas Smith ’01, widow of Otis Smith.<cite><a href="Otis Smith Farm.html">Otis Smith Farm</a></cite>
The Outing Reservation, ninety acres of land and a thirty-acre pond in Greenville, R. I., was purchased with funds given by the Class of 1906 at its twenty-fifth reunion in 1931.<cite><a href="Outing Reservation.html">Outing Reservation</a></cite>
The plan for such a wooded retreat for members of the university community had been conceived by Clinton C. White ’00, <a href="President.html">President</a> of the Brown Club of Rhode Island, and Professor W. H. Kenerson 1896.<cite><a href="Outing Reservation.html">Outing Reservation</a></cite>
The reservation and the main lodge, also the gift of the Class of 1906 were dedicated to the memory of its first class president, Florence John Harrington Price ’06, who was killed in action at Vimy Ridge, May 30, 1916.<cite><a href="Outing Reservation.html">Outing Reservation</a></cite>
Along with the plaque of dedication, there was another plaque in the lodge, containing a poem by Eliot G. Parkhurst ’06, which reads: During 1931-32 a second cabin, a gift of the Class of 1907, was built, and the <a href="Botany.html">Botany</a> Department conducted a reforestation project, planting 2,000 young pines, and labelled a number of different trees.<cite><a href="Outing Reservation.html">Outing Reservation</a></cite>
The 1907 Cabin was destroyed by fire in 1954 and rebuilt in 1955.<cite><a href="Outing Reservation.html">Outing Reservation</a></cite>
There were two other buildings, the boathouse built with funds raised by the classes of 1914, 1927, and 1932, and the "Cabana."<cite><a href="Outing Reservation.html">Outing Reservation</a></cite>
In May 1963 a Brown student who fell from a boat was drowned.<cite><a href="Outing Reservation.html">Outing Reservation</a></cite>
The University reluctantly put the property up for sale, and it was purchased in December 1965 by the YMCA, which had previously leased the property for use as a summer day camp.<cite><a href="Outing Reservation.html">Outing Reservation</a></cite>
With part of the proceeds from the sale was established the Class of 1906 recreation fund, which was later used for recreational facilities at the Mount Hope Grant.<cite><a href="Outing Reservation.html">Outing Reservation</a></cite>
Owl and Ring was founded in 1926 as a discussion group which evolved into a senior honorary society.<cite><a href="Owl and Ring.html">Owl and Ring</a></cite>
Reports that the society was dedicated to promoting separate Brown and Pembroke commencements were denied in 1933, but surfaced again in 1935 in "<a href="Bear Facts.html">Bear Facts</a>," which added, "In spite of the impressive name, nothing further has been heard of this organization except once a year at the final Class Sing in May, when new members are tapped by the outgoing berobed owls."<cite><a href="Owl and Ring.html">Owl and Ring</a></cite>
In 1939-40 the society was enlarged and given definite functions, including the guardianship of the bear mascot and the direction of the <a href="Campus.html">Campus</a> Sing and the Senior Frolic.<cite><a href="Owl and Ring.html">Owl and Ring</a></cite>
In September 1941 Owl and Ring was disbanded by the <a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a> for failing to live up to its resonsibilities.<cite><a href="Owl and Ring.html">Owl and Ring</a></cite>
Alpheus Spring Packard (1839-1905), professor of zoology and geology, was born in Brunswick, Maine, on February 19, 1839.<cite><a href="Packard, Alpheus S..html">Packard, Alpheus S.</a></cite>
Alpheus S. Packard graduated from Bowdoin in 1861.<cite><a href="Packard, Alpheus S..html">Packard, Alpheus S.</a></cite>
The "Cambridge Scientific School" was the Lawrence Scientific School at Harvard, where Packard went in 1861 to study with Agassiz, earning his tuition by taking care of insects, and other funds by working in the museum.<cite><a href="Packard, Alpheus S..html">Packard, Alpheus S.</a></cite>
Alpheus S. Packard received a bachelor of science degree from the school in 1864.<cite><a href="Packard, Alpheus S..html">Packard, Alpheus S.</a></cite>
In February 1864, Alpheus S. Packard wrote to his father, "I shall have to defer finishing my medical studies, though I very much want the degree.<cite><a href="Packard, Alpheus S..html">Packard, Alpheus S.</a></cite>
In the summer of 1860 Alpheus S. Packard took part in the Williams College expedition to Labrador, and in 1864 he joined the expedition of marine artist William Bradford.<cite><a href="Packard, Alpheus S..html">Packard, Alpheus S.</a></cite>
A Journal of Two Summer Cruises to that Region" in 1891.<cite><a href="Packard, Alpheus S..html">Packard, Alpheus S.</a></cite>
After serving as assistant surgeon of the First Maine Veteran Volunteers during the Civil War, Alpheus S. Packard became librarian and custodian of the Boston Society of Natural History in 1865 and curator of the Essex Institute in 1866.<cite><a href="Packard, Alpheus S..html">Packard, Alpheus S.</a></cite>
From 1867 to 1878 Alpheus S. Packard was curator and then director of the Peabody Academy of Science.<cite><a href="Packard, Alpheus S..html">Packard, Alpheus S.</a></cite>
Meanwhile, Alpheus S. Packard was state entomologist of Massachusetts from 1871 to 1873 and a member of the United States Entomological Commission from 1877 to 1882.<cite><a href="Packard, Alpheus S..html">Packard, Alpheus S.</a></cite>
Alpheus S. Packard came to Brown as professor of geology and zoology in 1878.<cite><a href="Packard, Alpheus S..html">Packard, Alpheus S.</a></cite>
Alpheus S. Packard published "Text-Book of Entymology" in 1898.<cite><a href="Packard, Alpheus S..html">Packard, Alpheus S.</a></cite>
In 1872 Alpheus S. Packard was elected a member of the National Academy of Sciences.<cite><a href="Packard, Alpheus S..html">Packard, Alpheus S.</a></cite>
Alpheus S. Packard gained international recognition in his field, as evidenced by his election in 1872 to the Imperial Zoological-Botanical Society of Vienna, in 1875 to the Société Royale des Sciences de Liègge, Belgium, in 1891 to the Society of Friends of Natural Science of Moscow, and in 1901 to the Linnaen Society of London.<cite><a href="Packard, Alpheus S..html">Packard, Alpheus S.</a></cite>
In 1899 Alpheus S. Packard was named honorary president of the Zoological Congress in Paris.<cite><a href="Packard, Alpheus S..html">Packard, Alpheus S.</a></cite>
Alpheus S. Packard died of blood poisoning on February 14, 1905 in Providence.<cite><a href="Packard, Alpheus S..html">Packard, Alpheus S.</a></cite>
Albert DeForest Palmer (1869-1940), professor of physics, was born in Tewksbury, Massachusetts, on July 21, 1869.<cite><a href="Palmer, Albert D..html">Palmer, Albert D.</a></cite>
Albert D. Palmer graduated from Middlebury High School in Vermont and received a bachelor of philosophy degree from Brown in 1891.<cite><a href="Palmer, Albert D..html">Palmer, Albert D.</a></cite>
Albert D. Palmer did two years of graduate work at Johns Hopkins University before returning to Brown to receive his Ph.D. in 1895.<cite><a href="Palmer, Albert D..html">Palmer, Albert D.</a></cite>
Albert D. Palmer was appointed instructor in physics in 1893 and was promoted to associate professor in 1896.<cite><a href="Palmer, Albert D..html">Palmer, Albert D.</a></cite>
An appreciation of Palmer’s work at Brown appeared in the memorial minute of the faculty in 1940: His book, "The Theory of Measurement," published in 1912, became a standard text in precision measurement.<cite><a href="Palmer, Albert D..html">Palmer, Albert D.</a></cite>
On his retirement in 1934 Albert D. Palmer moved to California and continued experimentation in a laboratory he built.<cite><a href="Palmer, Albert D..html">Palmer, Albert D.</a></cite>
Albert D. Palmer died in Pasadena on January 13, 1940.<cite><a href="Palmer, Albert D..html">Palmer, Albert D.</a></cite>
Calvin Park (1774-1847), professor of languages and of moral philosophy, was born in Northbridge, Massachusetts, on September 11, 1774.<cite><a href="Park, Calvin.html">Park, Calvin</a></cite>
Calvin Park graduated from Rhode Island College in 1797.<cite><a href="Park, Calvin.html">Park, Calvin</a></cite>
Calvin Park taught in Worcester, Massachusetts, from 1797 to 1800.<cite><a href="Park, Calvin.html">Park, Calvin</a></cite>
In 1800 Calvin Park was licensed as a Congregationalist minister.<cite><a href="Park, Calvin.html">Park, Calvin</a></cite>
Calvin Park was a tutor at the College from 1800 to 1804, librarian from 1800 to 1806, professor of learned languages from 1804 to 1811 and of moral philosophy and metaphysics from 1811 to 1825.<cite><a href="Park, Calvin.html">Park, Calvin</a></cite>
Calvin Park was ordained an evangelist in 1815 and was a pastor in Stoughton, Massachusetts, from 1826 to 1840.<cite><a href="Park, Calvin.html">Park, Calvin</a></cite>
Calvin Park died in Stoughton on January 5, 1847.<cite><a href="Park, Calvin.html">Park, Calvin</a></cite>
Charles William Parsons (1823-1893), professor of physiology, was born in Providence on September 6, 1823, the son of Professor <a href="Parsons, Usher.html">Usher Parsons</a>.<cite><a href="Parsons, Charles W..html">Parsons, Charles W.</a></cite>
Charles W. Parsons lived in Cambridge with the Holmes family and graduated from Harvard in 1840.<cite><a href="Parsons, Charles W..html">Parsons, Charles W.</a></cite>
Charles W. Parsons studied medicine with his father, at the medical schools in Boston and Philadelphia, and in Paris, and received his M.D. degree from Harvard in 1845.<cite><a href="Parsons, Charles W..html">Parsons, Charles W.</a></cite>
In 1848 Charles W. Parsons began to practice medicine with his father.<cite><a href="Parsons, Charles W..html">Parsons, Charles W.</a></cite>
After the resignation of <a href="Hill, Nathaniel P..html">Nathaniel P. Hill</a> in 1865, Parsons taught the physiology course at Brown on a temporary basis until 1867, when he was appointed lecturer in physiology.<cite><a href="Parsons, Charles W..html">Parsons, Charles W.</a></cite>
In October 1869 Charles W. Parsons wrote to Professor Caswell of his situation, "As the college does not propose to me a permanent appointment, I cannot rightly undertake such an engagement and sacrifice to it my professional business."<cite><a href="Parsons, Charles W..html">Parsons, Charles W.</a></cite>
Charles W. Parsons decided to resign in 1870, but taught the course for one more year.<cite><a href="Parsons, Charles W..html">Parsons, Charles W.</a></cite>
After Charles W. Parsons retired from his medical practice, he returned as professor of physiology in 1875 and taught until 1882, when he resigned because of his health.<cite><a href="Parsons, Charles W..html">Parsons, Charles W.</a></cite>
Charles W. Parsons was a respected physician, one of the original members of the Providence Medical Association and from 1860 to 1862 president of the Rhode Island Medical Association.<cite><a href="Parsons, Charles W..html">Parsons, Charles W.</a></cite>
Charles W. Parsons was a visiting physician at Rhode Island Hospital until 1874, and after that a consulting physician.<cite><a href="Parsons, Charles W..html">Parsons, Charles W.</a></cite>
Charles W. Parsons died in Providence on September 2, 1893.<cite><a href="Parsons, Charles W..html">Parsons, Charles W.</a></cite>
Usher Parsons (1788-1868), professor of anatomy and surgery in the early medical school, was born in Alfred, Maine, on August 18, 1788.<cite><a href="Parsons, Usher.html">Parsons, Usher</a></cite>
Usher Parsons attended the village school and worked on his father’s farm, and in 1800 attended Berwick Academy for about a year.<cite><a href="Parsons, Usher.html">Parsons, Usher</a></cite>
Usher Parsons worked in stores in Portland and Wells, and in 1807 began the study of medicine with Dr. Abel Hall of Alfred.<cite><a href="Parsons, Usher.html">Parsons, Usher</a></cite>
In 1809 Usher Parsons attended a course of anatomical lectures by Dr. Alexander Ramsay, a Scotsman, given in Fryeburg, Maine.<cite><a href="Parsons, Usher.html">Parsons, Usher</a></cite>
Usher Parsons would gladly have attended a second course, but, being unable to afford this, he took the occasion to reconsider his life:  He was promoted to the rank of surgeon on April 15, 1814.<cite><a href="Parsons, Usher.html">Parsons, Usher</a></cite>
During 1815 and 1816 he was attached to the frigate Java under Commodore Perry, which served in the Mediterranean, and returned to Newport in March 1817, bearing a new treaty with Algiers and eighteen mild cases of smallpox, which Parsons had induced through inoculation with the small pox virus to prevent more serious illness.<cite><a href="Parsons, Usher.html">Parsons, Usher</a></cite>
In July 1817 Parsons came to Providence and boarded with Major Samuel McClellan.<cite><a href="Parsons, Usher.html">Parsons, Usher</a></cite>
In November of that year Usher Parsons began attending lectures at the medical school in Boston, and in March 1818 he received an M.D. degree from Harvard, having written his dissertation on "the epidemic pneumonia of 1812-1813, as it appeared about Lake Erie."<cite><a href="Parsons, Usher.html">Parsons, Usher</a></cite>
In 1820 Parsons was named professor of anatomy and surgery at Dartmouth, and lectured there for a year.<cite><a href="Parsons, Usher.html">Parsons, Usher</a></cite>
Moving to Providence in April 1822, Usher Parsons entered into medical practice with Dr. <a href="Wheaton, Levi.html">Levi Wheaton</a> and was appointed professor of anatomy and surgery at Brown.<cite><a href="Parsons, Usher.html">Parsons, Usher</a></cite>
After the death of his wife in 1825, Usher Parsons boarded with McClellan until 1831.<cite><a href="Parsons, Usher.html">Parsons, Usher</a></cite>
In 1832 Usher Parsons built an office on Waterman Street.<cite><a href="Parsons, Usher.html">Parsons, Usher</a></cite>
Usher Parsons died in Providence on December 19, 1868.<cite><a href="Parsons, Usher.html">Parsons, Usher</a></cite>
John Peirce (1836-1897), professor of chemistry, was born in Providence on August 16, 1836, after the death of his father.<cite><a href="Peirce, John.html">Peirce, John</a></cite>
After graduation from Brown in 1856, John Peirce worked for a short time for a drug and dye company until the depression of 1857 caused him to leave his work and travel to Europe for a year with the Padelfords.<cite><a href="Peirce, John.html">Peirce, John</a></cite>
In 1862 John Peirce was appointed assistant professor of chemistry applied to the arts at Brown and was promoted to professor in 1863.<cite><a href="Peirce, John.html">Peirce, John</a></cite>
John Peirce died on March 3, 1897 in Providence.<cite><a href="Peirce, John.html">Peirce, John</a></cite>
The "News Letter" had made its first appearance in 1928, the year in which the name of the Women’s College was changed to <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a>.<cite><a href="Pembroke Alumna.html">Pembroke Alumna</a></cite>
In its second year, in March 1929, the "Brown Alumnae News Letter," "Published by the <a href="Alumnae Association.html">Alumnae Association</a> of Brown University," became a printed leaflet of four pages.<cite><a href="Pembroke Alumna.html">Pembroke Alumna</a></cite>
It continued in this format, growing over the years to eight pages, and from 1932 including occasional photographs.<cite><a href="Pembroke Alumna.html">Pembroke Alumna</a></cite>
The issue for February 1950 was a magazine with a photographic cover and a newly acquired title, "Pembroke News Letter."<cite><a href="Pembroke Alumna.html">Pembroke Alumna</a></cite>
The "News Letter" was edited by Gertrude Allen McConnell ’10 until her retirement in 1955, and then by Doris Hopkins Stapelton ’28 until 1957.<cite><a href="Pembroke Alumna.html">Pembroke Alumna</a></cite>
The change of title to "Pembroke Alumna" took place in October 1957.<cite><a href="Pembroke Alumna.html">Pembroke Alumna</a></cite>
Editors of the "Pembroke Alumna" were Polly Welts Kaufman ’51 from October 1957 to January 1968, Sally Kappelman Riggs ’62 from April 1968 to July 1971, after which the "Pembroke Alumna" merged with the "Brown Alumni Monthly."<cite><a href="Pembroke Alumna.html">Pembroke Alumna</a></cite>
The Pembroke Center for Teaching and Research on Women was established in 1981 and was dedicated in March 1982 during Women’s <a href="History.html">History</a> Week.<cite><a href="Pembroke Center for Teaching and Research on Women.html">Pembroke Center for Teaching and Research on Women</a></cite>
Pembroke College in Brown University was the name given to the Women’s College in 1928.<cite><a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a></cite>
The first women students had arrived in October 1891, after some years of negotiations.<cite><a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a></cite>
This brief early history of the founding of the Women’s College was included in the annual report of June 1898 of <a href="President.html">President</a> Andrews, who was responsible for its founding:  Margaret Shove Morriss became <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> of the Women’s College in 1923, taking over 350 students, a majority of them from the Providence area, with a staff consisting of a registrar, a physical education teacher, and a secretary.<cite><a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a></cite>
Pembroke College celebrated its fiftieth anniversary in 1941.<cite><a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a></cite>
<a href="President.html">President</a> Wriston, who had announced that "we will celebrate Pembroke’s Fiftieth Anniversary if there are five wars going on," made the anniversary the subject of the opening convocation of the academic year 1941-42.<cite><a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a></cite>
Miss Morriss continued as dean until 1950, with a leave of absence to travel in 1949-50.<cite><a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a></cite>
Nancy Duke Lewis was dean from 1950 to 1961, and Rosemary Pierrel from 1961 to 1971.<cite><a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a></cite>
In 1966 the 75th anniversary of the College featured a three-day arts festival, including the first public showing of the art collection of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Rothschild, a recital by the Paul Taylor dancers, poetry readings by professors of <a href="English.html">English</a>, and a 75th anniversary emblem designed by Professor Walter Feldman.<cite><a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a></cite>
Over the years Brown and Pembroke students merged their student organizations, attended coeducational classes, and in 1969 began living in coed dormitories.<cite><a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a></cite>
On November 12, 1970 a motion adopted by the Advisory and Executive Council of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> announced, "It is the sense of this meeting that it would be in the best interests of the University that appropriate steps be taken to consolidate the administrative functions at Pembroke College with corresponding functions at The College."<cite><a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a></cite>
On July 1, 1971, the offices of the two colleges for admission, financial aid, placement, housing, and counseling were merged in the final act of making Brown a truly coeducational university.<cite><a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a></cite>
The celebration of the one hundredth anniverary of women at Brown began with an Opening <a href="Convocation.html">Convocation</a> address by Smith College College <a href="President.html">President</a> Jill Ker Conway on September 3, 1991, and culminated in a four-day symposium in October, at which Mary Robinson, <a href="President.html">President</a> of Ireland, delivered the principal address.<cite><a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a></cite>
Pembroke Field, bounded by Hope, Meeting, Brook, and Cushing Streets, was formerly the estate of Charles T. Aldrich 1877 and Henry L. Aldrich 1876, received through their bequest and dedicated on October 24, 1936.<cite><a href="Pembroke Field.html">Pembroke Field</a></cite>
The Aldrich barn was transformed into the Pembroke Field House, which was opened on January 14, 1938 at a tea for the <a href="Alumnae Association.html">Alumnae Association</a> council.<cite><a href="Pembroke Field.html">Pembroke Field</a></cite>
The second floor was made into a lounge with a large fireplace, the gift of the class of 1936.<cite><a href="Pembroke Field.html">Pembroke Field</a></cite>
The fireplace accessories were the gift of the class of 1937, and the outside fireplace was the gift of the class of 1905.<cite><a href="Pembroke Field.html">Pembroke Field</a></cite>
In 1971 the Brown Club of Rhode Island raised funds to convert the Pembroke Field House into an alumni center.<cite><a href="Pembroke Field.html">Pembroke Field</a></cite>
In time Andrews took matters into his own hands, and with the assistance of Miss Sarah E. Doyle, principal of the girl’s high school in Providence, assembled a group of influential and interested women, who were invited to tea with Mrs. Andrews on January 31, 1895.<cite><a href="Pembroke Hall.html">Pembroke Hall</a></cite>
Jesse H. Metcalf donated five thousand dollars, and by February of 1896 there was enough money to begin.<cite><a href="Pembroke Hall.html">Pembroke Hall</a></cite>
The building was nearly completed by the target date of <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> in 1897, and the seniors were able to hold <a href="Ivy Day.html">Ivy Day</a> exercises there, but only with the contractors’ permission, as the building awaited the payment of an additional six hundred dollars before it could be transferred to the University.<cite><a href="Pembroke Hall.html">Pembroke Hall</a></cite>
At the dedication of the building on November 22, 1897, Sarah E. Doyle delivered an address tracing the history of the movement for collegiate education for women at Brown University from 1885 when a society of women asked the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> to modify its laws to admit women.<cite><a href="Pembroke Hall.html">Pembroke Hall</a></cite>
That <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a> was founded by a woman, Maria de St. Pol, widow of the Earl of Pembroke, in 1347.<cite><a href="Pembroke Hall.html">Pembroke Hall</a></cite>
The multiple purposes that a room in Pembroke Hall might serve were illustrated by a tongue-in-cheek description of the facilities in the <a href="Ivy Day.html">Ivy Day</a> issue of the "<a href="Sepiad.html">Sepiad</a>" in 1903.<cite><a href="Pembroke Hall.html">Pembroke Hall</a></cite>
After the opening of <a href="Sayles Gymnasium.html">Sayles Gymnasium</a> in 1907 and <a href="Alumnae Hall.html">Alumnae Hall</a> in 1927, Pembroke Hall was renovated for academic purposes, and the growing library moved to more spacious quarters on the top floor.<cite><a href="Pembroke Hall.html">Pembroke Hall</a></cite>
The "Pembroke Record" superseded the "<a href="Sepiad.html">Sepiad</a> Supplement," a newspaper which had been published by the <a href="Sepiad.html">Sepiad</a> Board since November 1919.<cite><a href="Pembroke Record.html">Pembroke Record</a></cite>
The title was changed to "The Record" in December 1922, and to "The Pembroke Record" in 1931.<cite><a href="Pembroke Record.html">Pembroke Record</a></cite>
Publication was suspended from August 1943 to October 1945, when the "Record" and the "Brown Daily Herald" joined in the weekly publication of the "Brown Herald-Record."<cite><a href="Pembroke Record.html">Pembroke Record</a></cite>
The "Record" resumed weekly publication on November 16, 1945.<cite><a href="Pembroke Record.html">Pembroke Record</a></cite>
It continued to be published through the 1960s, even after women were admitted to the staff of the "Brown Daily Herald."<cite><a href="Pembroke Record.html">Pembroke Record</a></cite>
In 1968-69, its final year, the paper changed its title to "Record" (no longer "Pembroke Record)," its format to tabloid size with "Record" in large ornamental letters, and its content to feature articles with occasional poetry and reviews.<cite><a href="Pembroke Record.html">Pembroke Record</a></cite>
The last issue, printed on May 5, 1970, in its first page under the words "Save the "Record!""<cite><a href="Pembroke Record.html">Pembroke Record</a></cite>
(Sidney Joseph) Perelman (1904-1979), humorist, was born in Brooklyn on February 1, 1904, but grew up in Providence, where his father raised chickens (for which his son cherished a life-long hatred), and operated a dry-goods store on Smith Hill.<cite><a href="Perelman, S. J..html">Perelman, S. J.</a></cite>
S. J. Perelman came to Brown in the fall of 1921, one of the "carpetbaggers," who commuted daily to the campus.<cite><a href="Perelman, S. J..html">Perelman, S. J.</a></cite>
In this capacity S. J. Perelman was brought before Dean <a href="Randall, Otis E..html">Otis Randall</a> and the Cammarian Club for an editorial in the January 1925 issue, which read in part: After leaving Brown he was a cartoonist and later writer for "Judge" magazine from 1925 to 1929, and for "College Humor" magazine from 1929 to 1930.<cite><a href="Perelman, S. J..html">Perelman, S. J.</a></cite>
In the early 1930s S. J. Perelman worked as a script writer for the Marx Brothers motion pictures, "Horsefeathers" and "Monkey Business."<cite><a href="Perelman, S. J..html">Perelman, S. J.</a></cite>
S. J. Perelman began writing for the "New Yorker" in 1934.<cite><a href="Perelman, S. J..html">Perelman, S. J.</a></cite>
His many humorous books included "Dawn Ginsbergh’s Revenge," which was published anonymously in 1929, "Parlor, Bedlam and Bath" in 1930, "Crazy Like a Fox" in 1944, "The Swiss Family Perelman" in 1950, and "The Road to Miltown" in 1957.<cite><a href="Perelman, S. J..html">Perelman, S. J.</a></cite>
In October 1970 Perelman left the United States to live in London "forever" as a "resident alien."<cite><a href="Perelman, S. J..html">Perelman, S. J.</a></cite>
S. J. Perelman returned to New York in 1972, having concluded that "English life, while very pleasant, is rather bland.<cite><a href="Perelman, S. J..html">Perelman, S. J.</a></cite>
When Perelman died in New York City on October 17, 1979, William Shawn, then editor of the "New Yorker," said of him, "He was utterly serious, but his medium was humor."<cite><a href="Perelman, S. J..html">Perelman, S. J.</a></cite>
Phi Beta Kappa admitted the Rhode Island Alpha chapter at Brown University in 1830.<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
An earlier effort in 1789 to establish a chapter at what was then Rhode Island College was denied by the Massachusetts Alpha at Harvard, because its committee of four tutors and one resident graduate considered the standards of the college so low as to admit "as Sophimores (sic) persons who would not rank as Freshmen at Cambridge."<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
Determined to have its own fraternal association of learned men, the College in 1797 formed the <a href="Federal Adelphi.html">Federal Adelphi</a>, an organization which flourished for over thirty years until <a href="President.html">President</a> Francis Wayland presented another petition for a branch of Phi Beta Kappa in 1829.<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
When Francis Wayland became president in 1827, he found that influential men among the <a href="Federal Adelphi.html">Federal Adelphi</a> were prepared to antagonize him as they had Asa Messer before him.<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
First Samuel Deane 1805, probably prompted by Wayland, sent a letter to Edward Everett of the Harvard chapter to inquire whether an application for a charter would be likely to be successful.<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
Some encouragement was probably received, as Wayland followed in 1829 with applications to the Alphas of Massachusetts, Connecticut, and New Hampshire for a charter for Rhode Island Alpha.<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
On July 21, 1830, the charter members named four foundation members, William G. Goddard 1812, Romeo Elton 1813, Alexis Caswell 1822, and George Burgess 1826, to assist in the organization of the chapter.<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
On August 14, 1830 eighty of the living graduates of Brown, whose scholarship records qualified them, were elected to membership in Rhode Island Alpha.<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
The obligation of secrecy was removed in 1832.<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
In 1881 at the centennial celebration of the Harvard chapter, when the National Council of Phi Beta Kappa was organized, the appointed delegates of Rhode Island Alpha were not able to attend.<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
The Brown chapter refused to ratify the constitution of the United Chapters until 1895, becoming the last chapter to join.<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
Until 1893 one-third of a class could be elected to membership, and one-half of that number could be chosen in the junior year.<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
As enrollment grew, the rule was changed in 1893 to admit one-fourth of the class with a maximum of 25.<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
In 1904 the maximum was changed to one-fifth and the minimum to one-sixth, and in 1914 another change set the minimum at one-eighth and the maximum at one-sixth.<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
After due consideration it was decided in 1883 that candidates for the Ph.B. degree were eligible for election.<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
In 1904 a requirement that members be chosen only from candidates for the A.B. or Ph.B. degree who had done two-fifths of their work in the humanities was adopted in order to discriminate between eligibility for Phi Beta Kappa and <a href="Sigma Xi.html">Sigma Xi</a>.<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
This requirement was abolished in 1931.<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
The laws of 1905 made graduates ineligible for alumni memberships until five years after graduation.<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
At the first literary exercises held in 1831, Francis Wayland was the orator and Samuel Deane was the poet.<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
Among the orators and poets have been Oliver Wendell Holmes in 1836, George William Curtis in 1854, Edward Everett Hale in 1885, and Woodrow Wilson in 1903.<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
After 1853, the exercises were held in alternate years.<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
In 1911 it was voted to discontinue the exercises.<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
However, an oration and a poem were delivered in 1915.<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
After 1894 there was an annual midwinter banquet, which after several years was succeeded by informal initiation luncheons.<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
Formal dinners were reinstated in 1909 and held in the spring.<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
In 1900 Rhode Island Alpha created a special section for graduates of the Women’s College.<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
The chapter celebrated its hundredth anniversary in 1930.<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
On this occasion Charles Evans Hughes 1881 delivered the principal address on the history of the chapter.<cite><a href="Phi Beta Kappa.html">Phi Beta Kappa</a></cite>
The Phildelphian Society was a fraternal organization of the 1820s, dedicated to liberty and learning.<cite><a href="Philadelphian Society.html">Philadelphian Society</a></cite>
A manuscript entitled "An Oration delivered before the Phildelphian Society, Freshman Class, Brown University, March 1822 by Onslow Peters a member" attests to the existence of the society in the absence of other records.<cite><a href="Philadelphian Society.html">Philadelphian Society</a></cite>
The first meeting of the Rhode Island branch was held on July 3, 1799, the last recorded meeting in November of 1810.<cite><a href="Philandrian Society.html">Philandrian Society</a></cite>
Charles Horace Philbrick (1922-1971), professor of English, was born in Providence on December 12, 1922.<cite><a href="Philbrick, Charles H..html">Philbrick, Charles H.</a></cite>
Charles H. Philbrick entered Brown in 1940, but his education was interrupted by service with the U.S. 8th Air Force stationed in England.<cite><a href="Philbrick, Charles H..html">Philbrick, Charles H.</a></cite>
Charles H. Philbrick finished his course work at Brown in the summer of 1946, and became an assistant in the English Department in the fall, before his formal graduation in 1947.<cite><a href="Philbrick, Charles H..html">Philbrick, Charles H.</a></cite>
Charles H. Philbrick was instructor in 1947-48 and earned his master’s degree that year.<cite><a href="Philbrick, Charles H..html">Philbrick, Charles H.</a></cite>
Charles H. Philbrick received his Ph.D. degree at Brown in 1953, having been instructor in English again since 1949.<cite><a href="Philbrick, Charles H..html">Philbrick, Charles H.</a></cite>
Charles H. Philbrick was appointed assistant professor in 1953, associate professor in 1959, and professor in 1967.<cite><a href="Philbrick, Charles H..html">Philbrick, Charles H.</a></cite>
Charles H. Philbrick won recognition when his poem, "New England Suite," won the Wallace Stevens National Poetry contest in 1962.<cite><a href="Philbrick, Charles H..html">Philbrick, Charles H.</a></cite>
Charles H. Philbrick published two other books of poetry, "Wonderstrand Revisited" in 1960, and "Voyages Down" in 1967, and a novel, "Westaway," in 1968.<cite><a href="Philbrick, Charles H..html">Philbrick, Charles H.</a></cite>
Charles H. Philbrick died on April 4, 1971 in Providence.<cite><a href="Philbrick, Charles H..html">Philbrick, Charles H.</a></cite>
The Philendean Society was established in 1815 for the purpose of providing assistance to indigent fellow students "whose poverty alone prevents their appearing among the brightest ornaments of our Institution."<cite><a href="Philendean Society.html">Philendean Society</a></cite>
A statistical account of the society in November 1825 reported seventeen members, thirteen beneficiaries, and a library of 135 volumes.<cite><a href="Philendean Society.html">Philendean Society</a></cite>
The minutes of the society and lists of members and beneficiaries indicate that it continued until 1828.<cite><a href="Philendean Society.html">Philendean Society</a></cite>
Books from the library of the society continued to be lent until 1846.<cite><a href="Philendean Society.html">Philendean Society</a></cite>
The Philermenian Society was called the "Misokosmian Society" when it was first organized by eighteen students in 1794.<cite><a href="Philermenian Society.html">Philermenian Society</a></cite>
In 1798 a new constitution provided for renaming the society the "Philermenian Society," increasing the membership to 45 (it had earlier been increased to forty), celebrating the society’s anniversary with appropriate literary exercises, and forming a library.<cite><a href="Philermenian Society.html">Philermenian Society</a></cite>
Both of these facts led in 1806 to the formation of a new "Republican" society named the "<a href="United Brothers.html">United Brothers</a>."<cite><a href="Philermenian Society.html">Philermenian Society</a></cite>
After the building of <a href="Hope College.html">Hope College</a> in 1822, rooms on the top floor were provided to the societies for holding meetings and keeping their libraries, which had formerly occupied space in the college library room.<cite><a href="Philermenian Society.html">Philermenian Society</a></cite>
The Philermenian Society had 3,224 volumes when a printed catalogue was issued in 1849.<cite><a href="Philermenian Society.html">Philermenian Society</a></cite>
The anniversary celebrations of the societies with student speakers were held in the college chapel until 1811, when the Philermenians first held their celebration at the First Congregational Church and chose graduate members as poet and orator.<cite><a href="Philermenian Society.html">Philermenian Society</a></cite>
Beginning in 1841, the two societies held a joint celebration, at which members were distinguished by the wearing of a blue ribbon by the Philermenians and a white ribbon by the <a href="United Brothers.html">United Brothers</a>.<cite><a href="Philermenian Society.html">Philermenian Society</a></cite>
A petition to <a href="President.html">President</a> Wayland in 1851 asking permission to hold meetings in the evening was denied, but was later granted by <a href="President.html">President</a> Sears.<cite><a href="Philermenian Society.html">Philermenian Society</a></cite>
Thomas W. Bicknell 1860, who had been "electioneered" by both societies, gave this description of his initiation into the Philermenian Society: The societies continued to meet regularly until about 1860, but interest in them waned as the number of Greek letter fraternities grew.<cite><a href="Philermenian Society.html">Philermenian Society</a></cite>
In an attempt to create interest the Philermenian Society joined the United States Literary League in 1862, becoming Omicron chapter.<cite><a href="Philermenian Society.html">Philermenian Society</a></cite>
The last joint celebration of the Philermenians and the <a href="United Brothers.html">United Brothers</a> occurred in 1863, the last initiation of members of new members in 1866.<cite><a href="Philermenian Society.html">Philermenian Society</a></cite>
The membership lists disappeared from the "<a href="Brown Paper.html">Brown Paper</a>," the libraries of the two societies were diminished by unsupervised borrowing from unlocked meeting rooms, and in 1869 the rooms assigned to the societies were made over into dormitory rooms.<cite><a href="Philermenian Society.html">Philermenian Society</a></cite>
The Philophysian Society was formed by seven students who met on July 17, 1818 at No.<cite><a href="Philophysian Society.html">Philophysian Society</a></cite>
Records of the Society (the earliest of which spell its names "Philophusian") exist up until 1826.<cite><a href="Philophysian Society.html">Philophysian Society</a></cite>
One of the exercises at the first <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> in 1769 was "a Syllogistic Dispute ... on this Thesis, "‘Materia cogitare non potest.’"" Notes taken by Solomon Drowne 1773 in his junior year reveal that <a href="President.html">President</a> Manning’s lectures in philosophy touched briefly upon psychology, intellectual and moral philosophy, ontology, and natural philosophy, and this instruction was completed in only a few days more than a month.<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
The Laws of 1783 prescribed "Hutchinsons moral Philosophy" in the third year and "Locke on the Understanding" in the fourth.<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
From 1811 to 1825 Calvin Park was professor of moral philosophy and metaphysics.<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
William Giles Goddard succeeded Park from 1825 to 1834, when he switched to the teaching of rhetoric and the evidences of Christianity, and <a href="President.html">President</a> Wayland became professor of moral and intellectual philosophy.<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
Ezekiel Gilman Robinson 1838, who studied under Wayland before the writing of the "Intellectual Philosophy," wrote of Wayland’s teaching; After Wayland, succeeding presidents continued to perform also as professors of moral and intellectual philosophy.<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
Barnas Sears taught from 1855 to 1867, and Ezekiel Gilman Robinson from 1872 to 1889.<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
