In the intervening years of 1867 to 1872, George Ide Chace took over in the place of Alexis Caswell, a mathematician who had come out of retirement to serve as president.<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
Until the late 1880s the instruction in philosophy consisted of two semesters in the fourth year, which included courses in Intellectual Philosophy (Hamilton’s Lectures of Metaphysics, Kant’s Critique of Pure Reason, Wayland’s Intellectual Philosophy, Porter’s The Human Intellect, Sully’s Outlines of <a href="Psychology.html">Psychology</a>) and Moral Philosophy (Robinson’s Principles and Practice of Morality), lectures in Natural Theology, and Evidences of Christianity, and an elective course of lectures on the <a href="History.html">History</a> of Philosophy.<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
The 1889-90 annual catalogue of the University reflects a change in the teaching of philosophy.<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
Logic, though not offered that year, is mentioned, indicating that the teaching of logic was now removed from the Department of <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a>, where it had been since 1874.<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
The 1890 catalogue states, "The primary aim in the required philosophical studies is to strengthen and discipline the pupil’s mind, and as far as possible to render him a safe, strong, independent thinker and investigator.<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
In 1890 the president met with graduate and honor students in a "Philosophical Seminary."<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
Edmund Burke Delabarre joined the department as associate professor of psychology in 1891 and started the first psychology laboratory.<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
Professor James Seth came in 1892 and taught philosophy until 1896.<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
Walter Goodnow Everett 1885, after several years of teaching Latin, was appointed associate professor of philosophy in 1894 and remained with the department until his retirement in 1930.<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
A Philosophical Club was started in 1893 for "the independent discussion of philosophical questions."<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
In October 1895 the Club invited William James, who had just published his paper, "Is Life Worth Living?"<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
William H. P. Faunce became president in 1899 and assumed the title of professor of moral and intellectual philosophy.<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
He gave a course in Practical Ethics until 1911-12.<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
Alexander Meiklejohn was instructor and assistant professor of philosophy from 1899 to 1902, and had the title of associate professor of logic and metaphysics from 1902 to 1912.<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
The Philosophy Club was reinstituted in 1926 and invited speakers who generated discussions which lasted past midnight.<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
In 1930 the department inaugurated Monday afternoon teas which provided informal meetings of the faculty and students.<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
<a href="Psychology.html">Psychology</a> was removed from the Philosophy Department in 1930.<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
In 1929 a course in the <a href="History.html">History</a> of Philosophy was instituted and was required of all students concentrating in philosophy.<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
Curt J. Ducasse joined the department in 1926, and in 1930 succeeded Professor Everett as chairman, a post he retained until his own retirement in 1951.<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
The department was enlarged by the arrival of Charles A. Baylis (logic and ethics) in 1927, Ralph M. Blake (history of philosphy and metaphysics) in 1930, Arthur E. Murphy (contemporary philosophy, epistemology, and ethics) in 1931, Frederick C. Dommeyer (social and ethics) and William Barrett (contemporary philosophy and aesthetics).<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
Vincent A. Tomas came in 1938, Roderick M. Chisholm and Richard C. Taylor in 1947, John Ladd in 1950, John W. Lenz in 1953, and Richard Schmitt in 1958.<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
Professor Chisholm ’38, who remained at Brown until his retirement in 1987, turned down many offers to teach elsewhere, but did accept visiting professorships at Harvard, Princeton, the University of Chicago, the University of Illinois in Urbana, and the University of California in Santa Barbara, and frequently taught at the University of Graz and the University of Würzburg in Austria.<cite><a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a></cite>
The Photographic Laboratory (Photo Lab) was established in 1939, primarily for the enlargement and dissemination of Brown’s mathematical library, already one of the best in the world.<cite><a href="Photographic Laboratory.html">Photographic Laboratory</a></cite>
On June 9, 1939, the Rockefeller Foundation agreed "to appropriate up to $49,000 to Brown University for expenses of installing a Microfilm Photographic Laboratory, and of supplementing through filming the resources of the <a href="Library.html">Library</a> in the field of mathematics during the period ending June 30, 1944."<cite><a href="Photographic Laboratory.html">Photographic Laboratory</a></cite>
The Photo Lab was located at 70 Waterman Street from 1952 until 1975, when it moved next door to the <a href="Cabinet.html">Cabinet</a>.<cite><a href="Photographic Laboratory.html">Photographic Laboratory</a></cite>
Physical education was unheard of until the arrival of Francis Wayland as president in 1827.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
Wayland, who was given to exercise as an aid to mental agility, installed a German "Turnplatz" on the campus in the spring of 1827 and regular exercises began in the summer term under George F. Haskins.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
Members of the faculty were encouraged to partake of the gymnastic program, and did so at first, but they soon found ways to avoid the exercises, which came to an end with the cold weather even before the 1827-28 annual catalogue was printed with its announcement, "A very complete Gymnasium, with every variety of apparatus for exercise, has lately been erected on the College grounds," the last mention of the Gymnasium.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
George A. Allen 1852 noted in his diary in 1850 that he had paid for a month’s use of a downtown gymnasium and had received a key.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
In 1869 an arrangement was made with Messrs. West and Hunt for the use of their gymnasium by the students on a voluntary basis, half the expense being borne by the college and half by the students.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
In 1884, arrangements were made for the students, who were dissatisfied with the limited accommodations which the Y.M.C.A. had afforded them, to use Smith’s Gymnasium in Butler Exchange for five dollars a year.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
In 1890, while awaiting the completion of the new gymnasium, students were able to make use of the Sanitary Gymnasium downtown on Aborn Street for five dollars a year.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
After Lyman Gymnasium opened in 1891, gymnasium work became required of all students four hours a week beginning in the second term of 1891-92.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
On March 3, 1898 an exhibition of the system of training was performed in Infantry Hall by six hundred students and attended by an equal number of spectators, "many of whom were educators from abroad."<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
The physical education requirement was changed in 1897 to three hours per week, and in 1905 was limited to freshmen and sophomores only.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
In 1913, in the wake of the Titanic disaster, a rule was passed requiring all students to be able to swim a distance of 150 feet before receiving their diplomas, and subsequently one period of swimming instruction was substituted for a period of gymnastic drill.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
Physical education was required for freshmen only in 1924, was reduced to two hours in 1947, and finally became voluntary in 1970.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
Mabel Potter 1897, as a freshman accosted <a href="President.html">President</a> Andrews after chapel and requested gymnastics for the women.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
At the time Andrews recommended walking for exercise, but by 1894 arrangements had been made for the use of a downtown gymnasium by the students.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
In 1897 the alumnae subscribed funds to purchase physical apparatus for the women and a Department of Physical Culture was established with Mabel Potter as instructor of physiology, hygiene, and sanitary science.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
Miss Potter reported a marked improvement in the condition of the students as evidenced by measurements taken in November 1897 and again in April 1898.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
Miss Potter was instructor in physical culture until 1901.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
Janet Auty was instructor from 1901 to 1904, followed by Jessie Adams from 1906, who resigned in December 1906 because of ill health, and was replaced by Helen Wilbur Paine, who taught until 1912.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
Dr. Jeannie Oliver Arnold was physician at the Women’s College from 1902 to 1912 and lectured to the students on care of the body, rest and exercise, food, and clothing.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
M. Elizabeth Bates was instructor in hygiene and physical education from 1913 to 1919, and was followed by Nellie E. Bussell from 1919 to 1922.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
Marjorie Brown was in charge from 1922 until 1926, when she left to marry H. Stanton Smith ’21, and was succeeded by Frances Dennett, who remained until 1930.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
In 1924 the department began to use its "schematograph" to produce posture drawings of freshman and sophomores, a practice which went on for many years.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
A four-year physical education requirement for women students was put effect in 1925.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
In 1935 the Physical <a href="Education.html">Education</a> Department purchased equipment for badminton, croquet, deck tennis, and horseshoes.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
In 1927 the women’s Physical <a href="Education.html">Education</a> Department acquired the use of a house at Glen Rock near Kingston, which belonged to Mrs. George Hayward and was available for the use of women students on weekends.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
The department formed an Outing Club and in 1934 had a cabin on the shore of Sand Dam reservoir in Chepachet.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
Frances Dennett Tiedemann was director of physical education in 1926 until 1930, when Bessie Rudd arrived to preside over women’s athletics and physical education until 1961.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
When the physical education requirement was dropped, the club teams suffered for several years, but various physical education staff members, often coaching two sports per season, kept the "club" spirit alive until the 1972 Olympics and Title IX sparked a revived interest in both voluntary physical education classes and intercollegiate competition.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
Fred E. Parker was the first director of men’s physical education from 1893 to 1903.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
Frederick Marvel followed from 1903 to 1938.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
Leslie Swain, who had been associate professor of physical training since 1920, stayed on until 1945.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
Physical education and intramurals were directed from 1946 to 1953 by Westcott E. S. Moulton, and after 1953 by John M. Heffernan.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
In 1971, upon the merger of Brown and Pembroke, the physical education programs of the two colleges were consolidated under Arlene Gorton ’52, who had succeeded Miss Rudd, as director, and the requirements were removed.<cite><a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a></cite>
Entries of the diary of Solomon Drowne 1773 describe experimental work in natural philosophy.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
The annual catalogue for 1823 listed Enfield’s "Institute of Natural <a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a>" in the curriculum for the junior year.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
In the 1829 catalogue the studies mentioned in the junior year were mechanics, pneumatics, hydrostatics, optics, and astronomy, to which a course in electricity and magnetism was added in 1831.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
Natural <a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a> was taught by Alexis Caswell from 1828 to 1850, by William Augustus Norton in 1850 and 1851, by Henry Day from 1851 to 1854, again by Caswell from 1855 to 1864.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
Samuel Stillman Greene was professor of natural philosophy and astronomy from 1864 to 1883.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
In 1869 Rowland Gibson Hazard and his son Rowland Hazard donated $40,000, for a professorship which would benefit the university and concurred in the recommendation of <a href="President.html">President</a> Caswell that the funds be used for the Hazard Professorship of Physics, to which Eli Whitney Blake was appointed.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
Physics became a very popular study with the arrival in 1870 of both the well-liked Professor Blake and a Holtz Electrical Machine, from which, in a darkened room, the students observed with wonder the power of electricity.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
Two members of Blake’s first class, juniors John J. Holbrook 1872 and Edwin A.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
Herring 1872 were inspired by his lectures to install a telegraphic line between their rooms at opposite ends of <a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a>.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
Blake was hampered by the lack of facilities, but finally reported in 1877, "The Physical laboratory was thrown open to students this year."<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
In 1887-88 Arnold Green added to the physical apparatus his gift of a barometer, solar radiometer, and hygrometer which had been used by Professor Alexis Caswell 1822 in his meteorological observations.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
In 1891 <a href="Wilson Hall.html">Wilson Hall</a> was opened for the use of the Physics Department.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
Its lecture room was used in 1891-92 for two <a href="University Extension.html">University Extension</a> courses, one in mechanics and the other in electricity, given by William D. Mount.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
The first Ph.D. degree in the Physics Department was awarded to Albert DeForest Palmer 1891 in 1895.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
Carl Barus was named to the Hazard professorship in 1895.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
Palmer remained at Brown and taught in the department until 1934, the last two years as associate professor on the Hazard Foundation.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
Carl W. Miller came in 1924 and taught until 1955.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
The Physics Department was reorganized in 1926, and Frederick George Keyes, head of the Department of <a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a> at M.I.T., was appointed acting head of the department.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
Harrison E. Farnsworth joined the department in 1926 and taught until 1970.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
R. Bruce Lindsay 1920, who returned to teach in 1930, became chairman of the department in 1934 and Hazard professor in 1936.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
Three Brown physics professors served as president of the Society, Lindsay in 1957, Robert W. Morse, who came to Brown in 1946, in 1966, and Robert T. Beyer, who came to Brown in 1950, in 1968.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
Lindsay and Beyer were both awarded the Gold Medal of the Society, and Arthur O. Williams, who joined the department in 1950, received its Pioneers Medal for work in Underwater Sound.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
The acoustics work of the department was primarily in underwater sound and in physical acoustics, especially nonlinear acoustics, a field in which Peter J. Westervelt, who joined the department in 1951, pioneered.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
Lindsay became <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> of the <a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a> in 1954, and Williams succeeded him as chairman of the department.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
Professor Russell A. Peck, who had joined the department in 1953, carried out research in experimental nuclear physics.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
In 1957 Williams was able to bring in Leon Cooper in solid state theory.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
Cooper was awarded the Nobel Prize in 1972 (with Bardeen and superconductivity.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
Williams was named the fourth Hazard professor in 1975, and was followed by Beyer as the fifth in 1984.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
Philip J. Bray, who had joined the department and begun work in applications of nuclear magnetic resonance to the study of the atomic structure of glass and crystalline materials, became chair of the department in 1963 and sixth Hazard professor in 1985.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
In the late 1960s money was received from Thomas J. Watson Jr. to develop further the program in solid state physics, but the the national decline of support in physics, the department shrank, and the astrophysics group was eliminated.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
Stiles served as chairman of the department from 1974 to 1980, and was succeeded by Charles Elbaum who was named Hazard professor in 1991.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
Robert Lanou followed as chairman in 1986, and Anthony Houghton in 1992.<cite><a href="Physics.html">Physics</a></cite>
Pi Kappa, was a junior society, said to be "reinstituted in 1900."<cite><a href="Pi Kappa.html">Pi Kappa</a></cite>
In the "<a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a>," beginning in 1901, the list of members of Pi Kappa appears, under this heading, "1864-1894 Re-Instituted 1900."<cite><a href="Pi Kappa.html">Pi Kappa</a></cite>
The "<a href="Brown Paper.html">Brown Paper</a>" includes in November 1864 and again in November 1865 a society called "Pi Kappa Fraternitas," with a list of members whose names are decidedly fictitious.<cite><a href="Pi Kappa.html">Pi Kappa</a></cite>
The revived society, if such it was, presented during <a href="Junior Week.html">Junior Week</a> in April 1901 a farce entitled "Through Thick and Thin" in Lyman Gymnasium, which the "Brown Daily Herald" described as "not at all pretentious in plot or length," but "bright and witty."<cite><a href="Pi Kappa.html">Pi Kappa</a></cite>
When Pi Kappa was replaced by the <a href="Brown Key.html">Brown Key</a> in 1930, the retiring members tapped the new Key members.<cite><a href="Pi Kappa.html">Pi Kappa</a></cite>
The Pizzitola Sports Center, built in 1987 and 1988 and opened in February 1989, is named the Paul Bailey Pizzitola Memorial Sports Center in memory of Paul Bailey Pizzitola ’81, whose father contributed two million dollars toward its construction.<cite><a href="Pizzitola Sports Center.html">Pizzitola Sports Center</a></cite>
The Heisman Lobby is named for John Heisman 1891.<cite><a href="Pizzitola Sports Center.html">Pizzitola Sports Center</a></cite>
Plantations House was opened in the fall of 1954 as a dormitory center for commuting students.<cite><a href="Plantations House.html">Plantations House</a></cite>
In the fall of 1962 Plantations House was assigned to the house at 20 Benevolent Street, and was later located at 219 Bowen Street from about 1970 until the early 1980s, when there was no further need for a day center for commuters.<cite><a href="Plantations House.html">Plantations House</a></cite>
One of the earliest examples is the valediction of Barnabas Binney 1774, pronounced at <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a>, when he bid farewell to the president, the professor, and his classmates.<cite><a href="Poetry.html">Poetry</a></cite>
Jonathan Maxcy 1787 at his <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> delivered "A Poem on the Prospects of America," which was published by subscription.<cite><a href="Poetry.html">Poetry</a></cite>
Paul Allen 1793 wrote "On leaving Rhode-Island College," and "The Pleasures of Literature," dedicated to the late <a href="President.html">President</a> James Manning.<cite><a href="Poetry.html">Poetry</a></cite>
In a lighter vein, Albert Gorton Greene 1820 wrote "Old Grimes" while he was a student, William M. Thayer 1843 wrote "The Bachelor’s Soliloquy," and Charles M. Sheldon 1883 wrote "I Want to be a Student."<cite><a href="Poetry.html">Poetry</a></cite>
John Hay 1858 wrote many poems, among them "Centennial" for the hundredth anniversary of the University in 1864.<cite><a href="Poetry.html">Poetry</a></cite>
"Brown Verse," subtitled "Selections from Verse published in the <a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a> and The <a href="Brown Magazine.html">Brown Magazine</a>; including Extracts from Class Poem," was compiled and edited by the <a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a> Board of 1893-94 in 1894.<cite><a href="Poetry.html">Poetry</a></cite>
Another volume, also entitled "Brown Verse," "A Selection of Brown University Undergraduate Poetry," was edited by Vernon Purinton Squires 1889 and Henry Robinson Palmer 1890 in 1888.<cite><a href="Poetry.html">Poetry</a></cite>
"College Hill Verse," "Being Selections from Student Publications of Brown University, 1894-1904," was compiled and arranged by Ilsley Boone 1904 in 1904.<cite><a href="Poetry.html">Poetry</a></cite>
"Two Centuries of Brown Verse, 1764-1964" was selected and edited by Sharon Brown as a Bicentennial Publication in 1965.<cite><a href="Poetry.html">Poetry</a></cite>
Some of the better known poets are John Hay 1858, Sam Walter Foss 1882, Winfield T. Scott ’31, and Charles H. Philbrick ’44.<cite><a href="Poetry.html">Poetry</a></cite>
William Carey Poland (1846-1929), professor of classics and art, was born in Goffstown, New Hampshire, on January 25, 1846.<cite><a href="Poland, William Carey.html">Poland, William Carey</a></cite>
William Carey Poland graduated from Brown in 1868 and was then principal of Worcester Academy for a year and a half.<cite><a href="Poland, William Carey.html">Poland, William Carey</a></cite>
William Carey Poland's career at Brown began as instructor of Greek in 1870, continued as instructor of Latin and Greek from 1871 to 1875, assistant professor of Latin and Greek from 1876 to 1889, and associate professor of Greek from 1889 to 1892.<cite><a href="Poland, William Carey.html">Poland, William Carey</a></cite>
In 1891-92 William Carey Poland was annual director of the American School of Classical Studies in Athens, and on his return was named the first professor of the history of art at Brown.<cite><a href="Poland, William Carey.html">Poland, William Carey</a></cite>
William Carey Poland also served as the curator of the Museum of Classical Archaeology from 1889 to 1893.<cite><a href="Poland, William Carey.html">Poland, William Carey</a></cite>
In the year 1875-76 William Carey Poland studied at the Universities of Berlin and Leipzig.<cite><a href="Poland, William Carey.html">Poland, William Carey</a></cite>
William Carey Poland was hired by Mrs. John Carter Brown to teach Latin to her sons, John Nicholas and Harold, and in 1878 was given a leave of absence from his duties at Brown to travel to Europe with the Browns to tutor his young charges.<cite><a href="Poland, William Carey.html">Poland, William Carey</a></cite>
His leave was extended to 1881 so William Carey Poland might prepare them for college.<cite><a href="Poland, William Carey.html">Poland, William Carey</a></cite>
They entered Brown in 1881 and 1882.<cite><a href="Poland, William Carey.html">Poland, William Carey</a></cite>
William Carey Poland continued as professor of the history of art until his retirement in 1915.<cite><a href="Poland, William Carey.html">Poland, William Carey</a></cite>
William Carey Poland was president of the Rhode Island School of Design from 1896 to 1907.<cite><a href="Poland, William Carey.html">Poland, William Carey</a></cite>
William Carey Poland lectured on the history of art at Boston University in 1901 and 1902, was secretary of the Commission of Colleges in New England on Admission Examinations from 1886 to 1905, and prepared the "Necrology of Brown University," which appeared in the "Providence Journal" annually on Commencement day, from 1888 to 1904.<cite><a href="Poland, William Carey.html">Poland, William Carey</a></cite>
William Carey Poland died in Providence on March 19, 1929.<cite><a href="Poland, William Carey.html">Poland, William Carey</a></cite>
Political Science was introduced in 1889 as an elective in the senior year.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
In earlier times the annual catalogues listed Vattel’s "Law of Nations" as one of the textbooks studied in the senior year in 1824 and 1825.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
Later Jeremiah Lewis Diman, professor of history and political economy from 1864 to 1880, included Roman, international, and constitutional law in his history course.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
In 1888 John Franklin Jameson replaced Andrews with the title of professor of history and political science.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
The two course offerings in 1889 were, in the first term, "The Constitutions of European and American States, together with a history of their internal politics during recent years," and, in the second term, "<a href="History.html">History</a> of Law, and International Law, together with the history of the external relations of European and American States during recent years."<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
In 1889-90 the senior class heard a series of lectures on law by local lawyers.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
In 1891 the department was expanded to include history, political science, and social science with George Grafton Wilson, newly-appointed associate professor of political and social science.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
A course in law was introduced in 1893.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
For several years beginning in 1894 two law courses were conducted by young graduates of the University, one in elementary law by Elmer Almy Wilcox 1891 and one in Roman law by Theodore Francis Green 1887.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
Green taught until 1897.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
The course in elementary law was taken over by Chester W. Barrows from 1899 until 1903, and then taught by William W. Moss until 1904, when the course, which had become a pre-law school course, was discontinued.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
A course in political theory was introduced in 1893, followed by a course in diplomacy in 1894-95, one in current political theory and practice in 1895-96, and one in municipal functions in 1897.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
In 1896-97, when constitutional revision came up in Rhode Island, one course became a mock convention to design a constitution for the state.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
A course on "The State" became part of a composite course in economics, political, and social science in 1898.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
In 1900 the annexation of the Philippines brought about a course in colonial administration.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
In 1907 the course, "Investigation of special topics," was given in connections with the Legislative Reference Bureau of the State <a href="Library.html">Library</a>.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
James Quayle Dealey, who began teaching at Brown in 1895, was head of the Department of Political and Social Science from 1910 to 1928.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
Dealey’s teaching was mostly in sociology, while John Corliss Dunning, assistant professor from 1912 to 1926, taught only political science.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
In those years there were courses in international relations and foreign governments, and other specialties, such as Sea Power (offered only in 1919), Business Law in 1919, American Foreign Policies in 1921, <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> Law in 1922, and State Government in 1925.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
Matthew C. Mitchell joined the department in 1926, succeeded Dealey as chairman in 1928, and continued as chairman of the Department of Political and Social Science until 1947, and thereafter as chairman of the separate Department of Political Science.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
Leland M. Goodrich, who was instructor in political science in 1922-23, returned as assistant professor in 1926, became head of the department in 1949, and left for Columbia in 1950.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
Guy Dodge became chairman in 1950 and added to the department Whitney Perkins in 1953, Elmer Cornwell in 1955, and Lea Williams in 1956, Elliot Goodman, who was an intern in the department in 1955, became instructor in 1956 and assistant professor in 1958.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
Erwin C. Hargrove came in 1960, and C. Peter Magrath a year later.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
Elmer Cornwell became department chairman in 1962.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
There were many changes in the late 1960s.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
The department expanded as a result of the establishment in 1965 of the East Asia Language and Area Center, with Lea Williams as director.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
This brought three new faculty members to the department, Jerome Grieder ’54 to teach modern Chinese history, King Chen to teach a course in the international relations of Communist China, and in 1966 Ying-mao Kau, a student of Chinese Communist government and social policy.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
African studies expanded with the arrival of Newell Stultz in 1965.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
Lyman Kirkpatrick also came in 1965, resigning after eighteen years with the Central Intelligence Agency.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
Edward N. Beiser, who came in 1968, an expert in public law, was instrumental in the founding in 1977 of the <a href="Center for Law and Liberal Education.html">Center for Law and Liberal Education</a>, of which he became the director.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
Thomas Anton, first holder of a named chair in the department, came in 1983 as the A. Alfred Taubman Professor of American Institutions.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
Nancy L. Rosenblum was in 1979 the first woman to join the department.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
Studies for the doctorate in political science were temporarily discontinued in 1975, but reinstated in 1987.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
In the 1980s the department added seven new professors and changed its emphasis to public policy.<cite><a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a></cite>
Polo was enjoyed briefly and informally in 1931, when a team of Brown students participated with three teams from the 103rd Field Artillery in an exhibition of indoor polo at the Armory of the Mounted Commands on North Main Street on March 21.<cite><a href="Polo.html">Polo</a></cite>
On May 25, 1916 members of the Rhode Island Cavalry and Battery A teams played a game which was the opening event of <a href="Junior Week.html">Junior Week</a>.<cite><a href="Polo.html">Polo</a></cite>
Horace Mann 1819 was honored in Famous American <a href="Issues.html">Issues</a> featuring educators in 1940.<cite><a href="Postage stamps.html">Postage stamps</a></cite>
The 4-cent stamp honoring Charles Evans Hughes 1881, which featured a likeness from a photograph by Harris and Ewing, was issued in 1962, the centennial of his birth.<cite><a href="Postage stamps.html">Postage stamps</a></cite>
Lillian Gilbreth ’15 Ph.D., who with her husband pioneered in time-motion studies in industry and was made famous by the book, "Cheaper by the Dozen," written by two of her children, was chosen to be one of Great American Series in 1984.<cite><a href="Postage stamps.html">Postage stamps</a></cite>
A U.S. Post Office was first installed at Brown in 1926, when it was placed in a rented section of a small building at the junction of Waterman and Brown Streets near Rockefeller Hall.<cite><a href="Post Office.html">Post Office</a></cite>
When the cafeteria was removed from the basement of <a href="Faunce House.html">Faunce House</a>, the Post Office moved in and opened on February 18, 1952.<cite><a href="Post Office.html">Post Office</a></cite>
The approximately 1,400 boxes of 1952 had grown to more than 6,000 in 1989, when the boxes were temporarily removed to the East Side post office, while the Brown post office was enlarged and renovated.<cite><a href="Post Office.html">Post Office</a></cite>
The new post office, with 6,411 student boxes (in numerical order for the first time in years) was rededicated on October 16, 1989, with regional postmaster Wallace Kido presiding and the release of 1,200 commemorative envelopes, decorated by reproduction of a photograph of the coat of arms over the <a href="Van Wickle Gates.html">Van Wickle Gates</a> and a print of the front campus in the middle of the nineteenth century.<cite><a href="Post Office.html">Post Office</a></cite>
Albert Knight Potter (1864-1948), professor of English, was born in South Berwick, Maine, on November 2, 1864.<cite><a href="Potter, Albert K..html">Potter, Albert K.</a></cite>
Albert K. Potter's father of the same name was a member of the Class of 1859 at Brown.<cite><a href="Potter, Albert K..html">Potter, Albert K.</a></cite>
Normal School and graduated from Brown in 1886.<cite><a href="Potter, Albert K..html">Potter, Albert K.</a></cite>
Albert K. Potter was principal of the high school in Middleboro, Massachusetts, from 1887 to 1890, and classical master at the high school in Springfield, Massachusetts, from 1890 to 1897.<cite><a href="Potter, Albert K..html">Potter, Albert K.</a></cite>
Albert K. Potter studied at the University of Leipzig and in Berlin, before becoming associate professor of English at Brown in 1898.<cite><a href="Potter, Albert K..html">Potter, Albert K.</a></cite>
Albert K. Potter was promoted to professor in 1915.<cite><a href="Potter, Albert K..html">Potter, Albert K.</a></cite>
Albert K. Potter retired from teaching in 1935.<cite><a href="Potter, Albert K..html">Potter, Albert K.</a></cite>
Albert K. Potter died in Providence on November 17, 1948.<cite><a href="Potter, Albert K..html">Potter, Albert K.</a></cite>
William Prager (1903-1980), professor of applied mathematics, was born in Karlsruhe, Germany on May 23, 1903.<cite><a href="Prager, William.html">Prager, William</a></cite>
In the early 1930s Prager was already a recognized expert in the fields of vibrations, plasticity, and the theory of structures.<cite><a href="Prager, William.html">Prager, William</a></cite>
William Prager served as acting director of the Institute of Applied Mathematics at the University of Güttingen, but was dismissed in 1933 for his anti-Nazi views.<cite><a href="Prager, William.html">Prager, William</a></cite>
In 1941, when Brown University was beginning a program of Advanced Instruction and Research in Mechanics and was in need of a director, Dean Roland G. D. Richardson of the Graduate School, himself a mathematician, wanted Prager.<cite><a href="Prager, William.html">Prager, William</a></cite>
Prager, his wife and 12-year-old son finally traveled by train to Bagdad, by plane to Karachi, India, and by ship, the "President Monroe," from Bombay around Capetown to New York, a forty-day journey which brought them to the United State in November 1941.<cite><a href="Prager, William.html">Prager, William</a></cite>
In 1965 William Prager left Brown to become professor of applied mechanics at the San Diego campus of the University of California.<cite><a href="Prager, William.html">Prager, William</a></cite>
William Prager was asked to come back in 1968.<cite><a href="Prager, William.html">Prager, William</a></cite>
After his retirement in 1973, Prager lived in Savognin, Switzerland.<cite><a href="Prager, William.html">Prager, William</a></cite>
In 1974 William Prager was elected a Corresponding Member of the Academy of Sciences at Paris, the highest honor in France for a scientist who is not a French citizen.<cite><a href="Prager, William.html">Prager, William</a></cite>
William Prager died in Savognin on March 17, 1980.<cite><a href="Prager, William.html">Prager, William</a></cite>
He is a member of the Board of Fellows, as prescribed by the <a href="Charter.html">Charter</a> of 1764, which listed the names of the "the present Fellows and Fellowship to whom the President when hereafter elected "who shall forever be of the Denomination called Baptist or Antepedo Baptist" – the words in italics are an interlineation – "shall be joined to compleat the Number.""<cite><a href="President.html">President</a></cite>
The sixteen presidents have been:  The inauguration of President Andrews took place at the first chapel service of the academic year at 8:30 A.M. on Wednesday, September 18, 1889.<cite><a href="President.html">President</a></cite>
On the occasion of President Faunce’s inauguration five divisions made up the procession to the <a href="First Baptist Church.html">First Baptist Church</a> on the afternoon of October 17, 1899.<cite><a href="President.html">President</a></cite>
President Barbour was inducted by Chancellor Arnold Buffum Chace on Friday, October 18, 1929, in the <a href="First Baptist Church.html">First Baptist Church</a>.<cite><a href="President.html">President</a></cite>
At the time of Wriston’s inauguration in 1937, J. Earl Clauson, describing the inauguration of Barbour in 1929, wrote in the "Providence Journal," "The inauguration ... came closer to bursting Brown’s cocoon of New England reticence than anything which had preceded it.<cite><a href="President.html">President</a></cite>
There were 900 invited guests, who marched to <a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a> for the ceremony at 4:00 o’clock on Wednesday, February 3, 1937.<cite><a href="President.html">President</a></cite>
President Keeney’s inauguration on Monday, October 31, 1955, was attended by 25 college presidents and 83 delegates from colleges and universities, among them Robert M. Keeney, who attended his son’s inauguration as alumnus and delegate of the Colorado School of Mines.<cite><a href="President.html">President</a></cite>
President Heffner’s inauguration was held on Saturday morning, October 15, 1966, in Meehan auditorium.<cite><a href="President.html">President</a></cite>
President Hornig was inaugurated on Sunday, October 4, 1970.<cite><a href="President.html">President</a></cite>
On the day of inauguration, Saturday, April 16, 1977, Harvard president Derek Bok spoke in <a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a> in the morning on "Liberal <a href="Education.html">Education</a> and Values for the Twenty-first Century."<cite><a href="President.html">President</a></cite>
Meanwhile, in Carmichael Auditorium a panel discussion on "Clinical Medicine in the Year 2000" was being held.<cite><a href="President.html">President</a></cite>
On the afternoon following the inauguration, Archibald MacLeish read from his poems and shared anecdotes with his audience in <a href="Alumnae Hall.html">Alumnae Hall</a> in a performance dedicated to the memory of Mark Donahue ’59, a loyal alumnus who became a race car driver and died in a crash in Austria in 1975.<cite><a href="President.html">President</a></cite>
President Gregorian was inaugurated on Sunday afternoon, April 9, 1989, at a ceremony preceded by three days of inaugural events and his 55th birthday on April 8.<cite><a href="President.html">President</a></cite>
The <a href="President.html">President</a>’s chain and pendant, which is worn on ceremonial occasions when the mace is carried, was an anonymous gift of an honorary alumnus in 1965.<cite><a href="President’s chain and pendant.html">President’s chain and pendant</a></cite>
The chain was presented by Chancellor H. Stanford McLeod on behalf of the donor at the Alumni Dinner preceding the <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> of 1965, at which <a href="President.html">President</a> Barnaby C. Keeney wore it for the first time.<cite><a href="President’s chain and pendant.html">President’s chain and pendant</a></cite>
A similar chain for the chancellor was presented by the <a href="President.html">President</a> to Chancellor Richard Salomon at the 1983 <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a>.<cite><a href="President’s chain and pendant.html">President’s chain and pendant</a></cite>
The pendant on the chancellor’s chain is the present seal of the University surrounded by laurel, suspended from the likeness of the first chancellor, Stephen Hopkins, in the middle of the date of founding, 1764.<cite><a href="President’s chain and pendant.html">President’s chain and pendant</a></cite>
Through the years misconceptions about the history of the chair have arisen, including a popular story that it was <a href="President.html">President</a> Manning’s chair, given to him by Hopkins, and left to the College by Manning in 1791.<cite><a href="President’s chair.html">President’s chair</a></cite>
The facts concerning the chair are contained in a letter from Stephen Hopkins Smith to <a href="President.html">President</a> Francis Wayland, written on September 10, 1848, when he presented the chair to the University, "In the contest between Hopkins and Ward for the Chief Magistracy of R.I., with various success to each party, for a number of years, a friend of Gov.<cite><a href="President’s chair.html">President’s chair</a></cite>
The <a href="President.html">President</a>’s House built in 1770 was a two-and-a-half story house situated to the northwest of the College Edifice.<cite><a href="President’s House.html">President’s House</a></cite>
A plaque just inside the 1872 Gate on Prospect Street commemorates its location.<cite><a href="President’s House.html">President’s House</a></cite>
In 1840 a new president’s house was erected on land donated by Nicholas Brown at the corner of Prospect and College Street (the present site of the John Hay <a href="Library.html">Library</a>) at a cost of $7000, which had been raised by subscription along with the funds for the building of <a href="Rhode Island Hall.html">Rhode Island Hall</a>.<cite><a href="President’s House.html">President’s House</a></cite>
The first <a href="President.html">President</a>’s House was moved down College Street to land owned by Charles Potter, where it stood on the north side in a block of adjoining houses until 1936, when the <a href="Rhode Island School of Design.html">Rhode Island School of Design</a> building was erected there.<cite><a href="President’s House.html">President’s House</a></cite>
The house was completed in time for <a href="President.html">President</a> Wayland’s usual levee on <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> evening, September 3, 1840.<cite><a href="President’s House.html">President’s House</a></cite>
In 1854 a brick barn was built for the use of the president on Prospect Street at the rear of the <a href="University Grammar School.html">University Grammar School</a> lot.<cite><a href="President’s House.html">President’s House</a></cite>
After the departure of <a href="President.html">President</a> Andrews in 1898, the house was not occupied by the president.<cite><a href="President’s House.html">President’s House</a></cite>
A year later it was already called the "old Presidential Mansion," when it was fixed up to provide temporary housing for students who had been displaced by the fire in <a href="Maxcy Hall.html">Maxcy Hall</a> on February 9, 1899.<cite><a href="President’s House.html">President’s House</a></cite>
The house was used as the "Brown University Cooperative Refectory" until it was torn down in 1908 for the building of the John Hay <a href="Library.html">Library</a>, at which time a new refectory was opened in a house at the corner of Waterman and Thayer Street, where Mrs. Hewitt kept a boarding house and board was four dollars a week.<cite><a href="President’s House.html">President’s House</a></cite>
In 1900 the "Brown Alumni Monthly" announced, "The old <a href="President.html">President</a>’s house has become unsuitable for a family, since the cable cars have turned College Hill into a railroad."<cite><a href="President’s House.html">President’s House</a></cite>
A new house for the president was built in 1901 at 180 Hope Street.<cite><a href="President’s House.html">President’s House</a></cite>
The present <a href="President.html">President</a>’s House was designed by William T. Aldrich and built in 1922 as the home of Rush Sturges.<cite><a href="President’s House.html">President’s House</a></cite>
Finding the house too large for their needs after their children were grown, Mr. and Mrs. Sturges sold the house to Brown in 1947 at a price which represented a substantial donation in memory of Mrs. Sturges’ father, Rowland Gibson Hazard 1876.<cite><a href="President’s House.html">President’s House</a></cite>
After the acquisition of the new house, the president’s house on Hope Street was used by the Department of <a href="Physics.html">Physics</a> and renamed Barus Hall in 1953.<cite><a href="President’s House.html">President’s House</a></cite>
Prince <a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a> Laboratory was dedicated on May 4, 1962, with a panel discussion on "<a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a> <a href="Education.html">Education</a> and Research – Stimulus to Modern Industrial Development."<cite><a href="Prince Engineering Laboratory.html">Prince Engineering Laboratory</a></cite>
Prospect House at 36 Prospect Street was acquired in 1920.<cite><a href="Prospect House.html">Prospect House</a></cite>
"Proteus," "the journal of undergraduate literature studies at Brown University," was first published in the fall of 1981.<cite><a href="Proteus.html">Proteus</a></cite>
It ceased publication in 1986.<cite><a href="Proteus.html">Proteus</a></cite>
The Providence Journal–Brown University Public Affairs Conference was first held in March 1980.<cite><a href="Providence Journal–Brown University Public Affairs Conference.html">Providence Journal–Brown University Public Affairs Conference</a></cite>
Subsequent conferences have been on the subjects: "Mass Media and the Elections" (1981), Who Will Save the American City?"<cite><a href="Providence Journal–Brown University Public Affairs Conference.html">Providence Journal–Brown University Public Affairs Conference</a></cite>
(1982), "The "The American High School" (1984), "Cost vs. Care: America’s Health Care Dilemma (1985), "Keeping America at Work" (1986), "Crime in America" (1987), "Ethics is American Public Life" (1988), "The Changing American Family" (1989), "Our Fragile Earth: Strategies for Survival (1990), "Free Expression after 200 Years" (1991), and "Who Will Save the American City?"<cite><a href="Providence Journal–Brown University Public Affairs Conference.html">Providence Journal–Brown University Public Affairs Conference</a></cite>
(1992).<cite><a href="Providence Journal–Brown University Public Affairs Conference.html">Providence Journal–Brown University Public Affairs Conference</a></cite>
The office was created in June 1949 by the Advisory and Executive Committee.<cite><a href="Provost.html">Provost</a></cite>
Zenas Bliss was appointed after the death of Arnold, and the post was vacant from the retirement of Bliss in June 1965 until the appointment of Merton Stoltz after the arrival of <a href="President.html">President</a> Heffner in 1966.<cite><a href="Provost.html">Provost</a></cite>
In 1978, when Maurice Glicksman assumed the office of provost, he continued with many of his former responsibilities as <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> of the <a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a> and Academic Affairs, and was given a new title, Provost and <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> of the <a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a>.<cite><a href="Provost.html">Provost</a></cite>
The Provosts of Brown have been: <ul><li>Samuel T. Arnold from 1949 to 1956;</li><li>Zenas R. Bliss from 1957 to 1965;</li><li>Merton P. Stoltz from 1966 to 1978;</li><li>Maurice Glicksman from 1978 to 1990;</li><li>Frank G. Rothman from 1990 to 1994;</li><li>James T. Pomerantz from 1995 to 1998;</li><li>William S. Psychology came into its own at Brown in 1892 after the arrival of Edmund Burke Delabarre, who installed Brown’s first psychology laboratory.<cite><a href="Psychology.html">Psychology</a></cite>
In his annual report for 1872, Robinson described his senior course, "In Intellectual <a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a> the attention of the class was directed to so much of psychology as pertains to the science of the mind, and to the fundamental principles of ontology, or metaphysics proper."<cite><a href="Psychology.html">Psychology</a></cite>
He taught by dictation, although toward the end of his career he introduced recently published text books, that of John Dewey in 1887-88 and of David Jayne Hill in 1888-89.<cite><a href="Psychology.html">Psychology</a></cite>
He wrote in his 1891 annual report, "Psychology, pursued by the senior class during the first term, was treated mainly from the rational point of view, yet with effort to give due attention to the certain and probable results of recent work of Experimental Psychology and Psychophysics.<cite><a href="Psychology.html">Psychology</a></cite>
Edmund Burke Delabarre started experimental work in psychology at Brown in 1892, and remained for forty years.<cite><a href="Psychology.html">Psychology</a></cite>
Although Delabarre trained some master’s level students, a vigorous graduate program did not exist until Leonard Carmichael came to Brown from Princeton as assistant professor in 1927.<cite><a href="Psychology.html">Psychology</a></cite>
In 1928 Harold Schlosberg came from Princeton to join the department.<cite><a href="Psychology.html">Psychology</a></cite>
Brown awarded its first Ph.D. degree in psychology in 1933 to Lester F. Beck, whose topic was "Manual Skills and the Measurement of Handedness."<cite><a href="Psychology.html">Psychology</a></cite>
In 1936 when Leonard Carmichael left Brown for the University of Rochester, he recommended as his replacement Walter S. Hunter, professor of genetic psychology at Clark University.<cite><a href="Psychology.html">Psychology</a></cite>
Carl Pfaffmann ’33, who won a Rhodes scholarship and earned a Ph.D. in physiology from Cambridge University, came back to Brown in 1940.<cite><a href="Psychology.html">Psychology</a></cite>
Hunter and Graham at Clark, came in 1938 as a researcher on leave from the University of Vermont.<cite><a href="Psychology.html">Psychology</a></cite>
He returned to Brown at Graham’s request in 1941 to do military research under a National Defense Research Committee contract.<cite><a href="Psychology.html">Psychology</a></cite>
Donald B. Lindsley, who came in 1938, did pioneering research in psychophysiolgy.<cite><a href="Psychology.html">Psychology</a></cite>
In 1939 brain wave records taken under his direction were admitted in a Rhode Island court for the first time as evidence in a murder trial.<cite><a href="Psychology.html">Psychology</a></cite>
Julius Kling, whose interest is experimental psychology, came in 1951.<cite><a href="Psychology.html">Psychology</a></cite>
Hunter retired from the chairmanship in 1954, and was succeeded by Schlosberg.<cite><a href="Psychology.html">Psychology</a></cite>
Among the faculty members he recruited were Trygg Engen (olfactory research) in 1954, Anthony Davids (behavior pathology of children) and Russell M. Church (perception and judgment of time) in 1955, Lewis Lipsitt (developmental research and founder of the <a href="Child Study Center.html">Child Study Center</a>) in 1957, Allan M. Schrier (primate behavior) in 1958, and Bryan E. Shepp (comparative studies of thinking and judgment) in 1964.<cite><a href="Psychology.html">Psychology</a></cite>
Rosemary Pierrel, an assistant and instructor from 1950 to 1955, returned as associate professor in 1961, when she became <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> of <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a>.<cite><a href="Psychology.html">Psychology</a></cite>
Since Schlosberg’s sudden death in 1964, the department has been chaired Julius W. Kling, Donald S. Blough, Peter D. Eimas, Russell M. Church, Bryan E. Shepp, and Jacques Wright.<cite><a href="Psychology.html">Psychology</a></cite>
The "Quarterly Quiz" of Brown University appeared for the first time in May 1931.<cite><a href="Quarterly Quiz.html">Quarterly Quiz</a></cite>
The Question Club was started in 1906 by six women students who generated interest by wearing cardboard pins in the form of a question mark.<cite><a href="Question Club.html">Question Club</a></cite>
The club was self-perpetuating at first, but in 1912 was changed into a representative club composed of the presidents of the student organizations, editors of student publications, and the president of the senior class.<cite><a href="Question Club.html">Question Club</a></cite>
Alonzo Wallace Quinn (1899-1977), professor of geology, was born in Halltown, Missouri, on May 28, 1899.<cite><a href="Quinn, Alonzo W..html">Quinn, Alonzo W.</a></cite>
Alonzo W. Quinn graduated from Denison University in 1924, then did graduate work at Kansas University and the State University of Iowa, where he received a master of science degree in 1926.<cite><a href="Quinn, Alonzo W..html">Quinn, Alonzo W.</a></cite>
Alonzo W. Quinn was instructor at Williams College from 1926 to 1928, when he began study for his Ph.D. degree at Harvard, which he earned in 1931.<cite><a href="Quinn, Alonzo W..html">Quinn, Alonzo W.</a></cite>
Meanwhile, Alonzo W. Quinn became instructor in geology at Brown in 1929.<cite><a href="Quinn, Alonzo W..html">Quinn, Alonzo W.</a></cite>
Alonzo W. Quinn was appointed assistant professor in 1936, associate professor in 1942, and professor in 1951.<cite><a href="Quinn, Alonzo W..html">Quinn, Alonzo W.</a></cite>
Alonzo W. Quinn was chairman of the Department of Geology from 1940 to 1961.<cite><a href="Quinn, Alonzo W..html">Quinn, Alonzo W.</a></cite>
With the help of a National Science Foundation grant in 1957 the department expanded, and at the time of Quinn’s retirement in 1968 had a staff of ten.<cite><a href="Quinn, Alonzo W..html">Quinn, Alonzo W.</a></cite>
Alonzo W. Quinn died on April 8, 1977.<cite><a href="Quinn, Alonzo W..html">Quinn, Alonzo W.</a></cite>
The Rake, first published by the Rake Collective in February 1980 with the support of Resource Center at Brown, contained this opening statement: "The idea for the RAKE was conceived during a demonstration at the statehouse protesting R. I. state trooper violence at Seabrook.<cite><a href="Rake.html">Rake</a></cite>
In 1988, the "new and improved" "Rake" sought input from its readers, both students and Brown workers, with this invitation, "You know what’s wrong with Brown.<cite><a href="Rake.html">Rake</a></cite>
After a brief absence, the "Rake" resumed publication in December 1991 as "the principle independent campus journal focused on critical debate and news about progressive politics on and off the campus."<cite><a href="Rake.html">Rake</a></cite>
Norris Watson Rakestraw (1895-1982), professor of chemistry, was born in Toledo, Ohio, on January 16, 1895.<cite><a href="Rakestraw, Norris W..html">Rakestraw, Norris W.</a></cite>
Norris W. Rakestraw received a bachelor of arts degree in 1916, a master of arts in 1917, and a Ph.D. in 1921, all from Stanford University.<cite><a href="Rakestraw, Norris W..html">Rakestraw, Norris W.</a></cite>
After study at Yale, Cambridge University, and the University of Copenhagen, Norris W. Rakestraw was assistant professor at Oberlin College for a year before coming to Brown in 1926 as assistant professor in charge of beginning work in chemistry.<cite><a href="Rakestraw, Norris W..html">Rakestraw, Norris W.</a></cite>
In 1931 Norris W. Rakestraw was appointed research associate at the newly established Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute.<cite><a href="Rakestraw, Norris W..html">Rakestraw, Norris W.</a></cite>
On leave during the 1933-34 academic year Norris W. Rakestraw visited most of the oceanographic stations of the world, facilitating his travel by learning to fly an airplane.<cite><a href="Rakestraw, Norris W..html">Rakestraw, Norris W.</a></cite>
Norris W. Rakestraw was editor of the Journal of Chemical Education from 1940 to 1955, during which time the circulation of the journal doubled.<cite><a href="Rakestraw, Norris W..html">Rakestraw, Norris W.</a></cite>
A pioneer in marine chemistry, Norris W. Rakestraw became professor at Scripps Institution of Oceanography in 1946.<cite><a href="Rakestraw, Norris W..html">Rakestraw, Norris W.</a></cite>
He received the James Flack Norris Award of the American Chemical Society in 1956.<cite><a href="Rakestraw, Norris W..html">Rakestraw, Norris W.</a></cite>
Norris W. Rakestraw also was the first recipient in 1964 of Skin Diver Magazine’s Annual Award for Outstanding Service to Youth in the Field of Oceanography.<cite><a href="Rakestraw, Norris W..html">Rakestraw, Norris W.</a></cite>
After retiring from Scripps in 1965, Norris W. Rakestraw was a foreign liaison officer and scientific adviser with the federal Office of Naval Research and the Naval Research Laboratory.<cite><a href="Rakestraw, Norris W..html">Rakestraw, Norris W.</a></cite>
Norris W. Rakestraw died on December 3, 1982 in Morongo Valley, California.<cite><a href="Rakestraw, Norris W..html">Rakestraw, Norris W.</a></cite>
The Randall Counselors program which began in 1976 revived the policy of personal counseling for individual students which had been the practice of former dean Otis E. Randall for whom the program was named.<cite><a href="Randall Counselors.html">Randall Counselors</a></cite>
Otis Everett Randall (1860-1946), professor of mechanical drawing and dean of the University, was born in North Stonington, Connecticut, on February 28, 1860.<cite><a href="Randall, Otis E..html">Randall, Otis E.</a></cite>
When Otis E. Randall graduated from Brown in 1884, his ambition was to be a professor of classics.<cite><a href="Randall, Otis E..html">Randall, Otis E.</a></cite>
Otis E. Randall earned a Ph.D. degree in 1896 and studied in Germany in 1899-1900.<cite><a href="Randall, Otis E..html">Randall, Otis E.</a></cite>
Otis E. Randall was assistant professor of mathematics and civil engineering in 1891-92, associate professor of mechanical drawing from 1892 to 1896, and professor of applied mechanics from 1896 until his retirement in 1930.<cite><a href="Randall, Otis E..html">Randall, Otis E.</a></cite>
Otis E. Randall's publications include "Directions in Regard to the Construction of Plates in Mechanical Drawing" in 1895, "Shades and Shadows in Perspective" in 1902, and a textbook, "Elements of Descriptive Geometry," in 1912.<cite><a href="Randall, Otis E..html">Randall, Otis E.</a></cite>
Otis E. Randall was named dean of the University when <a href="Meiklejohn, Alexander.html">Alexander Meiklejohn</a> left to become president of Amherst College in 1912.<cite><a href="Randall, Otis E..html">Randall, Otis E.</a></cite>
In June 1929 Otis E. Randall began a sabbatical leave prior to his retirement the next year.<cite><a href="Randall, Otis E..html">Randall, Otis E.</a></cite>
At the 1930 Commencement the Brown Club of Chicago presented a portrait of Randall painted by Howard E. Smith of Boston to the University.<cite><a href="Randall, Otis E..html">Randall, Otis E.</a></cite>
After his retirement Otis E. Randall remained active in educational circles and was elected president of the New England Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools in 1933.<cite><a href="Randall, Otis E..html">Randall, Otis E.</a></cite>
Otis E. Randall wrote a book, "The Dean’s Window," based on his experiences and observations in his seventeen years as dean, which covered a multitude of topics relating to students and alumni, and reflected his view of his office, of which he said he would have found the duties "most irksome if they had been wholly disciplinary, and robbed me of the opportunity which I prized above all others – of playing the part of the ‘big brother.’" In 1935 he embarked on what he considered the most interesting educational venture of his life, when he became chairman of the advisory committee of the Delphian Society, an organization of over 300,000 American women who were pursuing self-education with textbooks published by the Society.<cite><a href="Randall, Otis E..html">Randall, Otis E.</a></cite>
Otis E. Randall died on August 11, 1946 in Providence.<cite><a href="Randall, Otis E..html">Randall, Otis E.</a></cite>
Jay Saunders Redding (1906-1988), professor of English, was born in Wilmington, Delaware, on October 12, 1906.<cite><a href="Redding, Jay Saunders.html">Redding, Jay Saunders</a></cite>
After graduation in 1928, Jay Saunders Redding taught at Morehouse College until 1931, and came back to Brown for a master’s degree in 1932.<cite><a href="Redding, Jay Saunders.html">Redding, Jay Saunders</a></cite>
Jay Saunders Redding spent an additional year at Brown and studied at Columbia in 1933-34.<cite><a href="Redding, Jay Saunders.html">Redding, Jay Saunders</a></cite>
Jay Saunders Redding taught at Louisville Municipal College from 1934 to 1936, and at Southern University in Baton Rouge from 1936 to 1938.<cite><a href="Redding, Jay Saunders.html">Redding, Jay Saunders</a></cite>
Jay Saunders Redding was head of the English Department at State Teachers College, Elizabeth City, N. C., from 1938 to 1943, and professor of English at Hampton Institute from 1943 to 1966.<cite><a href="Redding, Jay Saunders.html">Redding, Jay Saunders</a></cite>
In the first semester of 1949-50 Jay Saunders Redding was a visiting professor at Brown, the first black appointed to the faculty.<cite><a href="Redding, Jay Saunders.html">Redding, Jay Saunders</a></cite>
In 1964-65 Jay Saunders Redding was a fellow in the Humanities at Duke.<cite><a href="Redding, Jay Saunders.html">Redding, Jay Saunders</a></cite>
Jay Saunders Redding's first book, "To Make a Poet Black," was published in 1939 and was followed by the autobiographical "No Day of Triumph" in 1942 and his first novel, "Stranger and Alone," in 1950.<cite><a href="Redding, Jay Saunders.html">Redding, Jay Saunders</a></cite>
Then followed Jay Saunders Redding's books on the black experience, "They Came in Chains" in 1951, "On Being Negro in America" in 1951, "The Lonesome Road" in 1958, and "The Negro," a book on the role of blacks in America, written for U. S. Information Agency distribution in 1967.<cite><a href="Redding, Jay Saunders.html">Redding, Jay Saunders</a></cite>
In 1954 Jay Saunders Redding wrote "An American in India" after a State Department assignment in India.<cite><a href="Redding, Jay Saunders.html">Redding, Jay Saunders</a></cite>
Redding became professor of American history and civilization at <a href="Washington, George.html">George Washington</a> University in 1969, and from 1971 until his retirement in 1975 he was Ernest I.<cite><a href="Redding, Jay Saunders.html">Redding, Jay Saunders</a></cite>
Jay Saunders Redding was a member of the Board of Fellows of Brown University from 1969 to 1981.<cite><a href="Redding, Jay Saunders.html">Redding, Jay Saunders</a></cite>
Jay Saunders Redding died on March 2, 1988 in Ithaca, New York.<cite><a href="Redding, Jay Saunders.html">Redding, Jay Saunders</a></cite>
The Registrar of the University dates back to 1828 when the office of "Register" was created and assumed by Lemuel H. Elliott, who had already been steward since 1826.<cite><a href="Registrar.html">Registrar</a></cite>
Elliott kept this job until 1864, and was succeeded in the position by William Douglas 1839 from 1864 to 1879, Francis W. Douglas 1868 from 1879 to 1884, Gilman P. Robinson 1878 from 1884 to 1889, John C. Stockbridge 1838 from 1889 to 1891, and Frederick T. Guild 1890 from 1891 to 1938.<cite><a href="Registrar.html">Registrar</a></cite>
Helen Lowe Urquhart was "Recorder of the College" from 1940 to 1945.<cite><a href="Registrar.html">Registrar</a></cite>
Gilbert E. Case was Registrar from 1945 to 1948.<cite><a href="Registrar.html">Registrar</a></cite>
The title was changed to Recorder in 1948, and William A. Jewett was appointed to the position.<cite><a href="Registrar.html">Registrar</a></cite>
Milton E. Noble ’44 was appointed Recorder in 1951.<cite><a href="Registrar.html">Registrar</a></cite>
His title was changed to Registrar in 1963, and he was succeeded by Katherine P. Hall in 1984.<cite><a href="Registrar.html">Registrar</a></cite>
Registration at the Women’s College and <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a> was conducted separately until 1963, when the introduction of automated records made it practical for all student registration to be under the University Registrar.<cite><a href="Registrar.html">Registrar</a></cite>
The Registrars of the Women’s College and <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a> were Emma Bradford Stanton 1896 from 1897 to 1932, Mildred Williamson Cull ’29 from 1932 to 1938, Esther Hervey Smith from 1938 to 1946.<cite><a href="Registrar.html">Registrar</a></cite>
Dorothy Spencer Horton was Recorder from 1944 to 1963.<cite><a href="Registrar.html">Registrar</a></cite>
Religious Societies flourished at Brown throughout the nineteenth century, the first known being the Praying Society formed by a few pious students in 1802 for the purpose of "their own sanctification and for the conversion of their fellow students," which held prayer meetings and corresponded with similar societies in other colleges.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
By 1820 the membership of the Society had grown to about thirty.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
In April 1820 there was a powerful religious revival in Providence, which spread to the students and brought about a prayer meeting attended by the whole student body, the conversion of many, and in February 1821 the formation of the Religious Society of Brown University as a successor to the Praying Society.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
Weekly meetings were held in the chapel, with occasional public meetings at the <a href="First Baptist Church.html">First Baptist Church</a>, and beginning in 1834, regular Sunday afternoon sermons by <a href="President.html">President</a> Francis Wayland.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
In May 1827 the Society chose to change its name to the Society for Missionary Inquiry, reflecting the desire of its members to learn more about the religious condition of the world.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
John Larkin Lincoln 1836 wrote in his diary on May 15, 1833, "Joined the Society of Inquiry to-night by a relation of my experience ...<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
The Society resumed its earlier name when another Society for Missionary Inquiry began in 1834.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
Following the revival of 1820 and similar revivals in other institutions, the custom of the "Concert of Prayer" or "College Fast" in the colleges began in 1823, and became an annual event celebrated in January or February.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
There were eight subsequent religious revivals at Brown between 1834 and 1858.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
The Religious Society disbanded in 1863 with the intention, according to the "<a href="Brown Paper.html">Brown Paper</a>," "that the work for which it existed might go on without its cumbrous interruptions."<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
The Society for Missionary Inquiry formed in 1834 at first consisted only of those who contemplated missionary labors, but was later opened to other interested persons.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
The Bishop Seabury Association was founded in May 1865.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
In the fall of 1866 a mission was opened in South Providence, its teachers chiefly from the association, and the next summer a chapel was built and a parish organized as Christ Church.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
In September 1868 the society took up work in East Providence, and a year later that mission was placed under the care of one of the first members of the association and became St. Mary’s Church.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
In the fall of 1869 the society proceeded to more missionary work in Elmwood.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
The society became inactive in the later 1870s.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
Notice of its existence and restated purpose are found in the "Students’ Hand-Book" in 1893: "The Bishop Seabury Association has been established and is maintained to meet the needs of those students who are accustomed to the ritual of the Protestant Episcopal Church.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
After 1903 the society was no longer listed in the "Students’ Hand-Book."<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
The Brown Christian Association was organized as the Young Men’s Christian Association of Brown University on November 16, 1881.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
In 1886 the Society for Missionary Inquiry which had existed since 1834 was merged with the association as the Department for Missionary Inquiry.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
On May 2, 1888, on a motion by Charles G. Hartsock 1889, a committee was formed to consider maintaining a missionary.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
In 1888 the association began publication of the "Students’ Hand-Book," which became "<a href="Bear Facts.html">Bear Facts</a>."<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
Students at the Women’s College organized the Young Women’s Christian Association in 1896-97.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
The association, which was at first limited to students of evangelical Protestant denominations, opened its membership to other Christian students in 1911, at which time it had to withdraw from the national organization and changed its name to the Christian Association.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
Senior Roy E. Clark ’01 was appointed general secretary of the Christian Association in 1900.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
By 1902 there were 344 faculty and student members.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
In 1909 the Association opened a "Brown Settlement" at 470 North Main Street for the purpose of offering classes in civics and <a href="English.html">English</a>, mainly to boys and young men, intended to reach "3 nationalities, the <a href="Jews.html">Jews</a>, the Irish, and the Italians."<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
By 1910 there were eighteen active Bible study classes with 185 members, a mission study group of 75 students, and a social service committee which secured volunteers for work in Providence.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
The membership policy was changed in 1916, abolishing the membership fee and requiring only "belief in the purposes of the Association."<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
The wide range of services provided by the Association may be seen in its report for 1924-25.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
In 1928 K. Brooke Anderson came to Brown as executive secretary of the Brown Christian Association, and remained in that position until his retirement in 1957.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
The Interfaith Commission was organized in 1936 to bring about better understanding among Catholics, <a href="Jews.html">Jews</a>, and Protestants.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
The Peace Commission became active in 1937, holding weekly meetings, sending out student speakers, and sponsoring demonstrations on Armistice Day and National Peace Day.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
The Brown and Pembroke Christian Associations came under the Chaplain’s office in the early 1950s with funding from the University, and the Newman Club and Hillel Club and other sectarian organizations were recognized and allowed to meet on campus for worship or study, but discouraged from holding social gatherings.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
In 1956 the Religious Embassy was replaced by Religious Symposium Week with meetings arranged by three groups, the University Christian Council, the Newman Club, and the Hillel Foundation.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
Reverend Sam H. Newcomer served as executive secretary of the Brown Christian Association from 1957 to 1963.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
In 1958 the University Christian Association was formed by the merger of the Brown Christian Association, the Pembroke Christian Association, and various student groups of the neighboring churches.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
Georgiana McLean was associate executive secretary of the University Christian Association from 1958 to 1960, and was succeeded by Nancy Simons, who was director of religious activities at Pembroke and became assistant chaplain in 1965.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
The groups affiliated with the U.C.A. were Canterbury (founded for Episcopalian students in 1947), Central Student Fellowship (Congregational), the Lutheran Student Association, Presbyterian Student Fellowship, Roger Williams Fellowship (Baptist), and Wesley Foundation (Methodist).<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
Groups not affiliated were the Christian Science Organization (founded in 1936) the Inter-Varsity Christian Fellowship, and the Newman Club for Catholic students.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
The Inter-Varsity Christian Fellowship started in 1947, when a few students began to meet informally for prayer, and soon joined an international network of that name.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
In 1989 the group became Brown Christian Fellowship.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
The University Christian Movement was formed in 1967, bringing together Protestant and Catholic groups in a single organization.<cite><a href="Religious Societies.html">Religious Societies</a></cite>
Religious Studies was the departmental name given in 1955 to the former Department of Biblical Literature and <a href="History.html">History</a> of Religions.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
The laws of 1783 did mention reading in the Greek New Testament as part of the curriculum of the freshman, but it appears that this study was conducted more for the sake of practice in Greek than for the purpose of religious instruction.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
By the 1820s a senior class had among their textbooks Joseph Butler’s "The Analogy of Religion, natural and revealed, to the Constitution and the Course of Nature," and William Paley’s "Natural Theology," and "Evidences of Christianity."<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
