In 1838-39 Adjunct Professor Horatio B. Hackett taught Hebrew literature for one year before leaving to teach at Newton Theological Institution.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
In 1890 J. R. Jewett, instructor in the Semitic languages and history, joined the faculty and taught the history of Islam and the Crusades in 1890-91, as well as a course in Hebrew.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
When Jewett left in 1895 for the University of Chicago, Charles Foster Kent took charge of the new Department of Biblical Literature and <a href="History.html">History</a>.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
The size of classes in Hebrew increased as theological institutions began to expect their students to have studied Hebrew in college, and in 1897-98 Rabbi David Blaustein was appointed instructor in Semitics.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
Henry Thatcher Fowler was professor of Biblical literature and history from 1901 to 1934.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
In 1914 "Courses in Religious <a href="Education.html">Education</a>" were offered to persons registered as special students, who were training as lay workers and directors of religious education in the community.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
In 1915 the Providence Biblical Institute sponsored a series of lectures in cooperation with the University and presented speakers from Harvard, Yale, and Union Theological Seminary.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
In 1915 the Department of <a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a> and the Department of Biblical Literature combined to teach a course in the <a href="History.html">History</a> of Religion.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
Millar Burrows came as assistant professor of Biblical literature and history of religion in 1925 and taught until 1934.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
Robert P. Casey was appointed professor of Biblical literature and history of religions, and named chairman of the department in 1934, which changed its name from Department of Biblical Literature and <a href="History.html">History</a> to Department of Biblical Literature and <a href="History.html">History</a> of Religions.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
Joaquim Wach came from Germany in 1935 as visiting professor and was named associate professor in 1939.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
He remained until 1946.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
Rabbi William G. Braude was a member of the department from 1937 to 1942, teaching Hebrew.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
William J. Robbins, a Baptist minister, joined the department in 1940 as instructor.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
After time off for service with the Army Corps of Chaplains from 1942 to 1946, he returned to earn his Ph.D. degree in 1947.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
He became chairman of the department in 1950, and was promoted to associate professor in 1952.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
The department expanded rapidly in the early 1960s.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
In 1957-58 there were two full-time faculty members, and for a long time the emphasis had been on the teaching of Biblical literature and the history of religions.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
By 1963 eight faculty members were teaching Christian ethics, the history of Judaism, the religions of India, ancient Greek religion, modern religious thought in the West, and religion and society.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
Beginning in 1963, with a grant from the James Foundation, visiting professors of Catholic studies were brought to Brown to teach for a semester, among them Daniel Callahan, Reverend Bernard Haring, and Monsignor John Tracy Ellis.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
Ernest S. Frerichs, who joined the department in 1953, developed the important undergraduate and graduate program in Judaica.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
Jacob Neusner, professor of Judaic studies, was appointed in 1968, after an experimental program funded by the Gottesman Foundation had brought a series of scholars scholars of Judaica to Brown.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
Among the internationally distinguished Visiting Professors who taught at Brown were Professor Gershom Scholem of the Hebrew University in 1956-57, Professor Salo W. Baron, who had retired from the Miller Chair at Columbia University in 1963, from 1966 to 1969, and Professor Yigael Yadin of the Hebrew University in 1969-70.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
In 1975 the Gottesman Foundation established the Ungerleider Distinguished Scholar in Judaic Studies, and Neusner was named to this post.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
The Judaic studies program was established in August 1982.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>
Professor Frerichs has been the sole director of the Program since 1985.<cite><a href="Religious Studies.html">Religious Studies</a></cite>

"Res Publica," subtitled "a journal of public opinion," was a Brown political journal which was started in March 1966 by a group of undergraduates, and published by Liber Brunensis Publications.<cite><a href="Res Publica,.html">Res Publica,</a></cite>
Publication ceased in June 1970.<cite><a href="Res Publica,.html">Res Publica,</a></cite>
The Resumed Undergraduate <a href="Education.html">Education</a> Program began in 1973, having been approved by the faculty in the fall of 1972 as an experimental six-year program to enroll students who had been away from formal study for at least five years and were at least 25 years old.<cite><a href="Resumed Undergraduate Education Program.html">Resumed Undergraduate Education Program</a></cite>
The Revolutionary War closed the college from December 1776 until September 1782.<cite><a href="Revolutionary War.html">Revolutionary War</a></cite>
When British and Hessian troops under Sir Peter Parker landed in Newport on December 7, 1776, <a href="President.html">President</a> Manning wrote, "This brought their Camp in plain View from the College with the naked Eye; upon which the Country flew to Arms &amp; marched for Providence, there, unprovided with Barracks they marched into the College &amp; dispossessed the Students, about 40 in Number."<cite><a href="Revolutionary War.html">Revolutionary War</a></cite>
On May 17, 1777, another notice in the "Providence Gazette," announced that, there being no hope of reopening the College, students were advised to continue their studies elsewhere and seniors might report to the College for examinations and graduation.<cite><a href="Revolutionary War.html">Revolutionary War</a></cite>
In April 1780 the troops left the College Edifice and the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> announced the reopening of the College on May 10.<cite><a href="Revolutionary War.html">Revolutionary War</a></cite>
Four of the seven graduates in the first class to graduate in 1769 served during the Revolution.<cite><a href="Revolutionary War.html">Revolutionary War</a></cite>
He died of wounds received during the battle of Long Island on August 27, 1776, the first Brown graduate to die in military service.<cite><a href="Revolutionary War.html">Revolutionary War</a></cite>
On May 25, 1778, while he was home on a visit to Warren, he was captured by British troops and confined in a guard-ship at Newport for a month.<cite><a href="Revolutionary War.html">Revolutionary War</a></cite>
James Mitchell Varnum, whose part in the <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> dispute in 1769 had been that America could not subsist independent of Britain, became Colonel of the "Kentish Guards" of East Greenwich, and later Colonel of the First Rhode Island Infantry and Colonel of the Ninth Continental Infantry.<cite><a href="Revolutionary War.html">Revolutionary War</a></cite>
He was promoted to the rank of brigadier-general in February of 1777.<cite><a href="Revolutionary War.html">Revolutionary War</a></cite>
Solomon Drowne 1773, Philip Padelford 1773, Barnabas Binney 1774, Pardon Bowen 1775, and Levi Wheaton 1782 all served as surgeons.<cite><a href="Revolutionary War.html">Revolutionary War</a></cite>
Ebenezer David 1772 was a chaplain in Colonel Varnum’s regiment and died after his discharge in 1778.<cite><a href="Revolutionary War.html">Revolutionary War</a></cite>
Esek Hopkins 1775, son of the admiral, was master of a privateer which captured the British ship "Westermoreland" in August 1776.<cite><a href="Revolutionary War.html">Revolutionary War</a></cite>
He was taken prisoner and said to have died in Halifax in 1777.<cite><a href="Revolutionary War.html">Revolutionary War</a></cite>
While the College was closed, the College <a href="Library.html">Library</a> was sent for safe-keeping to the home of William Williams 1769 in Wrentham, Massachusetts.<cite><a href="Revolutionary War.html">Revolutionary War</a></cite>
At its first meeting after the war, held on September 4 and 5, 1782, the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> granted degrees to seven students, appointed a committee to break the seal of the College bearing the portraits of the King and Queen of Great Britain, and ordered the return of the College <a href="Library.html">Library</a>.<cite><a href="Revolutionary War.html">Revolutionary War</a></cite>
The College Edifice had been badly damaged and the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> presented a bill for 1309 pounds, 3 shillings, and two pence to the Congress of the United States.<cite><a href="Revolutionary War.html">Revolutionary War</a></cite>
Ten years later the bill was resubmitted, having been increased by the addition of simple interest to 2300 pounds, 4 shillings, and 2 pence, or about $7,667.<cite><a href="Revolutionary War.html">Revolutionary War</a></cite>
On May 27, 1800 the College received from the Unitd States the sum of $2,779.13.<cite><a href="Revolutionary War.html">Revolutionary War</a></cite>
Rhode Island Hall was built in 1840.<cite><a href="Rhode Island Hall.html">Rhode Island Hall</a></cite>
At the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> meeting on September 8, 1836, a committee was appointed to "devise means for erecting a building for lecture rooms and rooms for the reception of geological and physiological specimens."<cite><a href="Rhode Island Hall.html">Rhode Island Hall</a></cite>
In 1838 $2500 had been raised from several contributors.<cite><a href="Rhode Island Hall.html">Rhode Island Hall</a></cite>
The needed impetus came in the form of a letter from Nicholas Brown, on March 18, 1839, presenting two lots of land on Waterman Street for a president’s house and a lot on George Street for "another College edifice for the accommodation of the Departments of Natural <a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a>, <a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a>, Mineralogy, <a href="Geology.html">Geology</a>, and Natural <a href="History.html">History</a>."<cite><a href="Rhode Island Hall.html">Rhode Island Hall</a></cite>
It was opened for public inspection on September 3, 1840 and dedicated on the following day, with an address written by Professor William G. Goddard, but read by Nathan B. Crocker because of Goddard’s illness, entitled "The Social Influence of the Higher Institutions of Learning."<cite><a href="Rhode Island Hall.html">Rhode Island Hall</a></cite>
In 1857 a collection of portraits of prominent Rhode Islanders painted at the expense of friends of the University through the efforts of John Russell Bartlett was placed in Rhode Island Hall.<cite><a href="Rhode Island Hall.html">Rhode Island Hall</a></cite>
An addition was constructed on the east side of the building in 1874.<cite><a href="Rhode Island Hall.html">Rhode Island Hall</a></cite>
In 1875 the portraits were moved to the second story of the addition, new glass cases were installed in the old building and the first floor of the addition, and the basement of the addition was given over to Professor J. W. P. Jenks’s weekly voluntary class in taxidermy.<cite><a href="Rhode Island Hall.html">Rhode Island Hall</a></cite>
In his report for 1877-78, Jenks was happy to report that "the recent introduction of Pawtuxet water to the skeletonizing Laboratory in the attic of Rhode Island Hall removes a hitherto insurmountable obstacle to efficient work in the osteological department of the Museum."<cite><a href="Rhode Island Hall.html">Rhode Island Hall</a></cite>
In 1882 a biological laboratory was installed in the basement.<cite><a href="Rhode Island Hall.html">Rhode Island Hall</a></cite>
In 1885 Professor Alpheus Packard reported the laboratory facilities much improved by the acquisition of the room at the rear of the Museum, from which the portraits had been removed to <a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a>.<cite><a href="Rhode Island Hall.html">Rhode Island Hall</a></cite>
Eventually the display cases in the museum obstructed the windows, and skylights were installed in the summer of 1886.<cite><a href="Rhode Island Hall.html">Rhode Island Hall</a></cite>
In 1904 a small addition on the south side of the building replaced the lean-to where live animals were kept.<cite><a href="Rhode Island Hall.html">Rhode Island Hall</a></cite>
When <a href="Biology.html">Biology</a> moved to <a href="Arnold Laboratory.html">Arnold Laboratory</a> in 1915, Rhode Island Hall was remodeled, and the <a href="Philosophy.html">Philosophy</a> Department was installed on the first floor, while the <a href="Geology.html">Geology</a> Department moved to the basement and the second floor from the basement of Sayles.<cite><a href="Rhode Island Hall.html">Rhode Island Hall</a></cite>
<a href="Geology.html">Geology</a> remained in the building until 1982, when it was renovated for office and classroom space.<cite><a href="Rhode Island Hall.html">Rhode Island Hall</a></cite>
Rhode Island School of Design entered into cooperation with Brown in 1902, when three courses at the school were opened to Brown students and counted as qualifications for a degree.<cite><a href="Rhode Island School of Design.html">Rhode Island School of Design</a></cite>
The School of Design had been founded in 1877 by a group of women, including Miss Sarah Doyle, with $1,675 left over from the funds of the Women’s Centennial Commission of Rhode Island.<cite><a href="Rhode Island School of Design.html">Rhode Island School of Design</a></cite>
The coeducational institution for students in art and design fulfilled, at least in part, a wish expressed by Ezekiel Gilman Robinson in 1873 that a scientific school should be established in Rhode Island for instruction in drawing, civil engineering, architecture, and fine arts.<cite><a href="Rhode Island School of Design.html">Rhode Island School of Design</a></cite>
William Carey Poland was president of the school from 1896 to 1907.<cite><a href="Rhode Island School of Design.html">Rhode Island School of Design</a></cite>
The Rhode Island Society for the Collegiate <a href="Education.html">Education</a> of Women was incorporated in 1896 with 36 charter members under the leadership of Sarah Doyle, principal of the girls’ department of Providence High School.<cite><a href="Rhode Island Society for the Collegiate Education of Women.html">Rhode Island Society for the Collegiate Education of Women</a></cite>
In January 1895 <a href="President.html">President</a> E. Benjamin Andrews had asked Miss Doyle for the names of influential women in Rhode Island and Mrs. Andrews had invited them to tea.<cite><a href="Rhode Island Society for the Collegiate Education of Women.html">Rhode Island Society for the Collegiate Education of Women</a></cite>
After collecting enough money to begin building in February 1896, the committee was disbanded and the Rhode Island Society for the Collegiate <a href="Education.html">Education</a> of Women was established in its place.<cite><a href="Rhode Island Society for the Collegiate Education of Women.html">Rhode Island Society for the Collegiate Education of Women</a></cite>
In 1911, Miss Doyle, observing that the <a href="Alumnae Association.html">Alumnae Association</a> was on a firm footing, suggested the disbanding of the Society, but her fellow members thought otherwise, and the students added their appreciation of the Society by dedicating the "<a href="Brun Mael.html">Brun Mael</a>" of that year to the Society "to whose interest and enthusiasm our College owes so much beauty and comfort."<cite><a href="Rhode Island Society for the Collegiate Education of Women.html">Rhode Island Society for the Collegiate Education of Women</a></cite>
Among the projects of the Society were the loan fund established early in the century and turned over to University management in 1941, the equipping of the infirmary, Doyle House, and the building of <a href="Howard Terrace.html">Howard Terrace</a>, named for Mrs. Elisha H. Howard, a president of the Society.<cite><a href="Rhode Island Society for the Collegiate Education of Women.html">Rhode Island Society for the Collegiate Education of Women</a></cite>
On September 14, 1971 (75 years to the day after its incorporation) the Society, which had become known as RISCEW or the "society with the long name," came to an end at a final luncheon featuring physical education director Bessie Rudd, who spoke on the history of the Society.<cite><a href="Rhode Island Society for the Collegiate Education of Women.html">Rhode Island Society for the Collegiate Education of Women</a></cite>
Brown’s Rhodes scholars have been Ralph Hervey Bevan ’04, Leonard Wolsey Cronkhite ’05, George Hurley ’07, Robert Wilbur Burgess ’08, Howard Alfred Taber ’10, Walter Clifford Johnson ’10, Norman Stephen Taber ’13, William Matthew Sullivan ’13, William Russell Burwell ’15, Daniel Parkhurst Spalding ’17, Marshall Nairne Fulton ’20, James Quayle Dealey ’20, William Chace Greene ’22, John Andrew Wilson ’23, Robert Lee Guthrie ’22 A.M., Robert Lee Baker ’23, Arthur Worthington Packard ’25, Gordon Keith Chalmers ’25, Richard Crocker Gurney ’28, Albert Charles Cornsweet ’29, Owen Franklin Walker ’33, Joseph Elmer Hawkins, graduate student 1933-34, Carl Pfaffmann ’33, Charles Bernard Lewis ’35, David Nickerson Barus ’49, Douglas Elliott Ashford ’50, Melvin D. Levine ’61, Thomas N. Bose ’69, Ira Magaziner ’69, Richard R. Crocker ’69, Richard H. Trainor ’70, Brian G. McHale ’74, Edmund Graham Gibbons ’74 Sarah Cleveland ’87, Katherine Finkelstein ’89, Jeffrey Shesol ’91, Piyush Robert Jindal ’92.<cite><a href="Rhodes Scholars.html">Rhodes Scholars</a></cite>
Richardson Hall, originally named <a href="Brunonia.html">Brunonia</a> Hall, was built in 1900 by Mrs. Mary A. Walworth of Boston as a private dormitory to accommodate 34 students in suites with such amenities as window seats and fireplaces and "Gegenstorm’s shower and needle baths."<cite><a href="Richardson Hall.html">Richardson Hall</a></cite>
The dormitory was purchased by the University in 1920 to help solve housing problems.<cite><a href="Richardson Hall.html">Richardson Hall</a></cite>
In the summer of 1951 it was converted to the use of the Graduate Division of Applied <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a> and renamed for Roland G. D. Richardson, who initiated the Applied <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a> program.<cite><a href="Richardson Hall.html">Richardson Hall</a></cite>
After Applied Math acquired new quarters in 1953, the building was once more a dormitory.<cite><a href="Richardson Hall.html">Richardson Hall</a></cite>
Roland George Dwight Richardson (1878-1949), professor of mathematics and dean of the Graduate School, was born in Dartmouth, Nova Scotia, on May 14, 1878.<cite><a href="Richardson, Roland G. D..html">Richardson, Roland G. D.</a></cite>
Roland G. D. Richardson graduated from Acadia College in 1898 and received a bachelor’s degree in 1903, a master’s in 1904, and a Ph.D. in 1906, all from Yale.<cite><a href="Richardson, Roland G. D..html">Richardson, Roland G. D.</a></cite>
Roland G. D. Richardson taught at two schools in Nova Scotia, Margaretsville School in 1895-96 and 1898-99 and Westport High School from 1899 to 1902.<cite><a href="Richardson, Roland G. D..html">Richardson, Roland G. D.</a></cite>
Roland G. D. Richardson was instructor in mathematics at Yale from 1904 to 1907, when he came to Brown as assistant professor of pure mathematics.<cite><a href="Richardson, Roland G. D..html">Richardson, Roland G. D.</a></cite>
Roland G. D. Richardson studied at Göttingen in 1908-1909.<cite><a href="Richardson, Roland G. D..html">Richardson, Roland G. D.</a></cite>
Roland G. D. Richardson was promoted to associate professor in 1912 and professor in 1915.<cite><a href="Richardson, Roland G. D..html">Richardson, Roland G. D.</a></cite>
Roland G. D. Richardson's title became professor of mathematics in 1928.<cite><a href="Richardson, Roland G. D..html">Richardson, Roland G. D.</a></cite>
Roland G. D. Richardson was head of the Department of Mathematics from 1915 to 1942.<cite><a href="Richardson, Roland G. D..html">Richardson, Roland G. D.</a></cite>
Roland G. D. Richardson was vice-president of the American Mathematical Society in 1920 and secretary of the society from 1921 to 1940.<cite><a href="Richardson, Roland G. D..html">Richardson, Roland G. D.</a></cite>
Roland G. D. Richardson was dean of the Graduate Department in 1926-27, and dean of the Graduate School which succeeded the department from 1927 until his retirement in 1948.<cite><a href="Richardson, Roland G. D..html">Richardson, Roland G. D.</a></cite>
Roland G. D. Richardson was also acting vice-president of the University in 1928-29.<cite><a href="Richardson, Roland G. D..html">Richardson, Roland G. D.</a></cite>
It was through Roland G. D. Richardson's efforts that the Program of Advanced Instruction and Research in Mechanics was established at Brown in 1941, and became the Graduate Division of Applied Mathematics in 1946.<cite><a href="Richardson, Roland G. D..html">Richardson, Roland G. D.</a></cite>
Charles Alexander Robinson, Jr. (1900-1965), professor of classics, was born in Princeton, New Jersey, on March 30, 1900.<cite><a href="Robinson, Charles Alexander.html">Robinson, Charles Alexander</a></cite>
Charles Alexander Robinson graduated from Princeton in 1922, and earned his master’s degree the next year.<cite><a href="Robinson, Charles Alexander.html">Robinson, Charles Alexander</a></cite>
Charles Alexander Robinson returned to Princeton as a John Harding Page Fellow in Classics, and came to Brown as instructor in Greek and Latin in 1928.<cite><a href="Robinson, Charles Alexander.html">Robinson, Charles Alexander</a></cite>
Charles Alexander Robinson became assistant professor the next year, associate professor in 1935, and full professor in 1945.<cite><a href="Robinson, Charles Alexander.html">Robinson, Charles Alexander</a></cite>
Charles Alexander Robinson was a student at the American School of Classical Studies in Athens in 1923, 1924, and 1925, and was appointed to the Management Committee of the School in 1928.<cite><a href="Robinson, Charles Alexander.html">Robinson, Charles Alexander</a></cite>
In 1934 and 1935 Charles Alexander Robinson was Professor of Greek Literature and Archaeology in Athens.<cite><a href="Robinson, Charles Alexander.html">Robinson, Charles Alexander</a></cite>
Charles Alexander Robinson led Brown’s first excavation program in Corinth in 1959.<cite><a href="Robinson, Charles Alexander.html">Robinson, Charles Alexander</a></cite>
In his university biography, after his list of accomplishments, he added, "The thing that matters most in my life is the fact that every Monday afternoon since 1928 Mrs. Robinson and I have been at home for my students."<cite><a href="Robinson, Charles Alexander.html">Robinson, Charles Alexander</a></cite>
His last appearance in December 1964 was described by W. Chesley Worthington ’23 in the "Brown Alumni Monthly:" "Though Charles Alexander Robinson had lately left his hospital room, his voice had its old booming vibrance, his joy in taking part was as infectious as ever.<cite><a href="Robinson, Charles Alexander.html">Robinson, Charles Alexander</a></cite>
Charles Alexander Robinson died of cancer on February 23, 1965 in Providence.<cite><a href="Robinson, Charles Alexander.html">Robinson, Charles Alexander</a></cite>
Ezekiel Gilman Robinson (1815-1894), seventh president of Brown University, was born in Attleboro, Massachusetts on March 23, 1815.<cite><a href="Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman.html">Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman</a></cite>
Ezekiel Gilman Robinson studied at academies in Wrentham, Massachusetts, in Pawtucket, and in New Hampton, New Hampshire, and entered Brown in the sophomore year in 1835.<cite><a href="Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman.html">Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman</a></cite>
Upon graduation in 1838 Ezekiel Gilman Robinson worked briefly for the American Tract Society, addressing churches on the work of the Society.<cite><a href="Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman.html">Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman</a></cite>
After his graduation from Newton and his ordination in 1842, Ezekiel Gilman Robinson was pastor of the Baptist Church in Norfolk, Virginia, for three years, during which he was also chaplain of the University of Virginia for one year.<cite><a href="Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman.html">Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman</a></cite>
Ezekiel Gilman Robinson moved to the Baptist Church in Cambridge in 1845, and resigned in less than a year to become professor of Hebrew in the theological seminary at Covington, Kentucky.<cite><a href="Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman.html">Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman</a></cite>
In 1849 Ezekiel Gilman Robinson became pastor of the Ninth Street Baptist Church in Cincinnati.<cite><a href="Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman.html">Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman</a></cite>
In 1853 Ezekiel Gilman Robinson became professor of Christian theology at Rochester Theological Seminary.<cite><a href="Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman.html">Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman</a></cite>
Ezekiel Gilman Robinson was named president in 1860.<cite><a href="Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman.html">Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman</a></cite>
Ezekiel Gilman Robinson was offered the presidency of Brown in 1867, but declined.<cite><a href="Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman.html">Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman</a></cite>
When approached again in 1871, Ezekiel Gilman Robinson reconsidered.<cite><a href="Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman.html">Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman</a></cite>
In his autobiography, Robinson wrote, "In the spring of 1871 there came again a proposal that I should accept the presidency of Brown University.<cite><a href="Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman.html">Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman</a></cite>
In August of 1872 Robinson left Rochester for Providence.<cite><a href="Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman.html">Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman</a></cite>
In his letter to the Corporation on March 20, 1889, Ezekiel Gilman Robinson wrote, "I am now the more ready to retire, because the prospects of the University have at no time since my connection with it been so encouraging as they now are, and because it is now in a condition from which, under wise guidance and with such changes as in due course of events will necessarily come, it can rapidly advance to a measure of usefulness not hitherto attainable."<cite><a href="Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman.html">Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman</a></cite>
Despite his satisfaction with the state of the University, his resignation was saddened by, and perhaps precipitated by the fact that his son, Gilman P. Robinson 1878, who had been registrar of the University since 1884, had been charged with failing to deposit cash payments of tuition to the credit of the University.<cite><a href="Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman.html">Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman</a></cite>
Gilman Robinson resigned in 1889 and the charges were dropped.<cite><a href="Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman.html">Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman</a></cite>
For most of 1890 Ezekiel Gilman Robinson supplied the pulpit of a church in Philadelphia and also lectured at Crozer Theological School and the theological institutions at Andover and Rochester.<cite><a href="Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman.html">Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman</a></cite>
Ezekiel Gilman Robinson gave a course of lectures at Brown in the spring of 1892.<cite><a href="Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman.html">Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman</a></cite>
In the fall of 1892 Ezekiel Gilman Robinson became professor of ethics and apologetics at the University of Chicago.<cite><a href="Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman.html">Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman</a></cite>
In the spring of 1894 Ezekiel Gilman Robinson preached at Vassar College, of which he had been a trustee since its founding, and shortly afterward became ill and was taken to the Boston city hospital, where he died on June 13.<cite><a href="Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman.html">Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman</a></cite>
When the class of 1884 decided to erect a gate in his memory in 1924, an editorial in the "Brown Alumni Monthly," recalled Robinson as viewed by his students, "We may not all have loved him then, but we respected him.<cite><a href="Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman.html">Robinson, Ezekiel Gilman</a></cite>
Robinson Hall was the "New <a href="Library.html">Library</a>" of 1878.<cite><a href="Robinson Hall.html">Robinson Hall</a></cite>
John Carter Brown 1816, who died in 1874, had bequeathed to the University a lot at the corner of Waterman and Prospect Streets as a site for a library, along with $50,000 for the building.<cite><a href="Robinson Hall.html">Robinson Hall</a></cite>
This amount, with his earlier gift, now grown to $20,000, made it possible to lay the foundation in the summer of 1875.<cite><a href="Robinson Hall.html">Robinson Hall</a></cite>
His widow paid the difference between what he had given and the final cost of $95,588 for the building, which was dedicated on February 16, 1878.<cite><a href="Robinson Hall.html">Robinson Hall</a></cite>
The "<a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a>" of February 12, 1878 included this description of the new <a href="Library.html">Library</a> Building: The four inscriptions were, first, the commemoration of the donor John Carter Brown, noting in Latin his dates of birth and death and his bequest of the building; second, the dates of the beginning and completion of the building; third, that the University was founded in 1764 and received its name in 1804 from Nicholas Brown; and fourth, an extract form the Book of Proverbs.<cite><a href="Robinson Hall.html">Robinson Hall</a></cite>
When the John Hay <a href="Library.html">Library</a> was opened in 1910, the intention of the <a href="Library.html">Library</a> Committee was to connect the two buildings and to house the departmental libraries in the former library.<cite><a href="Robinson Hall.html">Robinson Hall</a></cite>
The expense of remodeling proved too high, and in 1912 the building was partially opened to receive the Department of <a href="Economics.html">Economics</a> and its library of 10,000 volumes.<cite><a href="Robinson Hall.html">Robinson Hall</a></cite>
When it reopened in 1946 with eight classrooms and twenty offices, it was named Robinson Hall for Ezekiel Gilman Robinson during whose presidency it was built.<cite><a href="Robinson Hall.html">Robinson Hall</a></cite>
Still occupied by the Department of <a href="Economics.html">Economics</a>, the building displays some of its former beauty since its renovation in 1989 and 1990 by the Robinson Green Beretta <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a>.<cite><a href="Robinson Hall.html">Robinson Hall</a></cite>
Rochambeau House at 84 Prospect Street was the home of Chancellor Henry D. Sharpe 1894, which his wife, Mary Elizabeth Sharpe, helped architect Arthur Rice design in 1929.<cite><a href="Rochambeau House.html">Rochambeau House</a></cite>
Mrs. Sharpe, who died in 1985, asked that the house be given to Brown after her death.<cite><a href="Rochambeau House.html">Rochambeau House</a></cite>
John D. Rockefeller, Jr. (1874-1960) came to Brown in the fall of 1893 on the advice of a young minister at the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church, William Herbert Perry Faunce, later president of Brown, who recommended the college for its advantages of small classes, contact with professors, the inspiration of President E. B. Andrews, and the fact that "Providence is more healthful than New Haven."<cite><a href="Rockefeller, John D., Jr..html">Rockefeller, John D., Jr.</a></cite>
That’s why I like to come back to the campus from time to time, and particularly to these reunions where we all meet on the old-tine footing and where again, to you, I’m only ‘Johnny Rock.’" At the dedication of the John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Library in 1964, his son David Rockefeller noted, "at Brown my father discovered an intellectual challenge to which he could respond.<cite><a href="Rockefeller, John D., Jr..html">Rockefeller, John D., Jr.</a></cite>
John D. Rockefeller received an honorary master of arts degree in 1914 at the time of Brown’s sesquicentennial celebration, and an LL.D. degree in 1937, forty years after his graduation, when he served as chief marshal at the first Commencement presided over by President Wriston.<cite><a href="Rockefeller, John D., Jr..html">Rockefeller, John D., Jr.</a></cite>
John D. Rockefeller was awarded the Rosenberger Medal in 1931 and a Brown Bear award in 1956.<cite><a href="Rockefeller, John D., Jr..html">Rockefeller, John D., Jr.</a></cite>
In 1946 John D. Rockefeller wrote of his changed opinion, "In view of the new world in which we are living, this country needs ... trained men and women of vision, breadth and courage.<cite><a href="Rockefeller, John D., Jr..html">Rockefeller, John D., Jr.</a></cite>
In 1955 John D. Rockefeller contributed five million dollars which he identified as a compliment to Wriston on his retirement.<cite><a href="Rockefeller, John D., Jr..html">Rockefeller, John D., Jr.</a></cite>
Three years after her death, John D. Rockefeller married in 1951 Martha Baird Allen, widow of his classmate Arthur Allen.<cite><a href="Rockefeller, John D., Jr..html">Rockefeller, John D., Jr.</a></cite>
Together they gave to the University the Arthur Allen Room in the <a href="Hay, John.html">John Hay</a> Library in 1952.<cite><a href="Rockefeller, John D., Jr..html">Rockefeller, John D., Jr.</a></cite>
Rockefeller died in Tucson, Arizona, on May 11, 1960.<cite><a href="Rockefeller, John D., Jr..html">Rockefeller, John D., Jr.</a></cite>
When the John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Library was dedicated to him in 1964, his "credo," which had been expressed in a speech he delivered at the 75th anniversary celebration of Fisk University in 1941, was inscribed on the wall in the lobby of the library:<cite><a href="Rockefeller, John D., Jr..html">Rockefeller, John D., Jr.</a></cite>
The Rockefeller <a href="Library.html">Library</a> was dedicated on November 16, 1964.<cite><a href="Rockefeller Library.html">Rockefeller Library</a></cite>
Designed by Warner, Burns, Toan, Lunde, the building, which had been under construction since June of 1962, was planned to house 1,500,000 volumes in the humanities and social sciences, about twice the number present at the time of building, and to provide seating for 1,044 persons in the various reading rooms, studies, and carrels.<cite><a href="Rockefeller Library.html">Rockefeller Library</a></cite>
David Rockefeller spoke at the dedication on November 15, 1964 of the library named for his father, John D. Rockefeller, Jr. 1897, "an alumnus whose services to society were characterized by distinction and integrity, and whose relations to the University those of a devoted alumnus."<cite><a href="Rockefeller Library.html">Rockefeller Library</a></cite>
Rogers Hall was built in 1862 through the efforts of Professor Nathaniel P. Hill which resulted in raising subscriptions of $14,250.<cite><a href="Rogers Hall.html">Rogers Hall</a></cite>
When an addition was built in 1900 and used for other purposes as engineering instruction, the name was changed to Rogers Hall in honor of William Sanford Rogers, donor of $50,000 in 1872 to endow the Newport Rogers Professorship of <a href="Chemistry.html">Chemistry</a>.<cite><a href="Rogers Hall.html">Rogers Hall</a></cite>
After the new <a href="Metcalf Chemical Laboratory.html">Metcalf Chemical Laboratory</a> was built in 1924, the older laboratory was assigned for use for graduate research under Professor C. A. Kraus.<cite><a href="Rogers Hall.html">Rogers Hall</a></cite>
In 1986 the rear section of the building was razed and replaced by a new classroom building, which was opened in 1989 as the Richard and Edna <a href="Salomon Center for Teaching.html">Salomon Center for Teaching</a>.<cite><a href="Rogers Hall.html">Rogers Hall</a></cite>
William Rogers (1751-1824), the first student to matriculate, was born in Newport on July 22, 1751.<cite><a href="Rogers, William.html">Rogers, William</a></cite>
William Rogers enrolled on September 3, 1765, the day before the second annual meeting of the Corporation, at which <a href="Manning, James.html">James Manning</a> was elected president.<cite><a href="Rogers, William.html">Rogers, William</a></cite>
William Rogers was the only student until June 10, 1766, when Richard Stites, young brother-in-law of President Manning, enrolled.<cite><a href="Rogers, William.html">Rogers, William</a></cite>
At the first Commencement in 1769 William Rogers delivered an "oration on benevolence."<cite><a href="Rogers, William.html">Rogers, William</a></cite>
William Rogers taught for a while in Newport, was baptized by Gardner Thurston of Newport in 1770, and licensed to preach in August of 1771.<cite><a href="Rogers, William.html">Rogers, William</a></cite>
William Rogers was called to succeed <a href="Edwards, Morgan.html">Morgan Edwards</a> as pastor of the Baptist Church there and was ordained on May 31, 1772.<cite><a href="Rogers, William.html">Rogers, William</a></cite>
On March of 1776 William Rogers was appointed chaplain of Pennsylvania’s three battalions, and was promoted to a brigade chaplain in the Continental army in June 1778.<cite><a href="Rogers, William.html">Rogers, William</a></cite>
After William Rogers ended his military service in June 1781, he was approached by three different churches (of three different denominations), but declined any appointment, preferring to supply destitute churches in the Philadelphia area.<cite><a href="Rogers, William.html">Rogers, William</a></cite>
In 1784 William Rogers was called upon to perform a service for his Alma Mater, that of procuring in Philadelphia the new seal of the College which was to replace the colonial seal which bore the images of the King and Queen of England.<cite><a href="Rogers, William.html">Rogers, William</a></cite>
In 1789 William Rogers was appointed professor of English and oratory in the College and Academy of Philadelphia (which became the University of Pennsylvania).<cite><a href="Rogers, William.html">Rogers, William</a></cite>
William Rogers supplied the pulpit of the First Baptist Church in Philadelphia for two years after the death of its pastor, Thomas Ustick 1771.<cite><a href="Rogers, William.html">Rogers, William</a></cite>
William Rogers resigned his professorship in the University of Pennsylvania in 1812, attributing his departure to "Arbitrary Resolutions of its Trustees to which they were instigated by the restless and ambitious spirit of a despotical Provost John Andrews."<cite><a href="Rogers, William.html">Rogers, William</a></cite>
William Rogers died on April 7, 1824 in Philadelphia.<cite><a href="Rogers, William.html">Rogers, William</a></cite>
The Rosenberger Medal is awarded under the Susan Colver Rosenberger Fund, which was established by Jesse L. Rosenberger in 1919 as a memorial to his wife, the daughter of Charles K. Colver 1842.<cite><a href="Rosenberger Medal.html">Rosenberger Medal</a></cite>
There have been twenty recipients of the medal: William Williams Keen in 1925, Charles Evans Hughes in 1928, John Davison Rockefeller, Jr. in 1931, Charles Value Chapin in 1935, Mary Emma Woolley in 1937, Fred Tarbell Field in 1940, Henry Dexter Sharpe in 1944, Zechariah Chafee, Jr. in 1947, Warren Randolph Burgess in 1953, Rowland Roberts Hughes in 1955, Theodore Francis Green in 1956, Alexander Meiklejohn in 1959, Waldo Gifford Leland in 1965, Thomas John Watson, Jr. in 1968, Henry Merritt Wriston in 1976, Richard Salomon in 1982, Charles Carpenter Tillinghast, Jr. in 1982, Howard Robert Swearer in 1983, Otto Eduard Neugebauer in 1987, and Roderick Milton Chisholm in 1992.<cite><a href="Rosenberger Medal.html">Rosenberger Medal</a></cite>
The University Boat Club, sometimes called the Brown Navy, was organized on June 4, 1857.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
The Atalanta, six-oared and 44 feet long, described as "a cumbersome lap-streak, weighing three or four hundred pounds," made a single appearance at Lake Quinsigamond in Worcester on July 27, 1859 in a race with Harvard and Yale.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
The crew consisted of Adoniram Brown Judson 1859, Elnathan Judson 1859, Edward H. Sears 1862, Charles H. Perry 1859, Charles D. Cady 1861, and Pardon S. Jastram 1860.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
Hoping for a better showing, the Brown crew had another boat, named the <a href="Brunonia.html">Brunonia</a> and weighing 205 pounds, built by McKay of Williamsburg for the upcoming regatta in Worcester on July 24, 1860.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
On July 4, 1860 the <a href="Brunonia.html">Brunonia</a> entered a five-boat race including two Yale crews in the first general regatta in Providence.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
Interest in crew waned until the fall of 1869, when class crews were organized to take the place of rival clubs.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
In 1870 the freshman crew lost two three-mile races, one to the Narragansetts on June 2, and one to Harvard on June 17, but then brought Brown her first boating victory in Worcester in an exciting race in which Brown recovered time lost by a collision with the Amherst boat which had crossed over the bow of the Brown boat and, by executing a spectacular turn, overtook Yale and Harvard to win in 19 minutes, 21 seconds, six lengths ahead of second place Yale.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
At the intercollegiate regatta of July 21, 1871, held for the first time at Ingleside on the Connecticut River, the Harvard freshman crew beat the Brown freshmen, who might have lost even if it had not been necessary to alter course to avoid hitting a sight-seeing barge.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
The 1871 crew was under the charge of John Blew, a New York oarsman, and N. R. Knight of Providence was the trainer of the freshmen.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
The Rowing Association of American Colleges took over the regulation of the regatta, and at a meeting in Worcester in April 1872 set the date of the regatta and also decided that students in the scientific departments of universities were not eligible for university crews.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
In 1873 class crews at Brown competed against each other, but no crew was sent to Springfield.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
The next year the Class of 1877 crew went to Saratoga Springs, but did not finish the race.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
The college boat house burned on November 8, 1874.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
In January 1875 Brown was admitted as a voting member of the Rowing Association of American Colleges.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
At the race at Saratoga in 1875, Brown came in eighth after suffering "a combination of two ‘crabs’ and a broken oar."<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
No crew was sent to Saratoga in 1876, the boat club being in debt and preferring to spend its dues on new boats.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
Some of the indebtedness of the Club was defrayed by the proceeds ($216.23) of a series of "Boat Club Lectures" on art and public speaking in February and March of 1876.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
On November 22, 1876, a convention met at Worcester and formed a rowing association of New England colleges.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
Crew was given up in 1886-87 because of the impossibility of raising enough money to support both baseball and crew, the popularity of baseball naturally prevailing.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
It was not until 1949 that rowing was revived by a group of students who had rowed at their preparatory schools and got together to purchase for $100 a shell of questionable age, rumored to have been built for Harvard about 1930, but possibly older.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
Crew races became part of <a href="Spring Weekend.html">Spring Weekend</a>, the first in 1949 held in New Haven, and after that on the Seekonk River.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
In the second informal season, with Durand Echeverria as coach and Harlan Bartlett ’51 as captain, the crew was authorized in April 1950 to row under the name, "The Brown University Rowing Association, an Informal Organization of Brown Undergraduates."<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
The first intercollegiate race on the Seekonk since the 1870s was a victory for the Brown crew, which beat Clark University by four lengths and joyfully threw coxswain Ralph Gerstle into the river.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
Echeverria coached again in 1952.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
Success came in the 1953 season with joint coaching by Echeverria, Read, and Bartlett, as the crew defeated Dartmouth, gaining its first <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> win and the Atlantic Cup.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
Gordon "Whitey" Helander coached from 1958 to 1961 while he was a student at <a href="Rhode Island School of Design.html">Rhode Island School of Design</a>.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
His crews won the Dad Vail Regatta in 1959, 1960 and 1961.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
After an undefeated season the 1960 crew took part in the IRA regatta on Lake Onondaga at Syracuse without the presence of Helander, who was serving his annual Marine Corps military service.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
In 1961, when the crew had a 5-1 record, a fifth place in the Eastern Sprints at Worcester and a seventh in the IRA, rowing became recognized as an intercollegiate sport supported by the University.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
In August 1961 Victor H. Michalson came from coaching at Syracuse to become Brown’s first full-time crew coach.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
In 1962 Brown became a regular member of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges, and the next year won the Eastern Sprints at Worcester.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
The first Brown crew to row in the Henley Royal Regatta lost to a strong British crew, the London Tideway Scullers by one and one-half lengths on June 30, 1966, and was removed from competition after its first race.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
The 1970 freshman crew won an IRA championship, and Brown won the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> title in 1972.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
In 1973 the varsity eight finished second in the IRA national championships on Onondaga Lake.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
The 1979 crew won the Intercollegiate Rowing Association Regatta on Lake Onondaga.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
Steve Gladstone succeeded Michalson as coach in 1982.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
Brown won the Intercollegiate Rowing Association championship in 1983, 1986, and 1987.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
In 1984 Brown capped its undefeated regular season by winning the the Eastern Sprints and setting a course record while defeating the University of Bristol, Cambridge University’s Emmanuel College, the University of Washington, and Princeton to win the Ladies’ Challenge Plate at the Henley Regatta.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
The 1985 heavyweight crew, after an unbeaten regular season, lost in the Eastern Sprints and the IRA.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
In 1987 the Brown crew won both the Eastern Sprints and the Intercollegiate Rowing Association championship, and narrowly (by 46 one-hundredths of a second) missed winning the Cincinnati Regatta.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
The 1988 crew came in second in the IRA’s and third in the national championship on Lake Harsha in Ohio.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
The 1993 crew had a perfect season.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
The eight-man crew made up of Igor Boraska ’94 (an accomplished Croatian rower), Paul DiGiacomo ’93, David Filippone ’95, Gus Koven ’93, Jamie Koven ’95, Xeno Muller ’95 (who rowed for Switzerland in the 1992 Olympics), Tony Padula ’93, Chris Sahs ’94 (who rowed for the United States in the 1992 Olympics) and Brian Madden ’93, coxswain, won the Eastern Sprints, the Intercollegiate Rowing Association championships, and the national heavyweight eight championship.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
Women’s crew began in the spring of 1974.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
In the only meet of 1974 the crew outrowed Assumption College, Holy Cross, and Clark University on Lake Quinsigamond.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
Shells were borrowed from the men’s crew until November of 1976, when the first shell for the use of the women was acquired and named for Bessie Rudd, former director of physical education at Pembroke.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
The second shell obtained in 1978 was named for Judy and Paul Maddock ’33, and a launch acquired the same year was named for Marjorie and Stan Smith ’21.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
In 1979 the third shell was dedicated to the Smiths.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
Amram gave up his duties as part-time coach in 1979, and Gavin Viano was appointed as head coach.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
Two women crew members, Kathryn Reith ’78 and Betts Howes ’77 rowed in national competition in 1976 for the College Boat Club of the University of Pennsylvania.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
In 1983-84 Phoebe Plimpton coached her first novice boat to an undefeated dual season and a third place at the Eastern Sprints.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
The women’s varsity won its first Eastern Collegiate Rowing Association Championship in 1988 with a record time of 6:23.2 on the 1,950-meter course on Lake Waramaug in Connecticut.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
The 1990 women’s crew won its first Eastern Women’s Rowing Team Championship.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
In 1991 women’s crew boats finished first in the Head of the Ohio Regatta, second (but first collegiate) in the Head of the Connecticut, and tenth in the Head of the Charles.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
Coach John Murphy’s eight-year record from 1985 to 1992 was 30-26.<cite><a href="Rowing.html">Rowing</a></cite>
Bessie Huntting Rudd (1895-1978), director of physical education at Pembroke College, was born in Albion, New York, on June 4, 1895.<cite><a href="Rudd, Bessie H..html">Rudd, Bessie H.</a></cite>
A graduate of Radcliffe College in 1917, Bessie H. Rudd played varsity field hockey and was captain of the women’s basketball team.<cite><a href="Rudd, Bessie H..html">Rudd, Bessie H.</a></cite>
Bessie H. Rudd received a certificate of hygiene and physical education from Wellesley College in 1924.<cite><a href="Rudd, Bessie H..html">Rudd, Bessie H.</a></cite>
Bessie H. Rudd was assistant in the Department of Physical Education at Radcliffe College from 1918 to 1922, and assistant director of physical education from 1924 to 1930, when she became director of physical education at Pembroke.<cite><a href="Rudd, Bessie H..html">Rudd, Bessie H.</a></cite>
Bessie H. Rudd was promoted to associate professor of physical education in 1944 and named full professor in 1952.<cite><a href="Rudd, Bessie H..html">Rudd, Bessie H.</a></cite>
Bessie H. Rudd wrote frequently for the "National Field Hockey Guide," and was its editor in 1944.<cite><a href="Rudd, Bessie H..html">Rudd, Bessie H.</a></cite>
In 1931 Bessie H. Rudd was elected a national A-rated field hockey umpire.<cite><a href="Rudd, Bessie H..html">Rudd, Bessie H.</a></cite>
She retired in 1961, at which time the Bessie H. Rudd Award was established, to be presented annually to the woman who did the most to advance women’s athletics at Brown.<cite><a href="Rudd, Bessie H..html">Rudd, Bessie H.</a></cite>
In 1975 Bessie H. Rudd was the first woman to be inducted into the Brown Athletic Hall of Fame.<cite><a href="Rudd, Bessie H..html">Rudd, Bessie H.</a></cite>
Bessie H. Rudd favored compulsory physical education for all four years of college, and disapproved when the requirement was reduced to three years in 1960 and later abolished.<cite><a href="Rudd, Bessie H..html">Rudd, Bessie H.</a></cite>
Bessie H. Rudd died in Providence on January 11, 1978.<cite><a href="Rudd, Bessie H..html">Rudd, Bessie H.</a></cite>
Rugby as a club sport began in 1960, started by David Zucconi ’55, who had played rugby in England while stationed there with the Air Force.<cite><a href="Rugby.html">Rugby</a></cite>
In 1966 Brown defeated Notre Dame to win the Virginia Commonwealth Cup.<cite><a href="Rugby.html">Rugby</a></cite>
In 1968 Brown hosted the first annual <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> Rugby Tournament, winning over Columbia (11-0), Harvard (11-3), and Penn (6-3), and losing to Princeton (3-6).<cite><a href="Rugby.html">Rugby</a></cite>
In 1970 Brown won the Virginia Commonwealth Cup again by defeating Notre Dame, this time in overtime, but had a less successful tour in England, winning one of six games.<cite><a href="Rugby.html">Rugby</a></cite>
The 1974 team, led by Phil McMorrow ’75 (21 tries in eleven games), won the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> championship.<cite><a href="Rugby.html">Rugby</a></cite>
In 1977 when the team came in third for the national college title, the all-time record stood at 243-93-9.<cite><a href="Rugby.html">Rugby</a></cite>
Jay Fluck ’65 became a volunteer coach in 1981 and has continued to coach since then.<cite><a href="Rugby.html">Rugby</a></cite>
During this time Brown has won five <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> Tournament Championships (Spring) in 1983, 1985, 1986, 1987, and 1988.<cite><a href="Rugby.html">Rugby</a></cite>
Brown has also reached the Northeast Regional Collegiate Playoffs (Fall) on two occasions, in 1986 and in 1991.<cite><a href="Rugby.html">Rugby</a></cite>
The team has also toured extensively, to Ireland in 1983, to England and Wales in 1985, to Scotland in 1987, to Trinidad in 1988, to Ireland in 1990, and to England and Wales in 1991.<cite><a href="Rugby.html">Rugby</a></cite>
Women’s rugby started at Brown in 1987.<cite><a href="Rugby.html">Rugby</a></cite>
In 1991 the women’s team finished fourth of six teams in the Ivy Championships, and attained full member status in the New England Rugby <a href="Football.html">Football</a> Union.<cite><a href="Rugby.html">Rugby</a></cite>
<br />A reader adds that Brown Rugby also won the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> championships in 1980, with Jay Fluck as a part-time coach, and that Brian Moynihan ’81 was captain of the team in 1981.<cite><a href="Rugby.html">Rugby</a></cite>
Jonathan Russell (1771-1832), diplomat, was born in Providence on February 27, 1771, the son of Jonathan and Abigail (Russell) Russell.<cite><a href="Russell, Jonathan.html">Russell, Jonathan</a></cite>
His father was descended from John Russell, a 1640 resident of Charlestown, Massachusetts, to whom his mother of the same surname was not related.<cite><a href="Russell, Jonathan.html">Russell, Jonathan</a></cite>
Jonathan Russell graduated from Rhode Island College in 1791.<cite><a href="Russell, Jonathan.html">Russell, Jonathan</a></cite>
Jonathan Russell was known as an orator, and his Fourth of July oration in 1800 in the First Baptist Church in Providence was published in a number of editions.<cite><a href="Russell, Jonathan.html">Russell, Jonathan</a></cite>
Jonathan Russell's diplomatic career began when President James Madison appointed him chargé d’affaires in Paris in 1810.<cite><a href="Russell, Jonathan.html">Russell, Jonathan</a></cite>
From 1814 to 1818 Jonathan Russell was United States minister to Sweden and Norway.<cite><a href="Russell, Jonathan.html">Russell, Jonathan</a></cite>
In 1818 Jonathan Russell was recalled from Sweden by James Monroe, and the next year he settled in Mendon, Massachusetts.<cite><a href="Russell, Jonathan.html">Russell, Jonathan</a></cite>
After his one term in the United States House of Representatives, from 1821 to 1823, Russell retired from public life.<cite><a href="Russell, Jonathan.html">Russell, Jonathan</a></cite>
Jonathan Russell died in Boston on February 17, 1832.<cite><a href="Russell, Jonathan.html">Russell, Jonathan</a></cite>
William Warner Russell (1895-1977), professor of chemistry, was born in Franklin, Massachusetts, on November 25, 1895.<cite><a href="Russell, William W..html">Russell, William W.</a></cite>
William W. Russell graduated from Brown in 1918 and received a master of science degree from the University in 1920, after which he earned a second master’s in 1923 and a Ph.D. in 1926 from Princeton.<cite><a href="Russell, William W..html">Russell, William W.</a></cite>
William W. Russell came to Brown as an assistant professor in 1924, was promoted to associate professor in 1936, and named Newport Rogers Professor of Chemistry in 1950.<cite><a href="Russell, William W..html">Russell, William W.</a></cite>
William W. Russell retired in 1962.<cite><a href="Russell, William W..html">Russell, William W.</a></cite>
William W. Russell died on May 15, 1977 in Summit, New Jersey.<cite><a href="Russell, William W..html">Russell, William W.</a></cite>
Sailing began at Brown in February 1894 with the organization of a Yacht Club composed of students who owned or leased yachts and other interested students.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
The commodore was Albert G. Utley 1897, owner of the cutter Sharon.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
The vice-commodore was William T. Dorrance 1894, owner of the yacht Cingeria, and the secretary-treasurer was John W. Angell 1895, owner of the yacht Nadir.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
The 1895 "<a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a>" listed 31 yacht owners and thirty associate members in the club.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
C. Sherman Hoyt ’01 wrote in his published "Sherman Hoyt’s Memoirs" about the Yacht Club of his day: The Brown Yacht Club of 1903 had seventy members.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
Colgate Hoyt, Jr. ’05 was Commodore from 1903 to 1905.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
The revival of the Brown Yacht Club began with a meeting of thirty students on May 14, 1931.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
A yacht club with twenty members was represented in the 1932 "<a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a>," identified as "An organization whose aim is to stimulate interest in yachting and boating, and to promote further intercollegiate competition in races and regattas."<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
In 1934-35 the Club took part in an early winter intercollegiate "frost-bite’ dinghy race with M.I.T. and Yale.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
In 1936 a few students under Commodore Deane K. Fox ’37 and faculty advisor Zenas R. Bliss ’18, twice navigator of America’s Cup defenders, reorganized the club, bought dinghies, and raced informally with the Narragansett Boat Club, which had also provided headquarters for the new Brown Club.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
The club’s initial victory in an intercollegiate regatta sponsored by Brown and held in Bristol in May 1936 attracted alumni contributions of $2,400 for the purchase of eight Dyer dinghies to bring the fleet up to sixteen.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
On December 5, 1936 Brown hosted a regatta on the Seekonk and won over M.I.T., Harvard, Dartmouth, and Williams.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
In the spring of 1937 interclass competition open to all students began, with the purpose of selecting the best sailors to compete for Brown.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
In May 1937 the Brown Yacht Club finished first of fourteen entries on the Charles.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
In the fall season of 1937 the Brown club lost to M.I.T. and the Brown Alumni, before winning against Dartmouth in a dual regatta in which Brown took first and second places in all three races.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
In 1937 Brown was able to acquire the boat house of the Narragansett Boat Club on the Seekonk River.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
The remodelled boat house was dedicated on May 7, 1938 at an Intercollegiate Dinghy Racing Association Regatta.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
Leonard Romagna ’42 won the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association’s dinghy championship in 1940 and 1941 (both years Brown finished third) and in 1942 in fourteen races he scored eight firsts, two seconds, a third, a fourth, and two fifths for 181 out of Brown’s winning total of 313 points.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
Brown won national championships in 1942 and 1948 and was runner-up in 1938, 1949, and 1956.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
Brown’s chance at coming in first in the Nationals in 1956 was lost when Brown’s boat hit a marker and was beaten by Navy.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
In 1946 Brown, led by skippers Charlie Ill ’49 and Rick Wilson ’48, was second in competition for the Schell trophy, and the next year won the Danmark and Schell trophies.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
In the fall of 1948 Brown did not succeed in defending its trophies because Ill and Wilson elected to withdraw in order to give the less experienced Brown sailors a chance to compete.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
The Brown club won the Macmillan Trophy in 1950, and in 1954 won the Jack Wood trophy for the first time in 22 years of competition with M.I.T., Harvard, Dartmouth and Coast Guard.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
In the spring of 1955 the Yacht Club replaced its fleet of wooden boats with fifteen fiberglass racing dinghies.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
In the fall of 1955 the team won the New England championships and captured the Angsten Trophy at the mid-western championships.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
In 1956 the dinghy team won eleven of thirteen regattas in the fall, the New England Fall Championships, the Jeff Davis, Jack Wood, and Sherman Hoyt trophies and, with Tom Hazlehurst ’56 and John C. Quinn ’57 as skippers and Tom Breslin ’53 and Bob Goff ’57 as crew, successfully defended the the Angsten Trophy.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
Women sailors were invited to take part in an intercollegiate regatta on the Seekonk River on May 3, 1941.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
The first all-woman regatta at Brown in May 1947 was won by Connecticut College.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
In the late 1950s Dartmouth and the University of Rhode Island also hosted women’s regattas.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
In October 1956 Pembroke held for the first time a small fall regatta in addition to the annual spring invitational.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
In the spring of 1957 a constitution for a women’s intercollegiate sailing association was drawn up at Brown and presented to Wheaton College and Connecticut College for Women.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
Although the intercollegiate association did not materialize at this stage, the Pembroke Sailing Club was formed under Jessie Godfrey, who was replaced in 1958 by Janet Lutz.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
The Pembroke Sailing Club participated in women’s regattas in New England, and about 1962 Mary Paget of Radcliffe and Janet Lutz of Brown were able with input from the NEISA men to help the loosely organized women’s colleges to form the New England Women’s Intercollegiate Sailing Association.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
Brown won Ivy titles in 1964 with skippers Chuck Paine ’66 and Earl Harrington ’66, and again in 1973 with skippers Ed Holt ’74 and Willie DeCamp ’73.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
Since 1974, when the boat house presented by the Class of 1907 in 1937 was destroyed by fire, the club has sailed out of the Edgewood Yacht Club on Narragansett Bay.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
In 1978 the team won its third <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> title after finishing second in the Boston Dinghy Championships and in the Owen Trophy competition, with skippers Martha Starkweather and Nat Philbrick in the A Division and Reed Baer and Helen Ciriello in the B Division.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
From 1980 to 1990 Brad Dellenbaugh ’76 coached sailing, and Brown turned out a series of All-Americans, Douglas Smith in 1984, James Cummiskey ’85 in 1985, Paul Grimes ’86 in 1985 and 1986, David Ullrich ’87 in 1986 and 1987, Molly Starkweather ’86 in 1986, Kevin Hall ’91 in 1988, 1990, and 1991, Kris Farrar ’91 in 1989, 1990, and 1991, and Mike Zani ’92 in 1990 and 1991.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
In 1983 Brown won the New England fall championships for the first time since 1957, when Ted Turner ’60 sailed for Brown.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
Brown won another <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> championship in 1985.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
Brown won the intercollegiate women’s sailing championship in 1985, 1988, and 1989, and came in second in in 1986, 1987, and 1990.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
In 1991 the Brown sailing team won, for the first time and by one point over Navy, the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association’s prestigious Fowle trophy, which includes men’s, women’s, single-handed, team, and sloop championships.<cite><a href="Sailing.html">Sailing</a></cite>
The Salomon Center for Teaching, which has for its full name the Richard and Edna Salomon Center for Teaching, was dedicated on May 6, 1989.<cite><a href="Salomon Center for Teaching.html">Salomon Center for Teaching</a></cite>
The old <a href="Rogers Hall.html">Rogers Hall</a>, which was built as the chemical laboratory in 1862, became a large entrance lobby connected to the new building which houses a main auditorium for 576 persons on the first level, and below another auditorium for 220.<cite><a href="Salomon Center for Teaching.html">Salomon Center for Teaching</a></cite>
The Sarah Doyle Women’s Center has been in operation since 1975, as a result of a proposal the year before by the Working Group on the Status of Women, a coalition of 25 students, faculty, administrators and employees, who wanted a center where women of all ages could come together to discuss women’s issues.<cite><a href="Sarah Doyle Women's Center.html">Sarah Doyle Women's Center</a></cite>
The house at 185 Meeting Street was left to Pembroke by Mary H. Parsons and was first occupied in 1966 as the Alumnae House, home of the Pembroke <a href="Alumnae Association.html">Alumnae Association</a>.<cite><a href="Sarah Doyle Women's Center.html">Sarah Doyle Women's Center</a></cite>
Sayles Gymnasium was made possible by the subscription by Frank A. Sayles 1890 of $50,000 to the endowment fund of 1900, with the stipulation that the use of this money be later determined subject to his approval.<cite><a href="Sayles Gymnasium.html">Sayles Gymnasium</a></cite>
Friends of the Women’s College suggested a gymnasium for the women students, Sayles approved, and the cornerstone was laid on May 6, 1906.<cite><a href="Sayles Gymnasium.html">Sayles Gymnasium</a></cite>
The first social event in Sayles Gymnasium, a dance given by Delta Sigma sorority, took place on January 2, 1907, before the formal dedication on January 26.<cite><a href="Sayles Gymnasium.html">Sayles Gymnasium</a></cite>
About 1912 Sayles Gym was reorganized under Miss M. Elizabeth Bates, the new instructor in hygiene and physical education, to include Swedish apparatus in the gymnasium, a corrective room (for posture), a quiet rest room (for students unable to exercise), and a social rest-room "for the refreshment of the senses," where non-resident students could gather.<cite><a href="Sayles Gymnasium.html">Sayles Gymnasium</a></cite>
In the 1930s the rest room was available for use by any group of at least four students to stay overnight on special occasions, at a charge of twenty-five cents per person.<cite><a href="Sayles Gymnasium.html">Sayles Gymnasium</a></cite>
In 1990 the <a href="Physical Education.html">Physical Education</a> Department left Sayles Gymnasium, which was to be renovated for classroom use.<cite><a href="Sayles Gymnasium.html">Sayles Gymnasium</a></cite>
Sayles Hall was dedicated on June 4, 1881, a memorial to William Clark Sayles 1878 donated by his father, William F. Sayles.<cite><a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a></cite>
Young Sayles, who entered Brown in 1874, died on February 13, 1876.<cite><a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a></cite>
On June 14, 1878 his father wrote to <a href="President.html">President</a> Robinson offering $50,000 for a building "which shall be exclusively and forever devoted to lectures and recitations, and to meetings on academic occasions."<cite><a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a></cite>
In 1912 the Department of <a href="Economics.html">Economics</a> moved from the basement of Sayles Hall into the former library (<a href="Robinson Hall.html">Robinson Hall</a>), making space for the Department of <a href="Geology.html">Geology</a>.<cite><a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a></cite>
The organ in Sayles Hall was a gift in 1903 of Lucian Sharpe 1893 in memory of his parents.<cite><a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a></cite>
At <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> of 1903 the opening recital on the organ was given by eminent Belgian organist Chevalier August Wiegand.<cite><a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a></cite>
In 1924 Mrs. Lownes endowed an annual organ recital known as "Edgar J. Lownes Memory Day," a memorial to her late husband.<cite><a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a></cite>
In 1949 the organ received its first complete renovation, which involved the installation of a new console laid out by A. W. Imhoff of the Schantz Organ Company.<cite><a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a></cite>
The latest restoration by the Potter-Rathbun Company of Cranston was undertaken in 1990.<cite><a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a></cite>
The restored organ was rededicated on <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> weekend of 1992 with a performance by University organist Wayne Schneider of a new work by Stephen Scott ’69 M.A.<cite><a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a></cite>
The "Little <a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a>" came into being in 1945 toward the end of <a href="World War II.html">World War II</a>, when Chaplain Arthur L. Washburn and Vice-<a href="President.html">President</a> James P. Adams arranged to reopen a little room off the main hall on the first floor which had several years earlier had a small altar placed in it at the request of Professor Edmund L. Loughnan for meetings of undergraduate prayer groups.<cite><a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a></cite>
Dr. Washburn announced that the chapel was open daily "until 2200" for "quiet thought and prayer."<cite><a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a></cite>
An unexpected use of the chapel was the marriage there of at least one Brown graduate in 1945.<cite><a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a></cite>
On April 23, 1946 a stained glass window in the Little <a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a> was dedicated to the chaplains in the United States Service.<cite><a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a></cite>
Harold Schlosberg (1904-1964), professor of psychology, was born in Brooklyn, New York, on January 3, 1904.<cite><a href="Schlosberg, Harold.html">Schlosberg, Harold</a></cite>
Harold Schlosberg came to Brown in 1928 as an instructor of psychology.<cite><a href="Schlosberg, Harold.html">Schlosberg, Harold</a></cite>
Harold Schlosberg had graduated in 1925 from Princeton, where he earned his master of arts degree in 1926 and his Ph.D. in 1928 and had been a University Fellow and a Proctor Fellow.<cite><a href="Schlosberg, Harold.html">Schlosberg, Harold</a></cite>
Harold Schlosberg was promoted to assistant professor in 1930, associate professor in 1937, and professor in 1947.<cite><a href="Schlosberg, Harold.html">Schlosberg, Harold</a></cite>
In 1954 Schlosberg was appointed chairman of the department and in 1960 he was named Edgar J. Marston Professor.<cite><a href="Schlosberg, Harold.html">Schlosberg, Harold</a></cite>
Harold Schlosberg was responsible for the planning and supervision of construction of the <a href="Hunter, Walter S..html">Walter S. Hunter</a> Laboratory of Psychology, built in 1958, which finally replaced the old frame houses and the basements where the department had been poorly housed for years.<cite><a href="Schlosberg, Harold.html">Schlosberg, Harold</a></cite>
Harold Schlosberg was co-author with R. S. Woodworth of a revision in 1954 of Woodworth’s well-known "Experimental Psychology."<cite><a href="Schlosberg, Harold.html">Schlosberg, Harold</a></cite>
Harold Schlosberg died August 5, 1964 in Providence at the age of 61.<cite><a href="Schlosberg, Harold.html">Schlosberg, Harold</a></cite>
Detlev Walther Schumann (1900-1986), professor of German, was born in Kiel, Germany, on May 20, 1900.<cite><a href="Schumann, Detlev W..html">Schumann, Detlev W.</a></cite>
After receiving a Ph.D. degree from the University of Hamburg in 1923 Detlev W. Schumann taught in secondary schools in Germany until 1926, when he came to the United States.<cite><a href="Schumann, Detlev W..html">Schumann, Detlev W.</a></cite>
Detlev W. Schumann taught at Bowdoin College from 1926 to 1929, at Lincoln School of Teachers College at Columbia from 1929 to 1931, at the University of Missouri from 1931 to 1934, and at Swarthmore College from 1934 to 1935.<cite><a href="Schumann, Detlev W..html">Schumann, Detlev W.</a></cite>
In 1935 Detlev W. Schumann came to Brown as assistant professor of German, and was promoted to associate professor in 1936 and professor in 1946.<cite><a href="Schumann, Detlev W..html">Schumann, Detlev W.</a></cite>
Detlev W. Schumann left Brown in 1949 to teach at the University of Illinois, where he remained until 1957.<cite><a href="Schumann, Detlev W..html">Schumann, Detlev W.</a></cite>
Detlev W. Schumann taught at the University of Pennsylvania from 1957 to 1962.<cite><a href="Schumann, Detlev W..html">Schumann, Detlev W.</a></cite>
When an opportunity to return to Brown as chairman of the German Department arose in 1962, Schumann found himself taking a sentimental trip back to where he wanted to be, "in Marston Hall, which still had exactly the same musty (somewhat pleasantly musty!)<cite><a href="Schumann, Detlev W..html">Schumann, Detlev W.</a></cite>
In 1964 Detlev W. Schumann received the Medal of Merit First Class, one of the highest medals of the German government, for promoting student exchanges between Brown and the University of Kiel, for the quality of his scholarship and teaching in German studies, and for the contributions to German culture afforded by dissertations supervised by him.<cite><a href="Schumann, Detlev W..html">Schumann, Detlev W.</a></cite>
In 1965 Schumann represented Brown at the tercentenary of the University of Kiel, on which occasion he was made an "Ehrenbürger," or Honorary Fellow of the University.<cite><a href="Schumann, Detlev W..html">Schumann, Detlev W.</a></cite>
Detlev W. Schumann was chairman of the German Department until 1965, and retired from Brown in 1970.<cite><a href="Schumann, Detlev W..html">Schumann, Detlev W.</a></cite>
Detlev W. Schumann died in Providence on December 29, 1986.<cite><a href="Schumann, Detlev W..html">Schumann, Detlev W.</a></cite>
The Sciences <a href="Library.html">Library</a> opened in December 1971 after 31 months of construction beset by many delays.<cite><a href="Sciences Library.html">Sciences Library</a></cite>
A Seal for the College was ordered after the second annual meeting of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> in 1765.<cite><a href="Seal.html">Seal</a></cite>
The University owns a silver reproduction of the first seal made from an impression of the original in the Rhode Island Historical Society, which was presented to the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> in 1910 by the Rhode Island Chapter of the Society of Colonial Dames.<cite><a href="Seal.html">Seal</a></cite>
When a new seal was designed, <a href="President.html">President</a> Manning wrote in January 1784 to William Rogers 1769 of Philadelphia, "Inclosed you have the Device of the College Seal, which you are requested to procure engraved in the best Manner, &amp; and at the lowest Price, by the famous Engraver, who executes for the Public their curious Devices ... as you know the Poverty of the College we rely on you to obtain it on the best Terms."<cite><a href="Seal.html">Seal</a></cite>
Preliminary drawings of the second seal have been found in the papers of Solomon Drowne 1773, who appears to have had a hand in its design.<cite><a href="Seal.html">Seal</a></cite>
<a href="President.html">President</a> Wayland in his report to the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> on September 3, 1833, almost thirty years after the change of name from Rhode Island College to Brown University had taken place, pointed out that the seal had never been changed to bear the new name.<cite><a href="Seal.html">Seal</a></cite>
It is permissible to use the shield by itself without the crest, torse or motto, to vary the shape of shield provided it does not approach the lozenge (diamond) shape used for women’s arms, and to place a scroll lettered "Brown" and "1764" above the shield.<cite><a href="Seal.html">Seal</a></cite>
