An emblem for the bicentennial celebration of 1964 was composed of the first and third seals joined together.<cite><a href="Seal.html">Seal</a></cite>
The Women’s College occasionally made informal use of the arms of <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a> in Cambridge for decoration on <a href="Ivy Day.html">Ivy Day</a> programs and pins, even before the College took the name <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a> in 1928.<cite><a href="Seal.html">Seal</a></cite>
The arms are those of Maria de St. Pol, who founded <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a> (Cambridge) in 1347.<cite><a href="Seal.html">Seal</a></cite>
Her husband, Aymer de Valence, Earl of Pembroke, had died in 1324, contrary to a legend that he was killed in a tournament on their wedding day in 1321.<cite><a href="Seal.html">Seal</a></cite>
Barnas Sears (1802-1880), fifth president of Brown University, was born in Sandisfield in the Berkshires, Massachusetts, on November 19, 1802.<cite><a href="Sears, Barnas.html">Sears, Barnas</a></cite>
Barnas Sears entered Brown in 1822 and graduated in 1825, supporting himself by teaching school in the winter vacation and building stone walls in the summer.<cite><a href="Sears, Barnas.html">Sears, Barnas</a></cite>
At Commencement in 1825 Barnas Sears delivered an oration on "The Influence of Association Upon the Intellectual Character."<cite><a href="Sears, Barnas.html">Sears, Barnas</a></cite>
In 1827 Barnas Sears was named pastor of the First Baptist Church in Hartford.<cite><a href="Sears, Barnas.html">Sears, Barnas</a></cite>
Barnas Sears resigned in 1829 because of his health, and became professor of ancient languages at Hamilton Literary and Theological Institution.<cite><a href="Sears, Barnas.html">Sears, Barnas</a></cite>
Barnas Sears was appointed professor of biblical theology, for which he prepared himself by study in Germany from 1833 to 1835.<cite><a href="Sears, Barnas.html">Sears, Barnas</a></cite>
Barnas Sears returned to teach for about a year at Hamilton before becoming professor of Christian theology at Newton Theological Institution in 1836.<cite><a href="Sears, Barnas.html">Sears, Barnas</a></cite>
Barnas Sears taught at Newton until 1848, and was also president from 1839.<cite><a href="Sears, Barnas.html">Sears, Barnas</a></cite>
Barnas Sears published "A Grammar of the German Language" in 1842, "The Ciceronian: or the Prussian Method of Teaching the Elements of the Latin Language" in 1844, and collaborated with others in "Classical Studies: Essays on Ancient Literature and Art" in 1843.<cite><a href="Sears, Barnas.html">Sears, Barnas</a></cite>
Barnas Sears was also editor of the "Christian Review" from 1838 to 1841.<cite><a href="Sears, Barnas.html">Sears, Barnas</a></cite>
In 1848 Barnas Sears succeeded <a href="Mann, Horace.html">Horace Mann</a> 1819 as secretary of the the Massachusetts Board of Education.<cite><a href="Sears, Barnas.html">Sears, Barnas</a></cite>
In September 1855 Barnas Sears replaced <a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Francis Wayland</a> as president of Brown University.<cite><a href="Sears, Barnas.html">Sears, Barnas</a></cite>
First beset by the financial crisis of 1857-58 and later by the Civil War, Barnas Sears's administration was still able to produce a new chemistry laboratory, an endowment increased by about $210,000, and the beginning of a system of scholarships for the students.<cite><a href="Sears, Barnas.html">Sears, Barnas</a></cite>
John B. G. Pidge 1866 remembered the new teaching methods in Sears’s classes: The students so loved Sears, that when he left Brown and Providence on September 19, 1867, they formed a procession in order of classes which marched down the hill by his house, and then at the wharf, filed by, each student shaking his president’s hand.<cite><a href="Sears, Barnas.html">Sears, Barnas</a></cite>
Barnas Sears died on July 9, 1880 in Saratoga Springs, New York, where he had gone to improve his health and also to address the American Association of Teachers.<cite><a href="Sears, Barnas.html">Sears, Barnas</a></cite>
Lorenzo Sears (1838-1916), professor of rhetoric and American literature, was born in Searsville, Massachusetts, on April 18, 1838.<cite><a href="Sears, Lorenzo.html">Sears, Lorenzo</a></cite>
Lorenzo Sears graduated from Yale in 1861 and from the General Theological Seminary in New York in 1864.<cite><a href="Sears, Lorenzo.html">Sears, Lorenzo</a></cite>
Lorenzo Sears was ordained a priest of the Episcopal Church in 1865, and served as pastor in churches in Connecticut, Rhode Island, and New Hampshire, until 1885, when he gave up the ministry and became professor of rhetoric and English literature at the University of Vermont.<cite><a href="Sears, Lorenzo.html">Sears, Lorenzo</a></cite>
Lorenzo Sears was appointed associate professor of rhetoric at Brown in 1890, promoted to professor of rhetoric and oratory in 1892, and named the first professor of American literature in 1895.<cite><a href="Sears, Lorenzo.html">Sears, Lorenzo</a></cite>
Lorenzo Sears resigned in 1905 to devote himself to his writing.<cite><a href="Sears, Lorenzo.html">Sears, Lorenzo</a></cite>
Among Lorenzo Sears's works were "American Literature in the Colonial and National Periods," published in 1902, and "The Makers of American Literature," in 1905.<cite><a href="Sears, Lorenzo.html">Sears, Lorenzo</a></cite>
Lorenzo Sears died in Providence on February 29, 1916.<cite><a href="Sears, Lorenzo.html">Sears, Lorenzo</a></cite>
Sepiad was the literary magazine of the Women’s College, which first appeared in April 1901, brought forth by the efforts of Florence Rafter ’01, the first editor, Jessie Wheeler ’01, and Grace Jones ’01.<cite><a href="Sepiad.html">Sepiad</a></cite>
The name of the publication was inspired by a poem by Professor Courtney Langdon in the "<a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a>" of December 3, 1892, "The Sepiades," which he called for the newly arrived women students.<cite><a href="Sepiad.html">Sepiad</a></cite>
It came out monthly in 1901-1902, quarterly from 1902 to 1928, and irregularly from 1929 to its end in 1932.<cite><a href="Sepiad.html">Sepiad</a></cite>
On November 18, 1919 a small newspaper called "Sepiad Supplement" was issued after gaining the approval of a mass meeting of Student Government Association.<cite><a href="Sepiad.html">Sepiad</a></cite>
The next year the "Sepiad Supplement" came out about every three weeks, and by 1922 it became a newspaper in its own right, changing its title to "The Record."<cite><a href="Sepiad.html">Sepiad</a></cite>
The Sesquicentennial celebration marking the 150th anniversary of the founding of the University lasted for five sunny days, October 11 to 15, 1914.<cite><a href="Sesquicentennial celebration.html">Sesquicentennial celebration</a></cite>
First came the classes of 1870 through 1899 in caps and gowns of white and brown, then the classes of 1900 through 1905 in the Puritan garb of the first settlers of Providence, followed by the classes of 1906 through 1908 as Quakers in gray.<cite><a href="Sesquicentennial celebration.html">Sesquicentennial celebration</a></cite>
The classes of 1909 through 1914 dressed as the French soldiers who had occupied <a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a> during the Revolution, while the senior class of 1915 were soldiers of the Continental army.<cite><a href="Sesquicentennial celebration.html">Sesquicentennial celebration</a></cite>
Juniors wore uniforms of the War of 1812 and sophomores were French sailors of the Revolution.<cite><a href="Sesquicentennial celebration.html">Sesquicentennial celebration</a></cite>
Costumed representatives of special events came next, the crew of 1873, the 1870 baseball team, Colonial and early nineteenth-century gentlemen, and finally, those marchers of other days, a recreation of the Junior burial with coffin and books on their way to a "cremation."<cite><a href="Sesquicentennial celebration.html">Sesquicentennial celebration</a></cite>
On Wednesday an academic procession of twelve hundred, including many notable representatives of American and foreign educational institutions, marched to the Meeting House to hear the Historical Address by U.S. Supreme Court Justice Charles Evans Hughes 1881.<cite><a href="Sesquicentennial celebration.html">Sesquicentennial celebration</a></cite>
Celebrators could also enjoy three performances of "The Provoked Husband," a play within a play "In Colony Times," by Henry A. Barker and A. E. Thomas, which recalled the first production of "The Provoked Husband" in Providence in 1762, complete with John Brown and his trusty cannon in front of the improvised theatre, ready to ward off colonists who were protesting against the ungodly performance.<cite><a href="Sesquicentennial celebration.html">Sesquicentennial celebration</a></cite>
James Seth (1860-1924), professor of philosophy, was born in Edinburgh in 1860, was educated at George Watson’s College, and received a master of arts degree from the University of Edinburgh in 1881.<cite><a href="Seth, James.html">Seth, James</a></cite>
James Seth studied at the Universities of Leipzig, Jena, and Berlin, and in 1883 became assistant to Professor Campbell Fraser in Edinburgh.<cite><a href="Seth, James.html">Seth, James</a></cite>
In 1885 James Seth was appointed professor of philosophy at Dalhousie College.<cite><a href="Seth, James.html">Seth, James</a></cite>
James Seth was appointed associate professor of natural theology at Brown in 1892, and professor of philosophy and natural theology in 1894.<cite><a href="Seth, James.html">Seth, James</a></cite>
James Seth did not stay long, leaving in 1896 to become professor of moral philosophy at Cornell.<cite><a href="Seth, James.html">Seth, James</a></cite>
In 1898 James Seth returned to the University of Edinburgh to occupy the chair of moral philosophy for 26 years.<cite><a href="Seth, James.html">Seth, James</a></cite>
In April 1899 James Seth returned to Brown for the annual public lecture of the Philosophical Club, to speak on "Philosophy and Poetry."<cite><a href="Seth, James.html">Seth, James</a></cite>
James Seth died in Edinburgh on July 25, 1924.<cite><a href="Seth, James.html">Seth, James</a></cite>
Henry Dexter Sharpe (1872-1954), twelfth chancellor of Brown University, graduated in 1894.<cite><a href="Sharpe, Henry D. 1894.html">Sharpe, Henry D. 1894</a></cite>
Henry D. 1894 Sharpe was chancellor for twenty years, from 1932 to 1952.<cite><a href="Sharpe, Henry D. 1894.html">Sharpe, Henry D. 1894</a></cite>
In 1936 Henry D. 1894 Sharpe was named chairman of the University Council, a group formed to work out a long-term program for increasing Brown’s financial resources.<cite><a href="Sharpe, Henry D. 1894.html">Sharpe, Henry D. 1894</a></cite>
In 1927 Henry D. 1894 Sharpe donated five fellowships to the Graduate School, in the Departments of Biology, English, History, Mathematics, and Romance Languages.<cite><a href="Sharpe, Henry D. 1894.html">Sharpe, Henry D. 1894</a></cite>
Henry D. 1894 Sharpe donated over $200,000 to the Housing and Development Campaign in the 1940s, and at his suggestion his donation was the principal funding of the new classroom building, Whitehall, which was such a radical departure from the traditional architecture of the campus.<cite><a href="Sharpe, Henry D. 1894.html">Sharpe, Henry D. 1894</a></cite>
When Henry D. 1894 Sharpe died on May 17, 1954, his largest public bequest was to Brown.<cite><a href="Sharpe, Henry D. 1894.html">Sharpe, Henry D. 1894</a></cite>
Sharpe Refectory was built in 1950 at a cost of two million dollars to accommodate 1,640 students in the main dining room and the eighteen (seventeen for the fraternities) private dining rooms around the perimeter, with a cafeteria, the Ivy Room, in the basement for commuters and staff.<cite><a href="Sharpe Refectory.html">Sharpe Refectory</a></cite>
The refectory was named for Chancellor Henry D. Sharpe 1894, and opened in January 1951.<cite><a href="Sharpe Refectory.html">Sharpe Refectory</a></cite>
Later the service was changed to cafeteria style, and in 1982 the former private fraternity dining rooms were made available for the use of other groups.<cite><a href="Sharpe Refectory.html">Sharpe Refectory</a></cite>
Sigma Xi was established at Brown in 1900.<cite><a href="Sigma Xi.html">Sigma Xi</a></cite>
Professor Benjamin Franklin Clarke was the first president of the Brown chapter, which was reported by the "Brown Alumni Monthly" in 1901 as "Numbering as it does among its members almost the whole scientific faculty and many of the best of the graduate students."<cite><a href="Sigma Xi.html">Sigma Xi</a></cite>
"Signs and Symptoms" began as "The newsletter of Brown University’s Program in Medicine" in February 1975, changed its subtitle to "The newsletter of Brown University’s Medical <a href="Education.html">Education</a> Program" in the second issue, and changed it again in 1979 to "A publication of the Brown University Medical <a href="Education.html">Education</a> Program," and in 1988 to "An alumni publication of the medical school at Brown University."<cite><a href="Signs and Symptoms.html">Signs and Symptoms</a></cite>
"Sir Brown," subtitled "A Magazine for Brown Men," made its first appearance with a trial number which came out in May of 1936.<cite><a href="Sir Brown.html">Sir Brown</a></cite>
In the issue of February 1938 the editors, marking the end of the second year of publication and ready to turn the magazine over to a new board, took stock of their achievements: "We have given you a different type of magazine than any you have previously been offered.<cite><a href="Sir Brown.html">Sir Brown</a></cite>
Publication of the magazine came to an end in March 1942.<cite><a href="Sir Brown.html">Sir Brown</a></cite>
Slater Hall was erected in 1879.<cite><a href="Slater Hall.html">Slater Hall</a></cite>
The house at 66 Benefit Street belonged in 1836, and perhaps earlier, to John Slater, the son of Samuel Slater, builder of the first cotton mill in the country.<cite><a href="Slater Memorial Homestead.html">Slater Memorial Homestead</a></cite>
The house was inherited by John’s nephew, Horatio Nelson Slater, and after his death purchased by his widow, who presented it in 1900 to the Women’s College as a memorial to her husband.<cite><a href="Slater Memorial Homestead.html">Slater Memorial Homestead</a></cite>
When <a href="Miller Hall.html">Miller Hall</a> was built in 1911, Slater Memorial Homestead was purchased by Miss Ewerette Constable McVickar and friends and presented to the Episcopal Diocese of Rhode Island as a memorial to her brother, Bishop William McVickar.<cite><a href="Slater Memorial Homestead.html">Slater Memorial Homestead</a></cite>
Charles Hugh Smiley (1903-1977), professor of astronomy, was born in Camden, Missouri, on September 6, 1903.<cite><a href="Smiley, Charles H..html">Smiley, Charles H.</a></cite>
Charles H. Smiley attended the University of California at Los Angeles and the University of California at Berkeley, graduating with highest honors in mathematics in 1924, and earned his M.A. degree in 1925 and his Ph.D. in mathematics in 1927 at Berkeley.<cite><a href="Smiley, Charles H..html">Smiley, Charles H.</a></cite>
From 1927 to 1929 Charles H. Smiley was an instructor in mathematics at the University of Illinois in Urbana-Champaign.<cite><a href="Smiley, Charles H..html">Smiley, Charles H.</a></cite>
Charles H. Smiley was a Guggenheim fellow in 1929-30, working at the Royal Greenwich Observatory and visiting other European observatories.<cite><a href="Smiley, Charles H..html">Smiley, Charles H.</a></cite>
Charles H. Smiley was appointed assistant professor of mathematics at Brown in 1930 and associate professor of astronomy in 1938, at which time he was also made director of the Ladd Observatory and chairman of the Department of Astronomy.<cite><a href="Smiley, Charles H..html">Smiley, Charles H.</a></cite>
Charles H. Smiley was promoted to full professor in 1945.<cite><a href="Smiley, Charles H..html">Smiley, Charles H.</a></cite>
On one occasion in 1963 Charles H. Smiley flew in a U.S. Air Force jet at 48,000 feet, racing the moon’s shadow to view a lunar eclipse longer than any other observer.<cite><a href="Smiley, Charles H..html">Smiley, Charles H.</a></cite>
Charles H. Smiley also led several expeditions between 1947 and 1952 to determine the atmospheric refraction at low angular altitudes.<cite><a href="Smiley, Charles H..html">Smiley, Charles H.</a></cite>
In 1949 Charles H. Smiley travelled to Point Barrow, Alaska, on a Navy plane, and later that year flew with an Air Force plane to the true North Pole.<cite><a href="Smiley, Charles H..html">Smiley, Charles H.</a></cite>
Charles H. Smiley wrote a popular column, "Planets and Stars," which appeared in the "Providence Journal" from 1938 to 1957.<cite><a href="Smiley, Charles H..html">Smiley, Charles H.</a></cite>
Charles H. Smiley was a member of the editorial advisory board of "Sky &amp; Telescope" from 1941 to 1959.<cite><a href="Smiley, Charles H..html">Smiley, Charles H.</a></cite>
Smiley viewed his last eclipse in Providence in 1974.<cite><a href="Smiley, Charles H..html">Smiley, Charles H.</a></cite>
Charles H. Smiley died in Providence on July 26, 1977, having been stricken while mowing his lawn.<cite><a href="Smiley, Charles H..html">Smiley, Charles H.</a></cite>
Hezekiah Smith (1737-1805), early supporter of the College, was born in Hampstead, Long Island, on April 21, 1737.<cite><a href="Smith, Hezekiah.html">Smith, Hezekiah</a></cite>
Hezekiah Smith attended Hopewell Academy and graduated from New Jersey College (Princeton) in 1762 in the same class as <a href="Manning, James.html">James Manning</a>.<cite><a href="Smith, Hezekiah.html">Smith, Hezekiah</a></cite>
After his graduation Hezekiah Smith traveled in the South for his health and was ordained in Charleston in September 1763.<cite><a href="Smith, Hezekiah.html">Smith, Hezekiah</a></cite>
In May 1765 Hezekiah Smith became the pastor of the Baptist Church in Haverhill, Massachusetts.<cite><a href="Smith, Hezekiah.html">Smith, Hezekiah</a></cite>
From October 1769 to June 1770 Hezekiah Smith made a trip to South Carolina and Georgia, preaching and receiving subscriptions for Rhode Island College.<cite><a href="Smith, Hezekiah.html">Smith, Hezekiah</a></cite>
Hezekiah Smith collected about $2500, most of which was used for the College Edifice.<cite><a href="Smith, Hezekiah.html">Smith, Hezekiah</a></cite>
Hezekiah Smith continued as pastor of his church in Haverhill until his death on January 22, 1805.<cite><a href="Smith, Hezekiah.html">Smith, Hezekiah</a></cite>
Kendall Kerfoot Smith (1882-1929), professor of Greek literature and history, was born in Fitchburg, Massachusetts, on September 24, 1882.<cite><a href="Smith, Kendall K..html">Smith, Kendall K.</a></cite>
Durfee High School in Fall River, and graduated from Harvard in 1904.<cite><a href="Smith, Kendall K..html">Smith, Kendall K.</a></cite>
Kendall K. Smith earned a master of arts degree at Harvard in 1906, studied at the American School of Classical Studies in Athens, and returned to Harvard to earn a Ph.D. degree in 1909.<cite><a href="Smith, Kendall K..html">Smith, Kendall K.</a></cite>
Kendall K. Smith taught the classics at Harvard from 1909 to 1915.<cite><a href="Smith, Kendall K..html">Smith, Kendall K.</a></cite>
In 1915 Kendall K. Smith came to Brown as assistant professor of Greek literature and history.<cite><a href="Smith, Kendall K..html">Smith, Kendall K.</a></cite>
Kendall K. Smith was promoted to associate professor in 1923 and David Benedict Professor of Greek literature and history in 1927, when he became the head of the Department of Greek and Latin Classics.<cite><a href="Smith, Kendall K..html">Smith, Kendall K.</a></cite>
Kendall K. Smith died on November 26, 1929 in Providence.<cite><a href="Smith, Kendall K..html">Smith, Kendall K.</a></cite>
The Smith <a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a> Center was opened in 1973, replacing the 70 year old Colgate Hoyt pool.<cite><a href="Smith Swimming Center.html">Smith Swimming Center</a></cite>
The building with prefabricated sides and a roof with circus-tent peaks was erected in seven weeks, a very short time, preceded by a very long time since 1943, when coach Joe Watmough was encouraged to come to Brown with the idea that a new swimming pool was soon to be built.<cite><a href="Smith Swimming Center.html">Smith Swimming Center</a></cite>
For want of a name, the new pool was called "the natatorium," until March 24, 1976, when the pool was dedicated and named for H. Stanton Smith ’21, a benefactor active in alumni affairs and his wife, Marjorie Brown Smith, who had been acting director of physical education at <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a>.<cite><a href="Smith Swimming Center.html">Smith Swimming Center</a></cite>
Smoke first appeared in May 1931, edited and printed by Winfield T. Scott ’31 and R. Wade Vliet ’33, with Professor S. Foster Damon as advisory editor.<cite><a href="Smoke.html">Smoke</a></cite>
After 1934 up to the last issue dated May-August 1937, early poems by such poets as Richard Blackmur, William Carlos Williams, Robert Hillyer, and Wallace Stevens appeared in "Smoke."<cite><a href="Smoke.html">Smoke</a></cite>
Walter Henry Snell (1889-1980), professor of botany, was born in West Bridgewater, Massachusetts, on May 19, 1889.<cite><a href="Snell, Walter H..html">Snell, Walter H.</a></cite>
Walter H. Snell was sold to the Boston Red Sox and played ball during the summer of 1913.<cite><a href="Snell, Walter H..html">Snell, Walter H.</a></cite>
After receiving his master of arts degree in 1916, Walter H. Snell continued his studies at the University of Wisconsin.<cite><a href="Snell, Walter H..html">Snell, Walter H.</a></cite>
Walter H. Snell worked as a forest pathologist with the Bureau of Plant Industry from 1918 to 1920.<cite><a href="Snell, Walter H..html">Snell, Walter H.</a></cite>
Walter H. Snell came to Brown as assistant professor in botany in February 1920, to replace Professor York, who had resigned.<cite><a href="Snell, Walter H..html">Snell, Walter H.</a></cite>
In addition to his botanical pursuits, between 1921 and 1940, Walter H. Snell coached 47 football, baseball, and basketball teams.<cite><a href="Snell, Walter H..html">Snell, Walter H.</a></cite>
Walter H. Snell retired from coaching in 1940, but was soon back into Brown athletics, this time having been recruited in January 1943 to replace athletic director Thomas Taylor, who had left for military service.<cite><a href="Snell, Walter H..html">Snell, Walter H.</a></cite>
Walter H. Snell kept the job until 1947, kept the athletic program alive, and after the war, helped to revive hockey, lacrosse, and wrestling, which had been dropped for financial reasons.<cite><a href="Snell, Walter H..html">Snell, Walter H.</a></cite>
In 1942 Walter H. Snell was named Stephen T. Olney Professor of Botany.<cite><a href="Snell, Walter H..html">Snell, Walter H.</a></cite>
Walter H. Snell's title was changed to Professor of Natural History in 1945.<cite><a href="Snell, Walter H..html">Snell, Walter H.</a></cite>
As an aid to teaching courses in mycology and forest pathology, Walter H. Snell began collecting mycological terms and in 1936 produced a list, "Three thousand Mycological Terms," which was typed by his assistant, Esther A. Dick ’31.<cite><a href="Snell, Walter H..html">Snell, Walter H.</a></cite>
Walter H. Snell's "Glossary of Mycology" was published in 1957.<cite><a href="Snell, Walter H..html">Snell, Walter H.</a></cite>
Although Snell retired in 1959, he never left the campus, but went right on working.<cite><a href="Snell, Walter H..html">Snell, Walter H.</a></cite>
The culmination of Walter H. Snell's work was "The Boleti of Northeastern North America," written with Esther Dick, and published in 1970.<cite><a href="Snell, Walter H..html">Snell, Walter H.</a></cite>
After the death of his first wife in 1975, Walter H. Snell married his long-term assistant, Esther Dick.<cite><a href="Snell, Walter H..html">Snell, Walter H.</a></cite>
Walter H. Snell died in Providence on July 23, 1980 at the age of 91.<cite><a href="Snell, Walter H..html">Snell, Walter H.</a></cite>
Louis Franklin Snow (1862-1934), first dean of the Women’s College, was born in Providence on April 19, 1862.<cite><a href="Snow, Louis F..html">Snow, Louis F.</a></cite>
Louis F. Snow graduated from Brown in 1887 with a degree of bachelor of philosophy, after which he earned a bachelor of arts degree and a master of arts degree from Harvard in 1889 and 1890.<cite><a href="Snow, Louis F..html">Snow, Louis F.</a></cite>
Louis F. Snow became instructor in elocution at Brown in 1890.<cite><a href="Snow, Louis F..html">Snow, Louis F.</a></cite>
In 1892 Louis F. Snow became at the request of President Andrews the first dean of the newly formed Women’s College.<cite><a href="Snow, Louis F..html">Snow, Louis F.</a></cite>
Louis F. Snow resigned in 1900 to do advanced work in education leading to the receipt of his Ph.D. degree from Columbia in 1903.<cite><a href="Snow, Louis F..html">Snow, Louis F.</a></cite>
From 1903 to 1905 Louis F. Snow was secretary-treasurer of the Examiner Company in New York and in 1905-06 he was registrar of Teacher’s College at Columbia.<cite><a href="Snow, Louis F..html">Snow, Louis F.</a></cite>
Louis F. Snow then had a number of educational appointments: Chairman of the English Department at the Normal School, Cortland, New York, 1908-09; Dean of Teacher’s College and professor of education, State University of Kentucky, 1909-1911; professor of philosophy and education, Wells College, 1911-12; librarian, University of Pittsburgh, 1912-1914; chief of the English Department and librarian, University of the Philippines, 1914-1918.<cite><a href="Snow, Louis F..html">Snow, Louis F.</a></cite>
After war work in Washington, he taught briefly at the State Normal School, Natchitoches, Louisiana, and at the University of Alabama, and in 1921 became professor of English at the University of Chattanooga, where he remained until his retirement in 1931.<cite><a href="Snow, Louis F..html">Snow, Louis F.</a></cite>
Louis F. Snow died in Chattanooga on December 26, 1934.<cite><a href="Snow, Louis F..html">Snow, Louis F.</a></cite>
Soccer made its first appearance at Brown in 1912 when the Athletic Board voted to purchase a soccer ball and to erect goal posts on <a href="Lincoln Field.html">Lincoln Field</a>.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
Soccer became an organized sport in 1925 with an informal team coached by basketball coach Harold Evans, which on November 14, lost its only game, 0-1, to the Pawtucket Y.M.C.A. Brown’s first official soccer coach, Samuel Fletcher, lasted for 21 seasons, before he resigned in 1946 to move to Florida.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
Brown’s first winning season came in 1933.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
Fletcher’s top season records were 6-1-1 in 1934, 6-0-2 in 1936 when William Margeson ’37 led the team to a New England Soccer League title (and personally scored three goals in Brown’s first victory over Yale), 8-1-2 in 1937 (the only loss was to West Point), and 6-1 in 1945.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
His 1945 team, with Costa Rican star Joseph Novas, lost only to Yale.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
The season ended with a 1-0 overtime defeat of M.I.T., but by that time the team was under the coaching of Joe Kennaway, who succeeded Fletcher on November 1, 1946.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
In 1956, Brown, with only a 3-3 record in the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a>, was undefeated by non-Ivy opponents and finished with also undefeated Trinity College at the top of the New England Soccer League.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
Kennaway coached until 1959, with a fourteen-year record of 44-71-10  Cliff Stevenson was the first full-time soccer coach.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
He arrived in 1960, in time to play on the new field on <a href="Aldrich-Dexter Field.html">Aldrich-Dexter Field</a> which he described as "the only field in the United States where if it rained real hard, you could put a ball on the field and watch it float across to the other side."<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
The grading of the field improved, and so did Stevenson’s teams, from 1-9 the first year to a 1963 record of 11-2-1 and a tie with Harvard for the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> championship, the first of six straight <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> titles for Brown.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
The 1963 team also went to the NCAA tournament where it was defeated by Army, 1-3, in the quarterfinals.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
The 1964 Ivy championship was shared with Dartmouth.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
The 1965 team had a 12-1-1 record, was undefeated in the League, and lost, 2-6, to Navy in the quarterfinals of the NCAA tournament.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
In 1966 the record was 11-1, and Brown beat Army for the first time.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
In 1966 Victor DeJong ’68 was the first Brown Player to make the National Soccer Coaches of America first All-American team.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
The 1967 record was 13-0-1 (the one tie was with the University of Pennsylvania), but Brown was still barred from the NCAA tournament.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
The next year Brown, undefeated in 26 games since a loss to Dartmouth in October 1964, lost to Penn in the second game of the 1968 season.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
The 1968 team did get to play in the tournament and after beating Fairleigh-Dickinson in the NCAA opener at Brown, defeated Army, 3-1, then lost to Michigan State, 0-2, in the semifinals at Georgia Tech’s field.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
Ben Brewster’s twelve goals and seven assists for the season brought his career goals to 33 (tying Alan Young’s 1961-1963 record) and his career point total of 50 to a Brown record.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
Charles "Chip" Young ’72 made the All-Ivy team three times from 1969 to 1971.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
Brown finished third in the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> in 1972, but it was a good year, as Brown won its first New England championship since 1968, and the team scored the most goals in a season, 57, and the most points, 93.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
In 1973, after winning the Ivy title, the team advanced to the semi-finals of the NCAA tournament by defeating UConn, 1-0, Yale, 2-1, and Hartwick, 1-0, all in sudden-death games, only to lose to St. Louis, 1-3, in the semifinals.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
The 1974 team won another Ivy title and was defeated by the University of Connecticut in the NCAA regional playoffs.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
In 1975 Brown shared the Ivy title with Cornell and won the New England title, defeating the University of Connecticut in a game with four sudden-death overtime periods, followed by three penalty shots by Tom Walsh ’76, Steve Milone ’ 80, and Fred Pereira ’77.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
The record for 1976 was 11-3-1 overall and 7-0 for Brown’s fourth consecutive <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> title, and it was UConn’s turn to defeat Brown, 1-0, in the NCAA regionals.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
In 1977 Brown played and miraculously defeated top-ranked Clemson, 2-1, in the NCAA quarterfinals, then lost to Hartwick, 1-4, in the semifinals.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
The 1987 team finished with an 8-7 record, the best since 1983, when the record was 10-4-1 overall with a second place (5-2) finish in the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a>.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
During Stevenson’s thirty-one years of coaching at Brown his record was 251-160-30, and his teams had 24 winning seasons, captured ten <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> and seven New England titles, and advanced to the NCAA playoffs thirteen times (eleven of them from 1968 to 1978), and to the semifinals four times, in 1968, 1973, 1975, and 1977.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
Brown placed second in the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> in 1981 and 1983, fourth in the EAIAW in 1981.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
The record of coach Trevor Adair’s first season in 1991 was 7-6-2 overall and 3-3-1 in the league.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
Soccer coaches at Brown have been Sam Fletcher from 1925 to 1946, Joe Kennaway from 1946 to 1959, Cliff Stevenson from 1960 to 1990, and Trevor Adair since 1991.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
After several unofficial seasons the women’s soccer team coached by Dom Starsia ’73 won two of five games in its first varsity season in 1975.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
The 1976 team finished 7-1, losing only to Yale, and the 1977 team, the first coached by Phil Pincince, improved on that, with a 13-1 season in which they outscored their opponents 50-14, and lost only to Lake Champlain College in the final round of the Castleton State Tournament.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
Women’s soccer became an <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> sport in 1978.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
Pincince’s teams won the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> championship in 1980, and every year from 1982 through 1990, tying with Princeton in 1982 and with Cornell in 1987.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
In 1990 the Brown team was ranked 13th in the country.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
The winning streak ended in 1991, when the team finished below the .500 mark for the first time in the history of women’s soccer at Brown.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
Brown has had three four-time All-Ivy choices, Colleen O’Day ’86 from 1982 to 1985, Theresa Hirschauer ’89 from 1985 to 1988, and Suzanne Bailey ’91 from 1987 to 1990.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
Two others were named three times, Frances Fusco ’83 from 1979 to 1981, and Michelle Mosher ’83 from 1980 to 1982.<cite><a href="Soccer.html">Soccer</a></cite>
Sociology first appeared in the curriculum in 1891 when the Department of <a href="History.html">History</a> and <a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a> added Social Science to its title and George Grafton Wilson 1886 was appointed associate professor of political and social science.<cite><a href="Sociology.html">Sociology</a></cite>
In 1895 James Quayle Dealey was appointed assistant professor of social and political science.<cite><a href="Sociology.html">Sociology</a></cite>
In 1906, when Lester F. Ward, already well known for his work on botany and geology and his pioneer work in sociology, expressed a desire to leave government service and devote time to his writing, he was invited to become professor of sociology at Brown.<cite><a href="Sociology.html">Sociology</a></cite>
Harold S. Bucklin ’10 became an instructor in social science in 1915 while he studied for his Ph.D.<cite><a href="Sociology.html">Sociology</a></cite>
In 1923-24 he participated in the <a href="Brown-in-China.html">Brown-in-China</a> program as professor of sociology at Shanghai College.<cite><a href="Sociology.html">Sociology</a></cite>
Harold A. Gibbard and Clarence Glick were instructors and later assistant professors of sociology from 1938 to 1946.<cite><a href="Sociology.html">Sociology</a></cite>
Bucklin became chairman of Sociology within the Department of <a href="Political Science.html">Political Science</a> and Sociology in 1946, and was chairman of the separate Department of Sociology which was created in 1947.<cite><a href="Sociology.html">Sociology</a></cite>
Vincent H. Whitney came in 1946, and succeeded Bucklin as chairman in 1948.<cite><a href="Sociology.html">Sociology</a></cite>
In the next few years the department was enlarged by the arrival of Kurt B. Mayer in 1950, Harold W. Pfautz in 1952, Sidney Goldstein in 1955, Basil G. Zimmer in 1959, and James M. Sakoda in 1962.<cite><a href="Sociology.html">Sociology</a></cite>
Graduate studies focusing on demography and ecology were initiated, and a Ph.D. program was authorized in 1952.<cite><a href="Sociology.html">Sociology</a></cite>
After the University acquired the <a href="Haffenreffer Museum.html">Haffenreffer Museum</a> in 1956, J. Louis Giddings, an Arctic archeologist, was appointed director of the museum and associate professor of sociology.<cite><a href="Sociology.html">Sociology</a></cite>
In 1959 the department was renamed Department of Sociology and <a href="Anthropology.html">Anthropology</a>, which it remained until <a href="Anthropology.html">Anthropology</a> became a separate department in 1970.<cite><a href="Sociology.html">Sociology</a></cite>
Kurt B. Mayer became chairman of the department in 1957, and was succeeded by Sidney Goldstein in 1963.<cite><a href="Sociology.html">Sociology</a></cite>
In the 1960s a third specialization in social organization was added.<cite><a href="Sociology.html">Sociology</a></cite>
The graduate program in demography began in 1952, and the first Ph.D. degree specializing in demography was awarded in 1958.<cite><a href="Sociology.html">Sociology</a></cite>
When other departments became interested in population issues, the Population Studies and Training Center was created in 1965, and has since become a multidisciplinary unit organized to facilitate research and training in demography, with a core faculty from the Department of Sociology.<cite><a href="Sociology.html">Sociology</a></cite>
Softball became a varsity sport in 1975.<cite><a href="Softball.html">Softball</a></cite>
Women were reported by the "<a href="Sepiad.html">Sepiad</a>" to be playing "baseball" in the fall of 1905.<cite><a href="Softball.html">Softball</a></cite>
The women students took up baseball more seriously in 1920, playing interclass games at the <a href="Metcalf Botanical Garden.html">Metcalf Botanical Garden</a>.<cite><a href="Softball.html">Softball</a></cite>
A "Providence Journal" article in 1922, headed "Women Students at Brown Adopt National Game ... Enthusiasm Makes Amends for Occasional Lack of Skill," noted, "For three years inter-class games have been played by the women students ...<cite><a href="Softball.html">Softball</a></cite>
Intercollegiate baseball for women began on May 12, 1928, when the "Providence Journal" announced, under "Pembroke Pounders and Wallopers from Wheaton to Clash in <a href="Baseball.html">Baseball</a>," that "Brown University will send an almost secretly organized Varsity baseball team to the Hope high school field ... to play against the Wheaton College nine."<cite><a href="Softball.html">Softball</a></cite>
<a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a> played softball against other New England colleges in the late 1940s, but the program waned in the 1950s and began to improve again in the 1960s.<cite><a href="Softball.html">Softball</a></cite>
Arlene Gorton coached from 1962 to 1975.<cite><a href="Softball.html">Softball</a></cite>
The 1975 team won seven and lost four, and the 1976 team, under Carole Kleinfelder, won eight and lost three.<cite><a href="Softball.html">Softball</a></cite>
Gail Klock’s teams in 1977 and 1978 had losing seasons.<cite><a href="Softball.html">Softball</a></cite>
When Phil Pincince took over the team in 1979, he changed the Brown softball team from what he termed a "recreational opportunity" to a competitive varsity sport, and built its schedule from its fifteen-game schedule of New England opponents to over forty games with top Eastern colleges.<cite><a href="Softball.html">Softball</a></cite>
After Pincince’s first two years Brown has had consecutive winning seasons since 1981, and the women’s softball team won the Ivy title in 1982, tied with Princeton in 1986, came in second in the league in 1988, and won the championship again in 1990.<cite><a href="Softball.html">Softball</a></cite>
Lisa Gawlak ’89 was selected for the All-Ivy team four times from 1986 to 1989, and Theresa Hirschauer ’89 three-times, in 1986, 1987, and 1989.<cite><a href="Softball.html">Softball</a></cite>
Soldiers Memorial Gate was dedicated on April 6, 1921, the fourth anniversary of the entry to the United States into the first World War.<cite><a href="Soldiers Memorial Gate.html">Soldiers Memorial Gate</a></cite>
With student singers in mind James A. DeWolf 1861 wrote for the "<a href="Brown Paper.html">Brown Paper</a>" of 1860 a song called "Old Brown," which was renamed "<a href="Alma Mater.html">Alma Mater</a>" in 1869, and is well known.<cite><a href="Songs.html">Songs</a></cite>
In 1891 John B. Barbour 1891, Edward B. Birge 1891, and Arthur H. Colby 1891 compiled "Songs of Brown University," a collection of songs, mostly written by the students.<cite><a href="Songs.html">Songs</a></cite>
When Alfred G. Chaffee ’02 and Ralph W. McPhee ’07 compiled another songbook with the same title in 1908, they included not only the songs about Brown, but also the old familiar tunes that Brown men sang.<cite><a href="Songs.html">Songs</a></cite>
Some of the songs written in celebration of Brown were "Mother Dear, <a href="Brunonia.html">Brunonia</a>" and "Hail, <a href="Brunonia.html">Brunonia</a>," both with words by Henry R. Palmer 1890, "On the <a href="Chapel.html">Chapel</a> Steps," by Joel N. Eno 1883 and George C. Gow 1884, "Bruno," by A. G. Chaffee ’02, "God Bless Our University," with words by Henry R. Palmer 1890 and music by Jules Jordan, and "Bring the Victory to Brown," by Donald Jackson ’09.<cite><a href="Songs.html">Songs</a></cite>
In 1921 another songbook, also entitled "Songs of Brown University" was edited by William T. Hastings ’03 and Thomas B. Appleget ’17.<cite><a href="Songs.html">Songs</a></cite>
Professor Walter G. Everett wrote a <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> song while he was at Aigle, Switzerland, during the <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> season of 1922.<cite><a href="Songs.html">Songs</a></cite>
It was first sung at <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> in 1923.<cite><a href="Songs.html">Songs</a></cite>
There were songs which were inspired by specific occasions at Brown, as the "Boating Song" by Adoniram Brown Judson 1859, a member of the first crew, and "The Water Procession," by Francis E. Bliss 1868 and Francis Lawton 1869, which commemorated the march downtown to get water when the bucket of the college well was removed by the authorities in 1867-68.<cite><a href="Songs.html">Songs</a></cite>
"Bylo," a song borrowed and arranged by Alfred G. Chafee ’02, appeared in the 1908 songbook, with this verse, "I bought a rooster for fifty cents, B-R-O-double-U-N, The son-of-a-gun jumped over the fence," followed by the chorus, "Bylo, my Baby, B-R-O-double U-N ..." and later, with other verses, became a popular party song.<cite><a href="Songs.html">Songs</a></cite>
The best known songs of Brown are:  <br />by Donald Jackson ’09  "I’m a Brown Man Born" was adapted from "I’m a Tar-Heel Born," a song of the University of North Carolina, which was brought back in 1903 by the Brown baseball team which had played two games with North Carolina in a pre-season Southern trip.<cite><a href="Songs.html">Songs</a></cite>
Included were "<a href="Alma Mater.html">Alma Mater</a>" by Marion F. Catlin ’12, "College Days" by Grace Sherwood ’06, "Our College" by Mildred C. Bishop ’12, and "What Shall We Sing of College Days" by Hilda R. Bronson ’13 to music by Frank M. Bronson 1884.<cite><a href="Songs.html">Songs</a></cite>
The next songbook of the same title was edited and compiled by Frances P. O’Connor ’17 in 1917.<cite><a href="Songs.html">Songs</a></cite>
New songs included in the new book were the "Class Song" of the Classes of 1916, 1917, and 1918, and a timely "Voting Song," with words by May Sperry ’18 and music by Rose Presel ’18.<cite><a href="Songs.html">Songs</a></cite>
The Sophomore Masque began in 1907.<cite><a href="Sophomore Masque.html">Sophomore Masque</a></cite>
The Women’s College Class of 1909 decided that year not to continue the "initiation ceremonies," which the sophomores had been accustomed to inflict upon the freshmen.<cite><a href="Sophomore Masque.html">Sophomore Masque</a></cite>
The Class of 1909 decided to initiate the tradition of a "Class Flower."<cite><a href="Sophomore Masque.html">Sophomore Masque</a></cite>
Since the color of the Class of 1909 was pink, the class flower selected was the rose, chosen in secret to be presented at a masque written by the sophomores, which told the story of a princess, who had been put to sleep by a witch and could be awakened only by one flower.<cite><a href="Sophomore Masque.html">Sophomore Masque</a></cite>
Members of the Class of 1909, as creators of the custom, received by vote of the Student Government Association in their senior year the privilege of attending any future sophomore masques.<cite><a href="Sophomore Masque.html">Sophomore Masque</a></cite>
The Class of 1911 presented a Japanese doll, and proceeded to include her as "Kiko-No Hana" among the class members in the 1911 "<a href="Brun Mael.html">Brun Mael</a>."<cite><a href="Sophomore Masque.html">Sophomore Masque</a></cite>
The mascot of the Class of 1915 was a professor’s daughter, four-year-old Janet Benedict, who appeared in person.<cite><a href="Sophomore Masque.html">Sophomore Masque</a></cite>
"Winged Victory" was the mascot of the Class of 1917.<cite><a href="Sophomore Masque.html">Sophomore Masque</a></cite>
The Class of 1918 introduced the Clintonian lily, which was the class flower as its mascot.<cite><a href="Sophomore Masque.html">Sophomore Masque</a></cite>
In 1918 the masque became part of the <a href="May Day.html">May Day</a> ceremonies.<cite><a href="Sophomore Masque.html">Sophomore Masque</a></cite>
The mascots became a feature of <a href="Spring Day.html">Spring Day</a> in 1922.<cite><a href="Sophomore Masque.html">Sophomore Masque</a></cite>
The presentation of the class flower was included in the masque until 1936.<cite><a href="Sophomore Masque.html">Sophomore Masque</a></cite>
The masque of 1937 was different, having as its subject the despair of the inhabitants of the world about the evils of civilization, presented five scenes (Politics, Domestic Dilemma, Recreation, Economic, Religion) and a sixth (Vision), which represented "the unclassifiable philosophers in whose minds the barriers between the preceding five phases have never existed," who are supposed to unite the world.<cite><a href="Sophomore Masque.html">Sophomore Masque</a></cite>
<a href="May Day.html">May Day</a> and the masque became features of the Mother-Daughter Weekend in the 1950s and continued to be held until 1967.<cite><a href="Sophomore Masque.html">Sophomore Masque</a></cite>
Alpha Beta Fraternity was established in 1893 "to promote the mental and moral development of its members and to further social intercourse."<cite><a href="Sororities.html">Sororities</a></cite>
It began by featuring extemporaneous speeches, the first ones being "The Repeal of the Silver Bill" by Mary Emma Woolley 1894, the first president of the fraternity, and "The Trouble in Morocco" by Martha Clarke 1895.<cite><a href="Sororities.html">Sororities</a></cite>
The fraternity soon turned its attention to Shakespearean plays, and in 1896, with the performance of "Twelfth Night," began the annual presentation of a play by Shakespeare.<cite><a href="Sororities.html">Sororities</a></cite>
After 1898 the performances, which had been attended by women only, were open to the public.<cite><a href="Sororities.html">Sororities</a></cite>
The next sorority was Delta Sigma, which was formed as a local organization in 1896, and merged in 1901 with another local society, Alpha Delta Sigma at Tufts.<cite><a href="Sororities.html">Sororities</a></cite>
The other sororities established were Alpha Epsilon chapter of Kappa Alpha Theta, which began as a local society called Tri Kappa, in 1897, Theta Lambda Tau in 1901, Beta Delta Phi for Catholic women in 1903, Gamma Delta in 1903, Zeta Zeta Zeta in 1905, and Kappa chapter of Sigma Kappa in 1908.<cite><a href="Sororities.html">Sororities</a></cite>
In 1911 the Executive Committee, conceding that "the existence of fraternities was helpful during the earlier years of this College," now found them "deleterious to the welfare of the College," and expressing the opinion that in future organizations "students should be grouped not along lines of social cleavage, but on the basis of definite interests and purposes," voted that the fraternities in the Women’s College should henceforth admit no new members.<cite><a href="Sororities.html">Sororities</a></cite>
Sororities did not reappear on campus until 1974, when fourteen black women undergraduates.<cite><a href="Sororities.html">Sororities</a></cite>
In 1979 eleven women who had joined together to form a sorority decided to affiliate with Alpha Chi Omega, and conducted a "rush week," during which representatives of the national organization were on hand in the Crystal Room in <a href="Alumnae Hall.html">Alumnae Hall</a> to recruit pledges.<cite><a href="Sororities.html">Sororities</a></cite>
Alpha Chi Omega died out in 1983, but was revived the next year.<cite><a href="Sororities.html">Sororities</a></cite>
A chapter of the national Kappa Alpha Theta fraternity was formed in 1983 by nine women students who were joined by other members in cluster housing in Sears House for a year before being given housing in Diman House.<cite><a href="Sororities.html">Sororities</a></cite>
The Sphinx Club was started in March of 1904 by a group of students who desired an organization which would afford an opportunity for the discussion of intellectual problems.<cite><a href="Sphinx Club.html">Sphinx Club</a></cite>
The charter members of the club held their first meeting on March 31, 1904, with Faunce, Meiklejohn, and Professors Lindsay Todd Damon and Walter C. Bronson in attendance.<cite><a href="Sphinx Club.html">Sphinx Club</a></cite>
The name did not suit all of the members, so on January 31, 1905, when the club was nearly a year old, it was given its new name, "The Sphinx."<cite><a href="Sphinx Club.html">Sphinx Club</a></cite>
A ritual of initiation prepared by Professor Sharon Brown and first used on May 25, 1926, began, "The Sphinx invites you to hear her riddles," and ended, "In the solving of her riddles may you find the Truth.<cite><a href="Sphinx Club.html">Sphinx Club</a></cite>
When Arthur Upham Pope went to the University of California in 1911 as assistant professor of philosophy, he started a Sphinx Club on that campus.<cite><a href="Sphinx Club.html">Sphinx Club</a></cite>
The Sphinx Club became inactive in 1976.<cite><a href="Sphinx Club.html">Sphinx Club</a></cite>
When it was reactivated in 1984 by Bruce Donovan ’59, at that time <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> of Freshmen and Sophomores, the student members were the Meiklejohn Advisors, upperclass advisors to freshmen, and the faculty members were the Academic Advisors for Liberal <a href="Education.html">Education</a>.<cite><a href="Sphinx Club.html">Sphinx Club</a></cite>
As the "Brown Daily Herald" of March 26, 1902 remarked, "This term is the time for many seniors to make their work as light as possible and to thoroughly enjoy the remainder of their course."<cite><a href="Spring Day.html">Spring Day</a></cite>
Among the mascots of Spring Day have been: in 1914, "September Morn" draped in a barrel; in 1918, a Liberty Loan bond of the third issue; in 1920, a plaster ship labelled "Reconstruction" depicting a senior in cap and gown at the steering oar and a chained Bolshevist in the seat; in 1921, Charles Evans Hughes 1881 riding a "G.O.P." elephant; in 1932, a scene in which a chart of "Brown Securities, Ltd." showed a marked decline in student activities, while a figure labelled "Student Publications" pointed a pistol at his head, one with a lyre labelled "Glee Club" jumped through a window, and the Brown bear lay dead with his feet in the air (The cause of this debacle seemed to be the sign on the <a href="President.html">President</a>’s Office which read "Gone to China," as indeed he had); in 1933, a plaque on which an infant holding a pen rode Pegasus in combat with a soldier on a tank in front of the State House, while a Communist "boogeyman" loomed in the background – a commentary on the State’s reaction to the peace campaign which had been conducted by the "Brown Daily Herald."<cite><a href="Spring Day.html">Spring Day</a></cite>
In 1934 there were two Spring Day plaques, one showing the college infirmary full of suffering students, the other a desk clerk at the John Hay <a href="Library.html">Library</a> with a stop watch, the better to charge fines.<cite><a href="Spring Day.html">Spring Day</a></cite>
Spring Day exercises became part of Junior Weekend in 1935 and continued to be until <a href="World War II.html">World War II</a> intervened.<cite><a href="Spring Day.html">Spring Day</a></cite>
The Women’s College had its own Spring Day, initiated by the Class of 1922.<cite><a href="Spring Day.html">Spring Day</a></cite>
The festivities consisted of a breakfast followed by chapel exercises at which acting dean Anne Crosby Emery Allinson, honorary member of the Class of 1922, and Alfred H. Jones, chosen "favorite professor," spoke.<cite><a href="Spring Day.html">Spring Day</a></cite>
Women students ceased the observance of Spring Day in 1963.<cite><a href="Spring Day.html">Spring Day</a></cite>
Spring Weekend began in 1950, having evolved from the "All-<a href="Campus.html">Campus</a> Weekend," which had in 1948 replaced the longstanding <a href="Junior Week.html">Junior Week</a> and Junior Prom, which had lapsed during <a href="World War II.html">World War II</a>.<cite><a href="Spring Weekend.html">Spring Weekend</a></cite>
The 1950 weekend began on Friday with the inter-fraternity sing and the Hilltoppers Ball with the tapping of the new <a href="Brown Key.html">Brown Key</a> members, which had formerly been a feature of the junior prom.<cite><a href="Spring Weekend.html">Spring Weekend</a></cite>
In the 1960s concerts by celebrities took the place of the dances, and the <a href="Brown Key.html">Brown Key</a> tapping took place during the intermission.<cite><a href="Spring Weekend.html">Spring Weekend</a></cite>
Among the Spring Weekend performers were Ella Fitzgerald and Bo Diddley in 1965 and Janis Joplin, whose concert was crashed by 50 persons with forged tickets, in 1969.<cite><a href="Spring Weekend.html">Spring Weekend</a></cite>
In 1967 Peter, Paul and Mary sang, and Martin Luther King, coincidentally in Providence on other business, preached at the Sunday Protestant service in <a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a>.<cite><a href="Spring Weekend.html">Spring Weekend</a></cite>
In 1970 the entertainment was provided by Jefferson Airplane, Ray Charles, and Judy Collins and the preaching by William Sloane Coffin.<cite><a href="Spring Weekend.html">Spring Weekend</a></cite>
Drinking, always a traditional part of Spring Weekend, prompted the University in 1984 to provide an added service, off-duty state troopers who offered optional breathalyzer tests as a guide to responsible imbibing.<cite><a href="Spring Weekend.html">Spring Weekend</a></cite>
Squash was a club sport in the 1960s without official recognition by the University.<cite><a href="Squash.html">Squash</a></cite>
In fact, the plan for the new athletic complex in 1967-68 dropped squash courts from the plan.<cite><a href="Squash.html">Squash</a></cite>
Squash had been played informally in the 1930s, when teams played in a league composed of the University Club, the Hope Club, and the Agawam Hunt Club, which was later joined by a team of doctors from Rhode Island Hospital.<cite><a href="Squash.html">Squash</a></cite>
Two Brown teams were members of the Rhode Island Squash Association League in the 1950s.<cite><a href="Squash.html">Squash</a></cite>
In 1962-63 Harvard’s freshman coach gave instruction at Brown, and a club tournament was held.<cite><a href="Squash.html">Squash</a></cite>
In 1969 the club had 120 members and Gonzales was ranked eighth in the nation by the Intercollegiate Squash Racquets Association.<cite><a href="Squash.html">Squash</a></cite>
After a lapse, squash was reinstituted in 1984 as a "club-varsity" sport.<cite><a href="Squash.html">Squash</a></cite>
Varsity competition began in 1989, with <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> competition scheduled for 1990.<cite><a href="Squash.html">Squash</a></cite>
In 1991 the men’s squash team was ranked thirteenth in the nation.<cite><a href="Squash.html">Squash</a></cite>
Stuart LeGassick, who has coached the team since 1989 has a three-year record of 28-30 overall and 2-15 in the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a>.<cite><a href="Squash.html">Squash</a></cite>
Women students coached by Jan Lutz played squash in Marvel Gym in the early 1970s and had games with teams from the Pawtucket and Cranston YMCA’s.<cite><a href="Squash.html">Squash</a></cite>
In 1976 a group of women students, some of whom had played tennis, made up a squash team coached by Karen Melucci.<cite><a href="Squash.html">Squash</a></cite>
By 1977 Brown’s four top women players went to the National Intercollegiate Squash Championships.<cite><a href="Squash.html">Squash</a></cite>
Karen Melucci coached until 1979, and was followed by Peter Wood in 1979-80, and Paul Moses from 1980 to 1985.<cite><a href="Squash.html">Squash</a></cite>
The best years for women’s squash were 1980-81 (7-4), 1981-82 (7-4), and 1986-87 (8-2).<cite><a href="Squash.html">Squash</a></cite>
The team finished fourth in the Howe Cup Tournament in 1986 and was sixth in the nation in 1991.<cite><a href="Squash.html">Squash</a></cite>
Coach Norma Taylor’s record from 1985 to 1989 was 37-18; Stuart LeGassick’s from 1989 to 1992 was 12-17 overall and 5-8 in the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a>.<cite><a href="Squash.html">Squash</a></cite>
Sue Cutler ’88 was a four-time All-Ivy team choice from 1985 to 1988.<cite><a href="Squash.html">Squash</a></cite>
The Stadium on Elmgrove Avenue opened in 1925.<cite><a href="Stadium.html">Stadium</a></cite>
An all-home game schedule was arranged for 1925.<cite><a href="Stadium.html">Stadium</a></cite>
At Stadium Day in October 1950, <a href="President.html">President</a> Wriston repeated the lines of dedication in observation of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Stadium, an event attended by fifteen of the captains of the teams which played in the Stadium during its first 25 years.<cite><a href="Stadium.html">Stadium</a></cite>
He also initiated in 1944 dinners attended by local newspapermen, coaches and university officers to improve relations with the press.<cite><a href="Stadium.html">Stadium</a></cite>
In 1965, to conform with standards of the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a>, the scoreboard was redesigned by the Providence Electric Company in honor of the Samuel D. and Murray A. Cohen family.<cite><a href="Stadium.html">Stadium</a></cite>
In the summer of 1971 a new six-lane rubberized track of uniform width (the old one varied in width) was installed around the football field at an estimated cost of $40,000.<cite><a href="Stadium.html">Stadium</a></cite>
New aluminum seats were installed in 1979 at a cost of $90,000.<cite><a href="Stadium.html">Stadium</a></cite>
In 1985 the press box was named for Jay Barry ’50.<cite><a href="Stadium.html">Stadium</a></cite>
The Steward is mentioned in the Laws of the College in 1783 and his duties are described in detail there.<cite><a href="Steward.html">Steward</a></cite>
An attempt to correct this situation was made in 1802 by the appointment of a committee "for digesting a new plan for the Stewards department."<cite><a href="Steward.html">Steward</a></cite>
The new plan, reported on October 13, 1802, provided that $400 a year be allowed to the steward, who would now in addition to furnishing commons, take entire charge of the college buildings and grounds.<cite><a href="Steward.html">Steward</a></cite>
The first steward, Josias Arnold (1770 to 1773), was followed by William Holroyd (1773 to 1782) and Peregrine Foster (1782 to 1784).<cite><a href="Steward.html">Steward</a></cite>
In 1784-85 the position was occupied by a woman, Martha Eddy, widow of Richard Eddy, who served briefly in 1784.<cite><a href="Steward.html">Steward</a></cite>
Jesse Bolles served from 1803 to 1812, and Joseph Cady from 1812 to 1826.<cite><a href="Steward.html">Steward</a></cite>
In 1828 the office of register was created and Lemuel Elliott, who had begun his nearly forty years of service two years earlier, added the duties of that position to those of the steward.<cite><a href="Steward.html">Steward</a></cite>
The title of steward was dropped after Elliott’s retirement in 1864.<cite><a href="Steward.html">Steward</a></cite>
In 1884 a separate position of caretaker of buildings and grounds was created, to which Archibald G. Delaney was appointed, and the title of steward, though a misnomer for the new position, was revived.<cite><a href="Steward.html">Steward</a></cite>
Delaney was the steward until 1904, after which the position passed to Edwin Aylsworth Burlingame with the title of Superintendent of Buildings and Grounds.<cite><a href="Steward.html">Steward</a></cite>
Randall Stewart (1896-1964), professor of English, was born in Fayetteville, Tennessee, on July 25, 1896.<cite><a href="Stewart, Randall.html">Stewart, Randall</a></cite>
Randall Stewart received a bachelor of science degree from Vanderbilt University in 1917, a master of arts from Harvard in 1921, and a Ph.D. from Yale in 1930.<cite><a href="Stewart, Randall.html">Stewart, Randall</a></cite>
Randall Stewart taught at the University of Oklahoma from 1917 to 1920, and again in 1921-22, after a year as instructor at the United States Naval Academy.<cite><a href="Stewart, Randall.html">Stewart, Randall</a></cite>
Randall Stewart was assistant professor of English at the University of Idaho from 1923 to 1925, instructor at Yale from 1926 to 1931 and assistant professor from 1931 to 1934, and professor of English at Vanderbilt from 1934 until he came to Brown in 1937 with an appointment as full professor of English.<cite><a href="Stewart, Randall.html">Stewart, Randall</a></cite>
Randall Stewart published a biography of Hawthorne in 1948, was general editor of an anthology, "The Literature of the South" in 1952, and co-editor of "Masterpieces of English Literature" and "Masterpieces of American Literature."<cite><a href="Stewart, Randall.html">Stewart, Randall</a></cite>
In 1955 Randall Stewart left Brown for Vanderbilt University.<cite><a href="Stewart, Randall.html">Stewart, Randall</a></cite>
Randall Stewart taught at Vanderbilt until 1963.<cite><a href="Stewart, Randall.html">Stewart, Randall</a></cite>
Randall Stewart died on June 17, 1964.<cite><a href="Stewart, Randall.html">Stewart, Randall</a></cite>
Margaret Bingham Stillwell (1887-1984), librarian of the Annmary Brown Memorial, was born in Providence on January 26, 1887.<cite><a href="Stillwell, Margaret B..html">Stillwell, Margaret B.</a></cite>
Margaret B. Stillwell resided on Benefit Street and entered the Women’s College in 1905.<cite><a href="Stillwell, Margaret B..html">Stillwell, Margaret B.</a></cite>
Margaret B. Stillwell graduated in 1909, and was editor of "Brun Mael," the Women’s College yearbook which appeared for the first time in that year.<cite><a href="Stillwell, Margaret B..html">Stillwell, Margaret B.</a></cite>
Margaret B. Stillwell continued her work at the John Carter Brown Library until 1914, when she left for the New York Public Library, where she was a cataloger in the rare book division until 1917.<cite><a href="Stillwell, Margaret B..html">Stillwell, Margaret B.</a></cite>
From 1917 to 1953 Margaret B. Stillwell was curator of the Annmary Brown Memorial Library, while it was a private library and after it was deeded to Brown in 1948, at which time she joined the University staff as a full professor.<cite><a href="Stillwell, Margaret B..html">Stillwell, Margaret B.</a></cite>
Margaret B. Stillwell's many publications included "Incunabula and Americana, 1450-1800, A Key to Bibliographic Study" in 1931, and "Incunabula in American Libraries, A Second Census."<cite><a href="Stillwell, Margaret B..html">Stillwell, Margaret B.</a></cite>
Margaret B. Stillwell also wrote a book of verse, "Noah’s Ark in Early Woodcuts and Modern Rhyme," in 1942.<cite><a href="Stillwell, Margaret B..html">Stillwell, Margaret B.</a></cite>
Margaret B. Stillwell continued her campaign with the publication in 1945 of "The Pageant of Benefit Street."<cite><a href="Stillwell, Margaret B..html">Stillwell, Margaret B.</a></cite>
Margaret B. Stillwell was the first honorary woman member of the Grolier Club, elected in January 1977.<cite><a href="Stillwell, Margaret B..html">Stillwell, Margaret B.</a></cite>
Margaret B. Stillwell died on April 22, 1984.<cite><a href="Stillwell, Margaret B..html">Stillwell, Margaret B.</a></cite>
Merton Philip Stoltz (1913-1989), provost and acting president of Brown University, was born in Glidden, Wisconsin, on March 28, 1913.<cite><a href="Stoltz, Merton P..html">Stoltz, Merton P.</a></cite>
Merton P. Stoltz graduated from the University of Minnesota in 1934 and earned a master’s degree at Brown in 1936.<cite><a href="Stoltz, Merton P..html">Stoltz, Merton P.</a></cite>
After earning his Ph.D. at Minnesota in 1941, Merton P. Stoltz returned to Brown as assistant professor of economics.<cite><a href="Stoltz, Merton P..html">Stoltz, Merton P.</a></cite>
Merton P. Stoltz was named full professor in 1950.<cite><a href="Stoltz, Merton P..html">Stoltz, Merton P.</a></cite>
Merton P. Stoltz was chairman of the Department of Economics from 1956 to 1964, associate dean of the Graduate School from 1960 to 1964, and dean of the University from 1964 to 1966.<cite><a href="Stoltz, Merton P..html">Stoltz, Merton P.</a></cite>
One of the first acts of President Heffner on his arrival was to appoint Stoltz provost of the University, a post which had been vacant since June of 1965.<cite><a href="Stoltz, Merton P..html">Stoltz, Merton P.</a></cite>
Merton P. Stoltz was three times acting president of Brown, serving in 1969-70 between the presidencies of Heffner and Hornig, in the summer of 1972 while President Hornig recovered from a heart attack, and in 1976 between the presidencies of Hornig and Swearer.<cite><a href="Stoltz, Merton P..html">Stoltz, Merton P.</a></cite>
Merton P. Stoltz retired in 1978.<cite><a href="Stoltz, Merton P..html">Stoltz, Merton P.</a></cite>
As an economist Stoltz was chosen to head the Special Providence Committee on Municipal Revenue in 1957 and served on the Rhode Island Fiscal Study Commission in 1961.<cite><a href="Stoltz, Merton P..html">Stoltz, Merton P.</a></cite>
Tougaloo College awarded him an honorary LL.D. degree in 1977, and at Brown’s Commencement that year he received a standing ovation on the announcement by President Swearer of the establishment of the Merton P. Stoltz Professorship.<cite><a href="Stoltz, Merton P..html">Stoltz, Merton P.</a></cite>
Brown awarded him an honorary LL.D. degree in 1978.<cite><a href="Stoltz, Merton P..html">Stoltz, Merton P.</a></cite>
Merton P. Stoltz died on August 7, 1989 in Providence.<cite><a href="Stoltz, Merton P..html">Stoltz, Merton P.</a></cite>
Charles Arthur Stuart (1893-1962), professor of biology, was born in Lyon Mountain in northern New York on May 26, 1893.<cite><a href="Stuart, Charles A..html">Stuart, Charles A.</a></cite>
Charles A. Stuart entered Brown in 1914, childhood illness making him a little older than the usual freshman.<cite><a href="Stuart, Charles A..html">Stuart, Charles A.</a></cite>
He became interested in bacteriology after striking up an acquaintance through the basement window of Arnold Lab with Percy Meader 1914, who worked there evenings as a graduate student of bacteriologist <a href="Gorham, Frederic P..html">Frederic P. Gorham</a> and invited Stuart to join him.<cite><a href="Stuart, Charles A..html">Stuart, Charles A.</a></cite>
After World War I service with the Brown University unit of the United States Ambulance Corps, Stuart returned to graduate in 1919 as a member of the class of 1918.<cite><a href="Stuart, Charles A..html">Stuart, Charles A.</a></cite>
Charles A. Stuart stayed on to receive his master of science degree in 1919 and his Ph.D. in 1923.<cite><a href="Stuart, Charles A..html">Stuart, Charles A.</a></cite>
Appointed instructor in 1923, Charles A. Stuart was promoted to assistant professor in 1925, associate professor in 1931, and professor in 1944.<cite><a href="Stuart, Charles A..html">Stuart, Charles A.</a></cite>
In 1949 Charles A. Stuart was named the Robert P. Brown Professor of Biology.<cite><a href="Stuart, Charles A..html">Stuart, Charles A.</a></cite>
Beginning in 1925, Charles A. Stuart also gave lectures in bacteriology and immunology at the Rhode Island Hospital School of Nursing.<cite><a href="Stuart, Charles A..html">Stuart, Charles A.</a></cite>
Charles A. Stuart continued to work there after his retirement in 1960.<cite><a href="Stuart, Charles A..html">Stuart, Charles A.</a></cite>
Charles A. Stuart died on October 17, 1962 in Providence.<cite><a href="Stuart, Charles A..html">Stuart, Charles A.</a></cite>
In 1774 four delinquent students, John Hart 1776, Daniel Gano 1776, William Edwards 1776, and Walter Vigneron 1776, were publicly admonished for various "crimes," as being absent during study hours, spending time in idle entertainment, making noise, and moving a carpenter’s bench into the entry of the College Edifice.<cite><a href="Student conduct.html">Student conduct</a></cite>
Hart was the son of Reverend Oliver Hart, who had been awarded an honorary degree at the first <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> in 1769.<cite><a href="Student conduct.html">Student conduct</a></cite>
In the laws enacted by the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> in 1783, Chapter 3d, ("Concerning a religious, moral &amp; decent conduct") were the following rules: This last rule was revised in the 1803 laws to specify as unnecessary noises, "running violently, hallooing, or rolling things in the entries or down the stairs."<cite><a href="Student conduct.html">Student conduct</a></cite>
In 1817 <a href="President.html">President</a> Asa Messer was forced to to discipline eight students for burning the privy, noting that it was "not a small thing to alarm in the night, and by the cry of fire 10 to 12 thousand People."<cite><a href="Student conduct.html">Student conduct</a></cite>
In 1824 Messer felt that it was the result of his own theological quarrel with members of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> that "During our last spring and summer terms unusual disorder prevailed among out students.<cite><a href="Student conduct.html">Student conduct</a></cite>
Francis Wayland, succeeding Messer as president in 1827, revived the law that officers of the college must visit students daily in their rooms, and report all infractions of rules.<cite><a href="Student conduct.html">Student conduct</a></cite>
The student handbook in 1916 included notes on "College Courtesy" for the guidance of freshmen, who were reminded that "the same things are expected of a gentleman at Brown that are expected anywhere else; the fact that you have come to live in a society made up almost entirely of men does not alter the circumstances."<cite><a href="Student conduct.html">Student conduct</a></cite>
In the matter of student discipline the <a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a> became a link between the administration and the students, and was in 1922 credited by <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> Otis Randall for its assistance in "dealing with perplexing problems which are bound to arise frequently whenever two branches of a great organization look at conditions from widely differing standpoints."<cite><a href="Student conduct.html">Student conduct</a></cite>
In 1947 a Special Undergraduate Committee on Student Regulations which represented the <a href="Cammarian Club.html">Cammarian Club</a> and the Interfraternity Governing Board, working with the <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> of Students, formulated a "Gentlemen’s Agreement" for the purpose of governing the conduct of undergraduate students.<cite><a href="Student conduct.html">Student conduct</a></cite>
In 1966 an Advisory Committee on Student Conduct, appointed by <a href="President.html">President</a> Heffner and chaired by Professor C. Peter Magrath, recommended that matters of discipline be referred to a University Council on Student Affairs, which would include deans, faculty, the <a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a>, and students.<cite><a href="Student conduct.html">Student conduct</a></cite>
Another committee, appointed by <a href="President.html">President</a> Swearer and chaired by Rhode Island Supreme Court Justice Alfred H. Joslin ’35, reviewed the system in 1979-80, and decided that minor offenses should be handled by the deans and major offenses by the USCA.<cite><a href="Student conduct.html">Student conduct</a></cite>
This traditional "smoking-out" was popular in the 1850s and inspired a poem by John Hay, which was actually a parody of Ralph Waldo Emerson’s poem "Brahma," which had appeared in November 1857 in the first issue of the "Atlantic Monthly".<cite><a href="Student customs.html">Student customs</a></cite>
On May 9, 1962 there occurred a student disturbance that rivalled the tunnel riot.<cite><a href="Student customs.html">Student customs</a></cite>
In 1973 the object desired for a football game was Harvard’s Big-H drum.<cite><a href="Student customs.html">Student customs</a></cite>
Student Housing became available with the completion in 1772 of the second floor of <a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a>, where the students took up residence above their classrooms.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
When increased enrollment called for more dormitory rooms, <a href="Hope College.html">Hope College</a> was built in 1822.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
<a href="Slater Hall.html">Slater Hall</a> opened in 1879 and in 1895 <a href="Maxcy Hall.html">Maxcy Hall</a> was built to house both classrooms and dormitory rooms.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
<a href="Caswell Hall.html">Caswell Hall</a> was built in 1903.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
Dormitories of a temporary nature were put into use in 1892 with the opening of houses at 96 George Street with fifteen rooms and at 21 Brown Street with five rooms.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
In 1894 the house at 96 George Street was named Messer House, the house on Benevolent Street was named Pease House, and an additional dormitory next to Messer House was named Maxcy House.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
Pease House was not listed as a residence after 1897.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
In 1899 the "College Street House" with five rooms was added.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
<a href="Brunonia.html">Brunonia</a> Hall (now <a href="Richardson Hall.html">Richardson Hall</a>) was built in 1900 as a privately operated dormitory and acquired by the University in 1920.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
<a href="Hegeman Hall.html">Hegeman Hall</a> and <a href="Littlefield Hall.html">Littlefield Hall</a> were added in 1926.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
Students furnished their own rooms in a variety of styles until 1935, when all dormitories were furnished by the University.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
George House at 36 George Street was acquired in 1937.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
In 1939 a portion of the graduate dormitory, formerly occupied by Lambda Chi Alpha, was demolished to make room for the John Hay <a href="Library.html">Library</a> addition, and its residents were housed at a University owned building at 34 Olive Street.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
In the 1890s there was an informal dormitory for women at the corner of Waterman and Gano Streets.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
<a href="Slater Memorial Homestead.html">Slater Memorial Homestead</a> was donated for the use of women in 1900.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
<a href="Miller Hall.html">Miller Hall</a>, the first on-campus women’s dormitory, was built in 1910.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
East House on Meeting Street was acquired in 1912, the gift of Stephen O. Metcalf, and was used as a dormitory of the Women’s College.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
East House was closed when enrollment dropped in the early 1930s, but was opened again in 1935.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
The building was razed in 1952 to make room for the installation of <a href="Howard Terrace.html">Howard Terrace</a>.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
Wallace House on Cushing Street was a private boarding-house before it was purchased in 1914 and renovated for use as a cooperative dormitory.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
Bates House on Olive Street was bequeathed to the Women’s College by Isaac C. Bates in 1913.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
<a href="Metcalf Hall.html">Metcalf Hall</a> was built opposite <a href="Miller Hall.html">Miller Hall</a> in 1919, and these two buildings were joined to the newly built <a href="Andrews Hall.html">Andrews Hall</a> in 1947.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
Sharpe House at 130 Angell Street was acquired in 1921 and opened to fourteen women students in 1923.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
McVickar House (the other half of Sharpe House, numbered 132 Angell Street) was acquired in 1925, the gift of Stephen O. Metcalf, and was used as a dormitory of the Women’s College.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
In 1960 it became the headquarters of the <a href="Education.html">Education</a> Department.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
In 1933 the women’s dormitory at 215 Bowen Street became a cooperative house managed by the students and Sharpe House became a self-help house, where students performed work in exchange for reduced board payments.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
Angell House at 15 Keene Street, the former home of Walter Angell 1880, was given by Stephen O. Metcalf in 1938 and used as a <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a> dormitory.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
