Two dormitories were taken over for use as offices when the reconstruction of <a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a> was begun in 1939.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
During <a href="World War II.html">World War II</a>, fraternity houses at 65 Prospect Street and 96 Waterman Street were put to use as women’s dormitories in 1943.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
In 1946-47 women were also living in Allinson House (named for <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> Anne Crosby Emery Allinson) at 48 Lloyd Avenue, Appleton House at 71-73 Brown Street, and King House (named for <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> Lida Shaw King), at 34 Barnes Street.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
In 1949-50 Whittier House at 171 Meeting Street replaced Appleton House.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
A dormitory at 15 Benevolent Street was named Russell House in honor of Jonathan Russell 1791 in 1946.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
It was renamed <a href="Ames House.html">Ames House</a> in 1956.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
Also pressed into service were <a href="Adams House.html">Adams House</a> at 10-12 George Street, (named for Vice-<a href="President.html">President</a> James P. Adams), Hopkins House (the old "Arsdale" at 53 Waterman Street and named for Chancellor Stephen Hopkins), and <a href="Judson House.html">Judson House</a>, the former property of the Sisters of the Holy Nativity at 117-119 George Street (named for Adoniram Judson 1807).<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
Edwards House was the name given in honor of Morgan Edwards to the former <a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a> House at the corner of Brook and George Streets in 1947, when it became an undergraduate dormitory.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
In 1951 upperclass women lived in Andrews, Miller, and Metcalf Halls; Bates House was a cooperative house, and freshmen lived in Allinson, Angell, East, Sharpe and Whittier Houses.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
In 1953-53 Snow House at 156 Meeting Street, named for <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> Louis Franklin Snow, was added as a freshman house, and in 1954-55 Mary Emma Woolley House (named for one of the first women graduates) was opened for freshmen and sophomores at 99 Brown St.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
The next year Mary Woolley House and Stanton House (named for Emma Bradford Stanton 1896) at 85 Brown Street were upperclass dormitories and Snow House became one in 1956.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
After <a href="Champlin and Morriss Halls.html">Champlin and Morriss Halls</a> were opened in 1960, Sharpe House, Stanton House, Snow House, and King House were no longer occupied.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
<a href="Emery and Woolley Halls.html">Emery and Woolley Halls</a> completed the Pembroke Quadrangle in 1963.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
The fraternities continued to occupy their houses until the early 1950s, when the houses were deeded to the University in exchanged for quarters in the new residential quadrangle, later named <a href="Wriston Quadrangle.html">Wriston Quadrangle</a>, which opened in 1951.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
In 1957 the <a href="Keeney Quadrangle.html">Keeney Quadrangle</a> provided six more dormitories.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
Several dormitories for men were acquired with the purchase of the <a href="Bryant College.html">Bryant College</a> campus in 1969.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
In 1971 two new cooperative houses on Charles Field Street were opened.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
Fifty-seven Pembroke freshmen moved into the top two floors of Diman House in the <a href="Wriston Quadrangle.html">Wriston Quadrangle</a> in the fall of 1969, making it the first coeducational dormitory at Brown.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
<a href="President.html">President</a> Swearer, in his annual Hour with the <a href="President.html">President</a> in 1982, replied to the question, "Do co-ed dorms create problems or solve them?<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
I would have to say ‘yes.’"  Three apartment-style buildings for 168 students were built on Young Orchard Avenue in 1973.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
<a href="New Pembroke.html">New Pembroke</a> with rooms for 200 students was built on Thayer Street in 1974.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
In the fall of 1991 the Thayer Street Quadrangle, designed by Davis Brody Associates, provided additional accommodations for more than 300 students in a new dormitory complex of two L-shaped buildings bordered by Thayer, Power, and Charles Field Streets.<cite><a href="Student housing.html">Student housing</a></cite>
On February 19, 1773, the senior class addressed "The remonstrance of the Senior Class of Rhode Island College, to the respectable, the PRESIDENT and PROFESSOR of the Same," the subject being that the members of the class feared that they were going to be deprived of a public <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> because they were not accomplished orators.<cite><a href="Student protests.html">Student protests</a></cite>
Not long after this, on December 31, 1773, the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> was addressed by a committee representing all the classes, protesting that the steward was not providing the food prescribed.<cite><a href="Student protests.html">Student protests</a></cite>
In 1788 the problem was again <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a>, when the graduating class, learning that all the members of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> in attendance were to be given seats on the stage and fearing that there would not be room for the graduates, sent a polite petition that they should be seated on the stage as other classes before them.<cite><a href="Student protests.html">Student protests</a></cite>
In 1835 twenty-one members of the graduating class refused to accept their diplomas.<cite><a href="Student protests.html">Student protests</a></cite>
In their sophomore year 27 of the class of 1835 had signed a resolution stating that "we will use our respectful endeavors to persuade the honorable Authorities of B. U. to omit in our case the giving out of parts founded on a consideration of schollarship (sic) – but that, should we thus fail to persuade the honorable authorities, we will respectfully refuse to accept those parts."<cite><a href="Student protests.html">Student protests</a></cite>
In January 1835 three members of the class sought the permission of <a href="President.html">President</a> Wayland to petition the <a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a> on the subject of distribution of parts.<cite><a href="Student protests.html">Student protests</a></cite>
Thirteen of the 21 later received their degrees at their own request, and in 1875 it was "deemed expedient by the Board of Fellows that after so long a time has elapsed the names of the members of the Class who were entitled to degrees ... be now placed in the list of graduates," and have their names printed in the Triennial <a href="Catalogues.html">Catalogues</a>.<cite><a href="Student protests.html">Student protests</a></cite>
In 1851 the literary societies petitioned that they be allowed to meet in the evening, under the impression that "Such petitions expressing the united sentiments of a whole community cannot be disregarded."<cite><a href="Student protests.html">Student protests</a></cite>
Three faculty members resigned, and during what Walter C. Bronson describes in his "<a href="History.html">History</a> of Brown University" as the "so-called rebellion of 1851," the students used "the abusive epithets towards the <a href="President.html">President</a> and <a href="Faculty.html">Faculty</a>."<cite><a href="Student protests.html">Student protests</a></cite>
A long period of peace between students and administrators followed, only to be severely disrupted by the general unrest of the 1960s.<cite><a href="Student protests.html">Student protests</a></cite>
During the Vietnam War a student strike in May of 1970 followed upon the announcement on April 30 that Unites States troops had entered Cambodia, and on May 4 of the unfortunate death of four students shot by National Guardsmen during a demonstration at Kent State University.<cite><a href="Student protests.html">Student protests</a></cite>
On March 14, 1975, students gathered to protest the University’s proposed budget for 1975-76, charging that <a href="President.html">President</a> Hornig’s "White Paper" on the budget would cut financial aid and student services and also that the reduction of faculty would affect minorities.<cite><a href="Student protests.html">Student protests</a></cite>
On Thursday, April 24, 1975, <a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a> was occupied by forty black, Latin, and Asian-American students.<cite><a href="Student protests.html">Student protests</a></cite>
The students were voicing concern that Brown was not living up to commitments made after the black walkout in 1968.<cite><a href="Student protests.html">Student protests</a></cite>
On October 15, 1981, William Casey, director of the Central Intelligence Agency came to Brown to deliver the second lecture in a series on national security issues sponsored by the John M. Olin Foundation.<cite><a href="Student protests.html">Student protests</a></cite>
Brown students attracted worldwide media attention in 1984 as a result of a referendum included in the Undergraduate Council of Students election of October 11 and 12.<cite><a href="Student protests.html">Student protests</a></cite>
In November 1984 an informational meeting conducted by CIA recruiters was interrupted when one of the audience blew a police whistle and sixty students rose to make a citizen’s arrest "for solicitation to aid in the violation of national and international law."<cite><a href="Student protests.html">Student protests</a></cite>
A peaceful confrontation in April of 1986 involved the building of a shanty on the College Green by the Brown Free Southern Africa Coalition "to present to the administration, the Brown <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a>, and the greater Brown community a tangible image of the kind of misery and degradation our investments in South Africa are helping to maintain."<cite><a href="Student protests.html">Student protests</a></cite>
In 1987 a disruption of a <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> meeting by Students Against Apartheid demanding total divestment in South Africa resulted in the placing of twenty students on probation.<cite><a href="Student protests.html">Student protests</a></cite>
The Swearer Center for Public Service was founded in 1986 to support programs and provide resources to enable students to integrate public service into their education.<cite><a href="Swearer Center for Public Service.html">Swearer Center for Public Service</a></cite>
The inauguration of the Center took place on March 12-14, 1987, and included an addresss by Peace Corps Director Loret M. Ruppe and several workshops and forums.<cite><a href="Swearer Center for Public Service.html">Swearer Center for Public Service</a></cite>
The C. V. Starr National Service Fellowship Program, which began in 1982, awards $1,000 grants for educational expenses to students who have devoted a full year to public service before admission or during a leave of absence.<cite><a href="Swearer Center for Public Service.html">Swearer Center for Public Service</a></cite>
In 1991 the center was named the Howard R. Swearer Center for Public Service in honor of the late president of Brown University.<cite><a href="Swearer Center for Public Service.html">Swearer Center for Public Service</a></cite>
Howard Robert Swearer (1932-1991), fifteenth president of Brown University, was born in Hutchinson, Kansas, on March 13, 1932.<cite><a href="Swearer, Howard R..html">Swearer, Howard R.</a></cite>
Howard R. Swearer attended public schools in Wichita, and graduated from Princeton’s Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs in 1954.<cite><a href="Swearer, Howard R..html">Swearer, Howard R.</a></cite>
Howard R. Swearer earned his master’s degree in political science in 1956, and his Ph.D. degree in 1960, both from Harvard.<cite><a href="Swearer, Howard R..html">Swearer, Howard R.</a></cite>
Howard R. Swearer was appointed an American Political Science Association Congressional Fellow in 1959.<cite><a href="Swearer, Howard R..html">Swearer, Howard R.</a></cite>
Howard R. Swearer taught political science from 1960 to 1967 at UCLA, where he was also acting director of the Russian and East European Studies Center.<cite><a href="Swearer, Howard R..html">Swearer, Howard R.</a></cite>
In 1970 Howard R. Swearer became president of Carleton College, where he led a highly successful capital campaign.<cite><a href="Swearer, Howard R..html">Swearer, Howard R.</a></cite>
Howard R. Swearer accepted the presidency of Brown in August 1976 after having withdrawn as a candidate because of responsibilities at Carleton and some months later being persuaded to reconsider.<cite><a href="Swearer, Howard R..html">Swearer, Howard R.</a></cite>
Howard R. Swearer was quietly sworn in on January 18, 1977.<cite><a href="Swearer, Howard R..html">Swearer, Howard R.</a></cite>
From 1978-79 to 1987 Brown had ten balanced budgets and the endowment increased from $95.4 million to $356.7 million.<cite><a href="Swearer, Howard R..html">Swearer, Howard R.</a></cite>
In 1979, Harriet Sheridan, a former colleague of Swearer as dean of the College at Carleton College, became the first woman dean of the College at Brown.<cite><a href="Swearer, Howard R..html">Swearer, Howard R.</a></cite>
When the Faculty awarded him the Susan Colver Rosenberger Medal in 1983, this event marked the first time that a current president had been so honored.<cite><a href="Swearer, Howard R..html">Swearer, Howard R.</a></cite>
In the fall of 1984 Howard R. Swearer took a two-month leave from the University to travel in Asia, Indonesia, Australia, and Hawaii.<cite><a href="Swearer, Howard R..html">Swearer, Howard R.</a></cite>
In a survey in 1987 supported by the Exxon Education Foundation in which 485 educational leaders ranked college presidents, Swearer was considered to be among the most effective presidents in the country.<cite><a href="Swearer, Howard R..html">Swearer, Howard R.</a></cite>
In October 1987 Howard R. Swearer stunned the Brown community by announcing that he wished to resign the presidency.<cite><a href="Swearer, Howard R..html">Swearer, Howard R.</a></cite>
After leaving in December 1988, Howard R. Swearer was appointed director of Brown’s Institute for International Studies which he had helped to create.<cite><a href="Swearer, Howard R..html">Swearer, Howard R.</a></cite>
At Commencement in 1989 he and his wife, Jan Swearer, both received honorary degrees, which were awarded as a surprise in addition to the other scheduled honors of the occasion.<cite><a href="Swearer, Howard R..html">Swearer, Howard R.</a></cite>
Stricken with cancer, Howard R. Swearer moved to Thompson, Connecticut, where he died on October 19, 1991.<cite><a href="Swearer, Howard R..html">Swearer, Howard R.</a></cite>
Swimming at Brown began with the construction of the <a href="Colgate Hoyt Pool.html">Colgate Hoyt Pool</a> in 1903.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
The first meet in the new pool was held with Yale on February 4, 1903.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
The first aquatic tournament was held on March 7, 1904, when 150 spectators observed interclass relay races, diving, and a water polo game between the freshmen and the sophomores.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
Trainer Charlie Huggins organized intercollegiate swimming at Brown in 1905-1906, and was its unofficial coach until his death in 1924.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
In the first meet of the intercollegiate season held at Brown on January 22, 1907, Harvard won the swimming events, while Brown won the water polo contest, 6-0.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
In 1907-08 Brown, Williams, and Amherst formed a swimming league.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
In 1911 Brown defeated Amherst and Williams in dual meets, and lost to both in the triangular meet.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
In its most successful season to date, Brown won three out of four dual meets in 1913, and defeated Amherst and Williams in the triangular league.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
A very promising team in 1914-15 fell apart when five of its swimmers were disqualified after mid-year examinations.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
In 1919 the team under Coach Myron Finch, defeated Harvard, Harvard Dental School, and the Springfield Y.M.C.A., and lost to M.I.T. Brown won all seven dual meets in 1919-20, and, with two freshman barred by eligibility rules, took fifth place in the New England intercollegiate meet.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
The New England Intercollegiate Swimming Association was formed in the fall of 1921 by Amherst, Brown, Dartmouth, M.I.T., and Wesleyan.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
Brown, led by Davy Jones ’24, won the N.E.I.S.A. meets the next two years, taking seventeen out of nineteen possible firsts in 1922.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
Other All-American swimmers were Mark Coles ’26 in 1924, Raymond Hall ’31 in 1931, and Franklin M. White ’33 in 1931, 1932, and 1933.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
Matt Soltysiak ’40, whom sports writer Joe Nutter ’24, writing in 1940, called "the greatest swimmer in Brown history," competed in every event and was never defeated in New England competition.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
E. Leo Barry took over as coach in 1924.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
His eighteen-year overall record was 76-67-1, and his teams won eleven New England championships, nine of them consecutive between 1932 and 1940.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
On special occasions, such as Brown’s wins over Harvard in 1939 and Army in 1941, Barry himself dived into the pool at the end of the meet.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
Joe Watmough coached for 28 years, from 1943 to 1971.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
His teams won New England championships in 1950, 1951, 1958, and 1961.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
His best swimmer was Carl Paulson ’46, who was All-American in both 1943 and 1944 and won the national NCAA 200-yard butterfly championship in 1944.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
Edward Reed was named coach in 1971.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
One of Coach Reed’s first swimmers was Rich Burrows ’76, who broke every freshman record and in his freshman year set a New England championship record of 17:22 in the 1650 freestyle.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
When Brown’s 1974-75 team won the New England championships at the Brown pool, Burrows took three individual events for three new records, the 200 and 400 individual medleys and the 200 butterfly.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
David Sias has been the diving coach since 1973.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
The team was third in Eastern Seaboard Swimming and Diving Championships in 1983 and 1984.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
Steve Ennis ’86 tied for most points scored in the Eastern Seaboard Meet in 1984.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
A swimming test, which had been required of the male students since 1913, was first mentioned as a physical education requirement for women students in 1931-32.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
Mrs. Roger Higgins was the coach of women’s swimming from 1927 to 1929.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
May Atherton coached from in 1930 to 1932, and Ruth E. M’Coy from 1932 to 1936.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
The 1933 women’s swim team, led by Albina Osipowich ’33, who swam in the 1928 Olympics, in an undefeated season won meets with Wheaton, Jackson, and Radcliffe, and in a quadrangular meet took seven first places in eleven events.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
Another star swimmer for Pembroke was 1932 Olympic medalist Helen Johns ’36.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
In the 1960s Sarah Phillips started coaching women swimmers.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
Florence Filippo coached in 1971 and 1972, and Lynda Calkins from 1974 to 1978.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
In Dave Roach’s eight years as coach from 1978 to 1986, the team won three consecutive <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> championships in 1983, 1984, and 1985.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
Elaine Palmer ’84 won national championships in the 200 and 100 backstroke events in 1982.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
The team won its first Eastern championship in 1985, overtaking Penn State, the defending champion, to whom the Brown women had come in second in 1984 at the <a href="Smith Swimming Center.html">Smith Swimming Center</a>.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
Kendall Delgado ’88 was named outstanding swimmer of the meet, having won both the 400 individual medley and the 200 backstroke and placed third in the 500 freestyle and fourth in the 1650 freestyle.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
In 1986 the team won its second consecutive Eastern championship at Penn State, and Carolyn Ryder ’89 and Karen Dieffenthaller ’89 qualified for the Nationals.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
Jennifer Boyd ’90 set three Eastern Women’s Swimming League records in 1990, in the 100 yards butterfly, the fifty yards freestyle, and the 100 yards freestyle.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
Dave Roach, who began coaching the women’s team in 1978, had a 74-6-1 record for the next seven years; Mark Johnston’s record since 1986 is 43-16 overall and 24-11 in the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a>.<cite><a href="Swimming.html">Swimming</a></cite>
Philip Taft (1902-1976), professor of economics, was born in Syracuse, New York, on March 22, 1902.<cite><a href="Taft, Philip.html">Taft, Philip</a></cite>
In due time Philip Taft resumed his education, finished high school at night, and entered the University of Wisconsin, from which he graduated in 1932.<cite><a href="Taft, Philip.html">Taft, Philip</a></cite>
Taft earned his doctorate at the University of Wisconsin in 1935 and worked as an associate economist for the Social Security Board, before coming to Brown in 1937 as assistant professor of economics.<cite><a href="Taft, Philip.html">Taft, Philip</a></cite>
Philip Taft was promoted to associate professor in 1944 and professor in 1947.<cite><a href="Taft, Philip.html">Taft, Philip</a></cite>
Philip Taft was chairman of the Economics Department from 1949 to 1953.<cite><a href="Taft, Philip.html">Taft, Philip</a></cite>
Philip Taft was the author of numerous articles and fourteen books on the labor movement, among them, "The Structure and Government of Labor Unions" in 1954, "The AFL in the Time of Gompers" in 1957, "Organized Labor in American History" in 1964, and "Labor Politics, American Style" in 1968.<cite><a href="Taft, Philip.html">Taft, Philip</a></cite>
In 1949 Philip Taft became a consultant to the Department of Employment Security.<cite><a href="Taft, Philip.html">Taft, Philip</a></cite>
In 1950 Philip Taft was named by the President’s Council of Economic Advisors to a committee of experts on the New England economy, and in 1961 he was a member of a committee on labor-management reports set up by the U. S. Department of Labor.<cite><a href="Taft, Philip.html">Taft, Philip</a></cite>
Philip Taft retired in 1968, but kept an office in Robinson Hall and continued as before to work long hours on his research.<cite><a href="Taft, Philip.html">Taft, Philip</a></cite>
A letter from Meany written about two months before Taft’s death in Providence on November 17, 1976, mentioned Meany’s friendship for him and added, "Generations of students will continue to benefit from your scholarship and understanding of the economic, social and human aspects of the world of work."<cite><a href="Taft, Philip.html">Taft, Philip</a></cite>
Taliesin was a literary journal "published by the Evanescent Publishing Company," of which two issues appeared in 1967.<cite><a href="Taliesin.html">Taliesin</a></cite>
Jacob David Tamarkin (1888-1945), professor of mathematics, was born in Chernigov in the Ukraine on July 11, 1888.<cite><a href="Tamarkin, Jacob D..html">Tamarkin, Jacob D.</a></cite>
Jacob D. Tamarkin was educated at the Gymnasium of Emperor Alexander I in St. Petersburg, graduating in 1906.<cite><a href="Tamarkin, Jacob D..html">Tamarkin, Jacob D.</a></cite>
Jacob D. Tamarkin received the diploma of the first degree (the equivalent of a Ph.D.) from the University of St. Petersburg in 1910, and became an instructor at the University.<cite><a href="Tamarkin, Jacob D..html">Tamarkin, Jacob D.</a></cite>
In 1917 Jacob D. Tamarkin received the higher degree of Master of Applied Mathematics, and was appointed professor.<cite><a href="Tamarkin, Jacob D..html">Tamarkin, Jacob D.</a></cite>
In 1920 Jacob D. Tamarkin was given a leave of absence while he organized the Mathematical Institute of the University of Perm while serving as dean of the physico-mathematical faculty.<cite><a href="Tamarkin, Jacob D..html">Tamarkin, Jacob D.</a></cite>
The opportunity arrived when Jacob D. Tamarkin met a Dartmouth professor of mathematics in the summer of 1924 and they talked of a possible opening for him there.<cite><a href="Tamarkin, Jacob D..html">Tamarkin, Jacob D.</a></cite>
Jacob D. Tamarkin taught at Dartmouth from 1925 to 1927, when he left to became assistant professor of mathematics at Brown.<cite><a href="Tamarkin, Jacob D..html">Tamarkin, Jacob D.</a></cite>
In 1940 Jacob D. Tamarkin became co-editor of "Mathematical Reviews," published at Brown.<cite><a href="Tamarkin, Jacob D..html">Tamarkin, Jacob D.</a></cite>
While on leave of absence for his health, Jacob D. Tamarkin died in Bethesda, Maryland, on November 18, 1945.<cite><a href="Tamarkin, Jacob D..html">Tamarkin, Jacob D.</a></cite>
The A. Alfred Taubman Center for Public Policy and American Institutions was created in 1983 with a two million dollar gift from A. Alfred Taubman, developer of shopping centers and parent of a Brown student.<cite><a href="Taubman Center for Public Policy and American Institutions.html">Taubman Center for Public Policy and American Institutions</a></cite>
Will Samuel Taylor (1882-1968), professor of art, was born in Ansonia, Connecticut, on November 27, 1882.<cite><a href="Taylor, Will S..html">Taylor, Will S.</a></cite>
From 1910 to 1912 Will S. Taylor traveled in Alaska and British Columbia to do research in preparation for the series of murals depicting the North Pacific Indian which he painted for the American Museum of Natural History.<cite><a href="Taylor, Will S..html">Taylor, Will S.</a></cite>
While Will S. Taylor was executing these paintings between 1915 and 1925, he also taught painting at Pratt Institute.<cite><a href="Taylor, Will S..html">Taylor, Will S.</a></cite>
In 1926 Will S. Taylor traveled in Europe to do research for eight murals on the evolution of man for the Morgan Memorial Hall of the Museum of Natural History.<cite><a href="Taylor, Will S..html">Taylor, Will S.</a></cite>
In 1926 Will S. Taylor also was appointed assistant professor of art and curator of the art collection at Brown.<cite><a href="Taylor, Will S..html">Taylor, Will S.</a></cite>
Will S. Taylor was promoted to associate professor in 1931 and full professor in 1949.<cite><a href="Taylor, Will S..html">Taylor, Will S.</a></cite>
Will S. Taylor was chairman of the Department of Art from 1926 to 1949.<cite><a href="Taylor, Will S..html">Taylor, Will S.</a></cite>
Other mural paintings by Taylor include two in the Providence Street School in Worcester, Massachusetts, and one of the burning of the schooner Gaspee, which he painted for the new building of the Firemen’s Mutual and Union Mutual Insurance Company in Providence in 1954.<cite><a href="Taylor, Will S..html">Taylor, Will S.</a></cite>
Will S. Taylor retired from teaching in 1953.<cite><a href="Taylor, Will S..html">Taylor, Will S.</a></cite>
Will S. Taylor died on December 5, 1968, in New London, Connecticut.<cite><a href="Taylor, Will S..html">Taylor, Will S.</a></cite>
Thomas Alexander Tefft (1826-1859) was born in Richmond, Rhode Island, on August 2, 1826.<cite><a href="Tefft, Thomas A..html">Tefft, Thomas A.</a></cite>
At seventeen Thomas A. Tefft began to keep school himself, and began to design one room schoolhouses as early as 1844.<cite><a href="Tefft, Thomas A..html">Tefft, Thomas A.</a></cite>
On the further advice of Henry Barnard, in 1847 Tefft entered Brown.<cite><a href="Tefft, Thomas A..html">Tefft, Thomas A.</a></cite>
Thomas A. Tefft was still a student when Bucklin recommended him to <a href="Kingsbury, John.html">John Kingsbury</a> 1826 as the architect of the school for young ladies which Kingsbury was having built on Benefit Street.<cite><a href="Tefft, Thomas A..html">Tefft, Thomas A.</a></cite>
Before Thomas A. Tefft came to Brown, he had already designed the Providence railroad station which was built in 1848 under the superintendence of Bucklin.<cite><a href="Tefft, Thomas A..html">Tefft, Thomas A.</a></cite>
In 1850 the "New System," which introduced the Ph.B. degree obtainable in three years without the study of ancient languages, enabled Tefft to graduate in 1851, the first to earn that degree.<cite><a href="Tefft, Thomas A..html">Tefft, Thomas A.</a></cite>
At Brown Tefft became acquainted with the librarian and professor of modern languages, Charles Coffin Jewett 1835, who had traveled in Europe and visited libraries, and was able to aid him in his design of library buildings, including Lawrence Hall at Williams College and the American Antiquarian Society in Worcester.<cite><a href="Tefft, Thomas A..html">Tefft, Thomas A.</a></cite>
Thomas A. Tefft dreamed of visiting Europe to observe its architecture, and in December 1856 sailed for England to begin his tour.<cite><a href="Tefft, Thomas A..html">Tefft, Thomas A.</a></cite>
In 1858 Thomas A. Tefft published a pamphlet, "Universal Currency: a Plan for Obtaining a Common Currency in France, England, and America, Based on the Decimal System."<cite><a href="Tefft, Thomas A..html">Tefft, Thomas A.</a></cite>
Thomas A. Tefft had hoped to continue his travels to Greece and Egypt, but on the trip from Venice to Florence he became ill with a fever and died in Florence on December 12, 1859.<cite><a href="Tefft, Thomas A..html">Tefft, Thomas A.</a></cite>
In May of 1859 Thomas A. Tefft had written a verse beginning:  He was buried in Florence, but later his remains were removed to Swan Point Cemetery in Providence, which he had helped to survey and lay out, and rest beneath a monument of his own design.<cite><a href="Tefft, Thomas A..html">Tefft, Thomas A.</a></cite>
Tennis at Brown began in the early 1880s.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
The 1881 "<a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a>" notes the existence of the Alpha Delta Phi, Chi Phi, and Psi Upsilon tennis clubs.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
In the next two years there were several additional clubs, and on April 14, 1883, the Brown University Lawn Tennis Association was formed.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
The officers of the association were Abram Barker 1883, H. B. Gardner 1884, and J.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
B. Diman 1885.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
The 1890 "<a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a>" reported, "Tennis has developed wonderfully.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
Fred Hovey 1890, a future national champion who won the U.S. Doubles in 1893 and 1894 and the U.S. Singles in 1895, won the college championship in 1887 and successfully defended it against William R. Weeden 1891, the winner of the 1888 tournament.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
Hovey was second in the singles at the intercollegiate tournament in New Haven in 1889.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
J. D. E. Jones 1893 represented Brown at the intercollegiates for two years, but, like Hovey, his tennis career was at its best after college, when he won five Rhode Island state singles and five doubles titles and reached the semi-finals at the national tournament at the Newport Casino in 1906.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
In the intercollegiate tournament in 1893 Brown took firsts in both the singles and doubles, the former won by Malcolm Chace 1896, and the latter by Chace and Clarence Budlong 1897, a freshman who had won the interscholastic singles of the United States while he was in high school.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
At a tournament of the newly organized New England Tennis Association in 1900 at Longwood, Massachusetts, E. T. Gross ’01 won the singles championship, and teamed with Frank Gooding ’01 to win the doubles.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
There was a dual meet with M.I.T. in 1911, and in May 1912 a schedule of five games with Union, Williams, Harvard, Trinity, and Minnesota.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
Tennis was revived in 1920 after a lapse of several years and became a recognized sport in 1922.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
In 1925-26 eleven new clay courts were added, and Brown won six of eight dual meets.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
The teams of 1927 and 1928 were undefeated, and teams of the 1930s were generally successful.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
J. D. E. Jones coached at the beginning of the 1950s.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
"Rip" Engle took over from 1942 to 1944.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
Westcott E. S. Moulton served as coach from 1947 to 1949.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
Brown won six and lost two in Arthur Palmer’s first coaching season in 1950, and Bill Crafts ’50 and Ed Alsop ’51 reached the quarterfinals of the New England Intercollegiate Lawn Tennis Tournament.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
There were more winning seasons, nine of the eleven seasons before Brown’s entry into the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> in 1961.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
It was 1964 before the Brown team defeated its first Ivy opponent, Dartmouth with a 5-4 score.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
Palmer coached until 1965.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
Jim Dougherty coached from 1965 to 1975, Dave Johnson in 1977-78, and William Cullen from 1978 to 1982.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
Bob Woods began coaching in 1982.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
His first team in 1983 achieved a best ever season record, finished fourth in the Eastern Intercollegiate Tennis Association, third in New England, and fourth in the ECAC’s.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
In 1987 Tim Donovan ’89 became the first Brown player to win the New England championship twice.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
A women’s tennis association was formed in 1900 as an alternative to indoor gymnasium classes.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
Phoebe Smythe coached tennis in 1927-28, and Ruth E. M’Coy from 1930 to 1935.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
The women’s tennis team had its first undefeated season, 9-0 in the fall of 1974, followed by more successful seasons in the spring of 1975, 7-0, and the fall of 1975, 5-1, with the help of Nancy Fuld ’76 and Nancy Lewis ’77.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
The 1989 fall team finished off a 5-1 fall season by winning the Brown women’s first ECAC championship.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
The 1991 spring team finished its season with a 7-0 record and its first ever <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> championship.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
Coaches of women’s tennis have been Pat Schiltz from 1958 to 1964, Jan Lutz from 1964 to 1971, Joan Taylor from 1971 to 1978, Bill Cullen from 1978 to 1982, and Paul Moses from 1982 to 1985.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
Norma Taylor, who has coached since 1985, had a seven-year record of 48-67 overall and 22-27 in the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a>.<cite><a href="Tennis.html">Tennis</a></cite>
Theatre Arts became a separate department on July 1, 1978, after 77 years as part of the <a href="English.html">English</a> Department.<cite><a href="Theatre Arts.html">Theatre Arts</a></cite>
<a href="Dramatics.html">Dramatics</a> had flourished as an extra-curricular activity under Professors <a href="Thomas Crosby.html">Thomas Crosby</a>, Jr. 1894, Benjamin W. Brown ’19, and Janice Van De Water Brown, and continued under Mrs. Brown and James Barnhill after the death of Ben Brown in 1955.<cite><a href="Theatre Arts.html">Theatre Arts</a></cite>
John Emigh, John Lucas, Don Wilmeth, and Barbara Tannenbaum joined the faculty in the late 1960s, and in 1969 Theatre Arts became a separate concentration in the <a href="English.html">English</a> Department.<cite><a href="Theatre Arts.html">Theatre Arts</a></cite>
In 1969 Julie Strandberg began teaching dance in the women’s physical education department of <a href="Pembroke College.html">Pembroke College</a>.<cite><a href="Theatre Arts.html">Theatre Arts</a></cite>
In 1973 Theatre Arts was recognized as a program.<cite><a href="Theatre Arts.html">Theatre Arts</a></cite>
With the expectation of the renovation of <a href="Lyman Hall.html">Lyman Hall</a> into a theatre and dance studio, a plan was formed to make Theater Arts an independent department in 1980.<cite><a href="Theatre Arts.html">Theatre Arts</a></cite>
The name of the department was changed to the Department of Theatre, Speech, and Dance in 1987.<cite><a href="Theatre Arts.html">Theatre Arts</a></cite>
James O. Barnhill was chairman of the department until 1979, followed by Don B. Wilmeth until 1987.<cite><a href="Theatre Arts.html">Theatre Arts</a></cite>
John Emigh served until 1993, Nancy Dunbar until 1998, and Wilmeth again until 2001.<cite><a href="Theatre Arts.html">Theatre Arts</a></cite>
Spencer Golub became chair in 2001.<cite><a href="Theatre Arts.html">Theatre Arts</a></cite>
The Third World Center had its beginning when Afro House at 227 Bowen Street, which had been in use since 1969, was about to be be razed for the building of the <a href="New Pembroke.html">New Pembroke</a> dormitory complex, and new quarters were provided in 1972 in the basement of <a href="Churchill House.html">Churchill House</a>.<cite><a href="Third World Center.html">Third World Center</a></cite>
Calvin Hicks was coodinator from 1976 to 1979.<cite><a href="Third World Center.html">Third World Center</a></cite>
Felipe Floresca ’73 was appointed coordinator in April 1980, and was succeeded by Robert G. Lee in October 1981.<cite><a href="Third World Center.html">Third World Center</a></cite>
In 1985 Preston Smith was appointed director of the Center, and in 1986 the Center moved from <a href="Churchill House.html">Churchill House</a> to Partridge Hall.<cite><a href="Third World Center.html">Third World Center</a></cite>
Jeanne Smith was acting director in 1989-90, and Tommy Woon became director in 1990.<cite><a href="Third World Center.html">Third World Center</a></cite>
The first Third World All-Alumni Reunion held during the <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> weekend of 1990 included social activities and discussion sessions.<cite><a href="Third World Center.html">Third World Center</a></cite>
Thomas Crosby (1870-1947), professor of <a href="English.html">English</a> and director of Sock and Buskin, was born in Newport on August 8, 1870.<cite><a href="Thomas Crosby.html">Thomas Crosby</a></cite>
He graduated from Rogers High School and entered Brown in 1890.<cite><a href="Thomas Crosby.html">Thomas Crosby</a></cite>
He did better as Ponce de Leon in the Hammer and Tongs production "Florida Water, "an operetta written by Edward W. Corliss 1895.<cite><a href="Thomas Crosby.html">Thomas Crosby</a></cite>
After graduation in 1894, he stayed on as an instructor in <a href="English.html">English</a> and earned a master’s degree in 1895.<cite><a href="Thomas Crosby.html">Thomas Crosby</a></cite>
He taught at Worcester Academy and the <a href="University Grammar School.html">University Grammar School</a> before going to New York in 1898 to study at the Stanhope-Wheaton Dramatic School.<cite><a href="Thomas Crosby.html">Thomas Crosby</a></cite>
He would have liked a theatrical career, but his parents were opposed to the idea, and he returned to Brown and the <a href="English.html">English</a> Department in 1900.<cite><a href="Thomas Crosby.html">Thomas Crosby</a></cite>
He advanced to assistant professor in 1901, associate professor in 1910, and professor in 1925.<cite><a href="Thomas Crosby.html">Thomas Crosby</a></cite>
He helped to form Sock and Buskin, the Brown University Dramatic Society, in 1902, and the Players, an amateur group which appeared at the Talma Theatre on South Main Street, in 1909.<cite><a href="Thomas Crosby.html">Thomas Crosby</a></cite>
Crosby retired from teaching in 1939, but he continued to appear in plays.<cite><a href="Thomas Crosby.html">Thomas Crosby</a></cite>
In a 1941 interview he estimated that he had directed more than 200 shows and acted in as many more.<cite><a href="Thomas Crosby.html">Thomas Crosby</a></cite>
His last appearance on the stage in the <a href="Faunce House.html">Faunce House</a> was as Nathan’l Berry in the alumni production of Shore Acres, which marked the fortieth anniversary of Sock and Buskin in 1941.<cite><a href="Thomas Crosby.html">Thomas Crosby</a></cite>
He died on August 23, 1947 in Providence.<cite><a href="Thomas Crosby.html">Thomas Crosby</a></cite>
Frederick Neale Tompkins (1893-1978), professor of electrical engineering, was born in Providence on September 30, 1893.<cite><a href="Tompkins, Frederick N..html">Tompkins, Frederick N.</a></cite>
Before entering Brown Frederick N. Tompkins worked from 1912 to 1914 for Narragansett Electric Lighting Company.<cite><a href="Tompkins, Frederick N..html">Tompkins, Frederick N.</a></cite>
Frederick N. Tompkins received a bachelor of science degree in electrical engineering in 1918.<cite><a href="Tompkins, Frederick N..html">Tompkins, Frederick N.</a></cite>
Frederick N. Tompkins was appointed instructor in electrical engineering at Brown in 1918, and promoted to assistant professor in 1923 and associate professor in 1928.<cite><a href="Tompkins, Frederick N..html">Tompkins, Frederick N.</a></cite>
Frederick N. Tompkins retired in 1959.<cite><a href="Tompkins, Frederick N..html">Tompkins, Frederick N.</a></cite>
Frederick N. Tompkins died on June 19, 1978 in Providence.<cite><a href="Tompkins, Frederick N..html">Tompkins, Frederick N.</a></cite>
Tougaloo College and Brown entered into a compact in the spring of 1964, in which Brown volunteered to assist the struggling black college.<cite><a href="Tougaloo College.html">Tougaloo College</a></cite>
Professor Harold Pfautz of Brown was named director of the program and went to Tougaloo in the fall of 1964.<cite><a href="Tougaloo College.html">Tougaloo College</a></cite>
He remained until 1966.<cite><a href="Tougaloo College.html">Tougaloo College</a></cite>
In 1965 George A. Owens, who had been acting president for a year, was named the first black president of Tougaloo.<cite><a href="Tougaloo College.html">Tougaloo College</a></cite>
Tougaloo began when the American Missionary Association bought 500 acres of land with an antebellum mansion north of Jackson, Mississippi, in 1869 and acquired a charter from the state in 1871.<cite><a href="Tougaloo College.html">Tougaloo College</a></cite>
With the rise of the Black Power movement, Tougaloo no longer welcomed white students and the exchange ceased in 1970, and was not resumed until 1980.<cite><a href="Tougaloo College.html">Tougaloo College</a></cite>
In 1973 Tougaloo began a Health Services Summer Program for high school students.<cite><a href="Tougaloo College.html">Tougaloo College</a></cite>
By 1975 there were forty Tougaloo graduates in medical school.<cite><a href="Tougaloo College.html">Tougaloo College</a></cite>
In the summer of 1987 Charles Baldwin, who had been involved with Tougaloo since the beginning of the Brown-Tougaloo agreement, was asked to serve as interim president of the College.<cite><a href="Tougaloo College.html">Tougaloo College</a></cite>
"Town and Gown" appeared in October 1930.<cite><a href="Town and Gown.html">Town and Gown</a></cite>
An elaborate flier which heralded the publication listed the names of a number of important men on its board of directors, including Royal B. Farnum, educational director at the <a href="Rhode Island School of Design.html">Rhode Island School of Design</a>, as president of the board, and Hermon C. Bumpus 1884, former president of Tufts College, as secretary.<cite><a href="Town and Gown.html">Town and Gown</a></cite>
Track and field events began at Brown in 1878, when the Athletic Association held the first Field Day.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
The events were a rope pull between the Classes of 1879 and 1880, the standing broad jump, the running broad jump, the standing high jump, the running high jump, the shot put, the hundred yards dash, the three-legged race, the wheelbarrow race, and the base ball throw.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
The New England Intercollegiate Association was organized in 1887, and held its first meet on May 27 of that year.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
In the 1890 meet, Fred Hovey 1890 took second in the pole vault and E. A. Barrows 1891 won the high jump with five feet five inches.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
Frederick Marvel 1890 recalled the informality of track practice, "Brown students used what was known as the Sanitary Gymnasium on Aborn street, and the more zealous individuals did attain a fair measure of conditioning work for the few and infrequent tests of the time.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
In March of 1891 an indoor meet was held in <a href="Sayles Hall.html">Sayles Hall</a>, with the Sanitary Gymnasium, the Y.M.C.A., and the Narragansett Boat Club members as participants.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
Ed Weeks 1893 won the 25-yard dash and Everett A. Bowen 1892 the 600.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
Frank Sexton 1893 won the mile "walk" in 8 minutes 8 seconds, and G. N. Richmond 1892 won the mile in 5:35.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
He finished third in the 800-metres in the 1900 Olympics.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
At the New England Intercollegiate Athletic Association annual meet in 1902, Brown came in third of eight colleges after Amherst and Dartmouth, having placed first, second, and third in the two-mile bicycle race and scored in the one- and two-mile runs and the discus throw.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
In the 1904 NEIAA meet, Brown finished third, although for financial reasons only five men went to Worcester.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
Also in 1904, Brown held the first of the Brown University Interscholastic Track Association annual meets for area high school and business college athletes.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
In 1905 a new board running track, nine feet wide and about fourteen laps to the mile, occupied the space between the <a href="Colgate Hoyt Pool.html">Colgate Hoyt Pool</a> and the Thayer Street fence.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
Brown was second in the 1906 NEIAA meet, Tucker again winning the mile and two mile and John Mayhew ’09 the running broad jump.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
A track coach, Hugh C. McGrath, who was a graduate of Boston University, was hired in 1907.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
McGrath came back again in the spring of 1909 after a year’s absence.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
The 1910 "<a href="Liber Brunensis.html">Liber Brunensis</a>" called to mind "the same old story that has been told for years about Brown track athletics, – a story which has for its chief and never-ending theme, ‘Lack of money.’" In the spring of 1911 the Athletic Board voted to secure a regular coach.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
Edward J. O’Connor from Bates College was hired and coached until 1914.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
In the very successful indoor season of 1912 the relay team was undefeated.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
In 1913 Brown finished second again in the New Englands, and Taber set new New England records in the mile and half-mile.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
Archie Hahn, who won three medals in the 1904 Olympics, coached from 1915 to 1920, and Brown came in second in the New Englands in 1917, 1918, and 1920.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
In 1928 John Collier ’29 set a new record in the 120-yard high hurdles in the New Englands, and finished second in that event in the IC4A’s.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
In 1933 Thomas Gilbane ’33 won an IC4A championship in the shot put.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
The coaches after Archie Hahn were Alfred W. Haddleton, who had coached at Providence Technical High School and Moses Brown School and filled in at Brown in 1920-21, James E. Smith 1892 from 1921 to 1923, John Frederick Powers, former Notre Dame track star and coach at Worcester Academy, from 1924 to 1938, and Malcolm Williams from 1938 to 1941.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
George Anderson began coaching in 1941, but left for the Navy in 1942, and was replaced by Roland K. Brown, who coached from 1942 until 1944, with football coach Neil "Skip" Stahley designated as acting coach during those years.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
"Rip" Engle, was named coach in 1944.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
Carl S. Hector coached in 1945.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
When Ivan Fuqua, a member of the record-breaking 1600-meter relay team in the 1932 Olympics and former coach at the University of Connecticut, came to Brown in 1946, he was assured that a new field house and track would soon be built.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
Before this happened he had to leave, retiring in 1974.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
Fuqua’s teams won New England track and field titles in 1949, 1960, and 1961.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
Individual stars included 1947 and 1948 NAAU hammer throw champion and 1948 Olympic team member Bob Bennett ’48, NAAU 40-yard champion Bill Dwyer ’48, national high jump champion Dick Phillips ’50 (who won the IC4A, NCAA, and NAAU championships in 1949), and Gil Borjeson ’52, who in consecutive weeks in his junior year won both the NAAU and the IC4A shot put titles, and was NCAA hammer throw champion in 1952.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
In 1973 the Heptagonals were held at Brown for the first time in twenty years.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
In 1975 Brown came within one-tenth of a second of an undefeated season when the team lost to Dartmouth in the final event of the dual meet, the mile relay which Dartmouth won, 3:17.7 to Brown’s 3:17.8, for a final score of Dartmouth 78, Brown 76.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
In the 1988 NCAA track and field championships Greg Whiteley ’89 placed third in the 5,000 meters and Chris Schille ’88 finished seventh in the 10,000 meters.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
Doug Terry followed Fuqua in 1974.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
He resigned in the fall of 1984.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
Bob Rothenberg ’65 was named coordinator of track and men’s cross country in May 1983 and director of track and cross country for men and women in 1987.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
In 1974 two women students, Karen Zaccor ’78 and Andrea Thach ’77, wanted to start track and cross country for women.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
They received the support of physical education director Arlene Gorton, and the teams were formed in 1975.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
Jonathan Hird ’74 MAT was the part-time coach for both teams until 1979.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
In the spring of 1978 the women’s track team, with a 4-1 dual meet record, became the first Brown women’s team to win an <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> championship.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
Brown won the New Englands for a second time in 1980.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
In 1979 Sirkka Liisa Williams became the first full time coach for the women’s teams.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
Sue Latter Addison coached for one year in 1981-82.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
Jon Hird returned in 1982 and coached until 1986.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
Teri Smith ’91 set indoor and outdoor records in the 200 meter dash in 1989, and in 1991 won the 200 and 400 meter dashes and anchored the relay team which set a new 1600 meter relay record.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
In 1990-91 the women’s team came in second of ten in both the indoor and outdoor Heptagonals.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
The 1992 team won the Heptagonal Women’s Indoor Championships.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
Coach Bob Rothenberg’s five-year record since 1986 was 25-5 (16-2 indoor and 9-3 outdoor).<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
In 1979 the women’s cross country team had a 7-2 dual meet record, won the Rhode Island championships, and came in fourth in the New England championships.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
Anne Sullivan ’82, Harvard’s first woman All-American, transferred to Brown in 1979, and set <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> records in the 3,000 and 5,000 meters at the outdoor championships in 1979, placed sixth in the 10,000 meters in the national outdoor track championships in 1979, eighteenth in the national cross country championships in 1980, fourth in the Olympic trials (10,000 meters) in 1980, and set a record in the indoor track American Collegiate three-mile in 1980.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
John Hird’s coaching record from 1979 to 1986 was 25-21.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
Mike Muska coached women’s cross country from 1987 to 1991 with a five year record of 20-10-1.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
Bob Rothenberg began coaching the cross-country team in 1992.<cite><a href="Track.html">Track</a></cite>
A Treasurer was appointed in 1764.<cite><a href="Treasurer.html">Treasurer</a></cite>
The first treasurer, John Tillinghast, served until 1767, and was followed by Job Bennett from 1767 to 1775.<cite><a href="Treasurer.html">Treasurer</a></cite>
John Brown, one of the four Brown brothers, became treasurer in 1775, and managed the financial affairs of the university for 21 years, contributing generously from his own funds.<cite><a href="Treasurer.html">Treasurer</a></cite>
When he resigned in 1796, he still retained his place on the Board of Trustees.<cite><a href="Treasurer.html">Treasurer</a></cite>
Resigning that office a few days before his death in 1803, because of his lameness which "will continue to render me a useless member of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a>," he urged the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> in his letter of resignation to find the means to establish a Professorship of <a href="English.html">English</a> Oratory.<cite><a href="Treasurer.html">Treasurer</a></cite>
John Brown was succeeded by his nephew, Nicholas Brown 1786, who held the office for 29 years, from 1796 to 1825.<cite><a href="Treasurer.html">Treasurer</a></cite>
He was to be the one to establish the Professorship of Oratory and Belles Letters in 1804 with his contribution of $5000.<cite><a href="Treasurer.html">Treasurer</a></cite>
His election as Fellow in 1825 made the office of Treasurer vacant, and his nephew Moses Brown Ives 1812 was elected to fill his place.<cite><a href="Treasurer.html">Treasurer</a></cite>
Ives died in 1857, and was succeeded by his brother, Robert Hale Ives 1816.<cite><a href="Treasurer.html">Treasurer</a></cite>
Marshall Woods, who was named treasurer in 1866, unlike his predecessors of the last ninety years, was not a member of the <a href="Brown family.html">Brown family</a>, although he did marry Ann Brown Francis, whose mother was the daughter of former treasurer Nicholas Brown and whose father was the grandson of former treasurer John Brown.<cite><a href="Treasurer.html">Treasurer</a></cite>
The remaining treasurers have been Arnold Buffum Chace 1866 from 1882 to 1900; Cornelius S. Sweetland 1866 from 1900 to 1923; Frank W. Matteson 1892 from 1923 to 1933, Edwin Aylsworth Burlingame ’14, acting treasurer from 1933 to 1934; Harold C. Field 1894 from 1934 to 1949; George Burton Hibbert from 1949 to 1950; Gordon L. Parker ’18 from 1950 to 1965; Patrick J. James ’32 from 1965 to 1970; Joseph W. Ress ’26 from 1970 to 1979; Andrew M. Hunt ’51 from 1979 to 1988; and Marie J. Langlois ’64 since 1988.<cite><a href="Treasurer.html">Treasurer</a></cite>
Rohn Truell (1913-1968), professor of applied mathematics, was born on April 6, 1913, in Washington, D. C. He earned a bachelor of science degree in engineering at Lehigh University in 1935, and received his Ph.D. degree from Cornell in 1941.<cite><a href="Truell, Rohn.html">Truell, Rohn</a></cite>
Rohn Truell was a research physicist from 1942 to 1944 at the R.C.A.<cite><a href="Truell, Rohn.html">Truell, Rohn</a></cite>
Laboratories in Princeton, and from 1944 to 1946 at Stromberg Carlson Company and Cornell University.<cite><a href="Truell, Rohn.html">Truell, Rohn</a></cite>
In 1946 Rohn Truell was appointed assistant professor of physics at Brown.<cite><a href="Truell, Rohn.html">Truell, Rohn</a></cite>
Rohn Truell was promoted to associate professor in 1946, and became professor of applied mathematics in 1951.<cite><a href="Truell, Rohn.html">Truell, Rohn</a></cite>
Rohn Truell established the Metals Reseach Laboratory in 1948, and was chairman of the laboratory until his sudden death in Providence on January 10, 1968, following a stroke.<cite><a href="Truell, Rohn.html">Truell, Rohn</a></cite>
Tuition in 1770 was a lowly twelve dollars per year, and room rent was five dollars per year.<cite><a href="Tuition.html">Tuition</a></cite>
Tuition was increased at intervals, reaching $20 in 1801, $36 in 1827, $50 in 1864, and $75 in 1870.<cite><a href="Tuition.html">Tuition</a></cite>
In 1877 tuition was raised to $100 per year.<cite><a href="Tuition.html">Tuition</a></cite>
In 1902 a modest increase brought the fee up to $105, a rate which survived until 1917, when it leaped to $175.<cite><a href="Tuition.html">Tuition</a></cite>
After the war there were regular, but not drastic increases, $200 in 1919, $250 in 1921, $300 in 1922, $350 in 1925, and $400 in 1928.<cite><a href="Tuition.html">Tuition</a></cite>
There it remained during the depression years, then rose to $450 in 1940, and, after <a href="World War II.html">World War II</a>, to $500 in 1946.<cite><a href="Tuition.html">Tuition</a></cite>
By $100 increments every few years, the cost of tuition reached $700 in 1952.<cite><a href="Tuition.html">Tuition</a></cite>
By 1960 the rate had doubled to $1,400, and by 1990 through hefty annual increases was more than ten times that amount.<cite><a href="Tuition.html">Tuition</a></cite>
W(illiam) Freeman Twaddell (1906-1982), professor of German and linguistics, was born in Rye, New York, on March 22, 1906.<cite><a href="Twaddell, William Freeman.html">Twaddell, William Freeman</a></cite>
William Freeman Twaddell graduated from Duke University in 1926, and received his master’s degree in 1927 and his doctorate in 1930, both from Harvard.<cite><a href="Twaddell, William Freeman.html">Twaddell, William Freeman</a></cite>
From 1929 to 1946 William Freeman Twaddell taught at the University of Wisconsin, where he was chairman of the German Department from 1937 to 1946 and also of the Division of the Humanities from 1943 to 1946.<cite><a href="Twaddell, William Freeman.html">Twaddell, William Freeman</a></cite>
William Freeman Twaddell came to Brown as professor of Germanic languages in 1946.<cite><a href="Twaddell, William Freeman.html">Twaddell, William Freeman</a></cite>
In 1951 William Freeman Twaddell became professor of linguistics and German.<cite><a href="Twaddell, William Freeman.html">Twaddell, William Freeman</a></cite>
During a year’s leave of absence in 1950-51 William Freeman Twaddell was research editor for Merriam-Webster Dictionaries.<cite><a href="Twaddell, William Freeman.html">Twaddell, William Freeman</a></cite>
In 1954-55 William Freeman Twaddell was a Fulbright lecturer at Ain Shaims University in Egypt.<cite><a href="Twaddell, William Freeman.html">Twaddell, William Freeman</a></cite>
William Freeman Twaddell was chairman of a consortium of linguists from Brown, Cornell, the University of Michigan, and the University of Texas, which trained Egyptian teachers of English from 1958 to 1964.<cite><a href="Twaddell, William Freeman.html">Twaddell, William Freeman</a></cite>
On leave in 1957-58, William Freeman Twaddell was a senior fellow of the Princeton University Council on the Humanities.<cite><a href="Twaddell, William Freeman.html">Twaddell, William Freeman</a></cite>
From 1960 until his resignation in 1971 William Freeman Twaddell was chairman of the Department of Linguistics.<cite><a href="Twaddell, William Freeman.html">Twaddell, William Freeman</a></cite>
William Freeman Twaddell died on March 1, 1982.<cite><a href="Twaddell, William Freeman.html">Twaddell, William Freeman</a></cite>
The  United Brothers Society was formed in 1806 by students who had not been admitted to the only existing society for debate and literary improvement, the <a href="Philermenian Society.html">Philermenian Society</a>.<cite><a href="United Brothers.html">United Brothers</a></cite>
After their constitution was approved by <a href="President.html">President</a> Messer in April 1806, the society raised $120 for books for its library.<cite><a href="United Brothers.html">United Brothers</a></cite>
Among the founding members of the society were William L. Marcy 1808, Dutee J. Pearce 1808, Jonathan Going 1809, and Daniel Frost 1808.<cite><a href="United Brothers.html">United Brothers</a></cite>
It held its own exercises until 1841, when the United Brothers and the Philermenians began to have a joint celebration, at which the Brothers wore white ribbons to distinguish them from the Philermenians.<cite><a href="United Brothers.html">United Brothers</a></cite>
After 1859 there were few meetings of the United Brothers except for initiations, and the joint anniversaries ended in 1863.<cite><a href="United Brothers.html">United Brothers</a></cite>
<a href="Well.html">Well</a> before a formal program began, in 1785 Professor Benjamin Waterhouse gave a public lecture on natural history at the State House, and Professor Perez Fobes gave lectures on natural philosophy in 1790.<cite><a href="University Extension.html">University Extension</a></cite>
Professor George Ide Chace gave lectures to Providence metal workers in 1853.<cite><a href="University Extension.html">University Extension</a></cite>
The extension division was established in 1890-1891 with the appointment of Professor Wilfred Harold Munro as Director of University Extension.<cite><a href="University Extension.html">University Extension</a></cite>
In his report for 1892 <a href="President.html">President</a> Andrews set forth the purpose of the program: If the lectures won acceptance, the examinations did not.<cite><a href="University Extension.html">University Extension</a></cite>
In his 1893 report Munro stated that "except in the Laboratory Courses, the examination is not likely to play a very conspicuous part in University Extension in America.... the great American public has no desire again to undergo these afflictions of student days.<cite><a href="University Extension.html">University Extension</a></cite>
During the academic year 1896-97 Arthur E. Watson delivered a series of night lectures on electrical engineering to "a class of practical men" in the electrical laboratory.<cite><a href="University Extension.html">University Extension</a></cite>
In 1906-07 university extension was reorganized under Professor Walter B. Jacobs with four courses, <a href="English.html">English</a>, French, German, and history.<cite><a href="University Extension.html">University Extension</a></cite>
In 1910-11, when nine courses of ten lectures each were given, registration which had been 250 the year before increased to 567.<cite><a href="University Extension.html">University Extension</a></cite>
Jacobs was appointed Director of University Extension in 1915.<cite><a href="University Extension.html">University Extension</a></cite>
In the fall of 1920 there were 811 registrations, with 132 enrolled for the new extension certificate conferring "associate in university extension" for sixty credits of extension work, estimated to be the equivalent of two years of regular college work.<cite><a href="University Extension.html">University Extension</a></cite>
In 1923, 1,552 persons enrolled.<cite><a href="University Extension.html">University Extension</a></cite>
In 1928 there was an extension course specifically for local dentists.<cite><a href="University Extension.html">University Extension</a></cite>
When Jacobs retired as director in 1931, the courses had grown to sixty in a single semester, with an attendance of 3,500 persons.<cite><a href="University Extension.html">University Extension</a></cite>
A large registration of Rhode Island teachers was attracted to a series of lecture-discussion courses sponsored jointly by Brown and the Rhode Island State Department of <a href="Education.html">Education</a> from 1950 to 1952.<cite><a href="University Extension.html">University Extension</a></cite>
The regular schedule of extension courses came to an end in 1971.<cite><a href="University Extension.html">University Extension</a></cite>
The directors of University Extension who followed Jacobs were C. Emanuel Ekstrom in 1931, Gilbert E. Case in 1950, Hazel M. Woodmansee in 1960, and Charlotte Lowney Tomas ’57 in 1971.<cite><a href="University Extension.html">University Extension</a></cite>
Alumni College, a program designed to give the alumni a chance to return to the University and attend courses for a week in the summer, was first held in 1962.<cite><a href="University Extension.html">University Extension</a></cite>
It was repeated in 1963 with great success, but was then discontinued apparently because the low fees had caused the University to operate the program at a loss.<cite><a href="University Extension.html">University Extension</a></cite>
The campus program was revived in 1972 under the name, "The Summer of ’72," and has developed into the Continuing College, which offers a variety of programs designed to cultivate the alumni education.<cite><a href="University Extension.html">University Extension</a></cite>
Even though there were 1,213 people enrolled in 65 extension courses in 1974-75, University Extension was suspended in 1975 as part of the University’s solution to the fiscal emergency at that time.<cite><a href="University Extension.html">University Extension</a></cite>
In 1982-83 evening courses were reinstated, and a limited number of classes were offered, all taught by Brown faculty, but the relatively high fees discouraged applicants and the program was not a financial success.<cite><a href="University Extension.html">University Extension</a></cite>
In 1983 a new non-credit program, the "Brown Learning Community," directed by Mark Curran, <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> of Special Studies, was begun.<cite><a href="University Extension.html">University Extension</a></cite>
The Brown Humanities Institute was established in 1985 to provide monthly seminars led by Brown faculty for the benefit of local senior executives from business, government, and non-profit organizations.<cite><a href="University Extension.html">University Extension</a></cite>
The  University Grammar School was a natural outgrowth of the Latin School opened by James Manning in Warren in April 1764.<cite><a href="University Grammar School.html">University Grammar School</a></cite>
In 1770 the school moved to Providence along with the college and was for two years housed in the Brick School House.<cite><a href="University Grammar School.html">University Grammar School</a></cite>
The school and college were related closely enough for grammar school student Billy Edwards, son of Morgan Edwards, one of the founders of the college, to recite a piece from Homer at the close of the <a href="Commencement.html">Commencement</a> exercises in 1770.<cite><a href="University Grammar School.html">University Grammar School</a></cite>
In 1772 the Latin School was conducted in the College Edifice.<cite><a href="University Grammar School.html">University Grammar School</a></cite>
Ebenezer David 1772 was put in charge of the school which had twenty students in 1773.<cite><a href="University Grammar School.html">University Grammar School</a></cite>
A notice of the opening of a "Grammar School" in the College Edifice was announced on March 11, 1776 in the "Providence Gazette, but probably this school’s life was cut short by the closing of the college in December of 1776."<cite><a href="University Grammar School.html">University Grammar School</a></cite>
From 1783 to 1792 the Grammar School was conducted by William Wilkinson, first in the College Edifice until 1786, and thereafter again in the Brick School House.<cite><a href="University Grammar School.html">University Grammar School</a></cite>
In 1794 the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> recommended the establishment of a grammar school "as an appendage to this College."<cite><a href="University Grammar School.html">University Grammar School</a></cite>
At some time the school was established and Jeremiah Chaplin 1799, later president of Waterville College, was engaged as master.<cite><a href="University Grammar School.html">University Grammar School</a></cite>
In 1809 the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> voted that a suitable building be erected for the use of the grammar school and appointed a committee to raise the funds needed "to erect the same on the west line of the <a href="Steward.html">Steward</a>’s garden."<cite><a href="University Grammar School.html">University Grammar School</a></cite>
The cost of the building, erected in 1810, was $1,452.86, which was obtained from 118 persons, with Brown and Ives making up the final amount of $90.30 needed to cover the cost.<cite><a href="University Grammar School.html">University Grammar School</a></cite>
After a succession of schoolmasters, many of whom served for only a year or two, in 1845 Henry S. Frieze 1841 and Merrick Lyon 1841 joined in the operation of the school.<cite><a href="University Grammar School.html">University Grammar School</a></cite>
Under their management the enrollment increased enough that in 1852 they made at their own expense a 35-foot addition to the building.<cite><a href="University Grammar School.html">University Grammar School</a></cite>
When Henry Frieze left for the University of Michigan in 1854, the school was run by Merrick Lyon, who was in charge of the classical department, and his brother, Emory Lyon, who took over the <a href="English.html">English</a> and mathematical department.<cite><a href="University Grammar School.html">University Grammar School</a></cite>
In the 35 years that the Lyon brothers operated the school before the death of Merrick in 1888, 200 of their students went on to study at Brown.<cite><a href="University Grammar School.html">University Grammar School</a></cite>
In 1891 the building provided space for the classes of the first women students.<cite><a href="University Grammar School.html">University Grammar School</a></cite>
In 1898 the <a href="English.html">English</a> and Classical School founded by William A. Mowry and Charles B. Goff was merged with the University Grammar School into the University School.<cite><a href="University Grammar School.html">University Grammar School</a></cite>
University Hall was built in 1770.<cite><a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a></cite>
The first mention of a college building is found in Hezekiah Smith’s diary in which he reports on September 5, 1765, on the second annual meeting of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a>, "I was with the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> at Newport which sat upon the College business, and was elected one of the Fellows of the College.<cite><a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a></cite>
The latter committee, composed of Stephen Hopkins, Joseph Brown, and John Davis, in a report on September 8, 1769, recommended that "the building do not exceed sixty-six feet long, and thirty-six feet wide, and three stories high; – that it be a plain building, the walls of best bricks and lime, the door and window frames of red cedar; – that there be a cupola for a bell; – that the first building be so situated as to be one wing of the whole College edifice, when completed."<cite><a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a></cite>
Lawrence C. Wroth, in his unpublished manuscript, "The Construction of the College Edifice, 1770-1772, described the ensuing plans: In 1883 the interior of the building was renovated with the help of the funds left over from the building of <a href="Slater Hall.html">Slater Hall</a>.<cite><a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a></cite>
The "<a href="Brunonian.html">Brunonian</a> of February 10, 1883 came out against the expenditure of $45,000 for this purpose when "it would be far better to expend this sum in the erection of a new hall than in repairing the present dilapidated structure.<cite><a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a></cite>
The funds for the project came from $8399.37 left over from the building of <a href="Slater Hall.html">Slater Hall</a> and subscriptions sufficient to bring the total to over $47,000.<cite><a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a></cite>
In 1884 the Advisory and Executive Committee of the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> decreed "that tickets be sold to students wishing to use the bathing tubs in the basement of University Hall at the rate of 50 cents for five tickets."<cite><a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a></cite>
The administrative offices of the University were removed to the newly constructed <a href="Van Wickle Hall.html">Van Wickle Hall</a> in 1902.<cite><a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a></cite>
The United States Weather Bureau installed its Providence station on the fourth floor in October 1904, and remained for several years before moving to the Bannigan Building.<cite><a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a></cite>
In 1905 the exterior of the building was renovated through the generosity of Marsden J. Perry.<cite><a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a></cite>
When office space was badly needed in 1925, the dormitory rooms on the second floor were taken over, and offices of the Departments of <a href="English.html">English</a> and <a href="History.html">History</a> moved in.<cite><a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a></cite>
On May 11, 1927, a tablet placed on University Hall was dedicated to the memory of General Nathanael Greene, who had received an honorary degree in 1776, by the First Light Infantry Regiment of Rhode Island.<cite><a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a></cite>
In 1938 an anonymous donor, not a Brown graduate, gave $100,000 toward the fifth major reconstruction of University Hall and a year later added a similar amount.<cite><a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a></cite>
Architects Perry, Shaw and Hepburn were in charge of the work, which was begun in July 1939.<cite><a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a></cite>
The exterior walls had been restored in 1905, but now the crumbling foundation was replaced by a new foundation of steel and concrete hidden by materials suitable to the age of the building.<cite><a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a></cite>
New windows with small panes were installed, as were new chimneys, exact copies made of hand-moulded brick to simulate the chimneys shown in the print of the College Edifice which was produced in the 1790s from a drawing by David Leonard 1792.<cite><a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a></cite>
The design of the original cupola was a matter of discussion, some being of the opinion that it was hexagonal and Norman Isham 1886, architectural consultant, sure that it was octagonal.<cite><a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a></cite>
When the modern cupola was removed, remnants of the eight-sided original cupola were revealed, with the names of two former students and their classes, "Amos Hopkins 1792" and "Henry D’Wolfe 1803," carved on one of its uprights.<cite><a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a></cite>
At the rededication of University Hall on May 4, 1940, French ambassador Comte Rene Doynel de Saint-Quentin and Princeton president Harold W. Dodds took part in the ceremonies recalling the University’s early associations with France and Princeton.<cite><a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a></cite>
University Hall was designated a National Historic Landmark at ceremonies held on May 5, 1963, as part of Rhode Island Heritage Week.<cite><a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a></cite>
Winslow Upton (1853-1914), professor of astronomy, was born in Salem, Massachusetts, on October 12, 1853.<cite><a href="Upton, Winslow.html">Upton, Winslow</a></cite>
After his graduation from the Phillips School in 1869 at an age his father considered too young for college, Winslow Upton continued his study of music and other academic subjects in Boston for two years before entering Brown in 1871.<cite><a href="Upton, Winslow.html">Upton, Winslow</a></cite>
