At Commencement in 1875 Winslow Upton delivered the valedictory address, "Sympathy Essential to True Criticism."<cite><a href="Upton, Winslow.html">Upton, Winslow</a></cite>
Winslow Upton was employed for a short time at the Harvard College Observatory, going from there to the observatory of the University of Cincinnati, and earning a master’s degree in 1877.<cite><a href="Upton, Winslow.html">Upton, Winslow</a></cite>
From May 1878 to September 1879 Winslow Upton was a member of the staff of the Harvard Observatory, which experience was the inspiration for a skit, "The Observatory Pinafore, (obviously a parody on a Gilbert and Sullivan operetta), which included such lines as:Fifty years later this work came to light and was performed on December 31, 1929 at a meeting of the American Astronomical Association, to the delight of its audience."<cite><a href="Upton, Winslow.html">Upton, Winslow</a></cite>
After a short stint in Detroit with the Army Engineer Corps’ Lake Survey, Upton became a computer at the Naval Observatory in Washington in 1880.<cite><a href="Upton, Winslow.html">Upton, Winslow</a></cite>
Winslow Upton worked with the United States Signal Office from 1881 to 1883.<cite><a href="Upton, Winslow.html">Upton, Winslow</a></cite>
In May of 1883 Winslow Upton accompanied a group of scientists to Carolina Island in the Pacific to view a solar eclipse, an event which resulted in his writing "The Carolina Island Opera.<cite><a href="Upton, Winslow.html">Upton, Winslow</a></cite>
A few years later he was inclined to leave when the promised observatory had not materialized, but the welcome gift of Governor Herbert Ladd made it possible for Ladd Observatory to be built under Upton’s supervision in 1891.<cite><a href="Upton, Winslow.html">Upton, Winslow</a></cite>
Upton took a leave of absence in the academic year 1886-87, during which he spent six months in Germany, two months in England, and visited leading European observatories.<cite><a href="Upton, Winslow.html">Upton, Winslow</a></cite>
Winslow Upton observed the total solar eclipse of August 19, 1887 from the interior of Russia.<cite><a href="Upton, Winslow.html">Upton, Winslow</a></cite>
Winslow Upton was away again in 1896-97 at the southern station of the Harvard College Observatory in Arequipa, Peru.<cite><a href="Upton, Winslow.html">Upton, Winslow</a></cite>
Winslow Upton was appointed the first dean of the University in 1900, but resigned that position a year later.<cite><a href="Upton, Winslow.html">Upton, Winslow</a></cite>
In December 1913, after directing the Christmas music performed by his church choir, Winslow Upton became ill with pneumonia and died on January 8, 1914.<cite><a href="Upton, Winslow.html">Upton, Winslow</a></cite>
Urban Studies became recognized when <a href="President.html">President</a> Hornig established a Committee on Urban Studies with Professor Benjamin Chinitz as chairman in July 1971.<cite><a href="Urban Studies.html">Urban Studies</a></cite>
In the spring of 1972 the committee sponsored a lecture series, "Campaign ’72: The Urban <a href="Issues.html">Issues</a>."<cite><a href="Urban Studies.html">Urban Studies</a></cite>
Ten students graduated with an independent concentration in urban studies in 1972, and twenty in 1973.<cite><a href="Urban Studies.html">Urban Studies</a></cite>
A standard concentration in urban studies was approved in 1973, and a revised concentration program in 1975.<cite><a href="Urban Studies.html">Urban Studies</a></cite>
Professor Basil Zimmer of <a href="Sociology.html">Sociology</a> reorganized the Urban Studies Program in 1974 and was chairman until 1986.<cite><a href="Urban Studies.html">Urban Studies</a></cite>
J. Vernon Henderson, professor of economics, became Director of Urban Studies in 1986.<cite><a href="Urban Studies.html">Urban Studies</a></cite>
Otto Van Koppenhagen (1895-1978), professor of music, was born in Arnheim, The Netherlands, on January 19, 1895.<cite><a href="Van Koppenhagen, Otto.html">Van Koppenhagen, Otto</a></cite>
Otto Van Koppenhagen came to the United States in 1921 and spent his first summer on the island of Martha’s Vineyard, which reminded him of his home.<cite><a href="Van Koppenhagen, Otto.html">Van Koppenhagen, Otto</a></cite>
In 1930 Otto Van Koppenhagen bought a summer home in Edgartown, and in 1934 began a series of concerts held in his living room, which held an audience of 150, in which he was joined by his wife, a soprano, who was also a native of Arnheim.<cite><a href="Van Koppenhagen, Otto.html">Van Koppenhagen, Otto</a></cite>
Otto Van Koppenhagen spent 21 years as a cellist with the New York Philharmonic Orchestra, after which he came to Brown in 1949 as a visiting assistant professor of music.<cite><a href="Van Koppenhagen, Otto.html">Van Koppenhagen, Otto</a></cite>
The next year Otto Van Koppenhagen was appointed to the regular staff of the Department of Music, and in 1957 he was named associate professor of music (artist), a title used for the first time at Brown to distinguish a professor who is a performing musician from one involved in teaching and research.<cite><a href="Van Koppenhagen, Otto.html">Van Koppenhagen, Otto</a></cite>
Meanwhile Otto Van Koppenhagen's summer concert series in Edgartown continued, moving to St. Elizabeth’s Hall in 1939 and to the auditorium of the Methodist Church in 1950.<cite><a href="Van Koppenhagen, Otto.html">Van Koppenhagen, Otto</a></cite>
After retirement from Brown in 1961, Otto Van Koppenhagen continued to teach privately.<cite><a href="Van Koppenhagen, Otto.html">Van Koppenhagen, Otto</a></cite>
Otto Van Koppenhagen died in Providence on his eighty-third birthday, January 19, 1978.<cite><a href="Van Koppenhagen, Otto.html">Van Koppenhagen, Otto</a></cite>
The Van Wickle Gates were dedicated on June 18, 1901.<cite><a href="Van Wickle Gates.html">Van Wickle Gates</a></cite>
In 1905 it was decided to inscribe the stone tablet at the right entrance, which had been left blank for a bulletin board, with an inscription from Cicero selected by Professor Albert Granger Harkness, "Haec studia adolescentium alunt, senectutem oblectant, secundas res ornant, adversis perfugium ac solacium praebent," translated, "These studies fortify one’s youth, delight one’s old age; amid success they are an ornament, in failure they are a refuge and a comfort."<cite><a href="Van Wickle Gates.html">Van Wickle Gates</a></cite>
The gates were built with the bequest of Augustus Stout Van Wickle 1876, president of a bank and several coal corporations, who was killed in a skeet shooting accident in 1898.<cite><a href="Van Wickle Gates.html">Van Wickle Gates</a></cite>
Van Wickle Hall was built in 1902 and was originally called the Administration Building.<cite><a href="Van Wickle Hall.html">Van Wickle Hall</a></cite>
Its cornerstone was laid on June 18, 1901, the same day that the <a href="Van Wickle Gates.html">Van Wickle Gates</a> were dedicated, by Marjorie Van Wickle, daughter of Augustus Stout Van Wickle 1876, donor of the building.<cite><a href="Van Wickle Hall.html">Van Wickle Hall</a></cite>
When <a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a> became the administration building in 1940, the building was turned over to the Department of <a href="English.html">English</a> and renamed Van Wickle Hall.<cite><a href="Van Wickle Hall.html">Van Wickle Hall</a></cite>
Verney and Woolley Dining Halls were built in 1966 in the space between <a href="Champlin and Morriss Halls.html">Champlin and Morriss Halls</a> and <a href="Emery and Woolley Halls.html">Emery and Woolley Halls</a>, and named for Virginia Piggott Verney ’28, who was in 1951 the second woman elected to the Brown Board of Trustees, and Mary Emma Woolley 1894.<cite><a href="Verney and Woolley Dining Halls.html">Verney and Woolley Dining Halls</a></cite>
Officially in use in September 1966, the dining halls had previously been opened for four weeks during the previous May so that the four Pembroke classes might have the opportunity to dine in the new facility on successive weeks.<cite><a href="Verney and Woolley Dining Halls.html">Verney and Woolley Dining Halls</a></cite>
The Veterans College began as the Veterans Extension Division in the fall of 1947, when the G.I.<cite><a href="Veterans College.html">Veterans College</a></cite>
Brown selected 486 of the 1400 applicants for places in the Veterans Extension Division.<cite><a href="Veterans College.html">Veterans College</a></cite>
Vice Presidents have been part of the administration since 1925 when that title was given to Albert Davis Mead after several months during which he assumed some of the duties of <a href="President.html">President</a> Faunce, whose illness prevented his full attention to presidential responsibilities.<cite><a href="Vice Presidents.html">Vice Presidents</a></cite>
The only "vice president" recorded before that time was Perez Fobes, who actually served in the capacity of acting president while James Manning was in Congress in 1786.<cite><a href="Vice Presidents.html">Vice Presidents</a></cite>
Roland G. D. Richardson, who was dean of the <a href="Graduate School.html">Graduate School</a> served as acting vice-president in 1928-1929.<cite><a href="Vice Presidents.html">Vice Presidents</a></cite>
The <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> created a second post of vice president in 1932 and named James P. Adams, who had been acting vice president while Mead was acting president during <a href="President.html">President</a> Barbour’s absence in 1931-32.<cite><a href="Vice Presidents.html">Vice Presidents</a></cite>
Mead was vice president until 1936, Adams until 1945.<cite><a href="Vice Presidents.html">Vice Presidents</a></cite>
In 1945 F. Morris Cochran was appointed to the newly created post of business manager responsible for administration of the budget, also accounting, buildings and grounds, purchasing, dining rooms, and all business operations of the University.<cite><a href="Vice Presidents.html">Vice Presidents</a></cite>
In 1946 he was promoted to vice president with these same duties.<cite><a href="Vice Presidents.html">Vice Presidents</a></cite>
Bruce Bigelow, named vice president in 1945, acted as immediate deputy to the <a href="President.html">President</a> in the conduct of University affairs.<cite><a href="Vice Presidents.html">Vice Presidents</a></cite>
Thomas B. Appleget was appointed vice president in charge of public relations in 1949, his duties to include liaison work with the News Bureau and with fund-raising activities.<cite><a href="Vice Presidents.html">Vice Presidents</a></cite>
Appleget retired in June 1959 and his position was vacant until John Van Gassbeek Elmendorf arrived in May 1961 from Mexico, where he had been Executive Director of the Mexican-American Cultural Institute and for eight years a member of the faculty and an administrative officer at Mexico City College.<cite><a href="Vice Presidents.html">Vice Presidents</a></cite>
Malcolm S. Stevens was Vice <a href="President.html">President</a> for Administration from 1966 to 1975.<cite><a href="Vice Presidents.html">Vice Presidents</a></cite>
Paul F. Maeder was Vice <a href="President.html">President</a> (Finance and Operations) from 1972 to 1977.<cite><a href="Vice Presidents.html">Vice Presidents</a></cite>
Richard J. Ramsden was Vice <a href="President.html">President</a> (Administration and Finance) from 1977 to 1980, then Senior Vice-<a href="President.html">President</a> until 1982.<cite><a href="Vice Presidents.html">Vice Presidents</a></cite>
Frederick M. Bohen followed in that post from 1983 to 1990.<cite><a href="Vice Presidents.html">Vice Presidents</a></cite>
In 1991 Thomas P. Glynn became Senior Vice <a href="President.html">President</a> for Finance and Administration, Donald J. Reaves became Vice <a href="President.html">President</a> for Finance and Walter E. Holmes, Jr. became Vice <a href="President.html">President</a> for Administration.<cite><a href="Vice Presidents.html">Vice Presidents</a></cite>
Robert A. Reichley was named Vice <a href="President.html">President</a> (University Relations) in 1977, and retitled in 1991 Executive Vice <a href="President.html">President</a> (Alumni Relations, Public Affairs, and External Relations).<cite><a href="Vice Presidents.html">Vice Presidents</a></cite>
The title of Ronald A. Wolk was Vice <a href="President.html">President</a> for (University Relations and Development) until 1977, when he was named Vice <a href="President.html">President</a> and Director of the Capital Campaign.<cite><a href="Vice Presidents.html">Vice Presidents</a></cite>
Robert A. Seiple was Vice <a href="President.html">President</a> for Development from 1979 to 1983, when he was succeeded by Samuel F. Babbitt.<cite><a href="Vice Presidents.html">Vice Presidents</a></cite>
Ann W. Caldwell was appointed to the position in 1991 when Babbitt was named Senior Vice <a href="President.html">President</a> in charge of the new major capital campaign.<cite><a href="Vice Presidents.html">Vice Presidents</a></cite>
Pierre M. Galletti was Vice <a href="President.html">President</a> (<a href="Biology.html">Biology</a> and Medicine) from 1972 to 1991.<cite><a href="Vice Presidents.html">Vice Presidents</a></cite>
General Counsel Beverly E. Ledbetter was named Vice-<a href="President.html">President</a> and General Counsel in 1985.<cite><a href="Vice Presidents.html">Vice Presidents</a></cite>
Brian L. Hawkins became Vice <a href="President.html">President</a> for Computing and Information Services in 1986.<cite><a href="Vice Presidents.html">Vice Presidents</a></cite>
Don C. Wolfe assumed that position when Hawkins was named Vice <a href="President.html">President</a> for Academic Planning and Administration in 1992.<cite><a href="Vice Presidents.html">Vice Presidents</a></cite>
Levi C. Adams became Vice <a href="President.html">President</a> for Government and Community Affairs in 1992.<cite><a href="Vice Presidents.html">Vice Presidents</a></cite>
Volleyball was played by a coed team in 1971, which won every game in its first varsity season.<cite><a href="Volleyball.html">Volleyball</a></cite>
Under coach Cathy Fulford, who came in 1978, the teams progressed from a 7-17 first year record in 1978 through five 20-win seasons from 1980 to 1984 to the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> championship in 1988, becoming the first team other than Princeton or Penn to win since volleyball became a League sport in 1977.<cite><a href="Volleyball.html">Volleyball</a></cite>
In 1990 the team won the Rutgers Invitational and was second at Brown’s invitational and the Drexel Tournament, but finished fifth in the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> tournament.<cite><a href="Volleyball.html">Volleyball</a></cite>
Funding for women’s volleyball as a varsity sport was withdrawn in 1991 as part of the University’s budget reduction.<cite><a href="Volleyball.html">Volleyball</a></cite>
Joachim Wach (1898-1955), professor of Biblical literature, was born in Chemnitz, Saxony, Germany, on January 25, 1898.<cite><a href="Wach, Joaquim.html">Wach, Joaquim</a></cite>
Joaquim Wach enlisted in the German army in 1916, saw action as a cavalry officer, and became aide-de-camp to a district commissioner in "White Russia."<cite><a href="Wach, Joaquim.html">Wach, Joaquim</a></cite>
After the war, Joaquim Wach pursued his studies between 1919 and 1922 at the Universities of Munich, Berlin, Freiburg, and Leipzig, where he received his Doctor of Philosophy degree in 1922.<cite><a href="Wach, Joaquim.html">Wach, Joaquim</a></cite>
Joaquim Wach was made a Professor Extraordinary in 1929, and was awarded a Doctor of Theology degree at Heidelberg in 1930.<cite><a href="Wach, Joaquim.html">Wach, Joaquim</a></cite>
After leaving Nazi Germany, Joaquim Wach came in the fall of 1935 to Brown, where, as visiting professor of biblical literature, he taught courses in the sociology of religion, religious philosophies of the Orient, and the nature and principles of religious development.<cite><a href="Wach, Joaquim.html">Wach, Joaquim</a></cite>
Joaquim Wach was named associate professor in 1939 and taught until 1946.<cite><a href="Wach, Joaquim.html">Wach, Joaquim</a></cite>
Joaquim Wach's publications include "Das Verstehn," a three-volume work on the theory of general interpretations, published between 1926 and 1932, "An Introduction to the Sociology of Religion in 1932, and" "Sociology of Religion" in 1944.<cite><a href="Wach, Joaquim.html">Wach, Joaquim</a></cite>
Joaquim Wach continued teaching at Brown until 1946.<cite><a href="Wach, Joaquim.html">Wach, Joaquim</a></cite>
When Wach, who had first taken out his citizenship papers in 1938, applied for United States citizenship in 1946, his first petition in February was denied and his second in August granted.<cite><a href="Wach, Joaquim.html">Wach, Joaquim</a></cite>
Joaquim Wach died on August 27, 1955 in Locarno, Switzerland.<cite><a href="Wach, Joaquim.html">Wach, Joaquim</a></cite>
Hyatt Howe Waggoner (1913-1988), professor of English, was born in Pleasant Valley, New York, on November 19, 1913.<cite><a href="Waggoner, Hyatt H..html">Waggoner, Hyatt H.</a></cite>
Hyatt H. Waggoner graduated from Middlebury College in 1935, and received his master’s degree from the University of Chicago in 1936 and his Ph.D. from Ohio State University in 1942.<cite><a href="Waggoner, Hyatt H..html">Waggoner, Hyatt H.</a></cite>
After teaching at the University of Omaha from 1939 to 1942, Hyatt H. Waggoner was professor of English at the University of Kansas City from 1942 to 1956 and head of the English Department from 1952 to 1956.<cite><a href="Waggoner, Hyatt H..html">Waggoner, Hyatt H.</a></cite>
Hyatt H. Waggoner came to Brown as professor of English in 1956.<cite><a href="Waggoner, Hyatt H..html">Waggoner, Hyatt H.</a></cite>
Hyatt H. Waggoner was director of the American Civilization program from 1960 to 1970.<cite><a href="Waggoner, Hyatt H..html">Waggoner, Hyatt H.</a></cite>
Hyatt H. Waggoner was an authority on Nathaniel Hawthorne, well-known for his edition of "Hawthorne’s Selected Tales and Sketches" published in 1950, "Hawthorne: A Critical Study," in 1956, and "The Presence of Hawthorne" in 1979.<cite><a href="Waggoner, Hyatt H..html">Waggoner, Hyatt H.</a></cite>
Hyatt H. Waggoner was instrumental in authenticating Hawthorne’s "lost notebook" in 1978.<cite><a href="Waggoner, Hyatt H..html">Waggoner, Hyatt H.</a></cite>
In 1988 Hyatt H. Waggoner received the House of Seven Gables Hawthorne Award.<cite><a href="Waggoner, Hyatt H..html">Waggoner, Hyatt H.</a></cite>
Hyatt H. Waggoner's first book, in 1950, "The Heel of Elohim," was subtitled "Science and Values in Modern American Poetry."<cite><a href="Waggoner, Hyatt H..html">Waggoner, Hyatt H.</a></cite>
Hyatt H. Waggoner's other books included "William Faulkner: From Jefferson to the World" in 1959, "Emerson as Poet" in 1974, and "American Visionary Poetry" in 1982.<cite><a href="Waggoner, Hyatt H..html">Waggoner, Hyatt H.</a></cite>
Hyatt H. Waggoner's "American Poets: From the Puritans to the Present," published in 1968, was a 740-page volume which grew out of one of his courses.<cite><a href="Waggoner, Hyatt H..html">Waggoner, Hyatt H.</a></cite>
Hyatt H. Waggoner attended a Unitarian Church in the 1940s, was an Episcopalian through the 1950s, until his religious meanderings led him to a small federated church near his farmhouse in Rochester, Vermont.<cite><a href="Waggoner, Hyatt H..html">Waggoner, Hyatt H.</a></cite>
Waggoner retired from teaching in 1979.<cite><a href="Waggoner, Hyatt H..html">Waggoner, Hyatt H.</a></cite>
Hyatt H. Waggoner died on October 13, 1988 in Hanover, New Hampshire.<cite><a href="Waggoner, Hyatt H..html">Waggoner, Hyatt H.</a></cite>
Walter Hall at 80 Waterman Street, formerly the Delta Upsilon house, was in 1959 taken over by the <a href="Biology.html">Biology</a> Department as an annex to <a href="Arnold Laboratory.html">Arnold Laboratory</a>, to be used for graduate research in genetics, radiation biology, and allied fields.<cite><a href="Walter Hall.html">Walter Hall</a></cite>
The house was originally the John F. Chapin house, built in 1857.<cite><a href="Walter Hall.html">Walter Hall</a></cite>
Herbert Eugene Walter (1867-1945), was born in Burke, Vermont, on April 19, 1867.<cite><a href="Walter, Herbert E..html">Walter, Herbert E.</a></cite>
Herbert E. Walter studied at Lyndon Institute and graduated from Bates College in 1892.<cite><a href="Walter, Herbert E..html">Walter, Herbert E.</a></cite>
In the summer of 1892 Herbert E. Walter studied at the Marine Biological Laboratories at Woods Hole, where he came under the influence of <a href="Bumpus, Hermon Carey.html">Hermon Carey Bumpus</a>, who brought him to Brown.<cite><a href="Walter, Herbert E..html">Walter, Herbert E.</a></cite>
After receiving his M. A. degree from Brown in 1893, Herbert E. Walter studied for a year at the University of Freiburg.<cite><a href="Walter, Herbert E..html">Walter, Herbert E.</a></cite>
Herbert E. Walter taught high school biology in Chicago from 1894 to 1904.<cite><a href="Walter, Herbert E..html">Walter, Herbert E.</a></cite>
Herbert E. Walter's first book, "Studies in Animal Life," published in 1901, introduced the study of bird life into the Chicago schools.<cite><a href="Walter, Herbert E..html">Walter, Herbert E.</a></cite>
Herbert E. Walter received his Ph.D. degree from Harvard in 1906 and came to Brown as assistant professor of biology.<cite><a href="Walter, Herbert E..html">Walter, Herbert E.</a></cite>
Herbert E. Walter was promoted to associate professor in 1913 and professor in 1923.<cite><a href="Walter, Herbert E..html">Walter, Herbert E.</a></cite>
Two of Herbert E. Walter's books, "Genetics" and "The Human Skeleton" were published in 1913.<cite><a href="Walter, Herbert E..html">Walter, Herbert E.</a></cite>
In 1923 Herbert E. Walter's "Biology of the Vertebrates," which was used in universities nationwide, was published.<cite><a href="Walter, Herbert E..html">Walter, Herbert E.</a></cite>
Herbert E. Walter was assistant director of the Institute from 1917 to 1926.<cite><a href="Walter, Herbert E..html">Walter, Herbert E.</a></cite>
After retirement in 1937 Herbert E. Walter devoted time to revising his textbooks.<cite><a href="Walter, Herbert E..html">Walter, Herbert E.</a></cite>
Herbert E. Walter died suddenly on October 1, 1945.<cite><a href="Walter, Herbert E..html">Walter, Herbert E.</a></cite>
Lester Frank Ward (1841-1913), called the "father of American sociology," was born in Joliet, Illinois, on June 18, 1841, the youngest of ten children.<cite><a href="Ward, Lester F..html">Ward, Lester F.</a></cite>
Lester F. Ward moved with his parents to Iowa in 1855, but returned to Illinois two years later after the death of his father.<cite><a href="Ward, Lester F..html">Ward, Lester F.</a></cite>
Lester F. Ward's first published story, written at the age of sixteen, was "The Spaniard’s Revenge," which appeared in the St. Charles "Argus" in the spring of 1858.<cite><a href="Ward, Lester F..html">Ward, Lester F.</a></cite>
Lester turned to teaching school and studied at Susquehanna Collegiate Institute at Towanda from January 1861 to June 1862.<cite><a href="Ward, Lester F..html">Ward, Lester F.</a></cite>
Lester F. Ward enlisted in the Union army in August 1862, only a few days after his secret marriage to Elisabeth Vought.<cite><a href="Ward, Lester F..html">Ward, Lester F.</a></cite>
Lester F. Ward was wounded at Chancellorsville and discharged in November 1864.<cite><a href="Ward, Lester F..html">Ward, Lester F.</a></cite>
His situation at that time is summed up in his letter of February 8, 1865, to Abraham Lincoln, seeking support in his application for employment: Ward died on April 18, 1913 in Washington.<cite><a href="Ward, Lester F..html">Ward, Lester F.</a></cite>
George Washington visited the College in August 1790.<cite><a href="Washington, George.html">Washington, George</a></cite>
George Washington arrived in Providence at about 4 p.m. on August 18, after a seven-hour sail from Newport and was accompanied by Governor Clinton of New York, Thomas Jefferson, and several members of Congress, including Senator <a href="Foster, Theodore.html">Theodore Foster</a> 1770.<cite><a href="Washington, George.html">Washington, George</a></cite>
On August 19 Washington and his suite were escorted to the College by the students, and President Manning greeted him with an address in behalf of the Corporation: The references to the delayed exchange of congratulations were occasioned by the fact that Rhode Island was the last of the thirteen colonies to ratify the Constitution, having done so only on May 29, 1790 after several days of debate by the narrow margin of 34 affirmative votes to 32 negative.<cite><a href="Washington, George.html">Washington, George</a></cite>
On October 10, 1932 the University celebrated the bicentennial of the birth of Washington by unveiling a plaque on University Hall commemorating his visit in 1790.<cite><a href="Washington, George.html">Washington, George</a></cite>
The plaque was presented by Chancellor <a href="Sharpe, Henry D. 1894.html">Henry D. Sharpe</a> and an address was delivered by Professor <a href="Hedges, James B..html">James B. Hedges</a>.<cite><a href="Washington, George.html">Washington, George</a></cite>
Benjamin Waterhouse (1754-1846), professor of natural history, was born in Newport in March 4, 1754.<cite><a href="Waterhouse, Benjamin.html">Waterhouse, Benjamin</a></cite>
Although brought up in the Quaker religion by a father who had earlier in life been a Presbyterian, Benjamin Waterhouse never, in the words of <a href="Goddard, William Giles.html">William Goddard</a> 1846 "adopted the peculiarities of that quiet and useful sect, nor was he accustomed to unite with them in their religious worship."<cite><a href="Waterhouse, Benjamin.html">Waterhouse, Benjamin</a></cite>
In 1783 Benjamin Waterhouse was appointed professor of the theory and practice of medicine at Harvard, and the same year was elected a Fellow at Rhode Island College.<cite><a href="Waterhouse, Benjamin.html">Waterhouse, Benjamin</a></cite>
Benjamin Waterhouse continued in this position until 1791, and prior to 1788 delivered the first course of lectures on the subject of natural history in the United States at the State House in Providence.<cite><a href="Waterhouse, Benjamin.html">Waterhouse, Benjamin</a></cite>
In 1814 Benjamin Waterhouse was forced to resign his Harvard professorship, after his opposition to the plan to establish the Medical School in Boston and his attempt to start a rival medical school.<cite><a href="Waterhouse, Benjamin.html">Waterhouse, Benjamin</a></cite>
From 1813 to 1820 Benjamin Waterhouse was medical superintendent of all military posts in New England.<cite><a href="Waterhouse, Benjamin.html">Waterhouse, Benjamin</a></cite>
Benjamin Waterhouse spent his later life in literary pursuits, and died at the age of 92 on October 2, 1846 in Cambridge.<cite><a href="Waterhouse, Benjamin.html">Waterhouse, Benjamin</a></cite>
Arthur Eugene Watson (1866-1956), professor of engineering, was born in Providence on March 4, 1866.<cite><a href="Watson, Arthur E..html">Watson, Arthur E.</a></cite>
Arthur E. Watson graduated from Brown in 1888, and went to work with the Thompson-Houston Electric Company in Lynn, Massachusetts, and moved to Schenectady, New York, after the company became part of General Electric.<cite><a href="Watson, Arthur E..html">Watson, Arthur E.</a></cite>
Arthur E. Watson came back to Brown in 1895 as instructor in physics.<cite><a href="Watson, Arthur E..html">Watson, Arthur E.</a></cite>
Arthur E. Watson was promoted to assistant professor in 1899.<cite><a href="Watson, Arthur E..html">Watson, Arthur E.</a></cite>
Arthur E. Watson's title was changed to assistant professor of electrical engineering in 1914, and associate professor in 1920.<cite><a href="Watson, Arthur E..html">Watson, Arthur E.</a></cite>
In 1924 Arthur E. Watson designed the electrical plant for the airship Shenandoah.<cite><a href="Watson, Arthur E..html">Watson, Arthur E.</a></cite>
After retirement in 1936 Arthur E. Watson continued his research in electrical engineering projects, some of them for military purposes.<cite><a href="Watson, Arthur E..html">Watson, Arthur E.</a></cite>
When Watson died on October 29, 1956, Professor <a href="Tompkins, Frederick N..html">Frederick N. Tompkins</a> 1917, one of his students, wrote in the memorial minute for the faculty:<cite><a href="Watson, Arthur E..html">Watson, Arthur E.</a></cite>
The Watson report, officially the "Report of the Committee on Plans and Resources," was the result of a self-study requested by <a href="President.html">President</a> Hornig in October 1971.<cite><a href="Watson Report.html">Watson Report</a></cite>
The report was accepted by the <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> in February 1974.<cite><a href="Watson Report.html">Watson Report</a></cite>
Observing Brown’s great progress since the self-study, "The Policy in Force" in 1929, the committee recommended for the future:   <ul><li>That Brown concentrate on being a small university with a commitment to scholarship and instruction, with the size of the College limited for the time being to 5,150 full-time students or the equivalent thereof;<br /><br /></li><li>That Brown’s commitment to undergraduate education be strengthened by seeking resources to implement the New <a href="Curriculum.html">Curriculum</a>, impressing the faculty with the importance of undergraduate teaching, and establishing separate budgets for undergraduate instruction, graduate instruction, and research;<br /><br /></li><li>That, in an effort to be adequate in every department and outstanding in a significant number of departments, Brown should maintain towers of excellence representative of the humanities, creative and performing arts, social sciences, and sciences, expanding departments which show increasing student interest and scaling down those which are underutilized and overstaffed;<br /><br /></li><li>That the University study the problem of the large proportion of tenured faculty members, pay more attention to maintenance of the physical plant, and consider changing the academic calendar;<br /><br /></li><li>That tuition charges more nearly approximate the cost of education, with full payment required of those with the means to pay, and that financial aid be increased primarily through loans and work opportunities;<br /><br /></li><li>That Brown strive for a major increase in endowment, refrain from undertaking new projects until financial means are assured, and, in planning new buildings, seek endowment for their maintenance and operation; and<br /><br /></li><li>That planning Brown’s development become an ongoing operation with periodic reconsideration of guidelines.</li></ul><cite><a href="Watson Report.html">Watson Report</a></cite>
The Wayland Collegium for liberal learning was established in 1980 as a support system for inquiries on significant issues of human life.<cite><a href="Wayland Collegium for Liberal Learning.html">Wayland Collegium for Liberal Learning</a></cite>
Named "The Francis Wayland Collegium for Liberal Learning" for the fourth president of Brown, whose 1850 "New System" introduced the concept of electives into the curriculum, the Collegium owes its existence and continuation to the income from a single endowment, a gift of then Chancellor Richard Salomon ’32 and Mrs. Salomon.<cite><a href="Wayland Collegium for Liberal Learning.html">Wayland Collegium for Liberal Learning</a></cite>
The idea for the Collegium grew from the cooperation of <a href="Dean.html">Dean</a> Walter Massey, Professor George Morgan, and others, who throughout the year 1978-79 met to consider the best support for an interdisciplinary and experimental curriculum.<cite><a href="Wayland Collegium for Liberal Learning.html">Wayland Collegium for Liberal Learning</a></cite>
Francis Wayland (1796-1865), fourth president of Brown University, was born in New York City on March 11, 1796.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
Francis Wayland's father became a Baptist minister in 1807.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
Wayland entered Union College in 1811 and graduated in 1813.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
Francis Wayland studied medicine in Troy, and in the winter of 1814-15 attended medical lectures in New York City.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
Abandoning medicine to study for the ministry, Francis Wayland enrolled at Andover Seminary in 1816 and studied for one year under Moses Stuart before lack of funds forced him to withdraw.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
Francis Wayland was a tutor at Union College from 1817 to 1821, coming under the influence of President Eliphalet Nott, and in 1821 was called as minister of the First Baptist Church in Boston.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
Francis Wayland gained recognition for his sermon, "The Moral Dignity of the Missionary Enterprise," preached before the Baptist Missionary Society of Boston in 1823, and his discourses of "The Duties of an American Citizen" in 1825.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
Brown awarded him an honorary D.D. degree in 1822 and elected him a Fellow of the Corporation in 1825.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
Francis Wayland returned to Union College as professor of mathematics and natural philosophy in 1826.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
Wayland’s new fame in the Baptist church brought him the election as Messer’s successor as president of Brown in December 1826.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
Francis Wayland took up his position in February 1827, determined to improve the conduct of the students who had become unruly during the controversy prior to Messer’s resignation.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
"The Elements of Moral Science" was first published in 1835, "The Elements of Political Economy" in 1837, and "The Elements of Intellectual Philosophy" in 1854.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
In 1840 Francis Wayland visited England, Scotland, and France to study education abroad, and in 1842 wrote "Thoughts on the Present Collegiate System in the United States," urging changes in higher education.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
Lack of support for Francis Wayland's views caused the offer of his resignation as president in 1849, which in turn brought about the consideration of the Corporation and the withdrawal of the resignation.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
Francis Wayland's "Report to the Corporation of Brown University on changes in the system of collegiate education," read March 28, 1850, was accepted and laid the foundation for the "new curriculum" with more flexible entrance and degree requirements and the introduction of elective subjects.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
When the Dorr Rebellion broke out in Rhode Island, Wayland supported the extension of suffrage to non-landowners which Thomas W. Dorr represented, but did not support Dorr, who had been elected governor under the Constitution of the People’s Party formed in 1841, contending that the cause, though good, did not justify the overthrow of the legally constituted government and the attempt to impose the will of a doubtful majority.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
When Wayland found his second son, Heman Lincoln Wayland 1849, to be "more than usually self willed" at the age of fifteen months, he set about correcting the child by starving him until he succumbed to his father’s will over a day later.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
The elder Wayland described his success in "A Case of Conviction," signed "A Plain Man," in "The American Baptist Magazine" for October 1831.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
This contribution was duly noticed in the "Literary Subaltern" on December 1, 1831 in an article entitled "Analogy of Brutality," reminiscent of Wayland’s recent address, "A Discourse on the Philosophy of Analogy," before the new Phi Beta Kappa society.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
Edward H. Cutler 1857 recalled, "A mat lay in front of the platform in the chapel on which Francis Wayland regularly spat before going up into the desk at morning prayers," and William H. Pabodie 1855 wrote, "It was too flagrant a failing not to be attacked, so at one of the semi-annual exhibitions there appeared on the ‘mock programme’ prepared for the occasion the announcement that ‘Dr.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
Wayland, with his accustomed accuracy, will now snuff a candle with tobacco juice at a distance of five paces.’" Wayland retired in 1855, and moved to a new home at the corner of Governor and Angell Streets.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
In a letter to his friend, Bishop Alonzo Potter in 1859, Francis Wayland wrote, "you cannot keep a college in a right course any longer than while you hold the helm yourself.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
When Abraham Lincoln was assassinated on April 15, 1865, Wayland declined an invitation to attend and address a public meeting in the evening, whereupon it was decided that the citizens should come to his house.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
This was the last time Francis Wayland addressed his fellow-citizens, as he died on September 30, 1865.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
His eldest son, Francis Wayland, Jr. 1846, became Dean of the Yale Law School, and his second son, Heman Lincoln Wayland 1849 became president of Franklin College in 1870.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
Wayland Academy in Beaver Dam, Wisconsin, founded in 1853, was named for Francis Wayland in recognition of his interest in its establishment and his gift of books which was the beginning and nucleus of its library.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
In 1847 Francis Wayland donated five hundred dollars to the town, which with an equal amount raised by subscription made it possible to open a free library in the town in August of 1850.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
Since 1957, May 15 has been celebrated as Francis Wayland Day at Keio University in Japan.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
The date is the anniversary of May 15, 1868, when the Battle of Ueno raged within sight and earshot of the school, while Fukuzawa Yukichi, founder of the school in 1858, continued to read to his students from Wayland’s "Elements of Political Economy," which Fukuzawa had brought back with him from a visit to the United States the year before.<cite><a href="Wayland, Francis.html">Wayland, Francis</a></cite>
WBRU was the first college radio station in the country when it began in 1936 as the Brown Network, when George Abraham ’40 and David Borst ’40 strung wires for an inter-dormitory connection to relay the messages and recorded music which Abraham had begun broadcasting to his fellow students on November 30.<cite><a href="WBRU.html">WBRU</a></cite>
After the damage caused to the wiring by the 1938 hurricane, the lines were connected to the dormitory radiators, which served as antennae.<cite><a href="WBRU.html">WBRU</a></cite>
Within a few years twelve more colleges started stations, and in 1940 they formed the Intercollegiate Broadcasting System at an organizational meeting held at Brown on February 18, 1940.<cite><a href="WBRU.html">WBRU</a></cite>
The station identification of the Brown Network was B.U.B.C (for Brown University Broadcasting Company) until 1945, when, upon the prompting of Stephen Plimpton ’48, who hung felt banners with "WBRU" on the microphones, the network elected these call letters.<cite><a href="WBRU.html">WBRU</a></cite>
The station celebrated its tenth anniversary on November 30, 1946, with a half-hour program broadcast from <a href="Alumnae Hall.html">Alumnae Hall</a> throughout New England by the Yankee network.<cite><a href="WBRU.html">WBRU</a></cite>
In 1951 WBRU broke the long-distance record for collegiate broadcasting – from the Ice Palace in Colorado Springs, covering Brown’s appearance in the NCAA hockey tournament and sharing its coverage with Providence station WFCI for the benefit of Southern New England fans.<cite><a href="WBRU.html">WBRU</a></cite>
WBRU joined the Ivy Network in 1952, gaining the advantages of shared advertising and exchange of dramatic programs and sporting events.<cite><a href="WBRU.html">WBRU</a></cite>
WBRU continued to broadcast on closed circuit to the campus community until February 21, 1966, when WBRU-FM, with a new FCC license, reached outside with its first broadcast, a panel show on the Peace Corps.<cite><a href="WBRU.html">WBRU</a></cite>
Required as an FCC-licensed station to carry a certain amount of news coverage, WBRU was fortunate in being named an ABC radio news affiliate in 1968, after the other Providence FM stations declined.<cite><a href="WBRU.html">WBRU</a></cite>
In 1971, after WBRU-FM increased its power to 50,000 watts and moved its transmitting equipment to the roof of the Sciences <a href="Library.html">Library</a>, some interference was created with electronic equipment in the Barus-Holley Building and <a href="Prince Engineering Laboratory.html">Prince Engineering Laboratory</a>, but the most unusual development was that monkeys who had electrodes implanted for reading their brain waves were tuned into WBRU.<cite><a href="WBRU.html">WBRU</a></cite>
In 1976 the station gained attention for its documentary, "Brutality at the Children’s Center," which brought about investigations of the state-run O’Rourke Children’s Center in Providence.<cite><a href="WBRU.html">WBRU</a></cite>
In 1980, when WHJY switched from "beautiful music" to rock/heavy metal, WBRU lost its audience, ratings dropped, and the station was saved from backruptcy in 1981 by a $230,000 Brown-backed bank loan.<cite><a href="WBRU.html">WBRU</a></cite>
In 1988 WBRU changed its format from rock ’n’ roll to "cutting edge" rock, "somewhere between the presentable side of punk rock and the dangerous side of more traditional rock radio fare."<cite><a href="WBRU.html">WBRU</a></cite>
In 1990 WBRU placed fourth in the Best Radio Station (medium market) category in the national readers’ poll conducted by "Rolling Stone" magazine.<cite><a href="WBRU.html">WBRU</a></cite>
Clarence Mertou Webster (1892-1959), professor of English, was born in Hampton, Connecticut, on September 16, 1892.<cite><a href="Webster, Clarence M..html">Webster, Clarence M.</a></cite>
Clarence M. Webster graduated from Clark University in 1915 and earned a master’s degree from the University of Michigan in 1916.<cite><a href="Webster, Clarence M..html">Webster, Clarence M.</a></cite>
Clarence M. Webster taught at a number of institutions before earning his Ph.D. at Brown in 1935.<cite><a href="Webster, Clarence M..html">Webster, Clarence M.</a></cite>
A confirmed New Englander himself, Clarence M. Webster produced two books on Yankee life, "Puritans at Home" in 1936, and "Town Meeting Country" in 1945.<cite><a href="Webster, Clarence M..html">Webster, Clarence M.</a></cite>
To help out during the Second World War, Clarence M. Webster returned to teaching as an instructor in English at Brown, and was promoted to assistant professor in 1946 and associate professor in 1949.<cite><a href="Webster, Clarence M..html">Webster, Clarence M.</a></cite>
Clarence M. Webster was to have been appointed full professor in 1959.<cite><a href="Webster, Clarence M..html">Webster, Clarence M.</a></cite>
On January 24, 1959 Clarence M. Webster died after the operation.<cite><a href="Webster, Clarence M..html">Webster, Clarence M.</a></cite>
Karl S. Weimar (1916-1982), professor of German, was born in Philadelphia on December 1, 1916.<cite><a href="Weimar, Karl S..html">Weimar, Karl S.</a></cite>
Karl S. Weimar received his bachelor’s degree in 1937, his master’s in 1938, and his Ph.D. in 1944, all from the University of Pennsylvania.<cite><a href="Weimar, Karl S..html">Weimar, Karl S.</a></cite>
Karl S. Weimar was appointed instructor at the University of Delaware in 1940 and at the University of Illinois in 1943.<cite><a href="Weimar, Karl S..html">Weimar, Karl S.</a></cite>
Karl S. Weimar later taught at the Army training program at the University of Pennsylvania and the veteran’s extension division of Temple University, before coming to Brown in 1946.<cite><a href="Weimar, Karl S..html">Weimar, Karl S.</a></cite>
Karl S. Weimar was promoted to assistant professor in 1948, associate professor in 1954, professor in 1965, and was chairman of the German Department from 1967 to 1973.<cite><a href="Weimar, Karl S..html">Weimar, Karl S.</a></cite>
Karl S. Weimar published "Concept of Love in the Works of Hermann Stehr" in 1945, "German Language and Literature" in 1974, and "Views and Reviews of Modern German Literature" in 1975.<cite><a href="Weimar, Karl S..html">Weimar, Karl S.</a></cite>
Weimar was active in his community, serving on the school committee of his town, North Kingstown, from 1954 to 1960, when he bought a larger house in Warwick.<cite><a href="Weimar, Karl S..html">Weimar, Karl S.</a></cite>
In Warwick Karl S. Weimar was chairman of the school committee from 1962 to 1966.<cite><a href="Weimar, Karl S..html">Weimar, Karl S.</a></cite>
In 1975 Karl S. Weimar directed a production of "The Mikado" by the Academy Players of Kent County.<cite><a href="Weimar, Karl S..html">Weimar, Karl S.</a></cite>
Karl S. Weimar was active in the Boy Scouts from 1950 to 1970, first as assistant scoutmaster and later as a district commissioner.<cite><a href="Weimar, Karl S..html">Weimar, Karl S.</a></cite>
In 1977 Karl S. Weimar became part owner of the Book Gallery on Thayer Street.<cite><a href="Weimar, Karl S..html">Weimar, Karl S.</a></cite>
Karl S. Weimar died suddenly on February 12, 1982, after being stricken by a heart attack at the Brown printing shop.<cite><a href="Weimar, Karl S..html">Weimar, Karl S.</a></cite>
Sanitary conditions were not good, and, although there was never a major epidemic at the College, several students died from typhoid in the 1860s.<cite><a href="Well.html">Well</a></cite>
In 1868, when the registrar, tired of this mischief, refused to provide a new bucket after one of the disappearances, the students staged the long-remembered "water procession," carrying their mugs, tubs, pitchers and other vessels to be filled at the well in the middle of College Street and then marching downtown (accompanied by the American Brass Band) to attract the attention of the townspeople.<cite><a href="Well.html">Well</a></cite>
Plumbing was introduced into the basement of <a href="University Hall.html">University Hall</a> after the renovation of the building in 1883.<cite><a href="Well.html">Well</a></cite>
Benjamin West (1730-1813), professor of mathematics and natural history, was born in Rehoboth, Massachusetts, in March of 1730.<cite><a href="West, Benjamin.html">West, Benjamin</a></cite>
In 1753 Benjamin West moved to Providence and opened a school.<cite><a href="West, Benjamin.html">West, Benjamin</a></cite>
With Joseph Brown Benjamin West observed the transit of Venus on June 3, 1769, from a platform on an East Side street later named Transit Street.<cite><a href="West, Benjamin.html">West, Benjamin</a></cite>
The publication by West of "An Account of the Observation of Venus upon the Sun the Third Day of June 1769" and his observation of a comet in July of 1770 established his reputation, and he received honorary master of arts degrees from both Harvard and Rhode Island College (Brown) in that year.<cite><a href="West, Benjamin.html">West, Benjamin</a></cite>
West was also well known for his almanacs, the first of which, "An Almanack, for the year of our Lord Christ, 1763...," was published by <a href="Goddard, William Giles.html">William Goddard</a> on Providence’s first printing press.<cite><a href="West, Benjamin.html">West, Benjamin</a></cite>
For a Boston edition of the almanac, West took the name Bickerstaff, originated by Jonathan Swift, for his title, "Bickerstaff’s Boston Almanac for the Year of Our Lord 1768."<cite><a href="West, Benjamin.html">West, Benjamin</a></cite>
In 1781 Benjamin West was elected a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.<cite><a href="West, Benjamin.html">West, Benjamin</a></cite>
In 1786 Benjamin West was appointed professor of mathematics and astronomy at Rhode Island College, an appointment which was in fact a lectureship and which he did not take up until 1788, after he returned from a year of teaching mathematics at the Protestant Episcopal Academy in Philadelphia.<cite><a href="West, Benjamin.html">West, Benjamin</a></cite>
In 1798, Benjamin West's last year at the College, his title was changed to Professor of Mathematics and Natural Philosophy.<cite><a href="West, Benjamin.html">West, Benjamin</a></cite>
In 1802 Benjamin West became postmaster of Providence, a post which he held until his death on August 26, 1813.<cite><a href="West, Benjamin.html">West, Benjamin</a></cite>
West Cottage on Cushing Street was opened in 1915, with furnishings provided by the Rhode Island Society for the Collegiate <a href="Education.html">Education</a> of Women, to receive the overflow of women students who could not be accommodated in <a href="Miller Hall.html">Miller Hall</a>.<cite><a href="West Cottage.html">West Cottage</a></cite>
Nathanael West (1902-1940) was born Nathan Weinstein in New York on October 17, 1902.<cite><a href="West, Nathanael.html">West, Nathanael</a></cite>
With such a good start West was accepted at Brown and graduated two years later in 1924.<cite><a href="West, Nathanael.html">West, Nathanael</a></cite>
The "Liber Brunensis" for 1924, in which his name appears as "Nathaniel Von Wallenstein Weinstein," said of him, "Addicted to reading the latest and best, Nathanael West introduced ‘Jurgen’ and ‘DeMaupasant’ to us – for which we are truly thankful.<cite><a href="West, Nathanael.html">West, Nathanael</a></cite>
In 1933 Nathanael West went to Hollywood and wrote motion picture scripts, while he continued writing his novels.<cite><a href="West, Nathanael.html">West, Nathanael</a></cite>
"The Dream Life of Balso Snell" appeared in 1931, "Miss Lonelyhearts" in 1933, "A Cool Million" in 1934, and "The Day of the Locust" in 1939.<cite><a href="West, Nathanael.html">West, Nathanael</a></cite>
On December 22, 1940, West and his wife were killed in an automobile accident near El Centro, California, en route to Los Angeles from Mexico.<cite><a href="West, Nathanael.html">West, Nathanael</a></cite>
"Miss Lonelyhearts" failed as a play on Broadway in 1958, and a movie called simply "Lonelyhearts" about the same time did not meet with much success.<cite><a href="West, Nathanael.html">West, Nathanael</a></cite>
"The Day of the Locust," which has been called "the best novel ever written about Hollywood," was made into a movie in 1975.<cite><a href="West, Nathanael.html">West, Nathanael</a></cite>
Henry Wheaton (1785-1848), diplomat and authority on international law, was born in Providence on November 27, 1785.<cite><a href="Wheaton, Henry.html">Wheaton, Henry</a></cite>
At Commencement in 1802 Henry Wheaton delivered an oration on "Progress of the Mathematical and Physical Sciences during the Eighteenth Century."<cite><a href="Wheaton, Henry.html">Wheaton, Henry</a></cite>
After graduation Henry Wheaton read law in a local law office, and in 1805 went to Europe to study civil law at Poitiers.<cite><a href="Wheaton, Henry.html">Wheaton, Henry</a></cite>
In 1811 he married his cousin Catharine Wheaton, who was the daughter of <a href="Wheaton, Levi.html">Levi Wheaton</a> 1782.<cite><a href="Wheaton, Henry.html">Wheaton, Henry</a></cite>
In 1812 Henry moved to New York and became editor of the "National Advocate," for which he wrote about the War of 1812.<cite><a href="Wheaton, Henry.html">Wheaton, Henry</a></cite>
Henry Wheaton was a justice of the marine court of New York City from 1815 to 1819 and United States Supreme Court reporter from 1816 to 1827.<cite><a href="Wheaton, Henry.html">Wheaton, Henry</a></cite>
Henry Wheaton was a member of the New York State constitutional convention of 1821, served one term in the New York Assembly, and ran unsuccessfully for the United States Senate.<cite><a href="Wheaton, Henry.html">Wheaton, Henry</a></cite>
In 1827 President John Quincy Adams appointed him chargé d’affaires to Denmark, where Henry Wheaton negotiated a treaty recovering payment for the seizure of American ships and became proficient in the Danish language.<cite><a href="Wheaton, Henry.html">Wheaton, Henry</a></cite>
In 1835 Henry Wheaton was appointed chargé d’affaires at Berlin and two years later was promoted to envoy extraordinary and minister plenipotentiary to Prussia.<cite><a href="Wheaton, Henry.html">Wheaton, Henry</a></cite>
On his return to the United States in 1847 Henry Wheaton was offered a lectureship in civil and international law at Harvard, but was prevented by ill health from preparing his lectures.<cite><a href="Wheaton, Henry.html">Wheaton, Henry</a></cite>
Henry Wheaton died on March 11, 1848 in Dorchester, Massachusetts.<cite><a href="Wheaton, Henry.html">Wheaton, Henry</a></cite>
Among the writings which made Wheaton famous were "Elements of International Law," published in 1836, "Enquiry into the Validity of the British Claim to a Right of Visitation and Search of American Vessels Suspected to be Engaged in the African Slave Trade" in 1842, and "History of the Law of Nations in Europe and America, from the Earliest Times to the Treaty of Washington" (a work which was first written in French for a competition of the French Institute, in which it won honorable mention) in 1845.<cite><a href="Wheaton, Henry.html">Wheaton, Henry</a></cite>
The Library’s Wheaton Collection of International Law, founded in 1902, is named for him.<cite><a href="Wheaton, Henry.html">Wheaton, Henry</a></cite>
Levi Wheaton (1761-1851), professor of the theory and practice of medicine, was born in Providence on February 6, 1761.<cite><a href="Wheaton, Levi.html">Wheaton, Levi</a></cite>
During the war Levi Wheaton served as a surgeon on a privateer which was captured in the fall of 1782, after which he was placed on surgical duty on the prison ship Falmouth.<cite><a href="Wheaton, Levi.html">Wheaton, Levi</a></cite>
In 1782 Levi Wheaton wrote to the Brown Corporation, requesting a degree, which was granted.<cite><a href="Wheaton, Levi.html">Wheaton, Levi</a></cite>
In his petition Levi Wheaton mentioned that he had continued his studies alone until 1778 when he began the study of "physick" at the military hospital in Rhode Island, and had later "put himself under the direction of a Gentleman of the faculty."<cite><a href="Wheaton, Levi.html">Wheaton, Levi</a></cite>
Although Levi Wheaton lacked formal education in medicine, in 1812, Brown, having begun medical lectures the year before, awarded him an honorary M.D. degree, and in 1815, appointed him professor of the theory and practice of medicine.<cite><a href="Wheaton, Levi.html">Wheaton, Levi</a></cite>
Levi Wheaton continued to have private medical students in his practice, and he also continued to be a member of the Board of Trustees of Brown until his death on August 29, 1851.<cite><a href="Wheaton, Levi.html">Wheaton, Levi</a></cite>
Benjamin Ide Wheeler (1854-1927), president of the University of California, was born in Randolph, Massachusetts, on July 15, 1854.<cite><a href="Wheeler, Benjamin Ide.html">Wheeler, Benjamin Ide</a></cite>
Benjamin Ide Wheeler studied at New London Academy in New Hampshire and in 1871 entered Brown which he found to be "a cozy college and small, but for us it became great, because in the compactness of its life all its resources were available to use with a minimum of waste."<cite><a href="Wheeler, Benjamin Ide.html">Wheeler, Benjamin Ide</a></cite>
At Commencement in 1875 Benjamin Ide Wheeler delivered the classical oration, "Athens in the Days of Pericles."<cite><a href="Wheeler, Benjamin Ide.html">Wheeler, Benjamin Ide</a></cite>
From 1875 to 1879 Benjamin Ide Wheeler taught in the Providence High School, and from 1879 to 1881 he was instructor in Latin and Greek at Brown.<cite><a href="Wheeler, Benjamin Ide.html">Wheeler, Benjamin Ide</a></cite>
Benjamin Ide Wheeler received his Ph.D. from the University of Heidelberg in 1885.<cite><a href="Wheeler, Benjamin Ide.html">Wheeler, Benjamin Ide</a></cite>
Benjamin Ide Wheeler was instructor in German at Harvard from 1885 to 1886, professor of comparative philology and Greek at Cornell from 1886 to 1899.<cite><a href="Wheeler, Benjamin Ide.html">Wheeler, Benjamin Ide</a></cite>
In 1899 Benjamin Ide Wheeler was chosen to be the president of the University of California.<cite><a href="Wheeler, Benjamin Ide.html">Wheeler, Benjamin Ide</a></cite>
When Benjamin Ide Wheeler left in 1919 there were 6,983.<cite><a href="Wheeler, Benjamin Ide.html">Wheeler, Benjamin Ide</a></cite>
In 1889 all departments of the university were located in Berkeley, except for the professional schools in San Francisco.<cite><a href="Wheeler, Benjamin Ide.html">Wheeler, Benjamin Ide</a></cite>
In 1909-10 Benjamin Ide Wheeler was the Theodore Roosevelt Professor at the University of Berlin.<cite><a href="Wheeler, Benjamin Ide.html">Wheeler, Benjamin Ide</a></cite>
Benjamin Ide Wheeler's fondness for Germany which had begun in his student days continued when the World War began, causing the University of California in 1918 to appoint three members of the faculty as an unofficial advisory board to act as regents.<cite><a href="Wheeler, Benjamin Ide.html">Wheeler, Benjamin Ide</a></cite>
The board continued for six months after Benjamin Ide Wheeler's retirement in 1919, until his successor was installed.<cite><a href="Wheeler, Benjamin Ide.html">Wheeler, Benjamin Ide</a></cite>
In 1920 Benjamin Ide Wheeler went to Japan as a member of an unofficial commission to encourage friendly relations with the Japanese.<cite><a href="Wheeler, Benjamin Ide.html">Wheeler, Benjamin Ide</a></cite>
Benjamin Ide Wheeler went to Europe again in 1926, and died in Vienna on February 8, 1927.<cite><a href="Wheeler, Benjamin Ide.html">Wheeler, Benjamin Ide</a></cite>
Whitehall was built in 1946 behind <a href="Marston Hall.html">Marston Hall</a> on Brook Street to fill as quickly as possible the need for more classroom space required by the postwar increase in enrollment.<cite><a href="Whitehall.html">Whitehall</a></cite>
After use for many classes, Whitehall was closed on June 30, 1975, and was torn down to make way for the <a href="Center for Information Technology.html">Center for Information Technology</a> building.<cite><a href="Whitehall.html">Whitehall</a></cite>
John Greenleaf Whittier, the New England poet, was a Quaker member of the Board of Trustees from 1869 to 1892.<cite><a href="Whittier, John Greenleaf.html">Whittier, John Greenleaf</a></cite>
In the year after his appointment, on June 29, 1870, he favored the guests at the president’s levee with a poem on Roger Williams, which suggested his spiritual presence on the occasion of the day: Whittier was the champion of admission to women to Brown.<cite><a href="Whittier, John Greenleaf.html">Whittier, John Greenleaf</a></cite>
John Greenleaf Whittier wrote to a Providence woman in 1881, "I shall be glad to do all in my power to open the doors of Brown University to women."<cite><a href="Whittier, John Greenleaf.html">Whittier, John Greenleaf</a></cite>
Wilbour Hall on the corner of Prospect and George Streets was formerly the Dorrance mansion, owned and occupied by Delta Phi fraternity and since 1949 the home of the Department of <a href="Egyptology.html">Egyptology</a>.<cite><a href="Wilbour Hall.html">Wilbour Hall</a></cite>
It was named for Charles Edwin Wilbour 1854, in whose memory a chair of <a href="Egyptology.html">Egyptology</a> was established by his daughter.<cite><a href="Wilbour Hall.html">Wilbour Hall</a></cite>
The William Rogers Award, was established by the <a href="Associated Alumni.html">Associated Alumni</a> in 1984 to honor alumni who have used their careers to make significant contributions to humanity.<cite><a href="William Rogers Award.html">William Rogers Award</a></cite>
The second, in 1985, was Byron Lichtenberg ’69, the first civilian scientist to travel in space.<cite><a href="William Rogers Award.html">William Rogers Award</a></cite>
In 1986 the award was presented to Kurt Luedtke ’61, screenplay writer and former editor of the Detroit "Free Press."<cite><a href="William Rogers Award.html">William Rogers Award</a></cite>
Samuel Nabrit, the first African American to receive a doctorate from Brown, was honored in 1987.<cite><a href="William Rogers Award.html">William Rogers Award</a></cite>
The award was presented in 1988 to NBC economics correspondent Irving R. Levine ’44, in 1989 to Aaron T. Beck ’42, the founder of cognitive therapy, in 1990 to Kathryn S. Fuller ’68, president of the World Wildlife Fund, and in 1991 to Linda Mason ’64, executive producer of CBS News.<cite><a href="William Rogers Award.html">William Rogers Award</a></cite>
Alonzo Williams (1842-1901), professor of Germanic languages and literature, was born in Foster, Rhode Island, on September 14, 1842.<cite><a href="Williams, Alonzo.html">Williams, Alonzo</a></cite>
Alonzo Williams took part in the sieges of Fort Pulaski, Savannah, and Charleston, and in General Sherman’s March to the Sea, and was promoted to Second Lieutenant by the time he was mustered out in August of 1865.<cite><a href="Williams, Alonzo.html">Williams, Alonzo</a></cite>
After the war Alonzo Williams attended East Greenwich Academy to prepare for college and was admitted to Brown as a sophomore in 1867.<cite><a href="Williams, Alonzo.html">Williams, Alonzo</a></cite>
Alonzo Williams graduated in 1870 along with another war veteran, future president E. Benjamin Andrews.<cite><a href="Williams, Alonzo.html">Williams, Alonzo</a></cite>
Alonzo Williams then taught Greek, Latin, and German at the Friends’ School in Providence from 1871 to 1876.<cite><a href="Williams, Alonzo.html">Williams, Alonzo</a></cite>
Alonzo Williams was appointed professor of modern languages at Brown in 1876, and began his duties in 1877 after a year of study in Berlin, Leipzig, and Paris.<cite><a href="Williams, Alonzo.html">Williams, Alonzo</a></cite>
Alonzo Williams was named professor of Germanic languages and literature in 1892.<cite><a href="Williams, Alonzo.html">Williams, Alonzo</a></cite>
Upon the death of Professor J. Lewis Diman in 1881, Williams took over Diman’s courses in European and American constitutional history.<cite><a href="Williams, Alonzo.html">Williams, Alonzo</a></cite>
In 1889 Alonzo Williams was made chairman of the committee on graduate students, and he managed graduate affairs for the remainder of his life.<cite><a href="Williams, Alonzo.html">Williams, Alonzo</a></cite>
In 1889 Alonzo Williams was a delegate to the International Congress of Orientalists held in Stockholm.<cite><a href="Williams, Alonzo.html">Williams, Alonzo</a></cite>
During his last European trip in 1899-90 Alonzo Williams went to Leipzig for what he termed "a little private work in Old Norse with Prof. Mogk," and wrote in the January 1901 "Brown Alumni Monthly," "I never put in four months sterner work, and I’ll never do it again, in vacation."<cite><a href="Williams, Alonzo.html">Williams, Alonzo</a></cite>
Alonzo Williams became ill shortly thereafter and died on March 16, 1901 in Providence.<cite><a href="Williams, Alonzo.html">Williams, Alonzo</a></cite>
William Williams (1752-1823), was born in Hilltown, Bucks County, Pennsylvania, in 1752, the son of a prosperous farmer who had emigrated from Wales.<cite><a href="Williams, William.html">Williams, William</a></cite>
William Williams was educated at Hopewell Academy and in 1766 entered Rhode Island College, then in its second year of existence under the care of another Hopewell graduate, <a href="Manning, James.html">James Manning</a>, in the parsonage of the Baptist Church in Warren.<cite><a href="Williams, William.html">Williams, William</a></cite>
William Williams graduated with the first class of seven members in September 1769.<cite><a href="Williams, William.html">Williams, William</a></cite>
William Williams remained in Warren, teaching school, married Patience Miller, daughter of Colonel Nathan Miller, was baptized by his classmate Charles Thompson, pastor of the Warren Baptist Church in September 1771 and licensed to preach by that church in April 1773.<cite><a href="Williams, William.html">Williams, William</a></cite>
William Williams preached in Wrentham, Massachusetts, beginning in 1773, and opened an academy there, from which over the years about eighty of his students came to Rhode Island College.<cite><a href="Williams, William.html">Williams, William</a></cite>
William Williams became pastor of the Wrentham church in 1775 and was ordained the next year.<cite><a href="Williams, William.html">Williams, William</a></cite>
Williams continued as pastor of the church in Wrentham until his death on September 22, 1823.<cite><a href="Williams, William.html">Williams, William</a></cite>
George Grafton Wilson (1863-1951), professor of social and political science, was born in Plainfield, Connecticut, on March 29, 1863.<cite><a href="Wilson, George G..html">Wilson, George G.</a></cite>
George G. Wilson graduated from Brown in 1886.<cite><a href="Wilson, George G..html">Wilson, George G.</a></cite>
In 1887 George G. Wilson was, with Austen K. DeBlois, the first to receive an earned master of arts degree from Brown, and the next year the same two were awarded Brown’s first Ph.D. degrees.<cite><a href="Wilson, George G..html">Wilson, George G.</a></cite>
George G. Wilson was named associate professor of political and social science in 1891, and professor in 1895.<cite><a href="Wilson, George G..html">Wilson, George G.</a></cite>
In 1900 George G. Wilson began to teach at the Naval War College in Newport, where he continued as professor of international law for 37 years.<cite><a href="Wilson, George G..html">Wilson, George G.</a></cite>
George G. Wilson resigned from Brown in 1910 to become professor of international law at Harvard, For several years he had been teaching international law at Harvard, and after his resignation he continued to teach a course in international law at Brown and to be curator of the Wheaton Collection of International Law.<cite><a href="Wilson, George G..html">Wilson, George G.</a></cite>
George G. Wilson was one of the founders of the American Society of International Law in 1907.<cite><a href="Wilson, George G..html">Wilson, George G.</a></cite>
George G. Wilson was a member of the board of editors of the Society’s "Journal" from the beginning, and from 1924 to 1943 was editor-in-chief.<cite><a href="Wilson, George G..html">Wilson, George G.</a></cite>
George G. Wilson was named a director of the "Revue de Droit International" in 1913, and became a member of the Institute de Droit International.<cite><a href="Wilson, George G..html">Wilson, George G.</a></cite>
George G. Wilson retired from Harvard in 1936, but remained on the faculty of the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy, which had been opened in 1933 under the administration of Tufts College with the cooperation of Harvard, until 1941.<cite><a href="Wilson, George G..html">Wilson, George G.</a></cite>
George G. Wilson died in Cambridge on April 30, 1951.<cite><a href="Wilson, George G..html">Wilson, George G.</a></cite>
Born in 1818, he had early in life been apprenticed as a wool sorter and had learned a great deal about machinery.<cite><a href="Wilson Hall.html">Wilson Hall</a></cite>
In 1854 he started a chemical merchandising company in Providence, but did not meet with much success.<cite><a href="Wilson Hall.html">Wilson Hall</a></cite>
Wilson was awarded an honorary Master of Arts degree by Brown in 1872.<cite><a href="Wilson Hall.html">Wilson Hall</a></cite>
Wilson died in 1883 and the bequest was paid in 1887.<cite><a href="Wilson Hall.html">Wilson Hall</a></cite>
Wilson Hall was dedicated on June 15, 1891, a Romanesque style building of random ashlar sandstone with brownstone trim designed by Gould and Angell with a clock in the front side and a sundial on the south side.<cite><a href="Wilson Hall.html">Wilson Hall</a></cite>
The building was first occupied in February 1891 before all the floors were laid or any of the doors hung.<cite><a href="Wilson Hall.html">Wilson Hall</a></cite>
When the <a href="Engineering.html">Engineering</a> Building (<a href="Lincoln Field Building.html">Lincoln Field Building</a>) was built in 1903, the upper part of Wilson Hall was turned over to the Department of <a href="Mathematics.html">Mathematics</a> and its fine library.<cite><a href="Wilson Hall.html">Wilson Hall</a></cite>
The mathematics library moved to <a href="Metcalf Research Laboratory.html">Metcalf Research Laboratory</a> in 1938 and the department later moved to the old Delta Kappa Epsilon house, leaving Wilson Hall exclusively for the use of the <a href="Physics.html">Physics</a> Department.<cite><a href="Wilson Hall.html">Wilson Hall</a></cite>
That too moved in 1965 to the new <a href="Barus and Holley Building.html">Barus and Holley Building</a> and Wilson Hall was reconstructed to provide classrooms and meeting rooms.<cite><a href="Wilson Hall.html">Wilson Hall</a></cite>
J(ames) Walter Wilson (1896-1969), professor of biology, was born in Manchester, New Hampshire, on June 17, 1896.<cite><a href="Wilson, James Walter.html">Wilson, James Walter</a></cite>
This would be laid out as follows: one half of the first floor would be a well lighted, well ventilated, and roomy laboratory, equipped with the most modern biological, chemical, and physical apparatus; the other would contain a large library of all the scientific reference books procurable; the second floor, a museum containing anthropological curios and preserved biological specimens; and on the roof, an observatory containing the most modern astronomical apparatus ..." James Walter Wilson entered Brown in 1914 (he liked to point out that this was the same year that Arnold Laboratory was being built) and studied biology under Professor <a href="Mead, Albert D..html">Albert D. Mead</a>.<cite><a href="Wilson, James Walter.html">Wilson, James Walter</a></cite>
James Walter Wilson graduated in 1918, spent a year in the army, and returned to Brown as a graduate student in biochemistry under Professor <a href="Mitchell, Philip H..html">Philip H. Mitchell</a>.<cite><a href="Wilson, James Walter.html">Wilson, James Walter</a></cite>
James Walter Wilson's dissertation topic for his Ph.D. degree in 1921 was "Contributions to the Biochemistry of Vitamin A."<cite><a href="Wilson, James Walter.html">Wilson, James Walter</a></cite>
By 1936 James Walter Wilson was recognized for developing a technique in kidney research, a perfusion apparatus which circulated synthetic blood through rabbit kidneys.<cite><a href="Wilson, James Walter.html">Wilson, James Walter</a></cite>
In 1945 James Walter Wilson became chairman of the Department of Biology and Frank L. Day Professor of Biology.<cite><a href="Wilson, James Walter.html">Wilson, James Walter</a></cite>
He served as chairman until 1960, at which time President Keeney noted that Wilson "provided a climate which made it possible for members of the Biology Department to flourish intellectually and personally, and they have achieved a national reputation for their research and their teaching."<cite><a href="Wilson, James Walter.html">Wilson, James Walter</a></cite>
On Wilson’s 62nd birthday in 1958 about forty of his former graduate students gathered to honor him with a Seminar on the Biology of the Cell and a Symposium on Training Biologists.<cite><a href="Wilson, James Walter.html">Wilson, James Walter</a></cite>
President John F. Kennedy invited him to speak at the President’s Conference on Heart Disease and Cancer in 1961.<cite><a href="Wilson, James Walter.html">Wilson, James Walter</a></cite>
James Walter Wilson retired in 1966.<cite><a href="Wilson, James Walter.html">Wilson, James Walter</a></cite>
James Walter Wilson died on May 11, 1969 in Providence.<cite><a href="Wilson, James Walter.html">Wilson, James Walter</a></cite>
"Wing Tips" was a newspaper published by the students and staff of the Department of Air Science and Tactics for the Brown Air Force ROTC unit, beginning in March 1952.<cite><a href="Wing Tips.html">Wing Tips</a></cite>
It continued to appear as a monthly periodical in 1953.<cite><a href="Wing Tips.html">Wing Tips</a></cite>
The April Fool’s Day issue of the "Brown Daily Herald" in 1953 appeared with the format of "Wing Tips," and an oversized heading, "New England AFROTC units will be activated on 30th of month."<cite><a href="Wing Tips.html">Wing Tips</a></cite>
George Parker Winship (1871-1952), librarian of the John Carter Brown Library, was born in Bridgewater, Massachusetts, in 1871.<cite><a href="Winship, George Parker.html">Winship, George Parker</a></cite>
George Parker Winship graduated from Somerville Latin School, and in 1893 from Harvard University, where he received his master’s degree the next year.<cite><a href="Winship, George Parker.html">Winship, George Parker</a></cite>
George Parker Winship was employed in 1895 to catalogue and take charge of the private library of John Carter Brown 1816.<cite><a href="Winship, George Parker.html">Winship, George Parker</a></cite>
When the library was given to Brown University in 1904 and the John Carter Brown Library built to house it, Winship came along and remained as librarian until 1915.<cite><a href="Winship, George Parker.html">Winship, George Parker</a></cite>
At that time George Parker Winship became the librarian of the Widener Library, which had been given to Harvard as a memorial by the mother of Harry Elkins Widener, a book collector, who was lost when the Titanic sank in 1912.<cite><a href="Winship, George Parker.html">Winship, George Parker</a></cite>
On his departure from Providence, Winship was honored by his literary colleagues, Herbert O. Brigham 1899, Howard M. Chapin ’08, William Eaton Foster 1873, and <a href="Koopman, Harry Lyman.html">Harry Lyman Koopman</a>, at a dinner at the University Club.<cite><a href="Winship, George Parker.html">Winship, George Parker</a></cite>
After his retirement in 1936 George Parker Winship printed pamphlets on his small press at home.<cite><a href="Winship, George Parker.html">Winship, George Parker</a></cite>
George Parker Winship died on June 22, 1952 in Dover, Massachusetts.<cite><a href="Winship, George Parker.html">Winship, George Parker</a></cite>
Alva Woods (1794-1887), professor of mathematics and natural philosophy, was born in Shoreham, Vermont, on August 13, 1794.<cite><a href="Woods, Alva.html">Woods, Alva</a></cite>
Alva Woods graduated from Harvard in 1817 and entered the Theological Seminary at Andover.<cite><a href="Woods, Alva.html">Woods, Alva</a></cite>
In January 1819 Alva Woods took a year off to teach at the Academy, then returned to finish the three-year course at the Seminary in September 1821.<cite><a href="Woods, Alva.html">Woods, Alva</a></cite>
Alva Woods was ordained in October 1821.<cite><a href="Woods, Alva.html">Woods, Alva</a></cite>
After visiting the cultural institutions of Europe Alva Woods returned to teach at Columbian College, but it was not long before the financial straits of the college caused him to leave and accept the professorship of mathematics and natural philosophy at Brown in 1824.<cite><a href="Woods, Alva.html">Woods, Alva</a></cite>
Alva Woods served as president "ad interim" in 1826-27 after the resignation of <a href="Messer, Asa.html">Asa Messer</a>, and resigned in 1828 to become president of Transylvania University.<cite><a href="Woods, Alva.html">Woods, Alva</a></cite>
J. T. Kirkland of Harvard, writing to Henry Clay on January 5, 1828, recommending Woods for this position, said of him, "He is a ripe scholar, well grounded in the several parts of elementary knowledge.<cite><a href="Woods, Alva.html">Woods, Alva</a></cite>
In 1831 Woods accepted the presidency of the University of Alabama.<cite><a href="Woods, Alva.html">Woods, Alva</a></cite>
The effect of the southern climate on his health and the desire that his son, Marshall Woods, should be educated in the North prompted Woods to resign from the University of Alabama in 1837.<cite><a href="Woods, Alva.html">Woods, Alva</a></cite>
Alva Woods died in Hamilton, New York, on August 11, 1887.<cite><a href="Woods, Alva.html">Woods, Alva</a></cite>
Mary Emma Woolley (1863-1947), one of the first female graduates of Brown University and president of Mount Holyoke College, was born in South Norwalk, Connecticut, on July 13, 1863.<cite><a href="Woolley, Mary Emma.html">Woolley, Mary Emma</a></cite>
Years later Mary Emma Woolley wrote an account of her coming to Brown as one of the first women students: She taught in the Biblical Literature Department at Wellesley College, beginning as instructor in 1895 and advancing to professor in 1899.<cite><a href="Woolley, Mary Emma.html">Woolley, Mary Emma</a></cite>
The next year Mary Emma Woolley spent three months in England studying women’s education before assuming the presidency of Mount Holyoke College in January 1901.<cite><a href="Woolley, Mary Emma.html">Woolley, Mary Emma</a></cite>
Miss Woolley spent six months in China in 1921-22 as a member of the China Educational Commission.<cite><a href="Woolley, Mary Emma.html">Woolley, Mary Emma</a></cite>
Mary Emma Woolley was also a member of the Institute of Pacific Relations which met in Honolulu in 1925 and 1927.<cite><a href="Woolley, Mary Emma.html">Woolley, Mary Emma</a></cite>
As early as 1932 Mary Emma Woolley decided to retire as president at the centennial of Mount Holyoke in 1937 when she would be 74 years old.<cite><a href="Woolley, Mary Emma.html">Woolley, Mary Emma</a></cite>
After the centennial celebration, Mary Emma Woolley left her office in June 1937 and never visited Mount Holyoke again.<cite><a href="Woolley, Mary Emma.html">Woolley, Mary Emma</a></cite>
Mary Emma Woolley moved to the family home, "Fleur de Lys," which Jeanette Marks had inherited in 1914.<cite><a href="Woolley, Mary Emma.html">Woolley, Mary Emma</a></cite>
Over the years Mary Emma Woolley was awarded eighteen honorary doctorates, including one from Brown, and in 1937 received Brown’s highest award, the Susan Colver Rosenberger Medal.<cite><a href="Woolley, Mary Emma.html">Woolley, Mary Emma</a></cite>
Other honors included the Kossovo Medal of the Royal Red Cross of Yugoslavia, in 1931, the Monticello College Centenary Medal in 1938, and the Cristobol Colon Medal in 1940.<cite><a href="Woolley, Mary Emma.html">Woolley, Mary Emma</a></cite>
