In 1931 Mary Emma Woolley was chosen as one of the twelve greatest women in the United States (from a list of 2,786 women nominated by readers of "Good Housekeeping Magazine)" by a jury composed of Henry Van Dyke, Bruce Barton, Newton D. Baker, Booth Tarkington, and Otto H. Kahn.<cite><a href="Woolley, Mary Emma.html">Woolley, Mary Emma</a></cite>
In retirement Mary Emma Woolley began to write her autobiography, but suffered a stroke in 1944 which left her partially paralyzed.<cite><a href="Woolley, Mary Emma.html">Woolley, Mary Emma</a></cite>
Mary Emma Woolley died on September 5, 1947 at Fleur de Lys in Westport, New York.<cite><a href="Woolley, Mary Emma.html">Woolley, Mary Emma</a></cite>
John RoweWorkman (1918-1985), professor of classics, was born in Lancaster, Pennsylvania, on June 3, 1918.<cite><a href="Workman, John Rowe.html">Workman, John Rowe</a></cite>
John Rowe Workman was educated at Princeton, earning his bachelor’s degree in 1940, his master’s in 1942, and his Ph.D. in 1943.<cite><a href="Workman, John Rowe.html">Workman, John Rowe</a></cite>
John Rowe Workman served as part-time instructor at Princeton and taught at St. Mark’s School in Southboro, Massachusetts, before coming to Brown as instructor in 1947.<cite><a href="Workman, John Rowe.html">Workman, John Rowe</a></cite>
John Rowe Workman was promoted to assistant professor in 1949, associate professor in 1953, and full professor in 1966.<cite><a href="Workman, John Rowe.html">Workman, John Rowe</a></cite>
John Rowe Workman became the first W. Duncan MacMillan II Professor of Classics in 1979.<cite><a href="Workman, John Rowe.html">Workman, John Rowe</a></cite>
John Rowe Workman was chairman of the Department of Classics from 1959 to 1966.<cite><a href="Workman, John Rowe.html">Workman, John Rowe</a></cite>
John Rowe Workman was academic advisor and loyal supporter of the hockey team (his portrait hangs in Meehan Auditorium) and was revered by the students, so much so that the editors of "Bear Facts" chose to list him under "Brown Traditions:" He wrote "Arx Antiqua" in 1948, "A Term of College Latin" in 1954, and "New Horizons of Higher Education," describing the Identification and Criticism of Ideas curriculum at Brown, in 1959.<cite><a href="Workman, John Rowe.html">Workman, John Rowe</a></cite>
John Rowe Workman retired in 1985 to Lancaster, Pennsylvania, where he died on September 28, 1985.<cite><a href="Workman, John Rowe.html">Workman, John Rowe</a></cite>
As early as the summer of 1915 a few students went to the Citizens’ Training Center at Plattsburgh.<cite><a href="World War I.html">World War I</a></cite>
In 1916-17 the Brown Christian Association raised $4,300 to send two ambulances to France, and a number of Brown men volunteered to serve at their own expense with the American Ambulance Service.<cite><a href="World War I.html">World War I</a></cite>
In the spring of 1917 the the Reserve Officers Training Corps, which had been informally organized under Colonel Archibald C. Matteson 1893, was recognized by the War Department and placed under Major Charles W. Abbot, USA retired, who was given the title of Professor of Military Science and Tactics.<cite><a href="World War I.html">World War I</a></cite>
In the second semester of 1917-18, he was joined by Captain Alfred Douglas Borden of the Canadian Infantry, who had retired from active service after being wounded at Vimy Ridge.<cite><a href="World War I.html">World War I</a></cite>
In addition to drills on campus, battle manoeuvres were held in Lincoln Woods in May of 1917 and 1918.<cite><a href="World War I.html">World War I</a></cite>
During the summer of 1918 the University remained open to offer courses in chemistry, biology, and engineering and to accommodate 320 mechanics in two groups, who were sent by the government and lived in Lyman Gymnasium while they trained in the machine shops at Brown and the <a href="Rhode Island School of Design.html">Rhode Island School of Design</a>.<cite><a href="World War I.html">World War I</a></cite>
When the Man-Power Law was passed, men eighteen years old and over registered for the draft in September 1918.<cite><a href="World War I.html">World War I</a></cite>
These young men were encouraged to enter or return to college, and as a result, the entire student body at Brown was inducted into military service as members of the Student Army Training Corps or the Naval Unit on October 1, 1918.<cite><a href="World War I.html">World War I</a></cite>
Uniforms for the unit were provided by the Class of 1878.<cite><a href="World War I.html">World War I</a></cite>
After the Armistice on November 11, the government ordered the disbandment of the Student Army Training Corps on December 21, 1918.<cite><a href="World War I.html">World War I</a></cite>
The seniors gave up their <a href="Ivy Day.html">Ivy Day</a> in 1918 to devote their funds to war work, and the women made bandages, studied food conservation, and knit 85 sweaters for the Red Cross.<cite><a href="World War I.html">World War I</a></cite>
The statistics compiled by the War Records Committee and published in May 1919 listed 1,974 alumni, faculty, and students in military service during the war.<cite><a href="World War I.html">World War I</a></cite>
The Soldiers Memorial Arch was dedicated on April 6, 1921 to the memory of the 41 alumni and students and the one faculty member who died in service during the war.<cite><a href="World War I.html">World War I</a></cite>
On November 12, 1921, three years after the Armistice, Marshall Ferdinand Foch visited Brown, where he was greeted by a large crowd and awarded an honorary degree.<cite><a href="World War I.html">World War I</a></cite>
The summer of 1942 ushered in the accelerated program with 700 students enrolled in the added semester.<cite><a href="World War II.html">World War II</a></cite>
As the third semester of academic year 1942-43 began in February, 1943, nearly 300 students who were members of the Army Enlisted Reserve Corps left for active duty.<cite><a href="World War II.html">World War II</a></cite>
From May 1943 to May 1944 pre-meteorologists of the 58th Army Air Force Technical Training Detachment studied at Brown under three successive commanding officers, Major Arthur B. Campbell, Capt.<cite><a href="World War II.html">World War II</a></cite>
The "B" unit graduated 157 men selected for mathematical ability at the end of a six-month course in September 1943.<cite><a href="World War II.html">World War II</a></cite>
The "C" unit began a 48 week training program on May 3, 1943.<cite><a href="World War II.html">World War II</a></cite>
They also published the "Brownian Movement," which first appeared as a single-sheet newsletter on July 9, 1943, for the purpose of "confirming, denying, and preserving rumors and facts."<cite><a href="World War II.html">World War II</a></cite>
July 1, 1943, the first day of the summer semester was also the date on which the Navy V-12 program began on 131 college campuses across the nation.<cite><a href="World War II.html">World War II</a></cite>
2) the former V-1 students who came from junior and senior colleges and had joined the Navy as freshmen or sophomores before March 1943 and had been on inactive duty.<cite><a href="World War II.html">World War II</a></cite>
4) The Naval ROTC students who had been enlisted in the Brown unit which started in 1940.<cite><a href="World War II.html">World War II</a></cite>
The former students of the University who lost their lives in the war numbered 177, ranging from the Class of 1907 to the Class of 1947 and including four graduate students and one woman.<cite><a href="World War II.html">World War II</a></cite>
Shortly after the end of the war, Major General William Curtis Chase ’16 donated to the University a flag which had been captured by the Japanese from the headquarters of General Douglas MacArthur in Manila in 1942 and recaptured in February 1945 by the 12th U. S. Cavalry, a unit in Chase’s division.<cite><a href="World War II.html">World War II</a></cite>
Wrestling was one of the many accomplishments exhibited by the students at the University’s demonstration of its system of physical training held in Infantry Hall on March 3, 1898, although scant attention was received from the "Brown Daily Herald," which conceded, "The wrestling contests were interesting, too," and continued, "A particularly pleasant feature was the music furnished by the Brown Symphony Orchestra."<cite><a href="Wrestling.html">Wrestling</a></cite>
The legendary Frank (G. Franklin) Herrick was engaged by Athletic Director Frederick Marvel on an informal basis in about 1906 to give wrestling lessons to students two days a week, which was extended to three or more days through voluntary contributions by the students.<cite><a href="Wrestling.html">Wrestling</a></cite>
Herrick retired from professional wrestling and remained to coach at Brown until 1932.<cite><a href="Wrestling.html">Wrestling</a></cite>
In 1922-23 Brown won all six dual meets and the New England Intercollegiates.<cite><a href="Wrestling.html">Wrestling</a></cite>
Two more Spellman brothers, John ’24 (who was light heavyweight champion of the 1924 Olympics) and Frank ’28, followed Bob Spellman as captains of the wrestling team.<cite><a href="Wrestling.html">Wrestling</a></cite>
Another brother combination, Albert ’29 and Harry Cornsweet ’29 both had career records of 19 wins and one loss from 1927 to 1929.<cite><a href="Wrestling.html">Wrestling</a></cite>
Brown was second in the New England championships in 1925 and again in 1927, and first in 1929, after an undefeated season.<cite><a href="Wrestling.html">Wrestling</a></cite>
In March 1931 Brown hosted the first National Intercollegiate wrestling meet ever held on the east coast.<cite><a href="Wrestling.html">Wrestling</a></cite>
A new coach, Richard K. Cole, brought a new style of western wrestling to Brown in 1932.<cite><a href="Wrestling.html">Wrestling</a></cite>
Brown won the New Englands again in 1936 and 1937, but wrestling was discontinued after the 1939-40 season.<cite><a href="Wrestling.html">Wrestling</a></cite>
The sport was revived after the second World War with the arrival in 1946 of Ralph Anderton ’30, New England champion in the 135-pound class in his senior year, as coach.<cite><a href="Wrestling.html">Wrestling</a></cite>
The season of 1950-51, the best in 20 years, ended with an 8-1 record, the only loss being to Yale, and Dave Michael ’51 finished his collegiate career without a single defeat in dual competition.<cite><a href="Wrestling.html">Wrestling</a></cite>
Other outstanding seasons were 1954-55 (7-1-1) and 1956-57 (7-2).<cite><a href="Wrestling.html">Wrestling</a></cite>
In the first Ivy season of 1956-57 Brown won five and lost only to Cornell.<cite><a href="Wrestling.html">Wrestling</a></cite>
In 1973 wrestling was in danger of being dropped.<cite><a href="Wrestling.html">Wrestling</a></cite>
The wrestling team rejoined the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a> in 1982-83, and in 1984-85 was able to secure the place vacated by Colgate in the Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association.<cite><a href="Wrestling.html">Wrestling</a></cite>
With a new full-time coach, Dave Amato, by 1985-86 the team had improved enough to finish 16-8 (3-3 in the <a href="Ivy League.html">Ivy League</a>).<cite><a href="Wrestling.html">Wrestling</a></cite>
In 1987 Bob Hill ’88 became Brown’s first Easterns champion as he won the 150 pound class title.<cite><a href="Wrestling.html">Wrestling</a></cite>
The team was sixth in the EIWA in 1988 and fifth in 1989.<cite><a href="Wrestling.html">Wrestling</a></cite>
The wrestling coaches who followed Anderton were John F. Huntsman in 1963-64, Robert M. Litchard from 1964 to 1967, Mike Koval from 1967 to 1971, Jim Brumbaugh from 1971 to 1974; Joe Wirth from 1974 to 1980; Jim Tressler from 1980 to 1983; and Dave Amato since 1983.<cite><a href="Wrestling.html">Wrestling</a></cite>
The Wriston Fellowships were initiated by a gift of Thomas J. Watson, Jr. ’37 in 1972 in honor of former president Henry M. Wriston.<cite><a href="Wriston Fellowships.html">Wriston Fellowships</a></cite>
It had long been one of Wriston’s opinions, best expressed in his "The Nature of a Liberal College" published in 1937, that "Refreshment is a significant word for teaching; everything possible should be done to prevent staleness.<cite><a href="Wriston Fellowships.html">Wriston Fellowships</a></cite>
Henry Merritt Wriston (1889-1978), eleventh president of Brown University, was born in Laramie, Wyoming, on July 4, 1889.<cite><a href="Wriston, Henry M..html">Wriston, Henry M.</a></cite>
While a student there in 1910, Henry M. Wriston made his first visit to Brown to attend a fraternity (Delta Tau Delta) initiation.<cite><a href="Wriston, Henry M..html">Wriston, Henry M.</a></cite>
After graduation in 1911, Henry M. Wriston pursued graduate study at Harvard for three years, but left without completing his dissertation to return to Wesleyan as an instructor in history.<cite><a href="Wriston, Henry M..html">Wriston, Henry M.</a></cite>
By 1919, Henry M. Wriston was a full professor at the age of 30, and still without his Ph.D. During the World War he was an assistant manager of the Connecticut State Council of Defense, and demonstrated administrative talent which led to his appointment in 1919 as executive secretary of the Wesleyan endowment fund campaign.<cite><a href="Wriston, Henry M..html">Wriston, Henry M.</a></cite>
Wriston then took a leave of absence to work for his doctorate, which he received from Harvard in 1922.<cite><a href="Wriston, Henry M..html">Wriston, Henry M.</a></cite>
In 1925 Henry M. Wriston accepted the presidency of Lawrence College in Appleton, Wisconsin.<cite><a href="Wriston, Henry M..html">Wriston, Henry M.</a></cite>
When Henry M. Wriston left to become president of Brown in 1937, "Time" magazine summed up his accomplishments at Lawrence in its inimitable way:<cite><a href="Wriston, Henry M..html">Wriston, Henry M.</a></cite>
The Wriston Quadrangle was built between 1950 and 1952 on a site bordered by George, Thayer, Charles Field, and Brown Streets.<cite><a href="Wriston Quadrangle.html">Wriston Quadrangle</a></cite>
The architects tried, but in vain, to incorporate the Powel House, a Victorian mansion at the corner of George and Brown Streets built in 1865 by Thomas Poynton Ives Goddard 1846 into the plan.<cite><a href="Wriston Quadrangle.html">Wriston Quadrangle</a></cite>
In September 1951 students were living in five of the nine housing units, although some construction-related work still went on around them.<cite><a href="Wriston Quadrangle.html">Wriston Quadrangle</a></cite>
The quadrangle was dedicated on June 1, 1952 on a rainy day when Governor Dennis J. Roberts, architect Thomas Mott Shaw, contractors Thomas F. ’33 and William J. Gilbane ’33, and Arthur B. Homer ’17, chairman of the student housing board and donor of Wayland House, participated in the laying of the cornerstone.<cite><a href="Wriston Quadrangle.html">Wriston Quadrangle</a></cite>
The buildings were named for two Brown presidents and seven alumni, among them two Secretaries of State, three professors, a public health superintendent, and the man who led the Housing and Development campaign to finance the Quadrangle: Marcy House for William Learned Marcy 1808, Governor of New York, Secretary of War, and Secretary of State, Olney House for Richard Olney 1856, Attorney General and Secretary of State, Goddard House for William Giles Goddard 1812, newspaper editor and professor of moral philosophy and belles-lettres, Diman House for Jeremiah Lewis Diman 1851, professor of history and political economy, Sears House for Barnas Sears 1825, president from 1855 to 1867, Wayland House for Francis Wayland, president from 1827 to 1855, Chapin House for Charles V. Chapin 1876, professor of physiology, and superintendent of health in Providence, Harkness House for Albert Harkness 1842, professor of Greek, and Buxton House for G. Edward Buxton ’02, chairman of the Housing and Development Campaign which built the Quadrangle.<cite><a href="Wriston Quadrangle.html">Wriston Quadrangle</a></cite>
<a href="Sharpe Refectory.html">Sharpe Refectory</a> was named for Henry D. Sharpe 1894, Chancellor of the University.<cite><a href="Wriston Quadrangle.html">Wriston Quadrangle</a></cite>
Hughes Court is a memorial to Charles Evans Hughes 1881, former Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court and Charles Evans Hughes, Jr. ’09, former solicitor general of the United States.<cite><a href="Wriston Quadrangle.html">Wriston Quadrangle</a></cite>
Field Terrace honors Harold C. Field 1894, treasurer of the University from 1934 to 1949.<cite><a href="Wriston Quadrangle.html">Wriston Quadrangle</a></cite>
Patriots Court in the quadrangle was dedicated on November 15, 1952 as part of the fall <a href="Homecoming.html">Homecoming</a> activities.<cite><a href="Wriston Quadrangle.html">Wriston Quadrangle</a></cite>
The court was so named in memory of the men of Brown who have died in the service of their country since 1775.<cite><a href="Wriston Quadrangle.html">Wriston Quadrangle</a></cite>
The Morgan Witter Rogers Gate near the Refectory, was named for a member of the Class of 1914 and was a gift of his daughter.<cite><a href="Wriston Quadrangle.html">Wriston Quadrangle</a></cite>
The Edward Leo Barry Gate on Thayer Street honors Brown’s popular swimming coach who died in 1943, and its funding was begun by the Class of 1944 as seniors.<cite><a href="Wriston Quadrangle.html">Wriston Quadrangle</a></cite>
The <a href="Corporation.html">Corporation</a> named the quadrangle for <a href="President.html">President</a> Wriston at its meeting on August 16, 1955, on the occasion of his resignation.<cite><a href="Wriston Quadrangle.html">Wriston Quadrangle</a></cite>
Lawrence Counselman Wroth (1884-1970), librarian of the John Carter Brown Library, was born in Baltimore on January 14, 1884.<cite><a href="Wroth, Lawrence C..html">Wroth, Lawrence C.</a></cite>
Lawrence C. Wroth graduated from Johns Hopkins in 1905.<cite><a href="Wroth, Lawrence C..html">Wroth, Lawrence C.</a></cite>
The son of an Episcopal clergyman, Lawrence C. Wroth served as librarian of the Maryland Diocesan Library from 1905 to 1912.<cite><a href="Wroth, Lawrence C..html">Wroth, Lawrence C.</a></cite>
Lawrence C. Wroth was assistant librarian of the Enoch Pratt Free Library in Baltimore from 1912 to 1923, with a two-year absence with the 110th and 111th Field Artillery in France from 1917 to 1919.<cite><a href="Wroth, Lawrence C..html">Wroth, Lawrence C.</a></cite>
Wroth’s first book, published in 1911, was a biography of Parson Weems, <a href="Washington, George.html">George Washington</a>’s biographer, who gave us the story of the cherry tree.<cite><a href="Wroth, Lawrence C..html">Wroth, Lawrence C.</a></cite>
In 1922 Lawrence C. Wroth's "A History of Printing in Colonial America" brought him recognition by bibliographical scholars, among them the former librarian of the John Carter Brown Library, <a href="Winship, George Parker.html">George Parker Winship</a>, who wrote in his review, "American bibliography has reached a new level."<cite><a href="Wroth, Lawrence C..html">Wroth, Lawrence C.</a></cite>
In the spring of 1923 Lawrence C. Wroth came to Brown as librarian of the John Carter Brown Library.<cite><a href="Wroth, Lawrence C..html">Wroth, Lawrence C.</a></cite>
Lawrence C. Wroth retired from that position in 1957, retaining his 1932 appointment as Research Professor of American History until 1965.<cite><a href="Wroth, Lawrence C..html">Wroth, Lawrence C.</a></cite>
Lawrence C. Wroth published "The Colonial Printer" in 1931, "The Way of a Ship, an Essay on the Literature of Navigation" in 1936, and "The Early Cartography of the Pacific" in 1944.<cite><a href="Wroth, Lawrence C..html">Wroth, Lawrence C.</a></cite>
Lawrence C. Wroth's final book, "The Voyages of Giovanni da Verrazanno 1524-1528," was published only a few months before his death on December 25, 1970.<cite><a href="Wroth, Lawrence C..html">Wroth, Lawrence C.</a></cite>
"Yang Lang," subtitled "an illustrated journal devoted to burlesque and light literature" came out in March 1869 in a four-page newspaper format, announcing that it would be published monthly by the students of Brown University during the academic year.<cite><a href="Yang Lang.html">Yang Lang</a></cite>
The final issue appeared in January 1870.<cite><a href="Yang Lang.html">Yang Lang</a></cite>
Basil George Zimmer (1920-1990), professor of sociology, was born in Smith Creek, Michigan, on June 29, 1920.<cite><a href="Zimmer, Basil G..html">Zimmer, Basil G.</a></cite>
Basil G. Zimmer received his bachelor of arts degree in 1947, his master of arts in 1949, and his Ph.D. degree in 1954, all from the University of Michigan.<cite><a href="Zimmer, Basil G..html">Zimmer, Basil G.</a></cite>
Basil G. Zimmer was an instructor at Eastern Michigan University in 1950-51 and at the University of Michigan in 1951-52, assistant professor at Florida State University in 1952-53, and in 1953 became Resident Director of the University of Michigan Social Science Research Project.<cite><a href="Zimmer, Basil G..html">Zimmer, Basil G.</a></cite>
Basil G. Zimmer came to Brown as associate professor of sociology in 1959, and was promoted to professor in 1962.<cite><a href="Zimmer, Basil G..html">Zimmer, Basil G.</a></cite>
In 1974 Basil G. Zimmer reorganized the Urban Studies Program, of which he was chairman from that time until his retirement in 1986.<cite><a href="Zimmer, Basil G..html">Zimmer, Basil G.</a></cite>
Basil G. Zimmer's book, "Rebuilding Cities: The Effects of Dislocation and Relocation of Small Businesses," was published in 1964.<cite><a href="Zimmer, Basil G..html">Zimmer, Basil G.</a></cite>
Basil G. Zimmer died on June 12, 1990.<cite><a href="Zimmer, Basil G..html">Zimmer, Basil G.</a></cite>
